<abstract abstract-type="blurb">
<p>Now in its sixth edition, <italic>Persuasion: Social Influence and Compliance Gaining</italic> continues to boast an accessible voice and vibrant aesthetic that appeals to undergraduate students of communication, psychology, advertising, and marketing. In addition to presenting established theories and models, this text encourages students to develop and apply general conclusions about persuasion in real-world settings. Along the way, students are introduced to the practice of social influence in an array of contexts (e.g., advertising, marketing, politics, interpersonal relationships, social media, groups) and across a variety of topics (e.g., credibility, personality, deception, motivational appeals, visual persuasion). The new edition features an expanded treatment of digital and social media, up-to-date research on theory and practice, and enhanced discussions of topics such as political campaigning, emotional marketing, olfactory influence, and ethics. Instructors can also use the book&#x2019;s downloadable test bank, instructor&#x2019;s manual, and PowerPoint slides in preparing course material.</p>
</abstract>

<preface id="preface1">
<book-part-meta>
<title-group>
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_xvii">xvii</target>Preface for the Sixth Edition</title>
<alt-title alt-title-type="running-head">Preface</alt-title>
</title-group>
<contrib-group>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Gass</surname>
<given-names>Robert H.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Seiter</surname>
<given-names>John S.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
</contrib-group>
</book-part-meta>
<named-book-part-body>
<p>PERSUASION CONTINUES TO OCCUPY the attention of academics and non-academics alike. Not only scholars, but practitioners such as advertisers, lawyers, lobbyists, marketing firms, motivational speakers, politicians, public relations experts, social activists, syndicated columnists, and others have a vested interest in knowing how persuasion works. Therefore, students who aspire to careers in any of the &#x201C;people professions&#x201D; would be wise to acquire a basic understanding of how persuasion functions.</p>
<p>With each edition of this text, we marvel at how much persuasion changes over time, yet still remains the same. For example, controversies over &#x201C;fake news&#x201D; have altered the way people perceive facts and assess source credibility. Even so, credibility remains as central to the process of persuasion as ever. It is <italic>perceived</italic> credibility that counts. The credibility of news sources is in the eye of the beholder.</p>
<p>The observation that &#x201C;the more persuasion changes, the more it remains the same&#x201D; applies to almost every aspect of persuasion. Compliance-gaining strategies such as the &#x201C;foot in the door&#x201D; now occur in online settings. Audience analysis is key to persuasion, but rather than examining demographic data, persuaders can now use <italic>microtargeting</italic> to tailor their messages to niche groups. For example, in the 2016 presidential election, rumors swirled that Cambridge Analytica, a company that specializes in opinion mining and data analysis, identified low-information voters in key swing states and bombarded them with highly targeted messages (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="refpre_4">Confessore &#x0026; Hakim, 2017</xref>). Product placement, once only found on television and in movies, is now prevalent in novels, pop music, and virtual environments such as computer games. Fear appeals, long a staple of persuaders, have moved online. In addition to being fearful of Ebola, terrorism, and clowns, we can now be worried about cyberstalking, cyberbullying, and whatever diet and nutrition advice Gwyneth Paltrow is about to post.</p>
<p>In this edition, we address the increasing importance of digital and online persuasion, while emphasizing the importance of traditional forms of persuasion as well. Since the last edition, digital persuasion has come into its own. On social media, pop-up ads and banners have given way to more sophisticated forms of marketing, such as <italic>webtracking</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="refpre_1">Avergin, 2016</xref>). Using third-party cookies, <italic>canvas fingerprinting</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="refpre_5">Kirk, 2014</xref>), and other techniques, Web marketers can follow users&#x2019; activities across websites. &#x201C;Like&#x201D; a bluegrass video on YouTube, &#x201C;follow&#x201D; a fiddle player on Facebook, or post some banjo pictures on Instagram, and you&#x2019;ll start getting messages about hoedowns and honky-tonks in your area.</p>
<p>Persuasion on the Web also relies on <italic>sentiment tracking</italic> or <italic>opinion mining</italic>. For example, using natural language processing software, millions of tweets can be analyzed to see what topics, people, or brands are trending and what emotion-laden <target target-type="page" id="page_xviii">xviii</target>words or emojis are being used in connection with those topics or issues. Insights about political preferences, brand images, and economic trends can be gleaned from the results. As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="refpre_3">Bannister (2015)</xref> noted, &#x201C;shifts in sentiment on social media have been shown to correlate with shifts in the stock market&#x201D; (para. 3).</p>
<p>The widespread use of mobile technology has also been accompanied by increasing apps and techniques designed to influence. Texting, tweeting, and other apps disseminate word-of-mouth (WOM) messages. WOM is perceived by many as more genuine, authentic, and trustworthy than commercial advertising or expert opinions. Of course, marketers can sneak into these conversations via sponsored tweets and promoted posts. In many ways, social media has become a form of <italic>mass interpersonal persuasion</italic>. Posting a picture on Instagram may seem interpersonal in nature, but posts can be shared far beyond one&#x2019;s social network. Just ask Anthony Weiner.</p>
<p>Despite the advent of digital and social media, most of us still live in a face-to-face world, too. Traditional forms of influence still matter, and interacting &#x201C;in person&#x201D; is by far the most effective way to persuade other people. A retail salesperson talking to a customer has a much greater chance of success than a pop-up ad reminding you about the last item you viewed on Amazon.com. That said, we often underestimate our effectiveness in one-on-one-settings. For example, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="refpre_6">Roghanizad and Bohns (2017)</xref> found that when people were asked to judge their influence via email versus in person, they overestimated the former and underestimated the latter. Groups, too, exert enormous influence over people. Whether within a family, a classroom, a workplace, at a coffee shop with friends, or some other group setting, the pressure to conform or risk being isolated is potent. Mass persuasion has greater reach, but less effectiveness.</p>
<p>As long as humans occupy planet Earth, they will be engaged in persuading one another. If apes or machines do take over one day, who can say? For now, we believe a solid understanding of persuasion, social influence, and compliance gaining will be an asset in this world. With that in mind, we hope you catch our enthusiasm for this field of study and turn the pages of this book with a better understanding of how persuasion functions, an improved knowledge of ways to maximize your own persuasion efforts, and a greater ability to resist influence attempts, especially unscrupulous influence attempts, by others.</p>
</named-book-part-body>
<back>

</ref-list>
</back>
</preface>
<ack>
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_xix">xix</target>Acknowledgments</title>
<p>We would like to offer our heartfelt thanks to everyone at Routledge/Taylor &#x0026; Francis for their support throughout the process of completing this edition of our text. They are a skilled and talented group. We are especially grateful to Laura Briskman and Nicole Salazar for their relentless graciousness in answering our many questions and guiding us through the requirements for completing this project. Their patience is officially legendary. We also want to thank Josh Curtis and members of his team for painstakingly proofreading and copyediting the drafts of all the chapters.</p>
<p>We are also extremely grateful to the graduate and undergraduate students who offered numerous illustrations of real-life examples of persuasion. In particular, we single out Taylor Halverson for her excellent work. Every time we think we have taught the brightest group of students ever, another sharp group comes along. We also want to thank the many instructors using our book who have sent comments and suggestions for this edition, as well as the many short-course participants who have offered ideas and insights leading up to this edition.</p>
<p>Finally, we are fortunate to be working alongside the best colleagues anyone could ever hope for. Thank you all for making &#x201C;work&#x201D; a fun and rewarding place to be!</p>
</ack>
</front-matter>
<book-body>
<book-part book-part-type="chapter" id="chapter1">
<book-part-meta>
<title-group>
<label>1</label>
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_1">1</target>Why Study Persuasion?</title>
<alt-title alt-title-type="running-head">Why Study Persuasion?</alt-title>
</title-group>
<contrib-group>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Gass</surname>
<given-names>Robert H.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Seiter</surname>
<given-names>John S.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
</contrib-group>
</book-part-meta>
<body>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_2">2</target>ONE OF THE AUTHORS was enjoying a day at the beach with his family. As he sat in a folding chair, lost in a good book, he could hear the cries of seagulls overhead and the pounding of the surf. Nothing was bothering him. He was oblivious to the world around him. Or so he thought. As he reflected more on the situation, however, he became aware that he was being bombarded by persuasive messages on all sides. A boom box was playing a few yards away. During commercial breaks, various ads tried to convince him to choose a new cellphone provider, switch auto insurance companies, and try a hot, spicy cheeseburger. A nearby sign warned that no alcohol, glass objects, or smoking were permitted on the beach. A plastic bag in which a nearby family&#x2019;s children had brought their beach toys advertised Walmart on its side. The family picnic cooler proudly displayed its manufacturer, Igloo, as well.</p>
<p>And that was only the beginning. A plane flew overhead, trailing a banner that advertised a collect calling service. The lifeguard&#x2019;s tower displayed a Hurley logo. Their swimsuits were sponsored by Izod. The lifeguard&#x2019;s truck, a specially equipped Toyota, announced that it was the &#x201C;official emergency vehicle&#x201D; of &#x201C;Surf City USA,&#x201D; a moniker trademarked by the city of Huntington Beach, California. Oh, the indignity of being rescued by an unofficial vehicle.</p>
<p>There were oral influence attempts, too. His son tried to lure him into the water by saying, &#x201C;Come on, it&#x2019;s not that cold.&#x201D; But he knew better. His son <italic>always</italic> said that, no matter how cold the water was. &#x201C;Would you mind keeping an eye on our things?&#x201D; the family next to the author&#x2019;s asked. I guess our family looks trustworthy, he thought. His wife asked him, &#x201C;Do you want to walk down to the pier? They have frozen bananas.&#x201D; She knew he would be unable to resist the temptation.</p>
<p>And those were only the overt persuasive messages. A host of more subtle messages also competed for the author&#x2019;s attention. A few yards away, a woman was applying sun block to her neck and shoulders. The author decided he&#x2019;d better do the same. Had she nonverbally influenced him to do likewise? Nearby, a young couple was soaking up the sun. Both were wearing hats with the Nike &#x201C;swoosh&#x201D; logo. Were they &#x201C;advertising&#x201D; that brand? A young man with a boogie board ran by, headed for the water. His head was shaved and he sported a goodly amount of body art. Did his appearance advocate a particular set of values or tastes? Was he a billboard for an &#x201C;alternative&#x201D; lifestyle? A half dozen male heads turned in unison as a trio of bikini-clad women walked by. Were the males &#x201C;persuaded&#x201D; to turn their heads or was this simply an involuntary reflex? Two tan, muscular dudes were tossing a Frisbee back and forth. Both had six-pack abs. The author made a mental note to do more sit-ups. There seemed to be as many persuasive messages, or potentially persuasive messages, as there were shells on the beach.</p>
<p>The preceding examples raise two important issues. First, persuasion and social influence are pervasive. We are surrounded by influence attempts, both explicit and implicit, no matter where we are. As Cascio, Scholz, and Falk emphasize (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_10">2015</xref>):
<disp-quote>
<p>social influence is omnipresent, occurring through implicit observation of cultural norms, face-to-face and mediated interpersonal communication, as well as mass mediated communication. Even though individuals are often unaware of the power of social influence, research shows its effects on behavior in a wide variety of circumstances.</p>
<attrib>(p. 51)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_3">3</target>Second, it is difficult to say with any certainty what is and is not &#x201C;persuasion.&#x201D; Where should we draw the line between persuasion and other forms of communication? We address the first of these issues in this chapter. Here we examine the pervasive nature of persuasion and offer a rationale for learning more about its workings. In the next chapter, we tackle the issue of what constitutes <italic>persuasion</italic> and related terms such as <italic>social influence</italic> and <italic>compliance gaining.</italic></p>
<sec id="sec1_1">
<title>Aims and Goals</title>
<p>This is a book about persuasion. Its aims are at once academic and practical. On the academic side, we examine how and why persuasion functions the way it does. In so doing, we identify some of the most recent theories and findings by persuasion researchers. On the practical side, we illustrate these theories and findings with a host of real-life examples. We also offer useful advice on how to become a more effective persuader and how to resist influence attempts, especially unethical influence attempts, by others.</p>
<p>If learning how to persuade seems a bit manipulative, remember, we don&#x2019;t live in a society populated with unicorns and rainbows. The real world is brimming with persuaders. You can avoid learning about persuasion, perhaps, but you can&#x2019;t avoid persuasion itself. Besides, we can&#x2019;t tell you everything there is to know about persuasion. Nobody knows all there is to know about this subject. One of the points we stress throughout this book is that people aren&#x2019;t that easy to persuade. Human beings are complex. They can be stubborn, unpredictable, and intractable, despite the best efforts of persuaders.</p>
<p>Persuasion is still as much an &#x201C;art&#x201D; as it is a &#x201C;science.&#x201D; Human nature is too complicated, and our understanding of persuasion too limited, to be certain which influence attempts will succeed and which will fail. Think how often you flip the channel when a commercial costing millions of dollars to produce and air appears on television. As one advertising executive put it, &#x201C;half the money I spend on advertising is wasted &#x2026; but I don&#x2019;t know which half&#x201D; (cited in <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_3">Berger, 2011</xref>, p. 1). Think how many candidates for public office have spent fortunes campaigning, only to lose their elections. Or think how difficult it is for the federal government to convince people to stop smoking, practice safe sex, or avoid texting while driving&#x2014;behaviors that are in their own self-interest.</p>
<p>The science of persuasion is still in its infancy. Despite P. T. Barnum&#x2019;s axiom that &#x201C;there&#x2019;s a sucker born every minute,&#x201D; people are uncannily perceptive at times. It is tempting to believe that if one only knew the right button to push, one could persuade anybody. More often than not, though, there are multiple buttons to push, in the right sequence, and the sequence is constantly changing. Even so, persuasion is not entirely a matter of luck. Much is known about persuasion. Persuasion has been scientifically studied since the 1940s.<xref ref-type="fn" rid="fn1_1"><sup>1</sup></xref> Written texts on persuasion date back to ancient Greece.<xref ref-type="fn" rid="fn1_2"><sup>2</sup></xref> A host of strategies and techniques have been identified and their effectiveness or ineffectiveness documented. Persuaders are a long way from achieving an Orwellian nightmare of thought control, but a good deal is known about how to capture people&#x2019;s hearts and minds. Before proceeding further, we want to address a common negative stereotype about persuasion.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_2">
<title>Persuasion is not a Dirty Word</title>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_4">4</target>The study of persuasion has gotten some bad publicity over the years. Everyone seems to agree that the subject is fascinating, but some are reluctant to embrace a field of study that conjures up images of manipulation, deceit, or brainwashing. There is, after all, a sinister side to persuasion. Adolf Hitler, Charles Manson, Jim Jones, David Koresh, Marshall Applewhite, and Osama bin Laden were all accomplished persuaders&#x2014;much to the detriment of their followers.<xref ref-type="fn" rid="fn1_3"><sup>3</sup></xref> We, however, do not think of persuasion as the ugly stepsister in the family of human communication. Rather, we find the study of persuasion to be enormously intriguing. Persuasion is the backbone of many communicative endeavors. We can&#x2019;t resist the urge to learn more about how and why it works. Part of our fascination stems from the fact that persuasion is, on occasion, used for unsavory ends. It is therefore all the more important that researchers learn as much as they can about the strategies and tactics of unethical persuaders.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_3">
<title>Persuasion is Our Friend</title>
<p>Persuasion isn&#x2019;t merely a tool used by con artists, chiselers, charlatans, cheats, connivers, and cult leaders. Nobel Peace Prize recipients and Pulitzer Prize-winning journalists are also persuaders. In fact, most &#x201C;professional&#x201D; persuaders are engaged in socially acceptable, if not downright respectable, careers. They include advertising executives, bloggers, campaign managers, celebrity endorsers, clergy, congresspersons, diplomats, infomercial spokespersons, lawyers, lobbyists, mediators, media pundits, motivational speakers, political cartoonists, press secretaries, public relations experts, radio talk-show hosts, recruiters, salespersons, senators, social activists, syndicated columnists, and whistleblowers, to name just a few.</p>
<p>Let&#x2019;s focus on the positive side of persuasion for a moment. Persuasion helps forge peace agreements between nations. Persuasion helps expose corruption and open up closed societies. Persuasion is crucial to the fundraising efforts of charities and philanthropic organizations. Persuasion convinces motorists to buckle up when driving or refrain from driving when they&#x2019;ve had a few too many. Persuasion is used to convince a substance-abusing family member to seek professional help. Persuasion is how the coach of an underdog team inspires the players to give it their all. Persuasion is a tool used by parents to urge children not to accept rides from strangers or to allow anyone to touch them inappropriately. In short, persuasion is the cornerstone of a number of positive, prosocial endeavors. <italic>Very little of the good that we see in the world could be accomplished without persuasion.</italic></p>
<p>Persuasion, then, is a powerful and often prosocial force. Having highlighted the positive side of persuasion, we address the question of <italic>why</italic> the study of persuasion is so valuable. The next section, therefore, offers a justification for the study of social influence.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_4">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_5">5</target>The Pervasiveness of Persuasion: You Can Run but You Can&#x2019;t Hide</title>
<p>We&#x2019;ve already mentioned one of the primary reasons for learning about this subject: Persuasion is a central feature of every sphere of human communication. The same is true of social influence. We can&#x2019;t avoid it. We can&#x2019;t make it go away. Like Elvis impersonators in Las Vegas, persuasion is here to stay. Various estimates suggest that the average person is exposed to anywhere from 300 to 5,000 messages per day.<xref ref-type="fn" rid="fn1_4"><sup>4</sup></xref> There are more ways to persuade than ever before. Indeed, traditional persuasion in the form of political speeches, television commercials, print ads, billboards, and product placements in movies and television is alive and well. So too are protest marches, demonstrations, sit-ins, and other forms of symbolic action. In the last two decades, social media has been added to the mix. You can submit online reviews of products and services, post a YouTube video advocating your message, engage in <italic>hashtag activism,</italic> advocate a cause via Facebook, Twitter, or Instagram, solicit funding via crowdfunding platforms such as Kickstarter or GoFundMe, or promote change through a website such as <uri>www.change.org</uri> or <uri>www.dosomething.org</uri>. Let&#x2019;s consider one of these pervasive strategies, known as <italic>viral persuasion,</italic> more closely.</p>
<sec id="sec1_4_1">
<title>Tipping Points, Buzz Marketing, and Word of Mouth</title>
<p>Key concepts and principles associated with viral persuasion were laid out by Malcolm Gladwell in his bestseller, <italic>The Tipping Point</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_22">2000</xref>). Gladwell likens word-of-mouth (WOM) to a virus through which a message is spread until the whole society is &#x201C;infected.&#x201D; Based on what he calls <italic>&#x201C;the law of the few,&#x201D;</italic> a small number of influential people can generate a groundswell of support for an idea, brand, or phenomenon. If a message gains sufficient traction, it reaches a tipping point and becomes &#x201C;contagious.&#x201D; In order to reach the tipping point, however, a number of things have to happen.</p>
<sec id="sec1_4_1_1">
<title>&#x00DC;ber Influencers</title>
<p>First, the right kinds of people must be involved. Gladwell identifies three types of people who are essential to the process. <italic>Mavens</italic> possess specialized expertise. They are in the know. They may be celebrity chefs, fashionistas, fitness gurus, tech geeks, or wine snobs. Mavens needn&#x2019;t be rich or famous, but they must be ahead of the curve. They are the early adopters, opinion leaders, or what some call <italic>alpha consumers,</italic> the ones who hear about ideas and try out gadgets first. &#x201C;One American in ten,&#x201D; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_32">Keller and Barry (2003)</xref> maintain, &#x201C;tells the other nine how to vote, where to eat, and what to buy&#x201D; (p. 1).</p>
<p>In addition to mavens, Gladwell states that <italic>connectors</italic> are also essential. Based on the viral metaphor, they are carriers. They have large social networks. When connectors learn from mavens what the &#x201C;next big thing&#x201D; is, they spread the word. Since social circles tend to be overlapping, forwarding messages spreads them increasingly outward from their epicenter.</p>
<p>The last type Gladwell identifies is <italic>salespeople.</italic> They receive the message from a connector and then talk it up within their own circle of friends. Salespeople tell their friends, &#x201C;You must see this movie,&#x201D; &#x201C;You&#x2019;ve got to try this restaurant,&#x201D; or &#x201C;You gotta read this book.&#x201D;</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 1.1</label>
<caption><title>ALS ice-bucket challenge in New York City.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig1_1.jpg"/>
<p>Source: Saklova/Shutterstock.com</p>
</fig>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_4_1_2">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_6">6</target>Orchestrating the Next Big Thing</title>
<p>In addition to having the right kinds of people, some additional conditions must be satisfied for an idea to go viral. <italic>Context</italic> is critical. The idea must come along at the right time and place. Twitter, for example, wouldn&#x2019;t have worked before there was widespread mobile access to the Internet. An idea also must possess <italic>stickiness</italic>, which means that it is inherently attractive. Without some sort of natural appeal, people won&#x2019;t gravitate toward the idea or pass it along (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_24">Heath &#x0026; Heath, 2008</xref>). For example, in 2014, the ALS water bucket challenge, which dared people to dump ice water over their own or other people&#x2019;s heads, went viral, raising over &#x0024;100 million in the USA alone (<uri>www.als.org</uri>). Its stickiness was based, in part, on its eye-catching appeal, its urgency (there was a 24-hour deadline to respond), and the fact that it was for a good cause.</p>
<p><italic>Scalability</italic> is another requirement: It must be easy to ramp up production of the idea, product, or message to meet demand. The ice-bucket challenge met this requirement because almost everyone can find a bucket and some ice. Finally, <italic>effortless transfer</italic> is yet another ingredient in the recipe for an effective viral campaign. A viral campaign has to leverage free media. Ideas that can be spread by forwarding an email, including an attachment, or embedding a link are easy to disseminate. The more time, effort, or money it takes to spread the word, the less likely the idea will go viral. In the ice-bucket campaign, most challenges were issued from one friend to another via video.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_4_1_3">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_7">7</target>Infectious or Inexplicable?</title>
<p>Although viral marketing holds considerable potential, it is often a hit-or-miss strategy, with far more misses than hits. What&#x2019;s more, evidence for the effectiveness of tipping points is largely anecdotal, and there is no guarantee that an idea will gain traction. If one does, its shelf life is often limited. The ice-bucket challenge, for example, came and went in a few months. And flash mobs, another approach to viral marketing, were a flash in the pan.</p>
<p>The Word of Mouth Marketing Association (WOMM) offers advice for conducting viral campaigns. The very concept of viral marketing, however, is something of an oxymoron. A viral campaign is planned to appear unplanned. It is contrived to seem genuine. As consumers grow wise to the strategy, it will become less effective. There are also ethical questions about using friends as shills. The FTC now requires any online endorsement that involves compensation to be disclosed (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_74">Sprague &#x0026; Wells, 2010</xref>).</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_4_2">
<title>Nudges: Sometimes Less Is More</title>
<p>The ubiquitous nature of persuasion is also illustrated by <italic>nudge theory,</italic> developed by Richard <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_77">Thaler and Cass Sunstein (2008)</xref>. They maintain that subtle changes in the way choices are presented to people can influence, or &#x201C;nudge,&#x201D; them to behave in certain ways. For example, when men use a public restroom, they aren&#x2019;t always neat and tidy. They often miss the mark, to put it mildly, which increases janitorial costs significantly. To address this, folks at Amsterdam&#x2019;s Schiphol international airport gave men a target of their own. Specifically, urinals were installed that included a stenciled image of a housefly near the drain. The result? Having a target made all the difference. The men&#x2019;s aim improved considerably (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_77">Thaler &#x0026; Sunstein, 2008</xref>).</p>
<p>As another example, school cafeterias tried offering apples at lunch. Most of them wound up in the trash can. However, when kids were given sliced apples, as opposed to whole apples, they were 73 percent more likely to eat them (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_66">Schwartz, 2016</xref>). Similarly, when vending machines listed the calories in snack foods, people were more likely to make healthier choices.</p>
<p>Although some critics have accused nudge theory of being paternalistic (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_57">Pasquale, 2015</xref>), others (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_76">Sunstein, 2014</xref>) argue that people are free to resist nudges if they wish. Kids can still throw apple slices in the trash. They are simply being provided with options that encourage healthy behaviors (<uri>www.nudges.org</uri>). That said, some nudges may be perceived as more like shoves. To encourage organ donors, for example, some countries have adopted a &#x201C;presumed consent&#x201D; policy, meaning that a person must take the initiative to opt out if she or he does not want to be an organ donor.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_5">
<title>New Persuasion: Digital and Online Influence</title>
<p>Some people seem to spend their every waking moment texting, tweeting, blogging, or posting their views on all matter of subjects large and small. That said, social media isn&#x2019;t just an entertaining diversion, it is an important tool for influence. Whenever someone likes, follows, posts, shares, tweets or retweets, forwards, or comments on a message, online influence is taking place. Let&#x2019;s consider a few forms of digital influence.</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 1.2</label>
<caption><title>Persuasion is everywhere&#x2014;even in the womb.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig1_2.tif"/>
<p>Source: Baby Blues &#x00A9; 2001, Baby Blues Partnership. King Features Syndicate. Reprinted with special permission.</p>
</fig>
<sec id="sec1_5_1">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_8">8</target>eWOM: Digital Buzz</title>
<p>Earlier, we mentioned the importance of viral persuasion and word-of-mouth (WOM). Like WOM, electronic word of mouth (eWOM) is all the rage. People actively comment on brands, companies, political issues, and public figures via all manner of social media. By way of illustration, Twitter alone accounts for 6,000 tweets per second or 500 million tweets per day (<uri>www.internetlivestats.com</uri>). Eighty percent of Twitter users have mentioned brands in their tweets and 54 percent of users report that they have acted based on tweets (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_50">Midha, 2014</xref>).</p>
<p>Like WOM, eWOM is most effective when it is perceived as genuine rather than manufactured and peer driven rather than commercially sponsored. eWOM enjoys several advantages over traditional advertising and marketing techniques (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_18">Erkan &#x0026; Evans, 2016</xref>). It operates largely through interpersonal channels (cellphone, email, texting), lending it an air of authenticity. It is inexpensive compared to traditional media. And it is self-perpetuating. Moreover, eWOM is far more effective than traditional media at reaching younger audiences.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_5_2">
<title>Sponsored Content: The Native Advertisers Are Getting Restless</title>
<p>The rise of social media has spawned a surge in advertising masquerading as genuine peer-to-peer influence. For example, s<italic>ponsored content</italic> includes promoted tweets and Instagram posts, which are essentially paid advertisements. <italic>Native advertising</italic> involves ads posing as news stories. Native ads function as &#x201C;clickbait,&#x201D; luring in readers with snappy headlines or provocative photos. Both approaches are effective because many users have difficulty distinguishing such content from genuine material (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_80">Wojdynski, 2016</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_5_3">
<title>Opinion Mining and Sentiment Tracking: I Feel You</title>
<p>The Web is an opinion-rich environment. People constantly share their attitudes, opinions, and values via social media. And marketers are listening. Many companies, for example, now specialize in <italic>opinion mining</italic> and <italic>sentiment tracking</italic> by monitoring social media to gauge the public&#x2019;s mood in nearly real time (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_60">Ravi &#x0026; Ravi, 2015</xref>). Sophisticated algorithms can track how a person, brand, or issue is trending based, not only on the number of tweets generated, but also on how favorable, neutral, or negative those tweets are (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_33">Kennedy &#x0026; Moss, 2015</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_46">Lee, Yang, Chen, Wang, &#x0026; Sun, 2016</xref>). As an example, after analyzing over 10,000 online mentions from auto-enthusiast <target target-type="page" id="page_9">9</target>websites, the Ford Motor Company adopted a three-blink turn signal on all of its vehicles (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_63">Rosenbush &#x0026; Totty, 2013</xref>).</p>
<p>As sophisticated as such methods seem, a problem with opinion mining is that the data is often &#x201C;squishy&#x201D;&#x2014;that is, the people commenting aren&#x2019;t always articulate or coherent. Furthermore, the tone of a message&#x2014;that is, whether it is ironic, satirical, or hyperbolic&#x2014;can be hard for artificial intelligence to decipher. Nevertheless, programmers are getting better at analyzing and interpreting words related to feelings, emotions, and opinions.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_5_4">
<title>Gamification: You&#x2019;ve Got Game</title>
<p>Parents have known for decades that one way to get infants to eat their vegetables is by turning mealtime into a game. &#x201C;Here comes the airplane,&#x201D; the parent says with each spoonful of strained peas. A modernized version of this approach, known as <italic>gamification</italic>, is being used to stimulate consumer interest and involvement (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_49">McGonigal, 2011</xref>). Gamification applies video-game methods to other contexts to increase consumer engagement. People like to play games. They enjoy the competition. Why else would they spend hours on end playing Angry Birds or Candy Crush? Games are entertaining, challenging, and rewarding. Transforming a mundane task into a game can make it more fun and exciting.</p>
<p>Games also can be used to influence. Take exercise, for example. Thanks to a shoe sensor that allows runners to post information about their running distance, time, and calories burned, Nike+ provides customers with a fun way to socialize, compete, and &#x201C;play&#x201D; with each other using downloadable apps (Are you game? <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_1">2011</xref>). What&#x2019;s more, through points, badges, leaderboards, and other incentives, gamification keeps people coming back for more. This approach has been used to enhance education, improve workplace productivity, increase voter turnout, and promote awareness and participation in social causes.</p>
<p>Gamification is not without its critics, however. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_5">Ian Bogost (2011)</xref>, a professor and expert in video games as cultural artifacts, cautioned that &#x201C;&#x2018;exploitationware&#x2019; is a more accurate name for gamification&#x2019;s true purpose&#x201D; (para. 12). Critics charge that earning badges and points trivializes activities such as learning, working, exercising, or participating in social causes.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_5_5">
<title>Crowdsourcing and Crowdfunding: Lending a Helping Hand</title>
<p>Moving a heavy object, like a piano, isn&#x2019;t easy. To accomplish such a task, you might invite some friends to pitch in. Similarly, <italic>crowdsourcing</italic> puts out an open call for anyone online to participate in completing a task or solving a problem. Wikipedia was one of the earliest crowdsourcing platforms (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_45">Lee &#x0026; Seo, 2016</xref>). The online encyclopedia is collaborative. Content can be contributed and edited by any one. Crowdsourcing is premised on the assumption that wisdom is not the exclusive province of experts, but is distributed throughout the commons (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_36">Kitter, 2010</xref>). As an example, Doritos invited consumers to participate in a &#x201C;Crash the Super Bowl&#x201D; contest by generating their own ideas for a 30-second commercial (for examples, got to <uri>www.youtube.com/watch?v=8vVIUBU1gZs</uri>). As another example, Starbucks&#x2019;s &#x201C;White Cup Contest&#x201D; contest solicited customers&#x2019; suggestions for a graphic design for a limited edition coffee cup. Contestants posted their creations via &#x0023;WhiteCupContest.<target target-type="page" id="page_10">10</target></p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 1.3</label>
<caption><title>Persuasive messages must struggle to cut through the background of media clutter.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig1_3.jpg"/>
<p>Source: Reprinted with permission: <uri>www.andysinger.com</uri></p>
</fig>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_11">11</target>While crowdsourcing has assisted in solving problems in astronomy, legislation, language translation, and urban planning, among many areas, it is not without its critics. Detractors complain that crowdsourcing is exploitative; it relies on the unpaid labor and efforts of others. Another complaint is that the wisdom of the commons isn&#x2019;t always so wise. For example, when NASA asked people to submit names for a new section of the International Space Station, the crowd chose &#x201C;Colbert&#x201D; (after the late-night comedian) over names like &#x201C;Serenity,&#x201D; &#x201C;Earthrise,&#x201D; and &#x201C;Tranquility.&#x201D; NASA went with the name &#x201C;Tranquility&#x201D; anyway.</p>
<p>A related strategy, <italic>crowdfunding,</italic> involves raising money through online donations. Websites such as Kickstarter, GoFundMe, and Indiegogo allow people to ask for donations or start-up funds for a cause or business venture. On the plus side, crowdfunding gives &#x201C;the little guy&#x201D; or a good cause the chance to be noticed. On the downside, some of the requests are scams (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_20">Fredman, 2015</xref>) and most start-ups fail. The SEC recently adopted rules regulating crowdfunding practices online.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_5_6">
<title>Persuasive Technology: My Heart Says Yes, but My Watch Says No</title>
<p>Persuasive technology focuses on devices &#x201C;aimed at changing users&#x2019; attitudes or behaviors through persuasion and social influence, but not through coercion or deception&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_58">Persuasive Technology, 2016</xref>, para. 1). Smart devices and wearable technology &#x201C;are not just persuasive but specifically aimed at forging new habits&#x201D; <italic>(MIT Technology Review,</italic> p. 64). Smartwatches, for example, exhort wearers to take action via taps, vibrations, or other haptic cues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_21">Gilmore, 2016</xref>). Got a big date coming up? An app developed by MIT can tell you if you sound boring, nervous, happy, or sad based on your speech pattern (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_44">Lee, 2017</xref>). As an alternative, you could always check to see if your date is asleep.</p>
<p>Fitness trackers not only track your daily step count, they also encourage you to exercise. For example, Fitbit&#x2019;s display shows a flower that grows or shrinks based on your activity level. Taking that concept one step further, Nissan Leaf owners can view an LCD display of a pine tree that grows as they drive more efficiently.</p>
<p>As part of the Internet of Things, smart pill bottles can remind people when to take their medicine (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_56">Orji &#x0026; Moffat, 2016</xref>). Skip a dose and a light will glow or a chime will sound, followed by a text or phone-call reminder. For some patients, taking their medicine at the right time each day is a matter of life and death. As many as 125,000 deaths per year and &#x0024;105 billion in medical costs are attributable to patients not taking medicine properly (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_65">Ruggerio &#x0026; Wick, 2016</xref>).</p>
<p>Persuasion will continue to play a major role in traditional contexts, such as advertising and marketing. It is worth noting, though, that persuasion also plays a key role in a variety of not-so-obvious contexts. We examine two such contexts next: persuasion in the sciences, and persuasion in the arts.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_6">
<title>Persuasion in the Sciences</title>
<p>You may not think of them this way, but scientists are persuaders (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_23">Glassner, 2011</xref>). The ongoing debate about climate change illustrates the persuasive challenge facing climatologists. Despite widespread agreement among evolutionary biologists that evolution is a fact rather than a theory, there is a continuing social controversy over the teaching of creationism alongside evolution in public school curriculums. Even in <target target-type="page" id="page_12">12</target>fields such as chemistry, mathematics, or physics&#x2014;the so-called hard sciences&#x2014; persuasion plays a major role.<xref ref-type="fn" rid="fn1_5"><sup>5</sup></xref> Scientists often have to convince others that their research possesses scientific merit and social value. They also have to argue for the superiority of their theories over rival theories. In this respect, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_38">Thomas Kuhn (1970)</xref> argues that all scientists employ &#x201C;techniques of persuasion in their efforts to establish the superiority of their own paradigms over those of their rivals&#x201D; (p. 151). Similarly, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_53">Mitroff (1974)</xref> comments that &#x201C;the notion of the purely objective, uncommitted scientist [is] na&#x00EF;ve. &#x2026; The best scientist &#x2026; not only has points of view but also defends them with gusto&#x201D; (p. 120). Scientists must do more than conduct experiments and report their results. They also must persuade other scientists, funding agencies, and the public at large of the merits of their work.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_7">
<title>Persuasion in the Arts</title>
<p>Another not-so-obvious context for persuasion is the arts. Not all art is created &#x201C;for art&#x2019;s sake.&#x201D; Art serves more than an aesthetic or decorative function. Artists have strong opinions and they lend expression to their opinions in and through their work. Consider film as an art form, for example. Movies such as <italic>12 Years a Slave, Life Is Beautiful</italic>, and <italic>Schindler&#x2019;s List</italic> demonstrate the power of the camera to increase awareness, change attitudes, alter beliefs, and shape opinions. Other art forms have the capability to persuade as well. Playwrights, painters, muralists, sculptors, photographers, and dancers give voice to their political and social views through their art.</p>
<p>Think about painting for a moment. Many of the famous works hanging in museums were created out of a sense of social conscience. Using images rather than words, artists comment on social conditions, criticize society, and attempt to transform the social order. We examine this issue in more detail in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter14">Chapter 14</xref>, but for now let&#x2019;s consider one particular work of art, Pablo Picasso&#x2019;s <italic>Guernica</italic>. Through this painting, Picasso offered a moral indictment of war and man&#x2019;s inhumanity to man. The painting features people and animals, the victims of the indiscriminate bombing of a Basque town during the Spanish Civil War, in various states of agony, torment, and grief. As Von Blum (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_79">1976</xref>) notes, &#x201C;the purpose of the painting is frankly propagandistic. The artist&#x2019;s intent was to point out the inhuman character of Franco&#x2019;s fascist rebellion&#x201D; (p. 92). Picasso wasn&#x2019;t trying to paint a &#x201C;pretty&#x201D; picture. He was making a moral statement. The painting has been dubbed by one art historian &#x201C;the highest achievement in modernist political painting&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_13">Clark, 1997</xref>, p. 39). Not only Picasso, but also many other artists express persuasive points of view in and through their art.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_8">
<title>Other Not-So-Obvious Contexts for Persuasion</title>
<p>Persuasion operates in a variety of other contexts, some of which are not so obvious. We highlight a few here as illustrations. Social scientists have studied bumper stickers as a form of political expression and as an unobtrusive means of measuring attitudes (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_17">Endersby &#x0026; Towle, 1996</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_67">Sechrest &#x0026; Belew, 1983</xref>). Scholars have examined the effects of intercessory prayer (offered for the benefit of another person) on recovery from illness (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_19">Frank &#x0026; Frank, 1991</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_25">Hodge, 2007</xref>). Studies have examined the <target target-type="page" id="page_13">13</target>military&#x2019;s use of social influence (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_12">Cialdini, 2011</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_34">King, 2010</xref>). Other researchers have focused on 12-step programs, such as Alcoholics Anonymous, and other support groups as forms of self-help and group influence (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_31">Kassel &#x0026; Wagner, 1993</xref>). Some studies have investigated terrorism as a form of persuasion by examining how jihadists are radicalized and recruited and how effective the use of violence is on the groups who are targeted (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_4">Bhui &#x0026; Ibrahim, 2013</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_26">Iyer, Hornsey, Vanman, Esposo, &#x0026; Ale, 2015</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_39">Kydd &#x0026; Walter, 2006</xref>). As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_78">Tuman (2010)</xref> observed, &#x201C;the real goal of the communicated message in terrorism may be persuasion: to persuade audience members that chaos and fear will be their lot in life, to persuade them to pay attention to an issue they have ignored&#x201D; (p. 37). One scholar has written about compliance-gaining tactics found in dramatic plays, such as Shakespeare&#x2019;s <italic>Hamlet</italic> and Ibsen&#x2019;s <italic>A Doll&#x2019;s House</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_35">Kipnis, 2001</xref>). One of the authors investigated various styles and strategies of panhandling to see which ones proved most effective (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_61">Robinson, Seiter, &#x0026; Acharya, 1992</xref>). Research on the study of robotic persuasion is just beginning to emerge. One study found, for example, that having a robot whisper instructions to people increased their motivation to perform a boring task (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_55">Nakagawa, Shiomi, Shinozawa, Matsumura, Ishiguro, &#x0026; Hagita, 2013</xref>). Another study focused on the effect of robot-to-human touch as a method of compliance gaining (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_69">Shiomi, Nakagawa, Shinozawa, Matsumura, Ishiguro, &#x0026; Hagita, 2017</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_9">
<title>Weird Persuasion</title>
<p>Sometimes persuasion is downright weird. A case in point involved Kensington, Canada, where the police department threatened that any motorist arrested for drunk driving would be subjected to Nickelback music while riding in the police cruiser to the station (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_81">Zenteno, 2016</xref>). When the story went viral, Colin Jost, the news co-host of <italic>Saturday Night Live</italic>, joked, &#x201C;Just make sure the crash kills you.&#x201D; Ultimately, the policy was rescinded because the seriousness of the message was obscured by the frivolousness of the strategy.</p>
<p>Yet another example of weird persuasion occurred in Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, UK. The citizens wanted to stop rowdy teens from loitering at an underpass at night. Their solution was to install street lights with a bright pink hue. Why pink, you ask? Pink light highlights acne. Teens with blemishes didn&#x2019;t want to be seen with bright, glowing acne. The plan worked: The teens moved on (Spotty teens, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_73">2009</xref>).</p>
<p>Scholars sometimes investigate quirky aspects of persuasion, too. Did you know that participants in a study who consumed caffeine were more easily persuaded than participants who had no caffeine (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_48">Martin, Hamilton, McKimmie, Terry, &#x0026; Martin, 2007</xref>)? Now you do. As long as the participants were motivated to pay attention to the message, caffeine consumption increased agreement. Here is another strange finding: Washing one&#x2019;s hands not only produces cleaner hands, it also reduces a person&#x2019;s sense of guilt (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_30">Kaspa, 2013</xref>). The explanation for this is related to a phenomenon called <italic>embodied cognition</italic>, wherein physical behaviors often affect higher mental states.</p>
<p>Other researchers found that mixed-handed people were more persuadable and more gullible than purely left- or right-handed people (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_11">Christman, Henning, Geers, Propper, &#x0026; Niebauer, 2008</xref>). And Bri&#x00F1;ol and Petty (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_8">2003</xref>) discovered that asking people to nod their heads up and down (as if in agreement) made them more <target target-type="page" id="page_14">14</target>agreeable than shaking their heads back and forth (as if in disagreement). What is the point of such research, you ask? Such studies illustrate both the complexities and subtle nuances of persuasion.</p>
<p>Persuasion, then, can be found in obvious and not-so-obvious places. Before concluding this section, we examine one additional context in which persuasion occurs: the interpersonal arena.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_10">
<title>Persuasion in Interpersonal Settings</title>
<p>The extent of influence exerted in the interpersonal arena should not be underestimated. Although we may think of Madison Avenue as all-powerful, face-to-face influence is far more effective. Yet people tend to underestimate the effectiveness of in-person influence compared to other communication contexts. One study, for example, found that people making requests underestimated how successful face-to-face requests would be, compared to email requests (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_62">Roghanizad &#x0026; Bohns, 2017</xref>). Another study found that people tend to underestimate their influence on others when it comes to questionable requests. Participants were asked to estimate how successful they would be at convincing a stranger to commit a minor act of vandalism (writing the word &#x201C;pickle&#x201D; on a page in a library book). Overall, 87 percent of the participants underestimated how persuasive they would be. On average, they were twice as effective as they thought (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_6">Bohns, Roghanizad, &#x0026; Xu, 2014</xref>).</p>
<p>Despite all the money spent on traditional advertising and the increasing amounts being spent on new media, most influence attempts still take place in face-to-face settings. Some 90 percent of word-of-mouth recommendations, for example, take place offline (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_54">Moore, 2011</xref>). On a daily basis we are bombarded with persuasive requests in the interpersonal arena. Your brother wants you to hurry up and get out of the bathroom. A homeless person asks if you can spare some change. Your parents try to talk you out of getting a tongue stud. Or worse yet, your significant other uses the &#x201C;F&#x201D; word to redefine your relationship: That&#x2019;s right; she or he just wants to be &#x201C;friends.&#x201D; Aaahhh! Naturally, we persuade back as well, targeting others with our own entreaties, pleadings, and requests for favors.</p>
<p>Why is interpersonal influence so much more effective? Because it seems more genuine and less conspicuous. Consider the following scenario:
<disp-quote>
<p><italic>The bait:</italic> Your friend calls up and says, &#x201C;Hey, what are you doing Friday night?&#x201D;</p>
<p><italic>The nibble:</italic> Anticipating an invitation to go somewhere, you reply, &#x201C;Nothing much, why?&#x201D;</p>
<p><italic>You&#x2019;re hooked and reeled in:</italic> &#x201C;Well, I wonder if you could help me move into my new apartment then?&#x201D;</p>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>At least when you watch a television commercial you <italic>know</italic> the sponsor is after something from the outset. In interpersonal encounters, others&#x2019; motives may be less transparent. Most communication scholars agree that if you have a choice of mediums for persuasion, you should choose the interpersonal arena. Our advice: Next time you want to turn in a paper late, talk to your professor in person.</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_15">15</target>From our discussion thus far, it should be apparent that persuasion functions as a pervasive force in virtually every facet of human communication. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_9">Kenneth Burke (1966)</xref>, among others, has written that humans are, by their very nature, symbol-using beings. One vital aspect of human symbolicity involves the tendency to persuade others. We are symbol users, and one of the principal functions of symbol usage is persuasion.</p>
<p>The recognition that social influence is an essential, pervasive feature of human symbolic action provides the strongest possible justification for the study of persuasion. Persuasion is one of the major underlying impulses for human communication. By way of analogy, one can&#x2019;t understand how an automobile works without taking a look under the hood. Similarly, one can&#x2019;t understand how human communication functions without examining one of its primary motives&#x2014;persuasion.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_11">
<title>Five Benefits of Studying Persuasion</title>
<p>Given that persuasion is an inevitable fact of life, we offer five primary benefits of learning about persuasion. We refer to these as the instrumental function, the knowledge and awareness function, the defensive function, the debunking function, and the well-being function. We examine each of these in turn.</p>
<sec id="sec1_11_1">
<title>The Instrumental Function: Be All That You Can Be</title>
<p>One good reason for learning about persuasion is so that you can become a more effective persuader yourself. We refer to this as the <italic>instrumental function</italic> of persuasion, because persuasion serves as an instrument, or a means to an end. We view the ability to persuade others as an important aspect of communication competence. <italic>Communication competence</italic> involves acting in ways that are perceived as effective and appropriate (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_72">Spitzberg &#x0026; Cupach, 1984</xref>). Competent communicators possess the skills needed to achieve their objectives in fitting ways for the particular situation.</p>
<p>A competent persuader needs to know how to analyze an audience in order to adapt the message to the audience&#x2019;s frame of reference. She or he needs to be able to identify which strategies are appropriate and which will enjoy the greatest likelihood of success. A competent persuader also must know how to organize and arrange a persuasive message for maximum benefit. These are only some of the abilities required for successful persuasion.</p>
<p>But achieving the desired outcome is only one facet of communication competence. How one goes about persuading also matters. A competent persuader needs to be viewed as persuading in acceptable, appropriate ways. This means a persuader must be aware of social and cultural norms governing the persuasive situation. For example, a parent who publicly berates his or her child during a soccer match may be seen by other parents as engaging in boorish behavior.</p>
<p>We are confident that by learning more about persuasion you will become a more effective and appropriate persuader. Of course, not every influence attempt will succeed. By applying the principles and processes presented in this text, and by adhering to the ethical guidelines we offer, you should be able to improve your competence as a persuader.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_11_2">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_16">16</target>The Knowledge and Awareness Function: Inquiring Minds Want to Know</title>
<p>Another good reason for learning about persuasion is because it will enhance your knowledge and awareness of a variety of persuasive processes. Knowledge is power, as the saying goes. There is value in learning more about how persuasion operates. You may not plan on going into advertising for a living, but simply knowing how branding operates is worthwhile in and of itself. You may not plan on joining a cult (who does?), but learning more about what makes persons susceptible to cult conversion is worthwhile nonetheless. Simply from the standpoint of an observer, learning about these topics can be fascinating.</p>
<p>An additional benefit of learning about how persuasion functions concerns overcoming <italic>habitual persuasion</italic>. Many people rely on habitual forms of persuasion, regardless of whether they are effective. They get comfortable with a few strategies and tactics that they use over and over again. A good deal of our communication behavior is &#x201C;mindless,&#x201D; as opposed to mindful, meaning we don&#x2019;t pay much attention to how we communicate (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_40">Langer, 1978</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_41">1989a</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_42">1989b</xref>). Sometimes persuasion operates this way. Just as runners, swimmers, and other athletes need to learn to adjust their breathing in response to different situations, persuaders&#x2014;to maximize their effectiveness&#x2014;need to learn to adapt their methods to different audiences and situations. Persuasion isn&#x2019;t a &#x201C;one-size-fits-all&#x201D; form of communication.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_11_3">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_17">17</target>The Defensive Function: Duck and Cover</title>
<p>A third reason for learning about how persuasion operates is vital in our view: The study of persuasion serves a <italic>defensive function</italic>. By studying how and why influence attempts succeed or fail, you can become a more discerning consumer of persuasive messages, unlike the hapless fellow depicted in <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig1_4">Figure 1.4</xref>. If you know how persuasion works, you are less likely to be taken in. It is worth noting that people tend to <italic>underestimate</italic> the influence of advertising on themselves and <italic>overestimate</italic> its effects on others, a phenomenon known as the <italic>third-person effect</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_14">Davidson, 1983</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_27">Jensen &#x0026; Collins, 2008</xref>). Thus, you may be more defenseless than you realize.</p>
<fig id="fig1_4" position="float">
<label>Figure 1.4</label>
<caption><title>A little persuasive acumen just might save you from yourself.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig1_4.jpg"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; Lee Lorenz/The New Yorker Collection/<uri>www.cartoonbank.com</uri></p>
</fig>
<p>Throughout this text, we expose a number of persuasive tactics used in retail sales, advertising, and marketing campaigns. For example, we have found in our classes that after students are given a behind-the-scenes look at how car salespeople are taught to sell, several students usually acknowledge, &#x201C;Oh yeah, they did that to me.&#x201D; Admittedly, a huckster could also take advantage of the advice we offer in this book. We think it is far more likely, however, that the typical student reader will use our advice and suggestions as weapons <italic>against</italic> unethical influence attempts. <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box1_1">Box 1.1</xref>, for example, offers advice on how to recognize various propaganda ploys. In later chapters of this book, we warn you about common ploys used by all manner of persuaders, from cult leaders to panhandlers to funeral home directors.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_11_4">
<title>The Debunking Function: Puh-Shaw</title>
<p>A fourth reason for studying persuasion is that it serves a <italic>debunking function</italic>. The study of human influence can aid in dispelling various &#x201C;common-sense&#x201D; assumptions and &#x201C;homespun&#x201D; notions about persuasion. Traditional wisdom isn&#x2019;t always right, and it&#x2019;s worth knowing when it&#x2019;s wrong. Some individuals cling tenaciously to folk wisdom about persuasive practices that are known by researchers to be patently false. For example, many people believe that subliminal messages are highly effective and operate in a manner similar to that of post-hypnotic suggestion. This belief is pure poppycock, as we point out in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter15">Chapter 15</xref>.</p>
<p>Of considerable importance, then, are empirical findings that are <italic>counterintuitive</italic> in nature&#x2014;that is, they go against the grain of common sense. By learning about research findings on persuasion, the reader can learn to ferret out the true from the false, the fact from the fiction.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_11_5">
<title>Well-Being and Self-Worth: I Feel Good</title>
<p>A fifth benefit of learning about persuasion is that the ability to persuade others improves one&#x2019;s subjective sense of well-being. There is a sense of satisfaction that comes from persuading others. Researchers have found that influencing others satisfies five basic needs, which are accuracy, belonging, self-worth, control, and meaning (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_7">Bourgeois, Sommer, &#x0026; Bruno, 2009</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_71">Sommer &#x0026; Bourgeois, 2010</xref>). The first need, accuracy, refers to the desire to be right about one&#x2019;s beliefs and attitudes. One of the author&#x2019;s spouses likes to joke, &#x201C;I married Mr. Right. Mr. <italic>always</italic> Right.&#x201D; Winning someone over is one way of validating one&#x2019;s own views.</p>
<boxed-text id="box1_1">
<label><target target-type="page" id="page_18">18</target>Box 1.1</label>
<caption><title>Persuasion Versus Propaganda and Indoctrination</title></caption>
<p>What are propaganda and indoctrination and how do they differ from persuasion? To a large extent, it is a matter of perspective. People tend to label their own messages as persuasion and the other guy&#x2019;s as propaganda. The same applies to indoctrination: We tend to think that our government educates its citizens, but foreign governments, especially those we dislike, indoctrinate their citizens. Understood in this way, propaganda and indoctrination are largely pejorative terms used to describe persuasive messages or positions with which people disagree. Gun control advocates claim the NRA uses propaganda to thwart legislation that would place restrictions on gun sales. Opponents of school prayer think that requiring students to recite a prayer in class constitutes a form of religious indoctrination. When accused of propagandizing, the common defense is to state that one was only engaged in an education or information campaign. Thus, whether a given attempt at influence, such as the D.A.R.E. campaign, is persuasion, propaganda, or indoctrination is largely in the eye of the beholder.</p>
<p>Definitions of propaganda are many and varied, but we happen to think Pratkanis and Aronson&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_59">1991</xref>) definition does a good job of capturing the essence of the term:
<disp-quote>
<p>Propaganda was originally defined as the dissemination of biased ideas and opinions, often through the use of lies and deception. &#x2026; The word propaganda has since evolved to mean mass &#x201C;suggestion&#x201D; or influence through the manipulation of symbols and the psychology of the individual. Propaganda is the communication of a point of view with the ultimate goal of having the recipient come to &#x201C;voluntarily&#x201D; accept the position as if it were his or her own.</p>
<attrib>(p. 9)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>Different scholars have offered different views on the nature and characteristics of propaganda (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_16">Ellul, 1973</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_29">Jowett &#x0026; O&#x2019;Donnell, 1986</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_70">Smith, 1989</xref>). However, there are some essential characteristics on which most scholars agree. These are as follows:
<list list-type="simple">
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Propaganda has a strong ideological bent. Most scholars agree that propaganda does not serve a purely informational function. Propaganda typically embodies a strong bias, such as that of a &#x201C;left-wing&#x201D; or &#x201C;right-wing&#x201D; agenda. The campaign of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) to promote animal rights would fall into this category. Propagandists aren&#x2019;t trying to be neutral or objective. They are working a specific agenda.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Propaganda is institutional in nature. Most scholars agree that propaganda is practiced by organized groups, whether they happen to be government agencies, political lobbies, private corporations, religious groups, or social movements. For instance, the Anti-Defamation League is an organization founded to prevent libeling and slandering of Jewish people. Although individuals might use propaganda too (a parent might tell a child, &#x201C;Santa only brings presents for good girls and boys&#x201D;), the term usually is associated with institutional efforts to persuade.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Propaganda involves mass persuasion. Most scholars agree that propaganda targets a mass audience and relies on mass media to persuade. Propaganda is aimed at large numbers of people and, as such, relies on mass communication (TV, radio, posters, billboards, email, mass mailings, etc.) to reach its audience. Thus, gossip that was shared by one office worker with another at the water cooler wouldn&#x2019;t constitute propaganda, but a corporate rumor that was circulated via email would.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Propaganda tends to rely on ethically suspect methods of influence. Propagandists tend to put results first and ethics second. This characteristic is probably the one that laypersons most closely associate with propaganda and the one that gives it its negative connotation.</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_19">19</target>What are some of the questionable tactics used by propagandists? The Institute for Propaganda Analysis, which was founded in 1937, identified seven basic propaganda techniques, which still exist today (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_51">Miller, 1937</xref>). These include the plain folks appeal (&#x201C;I&#x2019;m one of you&#x201D;), testimonials (&#x201C;I saw the aliens, sure as I&#x2019;m standing here&#x201D;), the bandwagon effect (everybody&#x2019;s doing it), card-stacking (presenting only one side of the story), transfer (positive or negative associations, such as guilt by association), glittering generalities (idealistic or loaded language, such as &#x201C;freedom,&#x201D; &#x201C;empowering,&#x201D; &#x201C;family values&#x201D;), and name calling (&#x201C;racist,&#x201D; &#x201C;tree hugger,&#x201D; &#x201C;femi-Nazi&#x201D;).</p>
</boxed-text>
<p>The need for belonging reflects the desire for social inclusion. People value social connections. Persuading others is one means of establishing and maintaining relationships. People also strive to maintain a positive self-concept or sense of self-worth. The ability to persuade others enhances a person&#x2019;s self-esteem. The need for control, or perceived control, stems from a desire to shape our environment and exert influence over those with whom we interact. Some people like to be in charge, take over, and have things their way. Others are content to let someone else take the helm. Yet everyone seeks some degree of self-efficacy or a sense that she or he is in control of their life. Lastly, people want to believe there is meaning and purpose in their lives. One way of demonstrating one&#x2019;s value or importance is by influencing others.</p>
<p>We hope you&#x2019;ll agree, based on the foregoing discussion, that there are quite a few good reasons for studying persuasion. We hope we&#x2019;ve persuaded you that the study of persuasion can be a prosocial endeavor. That brings us back to an earlier point, however: Not all persuaders are scrupulous. At this juncture, then, it seems appropriate that we address two common criticisms related to the study of persuasion.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_12">
<title>Two Criticisms of Persuasion</title>
<sec id="sec1_12_1">
<title>Does Learning About Persuasion Foster Manipulation?</title>
<p>We&#x2019;ve already touched on one of the common criticisms of studying persuasion: the notion that it fosters a manipulative approach to communication. We address ethical concerns surrounding the study and practice of persuasion more specifically in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter16">Chapter 16</xref>. For the time being, however, a few general arguments can be offered in response to this concern. First, our principal focus in this text is on the <italic>means</italic> of persuasion (e.g., how persuasion functions). We view the means of persuasion not so much as moral or immoral, but rather as amoral, or ethically neutral. In this respect, persuasion can be likened to a tool, such as a hammer. Like any other tool, persuasion can be put to good or bad use. If this sounds like a cop-out, read what Aristotle had to say on this same point in his <italic>Rhetoric</italic>:
<disp-quote>
<p>If it is urged that an abuse of the rhetorical faculty can work great mischief, the same charge can be brought against all good things (save virtue itself), and especially against the most useful things such as strength, health, wealth, and military skill. Rightly employed, they work the greatest blessings; and wrongly employed, they work the greatest harm.</p>
<attrib>(1355b)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>Related to this idea is the fact that tools can be used in good or bad ways, depending on their user. We believe that first and foremost, a <italic>persuader&#x2019;s motives</italic> <target target-type="page" id="page_20">20</target>determine whether a given influence attempt is good or bad, right or wrong, ethical or unethical. We maintain that the moral quality of a persuasive act is derived primarily from the ends a persuader seeks, and only secondarily from the means the persuader employs. It isn&#x2019;t so much <italic>what</italic> strategies and tactics a persuader uses as <italic>why</italic> he or she uses them.</p>
<p>To illustrate, suppose you asked us whether the use of &#x201C;fear appeals&#x201D; is ethically justified. We would have to say, it depends. If a fear appeal were being used to warn sexually active teens of the risks of HIV infection from unprotected sex, we would tend to say the appeal was justified. If a fear appeal were being used by a terrorist who threatened to kill a hostage every hour until his demands were met, we would say the appeal was unjustified. In each case, the motives of the persuader would &#x201C;color&#x201D; the use of the fear appeal. Consistent with our tool analogy, fear appeals, like other persuasive strategies, can be used for good or bad ends.</p>
<p>A second response to this criticism was highlighted earlier. The study of persuasion performs a <italic>defensive function</italic> insofar as it educates people to become more discriminating consumers of persuasive messages. For instance, we believe our &#x201C;Tips on Buying a New or Used Car&#x201D; (see <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box1_2">Box 1.2</xref>) are useful to any potential car buyer who wants to avoid being manipulated at a car lot. By increasing your awareness of the ploys of would-be persuaders, this text performs a watchdog function. You can use the information contained herein to arm yourself against the tactics of unscrupulous persuaders.</p>
<p>A third response that bears mentioning is that in denouncing the study of persuasion, antimanipulation types are also attempting to persuade. The message that persuasion is manipulative or exploitative is itself a persuasive appeal that advocates a position regarding the &#x201C;proper&#x201D; study of communication. When one group claims to know best how human communication should be studied, they are, in fact, standing on the persuasion soapbox themselves.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_12_2">
<title>Are Persuasion Findings Too Inconsistent or Confusing?</title>
<p>An additional complaint is that the study of persuasion has led to findings that are overly qualified, or contradictory in nature. Empirical investigations of persuasion, it is argued, have not yielded clear and consistent generalizations. There is no &#x201C;<italic>E</italic> = <italic>mc</italic><sup>2</sup>,&#x201D; no &#x201C;second law of thermodynamics,&#x201D; no universal when it comes to persuasion.</p>
<p>First, the complaint that persuasion isn&#x2019;t worth studying because the findings are often inconclusive or contradictory makes little sense. Quite the opposite: We believe that persuasion warrants study precisely because it <italic>is</italic> so elusive. Underlying this criticism is the expectation that reality is, or should be, simple and uncomplicated. Like it or not, understanding reality is hard work. As we&#x2019;ve already noted, human beings are complex creatures who rarely respond to messages for one and only one reason. Actually, we find this to be a redeeming feature of humanity. We rejoice in the fact that we aren&#x2019;t an altogether gullible, predictable, or controllable species.</p>
<p>A second response to this criticism is simply that persuasion research <italic>has</italic> revealed a number of significant, relevant generalizations. You&#x2019;ll find many such generalizations throughout this book. Newer techniques of statistical analysis, such <target target-type="page" id="page_21">21</target>as <italic>meta-analysis</italic>,<xref ref-type="fn" rid="fn1_6"><sup>6</sup></xref> have made it possible to reconcile some of the previous inconsistencies in the literature. In this text, we identify a number of noteworthy, albeit qualified, generalizations that are based on the most recent meta-analyses available.</p>
<boxed-text id="box1_2">
<label><target target-type="page" id="page_22">22</target>Box 1.2</label>
<caption><title>Tips on Buying a New or Used Car</title></caption>
<p>Given the current state of the economy and the economic fix in which car dealers find themselves, buying a car nowadays is easier than before. Car dealers are eager to sell cars. Nevertheless, car salespersons, especially used car salespersons, have a bad reputation. We&#x2019;ve met some honest, upstanding sellers. We&#x2019;ve also met some shady operators. Because a car is a major purchase, one would be well advised to err on the side of caution when negotiating with a car salesperson. Caveat emptor, as the saying goes: Let the buyer beware.</p>
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p>Be wary. Remember, buying a car is a ritual in which the car dealer has the upper hand. This is the prototype for high-pressure sales. They are professionals. They sell cars every day. You are an amateur. Who do you think has more experience with persuasion in this setting?</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Do your homework before you go visit a car dealer. Read up on the makes and models in which you&#x2019;re interested. Find out about performance criteria, standard features, and options before setting foot on a car lot. Consumer Reports compares used cars on reliability, safety, and other criteria based on data from actual owners. Research shows that doing your homework can save you money (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_68">Seiter &#x0026; Seiter, 2005</xref>).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Keep a poker face. If the salesperson knows you are eager or excited about the car purchase, he or she will smell blood. Once the salesperson knows you are emotionally attached to a particular car, you&#x2019;ll wind up paying more.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Take a calculator with you. Car salespersons like to pretend that the prices of things are entirely up to the calculator (&#x201C;Hey, let&#x2019;s see how the numbers shake out&#x201D;). The implication is that the numbers aren&#x2019;t negotiable or flexible. Everything is negotiable. Do your own figuring to see if the numbers &#x201C;shake out&#x201D; the same way. If not, ask why.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Once you are on the car lot, dealers will try to keep you there. They may put you in a cubicle, holding you &#x201C;hostage&#x201D; during the negotiations. Their psychological strategy is to wear you down. After hours of haggling, you&#x2019;ll become mentally drained and more likely to give in. They may ask for the keys to your trade-in, presumably to look it over and determine its value. Once they have your keys, you can&#x2019;t leave.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The car salesperson will want to avoid talking about the total price of the car, opting instead to discuss the monthly payment you can afford. You, however, should focus on four things: (a) the total purchase price, (b) the finance period, (c) the interest rate, and (d) the monthly payment. Don&#x2019;t discuss the monthly payment unless you are clear on the finance period involved (a 3-year loan, 4-year loan, 5-year loan, etc.). If you admit you can afford &#x0024;300 per month, the salesperson may simply switch to a longer finance period&#x2014;say, 4 years, instead of 3, thereby adding thousands of dollars to the total purchase price.</p></list-item>
