<list-item><p>During the negotiations, the salesperson may leave the room a number of times to talk with the &#x201C;sales manager.&#x201D; This is all choreographed. The salesperson can&#x2019;t agree to anything without checking with this mysterious figure, so the person with whom you are negotiating really can&#x2019;t commit to anything. You, however, will be asked to commit to a lot of things. Don&#x2019;t.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The salesperson will act like he or she is your best friend, even though you just met. The salesperson will look for ways to identify with you or ingratiate himself or herself to you to establish camaraderie (&#x201C;You like fly fishing? That makes two of us.&#x201D; &#x201C;Whaddya-know, my granddaughter is named &#x2018;Fifi&#x2019; too!&#x201D;). During the negotiations, the salesperson will pretend he or she is on your side and is willing to go out on a limb for you (&#x201C;Well, my sales manager may <target target-type="page" id="page_23">23</target>kick my butt for even taking him this offer, but hey, I like you&#x201D;). Remember, these two are working as a team, against you. Don&#x2019;t be confused for a moment about where the salesperson&#x2019;s loyalties reside. 9. The car salesperson will do all kinds of things to get you to make a commitment to buy (&#x201C;What would it take to get you to buy this car? Just tell me, whudda-I-godda-do to get you in this car?&#x201D;). Often, the salesperson will ask you to write down any amount you&#x2019;re offering on a slip of paper or an offer sheet, even though it isn&#x2019;t legally binding (it does increase your psychological commitment, however). The car dealer wants you to sit in the car, take it for a test spin, smell the upholstery, because then you will become psychologically committed to owning the car.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>If you get close to a deal, or alternatively, if a deal seems to be coming apart, don&#x2019;t be surprised if another salesperson comes in to take over the negotiations. Often a &#x201C;closer&#x201D; is sent in (sort of like a relief pitcher in baseball) to complete the sale.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Beware of &#x201C;loss leaders&#x201D; (advertised specials at absurdly low prices). These are come-ons designed to get you onto the lot. Once there, however, you&#x2019;ll be subjected to the &#x201C;old switcheroo.&#x201D; You&#x2019;ll find there is/was only one car at that price. You will probably be told, &#x201C;Sorry, it&#x2019;s already sold &#x2026; but I can make you a honey of a deal on &#x2026;&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The sale isn&#x2019;t over simply because you&#x2019;ve agreed on a price. You still have to deal with the dreaded &#x201C;finance person.&#x201D; You&#x2019;ll be given the impression that you&#x2019;re simply seeing the finance person to sign documents and process paperwork. Don&#x2019;t let down your guard. The finance person will try to add on thousands of dollars in the form of extended warranties, antitheft systems, and protective coatings.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The interest rate is just as important as the price of the car. Shop around for a car loan from a bank or credit union before you shop for a car. The rates may be lower and you can find out exactly how much you qualify for in advance.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Shop around for prices on options such as stereos before you go to a car dealer. People often bargain well on the purchase price, then give up everything they&#x2019;ve gained by failing to bargain on the price of extras. The price of everything is negotiable.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Don&#x2019;t let the salesperson know in advance that you have a trade-in. Any bargaining gains you make on the purchase price of the new car will just be deducted from the trade-in value of your used car. Sell the used car on your own, if at all possible. If that&#x2019;s not possible, you can always mention your trade-in after you&#x2019;ve negotiated the price of the new car.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Don&#x2019;t get a lemon. Buying a used car can be particularly risky. One of the authors bought a used sports car on eBay. How did he know from a mere picture and description whether the car was in good shape? He ran a CARFAX history on the car, easily available online (see <uri>www.carfax.com</uri>), which revealed that the car had had only one previous owner; had never been stolen, totaled, or repossessed; had correct odometer readings; and had passed a smog check each year when the vehicle registration was renewed. Since the car was coming from another state, the author went one step further and hired an independent mechanic to perform a &#x201C;prepurchase inspection&#x201D; on the car, at a cost of about &#x0024;150. We strongly suggest you do the same for any used car. After all, how much can the average consumer tell about a car from looking under the hood and kicking the tires?</p></list-item>
</list>
</boxed-text>
<p>You&#x2019;ll notice in this book that we&#x2019;ve drawn on the people in the trenches themselves to learn how persuasion works in particular contexts and settings. We&#x2019;ve talked to used car salespersons, funeral home operators, retail clothing clerks, advertising firms, former cult members, door-to-door salespersons, and telemarketers to find out&#x2014;from the horse&#x2019;s mouth, so to speak&#x2014;how persuasion operates.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_13">
<title>Ethical Concerns about the Use of Persuasion</title>
<p>We would be remiss if we concluded this chapter without emphasizing the importance of ethics in the persuasion process. We wish to underscore the point that the use of <target target-type="page" id="page_24">24</target>persuasion is fraught with ethical concerns. We raise a number of such concerns in <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box1_3">Box 1.3</xref> for you to ponder. Our position is that in learning how to become a more effective persuader, you should strive to be an ethical persuader as well. In the final chapter, we address a number of ethical questions related to various strategies and techniques of persuasion discussed throughout the text. We wait until the final chapter to fully examine ethical concerns for two reasons: First, until you&#x2019;ve learned more about persuasion, you may not fully appreciate all of the ethical issues that are involved. Second, after you&#x2019;ve studied the full scope of persuasion as we present it in this text, you&#x2019;ll be in a much better position to place these ethical questions in perspective.</p>
<boxed-text id="box1_3">
<label>Box 1.3</label>
<caption><title>Ethical or Unethical Persuasion? You Decide</title></caption>
<p>Instructions: For each of the following scenarios, indicate how ethical or unethical you perceive the persuader or the persuasive strategy to be, based on a five-point scale (with 1 being &#x201C;highly ethical&#x201D; and 5 being &#x201C;highly unethical&#x201D;).</p>
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p>A student pretends to cry in a professor&#x2019;s office in an attempt to coax the professor into giving her a makeup exam. Is this ethical persuasion?</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>A persuader advances an argument he doesn&#x2019;t believe in, but that he thinks will be convincing to his listeners. The argument isn&#x2019;t untrue or invalid; it just happens to be one with that the persuader himself does not agree. Is this ethical persuasion?</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>A car salesperson emphasizes that the model of car a customer is considering has &#x201C;more horsepower and better mileage than the competition.&#x201D; The salesperson fails to mention that the car has worse reliability and a worse safety record than the competition. Is this ethical persuasion?</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>A skilled attorney successfully defends a client she knows to be guilty. Is this ethical persuasion?</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>A minister tells his congregation that a vote for a particular candidate is &#x201C;a vote for the Devil incarnate&#x201D; and that the scriptures demand that the faithful cast their ballots for another candidate. Is this ethical persuasion?</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>A persuader sincerely believes in the arguments she is presenting, but the facts and information she cites are incorrect and outdated. Is this ethical persuasion?</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Parents use a fear appeal to convince their child to clean her room. &#x201C;Santa doesn&#x2019;t bring presents to children with dirty rooms,&#x201D; they warn. Is this ethical persuasion?</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>A children&#x2019;s cereal states on the box, &#x201C;High in the vitamins kids need&#x201D; but doesn&#x2019;t mention that the cereal is high in sugar, too. Is this ethical persuasion?</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>A newlywed husband is upset that his wife wants to go to a dance club with some of her single friends for drinks. &#x201C;If you go,&#x201D; he warns, &#x201C;I&#x2019;m going to a strip club with some of my friends.&#x201D; Is this ethical persuasion?</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>A political campaign runs a series of negative attack ads against an opponent, not because the campaign manager prefers to but because voter surveys show that negative ads will work, whereas ads that take the political &#x201C;high road&#x201D; won&#x2019;t. Is this ethical persuasion?</p></list-item>
</list>
</boxed-text>
</sec>
<sec id="sec1_14">
<title>Summary</title>
<p>We hope that we&#x2019;ve convinced you of the ubiquity of persuasion in human interaction. The capacity to persuade is one of the defining features of humankind. This fact provides the strongest possible reason for studying persuasion. Given that learning about persuasion serves an instrumental function, a knowledge and awareness function, a defensive function, a debunking function, and a well-being and self-worth function, we believe there is ample justification for studying this topic. Finally, rejoinders to two current criticisms of the study of persuasion were offered. Hopefully, a persuasive case has been made for learning about persuasion.</p>
<p>One other thing: Did we mention that learning about persuasion can also be fun?</p>
</sec>
</body>
<back>
<fn-group>
<title>Notes</title>
<fn id="fn1_1"><label>1</label><p>The scientific study of persuasion dates back to the 1940s and 1950s, when Carl Hovland founded the Yale Attitude Research Program as part of the war effort.</p>
<p>The government wanted to know how to counter enemy propaganda that could affect the morale of troops and how susceptible POWs were to brainwashing.</p></fn>
<fn id="fn1_2"><label>2</label><p>Aristotle&#x2019;s work <italic>Rhetoric</italic> is one such text that has survived the test of time. Written in the fourth century BCE, Aristotle&#x2019;s work has had a lasting influence on our understanding of persuasion. Many of his insights and observations are considered valid even today.</p></fn>
<fn id="fn1_3"><label>3</label><p>Note that with the exception of Hitler, these charismatic leaders enjoyed a limited following. The rest of us weren&#x2019;t taken in by their claims, suggesting that people, in general, aren&#x2019;t that gullible after all.</p></fn>
<fn id="fn1_4"><label>4</label><p>A <italic>New York Times</italic> article (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_75">Story, 2007</xref>) sets daily ad exposure at up to 5,000 ads per day. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_64">Rosseli, Skelly, and Mackie (1995)</xref> state, &#x201C;even by conservative estimates, the average person is exposed to 300&#x2013;400 persuasive messages a day from the mass media alone&#x201D; (p. 163). <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_28">Jones (2004)</xref> pegs the number of advertising messages at 300 to 1,500 every day, but indicates that some estimates are as high as 3,000 per day&#x2014;a number Jones labels fanciful (p. 12). Without saying who says so, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_3">Berger (2011)</xref> reports that &#x201C;some estimate that we are exposed to 15,000 commercial messages each day&#x201D; (p. 101).</p>
<p>We are suspicious of such estimates, however, because they may simply represent &#x201C;unknowable&#x201D; statistics. At the very least, estimates of the number of persuasive messages to which the average person is exposed involve extrapolations, and the criteria upon which the extrapolations are based aren&#x2019;t always provided. What&#x2019;s more, <target target-type="page" id="page_25">25</target>the estimates often contradict one another. By way of illustration, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_3">Berger (2011)</xref> maintains that &#x201C;advertisers spend around &#x0024;800 per person in the United States on advertising&#x201D; (p. 101), whereas <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_15">Dupont (1999)</xref> claims, &#x201C;In the U.S., close to &#x0024;400 for every man, woman, and child are invested in advertising each year&#x201D; (p. 8). Which, if either, estimate is correct?</p></fn>
<fn id="fn1_5"><label>5</label><p>We don&#x2019;t have sufficient space to devote to this topic here, but suffice it to say that the traditional notion of scientific realism is under siege from the antirealism camp (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_37">Kourany, 1998</xref>). The antirealists argue that science is neither purely objective nor impartial but heavily value laden (see also <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_43">Laudan, 1984</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1_47">Longino, 1990</xref>).</p></fn>
<fn id="fn1_6"><label>6</label><p><italic>Meta-analysis</italic> refers to a statistical technique that allows a researcher to combine the results of many separate investigations and examine them as if they were one big super study. A meta-analysis is capable of revealing trends across a number of studies and resolving apparent inconsistencies among studies.</p></fn>
</fn-group>

<ref id="ref1_20"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Fredman</surname>, <given-names>K.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2015</year>). <article-title>Fund me or fraud me? <ref id="ref1_21"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Gilmore</surname>, <given-names>J. <ref id="ref1_66"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Schwartz</surname>, <given-names>E.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2016</year>, <month>May</month> <day>20</day>). <article-title>Why we eat sliced apples</article-title>. <source>Econlife</source>. <date-in-citation content-type="retrieved">Retrieved on <month>February</month> <day>19</day>, <year>2017</year></date-in-citation> from: <uri>http://econlife.com/2016/05/behavioral-nudges-and-apple-consumption/</uri></mixed-citation></ref>

<ref id="ref1_69"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Shiomi</surname>, <given-names>M.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Nakagawa</surname>, <given-names>K.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Shinozawa</surname>, <given-names>K.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Matsumura</surname>, <given-names>R.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Ishiguro</surname>, <given-names>H.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Hagita</surname>, <given-names>N.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2017</year>). <article-title>Does a robot&#x2019;s touch encourage human effort?</article-title> <source>International Journal of Social Robotics</source>, <volume>9</volume>, <fpage>5</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>15</lpage>. doi:<object-id>10.1007/s12369&#x2013;016&#x2013;0339-x</object-id></mixed-citation></ref>

<ref id="ref1_73"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><person-group person-group-type="author"><collab>Spotty teens</collab></person-group> (<year>2009</year>, <month>March</month> <day>25</day>). <article-title>Spotty teens deterred from underpasses by acne light</article-title>. <source>The Telegraph</source>. <date-in-citation content-type="retrieved">Retrieved on <month>March</month> <day>29</day>, <year>2009</year></date-in-citation>, from: <uri>www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/law-and-order/5049757/Spotty-teens-detered-from-underpasses-by-acne-light.html</uri></mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref1_74"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Sprague</surname>, <given-names>R.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Wells</surname>, <given-names>M. E.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2010</year>). <article-title>Regulating online buzz marketing: Untangling a web of deceit</article-title>. <source>American Business Law Journal</source>, <volume>47</volume>(<issue>3</issue>), <fpage>415</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>454</lpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref1_75"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Story</surname>, <given-names>L.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2007</year>, <month>January</month> <day>15</day>). <article-title>Anywhere the eye can see, it&#x2019;s likely to see an ad</article-title>. <source>The New York Times</source>. <date-in-citation content-type="retrieved">Retrieved on <month>February</month> <day>20</day>, <year>2017</year></date-in-citation> from: <uri>www.nytimes.com/2007/01/15/business/media/15everywhere.html?pagewanted=all&#x0026;_r=0</uri></mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref1_76"><mixed-citation publication-type="book"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Sunstein</surname>, <given-names>C. The politics of libertarian paternalism</source>. <publisher-loc>New Haven, NJ</publisher-loc>: <publisher-name>Yale University Press</publisher-name>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref1_77"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Thaler</surname>, <given-names>R. <ref id="ref1_79"><mixed-citation publication-type="book"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Von Blum</surname>, <given-names>P.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>1976</year>). <source>The art of social conscience</source>. <publisher-loc>New York</publisher-loc>: <publisher-name>Universe Books</publisher-name>.<target target-type="page" id="page_29">29</target></mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref1_80"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Wodjynski</surname>, <given-names>B. W.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2016</year>). <article-title>The deceptiveness of sponsored news articles: How readers recognize and perceive native advertising</article-title>. <source>American Behavioral Scientist</source>, <volume>60</volume>(<issue>12</issue>), <fpage>1475</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>1491</lpage>. doi:<object-id>10.1177/000276421666014</object-id></mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref1_81"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Zentino</surname>, <given-names>R.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2016</year>, <month>November</month> <day>30</day>). <article-title>Canadian cops to punish drunk drivers with Nickelback tunes</article-title>. <source>CNN</source>. <date-in-citation content-type="retrieved">Retrieved on <month>February</month> <day>20</day>, <year>2017</year></date-in-citation> from: cnn.com/2016/11/30/americas/ police-canada-nickelback-dui-trnd/</mixed-citation></ref>
</ref-list>
</back>
</book-part>
<book-part book-part-type="chapter" id="chapter2">
<book-part-meta>
<title-group>
<label>2</label>
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_30">30</target>What Constitutes Persuasion?</title>
<alt-title alt-title-type="running-head">What Constitutes Persuasion?</alt-title>
</title-group>
<contrib-group>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Gass</surname>
<given-names>Robert H.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Seiter</surname>
<given-names>John S.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
</contrib-group>
</book-part-meta>
<body>
<p>WHAT IS PERSUASION? How broad or narrow is the concept? Is persuasion a subset of human communication in general, much like baseball is a subset of sports? Or is persuasion an element found in all human communication in the same way that coordination plays a role in every sport? Not surprisingly, different authors view the concept of persuasion in different ways and have adopted different definitions of the term. In this chapter, we explore some of the ways that persuasion has been defined. We offer our own rather broad-based, far-reaching conceptualization of persuasion based on five limiting criteria. We also present our own model of what persuasion is (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_22">Gass &#x0026; Seiter, 1997</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_23">2000</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_24">2004</xref>) and examine three additional models (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_10">Chaiken, 1979</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_11">1987</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_20">Eagly &#x0026; Chaiken, 1993</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_41">Petty &#x0026; Cacioppo, 1986a</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_42">1986b</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_29">Kruglanksi &#x0026; Thompson, 1999a</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_30">1999b</xref>) of how persuasion functions.</p>
<p>You may have encountered some unusual uses of the term <italic>persuasion.</italic> For example, we have a friend in the construction industry who refers to his <target target-type="page" id="page_31">31</target>sledgehammer as his &#x201C;persuader.&#x201D; He tends to err on the side of cutting a 2 &#x00D7; 4 board too long, rather than too short, and then &#x201C;persuading&#x201D; it into place. As another example, you may recall seeing an old gangster movie in which a mob boss orders his henchman to take somebody out back &#x201C;for a little gentle persuasion,&#x201D; meaning a beating. Although we don&#x2019;t normally associate persuasion with pounding lumber or pummeling people, even in ordinary usage the term does have a wide variety of meanings. Consider each of the hypothetical situations in <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box2_1">Box 2.1</xref>, &#x201C;What Constitutes Persuasion?&#x201D; Which of these scenarios do <italic>you</italic> consider to be persuasion?</p>
<boxed-text id="box2_1">
<label>Box 2.1</label>
<caption><title>What Constitutes Persuasion?</title></caption>
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p>Muffin notices a grubby-looking weirdo in one of the front seats of the bus she is boarding. She opts for a seat toward the rear of the bus. Did the man &#x201C;persuade&#x201D; her to sit elsewhere?</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Benny Bigot is the principal speaker at a park rally to recruit more members to the American Nazi party. Many of the people who hear Benny are so turned off by his speech that they are more anti-Nazi than they were before they attended the rally. Did Benny &#x201C;persuade&#x201D; them?</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>During a dramatic pause in his lecture for his three-hour night class, Professor Hohum hears a student&#x2019;s stomach growling. The professor then decides it would be a good time for the class to take a break. Did the student &#x201C;persuade&#x201D; Professor Hohum?</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Babbs is standing at a street corner, watching passersby. The first three people she sees are wearing sweatshirts with political and/or social slogans emblazoned across the front. The fourth person to pass by is wearinga plain white T-shirt. Are the first three people &#x201C;persuading&#x201D; Babbs? Is the fourth?</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Sheldon makes a new year&#x2019;s resolution to go on a diet. To remind himself not to snack, he sticks a picture of a male model with &#x201C;six pack&#x201D; abs on his refrigerator. Later, when he has an ice-cream craving, he sees the picture and decides to have an apple instead. Did Sheldon &#x201C;persuade&#x201D; himself?</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Bubba is at the supermarket, pondering which of two brands of beer to purchase. After studying both brands attentively, he opts for an imported brand. Unbeknown to him, another shopper observed his deliberations. That shopper then walks over to the display and selects the same brand. Did &#x201C;persuasion&#x201D; take place?</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Trudy is an impressionable freshperson who is in a jam. She has just realized a term paper is due in her philosophy class. Desperate, she asks Rex, who is the captain of the debate squad, if he will help her. Rex offers to give her an &#x201C;A&#x201D; paper he submitted when he had the same class 2 years prior if Trudy will sleep with him. Is Rex using &#x201C;persuasion&#x201D;?</p></list-item>
</list>
</boxed-text>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_32">32</target>Adding to the difficulty of defining persuasion is the fact that persuasion also goes by a variety of other names. Some of its aliases include terms such as <italic>advising, brainwashing, coercion, compliance gaining, convincing, education, indoctrination, influence, manipulation,</italic> and <italic>propaganda.</italic> Of course, whether these terms are considered synonyms for persuasion, or simply related terms, depends on one&#x2019;s definition of persuasion.</p>
<p>Defining a concept is analogous to building a fence. A fence is designed to keep somethings in and other things out. In the same way, a definition encompasses some elements or aspects of a concept while excluding others. Which &#x201C;species&#x201D; of human communication is to be found inside the &#x201C;barnyard&#x201D; of persuasion depends on the size and shape of the fence a particular author builds. Fortunately, the differences in various definitions can be clarified, if not resolved, by focusing on two key considerations. We turn to these next.</p>
<sec id="sec2_1">
<title>Pure Versus Borderline Cases of Persuasion</title>
<p>The first consideration is whether one is interested in pure persuasion or borderline cases of persuasion. By <italic>pure persuasion</italic>, we mean clear-cut cases of persuasion, on which most people would agree. Everyone would agree that a presidential debate, or a television commercial, or an attorney&#x2019;s closing remarks to a jury are instances of persuasion. Such examples represent &#x201C;paradigm cases&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_39">O&#x2019;Keefe, 2016</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_54">Simons, 1986</xref>) because they are at the core of what we think of when we envision persuasion at work. Other instances, though, lie closer to the boundary or periphery of what we normally think of as persuasion. These instances we refer to as <italic>borderline cases</italic> of persuasion. Not everyone would agree that a derelict&#x2019;s mere appearance &#x201C;persuades&#x201D; passersby to keep their distance. Nor would everyone agree that involuntary reflexes such as burps, blinking, and pupil dilation constitute &#x201C;persuasive&#x201D; phenomena. These cases are less clear-cut, more &#x201C;iffy.&#x201D; Much of the disparity in definitions is rooted in the fact that some authors are concerned with pure persuasion, whereas other authors are concerned with borderline cases as well. It isn&#x2019;t so much a matter of being right or wrong as it is a matter of how wide a net each author wishes to cast. The preliminary model of the scope of persuasion (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig2_1">Figure 2.1</xref>) illustrates this distinction in approaches.<xref ref-type="fn" rid="fn2_1"><sup>1</sup></xref> As the shading in the model suggests, the dividing line between pure and borderline persuasion is fuzzy, rather than distinct.</p>
<fig id="fig2_1" position="float">
<label>Figure 2.1</label>
<caption><title>Preliminary model of persuasion.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig2_1.tif"/>
</fig>
<p>Although we don&#x2019;t think there is a single, correct definition of persuasion, we do think there are somethings that a functional, contemporary definition of persuasion ought to do. A contemporary definition should take into account the rich complex of verbal, nonverbal, and contextual cues found in interpersonal encounters. A contemporary definition also should acknowledge the many subtle, implicit cues that accompany face-to-face influence attempts. By implicit cues, we mean communication that occurs at a very low level of awareness, or even unconsciously. As an example, cultural factors might influence a person&#x2019;s choice of compliance-gaining strategies, without the person even realizing it (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_56">Wiseman et al., 1995</xref>). Such implicit communication is, in fact, quite common (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_31">Langer, 1978</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_32">1989a</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_33">1989b</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_51">Roloff, 1980</xref>) and an important ingredient in persuasion. The definition and model of persuasion that we offer later in this chapter take these features into account.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec2_2">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_33">33</target>Limiting Criteria for Defining Persuasion</title>
<p>A second consideration in defining persuasion involves the limiting criteria that form the basis for a given definition. Different scholars apply different litmus tests when defining persuasion. Five basic criteria can be gleaned from the various definitions offered in the literature (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_24">Gass &#x0026; Seiter, 2004</xref>). We examine each of these criteria in turn.</p>
<sec id="sec2_2_1">
<title>Intentionality</title>
<p>Is persuasion necessarily conscious or purposeful? Is there such a thing as &#x201C;accidental&#x201D; persuasion? Many who write about persuasion adopt a source-centered view by focusing on the sender&#x2019;s intent as a defining feature of persuasion. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_40">Perloff (2013)</xref> adopts this view, stressing that &#x201C;persuasion does involve a deliberate attempt to influence another person. Persuaders must intend to change another individual&#x2019;s attitude or behavior and must be aware (at least at some level) that they are trying to accomplish this goal&#x201D; (p. 18). For some authors, intentionality is the litmus test that distinguishes <italic>persuasion</italic> from <italic>social influence</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_24">Gass &#x0026; Seiter, 2004</xref>).</p>
<p>Certainly, pure persuasion would seem to be intentional. When we think of obvious cases of persuasion we tend to think of situations in which one person purposefully tries to influence another. But what about borderline cases of persuasion? We believe that many influence attempts take place without any conscious awareness on the part of the persuader.</p>
<p>As just one instance, parents quite commonly instill beliefs, impart values, and model behavior for their children, a phenomenon known as <italic>social modeling</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_4">Bandura, 1977</xref>). Yet they may not realize how much of what they say and do is absorbed by their young-uns. As any parent will attest, many of the lessons parents &#x201C;teach&#x201D; their children are completely unintended. Another form of unintentional influence involves <target target-type="page" id="page_34">34</target><italic>socialization</italic> processes. From the moment children are born, they are socialized into their respective gender roles, cultural customs, religious practices, and socioeconomic habits. Some socialization processes are mindful, but many are not.</p>
<p>A second way in which an intent criterion is problematic is that people do not always know what specific outcome they are seeking. Face-to-face encounters, in particular, are laden with spontaneity. Social influence may arise in and through our interaction with others, rather than as a result of planning and forethought. Sometimes persuasion just happens.</p>
<p>A third problem with relying on an intent criterion involves situations in which there are unintended receivers. Imagine a scenario in which two people are discussing which bets to place on a horse race. One tells the other about an inside tip on a horse that&#x2019;s a &#x201C;sure thing.&#x201D; A third party overhears the conversation and places a wager on the horse. In such situations, persuaders don&#x2019;t intend for third parties to be influenced, yet they often are. Two studies (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_25">Greenberg &#x0026; Pyszczynski, 1985</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_27">Kirkland, Greenberg, &#x0026; Pyszczynski, 1987</xref>) clearly demonstrate the operation of the <italic>unintended receiver effect</italic>. In these studies, the researchers created a situation in which third parties overheard an ethnic slur directed against an African American. The results of both studies revealed that the overheard ethnic slur led to lower evaluations by the third parties of the individual at whom the slur was directed. Notice that a reliance on an intent standard for defining persuasion tends to make senders less accountable for the consequences of their unintended communication. If a message has harmful effects, the source can disavow any responsibility by claiming &#x201C;that&#x2019;s not what I intended.&#x201D;</p>
<p>A fourth limitation lies in the difficulty of ascertaining another&#x2019;s intent. There can be a difference between a persuader&#x2019;s <italic>stated</italic> intent versus his or her <italic>actual</italic> intent. Who makes the determination in such cases? The sender? The receiver? A third party?</p>
<p>Finally, resolving the issue of intent is particularly difficult in interpersonal contexts, in which both parties may be engaged simultaneously in attempts at influence. When there are two interactants, whose intent counts? Intent-based definitions, we believe, are ill suited to modern conceptualizations of human interaction as a two-way venture. The linear view of persuasion that such definitions imply, from sender to receiver, ignores opportunities for mutual influence.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec2_2_2">
<title>Effects</title>
<p>The effects criterion poses the question: Has persuasion taken place if no one is actually persuaded? Some authors adopt a receiver-oriented definition of persuasion by restricting its use to situations in which receivers are somehow changed, altered, or affected. Daniel O&#x2019;Keefe (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_39">2016</xref>) underscores this perspective when he writes:
<disp-quote>
<p>The notion of success is embedded in the concept of persuasion. Notice, for instance, that it doesn&#x2019;t make sense to say, &#x201C;I persuaded him, but failed.&#x201D; One can say, &#x201C;I <italic>tried</italic> to persuade him, but failed,&#x201D; but to say simply, &#x201C;I persuaded him&#x201D; is to imply a successful attempt to influence.</p>
<attrib>(pp. 2&#x2013;3)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>Although we recognize the attraction of this point of view, we believe there are problems with limiting the definition of persuasion in this way. We take the position <target target-type="page" id="page_35">35</target>that even if a person is communicating badly, he or she is <italic>still</italic> communicating. Similarly, we believe that a person can be engaged in persuasion even if it is <italic>ineffective</italic> persuasion. The same can be said for most other activities. A salesperson might fail to close a deal but would still be engaged in selling. A dancer might dance badly, stepping on his or her partner&#x2019;s toes, but would still be engaged in dancing. In short, a person can be engaged in an activity whether the person is doing it well or not.</p>
<p>An effects criterion emphasizes persuasion as a <italic>product</italic>. Such an orientation, however, bears little fidelity to current conceptualizations of human communication as a <italic>process</italic>. If we think of persuasion only as an outcome or a thing, then an effects orientation makes perfectly good sense. We maintain that persuasion is better understood as an activity in which people engage. This is more than semantic quibbling. By approaching persuasion as a process, scholars and researchers are more likely to gain insights into how it functions, or what makes it tick, because they are focusing on <italic>what&#x2019;s going on</italic>, not simply on how things turn out.</p>
<p>A second weakness is the same as that already associated with an intent criterion: An effects criterion embodies a linear view of persuasion, from source to receiver. In face-to-face encounters, however, there isn&#x2019;t simply <italic>a</italic> source and <italic>a</italic> receiver. Both parties may be simultaneously engaged in persuasion. They shape, adapt, and adjust their strategies in response to one another (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_50">Prislin et al., 2011</xref>).</p>
<p>A third problem with relying on an effects criterion is that it is often difficult, if not impossible, to measure persuasive effects. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_52">Rotzoll and Haefner (1996)</xref>, for example, concluded that only 20 to 40 percent of advertising is effective. The other 60 to 80 percent is also persuasion&#x2014;it&#x2019;s just ineffective persuasion. In fact, the ability to measure persuasive outcomes may hinge entirely on the sensitivity of one&#x2019;s measuring instruments (scales, surveys, sales figures, etc.). Furthermore, what constitutes the threshold for a successful versus unsuccessful attempt at persuasion? How much attitude or behavior change must take place to say persuasion has occurred? And what about the occasional odd circumstance in which persuasion &#x201C;boomerangs&#x201D;&#x2014; that is, a persuader achieves an effect that is <italic>contrary</italic> to his or her intended purpose? Such questions, we believe, highlight the many vagaries inherent in relying on an effects criterion.</p>
<p>We do agree that, as with an intent criterion, pure cases of persuasion can usually be evaluated by their overall effectiveness. Even then, persuasion is rarely an all-or-nothing venture. If one also wishes to focus on borderline cases of persuasion, one must accept the fact that partial persuasion is more the rule than the exception. Notice, too, that there is some tension between relying on intent and effects as limiting criteria: What is achieved isn&#x2019;t always what is intended, and what is intended isn&#x2019;t always what is achieved.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec2_2_3">
<title>Free Will and Conscious Awareness</title>
<p>Many authors endorse the view that there is a distinction between persuasion and coercion. This view is also receiver based, but it focuses on whether a person is aware that she or he is being persuaded and how much freedom the person has to accept or reject the message. Persuasion, these authors suggest, is noncoercive. As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_54">Herbert Simons (1986)</xref> puts it, &#x201C;persuasion is a form of influence that predisposes, but does not impose&#x201D; (p. 22). <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_40">Richard Perloff (2013)</xref> also makes this point when he states that persuasion requires &#x201C;an atmosphere of free choice&#x201D; (p. 27).</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 2.2</label>
<caption><title>&#x201C;Persuasion&#x201D; and &#x201C;coercion&#x201D; often coexist side by side.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig2_2.tif"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; Robert Mankoff/The New Yorker Collection/<uri>www.cartoonbank.com</uri></p>
</fig>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_36">36</target>It naturally follows that if a person is unaware that an influence attempt is taking place, she or he can&#x2019;t consciously resist it. Thus, mindfulness is a prerequisite for free choice. Nevertheless, we believe that persuasion can and does occur without the conscious awareness of receivers. For example, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_2">Ackerman, Nocera, and Bargh (2010)</xref> found that evaluations of job applicants can be shaped in important yet unconscious ways. Participants in an experiment were asked to evaluate resumes of job applicants. Some participants read resumes attached to heavier clipboards, while others read resumes attached to lighter clipboards. The results were intriguing. Applicants whose resumes were attached to heavier clipboards were rated higher overall and as being more serious than their &#x201C;lightweight&#x201D; counterparts. The physical weight of the clipboards translated into judgments about whether the applicants themselves were more substantial. Our advice, if you want to be seen as having more &#x201C;gravitas&#x201D;: print your resume on a heavier bond of paper or, better yet, chisel it in stone.</p>
<p>In fact, many influence attempts succeed precisely because they operate at a low level of awareness. For example, consumers generally may be aware that product planting (placing products in movies and TV shows) is common, but they may not know how prevalent the practice is, let alone recognize each and every instance of product planting that occurs. Persuasion that relies on social networking, such as word of mouth (WOM), is designed to seem spontaneous rather than planned. A person might receive a link to a funny website from a friend, not realizing that the site was developed as a marketing tool by a commercial entity.</p>
<p>You may think of persuasion and coercion as being separate and distinct, but in our view, they aren&#x2019;t so much polar opposites as close relatives. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_49">Powers (2007)</xref> agrees when she asks:
<disp-quote>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_37">37</target>Does a coercion claim have to show that another choice was in fact available? Just how available does the other choice have to be? Is it necessary to present all possible alternatives in order to avoid a charge of coercion? How equal do the choices have to be and how aware does the receiver have to be of those choices, and who decides what <italic>available</italic> means?</p>
<attrib>(p. 128)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>In fact, we would suggest that most influence attempts we encounter in daily life include both persuasive and coercive elements. Rarely in life is one free to make a completely unfettered choice. There are almost always strings attached. This is particularly true of face-to-face encounters. If a friend asks to borrow 20 bucks, we can say &#x201C;no,&#x201D; but there may be relational consequences for declining.</p>
<p>Rarely, too, are influence attempts completely coercive. For example, holding a gun to another person&#x2019;s head would seem to be an obvious example of coercion. We readily admit that this situation is <italic>primarily</italic> coercive. But what if the victim doesn&#x2019;t believe the gun is loaded? Or what if the victim thinks the threatener is bluffing? To be successful, a threat&#x2014;even a threat of violence&#x2014;must be perceived as credible. Thus, even in what might seem like a clear-cut case of coercion there are persuasive elements at work. And conversely, even in what appear to be cut-and-dried cases of persuasion, there may be coercive features operating. In our view, the issue isn&#x2019;t so much <italic>whether</italic> a situation is persuasive or coercive as <italic>how</italic> persuasive or coercive the situation is.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec2_2_4">
<title>Symbolic Action</title>
<p>A number of authors maintain that persuasion begins and ends with symbolic expression, which includes language as well as other meaning-laden acts, such as civil disobedience and protest marches. This approach focuses on the means, or channel, of persuasion as a limiting criterion. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_7">Timothy Borchers (2013)</xref> endorses this view, noting that &#x201C;our definition of persuasion uses the phrase &#x2018;language strategies and/or other symbols&#x2019; to indicate the content of persuasion&#x201D; (p. 19). Similarly, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_37">Gerald Miller (1980)</xref> maintains that &#x201C;in most instances, language is an integral aspect of the persuasive transaction&#x201D; (p. 5). <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_40">Richard Perloff (2013)</xref> also adheres to this point of view, noting that &#x201C;Persuasion is a symbolic process&#x201D; (p. 17).</p>
<p>Authors who limit the scope of persuasion to symbolic action fear that without such a limitation, all human behavior could be construed as persuasion. Their point is well taken. However, restricting the medium for persuasion to words or symbols leads to a rather disjointed view of persuasion. We believe that a definition that limits persuasion to words and clearly codified symbols leaves out too much. Most magazine ads emphasize pictures rather than words. In fact, one study suggests that the text of a typical ad is read by fewer than 10 percent of the readers (Starch, cited in <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_19">Dupont, 1999</xref>). The same is true of television commercials. It seems arbitrary to limit persuasion to the words contained in an ad or a commercial, without considering the role of the images as well. We think that the <italic>whole</italic> ad or the <italic>whole</italic> commercial persuades.</p>
<p>We also believe that some of the most intriguing aspects of persuasion can be found in nonverbal behavior, which lies on the periphery of symbolic action. For example, research on the physiological correlates of deception demonstrates that <target target-type="page" id="page_38">38</target>a variety of involuntary nonverbal cues (such as blinking, smiling, and pupil dilation) are positive indicators of lying (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_14">DePaulo, Stone, &#x0026; Lassiter, 1985</xref>). We focus on deception as a form of persuasion in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter12">Chapter 12</xref>. Research on source credibility reveals that physical attributes, such as height or attractiveness, influence judgments of source credibility (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_10">Chaiken, 1979</xref>). We examine such factors in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter4">Chapter 4</xref>. We also can think of situations in which pure behavior&#x2014;for example, nonsymbolic actions&#x2014;are nevertheless persuasive. When a basketball player makes a head fake to fool a defender, we would maintain that the player is <italic>persuading</italic> the defender to go the wrong way. The fake is all behavior, but the player has to <italic>sell</italic> the fake to get the defender to &#x201C;bite&#x201D; on it.</p>
<p>We believe that restricting the study of persuasion exclusively to symbolic expression leads to a fragmented understanding of the subject. Persuasion involves more than language usage or symbol usage. A whole host of factors are at work. Interestingly, many authors who profess an adherence to symbolic action nevertheless treat a variety of nonsymbolic aspects of behavior, such as those just mentioned, in their texts.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec2_2_5">
<title>Interpersonal Versus Intrapersonal</title>
<p>How many actors are required for persuasion to take place? A last limiting criterion that deserves mention is whether persuasion can involve only one person or whether persuasion requires the participation of two or more distinct persons. Some scholars adopt the view that engaging in persuasion is like dancing the tango: it takes two (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_5">Bettinghaus &#x0026; Cody, 1994</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_26">Johnston, 1994</xref>). We agree in the case of the tango, but not in the case of persuasion. In fact, we maintain that attempts at self-persuasion are quite common (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_3">Aronson, 1999</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_40">Perloff, 2013</xref>). A person might search for a rationalization to do something he or she wants to do, such as blowing the rent money on front-row concert tickets. In such cases, people talk themselves into whatever they wish to do.</p>
<p>We are sympathetic to the &#x201C;two or more&#x201D; perspective but suggest that, once again, the issue comes down to whether one wishes to focus exclusively on pure cases of persuasion or borderline cases as well. We heartily agree that when we think of pure cases of persuasion, we conjure up an image of one person persuading another. When we include borderline cases, we imagine instances in which individuals sometimes try to convince themselves.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec2_3">
<title>A Model of the Scope of Persuasion</title>
<p>In light of the five limiting criteria just discussed, we can now offer an enhanced model (see <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig2_3">Figure 2.3</xref>) that encompasses both pure and borderline cases of persuasion (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_24">Gass &#x0026; Seiter, 2004</xref>). As with the preliminary model, the inner circle represents pure persuasion&#x2014;that is, what we think of as the core of persuasion. The outer circle represents borderline persuasion. Superimposed on top of these two circles are five wedges, each representing one of the five limiting criteria previously discussed. The inner portion of each wedge represents the pure case for that criterion. The outer portion represents the borderline case. Once again, the shading between the inner and outer circles reflects the fuzzy dividing line that exists between pure and borderline persuasion.</p>
<fig id="fig2_3" position="float">
<label>Figure 2.3</label>
<caption><title>Enhanced model of persuasion.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig2_3.tif"/>
</fig>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_39">39</target>Based on this enhanced model, you can appreciate the fact that different definitions feature different wedges of the inner and outer circles. Source-oriented definitions restrict persuasion to the inner circle of the &#x201C;intentional&#x2013;unintentional&#x201D; wedge. Receiver-based definitions limit persuasion to the inner circle of the &#x201C;effects&#x2013;no effects&#x201D; wedge. Other receiver-based definitions favor the inner circle with respect to the &#x201C;free choice&#x2013;coercion&#x201D; criterion, and so on.</p>
<p>As you can also see from the enhanced model, some definitions concern themselves with several wedges at the same time, whereas other definitions are based on a single limiting criterion. It&#x2019;s worth noting that all definitions of persuasion&#x2014; including our own, which we present shortly&#x2014;are linguistic constructs. They exist in the world of words. Whether a given situation involves persuasion is not a matter of fact but of judgment.</p>
<p>Our own preference is for an expanded view of persuasion that includes borderline cases as well as pure persuasion. We tend to side with the view that persuasion is sometimes unintentional; that it sometimes has no discernible effects; that people aren&#x2019;t always aware of when it is occurring; that it often includes at least some coercive features; that it needn&#x2019;t be conveyed exclusively via symbols; and that humans do, on occasion, engage in self-persuasion. Many of the topics discussed in later chapters reside in the outer ring of our model. As we&#x2019;ve already indicated, we believe that some of the most intriguing aspects of persuasion can be found there. We firmly believe we must look at both the inner and outer rings to fully understand the phenomenon of persuasion.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec2_4">
<title>The Context for Persuasion</title>
<p>Consistent with current conceptualizations of persuasion, we view social influence as a process. Thus far, however, our model has remained relatively static. A final feature must be incorporated into our model to reflect the nature of persuasion as a process. <target target-type="page" id="page_40">40</target>That feature is the <italic>context</italic> for persuasion. The context in which persuasion occurs&#x2014; for example, within a small group, via mass media, in an organizational setting, and so forth&#x2014;is crucial because it is the context that determines the nature of the communication process. In a face-to-face setting, for example, influence is a mutual, two-way process. In an advertising setting, influence tends to be more linear, from the advertiser to the consumer (there may be feedback from consumers, but it is delayed). Each context imposes its own unique set of constraints on the options available to persuaders.</p>
<p>By context, we don&#x2019;t simply mean the number of communicators present, although that is certainly one key factor. The context for communication also includes how synchronous or asynchronous communication is. Synchronous communication refers to the simultaneous sending and receiving of messages. Such is the case in face-to-face interaction. Asynchronous communication refers to a back-and-forth process that involves some delay, such as email or texting.</p>
<p>Another contextual factor is the ratio of verbal to nonverbal cues that are present. A print ad consisting entirely of text would rely exclusively on verbal cues (words) to persuade. A poster featuring only an image would rely exclusively on nonverbal cues to persuade. Most persuasive messages involve both verbal and nonverbal cues. The ratio of verbal to nonverbal cues available in any persuasive situation imposes particular constraints on the persuasion process.</p>
<p>An additional contextual factor is the nature and type of media used in the persuasion process. Television commercials, radio ads, magazine ads, and telemarketing are traditional media for persuasion. New media include blogs, Face-book, Twitter, and YouTube, among many others. Face-to-face encounters, such as door-to-door sales and panhandling, are unmediated. As with the other contextual factors, each medium imposes its own constraints on the persuasion process.</p>
<p>Yet another contextual factor involves the goals of the participants. Often, but not always, participants enter into communication encounters with specific objectives in mind (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_15">Dillard, 1990</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_16">1993</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_17">2004</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_18">Dillard, Segrin, &#x0026; Harden, 1989</xref>). <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_8">Canary and Cody (1994)</xref> break down these goals into three types&#x2014;self-presentational goals, relational goals, and instrumental goals. <italic>Self-presentational goals</italic> have to do with identity management. People want to project a favorable image of themselves to others. <italic>Relational goals</italic> have to do with what people want out of their relationships&#x2014; how to develop them, improve them, change them, and so forth. <italic>Instrumental goals</italic> involve attempts at compliance gaining. People&#x2019;s goals may be thwarted or may change during a persuasive encounter.</p>
<p>A final contextual variable involves sociocultural factors that affect the persuasion process. People from different cultures or subcultures may persuade and be persuaded in different ways (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_35">Ma &#x0026; Chuang, 2001</xref>). For example, research suggests that some cultures prefer more indirect approaches to compliance gaining (hinting, guilt, reliance on group norms), whereas other cultures prefer more direct approaches to compliance gaining (direct requests, demanding) (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_56">Wiseman et al., 1995</xref>). Different cultural traditions can dramatically affect what is expected or accepted in the way of influence attempts.</p>
<p>Note that all of these contextual factors are operating at once in a given persuasive situation. Each of the contextual factors constrains the process of persuasion in one way or another. The context involves the totality of the relationships among all these <target target-type="page" id="page_41">41</target>factors. The final version of our model, depicted in <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig2_4">Figure 2.4</xref>, illustrates how persuasion is shaped by context (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_24">Gass &#x0026; Seiter, 2004</xref>). Context, then, is what determines the nature of the process involved in a given persuasive situation.</p>
<fig id="fig2_4" position="float">
<label>Figure 2.4</label>
<caption><title>Completed model of persuasion. This figure illustrates three of many possible persuasive situations.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig2_4.tif"/>
</fig>
</sec>
<sec id="sec2_5">
<title>A Working Definition of Persuasion</title>
<p>At last we arrive at our own definition of persuasion. Our view is that <italic>persuasion involves one or more persons who are engaged in the activity of creating, reinforcing, modifying, or extinguishing beliefs, attitudes, intentions, motivations, and/or behaviors within the constraints of a given communication context</italic>. The advantage of our definition is that it encompasses the full scope of persuasion, both pure and borderline cases. Our definition also emphasizes persuasion as an activity or a process; it is something people do. Our definition encompasses the notion that in face-to-face encounters, persuasion is a two-way street. Each party has an opportunity to influence the other. With respect to our definition, we also wish to stress that persuasion doesn&#x2019;t involve simply changing one&#x2019;s own or another&#x2019;s mind, though that is the most typical connotation (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_37">Miller, 1980</xref>). Persuasion also can involve creating new beliefs or attitudes, where none existed before. It also can involve reinforcing, strengthening, or solidifying attitudes already held by receivers. And persuasion also can involve attempts to extinguish or eliminate beliefs and attitudes. The latter approach is exemplified by Alcoholics Anonymous&#x2019;s position that alcoholics must abandon the belief that other people are responsible, or circumstances are to blame, for their dependency.</p>
<p>If our definition seems expansive, it is because we believe the topic of persuasion itself is rather far ranging. We wish to examine not only the core of persuasion in this text but its periphery as well. The majority of our examples focus on pure cases of persuasion. However, from time to time we dabble on the fuzzy outer edges. We find some of the borderline cases of persuasion quite interesting, and we believe you will too.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec2_6">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_42">42</target>So what isn&#x2019;t Persuasion?</title>
<p>Given the breadth of our definition, you&#x2019;re probably wondering, &#x201C;What <italic>isn&#x2019;t</italic> persuasion?&#x201D; We address this concern now. Our position is that the ingredients for persuasion can be found in most, if not all, communication transactions. The degree to which these persuasive ingredients are present is what matters. We think most human communication involves at least the <italic>potential</italic> to influence. Of course, one may choose not to focus on the persuasive, or potentially persuasive, elements in a communication situation. One can concentrate on some other aspect of communication instead. The potential for persuasion remains nonetheless. What matters, then, is how persuasive a given communication situation is, not whether a communication situation is persuasive.</p>
<p>Many other features of communication besides persuasion can command one&#x2019;s attention. For example, one can examine the role of self-disclosure and relationship satisfaction without discussing persuasion. One can study effective listening skills, regardless of whether the message listened to is persuasive or not. One can study nonverbal cues and liking without focusing on persuasion. One can look at how people try to save face during conflicts without involving persuasion. Persuasive elements needn&#x2019;t comprise the focus of attention even if they are present. One can focus on other relevant features of human communication to the exclusion of persuasive processes.</p>
<p>Although we believe that nearly all human communication is potentially persuasive, we don&#x2019;t believe the same about all human behavior. The mere act of breathing, in and of itself, doesn&#x2019;t seem like persuasion to us&#x2014;although under the right circumstances it could be (such as pretending to be out of breath). Tripping over a rock, by itself, doesn&#x2019;t seem like a persuasive act to us, although, again, under certain conditions it could be (such as feigning clumsiness). Biological functions, such as sneezing, coughing, or vomiting don&#x2019;t strike us as being persuasive, though, again, a person could fake having allergies, a cold, or a hangover to influence someone else. A good deal of human behavior, then, we don&#x2019;t consider to be persuasion, unless and until some additional conditions are met. We don&#x2019;t think everything humans do is persuasive.</p>
<p>There are also some forms of communication that we&#x2019;ve excluded from consideration in this text for purely practical reasons. We don&#x2019;t discuss torture as a form of persuasion, although some, like <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_1">Abbott (2016)</xref> call it persuasion at its most gruesome. We also don&#x2019;t address the possibility of human-to-animal persuasion, or vice versa, though such a case probably could be made. Furthermore, we don&#x2019;t consider a whole range of studies on how plants, such as willow trees or sugar maples, can warn other trees about insect infestations. There are biologists, though, who study &#x201C;talking trees&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_36">McGowan, 2013</xref>). We don&#x2019;t examine the power of hypnotic suggestion as a form of influence. We don&#x2019;t examine attempts to persuade via telepathy, paranormal, or psychic activity either. We&#x2019;ve heard that some people with cancerous tumors try to &#x201C;talk to&#x201D; their cancer and &#x201C;persuade&#x201D; it to go away. We don&#x2019;t deal with that topic here, except insofar as it may constitute a form of self-persuasion. We also don&#x2019;t address a host of other intriguing topics, such as the role of genetics and neuropsychology in persuasion. We simply don&#x2019;t have the space to devote <target target-type="page" id="page_43">43</target>to those topics here. Thus, as big as the fence that we&#x2019;ve built is, there is a lot of human communication we&#x2019;ve left out.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec2_7">
<title>Dual Processes of Persuasion</title>
<p>Now that we&#x2019;ve clarified what we think persuasion is, we want to take a look at how it functions. To this end, we present a brief explanation of two prevailing models of persuasion. Both are known as <italic>dual process</italic> models (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_13">Chaiken &#x0026; Trope, 1999</xref>) because they postulate that persuasion operates via two basic paths. The two models share many similarities and, in our opinion, both do an excellent job of explaining how persuasive messages are perceived and processed.</p>
<sec id="sec2_7_1">
<title>The Elaboration Likelihood Model of Persuasion</title>
<p>Richard Petty and John Cacioppo&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_41">1986a</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_42">1986b</xref>) <italic>elaboration likelihood model of persuasion</italic> (ELM), is one of the most widely cited models in the persuasion literature.<xref ref-type="fn" rid="fn2_2"><sup>2</sup></xref> Their model proposes two basic routes to persuasion that operate in tandem. The first of these they call the <italic>central route</italic>. The central route, or <italic>central processing</italic>, as they sometimes refer to it, involves <italic>cognitive elaboration</italic>. That means thinking about the content of a message, reflecting on the ideas and information contained in it, and scrutinizing the evidence and reasoning presented. The second route to persuasion is known as the <italic>peripheral route</italic>. The peripheral route, or <italic>peripheral processing</italic>, as it is sometimes called, involves focusing on cues that aren&#x2019;t directly related to the substance of a message. For example, focusing on a source&#x2019;s physical attractiveness, or the sheer quantity of arguments presented, or a catchy jingle as a basis for decision making would entail peripheral processing. According to the ELM, the two routes represent the ends, or anchor points, of an elaboration continuum (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_45">Petty, Rucker, Bizer, &#x0026; Cacioppo, 2004</xref>). At one end of the continuum, a person engages in no or low elaboration. At the other end, a person engages in high elaboration.</p>
<p>To illustrate the two basic routes, imagine that Rex and Trudy are on a date at a restaurant. Trudy is very health conscious, so she studies the menu carefully. She looks to see whether certain dishes are fatty or high in calories. When the food server arrives to take their order, she asks, &#x201C;What kind of oil is used to prepare the pasta?&#x201D; She might sound picky, but Trudy is engaging in central processing. She is actively thinking about what the menu says. Rex, however, is smitten with Trudy&#x2019;s good looks. He hardly looks at the menu, and when the food server asks for his order, he says, &#x201C;I&#x2019;ll have what she&#x2019;s having.&#x201D; Rex is engaging in peripheral processing. He&#x2019;s basing his decision on cues that are unrelated to the items on the menu.</p>
<p>Petty and Cacioppo acknowledge the possibility of <italic>parallel processing</italic>&#x2014;that is, using both routes at once (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_44">Petty, Kasmer, Haugtvedt, &#x0026; Cacioppo, 2004</xref>). For example, when people judge the credibility of websites, they consider the look and layout of a website (peripheral cue) and the content of the website (central processing) (SanJos&#x00E9;-Cabezuo, Guti&#x00E9;rrez-Arranze, &#x0026; Guti&#x00E9;rrez-Cill&#x00E1;n, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_53">2009</xref>). However, Petty and Cacioppo (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_41">1986a</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_42">1986b</xref>) suggest that there is usually a trade-off between central and peripheral processing, such that a person tends to favor one route over the other. Whether a person emphasizes the central or the peripheral route hinges on two basic factors. The first of these is the individual&#x2019;s <italic>motivation</italic> to engage in central processing. Because central processing requires more mental effort, a person with greater <target target-type="page" id="page_44">44</target>motivation is more likely to rely on central processing. Typically, this means the person has <italic>high involvement</italic> with the topic or issue. That is, the topic or issue matters to him or her, or affects him or her personally. If a person has <italic>low involvement</italic> with a topic or issue, he or she will be less inclined to engage in central processing, and more likely to resort to peripheral processing. For example, voters with little knowledge are more likely to be swayed by politicians&#x2019; looks than voters who are informed about the candidates&#x2019; positions (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_34">Lenz &#x0026; Lawson, 2011</xref>).</p>
<p>The second factor that determines whether a person will rely on central or peripheral processing is his or her <italic>ability</italic> to process information. A person must not only be willing but also able to engage in central processing. Some people are more adept at grasping ideas, understanding concepts, and making sense of things. Some people also have more knowledge of or expertise in certain topics or issues than others. Thus, receivers are more likely to process a persuasive message via the central route if they have the motivation and ability to do so. If they lack the motivation or the ability, they will tend to rely on peripheral processing instead.</p>
<p>Aside from ability and motivation, a variety of other factors can tilt the balance in favor of central or peripheral processing. These include distractions, such as background noise, time constraints, a person&#x2019;s mood, or a personality trait called <italic>need for cognition.</italic> Need for cognition has to do with how much a person enjoys thinking about things. We discuss this trait in more detail in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter5">Chapter 5</xref>.</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 2.5</label>
<caption><title>Peripheral processing in action.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig2_5.tif"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; Joe Martin. All Rights Reserved. Reprinted with permission.</p>
</fig>
<p>The type of processing affects the persistence of persuasion. Researchers have found that persuasion via the central route tends to be more long lasting, whereas persuasion via the peripheral route tends to be more short-lived (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_9">Carpenter, 2015</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_43">Petty, Haugtvedt, &#x0026; Smith, 1995</xref>). This seems sensible: When we think about ideas, <target target-type="page" id="page_45">45</target>they are more likely to be absorbed. Similarly, persuasion that takes place via central processing also tends to be more resistant to counterinfluence attempts than persuasion via peripheral processing. This also makes sense: If you&#x2019;ve thought through your position, you&#x2019;re less likely to &#x201C;waffle.&#x201D; Researchers also have found that if receivers disagree with the content of a message, using central processing causes them to generate more counterarguments. That is, they mentally rehearse their objections to the message. If receivers disagree with a message and rely on peripheral processing, however, they will generate fewer counterarguments or other unfavorable thoughts about the message. A useful generalization when persuading, then, is that to make persuasion last, you&#x2019;ve got to make people think.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec2_7_2">
<title>The Heuristic Systematic Model of Persuasion</title>
<p>Another model of persuasion that bears many similarities to the ELM is Shelley Chaiken and Alice Eagly&#x2019;s <italic>heuristic systematic model</italic>, or HSM (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_11">Chaiken, 1987</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_12">Chaiken, Liberman, &#x0026; Eagly, 1989</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_13">Chaiken &#x0026; Trope, 1999</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_20">Eagly &#x0026; Chaiken, 1993</xref>). As with the ELM, the HSM operates on the assumption that individuals rely on two different modes of information processing. One mode, called <italic>systematic processing</italic>, is more thoughtful and deliberate. Systematic processing in the HSM is roughly analogous to central processing in the ELM. The other mode, called <italic>heuristic processing</italic>, relies on mental shortcuts. Heuristic processing is based on the application of <italic>decision rules</italic> or <italic>heuristic cues</italic> that help simplify the thought process. An example of a decision rule would be buying a TV based on its brand name (&#x201C;Sony televisions are reliable&#x201D;). An example of a heuristic cue would be choosing one wine over another because the bottle is prettier. Heuristic processing in the HSM is roughly equivalent to peripheral processing in the ELM.</p>
<p>Chaiken and Eagly&#x2019;s model also maintains that <italic>simultaneous processing</italic> of messages is commonplace. Messages travel the heuristic and systematic routes concurrently. As with the ELM, the HSM states that <italic>motivation</italic> and <italic>ability</italic> are two primary determinants of the extent to which heuristic or systematic processing will be used. A problem for both models is that, to date, there is limited empirical evidence of simultaneous processing, at least in laboratory studies of persuasion (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_6">Booth-Butterfield et al., 1994</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_12">Chaiken et al., 1989</xref>).</p>
<p>Another feature of the HSM is the <italic>sufficiency principle</italic>, which states that people strive to know as much as they need to when making a decision, but no more or less. On one hand, people want to devote the time and attention to issues that they deserve. On the other hand, people can&#x2019;t afford to spend all their time and mental energy worrying about every little thing. Therefore, people balance their heuristic and systematic processing to create the best &#x201C;fit&#x201D; for the issue at hand.</p>
<p>By way of illustration, suppose Irwin is thinking of buying a digital camera. If Irwin didn&#x2019;t know much about such devices, he could take one of two approaches. He could rely on systematic processing by reading up on digital cameras. He would likely adopt this route if he thought he really needed a digital camera (motivation) and he lacked the necessary knowledge about them (sufficiency principle). He also would need time to gather information and be able to understand it (ability). Alternatively, he could opt for heuristic processing. He could base his decision on a friend&#x2019;s advice using a simple decision rule (&#x201C;Lance knows his cameras&#x201D;) He could base his decision on a heuristic cue, such as the brand (&#x201C;Canon is the best brand&#x201D;). He would be more <target target-type="page" id="page_46">46</target>likely to resort to heuristic processing if he didn&#x2019;t really need a digital camera&#x2014;it was only an electronic toy (low motivation)&#x2014;or if he didn&#x2019;t think he could make sense of the information about cameras anyway (lack of ability).</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 2.6</label>
<caption><title>Heuristic processing is more reflexive than reflective.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig2_6.tif"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; Alex Gregory/The New Yorker Collection/<uri>www.cartoonbank.com</uri></p>
</fig>
<p>Both the ELM and HSM are useful for explaining and predicting people&#x2019;s reactions to persuasive messages. Literally dozens of studies devoted to testing the explanatory and predictive power of these two models have been conducted. These studies have generally upheld the models&#x2019; utility. Although both models have their critics (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_29">Kruglanski &#x0026; Thompson, 1999a</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_30">1999b</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_38">Mongeau &#x0026; Stiff, 1993</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_55">Stiff &#x0026; Boster, 1987</xref>), it is safe to say that they enjoy considerable support in the literature. We develop and amplify principles related to the ELM and HSM throughout this text. Because we refer to both models repeatedly, it would be worth your while to familiarize yourself with their basic concepts for later reference.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec2_8">
<title>The Unimodel of Persuasion</title>
<p>An alternative to dual process models of persuasion is the <italic>unimodel</italic> developed by Arie Kruglanski and Erik Thompson (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_29">Kruglanski &#x0026; Thompson, 1999a</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_30">1999b</xref>). Kruglanski and Thompson posit that, rather than two distinct modes of information processing, there is a single route to persuasion. Central processing isn&#x2019;t qualitatively different from peripheral processing, according to the <italic>unimodel</italic>; there is simply more or less of it. Kruglanski maintains that the alleged differences in processing based on the ELM and HSM merely reflect differences in the messages themselves. Longer, more complex messages require more thought, while shorter, simpler messages require less thought (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_21">Erb, Pierro, Mannetti, Spiegel, &#x0026; Kruglanski, 2007</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_28">Kruglanski et al., 2006</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_48">Pierro, Mannetti, Erb, Spiegel, &#x0026; Kruglanski, 2005</xref>).</p>
<p>Despite the simplicity of the <italic>unimodel</italic>, we believe there are cases in which persuasive messages are processed in fundamentally different ways (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_47">Petty, Wheeler, &#x0026; Bizer, 1999</xref>). <target target-type="page" id="page_47">47</target>For example, a consumer who responded to a fear appeal emotionally or reflexively would be quite different from a consumer who responded to a fear appeal rationally or reflectively. Even so, the <italic>unimodel</italic> raises important questions about whether and how dual processing occurs. Some scholars have questioned whether dual processing has ever been empirically documented (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_6">Booth-Butterfield et al., 1994</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec2_9">
<title>Summary</title>
<p>We began this chapter by presenting a preliminary model of persuasion that distinguishes pure from borderline cases of persuasion. We identified five limiting criteria for defining persuasion that are reflected in our own model of persuasion. We followed our model with our own broad-based, far-reaching definition of persuasion. Finally, we provided a brief explanation of Petty and Cacioppo&#x2019;s <italic>elaboration likelihood model</italic> (ELM) of persuasion and Chaiken and Eagly&#x2019;s <italic>heuristic systematic model</italic> (HSM) of persuasion. An alternative to dual-process models, the <italic>unimodel</italic>, also was presented.</p>
</sec>
</body>
<back>
<fn-group>
<title>Notes</title>
<fn id="fn2_1"><label>1</label><p>More than two decades ago, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_54">Simons (1986</xref>, p. 116) introduced a model of persuasion having concentric circles, representing pure persuasion, peripheral persuasion, and non-persuasion. Our preliminary model (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig2_1">Figure 2.1</xref>) draws on his work.</p></fn>
<fn id="fn2_2"><label>2</label><p>Not all scholars are enamored with Petty and Cacioppo&#x2019;s model. Among others, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_38">Mongeau and Stiff (1993)</xref> and <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_55">Stiff and Boster (1987)</xref> have criticized the ELM for its theoretical and empirical limitations. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_46">Petty, Wegener, Fabrigar, Priester, and Cacioppo (1993)</xref> and <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2_44">Petty, Kasmer, Haugtvedt, and Cacioppo (2004)</xref> have responded to many of the criticisms directed against their model.</p></fn>
</fn-group>

</book-part>
<book-part book-part-type="chapter" id="chapter3">
<book-part-meta>
<title-group>
<label>3</label>
