<title><target target-type="page" id="page_51">51</target>Attitudes and Consistency</title>
<alt-title alt-title-type="running-head">Attitudes and Consistency</alt-title>
</title-group>
<contrib-group>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Gass</surname>
<given-names>Robert H.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Seiter</surname>
<given-names>John S.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
</contrib-group>
</book-part-meta>
<body>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_52">52</target>IF SOMEONE SAID, &#x201C;Mabel has an attitude,&#x201D; you might think she was being irritable. However, the word <italic>attitude</italic> doesn&#x2019;t have the same meaning for social scientists that it does in everyday parlance. Social scientists have long been fascinated with the study of attitudes on all manner of subjects. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_79">Prislin and Crano (2008)</xref> went so far as to say that social scientists have carried on an &#x201C;unremitting romance with attitudes over the past half-century&#x201D; (p. 3). The honeymoon isn&#x2019;t over. Attitudes remain a vital element in understanding how persuasion works today.</p>
<p>Just why are attitudes so important to understanding persuasion? The reason is that attitudes help to predict, explain, and modify behavior. Just as a baker uses yeast as a catalyst in baking bread, persuaders rely on attitudes as a means of bringing about changes in receivers. An understanding of attitudes is, therefore, a key ingredient in any recipe for persuasion. For this reason, this chapter is devoted to a discussion of attitudes. We begin by considering what an attitude is.</p>
<sec id="sec3_1">
<title>What is an &#x201C;Attitude&#x201D; in 20 Words or Less?</title>
<p>There is now general agreement among social scientists that an attitude is a &#x201C;psychological tendency that is expressed by evaluating a particular entity with some degree of favor or disfavor&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_22">Eagly &#x0026; Chaiken, 1993</xref>, p. 1). Let&#x2019;s examine some key aspects of this definition more closely. First, attitudes reflect <italic>tendencies</italic> or <italic>predispositions</italic> to respond to things in predictable ways. We don&#x2019;t have time to reflect on each and every action we take in life, so attitudes provide us with mental templates that guide our behavior.</p>
<p>This is not to say that there is a one-to-one correspondence between attitudes and behaviors. A person may have a favorable attitude toward losing weight but may not stay on a diet. To a large extent, though, our attitudes do correspond with our behaviors. For example, people who favor gun-control laws are less likely to own guns than people who oppose such laws. Attitudes have been shown to predict environmental behavior, consumer behavior, voting behavior, contraceptive use, marijuana use, discrimination based on race, and numerous other behaviors (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_45">Holland, Verplanken, &#x0026; van Krippenberg, 2002</xref>).</p>
<p>A second feature of attitudes is that they represent favorable or unfavorable evaluations of things. This <italic>evaluative dimension</italic> is, perhaps, the most central feature <target target-type="page" id="page_53">53</target>of attitudes (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_21">Dillard, 1993</xref>). If a person says, &#x201C;I can&#x2019;t stand Marmite&#x201D; or &#x201C;I love Vegemite,&#x201D; the person is expressing his or her attitudes toward the two sandwich spreads. Along with their valence, attitudes <italic>vary in degree or intensity</italic>. Not all attitudes are equal. Stronger attitudes, whether positive or negative, tend to be better predictors of behavior and less subject to change.</p>
<p>A third aspect of attitudes is that they are always directed toward an <italic>attitude object.</italic> Attitudes may be held in memory or formed on the spot (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_4">Argyriou &#x0026; Melawar, 2011</xref>), but people hold attitudes <italic>about</italic> things or <italic>toward</italic> things. The attitude object can be another person, an idea, a policy, an event, or a situation. Attitudes toward a complex issue may be composed of multiple attitudes toward a variety of sub-issues.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_2">
<title>So how Do You Measure the Durn Things?</title>
<p>If you want to know how much you weigh, you can stand on a scale. If you want to know how tall you are, you can use a tape measure. But what if you want to measure someone&#x2019;s attitudes? Attitudes can&#x2019;t be observed directly. They are inside people&#x2019;s heads. As such, social scientists have developed a number of methods&#x2014;both <italic>explicit</italic> and <italic>implicit</italic>&#x2014;for measuring attitudes.<xref ref-type="fn" rid="fn3_1"><sup>1</sup></xref> Let&#x2019;s take a look at each of these approaches.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_3">
<title>Explicit Measures: Self-Report Scales</title>
<p>The old saying, &#x201C;Straight from the horse&#x2019;s mouth&#x201D; suggests that whatever is being shared comes directly from the source. With that in mind, <italic>self-report scales</italic> might be thought of as &#x201C;straight-from-the-horse&#x2019;s-mouth&#x201D; measures. That&#x2019;s because self-report scales measure attitudes by directly asking people to reveal their attitudes. Because people know their attitudes are being measured, self-reports are considered to be <italic>explicit measures</italic> of attitudes (Petty, Fazio, &#x0026; Bri&#x00F1;ol, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_76">2009</xref>). Two widely used self-report scales are <italic>Likert</italic> scales and <italic>semantic differential</italic> scales.</p>
<sec id="sec3_3_1">
<title>Likert Scales</title>
<p>Rensus Likert&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_59">1932</xref>) &#x201C;equal appearing interval&#x201D; scales are among the most popular in use today. You&#x2019;ve probably already completed a number of them yourself. A Likert scale consists of a series of statements about some attitude object, followed by a continuum of choices ranging from &#x201C;strongly agree&#x201D; to &#x201C;strongly disagree&#x201D; (see <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig3_1">Figure 3.1</xref>). A respondent&#x2019;s attitude is represented by the average of his or her responses to all the statements in the scale. The scales are easy to construct and administer and enjoy widespread acceptance in academia, government, and industry.</p>
<fig id="fig3_1" position="float">
<label>Figure 3.1</label>
<caption><title>Examples of Likert-type scale items.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig3_1.tif"/>
</fig>
<sec id="sec3_3_1_1">
<title>Semantic Differential Scales</title>
<p>Although its name may be unfamiliar, you are probably already acquainted with the <italic>semantic differential</italic> scale (see <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig3_2">Figure 3.2</xref>), developed by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_70">Osgood, Tannenbaum, and Suci (1957)</xref>. This scale is based on the <italic>connotative</italic> meanings that words have for people. It consists of a series of bipolar adjective pairs or, more simply, opposites, such as light&#x2013;dark, fast&#x2013;slow, happy&#x2013;sad, and so on. In completing the scale, a respondent checks the &#x201C;semantic&#x201D; space between each adjective pair that best reflects his or her overall attitude toward the concept in question. The respondent&#x2019;s overall attitude is represented by the average of the spaces checked on all of the items.</p>
<fig id="fig3_2" position="float">
<label>Figure 3.2</label>
<caption><title>Examples of semantic differential scale items.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig3_2.tif"/>
</fig>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_3_2">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_54">54</target>Visually Oriented Scales</title>
<p>Other visually oriented methods of measuring attitudes via self-reports also have been developed. Visual scales make it easier for respondents to conceptualize their attitudes, because they can &#x201C;see&#x201D; where their attitudes fit on a scale or continuum. The <italic>visual analog scale</italic> or VAS (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_33">Flynn, van Schaik, &#x0026; van Wersch, 2004</xref>), for example, simply asks respondents to place a mark along a continuum. A Web tool for creating such a scale can be found at <uri>www.vasgenerator.net</uri> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_81">Reips &#x0026; Funke, 2008</xref>). Other visual scales include simple drawings of facial expressions. The expressions represent different degrees of favor or disfavor toward the attitude object, ranging from smiling to frowning (see <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig3_3">Figure 3.3</xref>).</p>
<fig id="fig3_3" position="float">
<label>Figure 3.3</label>
<caption><title>Example of a visually oriented attitude scale.</title></caption>
<p>Source: From Brock, T.C., &#x0026; Shavitt, S. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_12">1994</xref>).</p>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig3_3.jpg"/>
</fig>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_3_3">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_55">55</target>Pitfalls in Measuring Attitudes</title>
<p>Although explicit measures are fairly easy to administer, they have drawbacks. A reliance on self-reports presumes that people are aware of their attitudes and that they are willing and able to report them. One limitation of self-reports is known as <italic>social desirability bias</italic>. When people know that their words or actions are on display, they may exhibit what they perceive to be socially acceptable norms of conduct. During a job interview, for example, a person might express &#x201C;politically correct&#x201D; attitudes to win favor with the interviewer.</p>
<p>A second pitfall involves the problem of <italic>non-attitudes.</italic> People don&#x2019;t want to appear uninformed or unintelligent. So quite often, when they are asked for their attitude on a particular issue, they simply make one up&#x2014;on the spot! They fear that saying &#x201C;I don&#x2019;t know&#x201D; or &#x201C;I don&#x2019;t care&#x201D; will make them look uninformed. For example, when late-night host Jimmy Kimmel asked passersby who won a &#x201C;First Lady/Man&#x201D; debate between Bill Clinton and Melania Trump, a number of people expressed strong opinions. No such debate ever took place, however (<uri>www.youtube.com/watch?v=vG8lVhyWPmI</uri>).</p>
<p>A third drawback has to do with <italic>mindfulness.</italic> In order for a person to mark the space on any self-report measure, the person must be aware of what his or her attitude is. Unfortunately, respondents often, quite literally, don&#x2019;t know their own minds. For example, a person could harbor racist, sexist, or homophobic attitudes, without consciously realizing it.</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_56">56</target>Implicit Measures: What&#x2019;s Rattling Around Inside Your Brain? To avoid the pitfalls just described, social scientists utilize <italic>implicit measures</italic> of attitudes (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_35">Goodall, 2011</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_95">Wittenbrink &#x0026; Schwartz, 2007</xref>). Such measures assume that unconscious attitudes can be accessed, thereby reducing conscious bias on the part of respondents (Petty, Fazio, &#x0026; Bri&#x00F1;ol, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_76">2009</xref>). We discuss these measures next.</p>
<sec id="sec3_3_3_1">
<title>Implicit Association Test (IAT)</title>
<p>The best known implicit measure is the <italic>Implicit Association Test</italic> or IAT (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_37">Greenwald, McGhee, &#x0026; Schwartz, 1998</xref>). Respondents are asked to press keys on a computer key board in a series of rapid-fire word-association tasks. The snap judgments reveal their underlying attitudes. To illustrate, let&#x2019;s say you wanted to find out whether managers harbor negative stereotypes toward employees with disabilities. On the IAT, managers with negative attitudes would be faster at classifying word pairs, such as &#x201C;disabled/unpleasant&#x201D; or &#x201C;able-bodied/happy&#x201D; compared to word pairs, like &#x201C;disabled/pleasant&#x201D; or &#x201C;able bodied/sad&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_94">Wilson &#x0026; Scior, 2014</xref>). The speed at which respondents press the keys signifies the strength of association for their stereotypes. Variations of the IAT have been developed to measure implicit attitudes toward gender, age, weight, religion, race, disability, and many other topics.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_3_3_2">
<title>Other Implicit Measures</title>
<p>A variety of other implicit measures have been developed, including the <italic>affect misattribution procedure</italic> or AMP and <italic>evaluative priming</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_25">Fabrigar, Krosnick, &#x0026; MacDougall, 2005</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_27">Fazio &#x0026; Olson, 2003</xref>). We don&#x2019;t have sufficient space to examine them all here. What all these measures have in common, though, is that they tap into attitudes that people may be unable or unwilling to divulge. Not surprisingly, implicit measures do not always produce the same results as explicit measures, prompting some to ask, &#x201C;So which is the <italic>real</italic> attitude?&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_38">Greenwald, Poehlman, Uhlmann, &#x0026; Banaji, 2009</xref>). The answer is both. For judgments that are made reflexively or impulsively, implicit measures tend to be more reliable. For judgments that are made more thoughtfully or deliberately, explicit measures tend to yield better results.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_3_4">
<title>More Roundabout Ways of Measuring Attitudes</title>
<p>In addition to explicit and implicit measures, a variety of other, less scientific means can be used to infer people&#x2019;s attitudes. These include inferring attitudes from appearances, from associations, and from behavior.</p>
<sec id="sec3_3_4_1">
<title>Judging a Book by Its Cover&#x2014;Appearances</title>
<p>Attitudes may be inferred from appearances. In fact, people do this all the time. Take, for example, the ability to spot homosexuals, known by the slang term <italic>gaydar</italic>. In controlled studies, observers were able to judge the sexual orientation of females and males at greater than chance odds, based on facial cues, posture, gestures, and gait (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_83">Rule, Ambady, &#x0026; Hallett, 2009</xref>). As another example, observers correctly guessed which political parties candidates belonged to, based solely on photographs, at a much higher rate than chance would predict (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_82">Rule &#x0026; Ambady, 2010</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_84">Rule, Ambady, Adams, &#x0026; Macrae, 2008</xref>).</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_57">57</target>The danger of relying on such appearance-based cues, however, is that the person may commit a &#x201C;sweeping generalization.&#x201D; Not every black teen wearing a hoodie is a thug, nor is every white teen with a shaved head a skinhead.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_3_4_2">
<title>Birds of a Feather&#x2014;Associations</title>
<p>&#x201C;You can tell a person,&#x201D; so the saying goes, &#x201C;by the company he or she keeps.&#x201D; A person who enjoys hunting, for example, may well belong to the NRA. A cancer survivor might participate in a bike ride for the Livestrong Foundation. It makes sense that people enter careers, join organizations, and establish affiliations with groups of like-minded people. Politicians rely on the fact that people who share similar attitudes tend to form memberships. This enables politicians to curry favor with &#x201C;voting blocs.&#x201D;</p>
<p>How does all of this relate to persuasion? By knowing that members of unions, professional associations, churches, and other organizations tend to share similar attitudes, politicians can tailor their messages to each group&#x2019;s frame of reference. Marketers use a technique called <italic>segmentation analysis</italic> to target their advertising campaigns to specific groups of consumers, such as soccer moms, NASCAR dads, or Millennials. We focus more on this topic in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter5">Chapter 5</xref>.</p>
<p>Note that the approach of inferring attitudes based on associations is not without limitations. People may join organizations for all kinds of reasons, some of which have little or nothing to do with the group&#x2019;s avowed purpose. We know of a &#x201C;fun run,&#x201D; for example, that was created to celebrate health and individuality. We also know someone planning to run it. Why? There&#x2019;s a unicorn medal awarded at the finish line.</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 3.4</label>
<caption><title>It is often possible to infer attitudes from clothing and other artifacts.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig3_4.jpg"/>
<p>Source: Heidi Besen/Shutterstock.com</p>
</fig>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_3_4_3">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_58">58</target>You Are What You Do&#x2014;Behavior</title>
<p>Inferences about other people&#x2019;s attitudes are often based on brief glimpses or &#x201C;thin slices&#x201D; of their behavior (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_3">Ambady, 2010</xref>). A person&#x2019;s overt actions, mannerisms, habits, and nonverbal cues can be used to infer his or her attitudes. If a person participates in a &#x201C;Resistance March,&#x201D; it&#x2019;s a pretty good indication that he or she holds anti-Trump attitudes. If a person buys season tickets to the philharmonic orchestra, it&#x2019;s a fairly safe bet that he or she likes classical music. Indeed, concealing one&#x2019;s attitudes can be difficult, precisely because one&#x2019;s actions tend to give one away. Actions speak louder than words, as the saying goes.</p>
<p>Of course, inferring attitudes from behavior can be fraught with difficulties. A meta-analysis (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_54">Kim &#x0026; Hunter, 1993</xref>) of more than 100 attitude&#x2013;behavior studies sheds some light on the extent to which attitudes reflect behavior and vice versa. Kim and Hunter found that in many cases, researchers made poor choices about which attitudes to examine in relation to particular behaviors. They found that when the attitude measures employed were <italic>truly relevant to the behaviors in question,</italic> attitude&#x2013;behavior consistency (ABC) was quite high. Past studies that found weaker ABC may have been looking at the wrong attitudes. The bottom line is that behavior can be extremely revealing of attitudes, but care must be exercised in determining which attitudes are germane to which behaviors. Some ways of improving ABC are identified in <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box3_1">Box 3.1</xref>.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_3_5">
<title>Physiological Measures of Attitude</title>
<p>Affect or emotion is often accompanied by physiological reactions. To date, however, efforts to identify biological markers of affect have produced &#x201C;iffy&#x201D; results (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_25">Fabrigar, Krosnick, &#x0026; MacDougall, 2005</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_72">Petty &#x0026; Cacioppo, 1983</xref>). Researchers have studied pupil dilation, which can signify arousal and galvanic skin response (GSR), which measures changes in the electrical conductivity of the skin. The problem with these measures is that they are <italic>bi-directional indicators</italic> of attitude, meaning that they can signal positive <italic>or</italic> negative responses. For example, your heart rate might increase upon seeing someone you like, a positive reaction, or upon seeing someone you dislike, a negative reaction.</p>
<p>Micromomentary facial movements have also been examined as signs of emotion. Such movements are involuntary and last for only a fraction of a second (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_77">Porter &#x0026; ten Brink, 2008</xref>). They are, therefore, hard to detect. Furthermore, although microexpressions indicate that an emotion is being suppressed, they don&#x2019;t reveal what emotion or why (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_17">Ciolacu, 2014</xref>).</p>
<p>More recently, researchers have turned to neuroscience to study attitudes (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_15">Cacioppo, Cacioppo, &#x0026; Petty, 2017</xref>). Through the use of techniques such as <italic>functional magnetic resonance imaging</italic> (fMRI), neural activity in different regions of the brain can reveal different reactions to stimuli (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_14">Cacioppo, Berntson, &#x0026; Decety, 2012</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_26">Falk, Berman, Mann, Harrison, &#x0026; Lieberman, 2010</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_62">McDermott, 2009</xref>). While offering considerable promise as a tool for measuring attitudes, however, fMRI is not there yet (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_52">Jack &#x0026; Appelbaum, 2010</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_92">Tingley, 2006</xref>). One neuroimaging study of swing voters, for example, predicted the wrong candidates as the likely winners in the 2008 presidential election (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_51">Iacoboni et al., 2007</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_66">Mind Games, 2007</xref>).</p>
<boxed-text id="box3_1">
<label><target target-type="page" id="page_59">59</target>Box 3.1</label>
<caption><title>When Do Attitudes Coincide With Behavior?</title></caption>
<p>Just because a moviegoer tends to prefer action-adventure movies over comedies doesn&#x2019;t mean that he or she will always insist on seeing the former instead of the latter. So when can we expect attitudes to coincide with behavior? There tends to be greater attitude-behavior consistency (ABC) when:
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p>Stronger as opposed to weaker attitudes are involved. Stronger attitudes are better predictors of behavior. When attitudes are weaker, people may use the reverse approach; they infer their attitudes from their behavior (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_45">Holland, Verplanken, &#x0026; Van Knippenberg, 2002</xref>). If a woman&#x2019;s last three boyfriends had long hair, she might decide, &#x201C;I guess I like shaggy guys.&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Multiple attitudes aren&#x2019;t confused with single attitudes. A person doesn&#x2019;t have one attitude toward &#x201C;immigrants,&#x201D; for example. Immigrants from one country might be preferred over those from another country. ABC is greater when a single attitude is measured within a specific situation, place, and time.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x201C;Multiple act criteria&#x201D; are employed. Giving people different opportunities to manifest their attitudes improves the &#x201C;fit&#x201D; between attitudes and behavior. One-shot measures aren&#x2019;t as reliable. If you want to assess a person&#x2019;s attitudes toward homeless people, for example, you should examine her or his behavior toward more than one homeless person in more than one setting.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The attitudes are based on personal experience. Attitudes formed as a result of direct personal experience tend to correspond more closely with actual behavior. Secondhand attitudes, shaped by the media or based on what others have told us, do not predict behavior as well.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Attitudes that are central to the belief system are involved. Attitudes that are central to a person&#x2019;s core beliefs tend to be better predictors of behavior than attitudes that are tangential to the person&#x2019;s belief system. A person&#x2019;s attitudes about &#x201C;marital fidelity&#x201D; would be more revealing of his or her behavior in relationships than his or her preferences regarding pineapple on pizza.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Attitude certainty is high. The more certain a person is about the correctness of an attitude, the greater the effect on the person&#x2019;s behavior. As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_93">Tormala and Rucker (2015)</xref> note:
<disp-quote>
<p>people who are certain of their beliefs are more likely to buy, buy sooner, and spend more. They&#x2019;re more likely to sign petitions and to vote. They&#x2019;re more willing to express their opinions, endorse products, advocate for causes, and try to persuade others to adopt their views.</p>
<attrib>(p. 98)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
</boxed-text>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_60">60</target>Bear in mind that the more complex the attitudes are, the more difficult the task of reducing them to purely physiological terms. At present, physiological measures appear to be less reliable, and more difficult to administer, than other &#x201C;low-tech&#x201D; measures of attitude.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_4">
<title>The Reasoned Action Approach (RAA)</title>
<p>Up to this point, we&#x2019;ve seen that attitudes often lead to behaviors. That said, there are other factors involved. To illustrate, consider Martin Fishbein and Icek Ajzen&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_32">2010</xref>) <italic>reasoned action approach</italic> (RAA), which views <italic>intention</italic> as the best predictor of behaviour. That is, a person&#x2019;s intention to perform a behavior is the best indicator of whether or not the person will actually carry out the behavior. Keep in mind, however, that intentions don&#x2019;t always correspond with behavior, as anyone who has set an alarm clock for an early wake up, then hit the snooze button, well knows. One way to improve the correspondence between intention and behavior is to be specific about the behavior in question. Thus, rather than asking whether someone intends to exercise more often, you could ask whether he or she intends to walk more often. Better yet, you could ask whether he or she intends to walk at least 20 minutes per day, three days per week, starting next Monday, which is more specific still. Bottom line? The more specific the intention is to a particular behavior, the more accurate your prediction will be.</p>
<sec id="sec3_4_1">
<title>Behavioral Beliefs and Attitudes: Believe It or Not</title>
<p>Not only that, your accuracy will improve even more if you can figure out what forms a person&#x2019;s intentions. According to the reasoned action approach, three key elements are involved. The first is a person&#x2019;s <italic>behavioral beliefs and attitudes</italic>. Suppose you wanted to convince your friend, Minnie, to wear a helmet when riding her bicycle. You could start by discovering her beliefs and attitudes toward wearing a helmet. Is she aware of specific dangers? Does she believe that helmets can protect her? You may have to convince Minnie that cyclists are at risk and that wearing a helmet is essential to her safety. &#x201C;I care more about your brain than your hair,&#x201D; you might say. &#x201C;Besides, if you&#x2019;re a vegetable, you&#x2019;ll have bed head anyway.&#x201D;</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_4_2">
<title>Normative Beliefs: It&#x2019;s What the Cool Kids Are Doing</title>
<p>Second, <italic>normative beliefs</italic>, based on what significant others think or do, also shape intentions. Two types of normative beliefs are involved. <italic>Descriptive norms</italic> refer to what people generally or typically do. Does Minnie think helmet wearing is a common practice among her friends, family, or cyclists in general? <italic>Injunctive norms</italic>, on the other hand, refer to what people should or ought to do. Does she face social pressure to wear a helmet, or conversely, social sanctions for wearing one? If Minnie perceives that her friends think helmets are dorky, you may have to convince her otherwise. You might point out that professional cyclists, snowboarders, or BMX riders, look snazzy when sporting a helmet. &#x201C;Hey,&#x201D; you might say, &#x201C;Matt Damon, an avid cyclist, always dons a helmet. So do Jake Gyllenhaal and Pink. Daft Punk wear helmets when they aren&#x2019;t even riding!&#x201D;</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_4_3">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_61">61</target>Perceived Behavioral Control: I Got This</title>
<p>The third element in forming intentions is <italic>perceived behavioral control</italic>. Behavioral control involves a person&#x2019;s confidence that she or he is capable of performing a given behavior. Wearing a helmet isn&#x2019;t that difficult, but Minnie may need help picking one out and making sure it fits. Some behaviors, like riding 100 miles on a bike, are harder to perform. Minnie might want to do a centennial ride, but she may believe that she is not capable of riding that far. You might have to convince her that she can build up to a longer ride. You could tell her &#x201C;Try a 20 mile ride. As you build up your stamina, you can go for longer rides. All it takes is willpower.&#x201D;</p>
<p>In combination, these three elements, behavioral and attitudinal beliefs, normative beliefs, and perceived behavior control, shape a person&#x2019;s behavioral intention, which, in turn, guides his or her behavior (see <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig3_5">Figure 3.5</xref>). The stronger the intention, the more likely a person is to perform a given behavior. A few qualifications to the RAA are worth mentioning. First, past behavior strengthens the intention&#x2013;behavior correlation. In other words, if a person has already performed a behavior, like donating to a specific charity, it is more likely that she or he will perform it again. Second, <italic>actual control</italic>, not just perceived behavior control, matters too. A person may overestimate or underestimate her or his ability to perform a behavior. Despite the best intentions, for example, not every yoga enthusiast can do an Eka Hasta Vrksasana (one-handed tree pose) or a Pungu Mayurasana (wounded peacock pose). These caveats notwithstanding, the RAA has proven to be reliable and accurate in predicting intentions and behaviors (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_31">Fishbein, 2008</xref>).</p>
<fig id="fig3_5" position="float">
<label>Figure 3.5</label>
<caption><title>The reasoned action approach.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig3_5.tif"/>
<p>Source: Adapted from <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_32">Fishbein &#x0026; Ajzen (2010)</xref>.</p>
</fig>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_5">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_62">62</target>The Persistence of Attitudes</title>
<p>A final feature of attitudes we wish to address is their persistence. Attitudes are malleable and change over time. They aren&#x2019;t as fleeting as moods or emotions, but neither are they etched in stone. Sometimes a person&#x2019;s attitude will change in response to a single, brief exposure to a persuasive message. Sometimes a person&#x2019;s attitude will endure for years. What makes some attitudes so durable and others so transitory?</p>
<p>Petty and Cacioppo&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_73">1986a</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_74">1986b</xref>) <italic>elaboration likelihood model</italic> (ELM), discussed in the previous chapter, provides a useful answer to this question. Attitudes formed via central processing&#x2014;for example, those involving thought and deliberation&#x2014;are more persistent and resistant to change than attitudes formed via peripheral processing, which rely on mental shortcuts (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_75">Petty, Cacioppo, Strathman, &#x0026; Priester, 2005</xref>). The reason is because actively thinking about an issue seems to &#x201C;plant&#x201D; the attitude more firmly. Because peripheral processing requires little mental effort, attitudes formed as a result of peripheral processing tend to be more short-lived.<xref ref-type="fn" rid="fn3_2"><sup>2</sup></xref></p>
<p>What does this mean for you as a persuader? If you want a message to have a lasting effect on receivers&#x2019; attitudes, you should design and deliver it in such a way as to promote central processing (i.e., active thinking). How can you encourage central processing? Increasing receivers&#x2019; involvement is one way of promoting central processing. Explaining why a topic or issue is relevant to receivers and how it affects them personally will increase their <italic>motivation</italic> to use central processing. Adapting your message to the receivers&#x2019; levels of understanding will increase their <italic>ability</italic> to engage in central processing. In short, if you can get your listeners to actively think about your message, you are more likely to change their attitudes for the long term, not just the short term.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_6">
<title>Attitudes as Associate Networks: Your Mind is a Web</title>
<p>Our attitudes are interrelated. In some ways, our attitudes, beliefs, and values can be likened to a spider&#x2019;s web. Like the fine silky threads of a spider&#x2019;s web, they are connected to one another in a delicate balance. Attitudes, therefore, exist in elaborate <italic>associative networks</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_91">Tesser &#x0026; Shaffer, 1990</xref>). An individual may or may not be consciously aware of all these connections. To a large extent, these associative networks operate implicitly&#x2014;that is, without the individual&#x2019;s conscious awareness. A change in one attitude affects other attitudes, beliefs, opinions, and values. Like jiggling a spider&#x2019;s web, a vibration in one attitude can trigger reverberations in other cognitive structures. These mental reverberations may be quite minor, or they can be of major consequence to the individual.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_7">
<title>Manufacturing Favorable Associations: Jiggling the Web</title>
<p>Why would anyone buy automobile insurance from a company whose spokesperson is an animated gecko with an Aussie accent? Or, for that matter, why would anyone buy a laundry detergent because its logo is emblazoned on a race car? The associative networks in which attitudes exist are critical to such influence attempts. Persuaders actively seek to create connections among these networks. They want to link their messages with favorable attitudes and avoid associations with unfavorable attitudes.</p>
<sec id="sec3_7_1">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_63">63</target>Brands and Branding: That&#x2019;s the Life</title>
<p>A clear case of manufacturing favorable associations can be found in <italic>branding</italic>. The point of branding is to create a distinctive product image that is linked to favorable qualities. These may be tangible or intangible in nature. Different brands conjure up different images in the minds of consumers. Walmart&#x2019;s appeal is based on value or low prices. Nordstrom&#x2019;s appeal is based on quality and customer service.</p>
<p>Let&#x2019;s examine how these associations are created. Consider the energy drink Red Bull. When you think of Red Bull, what associations come to mind? Do you think of speed, danger, or risk taking? One study (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_9">Brasel &#x0026; Gips, 2011</xref>) found that consumers used descriptors such as <italic>hyper</italic>, <italic>speed</italic>, <italic>extreme</italic>, and <italic>dangerous</italic> in relation to the energy drink. A look at the kinds of events Red Bull sponsors helps explain why. Red Bull sponsors &#x201C;extreme&#x201D; sports, such as adventure racing, mountain biking, cliff diving, and other &#x201C;gravity&#x201D; sports. If downhill &#x201C;street luging&#x201D; is your thing, you might want to down a Red Bull beforehand. Thanks to branding, the drink &#x201C;goes with&#x201D; the sport.</p>
<p>As another illustration, consider beer commercials. The spots almost always depict people, usually males, in pairs or groups (never drinking alone) socializing and having a good time. What is the image or association the ads are projecting? <italic>Beer</italic> = <italic>fun.</italic> It&#x2019;s a simple formula. Drinking beer is equated with good times and camaraderie. So strong is the association that some people might find it hard to imagine a Super Bowl Sunday <target target-type="page" id="page_64">64</target>party, St. Patrick&#x2019;s Day gathering, <italic>Cinco de Mayo</italic> celebration, Labor Day shindig, or Fourth of July revelry that didn&#x2019;t include beer. No suds, no buds.</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 3.6</label>
<caption><title>Source: BIZARRO &#x00A9; by Dan Piraro. Reprinted with permission. Universal Press Syndicate. All Rights Reserved.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig3_6.tif"/>
</fig>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_7_2">
<title>Who Are You Wearing? Brand Personality</title>
<p>Some brands have their own personality. They are imbued with human qualities with which consumers identify. Brands may be perceived as honest, fun, exciting, cool, sophisticated, sexy, or nerdy. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_1">Aaker (1997)</xref> developed the brand personality scale, which rates brands on the basis of characteristics such as perceived sincerity, excitement, competence, sophistication, and ruggedness. What&#x2019;s more, a brand&#x2019;s personality tends to &#x201C;rub off&#x201D; on consumers (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_71">Park &#x0026; John, 2010</xref>). After shopping at Victoria&#x2019;s Secret, for example, females might see themselves as more attractive, sexy, or glamorous.</p>
<p>Modern branding includes cultivating <italic>brand relationships</italic>. Some consumers may regard a brand as they would a best friend (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_34">Fournier, 1998</xref>), while others may view brands as extensions of themselves (Belk, 1998). As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_39">Halloran (2014)</xref> observes, &#x201C;we don&#x2019;t just consume or interact with brands. We engage in relationships with them. With some brands, we have wild, short-term flings. Others stay with us for a lifetime&#x201D; (p. 3). Brands also serve as vehicles for self-expression (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_89">Swaminathan, Stilley, &#x0026; Ahluwalia, 2009</xref>). Some consumers go so far as to get brands tattooed on their bodies (Orend &#x0026; Gagn&#x00E9;, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_68">2009</xref>).</p>
<p>Branding occurs in other ways. <italic>Aspirational brands</italic> are those that consumers admire and aspire to own one day. They represent the ideal. Rolex watches, Viking stoves, and Gucci handbags fall into this category. The Martha Stewart brand is aspirational. Few women will actually make the complicated recipes featured in her magazine, but they like to think that they could. Aspirational brands may be so expensive that consumers settle for knock-off versions instead.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_7_3">
<title>Authenticity: Keeping It Real</title>
<p>Another approach is brand <italic>authenticity,</italic> which emphasizes genuineness, integrity, and down-to-earth values. The website Etsy is devoted to such goods. Authentic brands may be hand crafted, like craft beers and artisanal cheeses. They may be ecofriendly, like &#x201C;farm-to-table&#x201D; restaurants and boutique bicycles. They often have a story to tell. They emphasize the values of the person or company behind the brand. Ben &#x0026; Jerry&#x2019;s ice cream is a case in point. Authentic brands may try to build a community around the brand. Dove&#x2019;s &#x201C;real beauty&#x201D; campaign exemplifies this theme.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_7_4">
<title>Cause-Related Marketing: The Feel-Good Factor</title>
<p>Many consumers want to make the world a better place. Corporations want to sell things. So why not align consumers&#x2019; purchases with doing good deeds? <italic>Cause-related marketing</italic> (CRM) makes consumers feel good about themselves by feeling good about their purchases. They aren&#x2019;t just shopping. They are contributing to the greater good. The expression &#x201C;think globally, shop locally&#x201D; reflects this trend.</p>
<p>Suppose you are a conscientious consumer seeking an upscale cup of coffee. Why not buy a Fair Trade cup of joe? It comes with a psychological pat on the back for doing a good deed. TOMS Shoes, Product (RED), the Livestrong brand, and the Susan G. Komen Foundation&#x2019;s pink ribbon products employ this strategy.</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_65">65</target>Cause-related marketing is part of a larger trend toward <italic>corporate social responsibility</italic> (CSR). Corporations want to be seen as good citizens, giving back to communities, and engaging in philanthropy. Although &#x201C;shopping as philanthropy&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_24">Einstein, 2012</xref>) may seem like a win&#x2013;win&#x2013;win for the consumer, the company, and the charity, there is a downside as well. A concept called <italic>moral licensing</italic> suggests that if a person buys a cause-related product, she or he may be less likely to make an actual donation to that cause (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_57">Krishna, 2011a</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_58">2011b</xref>). &#x201C;I&#x2019;ve already done a good deed&#x201D; the person reasons. Yet the amount that actually goes to the charity may be a few cents on the dollar. Sending even one dollar directly to the charity might do far more good.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_7_5">
<title>Sloganeering</title>
<p>Another means of fostering favorable associations is through <italic>sloganeering.</italic> The importance of slogans in persuasion is underscored by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_87">Sharkansky (2002)</xref>, who observes, &#x201C;politics would be poorer without them, advertising could not exist, and religion would be in trouble&#x201D; (p. 75). Consider the following advertising taglines. Notice the positive associations they are designed to instill with respect to each product.</p>
<verse-group>
<verse-line>&#x201C;When you&#x2019;re here, you&#x2019;re family.&#x201D; (Olive Garden)</verse-line>
<verse-line>&#x201C;Breakfast of champions.&#x201D; (Wheaties)</verse-line>
<verse-line>&#x201C;Like a good neighbor, State Farm is there.&#x201D; (State Farm)</verse-line>
<verse-line>&#x201C;We&#x2019;ll leave the light on for you.&#x201D; (Motel 6)</verse-line>
<verse-line>&#x201C;Because you&#x2019;re worth it&#x201D; (L&#x2019;Or&#x00E9;al)</verse-line>
</verse-group>
<p>The slogans imbue the products with positive qualities that, over time, become embedded in receivers&#x2019; minds. If you feel like &#x201C;eatin&#x2019; good in the neighborhood,&#x201D; where would you go for dinner?</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_7_6">
<title>Sponsorship</title>
<p>Another way of linking products and services with favorable attitudes is through <italic>sponsorship.</italic> Earlier, we mentioned Red Bull&#x2019;s sponsorship of extreme, gravity sports. Most major sporting events now have corporate sponsors who provide funding in return for the right to associate their products with the event. Almost every stadium and ballpark in America now has a corporate sponsor.</p>
<p>Naturally, advertisers aren&#x2019;t the only ones who try to tie themselves to favorable associations. When candidates for political office kiss babies, eat home cooking, and stand next to the flag, they are trying to link themselves to positive, patriotic values. Negative political campaigning, or &#x201C;mudslinging,&#x201D; serves the same purpose in reverse: A candidate seeks to link his or her opponent with negative associations.</p>
<p>A major tenet of persuasion thus involves establishing favorable connections between attitudes and attitude objects. Persuaders try to establish these connections by selling an image or lifestyle. When you buy a product, you are buying into the image as well (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_34">Fournier, 1998</xref>). But do you really need to have a relationship with your <target target-type="page" id="page_66">66</target>credit card (&#x201C;My card, my city&#x201D; [American Express])? Do you really want brands to define you (&#x201C;Do you speak Prada?&#x201D;)? Sometimes it is important to break the connections that advertisers are trying to create.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_8">
<title>Psychological Consistency</title>
<p>People strive to be consistent. This simple principle forms the basis for a whole host of theories, variously known as &#x201C;cognitive consistency&#x201D; theories (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_28">Festinger, 1957</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_44">Heider, 1958</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_69">Osgood &#x0026; Tannenbaum, 1955</xref>). Consistency was originally conceived of as a &#x201C;drive-reduction&#x201D; theory. More current thinking suggests that consistency is also socially motivated and is as much an attempt to manage face and project a favorable self-image as it is an internal drive (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_36">Greenwald &#x0026; Ronis, 1978</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_61">Matz &#x0026; Wood, 2005</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_85">Scher &#x0026; Cooper, 1989</xref>). Although the individual theories differ somewhat in their approaches, we&#x2019;ve integrated the tenets of several theories here in order to present a more coherent perspective. Though this principle is fairly basic, the recognition that most people strive to remain consistent in their thoughts, words, and deeds reveals a good deal about processes of social influence.</p>
<sec id="sec3_8_1">
<title>The Inner Peace of Consistency</title>
<p>When harmony exists among our attitudes, beliefs, values, and behavior, life is ducky. When there are inconsistencies in what we think, say, or do, however, we tend to experience psychological discomfort. A classic example is that, for smokers, the knowledge that they smoke and that smoking causes cancer is psychologically uncomfortable. Another example involves children whose parents are undergoing a divorce or separation. The children often experience psychological conflict because they can&#x2019;t understand why two people, whom they love, don&#x2019;t want to remain married.</p>
<p>The amount of psychological discomfort that results from holding incompatible attitudes is not the same in all situations. The degree of discomfort depends on the <italic>centrality</italic> of the attitudes involved. If the issue is relatively minor (for example, a person prefers plastic grocery bags but knows paper bags are better for the environment), the amount of psychological discomfort will be small. If the issue is major, as when attitudes involve core beliefs or values, then the psychological consequences can be enormous (for example, the mother of a teenage girl is fervently pro-life but learns that her daughter has just had an abortion).</p>
<p>To understand the nature and effects of psychological consistency, attitude theorists have developed a means of graphically depicting compatible and incompatible attitude states. For example, suppose that Muffin thinks of herself as a firm believer in animal rights. However, while out shopping, she finds a leather jacket that looks &#x201C;totally cool.&#x201D; Her attitudes toward animal rights and owning the jacket are in conflict. Her psychological dilemma is depicted in <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig3_7">Figure 3.7</xref>.</p>
<fig id="fig3_7" position="float">
<label>Figure 3.7</label>
<caption><title>Muffin&#x2019;s dilemma: an illustration of consistency theory.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig3_7.jpg"/>
</fig>
<p>According to consistency theory, Muffin will experience psychological stress no matter what decision she makes. If she buys the jacket, she&#x2019;ll sacrifice her principles; if she doesn&#x2019;t buy the jacket, she&#x2019;ll forgo an opportunity to look cool. Muffin&#x2019;s case is not unique. We are all confronted with dilemmas involving our attitudes, beliefs, and behaviors on a daily basis. Because psychological inconsistency is unpleasant we are motivated to avoid it, deny it, reduce it, or eliminate it when it occurs.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_8_2">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_67">67</target>Methods of Maintaining Consistency</title>
<p>How do people go about reconciling incompatible attitudes when they occur? People don&#x2019;t necessarily preserve or restore psychological consistency in logical ways. They do so in psychological ways&#x2014;that is, ways they find psychologically satisfying or comfortable but that may or may not be strictly logical. Using the example of Muffin, scholars suggest a number of possible routes for resolving inconsistency:
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p><italic>Denial:</italic> Denying or ignoring any inconsistency. &#x201C;I really don&#x2019;t like that jacket after all&#x201D; or &#x201C;I don&#x2019;t really need a jacket now.&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Bolstering:</italic> Rationalizing or making excuses. &#x201C;That cow is already dead, so what difference can it make?&#x201D; or &#x201C;Sooner or later someone will come along and buy that jacket anyway.&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Bargaining:</italic> Striving to reach a compromise between the conflicting attitudes. &#x201C;I&#x2019;ll buy the jacket and volunteer to work at an animal shelter.&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Differentiation:</italic> Separating or distinguishing the attitudes in conflict. &#x201C;The jacket is cowhide. Cows aren&#x2019;t an endangered species. It&#x2019;s not as if I&#x2019;m buying a jacket made from a baby harp seal or a spotted owl.&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Transcendence:</italic> Focusing on a larger or higher level. &#x201C;No one is perfect. We all give in to temptation every once in a while.&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Modifying one or both attitudes:</italic> Altering the attitudes themselves to become more consistent. &#x201C;I need to be more practical and keep my concern for animals&#x2019; rights in perspective.&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Communicating:</italic> Trying to convince others to change or convince others one did the right thing. &#x201C;I&#x2019;ll just have to convince my friends that I&#x2019;m not a hypocrite when they see me in my new jacket.&#x201D;</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_68">68</target>Of course, these are only some of the ways people go about maintaining consistency. In trying to gauge which approach a person will use, a good rule of thumb is that people follow an <italic>efficiency principle</italic>; they tend to reduce dissonance in the most efficient way possible&#x2014;that is, they tend to follow the path of least resistance in finding a way to restore consistency. Changing an inconsequential attitude to restore consistency, for example, is much more likely than changing a core attitude.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_8_3">
<title>Marketing Strategies: How to Have Your Cake and Eat It Too</title>
<p>Now that you understand the basic nature of consistency theories, let&#x2019;s look at how neatly consistency theories apply to persuasion. Imagine that you are at the supermarket. You have a craving for ice cream, but you&#x2019;re on a diet. No problem. You can buy a &#x201C;light&#x201D; brand with reduced fat and fewer calories. In fact, thanks to modern technology, you can choose from a veritable array of frozen desserts including ice milk, frozen yogurt, diabetic ice cream, fruit sorbet, or a nonfat, nondairy product. Think how many other products at the grocery store rely on the principle of &#x201C;having your cake and eating it too.&#x201D; There are &#x201C;light,&#x201D; &#x201C;fat free,&#x201D; &#x201C;cholesterol free,&#x201D; &#x201C;high fiber,&#x201D; &#x201C;low sodium,&#x201D; &#x201C;calcium enriched,&#x201D; and &#x201C;natural&#x201D; food products on every shelf. The marketing strategy behind such products is to allow consumers to make food purchases that are consistent with their beliefs regarding health and nutrition.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_8_4">
<title>Brand Loyalty: Accept No Substitute</title>
<p>The concept of <italic>brand loyalty</italic> offers another useful illustration of psychological consistency. Advertisers want us to experience psychological discomfort if we change brands. By instilling brand loyalty in us, advertisers hope to discourage product switching. We are trained by Madison Avenue to remain faithful to one motor oil, be true to one long-distance provider, stay devoted to one pain reliever, or cherish a particular make of car. Consider the following slogans:
<verse-group>
<verse-line>&#x201C;Don&#x2019;t leave home without it.&#x201D; (American Express)</verse-line>
<verse-line>&#x201C;Like nothing else.&#x201D; (Hummer)</verse-line>
<verse-line>&#x201C;Only in a Jeep.&#x201D; (Jeep)</verse-line>
<verse-line>&#x201C;The best, or nothing.&#x201D; (Mercedes)</verse-line>
<verse-line>&#x201C;When you care enough to send the very best.&#x201D; (Hallmark cards)</verse-line>
</verse-group>
</p>
<p>All of these slogans are designed to foster brand loyalty on the part of the consumer and feelings of psychological inconsistency if consumers betray their usual brands.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_8_5">
<title>Write and Tell Us Why You Love This Book in 24 Words or Less</title>
<p>Yet another means of reinforcing brand loyalty is through active participation on the part of the consumer. Viewers can text in their votes on a variety of reality shows. Sometimes a prize is offered for calling a radio station or writing an essay about a <target target-type="page" id="page_69">69</target>product. Win or lose, the mere act of calling, writing, or texting is bound to increase one&#x2019;s allegiance. Active participation increases commitment.</p>
<p>Brand loyalty can also be encouraged through merchandising. People who wear branded clothing (a Cubs jersey, a Pink hoodie, a Fender T-shirt) are paying for the right to serve as walking billboards&#x2014;and engaging in self-persuasion to boot.</p>
<p>An example of how consumers succumb to merchandising pressure involves one of this book&#x2019;s ever-gullible authors. He liked the Indian maiden logo on Land O&#x2019;Lakes butter. So when he learned he could order two Land O&#x2019;Lakes mugs for only &#x0024;7.95, plus three proof-of-purchase seals from any Land O&#x2019;Lakes product, he couldn&#x2019;t resist. He switched from margarine to butter. He bought only Land O&#x2019;Lakes butter for the next three months (the amount of time it took to accumulate three proof-of-purchase seals). When he found he&#x2019;d lost one of the proof-of-purchase seals he was despondent. Did he give up? Nay, nay! He went out and bought another package of Land O&#x2019;Lakes butter <italic>he didn&#x2019;t even need,</italic> just to complete the trio of proof-of-purchase seals. The author is now the proud owner of a pair of Land O&#x2019;Lakes mugs, complete with Indian maiden logo, but let&#x2019;s examine what can be learned from this lesson:
<list list-type="bullet">
<list-item><p>The merchandising offer got the author actively involved in the process of reinforcing his own brand loyalty. Because the mugs themselves cost little to manufacture, the author was paying Land O&#x2019;Lakes for the privilege of becoming a loyal consumer.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The merchandising offer secured the author&#x2019;s brand loyalty for a period of 3&#x2013;4 months. In fact, the author still buys the Land O&#x2019;Lakes brand whenever he purchases butter (after all, he has the mugs to remind him where his loyalty lies).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><target target-type="page" id="page_70">70</target>The author bought and used far more butter than he otherwise would have without the mug offer. In fact, as he was closing in on that elusive third proof-of-purchase seal, he was searching high and low for ways to use butter.</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 3.8</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig3_8.jpg"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; Leo Cullum/ The New Yorker. Collection/<uri>www.cartoonbank.com</uri>. All Rights Reserved.</p>
</fig>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 3.9</label>
<caption><title>Merchandising can increase consumer commitment.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig3_9.jpg"/>
<p>Source: Photo by Robert Gass.</p>
</fig>
<p>Admittedly, the author got a little carried away, but that&#x2019;s the beauty of brand loyalty. We don&#x2019;t necessarily think or act rationally when our allegiance to a particular brand takes over.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_8_6">
<title>Marketing Inconsistency</title>
<p>Of course, other advertising campaigns, typically those for newer products or products with a smaller market share, use just the opposite strategy. These ads encourage us to switch brands. They realize that consumers can be set in their ways. These advertisers try to create psychological imbalance. They want us to have second thoughts about the products and services on which we&#x2019;ve been relying unquestioningly year after year. Consider the following advertising slogans:
<disp-quote>
<p>&#x201C;Think different.&#x201D; (Macintosh computers)</p>
<p>&#x201C;Think outside the bun.&#x201D; (Taco Bell)</p>
<p>&#x201C;Switch and play.&#x201D; (Nintendo)</p>
<p>&#x201C;I could have had a V8!&#x201D; (V8 vegetable juice)</p>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>Such slogans are based on the recognition that consumers can be set in their ways and seek to overcome this inertia by encouraging brand switching. Many other types of advertising campaigns are based on creating a state of psychological inconsistency.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_8_7">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_71">71</target>Capitalizing on Inconsistency</title>
<p>The use of consistency theory isn&#x2019;t only for advertisers, marketers, and other &#x201C;professional&#x201D; persuaders. You, too, can incorporate the principles of consistency theory in your own persuasive messages. One way you can accomplish this is to align your message with your audience&#x2019;s frame of reference. It is much easier to tailor a suit to fit a person than it is to change a person&#x2019;s figure to fit a suit. Similarly, successful persuasion isn&#x2019;t so much a matter of shifting receivers&#x2019; attitudes over to your position as it is a matter of adapting your message to the attitudes of your audience. A child who suggests to her mother, &#x201C;Let&#x2019;s play hooky and go to the zoo today. Zoos are very educational!&#x201D; is adapting her message to the mother&#x2019;s value system. Such adaptation is key to persuasion, which is why we discuss this strategy in more detail in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter5">Chapter 5</xref>.</p>
<p>Another way you can apply principles of consistency theory is to highlight potential inconsistencies in receivers&#x2019; attitudes. If you can demonstrate that some of the attitudes held by your receivers are incompatible, you may motivate them to change their attitudes in the direction you are advocating. Be cautious, however, when employing this strategy. If you attempt to drive too big a psychological wedge between your receivers&#x2019; attitudes, they may simply change their attitudes and come to dislike you.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_9">
<title>Cognitive Dissonance Theory (CDT)</title>
<p>Suppose you are a fan of Apple products. You are also aware that Chinese workers who assemble them work in deplorable conditions. Would you throw away your iPod, iPhone, or iPad? If you think of yourself as an honest person, would it bother you to download music illegally, or would you find a way to justify your piracy and disregard for copyright laws? People often hold contradictory positions on issues. Their talk doesn&#x2019;t match their walk. For example, many voters say they are opposed to &#x201C;Big Government&#x201D; and federal handouts, even though they are receiving government assistance. According to a nationwide survey (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_63">Mettler, 2011</xref>), 44 percent of Social Security recipients and 40 percent of Medicare recipients reported they did not receive any government assistance!</p>
<p>How can people hold such seemingly contradictory views? Why do they engage in what appears to be hypocritical behavior? Leon Festinger&#x2019;s <italic>cognitive dissonance theory</italic> (CDT) does a nice job of explaining how people rationalize contradictory decisions and behaviors in their own minds and to other people (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_18">Cooper, 2007</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_28">Festinger, 1957</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_29">1964</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_30">Festinger &#x0026; Carlsmith, 2007</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_41">Harmon-Jones &#x0026; Harmon-Jones, 2008</xref>). The basic idea is that after making a decision or performing a behavior, a person worries about whether she or he made the right decision or did the right thing. The person is therefore motivated to reduce the resulting dissonance. For this reason, CDT is often referred to as a &#x201C;post-decision theory.&#x201D; The anticipation of having to make a tough choice, however, also can produce dissonance. People sometimes say it &#x201C;hurts&#x201D; or it&#x2019;s &#x201C;painful&#x201D; to make a difficult decision. In fact, researchers found that taking acetaminophen reduced the pain of decision making (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_19">DeWall, Chester, &#x0026; White, 2015</xref>). The researchers concluded that &#x201C;the pain of decision making is not a mere metaphor&#x201D; (p. 119). Cognitive dissonance, it turns out, involves some of the same neural pathways associated with physical pain.</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_72">72</target>Aside from popping Tylenol, how else can people reduce cognitive dissonance? An intriguing aspect of CDT is the variety of ways in which people try to reconcile their angst. For example, they may employ a &#x201C;sour grapes&#x201D; strategy. Like the fox in Aesop&#x2019;s fable who tried repeatedly but failed to reach some grapes, they conclude, &#x201C;They were probably sour anyway.&#x201D;</p>
<sec id="sec3_9_1">
<title>Cognitive Dissonance and Buyer&#x2019;s Remorse</title>
<p>The theory of cognitive dissonance is closely connected to the phenomenon known as <italic>buyer&#x2019;s remorse.</italic> Imagine that a consumer shelled out a lot of money for a big, flat-screen TV, only to find out a few weeks later that a newer, better model was available for less money. To assuage their lingering doubts, buyers engage in dissonance-reduction strategies. One method, known as <italic>selective exposure,</italic> involves seeking out consonant information and avoiding dissonant information. The TV buyer might reread ads and articles recommending the brand he or she purchased and avoid ads and articles for other brands. Cognitive dissonance isn&#x2019;t an all-or-nothing phenomenon. It occurs in varying degrees. The amount of dissonance one experiences is known as the <italic>magnitude of dissonance.</italic> Spending &#x0024;8,000 on a plasma TV that wasn&#x2019;t very reliable would produce more dissonance than spending &#x0024;8 on a movie that wasn&#x2019;t very good.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_9_2">
<title>Polarization of Alternatives</title>
<p>When making a tough decision, a person tends to <italic>polarize</italic> the attractiveness of the alternatives once the decision is made. Suppose Lola has to decide between an iPhone and an Android. It is a close call. Each model has its pros and cons. Once Lola makes her choice, she will tend to disparage the unchosen brand and value the chosen brand even more. What was formerly a tough choice becomes a &#x201C;no brainer.&#x201D; The tendency to spread the alternatives is a form of self-justification (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_90">Tavris &#x0026; Aronson, 2007</xref>). It is easier to see choices in terms of &#x201C;black and white&#x201D; than shades of gray. This explains why voters who are initially torn between two candidates solidify their preference once they cast their ballot (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_8">Besley &#x0026; Joslyn, 2001</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_9_3">
<title>Cognitive Dissonance, Self-Image, and Culture</title>
<p>Cognitive dissonance can be largely internal in nature, such as when a person is confronted with a moral dilemma. Dissonance also can arise when one&#x2019;s self-image is inconsistent with one&#x2019;s beliefs, attitudes, or behaviors. For instance, a person who thinks of himself or herself as unprejudiced but who laughs at a racist, sexist, or homophobic joke might experience cognitive dissonance. There is a cultural component to dissonance as well. For Americans and others from individualistic cultures, dissonance tends to be more internally motivated, while for Asians and others from more collectivistic cultures, dissonance tends to be more socially motivated (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_49">Hoshino-Browne, Zanna, Spencer, Zanna, Kitayama, &#x0026; Lackenbauer, 2005</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_55">Kitayama et al., 2004</xref>). While some studies suggest that Asians have a greater tolerance for inconsistency (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_2">Aaker &#x0026; Sengupta, 2000</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_67">Nisbett, 2003</xref>), others suggest just the opposite (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_96">Xie, Jang, &#x0026; Cai, 2007</xref>). There is also evidence that dissonance is a culturally universal phenomenon (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_23">Egan, Santos, &#x0026; Bloom, 2007</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_9_4">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_73">73</target>Factors That Affect the Magnitude of Dissonance</title>
<p>Four paradigms that moderate cognitive dissonance have been studied by researchers (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_6">Beauvois &#x0026; Joule, 1999</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_42">Harmon-Jones &#x0026; Mills, 1999</xref>). One of these, known as the <italic>free choice paradigm,</italic> states that the greater the choice one has in making a decision, the more dissonance one will suffer. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_18">Cooper (2007)</xref> emphasizes that dissonance occurs <italic>only</italic> if the negative outcome of a freely chosen decision was foreseeable at the time the person made the choice. Otherwise the person can say, &#x201C;How was I to know?&#x201D; A second paradigm, known as <italic>belief disconfirmation,</italic> argues that dissonance is aroused when a person encounters information contrary to his or her beliefs. The person engages in denial and resorts to <italic>selective exposure</italic> by ignoring or distorting information that contradicts his or her belief system. A third paradigm is called <italic>induced compliance.</italic> When a person is forced to do something, little dissonance is aroused because the person can rationalize the action by saying &#x201C;I had no choice.&#x201D; The fourth paradigm, called the <italic>effort justification paradigm,</italic> centers on the amount of effort or sacrifice required: the greater the effort, the greater the dissonance.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_9_5">
<title>Dissonance and Persuasion: Putting It All Together</title>
<p>Persuasive messages can be tailored to either increase or decrease dissonance in receivers. A persuader might want to arouse dissonance in a target audience to get people to rethink their position on an issue. Or, conversely, a persuader might seek to allay people&#x2019;s doubts by reassuring them that their decision or action was justified. In this case, the persuader would want to convince receivers that they did the right thing and they had no other realistic alternative. Recent research shows that attitude change brought about by CDT can have lasting effects (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_86">S&#x00E9;n&#x00E9;meaud &#x0026; Somat, 2009</xref>).</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_10">
<title>Forbidden Fruit: Psychological Reactance</title>
<p>In 2003, Barbra Streisand filed a lawsuit against a photographer for taking aerial photos along California&#x2019;s coastline, including her Malibu home, and posting them on the Web. Prior to the lawsuit, few people had bothered to look at the photos. After the publicity surrounding the lawsuit, however, people flocked to the website in droves (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_5">Arthur, 2009</xref>). Half a million viewers logged on to see what the fuss was about. A judge subsequently dismissed the suit. Similarly, when the MPAA filed a lawsuit against The Pirate Bay for facilitating illegal downloading of movies, the website became more popular than ever (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_88">Sullivan, 2009</xref>). Attempts to muzzle information on the Web often backfire, a phenomenon Mike Masnick termed the <italic>Streisand effect</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_60">2005</xref>).</p>
<p>When people believe that their freedom is being threatened, they tend to rebel. Tell a little kid not to play with a particular toy and the kid won&#x2019;t be able to keep his grubby little hands off it. Tell your teenage daughter that you disapprove of her new boyfriend and she&#x2019;ll like him even more. The tendency to react defensively to perceived encroachments on our freedom is called <italic>psychological reactance</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_10">Brehm, 1966</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_11">Brehm &#x0026; Brehm, 1981</xref>). You may also know of it as &#x201C;reverse psychology.&#x201D;</p>
<p>Psychological reactance can help or hinder persuasion. Suppose a mother wants to get her picky 3-year-old to eat her broccoli. The mother could use a controlling <target target-type="page" id="page_74">74</target>message such as, &#x201C;You are going to sit there until you finish your broccoli.&#x201D; This approach might backfire, however, if the daughter is willing to sit and pout for an hour. Instead, the mother could use psychological reactance to her advantage by saying, &#x201C;Mabel, there is no way you can eat that broccoli in less than a minute. No way.&#x201D; Now the daughter may want to prove she&#x2019;s up to the challenge.</p>
<p>A wealth of studies on littering behavior reveal that a negative or punitive message (&#x201C;No littering!&#x201D; or &#x201C;Don&#x2019;t you dare litter.&#x201D;) actually <italic>increases</italic> littering compared to a polite message (&#x201C;Please pitch in.&#x201D;) (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_40">Hansmann &#x0026; Sholz, 2003</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_48">Horsley, 1988</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_50">Huffman, Grossnickle, Cope, &#x0026; Huffman, 1995</xref>). Stated simply, asking is a more effective strategy than ordering. Psychological reactance also has been examined on a variety of other topics, including alcohol consumption (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_20">Dillard &#x0026; Shen, 2005</xref>), condom use (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_80">Quick &#x0026; Stephenson, 2007</xref>), drug use (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_13">Burgoon et al., 2002</xref>), promotional health messages (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_65">Miller, Lane, Deatrick, Young, &#x0026; Potts, 2007</xref>), and smoking (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_64">Miller, Burgoon, Grandpre, &#x0026; Alvaro, 2006</xref>). The tendency to react negatively to perceived threats varies from person to person. These individual differences can be measured with the <italic>psychological reactance scale</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_46">Hong, 1992</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_47">Hong &#x0026; Faedda, 1996</xref>).</p>
<p>To avoid a boomerang effect, a persuader should be cautious about using controlling language. A politician who says &#x201C;You must vote for this proposition. It is the only way&#x201D; is practically daring voters to reject the measure. To use psychological reactance to his or her advantage, a persuader should acknowledge listeners&#x2019; personal autonomy. A politician who says &#x201C;I favor this measure, but you&#x2019;ll have to make up your own minds&#x201D; is less likely to provoke resistance. A persuader also can use psychological reactance against an opponent. For example, a candidate might argue &#x201C;My opponent wants to limit your health care options, but I want you to be able to choose your own health care provider.&#x201D; We return to the subject of psychological reactance in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter8">Chapter 8</xref> when we discuss the <italic>scarcity principle</italic>, and in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter11">Chapter 11</xref> when we discuss the <italic>evoking freedom technique</italic>.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_11">
<title>Counterattitudinal Advocacy: Playing Devil&#x2019;s Advocate</title>
<p>An even better approach to changing people&#x2019;s attitudes is to get them to persuade themselves. This can be accomplished by having them engage in what is called <italic>counterattitudinal advocacy</italic> (CAA). CAA involves having people create and present (orally or in writing) a message that is at odds with their existing attitudes&#x2014;for example, claiming they favor capital punishment when, in fact, they oppose it. Research demonstrates that after engaging in CAA, people&#x2019;s attitudes will tend to shift in the direction of the position advocated (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_28">Festinger, 1957</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_53">Kelman, 1953</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_78">Preiss &#x0026; Allen, 1998</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_86">S&#x00E9;n&#x00E9;meaud &#x0026; Somat, 2009</xref>). Mind you, their attitudes won&#x2019;t undergo a complete reversal. Some degree of attitude change takes place, such that the initially counterattitudinal position becomes somewhat more favorable in the people&#x2019;s minds.</p>
<p>The explanation is that CAA causes psychological conflict within people. They are aware of the inconsistency between their privately held beliefs and attitudes, and their public behavior. One means of resolving the conflict is to make their private beliefs and attitudes more consistent with their public behavior&#x2014;hence, the resultant shift in attitudes. This suggests an effective way of getting other people to persuade <target target-type="page" id="page_75">75</target>themselves. Simply try to get them to speak or act in a manner that is contrary to their attitudes. This can be accomplished by asking them to role-play for a few minutes, or to play devil&#x2019;s advocate for a while. The research demonstrates that attitude change should follow in the direction of the counterattitudinal position. When using this technique, however, it is important that the other people <italic>choose</italic> to engage in CAA, as opposed to being forced to do so. A meta-analysis by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_78">Preiss and Allen (1998)</xref> revealed that voluntarily engaging in CAA is the key to this strategy&#x2019;s effectiveness.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_12">
<title>I&#x2019;m All in: Increasing Commitment</title>
<p>Commitment goes hand in hand with persuasion. When people become committed to ideas, groups, causes, or decisions they find it difficult to change their minds. By way of example, did you know that once horse-racing fans have bet on a horse, they become even more convinced their horse will win (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_56">Knox &#x0026; Inkster, 1968</xref>)? Individuals who volunteer their time to work for political campaigns tend to overestimate the prospects of their candidate winning. The more public the nature of the commitment, the more psychologically entrenched people become.</p>
<p>Many social customs and rituals are designed to increase a person&#x2019;s sense of psychological commitment to an idea, group, cause, or decision. Wedding engagements do so. Fraternity initiation rituals do so as well. Boot camp in the military serves this purpose. Baptism achieves this goal. This also explains why people often announce their New Year&#x2019;s resolutions publicly. Doing so binds them all the more to their commitments. Political rallies, protest marches, and demonstrations accomplish this function for the participants. Whenever we make public statements or engage in public actions, we tend to become bound by our words or deeds. Yes, we can renege on what we&#x2019;ve said or done, but we will pay a psychological price for doing so. The greater the public commitment, the greater the toll paid.</p>
<sec id="sec3_12_1">
<title>Commitments Can &#x201C;Grow Legs&#x201D;</title>
<p>In the movie <italic>Tin Cup</italic> (1996), Roy McAvoy is a gifted golfer who makes his own bad luck. In a heroic comeback bid, he finds himself in contention to win the U.S. Open. He refuses to play it safe, however. On an over-water approach shot to the 18th hole, he goes for the flag. The ball lands in the water. Rather than cut his losses, he takes the same shot again and again, each time with the same result. On his 12th try, and down to his last ball, he finally clears the water and the ball rolls in the cup. He loses the tournament, but proves something to himself. Let&#x2019;s face it, we all behave a bit like Roy from time to time. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3_16">Robert Cialdini (1993)</xref> makes the interesting point that commitments sometimes &#x201C;grow legs.&#x201D; By this he means that once we become committed to a given course of action, we tend to remain steadfast in our determination, even if the reason for selecting that course of action is diminished, altered, or eliminated.</p>
<sec id="sec3_12_1_1">
<title>Getting Carried Away</title>
<p>A story involving one of the authors illustrates this phenomenon. The author wanted to build a retaining wall in his backyard. He was planning on spending &#x0024;1,000. Once he got several bids for the job, he discovered it would cost &#x0024;3,000 to &#x0024;4,000 for <target target-type="page" id="page_76">76</target>a stone wall rather than a block wall. He signed a contract with the lowest bidder for a &#x0024;3,000 retaining wall made of river rock. A few days before the work was to begin, the author had another idea. As long as he was going to all the trouble and expense, why not build in a recessed bench for reading? And, his wife added, why not add some steps, so it would be easy to get up and down? The &#x0024;3,000 wall soon became a &#x0024;4,000 wall.</p>
<p>But it didn&#x2019;t end there. Once the wall was completed, the author sprang for sprinklers and landscaping. After all, the wall looked so good, it was worth a little extra to make it a focal point of the backyard. In the end, the &#x0024;1,000 wall became a &#x0024;4,500 wall. Once the author got started, his commitment to build the rock wall of his dreams grew legs. He loves the wall, of course. He has to. It cost him a bundle.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_12_1_2">
<title>Throwing Good Money After Bad</title>
