<p>We all engage in similar behavior from time to time. The owner of an unreliable car keeps spending money on repairs, hoping this brake job or that muffler repair will finally be the last. The repair bills keep mounting, until they may eventually exceed the car&#x2019;s resale value. Does the owner throw in the towel? Nope. The owner becomes even more resolute the next time something breaks. &#x201C;I&#x2019;ve already poured two grand into that car. I can&#x2019;t give up now.&#x201D; A gambler bets on a football team that loses. The next week, he doubles the bet, feeling confident that he will win the next time around. He loses again. Does he wise up and cut his losses? No way. He becomes more determined than ever that the team will win. His resolve actually increases with each loss.</p>
<p>Once we&#x2019;ve invested our time and energy or poured our hearts and souls into a cause, a person, an idea, a project, or a group we find it difficult to let go. We may have second thoughts, but we repress them. We build up layers of rationalizations for remaining true to our original convictions.</p>
<p>Keep in mind, a large initial commitment isn&#x2019;t required in order for persuaders to take advantage of us. Even relatively simple acts, such as raising your hand, signing a petition, or filling out a form, can be enough. The fact that commitments can grow legs means that we are vulnerable to self-persuasion as well. Remember, we manufacture the additional reasons for bolstering our commitment ourselves. Once we become committed, we may become blind to alternative ways of seeing, thinking, or acting. Thus, we need to remain on guard, not only from others seeking to extract commitments from us but also from ourselves.</p>
<p>Before concluding this section, we wish to note that several worthwhile lessons can be learned from our discussion of commitment and consistency. First, don&#x2019;t allow persuaders to &#x201C;box you in&#x201D; by getting you to commit to something when you really don&#x2019;t want to. Feel free to say, &#x201C;I want to think it over&#x201D; or &#x201C;I want to consider some other options first&#x201D; or &#x201C;You&#x2019;re not trying to rush me into a hasty decision, are you?&#x201D; Second, don&#x2019;t paint yourself into a corner by making public commitments you really don&#x2019;t want, or intend, to keep. Be willing to say, &#x201C;Sorry, I&#x2019;d rather not&#x201D; or &#x201C;I have to say &#x2018;No&#x2019; this time.&#x201D; Third, if you do happen to make an ill-advised commitment, admit it and see what you can do to correct it. Don&#x2019;t double-down on a bad decision. Avoid becoming so preoccupied with saving face that you follow through on a really bad idea. When buying anything, ask about a return or refund policy in advance.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec3_13">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_77">77</target>Summary</title>
<p>The concept of <italic>attitude</italic> is central to the study of persuasion. Attitudes can&#x2019;t be directly observed. They can, however, be inferred and measured through a variety of explicit and implicit means, most commonly via standardized scales. The theory of reasoned action provides a useful, rational model of how attitudes and intentions guide behavior. People&#x2019;s attitudes tend to correlate with their behavior, more so when the attitudes are formed via central processing than peripheral processing. Attitudes formed via central processing are also more persistent and resistant to change. We discussed the fact that attitudes exist in associative networks, and that advertisers use these connections to foster favorable images and associations with their products and services. People have a tendency to strive for consistency among their attitudes, beliefs, and behaviors. Persuaders can adapt their messages either to reinforce consistency or to create inconsistency. Cognitive dissonance, a specialized form of consistency theory, explains how people go about rationalizing decisions after they have made them. The phenomenon of psychological reactance can be used to a persuader&#x2019;s advantage. Engaging in counterattitudinal advocacy or making commitments, especially public commitments, are two important means of facilitating influence, based on the theory of cognitive dissonance.</p>
</sec>
</body>
<back>
<fn-group>
<title>Notes</title>
<fn id="fn3_1"><label>1</label><p>The implicit&#x2013;explicit distinction is not a hard-and-fast distinction. Some explicit attitudes may be activated in a nearly automatic, spontaneous manner. Some implicit attitudes may not be beyond a person&#x2019;s conscious awareness.</p></fn>
<fn id="fn3_2"><label>2</label><p>This explanation is highly consistent with findings based on <italic>inoculation theory</italic>, which we discuss in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter9">Chapter 9</xref>. Inoculating receivers against opposing arguments (e.g., giving them a small dose of the arguments they are likely to hear, along with answers to those arguments) requires that they actively think about message content. This increased mental effort makes them more resistant to opposing arguments presented at a later date.</p></fn>
</fn-group>

O.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Ambady</surname>, <given-names>N.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Hallett</surname>, <given-names>K. C.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2009</year>). <article-title>Female sexual orientation is perceived accurately, rapidly, and automatically from the face and its features</article-title>. <source>Journal of Experimental Social Psychology</source>, <volume>45</volume>, <fpage>1245</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>1251</lpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref3_84"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Rule</surname>, <given-names>N. O.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Ambady</surname>, <given-names>N.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Adams</surname>, <given-names>R. <ref id="ref3_85"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Scher</surname>, <given-names>S. J.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Cooper</surname>, <given-names>J.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>1989</year>). <article-title>The motivational basis of dissonance: The singular role of behavioral consequences</article-title>. <source>Journal of Personality and Social Psychology</source>, <volume>56</volume>, <fpage>899</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>906</lpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref3_86"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>S&#x00E9;n&#x00E9;meaud</surname>, <given-names>C.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Somat</surname>, <given-names>A.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2009</year>). <article-title>Dissonance arousal and persistence in attitude change</article-title>. <source>Swiss Journal of Psychology</source>, <volume>68</volume>(<issue>1</issue>), <fpage>25</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>31</lpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref3_87"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Sharkansky</surname>, <given-names>I.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2002</year>). <article-title>Slogan as policy</article-title>. <source>Journal of Comparative Policy Analysis: Research and Practice</source>, <volume>4</volume>, <fpage>75</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>93</lpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref3_88"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Sullivan</surname>, <given-names>T.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2009</year>, <month>April</month> <day>22</day>). <article-title>The Pirate Bay case: Not necessarily a victory for Hollywood</article-title>. <source>Christian Science Monitor</source>, p. <fpage>6</fpage>.<target target-type="page" id="page_82">82</target></mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref3_89"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Swaminathan</surname>, <given-names>V.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Stilley</surname>, <given-names>K. M.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Ahluwalia</surname>, <given-names>R.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2009</year>). <article-title>When brand personality matters: The moderating role of attachment styles</article-title>. <source>Journal of Consumer Research</source>, <volume>35</volume>(<issue>6</issue>), <fpage>985</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>1002</lpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref3_90"><mixed-citation publication-type="book"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Tavris</surname>, <given-names>C.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Aronson</surname>, <given-names>E.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2007</year>). <source>Mistakes were made (but not by me)</source>. <publisher-loc>New York</publisher-loc>: <publisher-name>Harcourt</publisher-name>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref3_91"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Tesser</surname>, <given-names>A.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Shaffer</surname>, <given-names>D. R.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>1990</year>). <article-title>Attitudes and attitude change</article-title>. <source>Annual Review of Psychology</source>, <volume>41</volume>(<issue>1</issue>), <fpage>479</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>523</lpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref3_92"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Tingley</surname>, <given-names>D.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2006</year>). <article-title>Neurological imaging as evidence in political science: A review, critique, and guiding assessment</article-title>. <source>Social Science Information</source>, <volume>45</volume>(<issue>1</issue>), <fpage>6</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>33</lpage>. doi:<object-id>10.1177/0539018406061100</object-id></mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref3_93"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Tormala</surname>, <given-names>Z. D.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2015</year>). <article-title>How certainty transforms persuasion</article-title>. <source>Harvard Business Review</source>, <volume>93</volume>(<issue>9</issue>), <fpage>96</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>103</lpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref3_94"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Wilson</surname>, <given-names>M. C.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Scior</surname>, <given-names>K.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2014</year>). <article-title>Attitudes toward individuals with disabilities as measured by the implicit association test: A literature review</article-title>. <source>Research in Developmental Disabilities</source>, <volume>35</volume>, <fpage>294</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>321</lpage>. doi:<object-id>10.1016/j.ridd.2013.11.003</object-id></mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref3_95"><mixed-citation publication-type="book"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Wittenbrink</surname>, <given-names>B.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Schwartz</surname>, <given-names>N.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2007</year>) <source>Implicit measures of attitudes</source>. <publisher-loc>New York</publisher-loc>: <publisher-name>Guilford Press</publisher-name>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref3_96"><mixed-citation publication-type="conf-proc"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Xie</surname>, <given-names>X.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Jang</surname>, <given-names>A.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Cai</surname>, <given-names>D. A.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2007</year>, <month>November</month> <day>15</day>). <source>Are Asians really okay with contradictions? Using dissonance to explain cultural differences in responding to contradictions</source>. Paper presented at the <conf-name>annual meeting of the National Communication Association</conf-name>, <conf-loc>Chicago</conf-loc>.</mixed-citation></ref>
</ref-list>
</back>
</book-part>
<book-part book-part-type="chapter" id="chapter4">
<book-part-meta>
<title-group>
<label>4</label>
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_83">83</target>Credibility</title>
<alt-title alt-title-type="running-head">Credibility</alt-title>
</title-group>
<contrib-group>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Gass</surname>
<given-names>Robert H.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Seiter</surname>
<given-names>John S.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
</contrib-group>
</book-part-meta>
<body>
<p>BARACK OBAMA AND DONALD TRUMP have it. So do astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson and media mogul Oprah Winfrey. John F. Kennedy, Ronald Reagan, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. and Princess Diana had it. So did Adolf Hitler, unfortunately. Depending on whom you ask, Dwayne Johnson, Narendra Modi, Ellen DeGeneres, and Sir Richard Branson have it. What all these people have, or had, is <italic>charisma. Charisma</italic> is a lay term used to describe someone who possesses a certain indefinable charm or allure. Such a person may be said to have a magnetic personality or possess a sense of <italic>savoir faire</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_56">Riggio, 1987</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_57">2010</xref>).</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_84">84</target>There is a problem with describing people as charismatic, however. The term has no clear, precise meaning. Because charisma is a fuzzy concept, persuasion researchers tend to rely instead on a different but related concept called <italic>ethos,</italic> or <italic>source credibility.</italic> Ethos bears some similarity to charisma. However, whereas charisma represents an elusive, ineffable quality, ethos can be defined and measured with much greater precision. In this chapter, we examine the concept of ethos, or source credibility, and its relationship to persuasion. First we examine credibility as it relates to celebrity endorsers and spokespersons. Next we offer a definition, discuss the basic features, and explore the underlying dimensions that make up credibility. Then we consider how credibility functions according to Petty and Cacioppo&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_51">1986a</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_52">1986b</xref>) <italic>elaboration likelihood model</italic> of persuasion, and we examine a phenomenon known as the <italic>sleeper effect.</italic> Finally, we discuss credibility as it applies to both institutions and interpersonal settings.</p>
<sec id="sec4_1">
<title>Celebrity Selling Power: The Answer is in the Stars</title>
<p>Did you know that roughly one in four advertisements features a famous person (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_22">Elberse &#x0026; Verleun, 2012</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_63">Spry, Pappu, &#x0026; Cornwall, 2011</xref>)? Were you aware that approximately 10 percent of all advertising expenditures go to pay celebrity endorsers (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_1">Agrawal &#x0026; Kamakura, 1995</xref>)? Nike alone spends about &#x0024;500 million per year on celebrity endorsements (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_14">Bruno, 2011</xref>). Celebrities and athletes with a high <italic>Q-Score</italic> (their selling quotient)<xref ref-type="fn" rid="fn4_1"><sup>1</sup></xref> can command salaries in millions of dollars. No wonder <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_10">Berger (2011)</xref> claims we now live in a <italic>celebritocracy.</italic></p>
<p>Considering all the money that is spent on celebrity endorsements, you might be wondering whether they actually work. When asked, most consumers claim they would never buy a product based on a celebrity endorser&#x2019;s say-so (Study finds &#x2026;, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_65">2000</xref>). However, consumers may be more susceptible than they think. Indeed, a phenomenon known as the <italic>third-person effect</italic> reveals that people underestimate the effect advertising has on themselves and overestimate its effect on others (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_29">Jensen &#x0026; Collins, 2008</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_62">Shin &#x0026; Kim, 2011</xref>).</p>
<p>A recent meta-analysis (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_32">Knoll &#x0026; Mathis, 2017</xref>) found that celebrity endorsements improved consumers&#x2019; attitudes toward endorsed products, but not necessarily their intentions to purchase those products. Another study found that endorser credibility has a significant effect on <italic>brand equity</italic>, which refers to the value attached to a particular brand (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_63">Spry, Pappu, &#x0026; Cornwall, 2011</xref>). According to one study (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_22">Elberse &#x0026; Verleun, 2012</xref>), endorsers boost sales by about 20 percent on average. Celebrity endorsers appear to be most effective at promoting new products and services rather than established brands (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_21">Djafarova &#x0026; Rushworth, 2017</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_37">Kumkale, Albarrac&#x00ED;n, &#x0026; Seignourel, 2010</xref>). If celebrities didn&#x2019;t yield profits, advertisers wouldn&#x2019;t use them.</p>
<p>That said, some people argue that celebrity endorsers are losing their clout. Why? Consumers are relying more and more on social networks than spokespersons (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_75">Weir, 2011</xref>). In fact, some people rate bloggers as more credible than traditional news media (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_50">O&#x2019;Neil &#x0026; Eisenmann, 2017</xref>). Even so, celebrities with large numbers of followers, such as Kim Kardashian, Taylor Swift, and Justin Bieber, have considerable online clout.</p>
<sec id="sec4_1_1">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_85">85</target>The Match-Up Hypothesis: Why Jonah Hill Should Not Be Revlon&#x2019;s Spokesperson</title>
<p>The <italic>match-up hypothesis</italic> suggests that an endorser must be a good &#x201C;fit&#x201D; for the brand being endorsed (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_30">Kamins &#x0026; Gupta, 1994</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_33">Koernig &#x0026; Boyd, 2009</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_67">Till &#x0026; Busler, 2000</xref>). As such, Usain Bolt, the &#x201C;world&#x2019;s fastest man,&#x201D; is a natural choice for Gatorade. Likewise, Justin Bieber&#x2019;s huge fan base of young &#x201C;Beliebers&#x201D; makes him a good choice for Proactiv skin-care products.</p>
<p>One explanation of why celebrities should fit the brands they endorse stems from the <italic>meaning transfer perspective</italic>. According to this view, an endorser&#x2019;s public persona is projected onto a brand. The brand&#x2019;s image is then incorporated into the consumer&#x2019;s self-concept (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_39">McCracken, 1986</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_40">1989</xref>). By way of illustration, Ellen DeGeneres danced her way through one of American Express&#x2019;s &#x201C;My Life, My Card&#x201D; commercials. Independent-minded consumers who see themselves as &#x201C;dancing to their own tune&#x201D; can identify with DeGeneres, whom they see as successful while doing her own thing.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec4_1_2">
<title>Catch a Falling Star</title>
<p>Of course, there can be a downside to relying on well-known celebrities, athletes, or other famous figures. What happens if a famous person becomes embroiled in a scandal or a legal proceeding? When former Subway pitchman, Jared Fogle, was charged with distributing kiddie porn, the company tossed him like wilted lettuce. After it was revealed that celebrity chef Paula Dean made racist remarks off air, Home Depot and other sponsors dumped her like a pan of hot grease. Following news <target target-type="page" id="page_86">86</target>reports that Olympian Ryan Lochte falsely claimed that he was robbed at gunpoint during the 2016 Olympics, the swimmer&#x2019;s stock with Speedo and Polo Ralph Lauren sunk like a stone.</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 4.1</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig4_1.tif"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; David Sipress/ The New Yorker Collection <uri>www.cartoonbank.com</uri></p>
</fig>
<p>As these examples clearly show, if a celebrity, athlete, journalist, or politician is tainted by scandal, it can rub off on the sponsor&#x2019;s credibility (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_68">Till &#x0026; Shimp, 1998</xref>). To avoid the risk and expense of actual endorsers, many companies rely on fictional spokespersons. Aunt Jemima would never engage in insider trading. The Geico gecko will never be arrested for sexual assault. Mr. Clean won&#x2019;t ever test positive for steroid use, and the Keebler elves won&#x2019;t be charged with child pornography in an undercover sting operation. Having examined the downside of relying too heavily on credibility as a tool of persuasion, let&#x2019;s consider more carefully what it actually is and how it actually works.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec4_2">
<title>What is Credibility?</title>
<p>O&#x2019;Keefe (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_49">2002</xref>) defines credibility as &#x201C;judgments made by a perceiver (e.g., a message recipient) concerning the believability of a communicator&#x201D; (p. 181). We suggest that this definition should be extended to institutions as well. Private companies and governmental agencies also have images to protect. They want to be viewed favorably, too. In addition, it should be recognized that in face-to-face encounters there are really <italic>two</italic> sources whose credibility is at stake, because each party to the interaction is simultaneously a sender and a receiver of messages.</p>
<sec id="sec4_2_1">
<title>Credibility Is a Receiver-Based Construct</title>
<p>An important feature of O&#x2019;Keefe&#x2019;s definition is the recognition that credibility is a <italic>receiver-based construct.</italic> Credibility exists in the eye of the beholder. For example, Edward Snowden may be perceived as a heroic whistleblower by some, and as a publicity-seeking traitor by others. A celebrity who takes a strong political stand may be cheered by some and jeered by others. In short, if these folks are credible, it is because we bestow credibility on them. Modifying a time-worn philosophical question, one might ask, &#x201C;If a source stood in the middle of a forest and there were no one around to perceive him or her, would there be any credibility?&#x201D; Our answer is no. Different sources possess different abilities and attributes, but the value assigned to these abilities and attributes resides in the receiver, not in the source. Credibility is a perceptual phenomenon.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec4_2_2">
<title>Credibility Is a Multidimensional Construct</title>
<p>A second important feature of credibility is that it is not a unidimensional construct &#x2014;that is, it is not made up of only one element. Credibility represents a composite of several characteristics that others perceive in a source. Credibility is a <italic>multidimensional construct.</italic> An analogy may serve to clarify. Imagine that you were trying to define <italic>athleticism.</italic> It would be difficult to single out only one thing that makes an individual athletic. Athleticism requires strength, coordination, stamina, and quick reflexes, among other things. Similarly, credibility isn&#x2019;t a single characteristic, but a combination of qualities a source is believed to possess. We discuss these qualities shortly.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec4_2_3">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_87">87</target>Credibility Is a Situational/Contextual Phenomenon</title>
<p>A third feature of credibility is that it is a <italic>situational</italic> or <italic>contextual phenomenon.</italic> A persuader&#x2019;s credibility is subject to change from one audience or setting to another. The very qualities that are admired in a communicator in one setting may be derided in another setting. The president of the National Rifle Association might be well received when speaking before an audience of hunting and fishing enthusiasts. The same source might encounter a hostile reception, however, if he spoke before a group of animal rights advocates. Your own credibility is subject to such situational changes too. You may enjoy more credibility in one context&#x2014;for example, work, family, friends, school&#x2014;than in another.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec4_2_4">
<title>Credibility Is Dynamic</title>
<p>Credibility can change over time. For example, in his first 100 days in office, the public&#x2019;s disapproval of President Donald Trump increased 11 percent, from 41 to 55 percent (<uri>https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/trump-approval-ratings/</uri>). It is important to recognize, then, that credibility is <italic>dynamic:</italic> It fluctuates over time. A source&#x2019;s credibility can change even during the course of a single speech, sales pitch, or boardroom presentation.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec4_3">
<title>The Factor Analytic Approach to Credibility</title>
<p>Just as chefs are interested in what ingredients go into award-winning recipes, persuasion researchers have tried to determine the &#x201C;ingredients,&#x201D; or underlying dimensions, of credibility. In fact, as long ago as 380 BCE, Aristotle proclaimed in <italic>The Rhetoric</italic> that the ingredients &#x201C;which inspire confidence in the orator&#x2019;s character &#x2026; that induce us to believe a thing apart from any proof of it &#x2026; [are] good sense, good moral character, and good will&#x201D; (1378). Aristotle wasn&#x2019;t far off the mark.</p>
<p>In the 1960s and 1970s researchers began to use a statistical technique known as <italic>factor analysis</italic> to uncover the underlying dimensions or ingredients of credibility. Controversy emerged during this period over how many credibility dimensions there were and what they should be called (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_18">Cronkhite &#x0026; Liska, 1976</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_53">Pornpitakpan, 2004</xref>). Subsequent investigations, though, have clarified the situation considerably, if not completely.</p>
<sec id="sec4_3_1">
<title>Primary Dimensions of Credibility</title>
<p>There is now fairly solid evidence that there are three <italic>primary dimensions</italic> of credibility that almost always apply to the evaluation of sources. There are also multiple secondary dimensions that are more situation specific. To enhance your own credibility, you should focus on these primary dimensions. The secondary dimensions may or may not matter depending on your particular situation. The scale items used to measure these dimensions can be found in <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box4_1">Box 4.1</xref>.</p>
<sec id="sec4_3_1_1">
<title>Expertise</title>
<p>The first primary dimension of credibility is <italic>expertise</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_41">McCroskey, 1966</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_53">Pornpitakpan, 2004</xref>). To be credible, a persuader must know his or her stuff or, at least, <italic>appear</italic> to know his or her stuff. Sometimes a title alone, such as MD, PhD, or CPA, can confer credibility on a source. You have to be careful, though; not all <target target-type="page" id="page_88">88</target>titles mean what they say. For example, a person who uses the prefix Dr., may not be a medical doctor or an academic. Honorary doctoral degrees are sometimes awarded by universities, but only as a form of recognition. Kermit the Frog, for instance, received an honorary doctorate of &#x201C;amphibious letters&#x201D; from South Hampton College. What&#x2019;s more, it isn&#x2019;t difficult to buy a doctoral degree online from a non-accredited institution (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_6">Bartlett &#x0026; Smallwood, 2014</xref>). And, of course, some &#x201C;doctors,&#x201D; like Dr. Dre, Doc Rivers, and Doc Marten are simply nicknames.</p>
<boxed-text id="box4_1">
<label><target target-type="page" id="page_89">89</target>Box 4.1</label>
<caption><title>Bipolar Adjectives Used to Measure Credibility With a Semantic Differential Scale</title></caption>
<table-wrap>
<oasis:table frame="topbot" colsep="0" rowsep="0">
<oasis:tgroup cols="2">
<oasis:colspec colnum="1" colname="col1" align="left"/>
<oasis:colspec colnum="2" colname="col2" align="left"/>
<oasis:thead>
<oasis:row rowsep="1">
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>PRIMARY DIMENSIONS</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>SECONDARY DIMENSIONS</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
</oasis:thead>
<oasis:tbody>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Expertise</p>
<p>(also called competence or qualification)
<list list-type="simple">
<list-item><p>&#x2013; experienced/inexperienced</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; informed/uninformed</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; trained/untrained</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; qualified/unqualified</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; skilled/unskilled</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; intelligent/unintelligent</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; expert/inexpert</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; competent/incompetent</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; bright/stupid</p></list-item>
</list></p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Extroversion
<list list-type="simple">
<list-item><p>&#x2013; timid/bold</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013;verbal/quiet</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013;meek/aggressive</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013;talkative/silent</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
<p>Composure
<list list-type="simple">
<list-item><p>&#x2013; poised/nervous</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; relaxed/tense</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; calm/anxious</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; excitable/composed</p></list-item>
</list>
</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Trustworthiness <italic>(also called character, safety, or personal integrity)</italic>
<list list-type="simple">
<list-item><p>&#x2013; honest/dishonest</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; trustworthy/untrustworthy</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; open-minded/close-minded</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; just/unjust</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; fair/unfair</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; unselfish/selfish</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; moral/immoral</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; ethical/unethical</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; genuine/phony</p></list-item>
</list>
</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Sociability
<list list-type="simple">
<list-item><p>&#x2013; good-natured/irritable</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; cheerful/gloomy</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; friendly/unfriendly</p></list-item>
</list>
</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Goodwill
<list list-type="simple">
<list-item><p>&#x2013; cares about me/doesn&#x2019;t care about me</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; has my interests at heart/doesn&#x2019;t</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; have my interests at heart</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; not self-centered/self-centered</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; concerned with me/not concerned with me</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; sensitive/insensitive</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x2013; understanding/not understanding</p></list-item>
</list>
</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
</oasis:tbody>
</oasis:tgroup>
</oasis:table>
<table-wrap-foot>
<attrib>Source: Adapted from McCroskey, J. C, &#x0026; Young, T. J. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_44">1981</xref>). and McCroskey, J. C, &#x0026; Teven, J. J. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_43">1999</xref>).</attrib>
</table-wrap-foot>
</table-wrap>
</boxed-text>
<p>To be regarded as experts, sources needn&#x2019;t possess advanced degrees, specialized training, licenses, or credentials, however. For example, at an Alcoholics Anonymous meeting, members who had been alcoholics for 20 years, and who had been sober for the past 10 years, would likely be perceived as having expertise. Such members would know what they were talking about, because they had &#x201C;been there&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_20">Denzen, 1987</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_59">Robertson, 1988</xref>). Even astrologers, fortune-tellers, and psychics make attempts to establish their expertise. &#x201C;Don&#x2019;t pay for advice from phony psychics,&#x201D; a psychic website proclaims, &#x201C;We have <italic>genuine, certified psychics</italic> waiting to chat with you online.&#x201D;</p>
<p>Interestingly, a source&#x2019;s expertise doesn&#x2019;t always have to be in the field in which he or she is attempting to persuade. LeBron James and Cristiano Ronaldo, for example, aren&#x2019;t experts in electronics. Yet they are effective endorsers for Samsung. Endorsements by famous persons enjoy a <italic>halo effect</italic> that allows them to carry their credibility to new, unrelated fields. The halo effect isn&#x2019;t limited to famous people. In one study (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_58">Rind, 1992</xref>), a confederate working with the experimenter approached shoppers in the food court of a mall and asked them to buy raffle tickets. In one of the experimental conditions, he amazed the shoppers with his calculating ability (the confederate used a hidden transmitter, through which he received the correct answers). In another condition, he made a fool of himself by exhibiting poor calculating skills. In a third control condition, the confederate didn&#x2019;t profess to have any amazing skills. Shoppers bought significantly more raffle tickets when the confederate demonstrated astonishing calculating skills than in either of the other two conditions. It mattered not that the purpose of the raffle was unrelated to the confederate&#x2019;s amazing talent. Expertise, even unrelated expertise, then, can be an asset in persuasion. Bear in mind, however, that purchasing a raffle ticket is a fairly trivial act. We suspect that on a more involving issue, relevant expertise would be valued more highly by receivers.</p>
<p>Although we tend to think of expert sources as being highly confident, this is not always the case. Sources who already possess high credibility may be more influential when they express their opinions with less certainty, whereas sources who have lower credibility are more persuasive when they express their opinions with greater certainty (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_31">Karmarkar &#x0026; Tormala, 2010</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec4_3_1_2">
<title>Trustworthiness</title>
<p>The second primary dimension of credibility is <italic>trustworthiness</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_41">McCroskey, 1966</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_53">Pornpitakpan, 2004</xref>). A source may appear knowledgeable, but what if you don&#x2019;t think he or she is being truthful or can be trusted? If your car needs a brake job, you not only want a qualified mechanic, you want an <italic>honest,</italic> qualified mechanic. To be successful, persuaders must, therefore, convey an impression of honesty and integrity.</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_90">90</target>Perhaps you&#x2019;ve noticed that some advertisements in magazines or newspapers carry the logo &#x201C;As Seen On TV.&#x201D; The purpose in displaying this logo is to instill trust. Many consumers unthinkingly presume that only reputable companies can afford television commercials. The same applies to <italic>Yellow Pages</italic> ads that feature the ichthys logo, the Christian sign of the fish. Consumers may assume that an electrician, plumber, or carpenter who is a Christian is less likely to rip them off. Such &#x201C;sign reasoning&#x201D; may have merit. But then again, couldn&#x2019;t an unscrupulous tradesperson simply use the ichthys logo to dupe customers into believing that he or she is trust-worthy? Bernie Madoff, a stockbroker and investment advisor, seemed trustworthy, until he was exposed for operating a Ponzi scheme. He defrauded investors out of &#x0024;65 billion.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec4_3_1_3">
<title>Goodwill</title>
<p>The third primary dimension of credibility is <italic>goodwill</italic>. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_43">McCroskey and Teven (1999)</xref> suggest that goodwill is synonymous with <italic>perceived caring</italic>. That is, a source who seems to care about and take a genuine interest in the receiver is displaying goodwill. Goodwill can be demonstrated by displaying understanding for another person&#x2019;s ideas, feelings, or needs. Goodwill can also be demonstrated by displaying empathy&#x2014;that is, identifying with another person&#x2019;s feelings or situation. Goodwill can be displayed by responsiveness as well, by being open and receptive to another&#x2019;s communication attempts. A source who said, &#x201C;I hear where you are coming from&#x201D; or &#x201C;I can relate to that&#x201D; or &#x201C;I sympathize with how you feel&#x201D; would be displaying this quality.</p>
<p>Of the three primary dimensions just discussed, expertise seems to have the greatest effect on persuasion. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_76">Wilson and Sherrell (1993)</xref> revealed in a meta-analysis that the effect of expertise was greater than that of trustworthiness, attraction, or similarity on persuasion. The importance of the dimensions on persuasive outcomes, however, may depend on the particular topic or context for persuasion.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec4_3_2">
<title>Secondary Dimensions of Credibility</title>
<p>Researchers have uncovered several other dimensions of credibility that tend to be more situation specific. One of these, termed <italic>dynamism</italic> by some (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_13">Berlo, Lemert, &#x0026; Mertz, 1969</xref>) and <italic>extroversion</italic> by others (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_16">Burgoon, 1976</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_44">McCroskey &#x0026; Young, 1981</xref>), has to do with how energetic, animated, or enthusiastic the source appears. Obviously, it wouldn&#x2019;t do for a fitness trainer like Jillian Michaels, or a dancer like Julianne Hough, to appear sluggish or lethargic. Certain situations call for the source to be &#x201C;peppy&#x201D; and full of energy. However, a person who is too bubbly and effervescent, especially at the wrong times, may lose credibility (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_15">Burgoon, 1973</xref>). The trick is for a source to match his or her level of dynamism to the demands of the situation.</p>
<p>Another secondary dimension of credibility is <italic>composure</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_46">Miller &#x0026; Hewgill, 1964</xref>). In some situations, we expect a source to remain calm, cool, and collected. The character of James Bond, secret agent 007, exudes this quality. Captain Chesley &#x201C;Sully&#x201D; Sullenberger, who safely landed US Airways flight 1549 on the Hudson River, retained his composure during the entire ordeal. The flight recordings released by the FAA revealed that Sully was &#x201C;the epitome of composure under life-threatening pressure&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_45">McShane, 2009</xref>, p. 12). On the flip-side of the coin, a source who loses composure, or who seems nervous or ill at ease, may lose credibility. When Tom <target target-type="page" id="page_91">91</target>Cruise jumped up and down on Oprah&#x2019;s couch while proclaiming his love for Katie Holmes, viewers felt he had lost it.</p>
<p>An additional secondary dimension of credibility has been dubbed <italic>sociability.</italic> This dimension refers to a source&#x2019;s friendliness or outgoingness. To us, Paul Rudd, Emma Thompson, Rashida Jones, Tom Hanks, Reese Witherspoon, and Magic Johnson possess this quality, as do others who relate to people easily. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_60">Sanders (2006)</xref> emphasizes that friendliness, empathy, and authenticity go a long way in trying to persuade people. Sociability is particularly important in the &#x201C;people professions,&#x201D; such as sales, law, education, social work, and the like.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec4_4">
<title>The Factor Analytic Approach and the Real World</title>
<p>Given the extraordinary amount of attention devoted to the study of credibility, how do these dimensions hold up in the real world? The answer is, remarkably well. More than three decades of research by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_35">Kouzes and Posner (2017)</xref> involving thousands of people in leadership positions verify that admired people display competence, exhibit honesty, are inspiring, and forward-looking. Kouzes and Posner highlight the overlap with several of the dimensions described above. &#x201C;For trustworthiness, you can say <italic>honest</italic>. For expertise, you can say <italic>competent</italic>. For dynamism, you can say <italic>inspiring</italic>. In other words &#x2026; what has been reaffirmed &#x2026; is that above all else, people want leaders who are credible&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_34">2011</xref>, p. 16).</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 4.2</label>
<caption><title>Perceived expertise is a prerequisite for credibility.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig4_2.jpg"/>
</fig>
</sec>
<sec id="sec4_5">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_92">92</target>Credibility as a Peripheral Cue</title>
<p>Now that we&#x2019;ve explained what credibility is, we turn our attention to how and why it facilitates persuasion. To do so, we return to Petty and Cacioppo&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_51">1986a</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_52">1986b</xref>) <italic>elaboration likelihood model</italic> of persuasion (ELM), which was introduced in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter2">Chapter 2</xref>. According to the ELM, there are two distinct routes to persuasion; a <italic>central route</italic> and a <italic>peripheral route</italic>. The central route, involves thinking or <italic>cognitive elaboration</italic>. The peripheral route relies on mental shortcuts or <italic>heuristic cues</italic>.</p>
<p>Petty and Cacioppo conceptualize credibility as a peripheral cue to persuasion. When receivers have little at stake, their motivation to pay attention to a message is lower. They therefore tend to favor the peripheral route. As a general rule, source credibility exerts more influence on receivers who aren&#x2019;t highly involved in an issue. Credibility matters far less if receiver involvement is already high. Instead, credibility tends to work its magic when receiver involvement is low (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_7">Benoit, 1987</xref>). Receivers with low involvement are more likely to defer to sources, because doing so requires less mental effort than concentrating on the substance of a message. To put it bluntly, low-involved receivers are cognitively lazy. This limitation notwithstanding, we mustn&#x2019;t underestimate the importance of credibility. Credibility may be conceptualized as a peripheral cue, but it is still a big peripheral cue.</p>
<p>You can use this information to your advantage if you are trying to persuade receivers who perceive you as having low credibility. You should do everything you can to increase their involvement in the topic or issue. Explain why the issue is relevant to them. Emphasize how the topic or issue affects them directly. If you can increase your target audience&#x2019;s involvement in the topic or issue, they&#x2019;ll pay more attention to the message and less attention to your credibility.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec4_6">
<title>It&#x2019;s what&#x2019;s Up Front that Counts</title>
<p>When should a source&#x2019;s expertise be identified&#x2014;at the beginning or end of a persuasive message? Research findings strongly suggest that credibility tends to work only if the source is identified <italic>prior</italic> to the actual presentation of a persuasive message (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_9">Benoit &#x0026; Strathman, 2004</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_47">Nan, 2009</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_48">O&#x2019;Keefe, 1987</xref>). If the source is identified after the fact, credibility has little or no effect. Several studies, for example, found no differences in the persuasiveness of high- versus low-credibility sources when the sources were identified after the messages were presented (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_48">O&#x2019;Keefe, 1987</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_72">Ward &#x0026; McGinnies, 1974</xref>). <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_9">Benoit and Strathman (2004)</xref> suggest that this is because credibility affects the way receivers process a message. For credibility to do any good, therefore, receivers must consider the source&#x2019;s credibility as they process a persuasive message.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec4_7">
<title>The Sleeper Effect</title>
<p>The traditional view is that the impact of a persuasive message wanes over time (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_28">Hovland, Lumsdaine, &#x0026; Sheffield, 1949</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_64">Stiff, 1994</xref>). Receivers forget what was said or who said it. Persuasion wears off. The <italic>sleeper effect</italic>, however, suggests that under the right circumstances, the delayed impact of a message may be more effective than <target target-type="page" id="page_93">93</target>its initial impact (Kumkale &#x0026; Albarrac&#x00ED;n, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_36">2004</xref>)&#x2014;that is, the message might grow on receivers. Specifically, the sleeper effect posits that a message from a low-credibility source may increase in persuasiveness as time passes, compared to a message from a high-credibility source. Sound unlikely? It is, to some extent. Yet the sleeper effect has been documented by researchers, dating back more than 50 years (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_28">Hovland et al., 1949</xref>). How the sleeper effect works requires some explanation.</p>
<p>Imagine that one audience is exposed to a persuasive message from a source with high credibility. A second audience is exposed to the same persuasive message, but from a source with low credibility, by means of a <italic>discounting cue</italic>. A discounting cue consists of a disclaimer containing negative information about the source, the message, or both. For example, let&#x2019;s say the first group heard a message in favor of irradiating fruits and vegetables to kill bacteria before they are shipped to market. The second group would hear the same message, plus a disclaimer saying the message was drafted by a lobbyist for the agricultural industry whose real concern was agricultural profits, not consumer safety. The discounting cue would thus serve as an impediment to the effectiveness of the second message, a &#x201C;ball and chain,&#x201D; so to speak. Afterward, each group&#x2019;s attitudes toward irradiated produce would be measured.</p>
<p>Initially, the first group&#x2019;s attitudes should be much more favorable toward the topic than the second group&#x2019;s. After all, the first group heard the message from the high-credibility source. With the passage of time, however, things might change. The first group&#x2019;s attitudes would gradually decay over time. The second group&#x2019;s attitudes, however, might undergo a process known as <italic>disassociation,</italic> whereby the message is separated from its source in the minds of receivers. The second group might remember the message, but forget the discounting cue. If you&#x2019;ve ever heard someone say, &#x201C;I heard somewhere that &#x2026;&#x201D; or &#x201C;I read somewhere that &#x2026;&#x201D; you&#x2019;ve observed disassociation in action. Once the message was decoupled from its source, the ball and chain would be removed. The result would be that as the first group&#x2019;s attitudes diminished, the second group&#x2019;s attitudes would become more positive. <italic>Voil&#x00E0;</italic>! The sleeper effect.</p>
<p>Although the sleeper effect has been demonstrated in laboratory studies (Kumkale &#x0026; Albarrac&#x00ED;n, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_36">2004</xref>), it is difficult to produce on a consistent, reliable basis. Only a few studies have demonstrated an <italic>absolute</italic> sleeper effect (see <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig4_3">Figure 4.3</xref>) of the type we&#x2019;ve been discussing (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_26">Gruder et al., 1978</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_73">Watts &#x0026; Holt, 1979</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_74">Watts &#x0026; McGuire, 1964</xref>). An absolute sleeper effect occurs when a message from a high-credibility source loses favor over time, whereas a message from a low-credibility source gains favor over time. Other studies have demonstrated a <italic>relative</italic> sleeper effect (see <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig4_3">Figure 4.3</xref>), meaning that both messages lose favor over time, but the high-credibility message loses more favor than the low-credibility message (see reviews by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_2">Allen &#x0026; Stiff, 1989</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_3">1998</xref>). Some studies have failed to find a sleeper effect at all (see reviews by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_2">Allen &#x0026; Stiff, 1989</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_3">1998</xref>). The sleeper effect, then, can be pretty fickle.</p>
<fig id="fig4_3" position="float">
<label>Figure 4.3</label>
<caption><title>Illustration of an absolute and a relative sleeper effect.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig4_3.tif"/>
</fig>
<p>There is evidence, however, that fictional narratives can induce the sleeper effect (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_4">Appel &#x0026; Richter, 2007</xref>). Over time, a person may forget what was fact and what was fiction, and come to believe a fictional storyline. What implications does this hold for you as a persuader? In practice, it would be very difficult for an ordinary persuader, <target target-type="page" id="page_94">94</target>as opposed to a laboratory researcher, to satisfy all of the requirements for obtaining a sleeper effect. We believe there are far too many &#x201C;ifs&#x201D; associated with this strategy to recommend it to an ordinary persuader. Our advice is that you would be much better off trying to enhance your credibility as much as possible in the first place.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec4_8">
<title>Credibility and Image Management</title>
<p>Thus far, we&#x2019;ve discussed credibility strictly in connection with people. We believe the concept of credibility can be extended to corporations, organizations, governmental agencies, social movements, and other institutions as well. Such group entities care about how they are perceived by the public and other constituencies. They want to project positive images. And to a large extent, their power and ability to influence are linked to their images and their reputations. For these reasons, we maintain that the credibility construct applies equally well to institutional entities and individuals. Britain&#x2019;s slogan, &#x201C;keep calm and carry on,&#x201D; for example, embodies the dimension of composure for an entire nation.</p>
<p>As further illustration, consider the charitable activities of major corporations. McDonald&#x2019;s established Ronald McDonald House to provide assistance to hospital-bound children and their families. The National Football League donates generously to the United Way. Other companies contribute to the Make-A-Wish Foundation. In so doing, these corporations are demonstrating that they are good citizens in their communities. Doing good deeds enhances public perceptions of goodwill. We aren&#x2019;t suggesting that corporations are disingenuous when they sponsor causes or that corporate altruism is based solely on the profit motive. We do wish to point out, however, that philanthropic acts make for good public relations.</p>
<p>So important is image management for corporations, institutions, government agencies, and the like that entire departments, divisions, and staffs exist for just this purpose. They may be called publicists, press agents, mouthpieces, or spin doctors, but their goal is the same: to generate favorable publicity and avoid unfavorable <target target-type="page" id="page_95">95</target>media coverage. Even the military employs public relations officers, because good PR is part of good military strategy. Whatever the title of these types of positions, one of their primary missions is to maintain the credibility of the host institution.</p>
<p>On occasion, corporations, institutions, and government agencies commit blunders that damage their credibility. For example, the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico made BP the poster boy for evil oil companies. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_8">William Benoit (1995)</xref> refers to this process as <italic>image restoration</italic> and notes that such efforts are highly persuasive in nature (p. 6). Examples in which circumstances have forced corporations and other institutions to engage in image restoration abound. Volkswagen&#x2019;s credibility took a hit when it admitted that 11 million of its diesel engine cars were fitted with software designed to defeat emissions tests. Thus far, the automaker has paid out &#x0024;20 billion in fines, with more in the offing. VW ran a series of ads apologizing to customers and promising to make things right. Wells Fargo piqued consumers&#x2019; ire when it created 3.5 million bogus accounts without their customers&#x2019; permission. Soon after the company launched a &#x201C;make things right&#x201D; campaign. United Airlines suffered a public relations nightmare when airport security forcibly removed a passenger from one of its airplanes.</p>
<p><xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_8">Benoit (1995)</xref> notes that such defensive campaigns are commonplace. They are undertaken out of a necessity to restore the credibility of the corporation, institution, or agency whose image has been tarnished. Benoit highlights a variety of strategies aimed at image restoration. The specific strategies employed, of course, depend on the nature of the difficulty in which the institution finds itself and the range of available defenses.</p>
<p>We can see, then, that corporations and other institutions, not only individuals, possess credibility in varying amounts. We suspect that the same primary dimensions of credibility that apply to individuals apply equally well to corporations. We suspect that the secondary dimensions of credibility discussed previously, however, might differ. After all, the secondary dimensions don&#x2019;t always appear in studies of individuals&#x2019; credibility. This would appear to be a fruitful topic for future scholarly inquiry.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec4_9">
<title>Interpersonal Credibility, Impression Management, Facework, and Accounts</title>
<p>Ordinary folks can&#x2019;t hire their own public relations firm or employ a publicist to maintain a positive public image. They do engage in public relations campaigns, nonetheless. Ordinary persons tend to function as their own PR departments through impression management and facework.</p>
<p><italic>Impression management theory</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_66">Tedeschi &#x0026; Reiss, 1981</xref>) seeks to explain how persons go about trying to project a positive self-image.<xref ref-type="fn" rid="fn4_2"><sup>2</sup></xref> Individuals want others to form favorable impressions of them. In short, individuals want to be perceived as credible and likable. The importance of likability, specifically, is featured in <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box4_2">Box 4.2</xref>. Individuals attempt to manage others&#x2019; impressions of themselves by trying to say and do the right things. Engaging in &#x201C;politically correct&#x201D; behavior is an example of impression management at work.</p>
<p>Our position is that when an individual is engaging in impression management, he or she is engaging in persuasion. He or she is attempting to influence others&#x2019; <target target-type="page" id="page_96">96</target>impressions of him or her. At the same time, he or she is vulnerable to influence attempts by others. This is because persons are highly susceptible to persuasive appeals aimed at enhancing their own self-image. By way of illustration, a common preoccupation of teenagers, especially younger teens, is &#x201C;looking cool.&#x201D; If one teen can convince another that dressing or acting a certain way will make him or her look &#x201C;cool,&#x201D; the other teen is likely to conform to that style of dress or behavior. Most of us need look no further than our high school yearbooks to realize that we, too, were susceptible to the fads, trends, and fashions of our day.</p>
<boxed-text id="box4_2">
<label><target target-type="page" id="page_97">97</target>Box 4.2</label>
<caption><title>Icing on the Cake: The Benefits of Likability</title></caption>
<p>Suppose you are choosing which of two tour guides to hire. Both are equally knowledgeable and experienced. Their tour prices are the same and include the same itinerary. One guide, however, is more friendly and likable, the other more distant and aloof. Which one would you choose? If you are like us, you would rather spend your day with the more likable guide. As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_23">Gitomer (2015)</xref> observes, &#x201C;all things being equal, people prefer to do business with people they like. All things being not so equal, people still prefer to do business with people they like&#x201D; (p. 10).</p>
<p><xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_38">Lovas and Holloway (2009)</xref> explain that &#x201C;likability is a combination of characteristics including (but not limited to) interest, empathy and genuineness. In a professional context, likable people tend to be interesting to us, interested in us, empathetic, positive, non-judgmental, and genuine&#x201D; (p. 40). <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_60">Sanders (2006)</xref>, who refers to likability as the &#x201C;L-factor,&#x201D; defines likability as &#x201C;an ability to create positive attitudes in other people through the delivery of emotional and psychological benefits&#x201D; (p. 33). Interestingly, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton were the two most unlikable presidential candidates since modern polling began (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_27">Holyk &#x0026; Langer, 2016</xref>). In contrast, Bernie Sanders was rated the most likable candidate in 2016. Other likable public figures include Ellen DeGeneres, Tom Hanks, Chris Pratt, and Taylor Swift.</p>
<p>While important, likability only goes so far. If you were having brain surgery, would you prefer the best surgeon available or a lesser surgeon with a great bedside manner? For women in politics or the business world, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_17">Cooper (2013)</xref> argues that being likable and competent entails a double standard. Strong, successful women may be labeled as &#x201C;aggressive,&#x201D; &#x201C;abrasive,&#x201D; or &#x201C;difficult.&#x201D; She suggests that, for women, success and likability are often negatively correlated.</p>
<table-wrap>
<oasis:table frame="topbot" colsep="0" rowsep="0">
<oasis:tgroup cols="8">
<oasis:colspec colnum="1" colname="col1" align="left"/>

<oasis:colspec colnum="3" colname="col3" align="left"/>

<oasis:thead>

</oasis:row>
</oasis:thead>
<oasis:tbody>
<oasis:row>

</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>

<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Disagree</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Neutral</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Agree</p></oasis:entry>

<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Very Strongly Agree</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
</oasis:tbody>
</oasis:tgroup>
</oasis:table>
<table-wrap-foot>
<attrib>Source: <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_55">Reysen (2005)</xref></attrib>
</table-wrap-foot>
</table-wrap>
</boxed-text>
<p>Impression management also requires that people engage in <italic>facework,</italic> a term coined by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_24">Erving Goffman (1967</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_25">1974</xref>). A person&#x2019;s &#x201C;face&#x201D; refers to his or her social standing in the eyes of others. Facework involves negotiating one&#x2019;s social standing and social worth with others (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_69">Ting-Toomey, 1988</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_70">1994</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_71">Ting-Toomey &#x0026; Kurogi, 1998</xref>). For example, committing a social faux pas could result in the loss of one&#x2019;s own face. Facework would be required to restore one&#x2019;s face. Threatening or challenging another person could cause the other to lose face. Facework would again be required for the other to regain face.</p>
<p>As with identity management, we suggest that facework is inherently persuasive in nature. Facework involves goal-oriented communication that seeks particular outcomes or ends&#x2014;namely, &#x201C;satisfying one&#x2019;s own face wants and the face wants of one&#x2019;s interlocutor&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_19">Cupach &#x0026; Imahori, 1993</xref>, p. 117). For example, consider the related social rituals of asking someone out on a date and declining someone&#x2019;s invitation for a date. Both rituals, asking and declining, are persuasive in nature, and both are laden with face-saving implications. Although not synonymous with credibility, we see the concepts of face and facework as being closely related to the credibility construct. Maintaining one&#x2019;s face, we believe, is akin to maintaining one&#x2019;s credibility in the eyes of others.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec4_10">
<title>Strategies for Enhancing Credibility: Get Your Mojo Working</title>
<p>Having gained a better understanding of what credibility is and how it works, what can you do to enhance your credibility when persuading? A number of general guidelines are offered for improving your credibility. Keep in mind that because credibility is a receiver-based construct, what works on one listener or audience may not work on the next.</p>
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p><italic>Heed the Boy Scout motto: &#x201C;Be prepared.&#x201D;</italic> Before making your case, be as well prepared and well organized as possible. Think through your position beforehand and anticipate likely objections to your position. If you don&#x2019;t seem to know what you are talking about, your credibility will suffer. Research shows that unorganized messages are far less convincing than organized ones (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_42">McCroskey &#x0026; Mehrley, 1969</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_61">Sharp &#x0026; McClung, 1966</xref>).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Cite evidence for your position and identify the sources of your evidence.</italic> In a review of the effects of evidence usage, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_54">Reinard (1988)</xref> concluded that in almost all cases, citing evidence and sources significantly enhanced speaker credibility. This advice applies especially to low-credibility sources.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><target target-type="page" id="page_98">98</target><italic>Cite your own or your sources&#x2019; qualifications and expertise on the topic or issue up front.</italic> Remember, expertise is one of the primary dimensions of credibility. For credibility to enhance persuasion, however, the source&#x2019;s credentials must be identified prior to presenting the message. If you have expertise on a topic or an issue, let your listener(s) know. If you lack expertise on an issue, don&#x2019;t dwell on your deficiencies. Instead, explain how you came to develop an interest in the subject. Also, consider this: If, in fact, you know little or nothing about a topic, then you have no business trying to persuade others about that topic in the first place.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Attempt to build trust by demonstrating to your listener that you are honest and sincere.</italic> One approach is to demonstrate that you possess good moral character. Another is to acknowledge that although compliance would benefit you, it would benefit the other person as well; compliance would be in both parties&#x2019; mutual interest.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Display goodwill toward your audience.</italic> Don&#x2019;t seem aloof or indifferent. Show that you care about others, that you understand their ideas and their situation, that you empathize with their feelings and views, and that you are attentive and responsive to their communication attempts. For example, if a listener asks you a question, begin your answer by saying, &#x201C;If I heard you correctly, you want to know &#x2026;&#x201D; and end by asking, &#x201C;Does that address what you were asking?&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Improve your likability, or L-factor.</italic> Likability affects how you and your message are received. Some view likability as a form of emotional intelligence (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_60">Sanders, 2006</xref>). You can improve your L-factor by conveying warmth and immediacy. Smile often. Remember people&#x2019;s names. Listen. Thank people and accept compliments sincerely. Being genuine and authentic goes a long way.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Adopt a language and delivery style appropriate to the listener(s), topic, and setting.</italic> Your style of speech should be tailored to your particular receiver(s). Different receivers have different needs. In general, nonfluencies, pauses or gaps, and a choppy style of delivery hinder credibility (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_11">Berger, 1985</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_12">1994</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_46">Miller &#x0026; Hewgill, 1964</xref>). A reliance on &#x201C;uhms,&#x201D; &#x201C;ahs,&#x201D; and other fillers impairs credibility as well. An overreliance on slang, colloquialisms, or trite expressions can also compromise credibility.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Avoid a powerless style of communication. Use an assertive style of communication instead.</italic> A powerless communication style involves using tag questions (&#x201C;That was a good movie, don&#x2019;t you think?&#x201D;), hesitations (&#x201C;uhm,&#x201D; &#x201C;uh&#x201D;), qualifiers (&#x201C;kind of,&#x201D; &#x201C;sort of,&#x201D; &#x201C;perhaps,&#x201D; &#x201C;maybe&#x201D;), and negative preambles (&#x201C;This will probably sound really dumb, but &#x2026;&#x201D;). A reliance on powerless language signals to the other party that you perceive yourself as occupying a lower status position in the relationship. For more about this topic, refer to <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter7">Chapter 7</xref>, in which we examine the role of language in persuasion.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Emphasize your similarity to another to indirectly enhance your credibility.</italic> Listeners find it easier to identify with sources they perceive as similar to themselves. O&#x2019;Keefe (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref4_49">2002</xref>) points out two important caveats regarding similarity and influence. First, he emphasizes, the similarities must be relevant to the topic or issue. Commenting, &#x201C;Hey, I&#x2019;m a Libra, too!&#x201D; will probably get you nowhere unless the topic happens to center on astrology, horoscopes, and other similar topics. Second, O&#x2019;Keefe notes that the perceived similarities must involve positive, <target target-type="page" id="page_99">99</target>rather than negative, qualities. Stressing, &#x201C;I was arrested for shoplifting once, too&#x201D; may not enamor you to a new acquaintance, even though he or she may have confessed to a similar mistake.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>If you think you are perceived as having low credibility, try to increase receiver involvement and emphasize the central route to persuasion. Remember, receivers who are highly involved in a topic place less emphasis on source credibility and more emphasis on the substance of a message. If you suspect your target audience is skeptical of your credibility, explain how the topic or issue is directly relevant to them and then focus on the substance of the message. That will tend to encourage central processing on the part of your audience.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Have another source who is already perceived as highly credible introduce or endorse you. This is a common strategy used in election campaigns. Salespersons also use this strategy when they rely on referrals. The technique allows a source to piggyback on the established credibility of the person making the introduction or endorsement. Acquiring credibility via endorsements and introductions emphasizes the peripheral route to persuasion.</p></list-item>
</list>
</sec>
<sec id="sec4_11">
<title>Summary</title>
<p>As we&#x2019;ve seen, credibility is a complex construct. Yet there is one overriding generalization about credibility that persuaders can &#x201C;take to the bank&#x201D;: <italic>Credibility is a good thing to have if you are a persuader.</italic> As long as we keep in mind that credibility is a perceptual phenomenon, the generalization that high-credibility sources are more influential than low-credibility sources is as close as one can come to a universal &#x201C;law&#x201D; of persuasion.</p>
<p>In advancing this generalization, however, we believe it is important to underscore the point that credibility is a complex, multidimensional, situational communication phenomenon. Credibility can&#x2019;t be bought in a bottle or purchased out of a vending machine. In many persuasive settings, a source who has low or no initial credibility can do little or nothing about it. Low-credibility sources tend to be dismissed out of hand; receivers simply fail to attend to their messages. There is an old joke about how to become a multimillionaire: &#x201C;It&#x2019;s simple: First, get a million dollars, then &#x2026;&#x201D; Much the same advice can be offered for using credibility to enhance persuasion: &#x201C;It&#x2019;s simple: First, get a lot of credibility, then &#x2026;&#x201D;</p>
</sec>
</body>
<back>

<title>Notes</title>

</fn-group>

<ref id="ref4_74"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Watts</surname>, <given-names>W. <ref id="ref4_75"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Weir</surname>, <given-names>T.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2011</year>, <month>January</month> <day>17</day>). <article-title>Endorsers lose influence</article-title>. <source>USA Today</source>, p. <fpage>3C</fpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref4_76"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Wilson</surname>, <given-names>E. J.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Sherrell</surname>, <given-names>D. L.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>1993</year>). <article-title>Source effects in communication and persuasion research: A meta-analysis of effect size</article-title>. <source>Journal of the Academy of Marketing Science</source>, <volume>21</volume>, <fpage>101</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>112</lpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
</ref-list>
</back>
</book-part>
<book-part book-part-type="chapter" id="chapter5">
<book-part-meta>
<title-group>
<label>5</label>
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_104">104</target>Communicator Characteristics and Persuasion</title>
<alt-title alt-title-type="running-head">Communicator Characteristics</alt-title>
</title-group>
<contrib-group>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Gass</surname>
<given-names>Robert H.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Seiter</surname>
<given-names>John S.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
</contrib-group>
</book-part-meta>
<body>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_105">105</target>DO YOU HAVE A CELEBRITY CRUSH? Have you ever dreamt of Kerry Washington or Zac Efron? Spent hours on the Internet stalking Harry Styles or Jessica Alba? Retweeted or liked posts by Scarlett or Channing? Better yet, have you ever wondered whether your celebrity crush would like you back? Fortunately, for Spencer Morrill of Knoxville, Tennessee, the answer to that last question was &#x201C;no!&#x201D; Indeed, his celebrity crush&#x2014;the megastar pop singer, Katy Perry&#x2014;told him that she loved him &#x2026; or so he thought. Sadly, after &#x201C;dating&#x201D; Katy online for six years, after making her an engagement ring out of his great-grandmother&#x2019;s emerald, and after blowing 25 percent of his savings, Spencer learned that &#x201C;Katy&#x201D; was really a woman named Harriet from England. Spencer, it turns out, had been duped in what is commonly known as an online &#x201C;catfish scheme,&#x201D; in which the scammer pretends to be someone he or she is not. His ordeal was later featured on the MTV series <italic>Catfish</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_23">Delbyck, 2016</xref>).</p>
<p>If you&#x2019;re at all like us, you might be wondering how anyone could fall for such a hoax, especially for such a long period of time. But then again, when you consider all possible people, it&#x2019;s likely that someone would be gullible enough to fall for such a scheme.</p>
<p>However, although it seems that some people are more persuadable than others, the search for a single underlying trait or characteristic that makes people persuadable has not been successful. Persuasion is more complicated than that. And so are people. Even so, the characteristics of the people in a persuasive interaction cannot be ignored. All communicators are unique in terms of gender, age, personality, and background, and such characteristics are important to understanding the nature of social influence.</p>
<p>In this chapter, we explore the role communicator characteristics play in the process of persuasion. Although we don&#x2019;t have room to cover the immense number of characteristics that have been studied, we discuss several that past research has identified as being important to social influence. Then we discuss ways in which a communicator might analyze and adapt to an audience when trying to be persuasive. Before we begin, however, we note, as we have in earlier chapters, that persuasion is a two-way street. Thus, when we use the term <italic>communicator characteristics,</italic> we are not limiting our discussion to one person. The characteristics of all the interactants in a persuasive encounter are part of the equation.</p>
<sec id="sec5_1">
<title>Demographic Variables and Persuasion</title>
<p>If someone asked you to use 10 words to describe yourself, there is a good chance you would use demographic information to do so. Demographics include characteristics such as age, gender, ethnicity, and intelligence, which we discuss in the following sections.</p>
<sec id="sec5_1_1">
<title>Age and Persuasion: Pretty Please With Sugar on Top</title>
<p>The expression &#x201C;It&#x2019;s like taking candy from a baby&#x201D; suggests that children are easy targets for persuasion, and research indicates that this is generally true: Children tend to be especially vulnerable to persuasive trickery because they lack the ability to understand the nature and intent of persuaders (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_65">McAlister &#x0026; Cornwell, 2009</xref>). <target target-type="page" id="page_106">106</target>The implications of such research can be frightening. Indeed, we&#x2019;ve all heard stories of children who have been tricked or lured away by criminals (for more on this issue, see <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box5_1">Box 5.1</xref>).</p>
<p>What we may be less aware of, however, are other types of messages that may be persuading our children, or, for that matter, our fetuses! As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_57">Lindstrom (2011</xref>, p. 15) noted, because strong tastes and aromas (such as garlic and vanilla) pass through a mother&#x2019;s amniotic fluid and are actually &#x201C;tasted&#x201D; by a fetus, even unborn kids may be influenced to develop tastes inside the womb. He reported, for example, that Kopiko, a candy brand in the Philippines, supplied doctors with coffee-flavored candies to give away to pregnant mothers. Some time later, Kopiko introduced a new product&#x2014;coffee&#x2014;which was phenomenally successful, particularly among children in the Philippines.</p>
<p>Once outside the womb, it doesn&#x2019;t take long before kids are bombarded by the world of advertising. According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_57">Lindstrom (2011)</xref>, for example, by three months, 40 percent of all infants watch screen media regularly, and by two years, 90 percent of all children do. What&#x2019;s more, in the United States, typical kids are exposed to 40,000 commercials a year (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_53">Kunkel, Wilcox, Cantor, Palmer, Linn, &#x0026; Dowrick, 2004</xref>). These numbers become especially meaningful when you understand that advertisers do not always have children&#x2019;s best interests in mind. According to Lindstrom&#x2019;s sources (2011, p. 22), for instance, the clothing retailer Abercrombie <target target-type="page" id="page_107">107</target>&#x0026; Fitch marketed padded bikini tops to girls as young as eight, and Tesco, a retailer in the UK, released the &#x201C;Peekaboo Pole Dancing Kit,&#x201D; marketed to females under 10, as something to help them &#x201C;unleash the sex kitten inside.&#x201D;</p>
<boxed-text id="box5_1">
<label>Box 5.1</label>
<caption><title>&#x201C;Never Take Candy From Strangers&#x201D;</title></caption>
<disp-quote>
<p>I was certain it could never happen. After all, I&#x2019;m a very street-savvy, New York City parent. I write articles advising moms and dads on child safety. Needless to say, I&#x2019;ve been so conscientious in teaching my own children that my husband insists I&#x2019;m paranoid, and my daughter has more than once rolled her eyes heavenward at my often repeated warnings. Which is why I can hardly describe the sick feeling in my stomach as I watched my redheaded little boy and his friend Tahlor march right out of the park one spring afternoon with a total stranger.</p>
