<attrib>(<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_88">Rosen, 1994</xref>, p. 108)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
<p>Fortunately for Margery Rosen, this scene was only part of an informal experiment. To test how well she had trained her children, she had gotten Kenneth Wooden, an expert on the ways in which sex offenders lure children, to see if he could persuade her children to leave the playground with him. He didn&#x2019;t have much trouble. He told the boys he had lost a puppy and would give them money if they would help him find it. They went right with him, and so did several other children involved in the experiment (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_88">Rosen, 1994</xref>).</p>
<p>Many children aren&#x2019;t as fortunate as those involved in Rosen&#x2019;s experiment. Indeed, it&#x2019;s been estimated that one in four girls and one in six boys are sexually abused by age 18 (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_115">Wooden, 2014</xref>). Clearly, children are especially susceptible to persuasion, and sometimes the results are tragic. For that reason, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_113">Kenneth Wooden (1988)</xref> argued, &#x201C;Teaching your kids about the tricks that molesters use could save them from grievous harm&#x2014;even death&#x201D; (p. 149).</p>
<p>In an effort to prevent children from being molested, Wooden interviewed convicted molesters, pimps, and murderers and discovered several lures that are commonly used on children. Of the lures he said, &#x201C;Knowledge of them is so basic to a child&#x2019;s safety that they should be taught&#x2014;indeed must be <target target-type="page" id="page_108">108</target>taught&#x2014;by every parent&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_113">Wooden, 1988</xref>, p. 149). With this in mind, if you know, are, or plan to be a parent, here is an abbreviated list of lures and prevention strategies that <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_114">Wooden (1995</xref>; see also <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_25">Dickinson, 2002</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_88">Rosen, 1994</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_113">Wooden, 1988</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_116">Wooden, Webb, &#x0026; Mitchell, 2014</xref>) identified:
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p>The assistance lure. The lost puppy example described previously is an example of this lure. In it, the pedophile asks kids for directions, for help carrying packages, or for some other type of assistance. Children should be advised to keep their distance from strangers in cars. Children should tell the assistance seeker to ask another adult for help.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The authority and hero lures. Some molesters lure children by posing as police officers, Santa Claus, or other figures that children trust. Children should be taught that bad people can play tricks on children and that real heroes won&#x2019;t do certain things.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The affection/love lure. Some pedophiles lure children by promising them love and affection. Parents should know that 75 to 80 percent of sex crimes are committed by someone a child knows and trusts. Children should beware of anyone who wants excessive time alone with them and be encouraged to tell their parents about improper advances. Parents should trust their instincts.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The bribery lure. Children are often offered gifts from molesters. Parents should be suspicious of any new toys their children have. The age-old saying &#x201C;Never take candy from strangers&#x201D; is still true today.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The ego/fame lure. Youngsters are sometimes lured by modeling jobs or beauty contests that should be kept secret from mom and dad. For that reason, parents should accompany kids to such events, encourage openness, and check the credentials of &#x201C;would-be&#x201D; modeling agencies.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The emergency lure. Molesters might trick children by claiming &#x201C;a house is on fire&#x201D; or &#x201C;mommy had to go to the hospital.&#x201D; To prevent falling for this, parents and children should prearrange an emergency plan. Under no circumstance should a child ride with a stranger.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The fun and games lure. Molesters sometimes turn tickling, wrestling, and other games into intimate contact. Children need to be taught that there are good and bad touches. Bad touches (e.g., anywhere under a bathing suit) should be reported.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The pornography lure. Pedophiles have been known to use pornography to destroy their victims&#x2019; inhibitions. Wooden, therefore, advises parents to keep pornography out of the home so it does not seem legitimate.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The jobs lure. Molesters sometimes lure children by promising high-paying jobs. When suspicious, parents should accompany children to interviews, especially if the interview is in a secluded or unusual place, and ask to see a business license.</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
<p>Finally, parents and children need to be aware that the Internet has become a vehicle for strangers who prey on children. Parents should watch for warning signs, including pornography on a child&#x2019;s computer (often sent by sexual predators to desensitize victims) and telephone calls or mail from strangers (&#x201C;Beware &#x2019;Net predators,&#x201D; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_7">2001</xref>).</p>
<p>Although some psychologists have argued that teaching children about a potential molester only serves to terrify them and prevent the formation of friendships (for a discussion, see Teaching fear, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_106">1986</xref>), <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_88">Rosen (1994</xref>, 2014) and others have argued that teaching children to be cautious about potential molesters is little different from vaccinating them against a disease or teaching them to be safe around stoves or electrical sockets. Education should start at a young age, with the goal of making children cautious, not paranoid. As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_113">Wooden (1988)</xref> noted, children should be taught that most people are good and won&#x2019;t hurt them but should also realize that some people are bad and sick.</p>
</boxed-text>
<p>Unfortunately, until age eight, children do not understand the persuasive nature of advertising. Instead, kids think that ads are just there to inform them (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_74">Oates, Blades, &#x0026; Gunter, 2002</xref>). Worse yet, children may have an especially difficult time understanding the persuasive intent behind &#x201C;gamification,&#x201D; which promotes brands through fun and interactive online games (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_107">Vanwesenbeeck, Walrave, &#x0026; Ponnet, 2016</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_78">Panic, Cauberghe, &#x0026; De Palsmacker, 2013</xref>). Fortunately, however, at least two variables seem to decrease children&#x2019;s vulnerability to advertising: adult influence and getting older. First, research shows that if you interact with children during ads, you can increase their ability to critically examine the ads and provide them with a better understanding of the nature and purpose of advertising. One study, for example, found that when adults made factual (e.g., &#x201C;Those ads aren&#x2019;t telling the truth. Those toys look different in real life.&#x201D;) or evaluative (&#x201C;These ads are dumb. These toys aren&#x2019;t fun.&#x201D;) comments during advertisements, children were less persuaded by the ads (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_12">Buijzen, 2007</xref>). Second, as children become older, they become less susceptible to distorted claims (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_69">Mills &#x0026; Elashi, 2014</xref>). Notice, however, we say <italic>less</italic> susceptible, not immune. For example, Morgenstern, Isensee, Sargent, and Harwinkel (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_70">2011</xref>) found that teenagers who were exposed to a greater number of alcohol advertisements consumed larger amounts of alcohol.</p>
<p>So far, we&#x2019;ve made it clear that young people tend to be highly susceptible to persuasion. But what about older people? Although earlier studies indicated that elderly people may be more &#x201C;set in their ways,&#x201D; and, thus, less persuadable than younger folks, a newer generation of research supports the <italic>life-stages hypothesis</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_92">Sears, 1981</xref>), which suggests that there is a curvilinear relationship between age and persuadability (for a review, see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_27">Eaton, Visser, Krosnick, &#x0026; Anand, 2009</xref>). In other words, compared to youthful and elderly people, middle-aged people are less persuadable. Consistent with this hypothesis, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_56">Liao and Fu (2014)</xref> found that, compared to younger adults (19&#x2013;26), older adults (58&#x2013;80) were less skilled at judging the credibility of online health information. This is troubling, of course, considering that older people are frequent users of health information, even though the content of health-related websites is often rated as unsatisfactory (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_56">Liao &#x0026; Fu, 2014</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec5_1_2">
<title>Gender Differences and Persuasion: The Times, They Aren&#x2019;t a-Changin&#x2019;</title>
<p>Do men and women differ in their ability to influence others? Before you answer, we should warn you: This is a trick question. Although the lion&#x2019;s share of research reveals that men are more successful than women in their attempts to persuade others (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_14">Carli, 2004</xref>), their success has little to do with ability but rather a double-standard in audiences&#x2019; perceptions. This conclusion is supported by the work of <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_14">Carli (2004)</xref>, who demonstrated that gender stereotypes cause audiences to perceive males as more competent than females and to expect females to be warmer and more nurturing than males. As a result, women experience a double bind: They must perform better than men to be considered equally competent, and they are perceived negatively when they try to be direct, assertive, and forceful. In one study, for instance, when females adopted aggressive communication behaviors in debates, they were judged more <target target-type="page" id="page_109">109</target>harshly than males who adopted the same behaviors (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_63">Matthews, 2016</xref>). Similarly, a meta-analysis found that women were less persuasive when they used aggressive and assertive tactics than when they used more role-consistent, communal tactics (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_101">Smith, Watkins, Burke, Christian, Smith, Hall, &#x0026; Simms, 2013</xref>).</p>
<p>Consistent with this finding is Klingle&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_49">2004</xref>) <italic>reinforcement expectancy theory,</italic> which applies to persuasive encounters between doctors and patients. According to the theory, once a doctor has tried to persuade a patient to do something (e.g., take medication), the patient judges the appropriateness of the doctor&#x2019;s message. If the message is viewed as inappropriate, the patient rejects it. If it is viewed as appropriate, it guides the patient&#x2019;s future behavior. How does this relate to gender? According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_49">Klingle (2004)</xref>, because of certain norms, female doctors can&#x2019;t get away with using aversive strategies the same way that male doctors can. When female doctors use such strategies, they violate patients&#x2019; expectations about what is appropriate, and, as a result, patients are less likely to comply. According to the theory, then, male doctors can increase compliance by using either positive (e.g., &#x201C;Regular eating will make you feel so much better&#x201D;) or negative (&#x201C;You have two choices&#x2014;change your diet or spend the rest of your life wishing you had&#x201D;) influence strategies, but female doctors can increase compliance by using only positive strategies (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_49">Klingle, 2004</xref>).</p>
<p>In addition to having double standards about the use of various persuasive strategies, people also hold stereotypes about who seems better suited for selling certain products. In one study (Rodero, Larrea, &#x0026; V&#x00E1;zquez, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_86">2013</xref>), for example, people listened to various radio advertisements that featured male or female voices. Results indicated that people perceived the male voice as more appropriate for selling mechanical products and the female voice as more appropriate for selling body-hair removal products. No differences were observed for neutral products.</p>
<p>Up to this point, we&#x2019;ve seen that men and women differ regarding how successful they are when trying to persuade other people. But how do men and women compare when it comes to being persuaded? Early research suggested that women were more easily persuaded than men (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_15">Chaiken, 1979</xref>). Later, however, researchers who examined and summarized large numbers of studies on the topic questioned the notion of whether women were any different from men when it came to being persuaded (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_26">Eagly, 1978</xref>). As a result, many researchers abandoned the idea of general gender effects and instead tried to explain <italic>when</italic> gender differences could be expected. For instance, in Eagly&#x2019;s 1978 study, 32 percent of the studies published before 1970 (generally regarded as the onset of the women&#x2019;s movement) found that women were more easily influenced than men, but only 8 percent of the studies published after 1970 found the same result. Thus, evaporating gender differences might be the result of changing times and the attitudes of and toward women. However, considering the research we have discussed on how gender stereotypes affect males&#x2019; versus females&#x2019; ability to persuade, we doubt that this explanation is correct.</p>
<p>Even so, there is another possible explanation for the change in research findings before and after 1970. Specifically, earlier studies used male rather than female sources (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_109">Ward, Seccombe, Bendel, &#x0026; Carter, 1985</xref>), which means that male receivers were being persuaded by members of the same sex, whereas females were being persuaded by members of the opposite sex&#x2014;that is, in the earlier studies, there may have been a <italic>cross-sex effect</italic>, by which people were more easily influenced by members <target target-type="page" id="page_110">110</target>of the opposite sex than by members of the same sex. This effect, however, may be stronger for males persuading females than for females persuading males (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_109">Ward et al., 1985</xref>).</p>
<p>From our review so far, it is clear that generalizations about gender and persuasion are hard to come by. As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_17">Cody, Seiter, and Montagne-Miller (1995)</xref> argue, &#x201C;There is no simple model that links &#x2018;gender&#x2019; or &#x2018;sex&#x2019; to influenceability&#x201D; (p. 312). Instead, these researchers argue that persuadability is not so much related to one&#x2019;s gender as it is to one&#x2019;s goals, plans, resources, and beliefs (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_17">Cody et al., 1995</xref>). For instance, imagine that you are in a shopping mall, looking at clothing. If you don&#x2019;t intend to buy anything (goal), have decided you will look now and buy later (plan), have very little money (resources), and think that all salespersons are dishonest (beliefs), you will probably be more difficult to influence than if you intend to buy now, have lots of money, and believe salespersons are honest. In other words, it may not matter so much whether you are male or female; how easy you are to influence depends on your goals, plans, resources, and beliefs. Gender matters only to the extent that males and females have different goals, plans, resources, and beliefs. For instance, Cody and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_17">1995</xref>) found that when shopping for clothes, men and women tend to have different goals and that such goal differences were related to influenceability and the effectiveness of certain sales tactics. Likewise, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_77">Orji, Mandryk, &#x0026; Vassileva (2015)</xref> found that males and females differed in their responsiveness to different persuasive strategies.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec5_1_3">
<title>Ethnicity, Culture, and Persuasion: &#x201C;Me&#x201D; and &#x201C;We&#x201D; Perspectives</title>
<p>Cultural differences play a major role, both in terms of how people fashion influence attempts and how they respond to them. Perhaps the most commonly discussed dimension of cultural variability is known as <italic>individualism&#x2013;collectivism</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_39">Hofstede, 1983</xref>). Whereas people in collectivist cultures (e.g., China) tend to value harmony, concern for others, and the goals of the group over the goals of the individual, people in individualistic cultures (e.g., the United States) tend to value independence and the goals of the individual over the goals of a collective.</p>
<p>With that in mind, consider the following list of slogans (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_36">Han &#x0026; Shavitt, 1994</xref>, p. 346) and imagine which you would use to appeal to people in a collectivistic culture and which you would use to appeal to people in an individualistic culture:
<verse-group>
<verse-line>&#x201C;The art of being unique.&#x201D;</verse-line>
<verse-line>&#x201C;She&#x2019;s got a style all her own.&#x201D;</verse-line>
<verse-line>&#x201C;We have a way of bringing people closer together.&#x201D;</verse-line>
<verse-line>&#x201C;The dream of prosperity for all of us.&#x201D;</verse-line>
</verse-group>
</p>
<p>A study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_36">Han and Shavitt (1994)</xref> found that advertisements, such as the first and second in the previous list, that appealed to individual benefits, personal success, and independence were used more in the United States (an individualistic culture) than in Korea (a collectivistic culture) and were more persuasive in the United States than in Korea. Ads, such as the third and fourth, that appealed to group benefits, harmony, and family were used more often and were more persuasive in Korea than in the United States.</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_111">111</target>Also consistent with the notion that people from collectivistic cultures focus on groups and relationships, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_31">Fu and Yukl (2000)</xref> found that Chinese managers rated &#x201C;emphasizing coalitions&#x201D; and &#x201C;gift-giving&#x201D; among the most effective influence tactics, whereas managers from the United States preferred rational persuasion. Similarly, a study by Wiseman and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_112">2009</xref>) found differences between the persuasive strategies used by people from the United States, China, and Japan. For example, when trying to persuade roommates to be more quiet, people from the United States, who tend to be more individualistic and less concerned with saving face, preferred more direct strategies (e.g., &#x201C;You are making too much noise. Please be quiet&#x201D;) and strategies with individually controlled sanctions (&#x201C;If you don&#x2019;t quiet down, I&#x2019;ll be as noisy as possible when you are trying to study&#x201D;). People from China, who tend to be more collectivistic, preferred indirect strategies (e.g., commenting on how they like quiet moments) and strategies with group-controlled sanctions (e.g., &#x201C;Your noisiness shows a lack of consideration for others&#x201D;). However, people from Japan hinted less than people from both the United States and China, leading Wiseman and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_112">2009</xref>) to conclude that collectivism and individualism may not be opposite orientations. In fact, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_2">Agrawal (2015)</xref> suggested that people from individualistic cultures can sometimes be primed to behave in collectivistic ways and vice versa. For example, someone from an individualistic culture might be asked to think about family obligations (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_2">Agrawal, 2015</xref>). As such, sometimes culturally incongruent messages can be persuasive.</p>
<p>Finally, with regard to individualism&#x2013;collectivism, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_77">Orji (2015)</xref> identified several additional cultural differences. Specifically, people from collectivistic cultures perceived appeals to authority (e.g., expertise), consensus (e.g., others are doing it, so you should too), liking, and reciprocity (e.g., you are obligated to give back) as more persuasive than did people from individualistic cultures.</p>
<p>Although individualism and collectivism are important values affecting cross-cultural differences in persuasion, they are not the only ones. For example, after conducting interviews with people from the People&#x2019;s Republic of China and Taiwan, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_59">Ma and Chuang (2001)</xref> identified three influence tactics reflecting additional values of importance. First, <italic>anshi,</italic> or &#x201C;hinting&#x201D; (e.g., telling a friend who loaned you money that you&#x2019;d like to buy something if you weren&#x2019;t broke), compared to more direct strategies (e.g., demanding the money a friend borrowed), not only preserves harmony in a relationship, it is more respectful and seeks to save another person&#x2019;s face. Second, <italic>yi shen zuo ze,</italic> or &#x201C;setting an example by one&#x2019;s own action&#x201D; (e.g., a manager works exceptionally hard hoping her subordinates will do likewise), reflects the Chinese culture&#x2019;s mistrust of words. Third, <italic>tou qi suo hao,</italic> or &#x201C;feeding people what they relish&#x201D; (e.g., agreeing to do something another person loves before asking a favor), reflects a preference for indirectness, other-orientedness, and granting people &#x201C;face&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_59">Ma &#x0026; Chuang, 2001</xref>).</p>
<p>Similarly, a study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_30">Fitch (1994)</xref> found that distinctive cultural systems of beliefs, values, and symbols underlie differences in the influence messages used by people in the United States and Colombia. A recurring theme in the influence strategies used in the United States was &#x201C;empowerment.&#x201D; For instance, a manager observed in Fitch&#x2019;s study argued:
<disp-quote>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_112">112</target>A stumbling block to empowerment is the low self-esteem of people who have been told what to do. If we want them to make their own decisions, we have to build up their self-esteem. And that starts with asking, not telling people what to do.</p>
<attrib>(p. 194)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>In contrast, Colombians&#x2019; influence attempts centered on the concept of <italic>confianza</italic> (having trust or closeness in a relationship). For example, Colombians commonly ask intermediaries who have closer relationships with persuadees to deliver influence messages for them (e.g., &#x201C;You know Dioselina better than I do. Will you ask her to put up the signs?&#x201D;).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec5_1_4">
<title>Intelligence and Persuasion: Dumb and Dumber</title>
<p>Imagine you were offered a million dollars to persuade either Forrest Gump (if you haven&#x2019;t seen the movie, Forrest isn&#x2019;t known for his brains) or Albert Einstein to believe or do something. Who would you choose? Earlier work (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_67">McGuire, 1968</xref>) suggested that neither Forrest nor Albert&#x2014;but rather someone with moderate intelligence&#x2014;should be chosen. The idea was that Forrest would be difficult to persuade because he would be unable to comprehend a message, while Albert would be difficult because he would be better at scrutinizing a message. Later work, however, indicated that Forrest should be your choice. Indeed, a review of research by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_85">Rhodes and Wood (1992)</xref> indicated that less intelligent people are easier to persuade than people with a lot of smarts. Even so, we imagine that other variables may be important too. More intelligent people may be in a better position to process complex messages. Recall that when central processing is required, the ability to process a message is important. Less intelligent people may be more receptive to simpler messages or messages that encourage peripheral processing.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec5_2">
<title>Psychological and Communication States and Traits</title>
<p>Two common explanations for why people differ from one another centers on the notion of traits and states. A <italic>trait</italic> is a characteristic of a person presumed to be relatively stable across situations. A <italic>state</italic> varies from situation to situation. For instance, if we conceptualize anxiety as a trait, we would predict that a person possessing the trait would be anxious in practically all situations. On the other hand, if we conceptualize anxiety as a state, we would predict that there are certain situations in which a person becomes anxious. For instance, some people become very anxious when talking with authorities or when meeting members of the opposite sex. With these definitions in mind, we now turn to a discussion of some specific traits and states that have been the focus of research in the area of persuasion.</p>
<sec id="sec5_2_1">
<title>Self-Esteem and Persuasion: Feelin&#x2019; Kinda Low</title>
<p>Are individuals with low self-esteem more susceptible to influence attempts than individuals with high self-esteem? Although this notion seems reasonable, it is not supported by research (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_85">Rhodes &#x0026; Wood, 1992</xref>). This is because to be persuaded, a person must both receive and yield to a message. People with low self-esteem may be more likely to yield to a message because they lack confidence in themselves and their <target target-type="page" id="page_113">113</target>opinions. However, they may also be too concerned about their appearance and behavior to be receptive to a persuasive message. On the other hand, people with high self-esteem may be more receptive to persuasive messages. However, because they are more confident in themselves and their own opinions, they may be less likely to yield. Thus, research indicates that people with moderately high self-esteem are easier to persuade than people with either high or low self-esteem (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_85">Rhodes &#x0026; Wood, 1992</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec5_2_2">
<title>Anxiety and Persuasion: Living in Fear</title>
<p>Unless you&#x2019;ve grown up in a closet, you&#x2019;ve undoubtedly been exposed to messages about the dangers of global warming, secondhand cigarette smoke, gang violence, and so forth. How do you react to such messages? Do they make you overly nervous or tense? If so, you may be chronically anxious. Research suggests that anxiety, whether chronic or acute, may be related to persuadability, although the relationship is not clear. For instance, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_73">Nunnally and Bobren (1959)</xref> found that anxious people were more persuadable than nonanxious people, whereas <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_44">Janis and Feshbach (1965)</xref> found just the opposite. Moreover, research by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_55">Lehmann (1970)</xref> indicated that anxiety is related to persuasion as much as self-esteem is. Specifically, anxious people, compared to the nonanxious, may be more likely to yield to a message. However, because they may be distracted or overly worried, they may be less likely to receive a message. On the other hand, nonanxious people, compared to the anxious, may be more likely to receive a message but less inclined to do something about it (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_55">Lehmann, 1970</xref>). Finally, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_72">Nai, Schemeil, and Marie (2016)</xref> found that anxiety increases people&#x2019;s motivation to be accurate. As such, anxious folks, compared to calm ones, are more open to messages that challenge their opinions, and, as a result, are more persuadable.</p>
<p>Whatever the relationship between anxiety and persuasion, one thing is clear: When trying to persuade anxious people, be sure to include specific recommendations for avoiding the harms, along with reassurances that if they follow the recommendations, everything will be okay. As you&#x2019;ll see in more detail in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter13">Chapter 13</xref>, without such reassurances, people who are anxious may not respond well to fear appeals.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec5_2_3">
<title>Preference for Consistency: I Wouldn&#x2019;t Change a Thing</title>
<p>In <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter3">Chapter 3</xref>, we stated that people are generally motivated to be consistent with their attitudes and behavior. As with most things, however, there are exceptions to this statement. It turns out that individuals differ in their <italic>preference for consistency</italic> (PFC). While &#x201C;high PFCs&#x201D; value and strive to be consistent, &#x201C;low PFCs&#x201D; have a preference for change, spontaneity, and unpredictability (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_33">Guadagno &#x0026; Cialdini, 2010</xref>). As such, several studies indicate that high PFCs are more susceptible to the effects of cognitive dissonance. For example, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_94">S&#x00E9;n&#x00E9;meaud, Mange, Fointiat, and Somat (2014)</xref> induced a group of French students to feel hypocritical, which, presumably, would cause dissonance. Specifically, after listing the dangers of excessive alcohol consumption, the students were asked to consider previous situations in which they had consumed too much alcohol. Not surprisingly, compared to students who had not undergone this procedure, the &#x201C;hypocritical&#x201D; students were more willing to spend time helping young adults avoid alcohol abuse. This was especially true for high PFCs who had been made aware of their desire for consistency (S&#x00E9;n&#x00E9;meaud et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_90">2014</xref>) (for more on PFC, see <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter10">Chapter 10</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec5_2_4">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_114">114</target>Self-Monitoring and Persuasion: Periscope Up</title>
<p>In high school, a sister of one of the authors dated a guy who was a maniac on the dance floor. Out of context, you&#x2019;d never have guessed he was dancing. He used to stomp his feet and flap his hands wildly and out of rhythm. Some said he looked badly wounded. Others simply stared. But whatever went on around him, he seemed oblivious, not caring what others thought of him.</p>
<p>The account you&#x2019;ve just read is related to a personality trait called <italic>self-monitoring</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_102">Snyder, 1974</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_103">1979</xref>). The wild dancer in the story is what people who study personality would call a <italic>low self-monitor.</italic> If you are a low self-monitor, you tend to be less sensitive than others to social cues. In addition, you are not that concerned about what others think of your behavior. You are individualistic and may not always act in ways that are considered socially appropriate. You honestly express your thoughts and feelings, even though you may not be conforming to other people&#x2019;s expectations.</p>
<p>However, if you are a <italic>high self-monitor</italic>, you tend to be very sensitive to social cues. You pay close attention to what&#x2019;s considered appropriate in a given situation and act accordingly. You watch other people&#x2019;s behavior and are good at adapting to different audiences because you have a large repertoire of social skills. You are concerned with appearances and try to &#x201C;fit in&#x201D; with others, even when such behavior may contradict what you believe.</p>
<p>As you might expect, high and low self-monitors are persuaded differently. For instance, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_110">White and Gerstein (1987)</xref> conducted a study to investigate how high and low self-monitors might be persuaded to offer help to people with disabilities. Because they knew that high self-monitors want to &#x201C;look good,&#x201D; these researchers suspected that high self-monitors could be persuaded to help if they thought a social reward would result. To test this, high and low self-monitors heard lectures about Kitty Genovese, a woman who was murdered in New York City while many people watched but did not help. In one version of the lecture, subjects learned that people who help receive social rewards. In another version, subjects were told that helping others usually does not result in social rewards. Later, the subjects were phoned and asked to volunteer to help people who were visually impaired. Of those who&#x2019;d been told that helping results in social rewards, 80 percent of the high self-monitors volunteered, but only 48 percent of the low self-monitors did. When subjects did not expect social rewards, 68 percent of the low self-monitors volunteered, and only 40 percent of the high self-monitors did. In other words, high self-monitors are influenced by situations that yield social benefits or enhance their images. Low self-monitors are more internally motivated and less susceptible to external rewards.</p>
<p>Similarly, several studies in advertising suggest that high self-monitors are more influenced by &#x201C;image-based&#x201D; advertising. In contrast, low self-monitors are more interested in &#x201C;product-quality&#x201D; advertising. For example, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_104">Snyder and DeBono (1989)</xref> found that high self-monitors were willing to pay more money for a product that promised to improve their image (e.g., an ad shows a bottle of Canadian Club resting on a set of house blueprints and reads, &#x201C;You&#x2019;re not just moving in, you&#x2019;re moving up&#x201D;), whereas low self-monitors would pay more for a product that suggests high quality (e.g., an ad for Canadian Club that reads, &#x201C;When it comes to great taste, everyone draws the same conclusion&#x201D;). Moreover, high self-monitors reported liking <target target-type="page" id="page_115">115</target>cheese more when they believed it was from France (an image-enhancing country) than from Kansas (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_21">DeBono &#x0026; Rubin, 1995</xref>), liking perfume more when it was in an attractive rather than an unattractive bottle (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_22">DeBono, Leavitt, &#x0026; Backus, 2003</xref>), preferring an energy drink when it was labeled &#x201C;Fast Track&#x201D; rather than &#x201C;Energy Drink Enhancer&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_100">Smidt &#x0026; DeBono, 2011</xref>), and preferring champagne that was endorsed by four people rather than one person (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_71">Myers &#x0026; Sar, 2013</xref>). In contrast, low self-monitors based their judgments on the actual taste of the cheese and smell of the perfume, and preferred the label &#x201C;Energy Drink Enhancer.&#x201D; Finally, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_29">Evans and Clark (2012)</xref> found that low self-monitors were more confident in their thoughts about a persuasive appeal when the source of the appeal was described as being an expert (e.g., a doctor and researcher), while high self-monitors were more confident when the source was described as having an attractive image (e.g., an honor student, active in student government).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec5_2_5">
<title>Ego Involvement: Not Budging an Inch</title>
<p>One of the most important explanations of the process by which people are persuaded, presented by Muzafer Sherif, Carolyn Sherif, and Robert Nebergall (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_96">Sherif &#x0026; Sherif, 1967</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_97">Sherif, Sherif, &#x0026; Nebergall, 1965</xref>), is known as <italic>social judgment theory.</italic> We present the theory here because it focuses on receivers and is particularly relevant to a psychological characteristic known as <italic>ego involvement.</italic></p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 5.1</label>
<caption><title>High self-monitors: Daffodil Queen contestants eavesdropping on contestant interviews.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig5_1.jpg"/>
<p>Source: Reprinted by permission of Steven G. Smith.</p>
</fig>
<p>According to the theory, on any topic, whether it be abortion, an advertised product, or a favorite movie, there are a range of possible opinions that a person can hold. For example, one topic is what should be done with people who have been found guilty of first-degree murder. Here are several positions, some extreme, some moderate, which you might embrace on this topic. Murderers should:
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p><target target-type="page" id="page_116">116</target>Be pardoned if they have performed other good deeds during their lives.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Be allowed to pay &#x201C;blood money&#x201D; to the victim&#x2019;s family to avoid prison.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Receive a 5-year prison term.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Receive a 20-year prison term.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Receive a life sentence with a chance for parole.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Receive a life sentence with no chance for parole.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Be put to death.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Be tortured to death, along with all other violent criminals.</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
<sec id="sec5_2_5_1">
<title>Persuasion by Degrees</title>
<p><italic>Social judgment theory</italic> argues that on this continuum of positions, we each have a most preferred position, called an <italic>anchor.</italic> For instance, imagine that two people, Muffy and Mort, both agree most with position 6, that murderers should spend their lives in prison with no chance for parole. In <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig5_2">Figure 5.2</xref>, this anchor point is represented by an &#x201C;X.&#x201D; Of course, the anchor position is not the only position a person might find acceptable. You can see in <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig5_2">Figure 5.2</xref>, for example, that Muffy also would accept the death penalty as a fitting punishment. Together, with Muffy&#x2019;s anchor, these positions represent Muffy&#x2019;s <italic>latitude of acceptance.</italic> In other words, these are positions she finds tolerable. She would not, however, agree with all positions, for in addition to the latitude of acceptance, social judgment theory describes two other latitudes. The first, called the <italic>latitude of noncommitment,</italic> contains positions about <target target-type="page" id="page_117">117</target>which a person feels neutral or ambivalent. Muffy is neither for nor against murderers receiving life sentences with the possibility of parole; she is neutral. The second, called the <italic>latitude of rejection,</italic> contains positions that a person would reject. For example, Muffy rejects the idea that murderers be pardoned for good deeds, be allowed to pay blood money, spend 5 to 20 years in prison, or be tortured to death.</p>
<fig id="fig5_2" position="float">
<label>Figure 5.2</label>
<caption><title>Illustration of social judgment theory.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig5_2.tif"/>
</fig>
</sec>
<sec id="sec5_2_5_2">
<title>Changes in Attitude, Changes in Latitude</title>
<p>Notice in <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig5_2">Figure 5.2</xref> that the span of these latitudes is different for different people. Compared to Mort, Muffy has a larger latitude of rejection and narrower latitudes of noncommitment and acceptance. For this reason, Muffy is a good example of an ego-involved person. People are ego involved when an issue has personal significance to them and their sense of self. Thus, they become strongly committed to their stand on the issue and are more likely to reject other positions. A person might also be ego involved about one issue and not another. For instance, Muffy might have strong feelings about what happens to murderers, but care less about abortion, gun control, or gasoline prices.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec5_2_5_3">
<title>Assimilation&#x2013;Contrast Phenomenon: The Great Divide</title>
<p>Social judgment theory makes several important predictions about the process of persuasion. First, because people judge everything according to their anchor position, it is difficult, if not impossible, to persuade them to accept a position too far away from that anchor. For instance, if you tried to convince Mort that murderers should be pardoned for performing good deeds, you&#x2019;d be wasting your time (see <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig5_2">Figure 5.2</xref>); messages falling inside a person&#x2019;s latitude of rejection are bound to fail. In fact, the theory argues that when a message falls too far away from a person&#x2019;s anchor position, the person perceives the message to be farther away from the anchor than it really is. This is known as the <italic>contrast effect.</italic> However, the <italic>assimilation effect</italic> occurs when a message that falls within a person&#x2019;s latitude of acceptance is perceived to be closer to the anchor position than it really is. For example, although Mort would prefer that murderers be severely punished, if you told Mort that murderers should be moderately punished, he might decide that you basically agree and accept your position. Thus, whereas contrast leads to the rejection of a message, assimilation leads to successful persuasion.</p>
<p>You might have guessed by now that the contrast effect is more likely in ego-involved people than in people who are not ego involved. Indeed, it&#x2019;s difficult to persuade someone who is ego involved (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_98">Sherif, Kelly, Rodgers, Sarup, &#x0026; Tittler, 1973</xref>). Because their latitude of rejection is so large (and their latitude of acceptance is so narrow), obviously, they will reject most persuasive messages.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec5_2_5_4">
<title>Baby Steps: Nudging Someone Along</title>
<p>One of the things we like best about <italic>social judgment theory</italic> is how it suggests that persuasion is not a &#x201C;one-shot deal.&#x201D; We think the theory does a good job of illustrating that persuasion may have to occur over time. For example, imagine trying to persuade Muffy that murderers should merely be pardoned for good deeds (see <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig5_2">Figure 5.2</xref>). We&#x2019;ve already seen that trying to convince her of that will lead to rejection. But aiming messages nearer the anchor point might meet with more success. You might try to persuade Muffy that life in prison with a chance for parole is a good <target target-type="page" id="page_118">118</target>position. Then, if she agrees to that, later you could try to convince her that 20 years in prison is justified; some murderers do repent and reform. Get the idea? Anchor positions need to be moved gradually.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec5_2_6">
<title>Issue Involvement: What&#x2019;s This Have to Do With Me?</title>
<p>Although we just stated that involvement inhibits persuasion, in reality, things are more complicated than that. Indeed, the effect of involvement on persuasion depends on the type of involvement we&#x2019;re considering. Specifically, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_45">Johnson and Eagly (1990)</xref> argued that two types of involvement are ego involvement (a.k.a. v<italic>alue-relevant involvement</italic>), which is linked to enduring values embedded in a person&#x2019;s self-concept, and <italic>outcome-relevant involvement</italic> (a.k.a. <italic>issue involvement</italic>), which has to do with a person&#x2019;s current goals or outcomes (e.g., a cancer patient with the goal of using marijuana to minimize physical pain). Based on this notion, Johnson and Eagly analyzed a large number of studies and found that, consistent with social judgment theory, value-relevant involvement inhibited persuasion. Meanwhile, consistent with the <italic>elaboration likelihood model</italic> (see <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter2">Chapter 2</xref>), issue involvement caused people to pay closer attention to arguments in persuasive messages. Issue involvement facilitated persuasion when arguments were strong but inhibited persuasion when arguments were weak (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_45">Johnson &#x0026; Eagly, 1990</xref>). Another study found that when listening to messages promoting health, involved people were more persuaded by informational messages, while noninvolved people were more persuaded by testimonials (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_10">Braverman, 2008</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec5_2_7">
<title>Dogmatism, Authoritarianism, and Social Vigilantism: You Can&#x2019;t Teach an Old Dog New Tricks</title>
<p>In the classic movie <italic>A Few Good Men,</italic> Tom Cruise and Demi Moore defend two Marines, who, while following orders from their superior officers, accidentally killed a fellow soldier. Their defense? &#x201C;We were simply following orders.&#x201D;</p>
<p>History is replete with examples of this excuse. It was used by Nazi defendants at Nuremberg. It was repeated again during the Vietnam War by soldiers involved in the My Lai massacre, by Ollie North in the Iran-Contragate scandal, and by U.S. soldiers in charge of Iraqi detainees at Abu Ghraib. &#x201C;We were following orders&#x201D; is a timeworn excuse and a reflection of a personality trait known as <italic>authoritarianism</italic>.</p>
<p>Authoritarian people respect authoritative leadership and tend to follow authorities blindly (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_1">Adorno, Frenkel-Brunswik, Levenson, &#x0026; Sanford, 1950</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_3">Allport, 1954</xref>). They condemn those who question and deviate from conventional norms, exhibit hostility toward out-group members, and help cause and inflame intergroup conflict (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_4">Altemeyer, 1999</xref>). They are less forgiving and more vengeful toward unrepentant transgressors (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_48">Khoury, Struthers, Santelli, &#x0026; Marjanovic, 2012</xref>), and they raise children who are unaccepting of out-groups and who tend to associate with bullies (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_50">Knafo, 2003</xref>). They believe that power and rigid control are acceptable, and are likely to use physical punishment. Finally, if you are authoritarian, you may not have the self-insight to recognize it. According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_4">Altemeyer (1999)</xref>:
<disp-quote>
<p>If you tell people about authoritarianism, including the part about authoritarians being aggressive when backed by authority, and then ask them how willing they would be to help the federal government eliminate <target target-type="page" id="page_119">119</target>authoritarians, then&#x2014;you guessed it&#x2014;High [authoritarians] will be more willing to volunteer than others, to hunt themselves down. &#x2026; And yet, compared with most people, they think their minds are models of rationality and self-understanding.</p>
<attrib>(p. 159)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>A personality trait that is very much related to authoritarianism is <italic>dogmatism</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_87">Rokeach, 1960</xref>). In fact, according to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_16">Christie (1991)</xref>, dogmatism was introduced as a more general type of authoritarianism; although some argue that authoritarianism and dogmatism scales measure the same thing, others claim that the authoritarianism scale tends to identify closed-minded conservatives, whereas the dogmatism scale identifies closed-minded liberals and conservatives. Whatever the case, dogmatic people, like authoritarians, tend to be deferential to authorities. In addition, dogmatics are closed-minded, have difficulty being objective, and tend to believe there is only one right way to do things (i.e., their way).</p>
<p>With this in mind, you might think that such closed-mindedness makes authoritarian and dogmatic people difficult to persuade. Interestingly, however, a meta-analysis by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_82">Preiss and Gayle (1999)</xref> found just the opposite&#x2014;that is, compared to their counterparts, dogmatic and authoritarian people were <italic>easier</italic> to persuade. The authors suggested that the rigid beliefs of people with such traits might interfere with the way they scrutinize messages, thereby resulting in greater agreement with a message.</p>
<p>Note, however, that although Preiss and Gayle&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_82">1999</xref>) analysis is useful in some respects, we think it&#x2019;s too soon to conclude that dogmatic and authoritarian people are easy to persuade. Indeed, we suggest that more research needs to be conducted to determine <italic>when</italic> dogmatism/authoritarianism is positively related to persuasion and when it is not. By way of example, successfully persuading such people might depend on the nature of the source. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_37">Harvey and Beverly (1961)</xref>, for instance, reported that high authoritarians, compared to low authoritarians, are more likely to be influenced by a person who is a high-status authority. Similarly, a study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_20">DeBono and Klein (1993)</xref> found that when dogmatic people received persuasive messages from experts, they did not think much about the messages and, regardless of the quality of the messages, were more persuaded than people who were not dogmatic. However, when they received persuasive messages from nonexperts, dogmatics were more persuaded by strong arguments than by weak ones. Thus, it may be that authoritarians and &#x201C;high dogs,&#x201D; as people who are highly dogmatic are called by researchers, are especially vulnerable to messages from authority figures.</p>
<p>A related trait is known as <italic>social vigilantism</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_89">Saucier &#x0026; Webster, 2010</xref>). Like dogmatics, social vigilantes think their beliefs are superior to others&#x2019; beliefs. Unlike dogmatics, who tend to dismiss those who disagree with them, social vigilantes try to impress their beliefs onto others. By way of example, when confronted with a contrary view, a social vigilante in one study stated, &#x201C;Everyone does have a right to their own opinions. I just think you should know how ignorant you sound when you voice them&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_89">Saucier &#x0026; Webster, 2010</xref>, p. 19). Not surprisingly, research indicates that social vigilantes, compared to people measuring low on this trait, not only express more belief superiority, they also counterargue more (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_89">Saucier &#x0026; Webster, 2010</xref>), <target target-type="page" id="page_120">120</target>and attempt to dominate conversations (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_61">Maki &#x0026; Raimi, 2017</xref>). Finally, when trying to resist the persuasive attempts of others, social vigilantes use a variety of tactics, including getting emotionally upset and belittling their conversational partners (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_90">Saucier, Webster, Hoffman, &#x0026; Strain, 2014</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec5_2_8">
<title>Narcissism: How Do I Love Me? Let Me Count the Ways</title>
<p>In Greek mythology, Narcissus, who scorned those who loved him, saw his reflection in a pool of water and fell in love with himself. Not only that, he got a personality trait named after him. According to a review by Kausel and his colleagues (2016), narcissists have grandiose views of themselves, a lack of concern for others, and use a wide range of persuasive strategies to increase their self-concept and public image. What&#x2019;s more, narcissists are persuaded by messages that fuel their conceit. One study, for example, found that narcissists, compared to non-narcissists, were more likely to purchase high- versus low-distinctive merchandise (e.g., a &#x201C;limited-edition&#x201D; iPod case with personal name engraving rather than a &#x0024;50 gift card) (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_54">Lee, Gregg, &#x0026; Park, 2013</xref>). Another found that narcissists were fond of &#x201C;virtual mirror,&#x201D; a popular application that allows consumers to experience products virtually. Specifically, narcissists, compared to non-narcissists, were more inclined to purchase clothing when their own images, rather than the images of professional models, were overlaid with the clothing (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_5">Baek, Yoo, &#x0026; Yoon, 2016</xref>). Finally, when it comes to persuading potential sexual partners, narcissists are more likely to employ coercive tactics, including physical force, the use of alcohol, and manipulation (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_9">Blinkhorn, Lyons, &#x0026; Almond, 2015</xref>). Given that, it&#x2019;s hard to see what they see in themselves.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec5_2_9">
<title>Cognitive Complexity and Need for Cognition</title>
<p>How would you describe your best friend? Fun or boring? Intelligent or stupid? Superficial or disclosive? Even-tempered or moody?</p>
<p>According to a theory known as <italic>constructivism</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_24">Delia, O&#x2019;Keefe, &#x0026; O&#x2019;Keefe, 1982</xref>), people attempt to make sense of their world by using constructs like the ones just mentioned. <italic>Constructs</italic> are perceptual categories (e.g., fat/thin, popular/unpopular, strong/weak) that we use when evaluating everything from professors, to textbooks, to music, to arguments. Constructs can be compared to eyeglasses: Just as the size, shape, and color of lenses affect the way you see things, the constructs you use to filter messages influence the way in which you perceive the world. For instance, someone who evaluates you on the sole basis of whether you are Christian or non-Christian will see you much differently than someone who uses more constructs (such as kind or cruel, shy or extroverted, happy or sad, playful or serious, emotional or stoic) to evaluate you. Obviously, everyone has a unique system of constructs, and some people clearly use more constructs than others. People who use a large number of different and abstract constructs that are well integrated are known as <italic>cognitively complex,</italic> whereas those who use fewer and less abstract constructs are <italic>cognitively simple.</italic></p>
<p>People who are more cognitively complex, compared to those who are not, are better at seeing the world from their listeners&#x2019; perspective. As a general rule, they are better at adapting their messages to their listeners and are much more persuasive (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_108">Waldron &#x0026; Applegate, 1998</xref>).</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_121">121</target>When it comes to <italic>being</italic> persuaded, cognitively complex people may also differ from those who are cognitively simple. For instance, cognitively complex people may be more willing than people low in cognitive complexity to tolerate messages that are inconsistent with their cognitions (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_66">McGill, Johnson, &#x0026; Bantel, 1994</xref>).</p>
<p>In addition to being different in the degree to which they are cognitively complex, research shows that people differ in their <italic>need for cognition</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_13">Cacioppo &#x0026; Petty, 1982</xref>). People who are high in the need for cognition enjoy effortful thinking more than those low in the need. We also bet they like playing chess and torturing themselves with logic puzzles. According to some researchers, need for cognition is one facet of cognitive complexity (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_66">McGill et al., 1994</xref>). Whatever the case, compared to people who are low in the need for cognition, those high in the need for cognition are more tolerant of disagreement (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_58">Linvill, Mazer, &#x0026; Boatwright, 2016</xref>) and are viewed by discussion partners as more effective persuaders who generate more valid arguments for their views (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_99">Shestowsky &#x0026; Horowitz, 2004</xref>). Perhaps that is why research indicates that people who are high in the need for cognition are more effective salespeople than those who are low in the need for cognition (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_105">Sojka &#x0026; Deeter-Schmelz, 2008</xref>).</p>
<p>Research also shows that people high in the need for cognition are persuaded differently than their brain-relaxing counterparts. Although people high in the need for cognition pay close attention to messages, evaluating and scrutinizing all the time, people low in the need for cognition are less motivated to attend to messages and are persuaded by peripheral cues instead (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_13">Cacioppo &#x0026; Petty, 1982</xref>). Thus, if you&#x2019;re high in the need for cognition, you are persuaded by quality arguments. If you&#x2019;re low in the need for cognition, you may be persuaded by an attractive speaker (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_80">Perlini &#x0026; Hansen, 2001</xref>), a likable source (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_84">Reinhard &#x0026; Messner, 2009</xref>), a celebrity spokesperson (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_111">Williams-Piehota, Schneider, Pizarro, Mowad, &#x0026; Salovey, 2003</xref>), a lot of examples, or a snappy-sounding sales pitch, even if the arguments used are weak. For example, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_46">Kaufman, Stasson, and Hart (1999)</xref> found that when reading an article on evolution theory, the evaluations of people high in the need for cognition were not affected by the source of the article. In contrast, people low in the need for cognition rated the article favorably, but only if they thought it came from the <italic>Washington Post</italic> (a highly credible source). If they thought the article was from the <italic>National Enquirer,</italic> they did not rate it favorably. At least one implication is clear: If the ghost of Elvis Presley <italic>really</italic> wants a following, it should seek coverage in a more reputable publication.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec5_2_10">
<title>Persuasion and Aggression: Sticks and Stones</title>
<p>Persuasion is not always pretty. Spouse abuse is rampant. Parents beating children as a way to get them to behave is all too common. And who hasn&#x2019;t been called &#x201C;chicken,&#x201D; &#x201C;wimp,&#x201D; &#x201C;bitch,&#x201D; or &#x201C;brat&#x201D; by someone wanting to see a change in behavior? Clearly, aggression is the dark side of persuasion. On the other hand, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_41">Dominic Infante (1987)</xref> argues that aggression is not always bad; aggressive acts can be either constructive or destructive (or both), depending on the type of aggression and how it affects a relationship (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_41">Infante, 1987</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_83">Rancer, 2004</xref>). According to Infante, there are several forms of aggressive communication. We discuss two of them here.</p>
<p>First, <italic>verbal aggressiveness,</italic> a destructive form of aggression, involves the tendency to attack someone by using threats, profanity, insults, and teasing, and by insulting <target target-type="page" id="page_122">122</target>their character, competence, background, appearance, and so forth (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_83">Rancer, 2004</xref>). In short, verbal aggression is aimed at damaging another person&#x2019;s self-concept. As might be expected, compared to nonviolent marriages, violent ones are characterized by higher verbal aggressiveness (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_43">Infante, Chandler, &#x0026; Rudd, 1989</xref>). In other contexts, verbally aggressive teachers are perceived as less credible than their counterparts (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_64">Mazer &#x0026; Stowe, 2016</xref>), and verbally aggressive supervisors have less satisfied and committed employees (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_60">Madlock &#x0026; Dillow, 2012</xref>).</p>
<p>In contrast, <italic>argumentativeness,</italic> a constructive form of assertiveness, involves the tendency to defend and refute positions on controversial issues. Argumentative people approach arguments while nonargumentative people avoid them (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_83">Rancer, 2004</xref>). Although we sometimes have negative connotations about the word &#x201C;argument,&#x201D; research shows that argumentativeness is associated with employee satisfaction (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_42">Infante &#x0026; Gordon, 1991</xref>) and success in college (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_40">Infante, 1982</xref>). Moreover, while students perceive verbally aggressive instructors as having low credibility, they perceive argumentative instructors as having high credibility (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_28">Edwards &#x0026; Myers, 2007</xref>).</p>
<p>To us, perhaps the most interesting line of research on traits and influence examines the ways in which people &#x201C;edit&#x201D; their persuasive messages before they present them. Perhaps you&#x2019;ve caught yourself doing this&#x2014;you want to use a particular strategy, but something keeps you from doing it. A study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_35">Hample and Dallinger (1987)</xref> explored the reasons people keep themselves from using certain influence strategies and found that verbal aggressiveness is associated with these reasons. For example, compared to verbally aggressive people, those who are not verbally aggressive tend to suppress arguments because the arguments violate their principles (e.g., threats may be seen as unethical) or for person-centered reasons (e.g., using certain strategies may harm a person&#x2019;s image or a personal relationship). (For more detail on this topic, see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_34">Hample, 2016</xref>.)</p>
<p>Finally, although we&#x2019;ve painted a rather grim picture of verbal aggression, some of our own work (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_93">Seiter &#x0026; Gass, 2010</xref>) argues that such aggression may be acceptable in certain situations. Take political contests as an example. Unlike many people we&#x2019;ve heard grumbling about how negative and nasty political campaigns have become, we welcome political attacks. Don&#x2019;t get us wrong; we are not condoning all comments. Foes who labeled John Quincy Adams a tyrant and pimp, and Abraham Lincoln an ape and butcher were clearly out of line. On the other hand, we do not mind attacks, even those aimed at a politician&#x2019;s character, as long as the attacks are truthful, relevant, and appropriate. Voters should have the information they need to make tough choices, even if that information comes at a cost to potentially ineffective or unethical folks who are running for public office.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec5_3">
<title>Analyzing and Adapting to Audiences</title>
<p>To us, the most entertaining part of Super Bowl Sunday is its television advertisements. This, of course, is not surprising when you consider that businesses spend billions of dollars every year analyzing their audiences, trying to determine what will pique interests and sell products. Despite the big bucks, however, when attempting to market products to different cultural groups, businesses have made some pretty big blunders: Here are some classic examples:
<list list-type="bullet">
<list-item><p><target target-type="page" id="page_123">123</target>The Swedish furniture company Ikea agreed on the name &#x201C;Fartfull&#x201D; for one of its desks (Cross cultural marketing blunders, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_19">2012</xref>).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>When Kentucky Fried Chicken opened in China, its famous slogan &#x201C;Finger lickin&#x2019; good&#x201D; was mistranslated into Chinese characters that meant &#x201C;eat your fingers off&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_11">Brooks, 2013</xref>).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Imagine how those in the auto industry felt when they learned that, in Spanish, Nova means &#x201C;It doesn&#x2019;t go&#x201D;; in Portuguese, Pinto is slang for &#x201C;a small male organ&#x201D;; and Esso, pronounced phonetically in Japanese, means &#x201C;stalled car&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_18">Copeland &#x0026; Griggs, 1985</xref>).</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
<p>But wait! Corporations can still goof up, even when cultural differences are not involved. Take Target, for example. The mammoth discount store ran into trouble when a customer noticed that the same dress was listed as &#x201C;Manatee Gray&#x201D; in plus-sizes and &#x201C;Dark Heather Gray&#x201D; in regular sizes (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_52">Krupnick, 2013</xref>). Whoops!</p>
<p>The lesson here is simple: If you want to be influential, know whom you are talking to and adapt accordingly. Remember what we said earlier about cognitively complex people? Research shows that such people are more persuasive because they are able to see the world from other people&#x2019;s points of view. As a result, they tend to use person-centered influence tactics (i.e., tactics tailored specifically to the person they are trying to persuade; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_108">Waldron &#x0026; Applegate, 1998</xref>). This, to us, seems to be what persuasion is all about: adapting a message so it coincides with the receiver&#x2019;s frame of reference. To be sure, a persuader doesn&#x2019;t move the receiver to the message, the persuader moves the message to the receiver. It&#x2019;s what&#x2019;s called being &#x201C;market-driven&#x201D; in business, &#x201C;audience-centered&#x201D; in public speaking, and &#x201C;listener-oriented&#x201D; in interpersonal communication. It may also be the most important lesson you can <target target-type="page" id="page_124">124</target>learn about how to be a successful persuader. To influence other people, you should know as much as possible about them so you can appeal to their needs and wants, while at the same time avoid offending them. Of course, attempting to be too diplomatic can go too far. For example, we once heard a story of some people who asked a politician where he stood on a particular issue. So as not to alienate anyone, the politician replied, &#x201C;Some of my friends are for it, some of my friends are against it, and I&#x2019;m for my friends.&#x201D; If we&#x2019;d been in the audience, we would not have been impressed. Thus, it&#x2019;s important to adapt to an audience without coming across as insincere, &#x201C;smooth,&#x201D; or deceptive.</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 5.3</label>
<caption><title>Adapting the message to the audience&#x2019;s frame of reference.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig5_3.jpg"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; Arnie Levin/ The New Yorker Collection/ <uri>www.cartoonbank.com</uri>. All Rights Reserved.</p>
</fig>
<p>Entire books have been written on audience analysis (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_68">McQuail, 1997</xref>), and we cannot give full treatment to the topic here. However, to help you understand the types of issues involved, we discuss segmentation analysis, a special type of audience analysis, in <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box5_2">Box 5.2</xref>. In addition, we list a few guidelines that might be useful if you&#x2019;re ever faced with an audience that needs to be analyzed.</p>
<sec id="sec5_3_1">
<title>Pay Attention to the Situation</title>
<p>Remember what we discussed earlier in the chapter: Communicator characteristics <italic>and</italic> situations affect how audiences respond to persuasive messages. Knowing details about some aspects of a situation can be useful when preparing to persuade someone. For instance, will you be talking to one person or to a large audience? Will the setting be noisy, hot, colorful? Will the persuasion occur in the morning or evening? Will you be inside or out, in a church, or on a football field? Might there be hecklers? Are you expected to talk for five minutes, or can you blab for hours?</p>
<p>Obviously, the number of possible situations is endless. Even so, knowing something about the situation can help you adapt. It&#x2019;s important to try to put yourself in the shoes of your audience. Try to figure out what would appeal to you if you were in their situation and then adapt your message accordingly. Of course, remember to be an ethical persuader. In our opinion, analyzing the situation can help you do this. We&#x2019;ll have more to say about this topic in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter16">Chapter 16</xref>.</p>
<boxed-text id="box5_2">
<label>Box 5.2</label>
<caption><title>Bull&#x2019;s-Eye! An Examination of Targeted Micromarketing</title></caption>
<p>When you consider the billions of dollars that advertisers spend each year, it shouldn&#x2019;t surprise you to find out how much time they devote to learning &#x201C;things&#x201D; about their audience. But we have to admit&#x2014; we were surprised, even scared a little, by some of the things these folks know, or at least claim to know. Did you realize, for example, that based on your zip code, market researchers claim to know what you eat for breakfast, what kind of car you drive, what you watch on television, and a whole lot more? They base these predictions on research showing that people who have the same zip codes tend to be remarkably similar. Not only that, based on your zip code, marketers have dubbed you with funny-sounding nicknames like &#x201C;Blue-Blood Estates,&#x201D; &#x201C;Money and Brains,&#x201D; and &#x201C;Single City Blues.&#x201D; So, for example, if your zip code is 94117 or 15232, you are a &#x201C;Bohemian Mix,&#x201D; you&#x2019;re probably 18 to 34 years old, you enjoy liberal politics and classical records, read <italic>The New Yorker,</italic> and eat frozen waffles (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_6">Berger, 2004</xref>). See? Spooky!</p>
<p>Using zip codes to categorize consumers is just one example of what is known as micromarketing or market segmentation, which involves &#x201C;breaking a market down to definable, manageable segments <target target-type="page" id="page_125">125</target>and then tailoring your efforts to just one or two (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_75">Ogden, 2000</xref>, p. 29; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_91">Schewe &#x0026; Meredith, 2004</xref>). It sounds complicated, but nowadays, it&#x2019;s necessary. Clearly, advertising, campaigning, and marketing are not as easy as they used to be. For example, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_79">Penn (2007)</xref> argued that a once-universal audience has fragmented into hundreds of small groups or niches. Examples include &#x201C;Tech Fatales&#x201D; (women prone to buying technological equipment), &#x201C;30 Winkers&#x201D; (people getting less than seven hours of sleep a night), and &#x201C;Late-Breaking Gays&#x201D; (gay people who have come out of the closet later in life due to more social acceptance of homosexuality). These small groups, if understood correctly, can be adapted and appealed to, thus starting &#x201C;microtrends&#x201D; that can affect business and society in profound ways.</p>
<p>Of course, it&#x2019;s not only zip codes that help marketers segment audiences. They have a large list of ways to categorize their consumers. Knowing your age, for instance, may help them design ads that appeal to you. But wait&#x2014;it gets more complicated. For example, it is not enough to know that your main audience is composed of children. One marketing firm has argued that there are &#x201C;six species of kids,&#x201D; each requiring a different approach (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_32">Gertner, 2004</xref>, p. 102). According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_81">Debra Phillips (1999)</xref>, it may sound funny, but there&#x2019;s a big difference between being 10 years old and being 14, and advertisements aimed at teens are different than those aimed at &#x201C;the legions of 9- to 12-year-olds whimsically referred to as &#x2018;&#x2019;tweens&#x2019;&#x201D;(p. 126). Whereas &#x2019;tweens may scoff at the likes of Mickey Mouse and his pals (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_81">Phillips, 1999</xref>), younger children are still attracted to such characters.</p>
<p>If your head isn&#x2019;t spinning yet, just wait. We all know, for instance, that kids like candy, but different groups of kids (and adults) may have different tastes. If you&#x2019;re a marketer, here&#x2019;s when knowing the ethnicity of your target audience can come in handy. For example, market research suggests that while African Americans enjoy very sweet, hard candies in nonchocolate flavors like mint and coconut, Hispanic Americans like &#x201C;aggressive&#x201D; flavors like lollipops coated with chili powder and mixed with tamarind. Asian Americans, on the other hand, like the texture of chocolate (&#x201C;Serving ethnic markets,&#x201D; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_95">1999</xref>). When you consider this, along with the fact that African Americans, Hispanic Americans, and Asian Americans make up a large portion of the U.S. population, it is clear why marketers are targeting these groups with all sorts of appeals, including ethnic &#x201C;aisles&#x201D; in grocery stores and packaging that attracts certain ethnic groups (e.g., for many Asian Americans, candy packaged in tins connotes quality) (&#x201C;Serving ethnic markets,&#x201D; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_95">1999</xref>).</p>
<p>Of course, by now, we&#x2019;re sure you see that the number of ways that marketers can segment consumers is almost limitless. Indeed, in addition to using age, zip codes, and ethnicity, marketers design messages on the basis of gender, education, economic status, and career choice, just to name a few. As time goes by, consumer markets only promise to get smaller. This is especially true on the Internet, which, according to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_8">Bianco, Lowry, Berner, Arndt, and Grover (2004)</xref>, is an interactive medium that enables marketers to personalize messages and products for each consumer. One of the authors, for example, is a member of Netflix, a company that lets you order movies online. After viewing a movie, you can rate it and, based on your ratings, the company provides you with personalized recommendations for other movies you might like. If you have ever purchased a product from Amazon.com, you might have noticed the same feature: Every time you make a purchase, you may be giving information that can be used to persuade you in the future. In fact, according to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_57">Lindstrom (2011)</xref>, when you search Google, use Facebook, swipe your credit card, or download an iTunes song, data-mining companies are analyzing it and then selling your data to marketers. Even using those innocent-looking online coupons can help marketers target you. Specifically, those coupon&#x2019;s bar codes are encoded with information about you, which can be used by marketers later (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_57">Lindstrom, 2011</xref>).</p>
</boxed-text>
</sec>
<sec id="sec5_3_2">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_126">126</target>Keep Your Audience&#x2019;s Mind in Mind</title>
<p>In the old movie <italic>What Women Want,</italic> Mel Gibson played a male chauvinist advertiser who, after a freak accident, was able to read women&#x2019;s minds. Not surprisingly, Mel not only became an expert at attracting the opposite sex but could also design advertisements that women couldn&#x2019;t resist. The movie illustrates how much easier persuasion might be if you had ESP. Indeed, if you could look into people&#x2019;s minds and know their attitudes, values, and needs, we imagine that adapting your persuasive messages would be a piece of cake.</p>
<p>Although we can&#x2019;t teach you to be psychic, we can give you a few tips about &#x201C;reading&#x201D; people&#x2019;s attitudes, values, and needs. First, as you already know from <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter3">Chapter 3</xref>, there are a number of ways to measure or make guesses about people&#x2019;s attitudes (e.g., using scales, simply asking them, and so on). Once you know a person&#x2019;s attitudes, it is easier to show him or her how that attitude may be inconsistent with other attitudes, shifted to be stronger, and so forth.</p>
<p>Second, it may be possible to make guesses about a person&#x2019;s values based on other information. For example, values are often culturally determined. By learning the values of a culture, there&#x2019;s a reasonable chance you&#x2019;ve learned the values held by an individual within the culture. For instance, earlier in this chapter, we saw that people from the United States tend to value individuals over collectives and that people from China tend toward the opposite. With that in mind, persuasive messages that highlight and promote these values in their respective cultures should be more influential than those that do not. Remember, though, that stereotypes are not always accurate. Keep in mind that cultural values serve as guidelines for developing persuasive messages. Even so, such messages might backfire on some individuals.</p>
<p>Finally, though different individuals&#x2019; needs may vary drastically, some needs may be universal. Knowing about such needs could prove useful for designing persuasive messages. For example, do you think people who design and advertise smoke alarms know about basic security needs? You bet they do! If you&#x2019;ve ever seen one of those advertisements with a family standing at the curb in their pajamas while their house burns down in the background, you know what we&#x2019;re talking about. Advertisers know how to appeal to people&#x2019;s needs.</p>
<p>To help you get a better handle on the types of needs that may be used to motivate people, consider the now-classic typology presented by the humanistic psychologist <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_62">Abraham Maslow (1970)</xref>. According to Maslow, human needs are hierarchical, with the most basic biological needs at the lowest level of the hierarchy and more complex needs at the top.
