Specifically, Maslow argued that human needs were arranged in the following order, from most basic to most complex: physiological (e.g., the need for food and water), safety (e.g., the need for stability and security), belonging (e.g., the need for acceptance and love), esteem (e.g., the need to feel important and unique), and self-actualization (e.g., the need to grow, create, and understand). According to Maslow, before people are motivated to satisfy higher-level needs, their lower-level needs must be met. Thus, a person who is starving to death will be more interested in obtaining food than in boosting his or her self-esteem.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec5_3_3">
<title>Remember the Importance of Audience States and Traits</title>
<p>You know by now that communicator traits and states play a large role in persuasion. It&#x2019;s something to keep in mind if you&#x2019;re ever confronted by someone with traits or in <target target-type="page" id="page_127">127</target>the states we&#x2019;ve discussed. For example, we noted that anxious people require specific recommendations and reassurances when using fear appeals and that high self-monitors respond well to messages that promise to help them &#x201C;fit in.&#x201D; Previous research suggests that tailoring your appeals to the particular traits of your audience will make you more successful in your persuasive endeavors (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_38">Hirsch, Kang, &#x0026; Bodenhausen, 2012</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref5_51">Kraichy &#x0026; Chapman, 2014</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec5_3_4">
<title>Don&#x2019;t Forget About Audience Demographics</title>
<p>A person who can adapt to people of different ages, genders, cultures, and so forth obviously will be more successful than a person who can&#x2019;t. For example, when speaking to small children, using lots of statistics would probably lead to lots of &#x201C;ants in the pants.&#x201D; By the same token, a group of senior citizens would probably squirm or snooze if forced to listen to a speech about planning for pregnancy. Moreover, although we noted that there do not appear to be gender differences in persuadability, it doesn&#x2019;t mean a speaker can ignore the gender of her audience. Notice, for example, by using the word <italic>her</italic> in the previous sentence, we failed to address males who might be reading this book. In short, we&#x2019;re sure you get the point: Whenever possible, know about your audience&#x2019;s age, gender, socioeconomic status, and so forth. Then adapt.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec5_4">
<title>Summary</title>
<p>In this chapter, we discussed several communicator characteristics that affect the process of persuasion. First, we examined demographic variables, noting that some (e.g., age, ethnicity) influence the sending and receiving of persuasive messages, whereas others (e.g., gender) do not appear to be related to influenceability. Second, we showed how several psychological and communication states and traits (i.e., self-esteem, anxiety, preference for consistency, self-monitoring, ego involvement, dogmatism, authoritarianism, social vigilantism, narcissism, cognitive complexity, need for cognition, and aggression) influence persuasive communication. Finally, we examined the notion of audience analysis, indicating that persuaders, when possible, should attempt to adapt to the needs, wants, backgrounds, and so forth of their audiences.</p>
</sec>
</body>

G.</given-names> <surname>Greenwald</surname></string-name></person-group> (Eds.), <source>Attitude structure and function</source> (pp. <fpage>339</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>359</lpage>). <publisher-loc>Hillsdale, NJ</publisher-loc>: <publisher-name>Erlbaum</publisher-name>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref5_105"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Sojka</surname>, <given-names>J. <ref id="ref5_106"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><person-group person-group-type="author"><collab>Teaching fear</collab></person-group>. <ref id="ref5_107"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Vanwesenbeeck</surname>, <given-names>I.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Walrave</surname>, <given-names>M.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Ponnet</surname>, <given-names>K.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2016</year>). <article-title>Children and advergames: The role of product involvement, prior brand attitude, persuasion knowledge and game attitude in purchase intentions and changing attitudes</article-title>. <source>International Journal of Advertising</source>. doi:<object-id>10.1080/02650487.2016.1176637</object-id></mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref5_108"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Waldron</surname>, <given-names>V. <ref id="ref5_109"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Ward</surname>, <given-names>D. <ref id="ref5_110"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>White</surname>, <given-names>M. <ref id="ref5_111"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Williams-Piehota</surname>, <given-names>P.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Schneider</surname>, <given-names>T. R.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Pizarro</surname>, <given-names>L. <ref id="ref5_112"><mixed-citation publication-type="book"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Wiseman</surname>, <given-names>R. L.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Sanders</surname>, <given-names>J. A.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Congalton</surname>, <given-names>K. J.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Gass</surname>, <given-names>R. H.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Sueda</surname>, <given-names>K.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Du</surname>, <given-names>R.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2009</year>). <chapter-title>A cross-cultural analysis of compliance gaining: China, Japan, and the United States</chapter-title>. <ref id="ref5_113"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Wooden</surname>, <given-names>K.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>1988</year>, <month>June</month>). <article-title>How sex offenders lure our children</article-title>. <source>Reader&#x2019;s Digest</source>, pp. <fpage>149</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>154</lpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref5_114"><mixed-citation publication-type="book"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Wooden</surname>, <given-names>K.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>1995</year>). <source>Child lures: What every parent and child should know about preventing sexual abuse and abduction</source>. <publisher-loc>Arlington, TX</publisher-loc>: <publisher-name>Summit</publisher-name>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref5_115"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Wooden</surname>, <given-names>K.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2014</year>). <source>Child lures prevention: Think of it as a vaccine</source>. Retrieved from <uri>www.childluresprevention.com/research/vaccine.asp</uri> <date-in-citation content-type="retrieved">on <month>December</month> <day>20</day>, <year>2016</year></date-in-citation>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref5_116"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Wooden</surname>, <given-names>K.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Webb</surname>, <given-names>R.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Mitchell</surname>, <given-names>J.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2014</year>). <source>A profile of the child molester</source>. Retrieved from <uri>www.childluresprevention.com/research/vaccine.asp</uri> <date-in-citation content-type="retrieved">on <month>December</month> <day>20</day>, <year>2016</year></date-in-citation>.</mixed-citation></ref>
</ref-list>
</back>
</book-part>
<book-part book-part-type="chapter" id="chapter6">
<book-part-meta>
<title-group>
<label>6</label>
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_134">134</target>Conformity and Influence in Groups</title>
<alt-title alt-title-type="running-head">Conformity and Influence in Groups</alt-title>
</title-group>
<contrib-group>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Gass</surname>
<given-names>Robert H.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Seiter</surname>
<given-names>John S.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
</contrib-group>
</book-part-meta>
<body>
<p>BO, PEEP, SHEEP, AND THE HALE&#x2013;BOPP COMET may sound like the makings of a good fairytale, but, as the saying goes, truth is stranger than fiction, and, unfortunately, the story of Bo and Peep&#x2019;s sheep is a true one. We refer to the people of the Heaven&#x2019;s Gate cult as sheep because who else but sheep would believe what these people were told&#x2014;that they should commit mass suicide so they might shed their bodies and be whisked away by an alien spaceship that was flying around in the tail of the Hale&#x2013;Bopp comet? Whether they believed it or not, they did what their leaders, Bo and Peep, told them to do. In 1997, sheriff&#x2019;s deputies found the corpses of 21 women and 18 men decomposing in a home in Rancho Santa Fe, California. All of the members of the cult had apparently ingested a fatal mixture of phenobarbital, applesauce, pudding, and vodka (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_42">Gleick, 1997</xref>).</p>
<p>As authors who are interested in the process of social influence, we can&#x2019;t help but wonder how and why people like those in the Heaven&#x2019;s Gate cult can be persuaded to such extremes. Clearly, several factors must have contributed to the largest mass <target target-type="page" id="page_135">135</target>suicide in U.S. history. The cult members&#x2014;though reportedly bright and happy&#x2014;must have been highly persuadable. Moreover, the leaders of the cult, Marshall Herff Applewhite and Bonnie Lu Nettles (known as Bo and Peep), were highly charismatic and trusted by their followers. But beyond the characteristics of the cult leaders and members, we believe that a strong group dynamic may have contributed to the suicide. Indeed, although from society&#x2019;s perspective the members of the cult were deviants, there seemed to be pressure within the cult to &#x201C;fit in.&#x201D; For instance, the members of the cult reportedly looked the same, so much so that when the corpses were first discovered, they were believed to be men only. The cult members were described as having androgynous appearances; the women wore cropped hair, and many of the men, including the cult&#x2019;s leader, had been castrated. Finally, the cult members were known to dress the same, wearing what one person described as black pajamas. When the 39 corpses were found, each was dressed in black: black pants, black shirt, and brand-new black Nike shoes (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_42">Gleick, 1997</xref>).</p>
<p>We imagine that, if nothing else, being a member of a cult satisfies a need to belong. Cults often attract new members by providing seemingly loving environments for their new recruits. Along with this, however, comes pressure to fit in. With such pressure, it&#x2019;s easy to see how a cult member might have been sucked into the suicide. When you identify so strongly with people who are carrying out some action, the action not only seems more &#x201C;right,&#x201D; it becomes necessary for you to participate if you want to be part of the group. This is true not only in cults, a topic we revisit later in this chapter, but in other social collectives as well. Families, peer groups, workplaces, even classrooms, exert strong pressure on their members to behave in certain ways. For that reason, this chapter examines the role of groups in the process of social influence. We begin by discussing the topic of conformity.</p>
<sec id="sec6_1">
<title>Conformity as Persuasion: In with the Crowd</title>
<p>During a lecture by a sociology professor, in a classroom that held more than 100 people, an undergraduate student, known by both of your authors, removed his shirt, pants, shoes, and socks. Then, almost naked, he stood in the aisle, waiting to be noticed. The professor, who had been looking down at his notes, did not notice our friend until other people in the classroom began gasping and laughing. When the professor finally did look up, he was stunned. Undaunted, the nearly naked student looked down at himself and asked, &#x201C;Does this count?&#x201D;</p>
<p>Apparently, just before the student disrobed, the professor had been lecturing on the topic of norms and conformity. <italic>Norms</italic> are expectations held by a group of people about what behaviors or opinions are right or wrong, good or bad, acceptable or unacceptable, appropriate or inappropriate (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_3">Andrews, 1996</xref>). Once norms are understood, we feel pressure to conform to them. Of course, the professor had probably explained to our friend and his other students that some norms are explicit. <italic>Explicit norms</italic> are written or spoken openly. For example, road signs indicate how fast you are permitted to drive and game rules may send you to jail without collecting &#x0024;200. Some norms, however, are <italic>implicit</italic> and not so openly stated. For example, we imagine that when you&#x2019;re a guest in someone&#x2019;s home, you don&#x2019;t put your feet on the dinner table even though you&#x2019;ve never read a rule saying you shouldn&#x2019;t. Likewise&#x2014; and this is what the sociology professor told his class&#x2014;because we all conform to <target target-type="page" id="page_136">136</target>social norms, no one would take his or her clothes off in the middle of a classroom lecture. Of course, our friend, who prides himself on being a nonconformist, couldn&#x2019;t resist this challenge. The rest is history, and the professor now has a good story to tell whenever he lectures about norms and conformity.</p>
<sec id="sec6_1_1">
<title>In the Beginning: Early Research on Conformity Effects</title>
<p>Not everyone is like our friend, the student-stripper in the sociology class. As we&#x2019;ve noted, in most cases, people know the norms and try to go along with the crowd. Perhaps the most compelling experiment on the effects of conformity was conducted by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_6">Solomon Asch (1956)</xref>. Here&#x2019;s how his experiment worked: Asch gathered several (seven to nine) college students into a classroom and told them that they would be participating in an experiment about visual judgment. The students were asked to look at two large, white cards. As can be seen in <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig6_1">Figure 6.1</xref>, a single vertical line appeared on the first card, and three vertical lines, each of different length, appeared on the second card. The students&#x2019; task was simple: After observing both cards, they were asked to match lines&#x2014;that is, each student was asked to report out loud, to the rest of the group, which of the three lines on the second card was the same length as the line on the other card. According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_7">Asch (1966)</xref>, the experiment began uneventfully but changed rapidly:
<disp-quote>
<p>The subjects announce their answers in the order in which they have been seated in the room, and on the first round every person chooses the same matching line. Then a second set of cards is exposed: Again the group is unanimous. The members appear ready to endure politely another boring experiment. On the third trial there is an unexpected disturbance. One person near the end of the group disagrees with all the others in his selection of the matching line. He looks surprised, indeed incredulous, about the disagreement.</p>
<fig id="fig6_1" position="float">
<label>Figure 6.1</label>
<caption><title>example of Visuals Used in Asch&#x2019;s experiment. Subjects are asked which of the three lines on the comparison card (right) match the line on the reference card (left).</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig6_1.tif"/>
</fig>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 6.2</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig6_2.tif"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; Charles Barsotti/The New Yorker Collection/<uri>www.cartoonbank.com</uri>. All Rights Reserved.</p>
</fig>
<disp-quote>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_137">137</target>On the following trial he disagrees again, while the others remain unanimous in their choice. The dissenter becomes more and more worried and hesitant as the disagreement continues in succeeding trials; he may pause before announcing his answer and speak in a low voice, or he may smile in an embarrassed way.</p>
<attrib>(p. 320)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
<p>What the dissenting student in Asch&#x2019;s study did not know was that all of the other students in the group were planted by Asch and told beforehand to give the wrong answers. In other words, Asch was really interested in what a person would do when he or she was giving correct answers that are contrary to the answers of a near-unanimous group decision. What he found was that conformity was common; under group pressure, 75 percent of the subjects gave the wrong answer in at least one of the trials.</p>
<p>In short, then, Asch&#x2019;s experiment illustrates the tremendous power of groups to exert influence. Even so, not all of Asch&#x2019;s subjects behaved in the same way. For instance, about 25 percent remained fairly independent, rarely conforming to the group&#x2019;s answers. Moreover, about 10 percent of the subjects agreed with the group on almost every trial. Thus, it is probably true that some individuals are more prone to conformity than others. In addition, some situations may produce more conformity than others, a topic we discuss next.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec6_1_2">
<title>Variables Related to Conformity</title>
<sec id="sec6_1_2_1">
<title>Does Group Size Affect Conformity? The More the Scarier?</title>
<p>On the television show <italic>Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?</italic> contestants can make a bundle of money if they can answer a series of questions that become progressively more difficult. Of course, if they get stumped, the rules allow them to &#x201C;poll the audience,&#x201D; asking those in the studio for advice on one, and only one, question. With that in mind, if you were a contestant on the show and had the choice of an audience with 5 people or 500 people, which audience would you want? What if your choice were between an audience of 499 and 500 people? Would the extra person make a very big difference and, if not, at what point does adding people to the audience become less relevant?</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_138">138</target>Regardless of whether they watch <italic>Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?</italic>, for some time researchers have been interested in the role that group size plays in persuasion. Two of many theories that make different predictions about the relationship between group size and persuasion are <italic>social impact theory</italic> (SIT) (Latan&#x00E9;, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_67">1981</xref>) and the <italic>social influence model</italic> (SIM) (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_106">Tanford &#x0026; Penrod, 1984</xref>). The first, SIT, argues that the first person you add to a group has the most influence. Each additional member has some impact, but less than the person added before him or her. In contrast, SIM argues that the third and fourth people added to a group have the most impact because no minority is possible with only two people. In other words, it is easier to disagree with one person than it is to disagree with two or three people. After three or four people are added, however, the pressure to conform levels off.</p>
<p>Empirical results and meta-analyses on which is the better of these two perspectives are mixed (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_11">Bond, 2005</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_12">Bond &#x0026; Smith, 1996</xref>): Some studies support one perspective, some the other, and some neither. After reviewing the literature, we suspect that both models have found support because both may be accurate when you consider an additional variable&#x2014;that is, when you are making a decision in a group, you are motivated by two things: You want to be right and you want to be liked (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_21">Campbell &#x0026; Fairey, 1989</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_32">Deutsch &#x0026; Gerard, 1955</xref>). Specifically, sometimes we conform to a group because the group has <italic>informational influence&#x2014;</italic>that is, we have a desire to be right and we conform to the group because we think the group may be correct. However, sometimes we conform to a group because it has <italic>normative influence.</italic> This means that we conform in order to gain rewards (e.g., be liked) and avoid punishments (e.g., scorn) that are associated with agreement and disagreement.</p>
<p>What does this have to do with group size? According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_21">Campbell and Fairey (1989)</xref>, increasing the number of people in a group affects informational and normative processes differently. Specifically, when you want to be right, as in the millionaire example, the first person added has the most impact because each additional person&#x2019;s judgment is more likely to be redundant with others in the group. On the other hand, imagine you are just playing an &#x201C;at home&#x201D; version of <italic>Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?</italic> with some new neighbors. Your goal is not to win money, but just to fit in, be liked, and make some new friends. In this case, agreeing with the neighbors, especially when the number of them reaches two or three, is more likely, even if you think they are wrong. According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_11">Bond (2005)</xref>, normative influence is stronger when people respond in front of the group, while informational influence is stronger when people respond in private. That&#x2019;s not to say that these two forms of influence act independently. One study (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_69">Levitan &#x0026; Verhulst, 2016</xref>), for example, found that <italic>both</italic> normative and informational influence can have long-lasting effects on people&#x2019;s political attitudes. (For more about group size and conformity, see <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box6_1">Box 6.1</xref>.)</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec6_1_2_2">
<title>Security in Numbers: The Effect of More Than One Dissenter</title>
<p>Having an ally helps a person resist conforming to a group. For example, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_2">Allen and Levine (1971)</xref> found that a single subject is likely to conform when faced with four other people who disagree, but if one of those four sides with the subject, the subject continues to dissent. Interestingly, this seems to be the case even when the supporting partner&#x2019;s judgments are questionable. For example, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_2">Allen and Levine (1971)</xref> found that when trying to make judgments about visual stimuli, even a supporting partner <target target-type="page" id="page_139">139</target>who seemed visually impaired (e.g., wore thick glasses and seemed to have a hard time seeing) prevented subjects from conforming.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec6_1_2_3">
<title>Emotional Reaction of the Majority: Foaming at the Mouth</title>
<p>Since most people are motivated to fit in, it makes sense that getting angry at them when they disagree should increase their motivation to conform. At least that&#x2019;s what one group of researchers thought (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_51">Heerdink, van Kleef, Homan, &#x0026; Fischer, 2015</xref>). But they were wrong. Contrary to their hypothesis, when a majority group of members expressed anger, it led to anti-conformity, perhaps because the dissenter wanted to harm the group or restore freedom of choice (reactance). Bottom line? If you&#x2019;re trying to bring someone back into the fold, keep your cool.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec6_1_2_4">
<title>Moral Conviction: Wrong Is Wrong?</title>
<p>Imagine this scenario: Enemy soldiers are approaching your neighborhood. You and your neighbors try to hide, but, suddenly, your baby starts crying. The only way to keep from being discovered is to smother your baby. Is it morally wrong to do so?</p>
<p>So far, we&#x2019;ve seen that conformity influences the ways in which people answer factual questions (e.g., which lines are similar lengths?), but what about ethical questions like the one above? To find out, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_66">Kundu and Cummins (2013)</xref> asked research participants to respond, either alone or in groups of confederates, to the &#x201C;smother-baby&#x201D; question and others like it. Results indicated that participants were swayed by the opinions of others. Stated differently, moral judgments are vulnerable to group pressure too.</p>
<boxed-text id="box6_1">
<label>Box 6.1</label>
<caption><title>Majority Rules: How to Influence When You&#x2019;re Alone in a Group</title></caption>
<p>This chapter discusses the ways in which a majority of people can influence a minority. As many minority groups have illustrated throughout history, however, sometimes, the minority can influence the majority. This is especially true when the person in the minority is believed to have experience and expertise in whatever topic the group is discussing (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_49">Hart, Stasson, &#x0026; Karau, 1999</xref>).</p>
<p>Even when the person in the minority is not an expert, however, it may be possible for him or her to influence the majority. According to a review of research by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_106">Tanford and Penrod (1984)</xref>, two strategies that a minority member can try are (1) conforming with the group and then deviating and (2) consistently disagreeing with the group. The first tactic involves accumulating what might popularly be known as brownie points. Specifically, by going along with the group on most issues, you are more favorable in the group&#x2019;s eyes when you disagree. As a result, you may convince the group to go along with your point of view. In contrast, the second tactic involves disagreeing with the group consistently and competently. By doing this, whoever holds the minority point of view looks more confident and may get the group&#x2019;s attention (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_75">Moscovici &#x0026; Faucheux, 1972</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_76">Moscovici, Lage, &#x0026; Naffrechoux, 1969</xref>). Of course, these two tactics involve opposite behaviors, so if you&#x2019;re in the minority, don&#x2019;t try both; pick one tactic and stick to it. If you&#x2019;re able to convince even one member of the majority to join you, research suggests that others may follow suit (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_27">Clark, 1999</xref>). Finally, recent research indicates that the majority are more willing to consider minority viewpoints if they expect future interactions (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_97">San Martin, Swaab, Sinaceur, &#x0026; Vasiljevic, 2015</xref>). Considering that, you could always mention the likelihood of future interaction.</p>
</boxed-text>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_140">140</target>That said, there may be exceptions. Indeed, according to the <italic>morality as motivated resistance hypothesis</italic>, people with stronger moral convictions should be more resistant to majority influence than people with weaker convictions (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_4">Aramovich, Lytle, &#x0026; Skitka, 2012</xref>). Thus far, research supports this hypothesis. For example, Aramovich and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_4">2012</xref>) found that people with strong (versus weak) convictions against torture were more likely to express opposition to torturing suspected terrorists, even when their groups expressed support for such torture.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec6_1_2_5">
<title>Indoctrination: Intense Initiations and Mindless Membership</title>
<p>The only time one of your authors was formally initiated into a group, his high school&#x2019;s Varsity Club, he had to wear a dress and sing Christmas carols in a shopping mall (and it wasn&#x2019;t even Christmas time). Of course, there are more severe initiations than this. In 2003, for instance, a group of Chicago high school girls viciously hazed some younger girls by kicking, strangling, and pelting them with feces, urine, fish entrails, and blood. The same year, three young football players in Bellmore, New York, were sodomized with broomsticks, golf balls, and pinecones during a hazing incident. And although previous literature indicates that 50 percent or more of college athletes and fraternity and sorority members have been involved in hazing (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_108">Waldron, 2015</xref>), students are not the only ones participating. In recent incidents, for example, two U.S. servicemen committed suicide after being repeatedly abused by fellow soldiers, and four Texas firefighters were suspended after binding a rookie with duct tape and dousing him with water (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_55">Hosansky, 2013</xref>).</p>
<p>As brutal as these rituals sound, some argue that such practices build cohesiveness by encouraging bonding among new recruits and rookies (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_55">Hosansky, 2013</xref>). Interestingly enough, this may be true. Research suggests that we value a group more if our indoctrination into the group is severe and intense (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_5">Aronson &#x0026; Mills, 1959</xref>). Not only that, once we value a group, we are likely to conform to it. As the introduction to this chapter illustrated, religious cults provide a frightening example of the high level of compliance that may result from intense levels of indoctrination. Indeed, a disturbing number of cult members have died in mass suicides that were encouraged by their leaders (see <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box6_2">Box 6.2</xref>).</p>
<p>How do cults lure such people into their trap? <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_9">Baron (2000)</xref> noted that indoctrination into cults occurs in four stages. First, in the <italic>softening-up stage,</italic> recruits, often targeted when vulnerable (e.g., following a divorce or death of a loved one), are befriended by a member and invited to meetings. There, recruits are showered with attention and praise from cult members, a technique referred to as &#x201C;love bombing&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_90">Richmond, 2004</xref>). Often, recruits are &#x201C;squired&#x201D; by enthusiastic group members or &#x201C;messianic&#x201D; leaders, deprived of sleep, and then confused. The idea here is to lure, then stress, the recruits. In the second stage, <italic>compliance,</italic> the recruits tentatively experiment with some of the behaviors requested by the cult, which may include changes in diet, sleep, and appearance. Though in this stage recruits may simply be paying lip service to the demands of the cult, by the third stage, <italic>internalization,</italic> the recruits begin to consider some of the demands and beliefs of the cult (e.g., all nonmembers are evil) to be more acceptable. Finally, in the <italic>consolidation stage,</italic> recruits become loyal to the cult and demonstrate their allegiance with costly behaviors such as abandoning their careers or academic goals, donating all their personal possessions to the cult, and recruiting new members.</p>
<boxed-text id="box6_2">
<label><target target-type="page" id="page_141">141</target>Box 6.2</label>
<caption><title>Modern-Day Cults: A Sad Chronology</title></caption>
<table-wrap>
<oasis:table frame="topbot" colsep="0" rowsep="0">
<oasis:tgroup cols="2">
<oasis:colspec colnum="1" colname="col1" align="left"/>
<oasis:colspec colnum="2" colname="col2" align="left"/>
<oasis:tbody>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>1978:</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Reverend Jim Jones and 900 followers, including children, commit suicide in Jonestown, Guyana, by drinking cyanide-laced punch.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>1991:</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>A Mexican minister and 29 followers suffocate after he instructs them to keep praying and ignore toxic fumes filling the church.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>1993:</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>At least 80 Branch Davidians, followers of David Koresh, perish in a fire and shoot-out with the BATF at their compound in Waco, Texas.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>1993:</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Using primitive weapons, 53 Vietnamese tribal villagers commit suicide in the belief that they will go straight to heaven.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>1994:</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Sixty-seven members of the &#x201C;Order of the Solar Temple&#x201D; cult are found burned to death in the French Alps in Switzerland and in Quebec, Canada.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>1997:</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Thirty-nine members of the &#x201C;Heaven&#x2019;s Gate&#x201D; cult, led by Marshall</p>
<p>Applewhite, commit suicide in California. They die so they can join the Mother Ship following the Hale-Bopp comet.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>2000:</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>More than 900 members of a reclusive Christian doomsday cult in Africa are murdered by their leaders. Many are burned to death and many are buried in mass graves.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>2003:</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Members of the Raelians (a cult founded by Claude Vorilhon), now known as &#x201C;Rael,&#x201D; claim that with the assistance of Clonaid, a human cloning company, they have cloned two or more human infants. The claims have never been substantiated.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
</oasis:tbody>
</oasis:tgroup>
</oasis:table>
</table-wrap>
</boxed-text>
</sec>
<sec id="sec6_1_2_6">
<title>Identification and Conformity: You&#x2019;re My Kind of People</title>
<p>According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_19">Kenneth Burke (1950)</xref>, <italic>identification</italic> occurs when people achieve shared meaning. Burke argued that humans are motivated to communicate with one another to create identification. The notion of identification is important here because the more a person identifies with a group, the more power the group has to influence that person.</p>
<p>A group that has the power to influence us through the process of identification is known as a <italic>reference group.</italic> Of course, not all groups are reference groups. For example, you might get together with several other students to study for a test. It&#x2019;s unlikely that such a group would exert much influence on the way you think and behave on a daily basis. However, a group of people you admire and want to be like might have a strong impact on you, often without your even knowing it. Because we identify with reference groups, we tend to dress the way they dress, think the way they think, and act the way they act. With this in mind, it&#x2019;s not surprising that a considerable amount of research indicates that we tend to conform more to a group of people who are similar to us than to a group of people who are not (e.g., see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_82">Phua, 2013</xref>). Previous research, for example, found that university students were more likely to engage in high-risk sexual activity (i.e., unplanned, inebriated sex) <target target-type="page" id="page_142">142</target>(<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_54">Holman &#x0026; Sillars, 2012</xref>), and consume more alcohol (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_89">Reed, Lange, Ketchie, &#x0026; Clapp, 2007</xref>) when their peers approved of such behavior. Similarly, students and police officers reported being less willing to help a victim of intimate partner violence when they believed their reference group would avoid doing so also (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_8">Baldry &#x0026; Pagliaro, 2014</xref>).</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 6.3</label>
<caption><title>Cartoon by John Seiter.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig6_3.tif"/>
</fig>
<p>Although fitting in and getting along can be a good thing, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_100">Seiter (1998)</xref> argued that too much identification can have negative consequences in a variety of contexts. For example, in intercultural contexts, <italic>ethnocentrism,</italic> or the belief that one&#x2019;s culture is the standard by which all others should be evaluated, occurs when members of a culture identify too strongly with their own culture. In small group contexts, <italic>groupthink</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_58">Janis, 1972</xref>) occurs when the members in a group are so concerned with achieving consensus and getting along with each other that they don&#x2019;t disagree when they should. In organizational communication contexts, too much identification can lead to what Tompkins and his colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_16">Bullis &#x0026; Tompkins, 1989</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_107">Tompkins &#x0026; Cheney, 1985</xref>) call <italic>strong culture.</italic> Strong cultures exist when employees identify so much with their organization that they conform to the organization&#x2019;s values and actions.</p>
<p>As you might imagine, ethnocentrism, groupthink, and strong culture can result in some seriously negative consequences. For instance, ethnocentrism can lead to hatred, discrimination, and violence toward members of another culture (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_46">Gudykunst &#x0026; Kim, 1997</xref>). Moreover, groups and organizations characterized by groupthink and strong culture are notorious for bad decision making, because they involve collectives of people who are all thinking in the same way (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_101">Sims &#x0026; Sauser, 2013</xref>). Seiter (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_99">1995</xref>), for example, showed how a lumber company with a strong culture had difficulty <target target-type="page" id="page_143">143</target>communicating with people outside the organization. That&#x2019;s because inside the company, everyone thought things were rosy, and, as a result, the organization found itself threatened in the face of environmentalist attacks. Clearly, organizations and groups need members who will occasionally &#x201C;rock the boat,&#x201D; &#x201C;blow whistles,&#x201D; and &#x201C;play devil&#x2019;s advocate&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_70">Locke et al., 2001</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_88">Redding, 1985</xref>). In fact, although such dissenters can be seen as troublemakers, they can also be admired contributors who promote innovation, creativity, and better decisions (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_60">Jetten &#x0026; Hornsey, 2014</xref>). In short, then, it is apparent that identification, by enabling us to communicate, organize, and decrease division, can be a worthwhile goal. However, we must be moderate in promoting it because too much identification can be &#x201C;too much of a good thing&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_100">Seiter, 1998</xref>).</p>
<sec id="sec6_1_2_6_1">
<title>Communicator Characteristics and Conformity</title>
<p>In <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter5">Chapter 5</xref>, we discussed in some detail the ways in which communicator characteristics are related to persuasion. Many of the same characteristics examined there have also been studied by researchers interested in the topic of conformity.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec6_1_2_6_2">
<title>Sex Difference</title>
<p>In an analysis of a large number of studies, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_12">Bond and Smith (1996)</xref> concluded that females are more likely to conform than males. This seems to be the case regardless of when the studies were conducted (i.e., sex differences have not narrowed over time) or whether the participants in the studies were in the presence of the other group members. At least one study suggests that such differences may be due to confidence or lack thereof. Specifically, when performing tasks that favored males, females were less confident and conformed more than did males. For gender-neutral tasks, however, no differences in conformity were found (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_30">Cross, Brown, Morgan, &#x0026; Laland, 2016</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec6_1_2_6_3">
<title>Peer-suasion</title>
<p>The pressure to conform to peers begins early in life. Even preschoolers experience it (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_50">Haun &#x0026; Tomasello, 2011</xref>). Even so, we suspect that most people associate peer pressure with the teen years, perhaps for good reason. Indeed, Knoll and her colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_65">2015</xref>) found that teens, compared to younger children and adults, were more likely to value the opinions of other teens than those of adults. According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_74">McCoy (1991)</xref>, one study conducted on more than 3,000 teenagers found that more than two-thirds of them felt substantial peer pressure to have sex, drink, and take drugs. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_45">Gordon (1986)</xref> found that peer pressure is the most important factor in determining whether teens begin smoking. Moreover, because teens so desperately want to be accepted by their peers, for those who do not believe that they fit in with groups that pressure them, the consequences can be severe. For instance, not fitting in can lead to depression, the number-one risk factor for teen suicide (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_96">Royte, 1994</xref>). That being said, we must keep in mind that peer pressure is not always a bad thing. In her Pulitzer Prize-winning book, <italic>Join the Club</italic>, for instance, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_95">Tina Rosenberg (2011)</xref> argued that peer pressure, which she calls &#x201C;the social cure,&#x201D; can be used to transform the world for the better. As one example, she showed how groups of young nonsmokers with names such as &#x201C;Rage Against the Haze&#x201D; used peer pressure to cut the rate of teen smoking in half, something that government-led antismoking campaigns based on fear (e.g., smoking kills) were unable to do.</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 6.4</label>
<caption><title>&#x201C;Gee, Tommy, I&#x2019;d be lost without your constant peer pressure.&#x201D;</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig6_4.jpg"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; Jack Ziegler/The New Yorker Collection/<uri>www.cartoonbank.com</uri>. All Rights Reserved.</p>
</fig>
</sec>
<sec id="sec6_1_2_6_4">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_144">144</target>Personality</title>
<p>Several studies have identified various aspects of personality that are related to conformity. First, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_17">Burger (1987)</xref> found that people high in the desire to control events in their lives react negatively to group pressure and are, therefore, less likely to conform than people with a low desire for control. Second, high self-monitors, who pay close attention to social cues on appropriate behavior, are more likely to conform than low self-monitors (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_103">Snyder, 1987</xref>). Finally, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_94">Rose, Shoham, Kahle, and Batra (1994)</xref> found that people who are high in the need for affiliation and group identification conform more than people without such needs.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec6_1_2_6_5">
<title>Culture</title>
<p>After surveying more than 100,000 people in 40 different cultures, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_53">Hofstede (1984)</xref> identified four different dimensions of values along which any culture can be placed. He labeled these dimensions <italic>power distance, uncertainty avoidance, masculinity&#x2013; femininity,</italic> and <italic>individualism&#x2013;collectivism.</italic> <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_72">Lustig and Cassotta (1996)</xref> argued that each of Hofstede&#x2019;s dimensions can be applied to the topic of conformity.</p>
<p>First, people from cultures that score high on power distance value hierarchy and obedience to authority, whereas those who score low on power distance prefer equality and participative decision making. For that reason, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_72">Lustig and Cassotta (1996)</xref> argued that people from cultures with low power-distance scores (e.g., Israel, Australia, western European countries) are less likely to conform than those from cultures with high power-distance scores (e.g., the Philippines, Mexico, Venezuela, India, Singapore).</p>
<p>Second, people from some cultures avoid uncertainty and have little tolerance for ambiguity, whereas people from other cultures are more at ease with the unknown. Because ambiguous stimuli foster conformity more than unambiguous stimuli, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_72">Lustig and Cassotta (1996)</xref> argued that cultures that are uncomfortable with ambiguous <target target-type="page" id="page_145">145</target>situations (e.g., Greece, Portugal, Japan, Peru, Chile, Spain) should conform more than cultures that are comfortable with ambiguity (e.g., the United States, Singapore, India, England, Sweden).</p>
<p>Third, some cultures can be characterized as &#x201C;masculine&#x201D; because people in them value competition, strength, assertiveness, and achievement, whereas others can be characterized as &#x201C;feminine&#x201D; because people in them value cooperation, affection, intuition, and nurturance. As such, members from masculine cultures (e.g., Japan, Italy, Austria, Mexico, England, Venezuela) should conform less than members from feminine cultures (e.g., Scandinavian countries, Portugal, the Netherlands).</p>
<p>Finally, while people in individualistic cultures value personal goals and self-autonomy, those in collectivistic cultures emphasize the importance of group goals and harmony. For that reason, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_72">Lustig and Cassotta (1996)</xref> argued that individualists (e.g., people from the United States, England, Australia, Canada, Italy, Denmark) are less conforming than collectivists (e.g., people from Colombia, Korea, Peru, Taiwan, Pakistan, Chile). A meta-analysis by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_12">Bond and Smith (1996)</xref> supports this conclusion, finding conformity to be much higher among collectivists than individualists. In fact, even when they are encouraged to dissent, collectivists resist doing so more than individualists do (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_31">Curseu &#x0026; ten Brink, 2016</xref>). That said, although collectivists seem to be especially susceptible to normative influence (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_98">Savani, Wadhwa, Ulchida, Ding, &#x0026; Naidu, 2015</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_79">Oh, 2013</xref>), additional research found no difference between them and individualists when it came to conforming to informational influence (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_79">Oh, 2013</xref>).</p>
</sec>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec6_1_3">
<title>Social Proof: Using the Sheep Factor to Persuade Others</title>
<p>&#x201C;But, Mom, <italic>everybody&#x2019;s</italic> doing it,&#x201D; is a familiar childhood refrain. Even so, children are not the only ones who pattern their behavior after others. Much adult behavior is based on what <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_25">Cialdini (1993)</xref> has termed <italic>social proof</italic>. Specifically, social proof is the tendency to view behaviors as more appropriate or correct when a lot of other people are engaging in such behaviors. According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_25">Cialdini (1993)</xref>, however, although using social proof can be a handy shortcut for deciding how to behave, it can also make us vulnerable to the persuasive attempts of others. This is because we are more likely to engage in a behavior when persuaders lead us to believe that a lot of other people are engaging in that behavior.</p>
<p>One of the authors once met a person who makes money by playing a guitar and singing in subways and on street corners. The person explained that, even before she starts singing, she throws some of her own money into the open guitar case. Why? When people pass by, they think others have contributed and are more likely to do the same. Not surprisingly, this subway minstrel is not the only one who uses the principle of social proof to persuade others. In fact, the success of &#x201C;viral marketing&#x201D; (also discussed in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter1">Chapter 1</xref>) is largely based on this principle. In his bestselling book <italic>The Tipping Point</italic>, for example, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_41">Malcolm Gladwell (2002)</xref> argued that in the same way a sick person can start an epidemic of the flu, so too can a small group of influential people launch a fashion trend or boost the popularity of a new product. The idea is that consumers will see products being used or talked about by others and follow suit. This strategy of relying on social proof or word of mouth has become known as <italic>viral marketing</italic> and is catching on. Did you know, for example, that companies are hiring &#x201C;real people&#x201D; to use their products? These &#x201C;undercover&#x201D; <target target-type="page" id="page_146">146</target>consumers are meant to provide proof that the product is effective or worthwhile. For example, Hebrew National hired &#x201C;mom squads&#x201D; to host hotdog barbeques (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_44">Goodman, 2001</xref>), and marketers for the energy drink Red Bull decided they didn&#x2019;t even need people to spread the word. Instead, they filled sidewalk trash cans and bar tables with empty cans of the stuff (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_36">Eisenberg, 2002</xref>).</p>
<p>Once again, the idea is the same; if people see or hear about others using a product, they&#x2019;re more likely to try the product themselves. Research supports this notion as well. For example, a study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_29">Cody, Seiter, and Montagne-Miller (1995)</xref> found that when people are buying gifts for others, social proof is one of the most effective tactics that a salesperson can use. In fact, when salespersons told their customers that a particular product was &#x201C;the most popular,&#x201D; &#x201C;the best selling,&#x201D; or &#x201C;selling faster than we can bring them in,&#x201D; customers spent more money than when the salespersons used other tactics, such as praising the customer, doing favors for the customer, and trying to demonstrate expertise and trustworthiness (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_29">Cody et al., 1995</xref>). Why? It may be that people are less certain about purchases when buying for others than when buying for themselves.</p>
<p>Not surprisingly, social media is a haven for social proof as well. Would it surprise you to learn, for example, that some bloggers earn &#x0024;100,000 or more per year to promote certain brands? It&#x2019;s true. Those bloggers may seem ordinary enough, but beware&#x2014;their brand choices are not always random (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_110">Wolverson, 2013</xref>).</p>
<p>From an organization&#x2019;s point of view, digital marketing can also be tricky. Indeed, although social media can garner a lot of attention, it can also backfire spectacularly. Consider what happened when a British government agency tried to drum up support for a &#x0024;287 million research ship by allowing Internet users to suggest and vote on names. Do you suppose they ended up with a dignified name like &#x201C;Shackleton,&#x201D; &#x201C;Endeavor,&#x201D; or &#x201C;Falcon&#x201D;? Not a chance. It turns out that voters went with &#x201C;Boaty McBoatface&#x201D; instead. Similarly, imagine Taylor Swift&#x2019;s surprise when Internet voters chose a school for the deaf as a concert location, or Slovakian legislators&#x2019; astonishment when the public voted to name a pedestrian bridge after the celebrity Chuck Norris (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_93">Rogers, 2016</xref>).<xref ref-type="fn" rid="fn6_1"><sup>1</sup></xref></p>
<p>Another method for sparking word-of-mouth marketing is a selling strategy known as <italic>group buying</italic>, which encourages individual customers to make purchases through buying groups in order to receive a discounted group rate (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_61">Jing &#x0026; Xie, 2011</xref>). For example, a company might sell a &#x0024;100 item for &#x0024;75 if 20 people sign up to buy the item. As a result, customers who want the discount spread the word, essentially becoming sales agents for the company. The Internet, of course, is a ripe environment for this approach, and it is not surprising that a number of group-buying websites, such as Groupon.com, have emerged. According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_24">Chen and Lu (2015)</xref>, group buying is effective for marketing products, especially when those products are endorsed by members of our reference groups.</p>
<p>That said, online customer reviews of products and services can also operate as social proof. Take, for example, the following reviews of vacation resorts adapted from Expedia.com (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_13">Book, Tanford, Montgomery, &#x0026; Love, 2015</xref>, p. 13):
<disp-quote>
<p>&#x201C;We just got back yesterday and had the time of our lives! The resort was amazing &#x2026;&#x201D;</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_147">147</target>&#x201C;We cannot wait to go back!&#x201D;</p>
<p>&#x201C;Let me give you the real &#x2018;5 Star review&#x2019;. If you like old, dirty and run down hotels&#x2014;5 stars! If you like hard beds and bring your own air mattress&#x2014;5 stars! If you like a cesspool for a swimming pool&#x2014;5 stars!&#x201D;</p>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>According to a study by Book and her colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_13">2015</xref>), reviews such as these function like traditional word of mouth, yet have the capability of reaching far more customers. If fact, such reviews can be more influential than prices, especially when they are unanimously positive or negative (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_13">Book et al., 2015</xref>). Not surprisingly, online reviews are particularly persuasive when they contain quality information (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_40">Filieri, 2015</xref>).</p>
<p>Social proof, of course, has the power to influence more than buying behavior, as illustrated in a study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_18">Burger and Shelton (2011</xref>, p. 74). Specifically, these researchers posted two signs near elevators. One, using social proof, read, &#x201C;More than 90 percent of the time, people in this building use the stairs instead of the elevator.&#x201D; The other sign said, &#x201C;Taking the stairs instead of the elevator is a good way to get some exercise.&#x201D; Within two weeks, the number of people using the elevator instead of the stairs dropped 46 percent, but only in the social proof condition. No change was observed with the sign that merely encouraged exercise.</p>
<p>Although social proof is probably a universally effective persuasion tactic, it may be more effective when used in some cultures than others. Recall, for example, our earlier discussion about the distinction between individualistic and collectivistic cultures. According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_28">Cody and Seiter (2001)</xref>, because social proof is rooted in people&#x2019;s tendency to conform, it should be especially effective in collectivistic cultures where conformity is prevalent. This seems to be the case. For instance, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_26">Cialdini, Wosinska, Barrett, Butner, and Gornik-Durose (2001)</xref> conducted a study to see how well social proof worked in the United States (an individualistic culture) and Poland (a collectivistic culture). In the study, people from both cultures were asked to indicate how willing they would be to comply with three requests: once while considering that all their peers had complied with the request (high social proof), once while considering that half their peers had complied with the request (moderate social proof), and once while considering that none of their peers had complied (no social proof). Results of the study indicated that, in both cultures, as the level of social proof increased, so did compliance. This was especially true in Poland (Cialdini et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_26">2001</xref>).</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec6_2">
<title>Ostracism: Shuns and Guns</title>
<p>In 1976, on the campus where one of the authors teaches, a disturbed man shot and killed six students and one communication professor. In 1999, at Columbine High School in Colorado, two students, Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold, shot and killed 12 students and a teacher before committing suicide, and in 2007, Seung-Hui Cho killed 32 people on the Virginia Tech campus before committing suicide. More recently, in 2012, a gunman killed 20 children and 6 adults at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut. Sadly, such school shootings are all too prevalent. They leave us shaking our heads and asking, &#x201C;Why?&#x201D; What would lead people to do such horrible things? One explanation is <italic>ostracism</italic>, the act of excluding and ignoring <target target-type="page" id="page_148">148</target>others (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_22">Carter-Sowell, Chen, &#x0026; Williams, 2008</xref>). Indeed, according to Zadro and Williams&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_111">2006</xref>) sources, the Columbine killers acted out as a form of retaliation after being shunned by their peers.</p>
<p>Up to this point, we have seen how people&#x2019;s desire to belong can lead them to conform to that group, even if they think the group is wrong. The study of ostracism underlines just how important this need can be and how desperate for attention ostracized people can become. By way of example, Carter-Sowell and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_22">2008</xref>) noted that the &#x201C;Bind, Torture, Kill&#x201D; serial killer was so desperate for recognition that he wrote about it to the press: &#x201C;How many do I have to kill, before I get my name in the paper or some national attention?&#x201D; (p. 144).</p>
<p>Although the act of ostracism does not always lead to such violent incidents, research suggests that it can affect behavior in other ways. For instance, in order to gain the acceptance they seek, ostracized people may behave in more socially acceptable ways (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_38">Feinberg, Willer, &#x0026; Schultz, 2014</xref>). As Carter-Sowell and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_22">2008</xref>) argued, however, the need to fit in may render ostracized people easy marks for persuaders. To test this notion, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_92">Riva, Williams, Torstrick, and Montali (2014)</xref> conducted a study. In it, students played &#x201C;Cyberball,&#x201D; a computer ball-tossing game with two other players, who, unbeknown to the students, were actually computer generated and programmed to ostracize the students by hardly ever tossing the ball to them. After about two minutes of virtual shunning, the students were approached by the experimenter, who handed them a camera and commanded them to go outside when temperatures were below 30&#x00B0; Fahrenheit to take 39 creative pictures. As suspected, the students who had been ostracized were significantly more obedient. Judges rated their pictures to be significantly more creative than those taken by non-ostracized students.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec6_3">
<title>Deindividuation, Social Loafing, and Social Facilitation: Getting Lost in the Crowd</title>
<p>In previous sections, we saw how people can be pressured to conform to a group. This, however, is not the only way that groups can influence an individual. In this section we examine how groups can affect a person&#x2019;s behavior by causing the person to lose his or her sense of self or by making the person feel less responsible for his or her actions.</p>
<sec id="sec6_3_1">
<title>What a Riot: An Examination of Deindividuation</title>
<p>Crowds influence people&#x2019;s behavior; once we get lost in them, we tend to do things that we would never do alone. If you don&#x2019;t believe us, ask our friend who was one of the 500,000 people at the Woodstock concert in 1969. She won&#x2019;t say whether she was one of the people running around naked, but she admits to doing things she wouldn&#x2019;t have done if she had not been lost in the crowd.</p>
<p>This tendency &#x201C;to get lost in the crowd&#x201D; was first labeled <italic>deindividuation</italic> by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_39">Festinger, Pepitone, and Newcomb (1952)</xref>. Deindividuation is said to occur when being in a group causes people to become less aware of themselves and less concerned with how others will evaluate them (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_33">Diener, 1980</xref>). Because being in a large group makes a person both more aroused and anonymous, the person focuses less on himself or herself and behaves more impulsively.</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_149">149</target>Although running around naked at concerts may sound harmless enough, it is clear that deindividuation can have much more severe consequences. For example, one of the authors was a student at the University of Southern California when the Los Angeles riots broke out in 1992. Seeing firsthand the trashed storefronts and burnt buildings of the riot&#x2019;s aftermath made the potentially cruel nature of deindividuation all too real. The riots made it clear to everyone how powerful mob psychology can be: When one person starts wreaking havoc, others may be likely to follow. Consider, for example, the comments of a U.S. soldier trying to explain what caused him to kill innocent children and civilians during the My Lai massacre:
<disp-quote>
<p>I just went. My mind just went. And I wasn&#x2019;t the only one that did it &#x2026; a lot of people were doing it, so I just followed suit. I just lost all sense of direction, of purpose. I just started killing. I just started killing any kinda way I could kill. It just came. I didn&#x2019;t know I had it in me.</p>
<attrib>(Biton &#x0026; Sim, cited in <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_37">Epley &#x0026; Gilovich, 1999</xref>, p. 578)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>A classic study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_34">Diener, Fraser, Beaman, and Kelem (1976)</xref> illustrates how deindividuation can lead to such antisocial behavior. The researchers suspected that if any night of the year would lead to deindividuation, it was Halloween. To be sure, children usually trick-or-treat in groups and, because they wear costumes, are more anonymous than usual. To see if deindividuation would affect children&#x2019;s behavior, these researchers gave 1,352 trick-or-treaters, who were either trick-or-treating alone or in groups, the opportunity to steal candy or money from 27 homes in Seattle. How did the experiment work? When trick-or-treaters came to the door, an experimenter greeted them, commenting on their costumes. The experimenter asked some of the children their names, and other children were allowed to remain anonymous. The experimenter then left the room after telling the trick-or-treaters they could take one of the candies that was in a bowl near the door (there was also a bowl full of nickels and pennies). Unbeknown to the children, a hidden observer watched how much candy (and money) the children really took, and here&#x2019;s what the observer saw: When children were trick-or-treating alone, 7.5 percent of them took more candy than they were supposed to. When they were in groups, however, the thievery increased substantially; 20.8 percent stole candy. Moreover, when the children remained anonymous, they stole more candy and money than they did when the experimenter asked their names. In short, deindividuation led the trick-or-treaters to a night of petty crime.</p>
<p>Perhaps the most disturbing research on deindividuation focused on violent behaviors perpetrated in groups. First, in one study, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_73">Mann (1981)</xref> examined more than 150 newspaper accounts of what happened when people threatened to kill themselves by jumping from buildings. Mann found that in some cases, people who had gathered on the streets below actually baited the potential jumpers, encouraging them to leap to their deaths. Can you guess what one of the factors was that caused observers to egg on jumpers? According to Mann, when the crowds contained more than 300 people, baiting was more common than it was in smaller crowds. This, of course, is consistent with the notion that larger crowds produce more deindividuation.</p>
<p>Second, in an even more disturbing study, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_77">Mullen (1986)</xref> examined the relationship between the size of lynch mobs and the severity of atrocities committed <target target-type="page" id="page_150">150</target>by such mobs. To do so, he analyzed more than 300 newspaper reports to determine the following: (1) the number of people in each lynch mob; (2) whether the lynchings included violent acts, such as hanging, shooting, burning, lacerating, and dismembering the victims; and (3) whether the lynchings happened quickly or were prolonged and torturous. Results of the study indicated that victims suffered more when the lynch mobs were larger. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_77">Mullen (1986)</xref> concluded that &#x201C;these results support the contention that lynchers become less self-attentive, and thereby more likely to engage in acts of atrocity, as the lynchers become more numerous relative to the number of victims&#x201D; (p. 191).</p>
<p>Considering these studies, an important question concerns how deindividuation might be attenuated. Because deindividuation results from low self-awareness, the answer may lie in making people more aware of themselves. According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_87">Prentice-Dunn and Rogers (1982)</xref>, however, there are two types of self-awareness and only one is related to deindividuation. First, <italic>public self-awareness</italic> refers to how we view ourselves as social objects and our concerns about such things as our appearance and the impression we are making on others. <italic>Private self-awareness</italic> refers to our focus on hidden aspects of ourselves such as our thoughts, feelings, and perceptions (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_20">Buss, 1980</xref>). <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_87">Prentice-Dunn and Rogers (1982)</xref> found that deindividuation is decreased only when a person&#x2019;s private self-awareness is increased. This suggests, then, that to attenuate deindividuation, the object is to get people focused on their own thoughts and feelings. Thus, rather than state that people will get in trouble for their actions or look bad for doing something, it may be better to have them reflect on their personal views on what is right and wrong. (For more on deindividuation in a specific context, see <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box6_3">Box 6.3</xref>.)</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec6_3_2">
<title>Social Loafing: Not Pulling Your Own Weight</title>
<p>Have you ever had to push a stalled car or move a heavy piece of furniture with several other people? If so&#x2014;be honest for a moment&#x2014;did you give it your all? Or, because there were others to share the burden, did you slack off a bit? If you&#x2019;re at all like the average research participant, you probably did not work as hard as you could have. Indeed, research suggests that when working in groups, people may not try as hard as they do when working alone (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_48">Harkins, Latan&#x00E9;, &#x0026; Williams, 1980</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_62">Karau &#x0026; Williams, 1993</xref>). In short, like a lot of other people, you may be a social loafer.</p>
<p>According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_62">Karau and Williams (1993)</xref>, &#x201C;social loafing is the reduction in motivation and effort when individuals work collectively compared with when they work individually or coactively&#x201D; (p. 681). What causes such loafing? There are several explanations, although we only have room to discuss the most prominent perspectives (for a review of others, see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_47">Guerin, 1999</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_63">Karau &#x0026; Williams, 2001</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_70">Locke et al., 2001</xref>).</p>
<p>First, the <italic>collective effort model</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_63">Karau &#x0026; Williams, 2001</xref>) argues that we tend to get lazy if we don&#x2019;t expect our efforts to lead to personally valued outcomes or if we don&#x2019;t think our effort will be instrumental in obtaining those outcomes. Thus, social loafing occurs because we don&#x2019;t think we will get the credit we are due or achieve the results we desire.</p>
<p>Second, the <italic>free ride effect</italic> suggests that when they can get away with it, people try to benefit from the efforts of others&#x2014;that is, they slack off when others are working, when they are anonymous, and when they don&#x2019;t think their own efforts will be <target target-type="page" id="page_151">151</target>evaluated. Working in groups not only allows them to &#x201C;hide in the crowd&#x201D; without getting blamed for poor work but also enables them to reduce their own effort and still enjoy an equal share of the rewards (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_63">Karau &#x0026; Williams, 2001</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_70">Locke et al., 2001</xref>).</p>
<boxed-text id="box6_3">
<label>Box 6.3</label>
<caption><title>Computer-Mediated Conformity: When Group Members Flame the Same</title></caption>
<p>From what you&#x2019;ve read so far, you can see that being in the presence of a group can seriously affect your behavior. With that in mind, what do you suppose might happen if you were still able to communicate with a group but were removed physically from the group&#x2019;s presence? Liberation from social pressure? Freedom to do as you please without worrying about fitting in?</p>
<p>If that&#x2019;s what you were thinking, think again. Optimists once figured that email and the Internet might provide emancipation from group pressure, but empirical research suggests otherwise. For instance, a study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_109">Williams, Cheung, and Choi (2000)</xref> found that people using Internet chat rooms are likely to conform to the unanimous incorrect judgments of a group of strangers, especially after being ostracized by a previous group. Moreover, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_86">Postmes, Spears, and Lea (2000)</xref> found that the same types of norms and conformity that occur in face-to-face groups evolve in computer-mediated groups as well.</p>
<p>With that said, you probably won&#x2019;t be surprised to learn that communicating via computer does not make you immune to negative behaviors often evidenced in groups. In fact, some studies (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_59">Jessup, Connolly, &#x0026; Tansik, 1990</xref>) suggest that the anonymity afforded to people who communicate via computers makes uninhibited and inappropriate behavior (e.g., insulting others, using profanity) more likely than it is in face-to-face conversations. Such &#x201C;flaming,&#x201D; as it is called in the world of computer users, has been blamed on deindividuation, which, as you already know, is fostered by anonymity.</p>
<p>The good news is that computer-mediated group communication does not necessarily lead to negative behavior, but rather positive or negative behavior depending on the norms of the group with which one is communicating (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_104">Spears, Lea, &#x0026; Lee, 1990</xref>). Specifically, the social identity model of deindividuation effects (SIDE; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_85">Postmes, Spears, &#x0026; Lea, 1998</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_86">2000</xref>) argues that immersion in a group prompts greater conformity to the group&#x2019;s norms. Thus, if the group&#x2019;s norms are positive, you are more likely to engage in prosocial behaviors. If the group&#x2019;s norms are negative, you are more likely to &#x201C;flame.&#x201D;</p>
</boxed-text>
<p>Finally, the <italic>sucker effect</italic> occurs when people suspect that others may be taking a free ride. Rather than be a &#x201C;sucker&#x201D; who does all the work, people slack off in order to match the level of work done by others (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_70">Locke et al., 2001</xref>).</p>
<p>Whatever the reason for social loafing, one thing is clear: It, like deindividuation, can have disastrous effects. For example, in Richmond, California, in 2009, at least a dozen bystanders watched as a 15-year-old girl was beaten and gang-raped outside the building where her high school homecoming dance was being held. The ordeal lasted more than two hours before anyone summoned help. Likewise, social loafing has been <target target-type="page" id="page_152">152</target>observed in laboratory research. For instance, in a study by Latan&#x00E9; and Darley (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_68">1970</xref>), subjects were led to believe that they were having a conversation over an intercom with other subjects in the study. Some believed they were talking with only one other person; others believed they were talking with five other people. In reality, there were no other subjects, just tape-recorded messages. At one point during the conversation, one of the &#x201C;pretend subjects&#x201D; began choking and gasping as if having a seizure. Did the supposed victim receive help? The answer is &#x201C;it depends.&#x201D; When subjects thought they were in groups with five other people, only 30 percent of them helped. When the subject thought she or he was alone with the victim, 85 percent helped. The larger the group, the less likely people are to lend a hand.</p>
<p>Considering our discussion so far, you might be wondering how social loafing can be decreased. According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_62">Karau and Williams (1993)</xref>, social loafing can be reduced or overcome by:
<disp-quote>
<p>providing individuals with feedback about their own performance or the performance of their work group, monitoring individual performance or making such performance identifiable, assigning meaningful tasks, making tasks unique such that individuals feel more responsibility for their work, enhancing the cohesiveness of work groups, and making individuals feel that their contributions to the task are necessary and not irrelevant.</p>
<attrib>(p. 700)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>Furthermore, it may be easier to attenuate social loafing if you know the conditions under which it occurs. For instance, because loafing is more likely in larger groups, limiting the number of people in a group may be effective (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_1">Aggarwal &#x0026; O&#x2019;Brien, 2008</xref>). Moreover, earlier in this chapter, we talked about how we are more likely to conform to groups with which we identify. Knowing this, it&#x2019;s not surprising to find that people who identify with a group are not as likely to loaf as those who do not identify (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_10">Barreto &#x0026; Ellemers, 2000</xref>). For those who do not identify, another approach is to make them accountable for their work. Evidence for the effectiveness of this approach is mixed, however. For instance, while Aggarwal and O&#x2019;Brien (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_1">2008</xref>) found that university students were less likely to loaf on group projects when their peers evaluated them, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_35">Dommeyer (2007)</xref> did not. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_71">Lount and Wilk (2014)</xref> found that employees were less likely to loaf when their performance was posted publicly, but argued that it was because doing so triggered social comparison between workers, which, in turn, increased their motivation to work hard.</p>
<p>Another variable that influences the potential for loafing is the nature of the people involved in the task, suggesting that before you join a group, you should know whom you&#x2019;re joining. First, research indicates that people who are open to new experiences, conscientious, agreeable, and high in the need for cognition (see <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter5">Chapter 5</xref>) are less likely to loaf than their counterparts (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_64">Klehe &#x0026; Anderson, 2007</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_102">Smith, Kerr, Markus, &#x0026; Stasson, 2001</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_105">Tan &#x0026; Tan, 2008</xref>). Second, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_83">Pieterse and Thompson (2010)</xref> noted that <italic>diligent isolates</italic>, unlike social loafers, are people who increase their efforts and willingly work alone in an effort to rescue group projects. However, because they do not know how to delegate or have the social skills required for group projects, diligent isolates can be just as bad for group projects as social loafers. In fact, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_83">Pieterse and Thompson (2010)</xref> observed that the presence of diligent isolates promoted social <target target-type="page" id="page_153">153</target>loafing in other group members. Finally, the way in which people perceive themselves might influence the degree to which they loaf. Specifically, a study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_56">Huguet, Charbonnier, and Monteil (1999)</xref> found that people who see themselves as uniquely superior to others are most likely to loaf when working collectively on an easy task (i.e., imagining different uses for a knife).
