This is because they perceive their contribution to such a task as redundant, dispensable, and unlikely to make others aware of their superior talents. However, these types of people tend to work extra hard on difficult tasks (i.e., imagining different uses for a doorknob) (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_56">Huguet et al., 1999</xref>) or when they perceive their teammates as being unequipped for handling the task (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_84">Plaks &#x0026; Higgins, 2000</xref>). And why not? Such <italic>social compensation,</italic> as it is called in the literature, helps them maintain the belief that they are unique and reap possible rewards if their group does well (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_56">Huguet et al., 1999</xref>). What can we learn from such research? Consider this: If you ever ask a group to perform an easy task, watch out for people who think they&#x2019;re the cat&#x2019;s meow. If that sounds simple, consider one more thing: Most people see themselves as superior to the average person, a phenomenon known as <italic>self-serving bias</italic> (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_43">Goethals, Messick, &#x0026; Allison, 1991</xref>). Unfortunately, this probably means that when tasks are easy, there are a lot of loafers out there.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec6_3_3">
<title>Social Facilitation: Would You Rather Be Alone?</title>
<p>The presence of other people does not always lead to loafing. In fact, it can have the opposite effect. Years ago, for example, when one of the authors was on his high school&#x2019;s track team, he ran &#x201C;practice races&#x201D; by himself, attempting to beat his best time. No matter how hard he tried, however, he could never match his performance in real races. He didn&#x2019;t know it then, but his faster times in real races were most likely the result of <italic>social facilitation</italic>, or rather, the tendency to perform better when other people are around (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_112">Zajonc, 1965</xref>). The effect has been demonstrated time and time again, but before you decide to surround yourself with spectators the next time you write a research paper, consider this: The presence of others tends to improve performance on simple or well-rehearsed tasks while impairing performance on complex or unfamiliar tasks. Not only that, it can affect your health and bankroll. Did you know, for example, that as the number of diners increases, so does the amount of food consumed, especially when the people are friends and family (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_23">Cavazza, Graziani, &#x0026; Guidetti, 2011</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_52">Herman, 2015</xref>)? Moreover, the energizing effects of being around other people might cause people to take greater risks. To illustrate, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_91">Rockloff, Greer, and Fay (2011)</xref> observed people playing computerized slot machines alone or alongside others. Results revealed that people played faster and longer in the presence of other gamblers than when alone. The implications, of course, are that large commercial gaming venues might accelerate the pace at which gamblers part with their dough.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec6_4">
<title>How Groups Affect Decision Making: To Risk or not to Risk</title>
<p>Imagine that you&#x2019;re the parent of a small child, a daughter, with a serious heart condition. Because of the condition, your daughter has to refrain from any activity that might put too much strain on her. Your child&#x2019;s doctor, however, presents you with some interesting news: There&#x2019;s a new surgery your child can have that will make her completely healthy. There&#x2019;s a catch, however: The doctor tells you that there is <target target-type="page" id="page_154">154</target>a 1 percent chance your child will die from the surgery. What choice would you make? Would you allow the doctor to perform the surgery? If you thought &#x201C;yes,&#x201D; imagine that the odds are different; instead of a 1 percent chance, what if there were a 50 percent chance your child would die?</p>
<p>Interestingly, research has shown that when selecting between alternatives like the preceding ones, groups and individuals make different decisions. The first study on this subject was conducted by Stoner (1961, cited in <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_15">Brauer, Judd, &#x0026; Gliner, 1995</xref>), who found that individuals made riskier decisions when they were in groups than they did when alone. In other words, while an individual might decide to allow the surgery when there was a 1 percent chance of death, a group might allow it when there was a 50 percent chance. Following Stoner&#x2019;s study, several other researchers confirmed these results, and soon this effect became known as the <italic>risky shift phenomenon.</italic> Not all studies, however, confirmed this phenomenon. In fact, some later studies found just the opposite effect. Sometimes groups made decisions that were <italic>less</italic> risky than those made by individuals (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_78">Myers &#x0026; Arenson, 1972</xref>). How might such results be explained? According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_78">Myers and Arenson (1972)</xref>, instead of a risky shift phenomenon, what actually occurs is a <italic>group polarization phenomenon.</italic> In short, groups cause people to become more extreme in their decisions. Thus, if you are predisposed to making a slightly risky decision, being in a group may cause you to make a riskier decision; if you are predisposed to make a conservative decision, being in a group may cause you to make an even more conservative decision. As you might suspect, as decisions become more extreme, they might also become less accurate. Indeed, in one study (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_80">Palmer &#x0026; Loveland, 2008</xref>), poor, good, and average lecturers were evaluated by individuals or by people who engaged in group discussions. Results showed that group discussion led to less accurate ratings of the lecturers.</p>
<p>Although there are many explanations for why group polarization occurs, two are most prominent (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_14">Boster, 1990</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_15">Brauer et al., 1995</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_81">Pavitt, 1994</xref>). The first, <italic>social comparison theory</italic>, argues that we learn about ourselves by comparing ourselves to others. Because most people are average, when they compare their view to the views of others, they don&#x2019;t find much difference. Interestingly, however, because most people want to see themselves in a positive light, they don&#x2019;t want to be average; they want to be &#x201C;better than average.&#x201D; Thus, according to this theory, when people learn that their position is the same as that of everyone else in the group, they shift their position so that it is more extreme. Because everyone tends to do this, group polarization occurs.</p>
<p>A second perspective, <italic>persuasive arguments theory</italic>, asserts that, before entering a group discussion, each member has one or more arguments that support his or her own position. If you consider all these arguments together, there will be more supporting one position than another (e.g., there may be more support for a risky decision than there is for a conservative one). Persuasive arguments theory asserts that the position that has the best and largest number of arguments supporting it is the position toward which members shift.</p>
<p>Several authors have argued that these theories are not contradictory (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_14">Boster, 1990</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_57">Isenberg, 1986</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_81">Pavitt, 1994</xref>). In other words, <italic>both</italic> social comparison and persuasive arguments might contribute to group polarization. In addition, Brauer and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref6_15">1995</xref>) have argued that a third process might contribute to the extreme decisions made by groups. They noted that although social comparison and persuasive <target target-type="page" id="page_155">155</target>arguments explanations both focus on interpersonal processes (e.g., what we hear from other group members), <italic>intra</italic>personal processes also may affect polarization. Specifically, they argued that when making decisions in groups, we not only hear from other group members, we state our own opinion and defend it several times. Such repetition, they argued, also moves us toward polarization.</p>
<p>Before concluding this section, we wish to point out that, like the other topics we&#x2019;ve discussed in this chapter, group polarization can have disastrous effects. For instance, imagine being on the front lines in a hopeless battle. Who would you want deciding whether you should take a hill: one military leader or a group of them? How about if a decision were being made to start a war or launch a missile? Or imagine an innocent person accused of a crime. Would he or she be better off with or without a jury deciding on a verdict? You get the idea. As frequent members of groups, it is important to remember the effects that groups can have on us. Only then might we hope to be less vulnerable to their influence.</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 6.5</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig6_5.tif"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; Alex Gregory/ The New Yorker Collection/ <uri>www.cartoonbank.com</uri>. All Rights Reserved.</p>
</fig>
</sec>
<sec id="sec6_5">
<title>Summary</title>
<p>In this chapter we examined several topics related to influence in groups. First, we discussed early research on conformity and saw that several perspectives explain why people tend to conform. In addition, several factors (i.e., group size, moral conviction, having an ally, the intensity of indoctrination, the degree to which we identify with a group, communicator characteristics, and culture) influence how likely we are to conform. We also saw that social proof can be a powerful persuasive tactic because it relies on people&#x2019;s tendency to conform. We then saw that the presence of others can lead to deindividuation, social loafing, and social facilitation. Finally, for various reasons, groups tend to make more extreme decisions than do individuals (group polarization).</p>
</sec>
</body>
<back>
<fn-group>
<title>Note</title>
<fn id="fn6_1"><label>1</label><p>In all three cases, the organizations disregarded voters&#x2019; wishes. The boat was named &#x201C;Attenborough,&#x201D; the bridge was named &#x201C;Freedom Cycling Bridge,&#x201D; and Taylor Swift didn&#x2019;t play the concert, but she and four other organizations donated &#x0024;10,000 each to the school.<target target-type="page" id="page_156">156</target></p></fn>

</book-part>
<book-part book-part-type="chapter" id="chapter7">
<book-part-meta>
<title-group>
<label>7</label>
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_162">162</target>Language and Persuasion</title>
<alt-title alt-title-type="running-head">Language and Persuasion</alt-title>
</title-group>
<contrib-group>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Gass</surname>
<given-names>Robert H.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Seiter</surname>
<given-names>John S.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
</contrib-group>
</book-part-meta>
<body>
<p>WHEN WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE WROTE, &#x201C;A rose by any other name would smell as sweet,&#x201D; he found an eloquent way to note that words and the things they represent have no necessary connection. Indeed, you can&#x2019;t change a flower&#x2019;s scent just by renaming it &#x201C;armpit&#x201D; or &#x201C;manure.&#x201D; That being said, sometimes the names we give things affect how we react to those things. For example, because we attach meanings to words and names, we might react differently to a woman named Rose than we would to a man with the same name. As another illustration, consider the story of Adolf Hitler Campbell, a 3-year-old from Hunterdon County, New Jersey, whose parents were unable to get a supermarket to write the child&#x2019;s name on his birthday cake, presumably because of the connotations associated with such an infamous name. After meeting with resistance, the family, including Adolf&#x2019;s little sister, Joyce-Lynn Aryan Nation Campbell, hightailed it to Pennsylvania, where a Walmart employee was willing to produce their cake (&#x201C;Three-year-old Hitler,&#x201D; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_68">2008</xref>).</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_163">163</target>These examples illustrate an interesting property of language that is one of the main themes of this chapter. Specifically, because we associate meanings with words, words have the power to influence us. Indeed, the maxim &#x201C;The pen is mightier than the sword&#x201D; is correct. Words are the primary means of persuasion. They not only affect our perceptions, attitudes, beliefs, and emotions but they also create reality.</p>
<p>Because words are so important in the process of persuasion, the purpose of this chapter is to examine words and their effects on social influence. We begin by discussing the nature of symbols and of meaning, which are integral to understanding the relationship between language and persuasion.</p>
<sec id="sec7_1">
<title>Symbols, Meaning, and Persuasion: The Power of Babble</title>
<p>What is a <italic>symbol?</italic> A very basic definition is that a symbol is something that represents something else. Names are a good example. Your name represents who you are, just as the word <italic>pig</italic> represents an animal with a curly tail and slimy snout.</p>
<p>As noted above, one important characteristic of symbols is that they are arbitrary. In other words, symbols have no necessary connection to what they represent, although we sometimes seem to forget this. For example, S. I. Hayakawa (cited in <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_1">Adler, Rosenfeld, &#x0026; Towne, 1995</xref>) told the story of a little boy who thought that pigs were called pigs because they are so dirty. The word <italic>pig</italic>, however, has no direct connection to the curly-tailed animal, just as your name, although it may seem to fit, has no necessary connection to you&#x2014;that is, when your parents were trying to decide what to call you, there was nothing written in stone that said you had to be given a certain name. You could just as easily have been called Binky or Unga Bunga. Don&#x2019;t laugh&#x2014;the singer Frank Zappa named his children Moon Unit and Dweezil, and when tax authorities told a Swedish couple that they had to give their 5-year-old son a name or pay a fine, the couple named the child Brfxxccxxmnpcccclllmmnprxvclnmckssqlbb11116 (&#x201C;The best and worst,&#x201D; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_4">1996</xref>). As wrong as such names might seem, however, they&#x2019;re not. When it comes to finding representations of things, there&#x2019;s not one &#x201C;right&#x201D; word or symbol.</p>
<p>Because they are arbitrarily connected to what they represent, a second characteristic of symbols is that they are conventionalized, which means that if we want to use a symbol to communicate to someone else, we have to agree on the symbol&#x2019;s meaning. Without some measure of agreement on the meanings of words, communication and persuasion would be difficult, if not impossible. If you&#x2019;ve ever tried to communicate with someone who speaks a different language, you know this is true.</p>
<sec id="sec7_1_1">
<title>Connotative and Denotative Meaning: That&#x2019;s Not How I See It</title>
<p>Up to this point, we&#x2019;ve noted how important it is for communicators to agree on the meaning of the symbols they use. With that said, however, we are certain that, without telepathy, total agreement on the meaning of symbols is impossible. Of course, the degree to which people agree may depend on the type of meaning with which we&#x2019;re concerned. There are at least two meanings for every word. The first, the <italic>denotative</italic> meaning, is a word&#x2019;s direct, explicit dictionary definition.</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_164">164</target>The second type of meaning, <italic>connotative</italic>, refers to the thoughts and emotions associated with a word. As you might expect, the connotations associated with words vary widely from person to person. To illustrate, let&#x2019;s return to pigs. Although all of us might agree on the denotative meaning of the word <italic>pig</italic> (i.e., curly-tailed animal with snout), our attitudes associated with the word may be quite different. For instance, compared to a farmer&#x2019;s child who grew up sloppin&#x2019; hogs, a person who grew up reading books or watching movies about cuddly, talking pigs, such as Wilbur from <italic>Charlotte&#x2019;s Web</italic> or Babe from the movie <italic>Babe,</italic> would probably have a different view of pigs. In contrast, the members of some religious groups, Jews and Muslims, are forbidden to eat pork, which is perceived as unclean. Not long ago, in fact, a woman in Israel was sentenced to 50 years for depicting Allah as a pig.</p>
<p>As persuaders, it is important to recognize that the meanings of words are subjective. As scholars in the field of communication are fond of saying, &#x201C;Meanings are in people, not in words.&#x201D; Effective persuaders are aware of this and attempt to adapt their messages accordingly.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec7_1_2">
<title>Ultimate Terms: Speak of the Devil</title>
<p>Although connotative meanings tend to be more subjective than denotative meanings, sometimes the connotations associated with certain words are shared by large groups of people (i.e., societies and cultures). As a result, such words can be powerfully persuasive tools for motivating people. This is especially true of what <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_70">Richard Weaver (1953)</xref> labeled <italic>ultimate terms,</italic> which are words or phrases that are highly revered, widely accepted, and carry special power in a culture. According to Weaver, there are three types of ultimate terms. The first, <italic>god terms,</italic> carry the greatest blessing in a culture and demand sacrifice or obedience (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_23">Foss, Foss, &#x0026; Trapp, 1985</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_27">Hart, 1997</xref>). When Weaver wrote, he used terms such as <italic>fact</italic> and <italic>progress</italic> as examples of god terms. Modern-day god terms include <italic>family values</italic>, <italic>critical thinking</italic>, and <italic>teachable moment</italic>.</p>
<p>In contrast to god terms, Weaver argued that some terms, which he labeled <italic>devil terms,</italic> are perceived by a culture as associated with the absolutely abhorrent and disgusting. Examples of past devil terms include <italic>communism</italic>, <italic>Nazi</italic>, and <italic>fascist</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_23">Foss et al., 1985</xref>). Today, terms such as <italic>dead-beat dad</italic>, <italic>racist</italic>, <italic>terrorist</italic>, <italic>child molester</italic>, <italic>sweat shop</italic>, and <italic>hate crime</italic> might be considered devil terms. Because such terms represent what is evil or detestable to a culture, they can also be extremely persuasive (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_27">Hart, 1997</xref>).</p>
<p>Finally, Weaver labeled a third type, <italic>charismatic terms.</italic> Unlike god and devil terms, which are associated with something observable, charismatic terms, much like a charismatic person, have a power that in some ways is mysteriously given (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_23">Foss et al., 1985</xref>):
<disp-quote>
<p>&#x201C;Freedom&#x201D; and &#x201C;democracy&#x201D; are charismatic terms in our culture. We demand sacrifice in the name of these terms, yet the referents most of us attach to them are obscure and often contradictory. In fact, Weaver says, we may resist the attempt to define such terms, perhaps fearing that a term defined explicitly will have its charisma taken away.</p>
<attrib>(p. 66)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_165">165</target>What becomes clear, then, is that although god, devil, and charismatic terms have power, their ability to persuade is not stable; the connotations associated with such terms may change over time. For instance, calling someone a communist today would not have the same impact as it did in the days of Senator Joseph McCarthy.</p>
<p>Considering the power of ultimate terms, it is not surprising that politicians spend considerable amounts of money discovering the &#x201C;right&#x201D; terms to use in their ads and speeches. By way of example, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_39">Lemann (2000)</xref> noted that politicians use focus groups in order to discover specific words that should and should not be used in campaigns. The people in such groups watch ads and speeches while moving dials from right to left, indicating when they like or dislike what they are hearing and seeing. As a result, politicians learn an entirely new vocabulary of god and devil terms. For example, based on his research with focus groups, Frank Luntz, a political consultant, advises his candidates to say
<disp-quote>
<p>&#x201C;Department of Defense&#x201D; instead of &#x201C;Pentagon,&#x201D; &#x201C;opportunity scholarships&#x201D; instead of &#x201C;vouchers,&#x201D; &#x201C;tax relief&#x201D; instead of &#x201C;tax cuts,&#x201D; and &#x201C;climate change&#x201D; instead of &#x201C;global warming.&#x201D; The terms &#x201C;Washington&#x201D; and &#x201C;I.R.S.,&#x201D; Luntz says, always play as super-negative and should be attached to a policy you want to turn people against. &#x201C;Prosperity&#x201D; is super-positive. In general, words starting with an &#x201C;r&#x201D; or ending with an &#x201C;-ity&#x201D; are good&#x2014;hence &#x201C;reform&#x201D; and &#x201C;accountability&#x201D; work and &#x201C;responsibility&#x201D; really works.</p>
<attrib>(<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_39">Lemann, 2000</xref>, p. 100)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>Politicians might also use language to create other images. For instance, following the September 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and Pentagon, George W. Bush used words such as <italic>evil</italic>, <italic>those people</italic>, and <italic>demons</italic> to characterize people of Arab/ Middle Eastern descent. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_47">Merskin (2004)</xref> argued that Bush&#x2019;s speeches were carefully constructed and that the use of such words creates an enemy image by dehumanizing the &#x201C;other.&#x201D;</p>
<p>In addition to politicians, people in the business world are fond of using ultimate terms as persuasion devices. For instance, the word <italic>empowerment</italic> is a modern-day charismatic term on which marketers and advertisers have capitalized. Products and services that promise to <italic>empower</italic> people have become unavoidable. For instance, as a former suit salesman, one of the authors was regularly asked by customers where the &#x201C;power ties&#x201D; could be found or what was the &#x201C;power color&#x201D; for ties this year. The Hotel del Coronado in Southern California offers its guests &#x201C;power walks&#x201D; in the morning, and one of our colleagues told us about a seminar his sister attended that teaches its clients how to take &#x201C;power naps.&#x201D; Finally, one of the authors was recently notified that he is a <italic>Time</italic> magazine &#x201C;Power Subscriber.&#x201D; He can now read the news with gusto.</p>
<p>Other terms that seem to have appeal these days are <italic>extreme</italic>, <italic>alternative</italic>, and <italic>indie</italic>. Indeed, these words are popular now as &#x201C;rebel&#x201D; labels for things. There is, of course, alternative music and alternative clothes (e.g., baggy pants, visible boxer shorts, tattoos, piercings). There are also extreme sports, such as snowboarding, bungee jumping, skateboarding, and mountain biking. But does placing words in front of something necessarily make it cooler, or more &#x201C;edgy&#x201D;? Is &#x201C;alternative golf&#x201D; <target target-type="page" id="page_166">166</target>really alternative simply because the people playing it have man buns and wear tennis shoes (instead of golf shoes)? Does throwing some bacon and Monterey cheese on a Whopper really make it an &#x201C;Xtreme burger,&#x201D; as Burger King claims?</p>
<p>What is clear from this discussion is that words, when widely accepted as representing what is good or evil in a culture, have incredible persuasive potential. As we&#x2019;ve noted, being labeled a communist in the 1950s was hazardous. In the late 1600s, being labeled a witch in Salem, Massachusetts, was deadly. In the current political climate, labeling one&#x2019;s opponent as a socialist or fascist seems to be popular. A little later, we explore more thoroughly the power of such labeling. But first, we examine a topic related to ultimate terms.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec7_1_3">
<title>Aphorisms and Familiar Phrases: That Rings a Bell</title>
<p>Aphorisms are sayings, maxims, and adages that offer advice. They may be time honored (e.g., &#x201C;look before you leap&#x201D;) or more contemporary (&#x201C;love is fleeting, herpes is forever&#x201D;). They are found in economics, politics, religion, science, and everyday life. We see them on bumper stickers, political slogans, and advertising campaigns.</p>
<p>Aphorisms are persuasive because they are succinct, easily remembered, and appear to contain &#x201C;truisms.&#x201D; And because they are pithy, they require far less explanation. For example, the political expression &#x201C;A rising tide lifts all boats&#x201D; captures the essence of &#x201C;trickle-down economics,&#x201D; whereby economic policies that benefit the rich also benefit everyone else. Although some aphorisms may offer bad advice, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_40">Levine and Bleakley (2012)</xref> argue that aphorisms are undervalued in medicine. For example, simple adages, such as &#x201C;An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure&#x201D; and &#x201C;What you don&#x2019;t know can hurt you,&#x201D; are efficient ways of explaining the value of preventive medicine. In a similar vein, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_69">Vernon (2008)</xref> highlighted the importance of aphorisms in modern politics. &#x201C;In an age when the average attention span is apparently decreasing,&#x201D; he noted, &#x201C;the sagacious sound-bite could yet become the solution to&#x2014;rather than a symptom of&#x2014;the tendency to dumb down&#x201D; (p. 50). Texting, tweeting, and other social media seem ripe for persuasion in the form of aphorisms.</p>
<p>When are aphorisms most persuasive? <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_30">Howard (1997)</xref> conducted a study to find out when familiar phrases are influential. Using the elaboration likelihood model (see <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter2">Chapter 2</xref>) as a theoretical base, Howard suspected that familiar phrases would be most persuasive when people weren&#x2019;t able or motivated to scrutinize a message&#x2014; that is, familiar phrases, Howard thought, would act as peripheral cues to persuasion. To test this idea, he had groups of students listen to radio commercials trying to persuade them to plan for retirement. The commercials contained either familiar phrases (e.g., &#x201C;Don&#x2019;t put all your eggs in one basket&#x201D;) or literal phrases (e.g., &#x201C;Don&#x2019;t risk everything on a single venture&#x201D;). Half the students were able to carefully attend to the commercials, but the rest were distracted (i.e., they were asked to watch and record the nonverbal behavior of another person in the room). Results of the study indicated that the students who viewed commercials with familiar phrases were more persuaded than those who had not, but only when they were distracted. Those who were not distracted were persuaded (by strong arguments), regardless of whether familiar or literal phrases were used (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_30">Howard, 1997</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec7_1_4">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_167">167</target>Metaphors: One and the Same</title>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 7.1</label>
<caption><title>Cartoon from <italic>The New Yorker</italic> with doctor telling patient, &#x201C;Good news. The test results show it&#x2019;s a metaphor.&#x201D;</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig7_1.jpg"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; Leo Cullum/ The New Yorker Collection/ <uri>www.cartoonbank.com</uri>. All Rights Reserved.</p>
</fig>
<p>What is love? It depends, apparently, on whom you ask. Various singers, for instance, have called it &#x201C;a losing game&#x201D; (Amy Winehouse), &#x201C;a battlefield&#x201D; (Pat Benatar), &#x201C;a rose&#x201D; (Neil Young), &#x201C;a tower&#x201D; (U2), and &#x201C;a piano dropped from a fourth-story window&#x201D; (Ani DiFranco). In each of these cases, love was depicted through the use of metaphors, which are figures of speech that compare two things. In the process, aspects of one thing are transferred to the second (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_62">Sopory &#x0026; Dillard, 2002</xref>). It turns out that singers are not the only ones who are fond of using metaphors. Persuaders like them too, perhaps for good reason. Indeed, metaphors are persuasive (e.g., see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_17">Chang &#x0026; Yen, 2013</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_62">Sopory &#x0026; Dillard, 2002</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_66">Thibodeau, 2016</xref>). Thus, when Tropicana calls its orange juice &#x201C;Your daily ray of sunshine&#x201D; and Skittles invites you to &#x201C;taste the rainbow,&#x201D; they&#x2019;re not just being smart, they&#x2019;re clever foxes.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec7_1_5">
<title>The Power of Labeling</title>
<p>Earlier, we stated that names such as Dweezil and Brfxxccxxmnpcccclllmmn-prxvclnmckssqlbb11116 are not wrong, but we might have misled you. As arbitrary symbols, they work just fine, but pragmatically, how would you like to be saddled with such a name? Perhaps you wouldn&#x2019;t mind, but, whatever the case, one thing is clear: The name you use affects the way people respond to you. In fact, we know a person who changes his name every decade because he says that people respond differently to him depending on whether he&#x2019;s a Richard, a Jay, or a Hank. And research supports the idea that our friend is not simply a kook. For instance, according to the sources of Adler and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_1">1995</xref>), compared to names like Percival, Elmer, Isadore, and Alfreda, common names such as John, Michael, Karen, <target target-type="page" id="page_168">168</target>and Wendy are rated as more likable, active, and stronger. Moreover, when such names were placed on essays and evaluated by teachers, the more common names tended to receive higher grades than the less common ones. Finally, in a small study, a graduate student at MIT put 24 photos on the website <uri>www.hotornot.com</uri>. Interestingly, with different first names attached, the same photos were judged as more &#x201C;hot&#x201D; or more &#x201C;not&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_64">Strasser, 2005</xref>, p. E22).</p>
<p>It turns out that your name doesn&#x2019;t just affect how others behave or perceive you; it affects how you behave and perceive yourself as well. People, it seems, respond favorably to their own names. Several studies, for example, indicate that diners leave higher tips when food servers use their names than when they do not (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_61">Seiter, Givens, &#x0026; Weger, 2016</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_59">Seiter &#x0026; Weger, 2013</xref>). In one such study, food servers who had learned their customers&#x2019; names (by reading them on credit cards as customers paid their bills) addressed those customers in one of several ways. Specifically, they addressed customers (1) by using their first names (e.g., &#x201C;Thank you, Babbs.&#x201D;); (2) by using their titles plus last names (e.g., &#x201C;Thank you, Mr. Jones.&#x201D;); (3) by being formal yet impersonal (e.g., &#x201C;Thank you, sir/ma&#x2019;am.&#x201D;); or by using no form of address (i.e., &#x201C;Thank you.&#x201D;). Results of the study showed that diners left significantly higher tips in the first two conditions, with younger customers preferring to be addressed by their first names and older customers (age 54 and up) preferring to be addressed by their titles plus last names (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_59">Seiter &#x0026; Weger, 2013</xref>). Similarly, research shows that people purchased more (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_32">Howard &#x0026; Gengler, &#x0026; Jain, 1995</xref>) and complied more quickly (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_31">Howard &#x0026; Gengler, 1995</xref>) when their names were used than when their names were not used.</p>
<p>The power of labels extends far beyond the names that people are given (see <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box7_1">Box 7.1</xref>). To be sure, the labels we use to describe people or things reflect our attitudes about them and affect others&#x2019; reactions to the people and things labeled. For example, many years ago, children with divorced parents came from &#x201C;broken homes.&#x201D; Talk about stigmatization! Nowadays, we say children belong to &#x201C;single-parent&#x201D; or &#x201C;blended&#x201D; families.</p>
<p>The notion that the labels we use affect our attitudes about what we label lies at the heart of criticisms aimed at sexist language. For example, if a professor refers to all of his male students as &#x201C;men&#x201D; or &#x201C;sirs&#x201D; and to all of his female students as &#x201C;girls,&#x201D; &#x201C;broads,&#x201D; or &#x201C;dears,&#x201D; it not only says something about the professor&#x2019;s attitudes toward men and women but it also has the power to shape attitudes. Thus, when women are wrongly described in ways that make them seem inferior to men, people may begin to believe that women truly are inferior.</p>
<p>This is related to an idea that is commonly known as the <italic>Sapir&#x2013;Whorf hypothesis</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_57">Sapir, 1949</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_71">Whorf, 1956</xref>). The &#x201C;hard&#x201D; version of the hypothesis is deterministic, arguing that language dictates thought. The &#x201C;soft&#x201D; version is that language influences or affects thought. We subscribe to the latter view. For example, some languages assign gender to nouns. In German, doctor (<italic>der Doktor</italic>) is masculine, whereas nurse (<italic>die Krankenschwester</italic>) is feminine. If a German girl asks, &#x201C;What can I be when I grow up, mommy?&#x201D; the mother may be more likely to say a doctor than a nurse. Meanwhile, although it doesn&#x2019;t shove, the language provides a nudge.</p>
<p>The same dynamics are at work when people use racist language, which perpetuates the illusion that one racial group is superior to another. Ethnic/cultural references carry vastly different meanings. For example, Americans with an African <target target-type="page" id="page_169">169</target>heritage have been identified by terms such as <italic>African American, black, Negro, colored,</italic> and more derogatory terms as well. Such derogatory terms, whether racist or sexist, have the power to shape perceptions. One study, for example, found that referring to Mexican immigrants as &#x201C;illegal aliens&#x201D; (which connotes criminality) invoked greater prejudice than referring to them as &#x201C;undocumented workers&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_53">Pearson, 2010</xref>).</p>
<boxed-text id="box7_1">
<label><target target-type="page" id="page_170">170</target>Box 7.1</label>
<caption><title>Just a Spoonful of Sugar (and a Well-Chosen Name) Makes the Medicine Go Down</title></caption>
<p>In this chapter, we&#x2019;ve shown that names affect how we react to people. As you might have suspected, they also influence our reaction to products. For example, did you know that people react more favorably to sweaters and jellybeans that are given ambiguous color names (e.g., Moody Blue, Alpine Snow, and Monster Green) than less ambiguous color names (e.g., blueberry blue) (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_48">Miller &#x0026; Kahn, 2005</xref>)? Considering this: it&#x2019;s not surprising that a lot of attention goes into naming products. This may be especially true when naming prescription drugs.</p>
<p>Most of us refer to prescription drugs by their brand names. For example, we say &#x201C;Prozac&#x201D; rather than &#x201C;fluoxetine&#x201D; and &#x201C;Valium&#x201D; rather than &#x201C;diazepam.&#x201D; We do this because we&#x2019;ve been trained to by pharmaceutical manufacturers. Drug companies engage in &#x201C;branding&#x201D; when they air commercials and print ads urging us to &#x201C;ask your doctor about ____________.&#x201D; Is the Purple Pill right for you? Ask your doctor, but first go to the company&#x2019;s website for more online propaganda to offer your doctor.</p>
<p>Naming a drug is extremely important to how the drug is perceived by consumers/patients and, in turn, to the drug maker&#x2019;s bottom line (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_36">Kirkwood, 2003</xref>). The name has to be short (no more than three syllables), unique, easy to pronounce, easy to remember, and, importantly, it must convey the essence of what the drug does. But the name cannot be false or misleading, according to the FDA. Viagra, a pill for erectile dysfunction sufferers, is a classic case of the power of naming as it applies to drugs. The name Viagra was conjured up to convey two themes: vigor, virility, or vitality and power or force, such as the raw power of Niagara Falls. Yes, the Freudian association with a torrent of powerful water is intentional. Viagra sounds more manly than sildenafil citrate, its generic name, don&#x2019;t you think? Celebrex, an arthritis medicine, was so named because it suggests celebrating&#x2014;celebrating one&#x2019;s freedom to move without pain.</p>
<p>Companies such as the Brand Institute and Name Base/Medibrand are paid &#x0024;250,000 or more to come up with names for drugs that conjure up idealized associations. See if you can guess the positive associations pharmaceutical manufacturers are trying to create for the following drugs.
<list list-type="simple">
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Alleve: hint&#x2014;it <italic>alleviates</italic> something, right? (and that something happens to be minor arthritis pain).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Ambien: hint&#x2014;it creates a soothing <italic>ambience</italic> (to help you sleep better).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Claritin: hint&#x2014;it <italic>clarifies</italic> things, like watery eyes and a runny nose due to allergies.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Levitra: hint&#x2014;it <italic>levitates</italic> something (need we say more?).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Prevacid: hint&#x2014;it <italic>prevents</italic> something (and that something has to do with the last four letters of its name. Sounds better than its generic name, lansoprazole, doesn&#x2019;t it?).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Propecia: hint&#x2014;it <italic>propagates</italic> something (like hair restoration).</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
<p>The letters X and Z are popular in drug names because people think they sound scientific, hence names like Nexium, Paxil, Vioxx, Zanex, Zocor, and Zoloft. Now that you know how drugs are named, see if you can come up with effective names for hypothetical new drugs that would help Alzheimer&#x2019;s sufferers, diabetics, or kids with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).</p>
</boxed-text>
<p>Finally, consider these names: &#x201C;Citizens for the Environment,&#x201D; &#x201C;National Wetlands Coalition,&#x201D; and &#x201C;Greening Earth Society.&#x201D; Which would you say sounds the most environmentally friendly? Would it surprise you to learn that they&#x2019;re all names for anti-environmental think tanks? According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_13">Bricker (2014)</xref>, those names weren&#x2019;t accidental either. They were chosen on purpose to hide the organizations&#x2019; true intent: to prevent environmental regulations. By pretending to be environmentally friendly, they were more effective at manipulating public opinion (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_13">Bricker, 2014</xref>). This practice of posing as a nonprofit group in order to exploit others has been called <italic>astroturfing</italic> or <italic>astroturf activism</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_21">Durkee, 2017</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec7_1_6">
<title>Euphemisms and Doublespeak: Making the Worse Appear the Better and Vice Versa</title>
<p>In the fifth century BCE, a group of teachers known as Sophists created private schools in Athens, Greece. Students who wanted to learn from the Sophists were charged fees and were taught, among other subjects, oratory and persuasion. Soon, however, being a Sophist was so profitable that the occupation attracted a number of charlatans, who gave the Sophists a bad reputation (today, <italic>sophistry</italic> connotes deceitful or fallacious reasoning). In fact, Plato argued that the Sophists were more interested in lies than truths and more interested in dazzling audiences than in instructing them. Sophists, Plato argued, were skilled at making the &#x201C;worse cause appear the better&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_18">Corbett, 1971</xref>).</p>
<p>The practice of using words to make the worse appear the better (and vice versa) is still alive and well. Modern-day Sophists commonly use <italic>doublespeak</italic> (ambiguous or evasive language) and <italic>euphemisms</italic> (inoffensive terms substituted for offensive ones) to create messages with less sting. For example, in the business world, no one gets fired or laid off any more. Instead, companies engage in &#x201C;downsizing,&#x201D; &#x201C;right-sizing,&#x201D; or even &#x201C;bright-sizing.&#x201D; Mercedes no longer sells used cars; it sells &#x201C;pre-owned automobiles&#x201D; (try asking the Mercedes dealer, &#x201C;Was this car previously used, or simply owned?&#x201D;). Other companies give their employees job titles that sound more important or grandiose than they really are. A garbage collector is now a &#x201C;sanitation engineer.&#x201D; And, in Great Britain, legislation was introduced to substitute the stigmatized word <italic>prostitute</italic> with the phrase <italic>person who sells sex persistently</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_63">Stinchfield, 2007</xref>).</p>
<p>The use of doublespeak and euphemisms is rampant in other places as well. For example, the military refers to civilian casualties, killing enemy soldiers, and combat operations as &#x201C;collateral damage,&#x201D; &#x201C;servicing the target,&#x201D; and &#x201C;peacekeeping missions,&#x201D; respectively. Flight attendants don&#x2019;t talk about crashing in the ocean, only &#x201C;water landings&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_49">Murphy, 2001</xref>). In the medical field, terms such as <italic>assisted suicide</italic>, <italic>transsexual surgery</italic>, and <italic>cancer</italic> might instead be labeled <italic>hastening death</italic> (or <italic>death with dignity</italic>), <italic>gender reassignment</italic>, and <italic>a growth</italic>, respectively. Media reports use <target target-type="page" id="page_171">171</target>words like &#x201C;terrorism&#x201D; and &#x201C;terrorist&#x201D; less and less often, relying instead on ambiguous terms such as &#x201C;assailants,&#x201D; &#x201C;militants,&#x201D; &#x201C;extremists,&#x201D; and &#x201C;attackers&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_42">Matusitz, 2016</xref>). Politicians don&#x2019;t raise taxes or lie, they adopt &#x201C;revenue enhancing measures&#x201D; and &#x201C;misremember.&#x201D; And one of our friends is not allowed to have parties in her high school classes so, instead, has &#x201C;reinforcement for desirable behavior days.&#x201D; In the world of undertakers and funeral directors, people &#x201C;pass away&#x201D; rather than die, are &#x201C;interred&#x201D; rather than buried, and are called &#x201C;cases&#x201D; or &#x201C;patients&#x201D; rather than corpses. Instead of saying &#x201C;No,&#x201D; parents are fond of saying &#x201C;We&#x2019;ll see&#x201D; or &#x201C;Maybe later.&#x201D; And finally, in the abortion controversy, the words you use probably depend on the side you take. For example, <italic>pro-life</italic> is more value-laden than <italic>anti-abortion</italic> or <italic>anti-choice. Pro-choice</italic> avoids the term <italic>abortion</italic> altogether and sounds much nicer than <italic>anti-life</italic> or <italic>anti-anti-abortion.</italic></p>
<p>In the midst of all this word spinning, researchers (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_43">McGlone &#x0026; Batchelor, 2003</xref>) have identified two possible motives people might have for using euphemisms. First, people might use euphemisms because such words are less threatening and more respectful, therefore saving the &#x201C;face&#x201D; of audience members. Second, people might use euphemisms in order to be regarded as tasteful and sensitive, thereby saving their own &#x201C;face.&#x201D; To test these competing explanations, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_43">McGlone and Batchelor (2003)</xref> asked students communicating with someone via computer to describe various photographs, including two that depicted the aftermath of a urinating dog and a defecating parrot. Some students were led to believe that their identity would later be revealed to the person they were communicating with, while others were not. Results showed that the first group of students was more prone to using euphemisms, suggesting that saving their own face seemed to be their priority. It turns out, however, that when trying to create favorable impressions by spinning words, not <target target-type="page" id="page_172">172</target>just any euphemism will do. Indeed, a study by McGlone, Beck, and Pfeister (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_44">2006</xref>) found that because euphemisms with longer &#x201C;careers&#x201D; (e.g., &#x201C;use the restroom,&#x201D; &#x201C;go number two&#x201D;) are more familiar and draw less attention, people who use them are perceived more favorably than those who use newer, less familiar euphemisms (e.g., &#x201C;make room for tea,&#x201D; &#x201C;cast a pellet&#x201D;) (for more on doublespeak, see <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box7_2">Box 7.2</xref>).</p>
<boxed-text id="box7_2">
<label>Box 7.2</label>
<caption><title>If You Can&#x2019;t Say Something Nice, Spin It</title></caption>
<p>If you&#x2019;ve ever been asked to serve as a reference for someone, you know that it can be a complex business. Because what you say may no longer be confidential, saying something negative can lead to all kinds of personal and legal tangles. With that in mind, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_67">Robert Thornton (2003)</xref> has created the <italic>Lexicon of Inconspicuously Ambiguous Recommendations</italic> (LIAR). Here are some examples of what to say about people, depending on their flaws:
<disp-quote>
<p>If the person is inept: &#x201C;I recommend this man with no qualifications whatsoever.&#x201D; (p. 33)</p>
<p>If the person is extremely lazy: &#x201C;In my opinion, you will be very fortunate to get this person to work for you.&#x201D; (p. 5)</p>
<p>If the person is chronically absent: &#x201C;A man like him is hard to find.&#x201D; (p. 19)</p>
<p>If the person is dishonest: &#x201C;The man is simply an unbelievable worker.&#x201D; (p. 33)</p>
<p>If the person is a drunk: &#x201C;We remember the hours he spent working with us as happy hours.&#x201D; (p. 20)</p>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>Although we don&#x2019;t actually recommend using this lexicon, we think it is an entertaining way to illustrate how tricky language can be.</p>
</boxed-text>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 7.2</label>
<caption><title>Dilbert.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig7_2.tif"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; Scott Adams/Dist. by United Feature Syndicate, Inc.</p>
</fig>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec7_2">
<title>Language Intensity, Vividness, and Offensiveness</title>
<p>So far, we&#x2019;ve examined the nature of symbols and how they relate to the notion of meaning and the process of persuasion. We now turn to a discussion of specific variables related to language and persuasion. Three of these include language intensity, vividness, and offensiveness. These three variables are closely related. For example, when studying intense language, some authors include reviews of research on profanity, which, of course, has the potential to be quite offensive. However, it is possible to use intense language without being offensive. Moreover, although some definitions imply that vividness is a component or outcome of intense language (e.g., see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_26">Hamilton &#x0026; Stewart, 1993</xref>), others do not (e.g., see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_8">Bowers, 1964</xref>). Because these three topics are so closely related, we examine them together in this section. We then turn to a discussion of several theories that have been used to explain the relationship between intense language and persuasion.</p>
<sec id="sec7_2_1">
<title>&#x0023;&#x0023;&#x0040;!!!!&#x0023;&#x0023;: Profanity and Persuasion</title>
<p>Even though profanity, like any symbol, is arbitrary, it clearly plays a role in the process of persuasion, mostly because such strong connotations are associated with swearing. Perhaps this is why ancient rhetoricians like Quintilian advised against using profanity (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_56">Rothwell, 1971</xref>). Because profanity is so common (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_15">Cameron, 1969</xref>), <target target-type="page" id="page_173">173</target>some authors have asserted that it merits more attention as a form of persuasion. For instance, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_56">J. Dan Rothwell (1971)</xref> argued:
<disp-quote>
<p>Despite centuries of negative criticism, verbal obscenity has become a more frequent rhetorical device. It is successful in creating attention, in discrediting an enemy, in provoking violence, in fostering identification, and in providing catharsis. Its effects are governed by a variety of circumstances which need to be understood more fully. It has precipitated a police riot, brutal beatings, and even death. Hoping it will go away will not make it so. It is time to accept verbal obscenity as a significant rhetorical device and help discover appropriate responses to its use.</p>
<attrib>(p. 242)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>To explore more thoroughly people&#x2019;s perceptions of profanity, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_3">E. Scott Baudhuin (1973)</xref> gave students &#x201C;swear word&#x201D; booklets and asked the students to evaluate several words according to how offensive they were. Based on the students&#x2019; perceptions, he found that the words could be categorized into one of three categories: religious, excretory, and sexual. Which type of profanity did students find most offensive? The results of the study indicated that sexual words received the most negative responses. Religious profanities were perceived to be the least offensive.</p>
<p>If profanity is perceived to be offensive, are people who use it perceived negatively and are they less persuasive? Several studies have been conducted to test this question and most, but not all (e.g., see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_55">Rassin &#x0026; Van Der Heijden, 2005</xref>), indicate that if you want to be perceived as attractive, credible, and persuasive, you should clean up your language. For example, a study by Powell and his colleagues asked students to evaluate applicants who either did or did not cuss during a job interview. The researchers found that applicants with filthy mouths, regardless of their gender, were perceived as significantly less attractive than their counterparts (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_54">Powell et al., 1984</xref>). Similarly, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_7">Bostrom, Baseheart, and Rossiter (1973)</xref> found that, in general, using profanity damages a speaker&#x2019;s credibility. On the other hand, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_58">Scherer and Sagarin (2006)</xref> noted that society&#x2019;s stance about swearing has become more relaxed since many of these earlier studies were conducted. As such, they revisited the relationship between obscenity, credibility, and persuasion by having students listen to speeches in which a male speaker either did or did not use the word <italic>damn</italic>. Results showed that cussing had no effect on perceptions of the speaker&#x2019;s credibility, but when the speaker cussed, he was more persuasive than when he did not. Before you decide to become potty-mouthed the next time you&#x2019;re speaking, however, consider this: the students in this study were listening to speeches in favor of lowering tuition, a topic they presumably would be in favor of. In contrast, most of the classic studies on this topic asked participants to listen to topics they did not favor. In short, it may be that profanity is persuasive, but only under very specific conditions. Indeed, two studies found that perceptions of cussing depend on additional variables. Specifically, and not surprisingly, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_35">Johnson and Lewis (2010)</xref> found that people who cussed in formal settings were perceived as significantly less competent than people who cussed in less formal settings. Similarly, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_34">Johnson (2012)</xref> found that when cussing violated audience expectations in a positive way (e.g., people rated themselves as positively surprised by the cussing), ratings of the speaker&#x2019;s competence increased. Another study found that <target target-type="page" id="page_174">174</target>college students had mixed reactions when their instructors cussed. While the majority of students reported neutral to positive emotions, many reacted negatively (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_24">Generous, Houser, &#x0026; Frei, 2015</xref>).</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 7.3</label>
<caption><title>Dilbert.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig7_3.tif"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; Scott Adams/Dist. by United Feature Syndicate, Inc.</p>
</fig>
</sec>
<sec id="sec7_2_2">
<title>Political Correctness</title>
<p>Obviously, using profanity is not the only way to be verbally offensive. Earlier we discussed the notion of political correctness, which, in many ways, is all about being nonoffensive. Indeed, political correctness refers to issues of inclusive speech and advocacy of nonracist, nonageist, and nonsexist terminology (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_28">Hoover &#x0026; Howard, 1995</xref>).</p>
<p>Although political correctness is relevant to a wide range of contexts and topics, including issues of gender, race, ethnicity, age, socioeconomic status, and so forth, a study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_60">Seiter, Larsen, and Skinner (1998)</xref> focused on political correctness as it related to speaking about people with disabilities. In the study, college students read one of four hypothetical scenarios, each involving a person seeking donations who portrayed people with disabilities as &#x201C;normal&#x201D; (e.g., &#x201C;uses a wheelchair&#x201D;), &#x201C;heroic&#x201D; (e.g., &#x201C;handicapable&#x201D;), &#x201C;disabled&#x201D; (e.g., &#x201C;confined to a wheelchair&#x201D;), or &#x201C;pathetic&#x201D; (e.g., &#x201C;abnormal&#x201D;). After reading the scenarios, participants rated the speakers on scales measuring credibility and persuasiveness. Results of the study showed that, compared to communicators who portrayed people with disabilities as &#x201C;pathetic,&#x201D; communicators who portrayed such people as &#x201C;normal,&#x201D; &#x201C;heroic,&#x201D; and &#x201C;disabled&#x201D; were perceived as significantly more trustworthy and competent (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_60">Seiter et al., 1998</xref>). However, only communicators portraying people with disabilities as &#x201C;heroic&#x201D; and &#x201C;disabled&#x201D; were perceived as more persuasive than the communicator portraying such people as &#x201C;pathetic.&#x201D; How did the authors interpret these results? Perhaps by trying <italic>not</italic> to portray people with disabilities as victims, the communicator <target target-type="page" id="page_175">175</target>using &#x201C;normal&#x201D; language also did not demonstrate as urgent a need to help people with disabilities as the communicators using &#x201C;disabled&#x201D; and &#x201C;heroic&#x201D; language did (e.g., a child described as &#x201C;being confined to a wheelchair,&#x201D; or one who is aggrandized, may be perceived as requiring more help than a child described as &#x201C;using a wheelchair&#x201D;). Whatever the case, the results of this study suggest that individuals seeking donations for people with disabilities face a dilemma: How can a person raise money to help people with disabilities while at the same time describing people with disabilities in a politically correct and dignified manner?</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 7.4</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig7_4.tif"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; Robert Mankoff/The New Yorker Collection/<uri>www.cartoonbank.com</uri></p>
</fig>
</sec>
<sec id="sec7_2_3">
<title>The Effects of Vividness: A Picture&#x2019;s Worth a Thousand Words</title>
<p>According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_51">Nisbett and Ross (1980)</xref>, vivid information captures and holds our attention and excites our imagination because it is &#x201C;emotionally interesting, concrete and imagery-provoking, and proximate in a sensory, temporal, or spatial way&#x201D; (p. 45). By way of example, it&#x2019;s more vivid to say &#x201C;the glass crashed and shattered into pieces&#x201D; than it is to say &#x201C;the glass broke.&#x201D; Although previous research is somewhat inconsistent, a meta-analysis of over 40 studies found that vivid messages tend to be more persuasive than pallid ones (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_6">Blonde &#x0026; Girandola, 2016</xref>). This is especially true when vividness helps receivers recall information.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec7_2_4">
<title>Language Intensity</title>
<disp-quote>
<p>&#x201C;You are shockingly stupid&#x201D; versus &#x201C;You are not real smart.&#x201D;</p>
<p>&#x201C;The lumber industry is raping our forests&#x201D; versus &#x201C;The lumber industry is cutting down a lot of trees.&#x201D;</p>
</disp-quote>
<p>In the preceding pairs of phrases, which phrase has the strongest connotative meaning? Obviously, the first phrase in each pair. The terms <italic>shockingly</italic> and <italic>raping</italic> <target target-type="page" id="page_176">176</target>are more intense than terms found in the other phrases. Language that is intense is emotional, metaphorical, opinionated, specific, forceful, extreme, and evaluative. For that reason, perhaps, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_8">Bowers (1964)</xref> defined <italic>language intensity</italic> as &#x201C;the quality of language which indicates the degree to which the speaker&#x2019;s attitude deviates from neutrality&#x201D; (p. 215). Clearly, someone who compares &#x201C;cutting down trees&#x201D; to &#x201C;rape&#x201D; is far from neutral in his or her attitudes about the lumber industry. But is a person who uses such language persuasive? The best answer to that question may be &#x201C;it depends.&#x201D; To be sure, several variables have been found that affect the persuasiveness of intense language. With that said, let&#x2019;s examine four different theories that attempt to explain when and why intense language does or does not persuade.</p>
<p>First, <italic>reinforcement theory</italic> assumes that people are motivated to avoid pain and seek pleasure. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_10">Bradac, Bowers, and Courtright (1979</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_11">1980</xref>) assumed that the same is true when people are being persuaded. If a person generally agrees with the position advocated by a source, the person will find it rewarding and evaluate the source positively. The reverse is true if the person generally disagrees with the position advocated by the source. Language intensity is believed to enhance this effect. Specifically, if the listener generally agrees with the speaker, when the speaker throws some forceful language at the listener, the listener is even more motivated to agree. However, a listener who generally disagrees will react even more negatively than he or she normally would when the speaker uses intense language (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_11">Bradac et al., 1980</xref>).</p>
<p>A second perspective on language intensity is found in <italic>language expectancy theory</italic> (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_14">Burgoon &#x0026; Siegel, 2004</xref>). This theory assumes that we have expectations about what types of language are normal to use when trying to persuade other people. For example, we may not think it is normal for a speaker to use intense words such as <italic>rape</italic> and <italic>shockingly</italic>. According to language expectancy theory, when persuaders violate our expectations concerning normal language, those violations can either help or hurt the effectiveness of the persuasive message, depending on whether the violations are perceived in a positive or negative way. How violations are perceived depends on who is using the language. For instance, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_14">Burgoon and Siegel (2004)</xref> noted that highly credible sources are granted a &#x201C;wider bandwidth&#x201D; of acceptable communication than those with low credibility. As such, sources with low credibility are likely to be perceived in a negative way when they use language that is aggressive and intense. This, in turn, leads them to be less persuasive. The reverse is true for highly credible sources. For sources with non-established levels of credibility, using intense language may cause them to be perceived as less credible (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_33">Jensen, Averbeck, Zhang, &#x0026; Wright, 2013</xref>).</p>
<p>Third, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_26">Hamilton and Stewart (1993)</xref> have extended <italic>information processing theory</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_45">McGuire, 1968</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_46">1989</xref>) to explain the effects of intensity on persuasion. The theory argues that to be persuaded, you must first attend to and comprehend a persuasive message. If you attend to and comprehend the message, you then compare your own position on the message to the position that&#x2019;s being argued by the source. Ultimately, you may either accept or reject the source&#x2019;s position. According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_26">Hamilton and Stewart (1993</xref>; also see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_19">Craig &#x0026; Blankenship, 2011</xref>), language intensity affects this process by making a source&#x2019;s position on an issue seem more extreme compared to your own position. This can be good, up to a point. In general, some discrepancy between a persuader and a receiver&#x2019;s positions leads to <target target-type="page" id="page_177">177</target>increased attention and, therefore, more attitude change. However, as we noted in our discussion of social judgment theory in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter5">Chapter 5</xref>, too much discrepancy may lead a receiver to reject a message or to scrutinize a message so much that he or she fails to attend to all of the message&#x2019;s content. In addition, intense language tends to be more specific and vivid.</p>
<p>Finally, <italic>communication accommodation theory</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_25">Giles &#x0026; Wiemann, 1987</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_65">Street &#x0026; Giles, 1982</xref>) argues that when we communicate with others we adjust our style of speaking to their style in order to gain approval and increase communication efficiency. For example, we may try to talk the same way others talk so that they will like us better. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_2">Aune and Kikuchi (1993)</xref> conducted a study to see if this theory would predict the effectiveness of messages that either were or were not intense. In the study, speakers delivered intense and nonintense messages to people whose language style could be categorized as either intense or nonintense. Results of the study supported communication accommodation theory. Specifically, speakers using intense language were most persuasive with people who use intense language, whereas speakers using nonintense language were most persuasive with people who use nonintense language. Speakers who &#x201C;matched&#x201D; the style of their audience also were perceived as more credible.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec7_3">
<title>Powerless Language and Persuasion: Um&#x2019;s the Word</title>
<p>As a student, one of the authors had two speech professors who did not like the utterance <italic>um</italic> too much. One called <italic>ums</italic> social burps. The other, when listening to speeches, smacked her pencil on a desk whenever the author said <italic>um</italic>. It was not fun, but it beat electrical shocks. In retrospect, the author supposes he should be grateful to these professors, because <italic>ums</italic>, as well as a number of other utterances, prevent people who use them from being persuasive. Why? Because such utterances create the perception of <italic>powerlessness.</italic> In case you want to avoid using them when you talk, here is a list of such speech mannerisms with some examples in italics (also see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_12">Bradley, 1981</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_22">Erickson, Lind, Johnson, &#x0026; O&#x2019;Barr, 1978</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_37">Lakoff, 1973</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_38">1975</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_41">Lowenberg, 1982</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_50">Newcombe &#x0026; Arnkoff, 1979</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_52">O&#x2019;Barr, 1982</xref>):
<list list-type="bullet">
<list-item><p><italic>Hesitations</italic> (signal uncertainty or anxiety): &#x201C;<italic>Well,</italic> I, <italic>uh, you know, um,</italic> would like to borrow a dollar.&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Hedges</italic> (qualify the utterance in which they occur): &#x201C;I <italic>guess I sort of</italic> like you and <italic>kind of</italic> want to know you.&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Intensifiers</italic> (fortify the utterance): &#x201C;I <italic>really</italic> believe that and agree with you <italic>very</italic> much.&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Polite forms (indicate deference and subordination): &#x201C;<italic>Excuse me, if you wouldn&#x2019;t mind too much, I&#x2019;d appreciate</italic> it if you&#x2019;d <italic>please</italic> shut the door. <italic>Thank you</italic>.&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Tag questions</italic> (lessens the force of a declarative sentence): &#x201C;This is fun, <italic>don&#x2019;t you think?</italic> Much more fun than yesterday, <italic>isn&#x2019;t it?</italic>&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Disclaimers</italic> (utterances offered before a statement that anticipate doubts, signal a problem, or ask for understanding): &#x201C;I know this is a <italic>really dumb question,</italic> but &#x2026; ?&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Deictic phrases</italic> (phrases indicating something outside the speaker&#x2019;s vicinity): &#x201C;That man <italic>over there</italic> is the one who stole my wallet.&#x201D;</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_178">178</target>As noted previously, a considerable amount of research indicates that using these powerless forms of speech can prevent you from being persuasive (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_22">Erickson et al., 1978</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_50">Newcombe &#x0026; Arnkoff, 1979</xref>), even when you are using strong arguments (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_29">Hosman &#x0026; Siltanen, 2011</xref>). However, the relationship between power and speech may depend on additional factors. Two are noteworthy.</p>
<p>First, the type of powerless language a person uses may influence how he or she is perceived. Specifically, one problem with some research on powerless language is that it has lumped together all of the powerless forms previously discussed. However, some research indicates that this may not be the best idea, because not all the forms may be detrimental to a speaker. For instance, in one study, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_9">Bradac and Mulac (1984)</xref> found that using polite forms actually enhanced speakers&#x2019; credibility. Moreover, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_20">Durik, Britt, Reynolds, and Storey (2008)</xref> found that the use of colloquial-sounding hedges (e.g., &#x201C;kind of,&#x201D; &#x201C;sort of&#x201D;) undermined persuasive attempts, but the use of professional-sounding hedges (e.g., &#x201C;probably,&#x201D; &#x201C;may,&#x201D; &#x201C;seem to&#x201D;) did not.</p>
<p>Second, the type of language that is most effective may depend on who is using it. For example, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_5">Blankenship and Craig (2007)</xref> found that when low credible sources used tag questions, the sources were less persuasive regardless of whether their messages contained strong or weak arguments. In contrast, when highly credible sources used tag questions, the sources were more persuasive, but only when their messages contained strong arguments. Why? Presumably, if you already believe a source is credible, tag questions get you to think more carefully about the message being presented. If the message is strong, you will be more persuaded by it (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_5">Blankenship &#x0026; Craig, 2007</xref>).</p>
<p>In addition to sources&#x2019; credibility, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref7_16">Carli (1990)</xref> found that sources&#x2019; and receivers&#x2019; sex affects the persuasiveness of language. Specifically, females were persuasive with men when they used powerless forms of speech but persuasive with females when using powerful speech. For male speakers, it did not matter what form of speech was used. This may mean that women, compared to men, need to be more sensitive about the style of speech they use when trying to be persuasive. Clearly, along with the topics we discussed earlier, the results of this study suggest that men have negative stereotypes about women who use powerful speaking styles.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec7_4">
<title>Summary</title>
<p>In this chapter, we examined the role of language in the process of persuasion. We began with an examination and definition of the term <italic>symbol.</italic> Symbols are arbitrary but have the power to shape perceptions and construct social reality. Symbols also have connotative and denotative meanings, both of which affect persuasion. For example, we examined ultimate terms, which, because of their strong connotations, have incredible persuasive power in a culture. We also examined the power of labels and how, oftentimes, through the use of euphemisms and doublespeak, persuaders attempt to lessen (or strengthen) the connotative impact of a word. Finally, we discussed several language variables that affect persuasion. By making their words more vivid, intense, offensive, and powerless/powerful, persuaders affect the way audiences respond to their messages.<target target-type="page" id="page_179">179</target></p>
</sec>
</body>
