</book-part>
<book-part book-part-type="chapter" id="chapter8">
<book-part-meta>
<title-group>
<label>8</label>
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_183">183</target>Nonverbal Influence</title>
<alt-title alt-title-type="running-head">Nonverbal Influence</alt-title>
</title-group>
<contrib-group>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Gass</surname>
<given-names>Robert H.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Seiter</surname>
<given-names>John S.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
</contrib-group>
</book-part-meta>
<body>
<p>SHELLEY&#x2019;S BOYFRIEND WAS PROBABLY frowning as he watched one of this book&#x2019;s authors reach out and take Shelley&#x2019;s hand. At the time, the author was not thinking about Shelley&#x2019;s boyfriend, though; he was thinking about how pretty Shelley was. He remembers leaning toward her and gazing into her eyes. Her lips tightened into a grin as she squeezed the author&#x2019;s hand. He&#x2019;d never talked to her before this and was nervous, but even so, he had no trouble finding words. They came out smooth and suggestive. &#x201C;Pass the salt,&#x201D; he whispered. And, after swallowing hard and leaning even closer, he repeated those words&#x2014;&#x201C;Pass the salt, pass the salt&#x201D;&#x2014;again and again.</p>
<p>Don&#x2019;t get the wrong idea. Even after writing a book about persuasion, neither author is even close to Don Juan status. When one of us met Shelley years ago, he was a sophomore in college, where he, Shelley, and Shelley&#x2019;s boyfriend were taking an acting class. As part of an exercise, the instructor paired each of us students up with a stranger and asked us to convince the rest of the class that we were deeply and passionately in love. &#x201C;Pass the salt,&#x201D; however, was the only phrase we were allowed to use.</p>
<p>In retrospect, the author is not sure how persuasive an actor he was, but he did learn something that day: The words &#x201C;I love you&#x201D; are not all they are cracked up to be. Sure, it&#x2019;s nice to hear those words, but if you can convey the same meaning with &#x201C;pass the salt,&#x201D; who needs them? The point here is that, when we are trying to <target target-type="page" id="page_184">184</target>interpret meaning, there is a lot more involved than simply words. As the old saying goes, &#x201C;It&#x2019;s not what a person says, it&#x2019;s <italic>how</italic> the person says it that&#x2019;s important,&#x201D; which is why it is crucial that we understand something about nonverbal communication&#x2014; how we say things through the use of gestures, body movements, touch, spatial behavior, appearance, eye contact, and so forth. In this chapter, we are interested in focusing on one particular question about nonverbal communication&#x2014;that is, in what way does nonverbal communication influence the process of persuasion?</p>
<p>According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_22">Burgoon (1994)</xref>, nonverbal communication plays an important role in the process of social influence for several reasons. First, we can use nonverbal behavior to create certain impressions of ourselves. If we are successful in making ourselves appear powerful, authoritative, credible, or attractive, we may also be more persuasive. (For a different twist on nonverbal behavior and impression management, see <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box8_1">Box 8.1</xref>.) Second, through the use of nonverbal behaviors, people can establish intimate relationships. In other words, nonverbal cues, such as touch, can be influential in developing rapport. Third, nonverbal behaviors can heighten or distract attention from persuasive messages that are likely to reinforce learning. For example, a teacher can use nonverbal cues to get his or her students to pay more attention to a message, and a heckler can use such tactics to distract listeners. Fourth, through non-verbal cues, a person can be reinforced to imitate a model&#x2019;s behavior. Fifth, nonverbal cues can be used to signal a person&#x2019;s expectations and elicit behavior that conforms to those expectations. For example, a simple frown can inform a child that he or she is not behaving appropriately. And finally, nonverbal behaviors can be used to violate people&#x2019;s expectations so as to distract them. Later in the chapter, for instance, we&#x2019;ll see that standing too close to another person can, under some circumstances, make that person more compliant.</p>
<p>Of course, we don&#x2019;t have the space needed in one chapter to discuss every aspect of nonverbal communication. We have, therefore, chosen to focus on those areas that we find the most important and intriguing. We begin by discussing a model that suggests that the relationship between nonverbal behavior and persuasion is quite simple.</p>
<boxed-text id="box8_1">
<label>Box 8.1</label>
<caption><title>Smirks and Sneers Behind Your Back: Influencing Impressions of Others</title></caption>
<p><italic>Impression management theory</italic> (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_34">Goffman, 1959</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_99">Schlenker, 1980</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_121">Tedeschi &#x0026; Reiss, 1981</xref>) suggests that people control their behaviors&#x2014;particularly nonverbal behaviors&#x2014;in order to create desired impressions of themselves (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_71">Leathers, 1997</xref>). If you want to be liked, for instance, you might smile. If you want to be intimidating, you might frown. Clearly, however, our nonverbal behavior can affect impressions other than those made about us. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_102">Seiter (2001)</xref>, for example, argued that impression management theory should be expanded to include the ways in which we strategically attempt to control impressions made of others. Although such attempts might be aimed at making others appear better, Seiter maintained that sometimes our attempts to appear honest and desirable are undermined by others&#x2014;that is, sometimes other people may attempt to make us appear undesirable and dishonest.</p>
<p>One context in which such attempts might occur is a political debate. Indeed, because candidates&#x2019; versions of a story often differ, they may look for opportunities to make their opponents appear <target target-type="page" id="page_185">185</target>deceptive. For instance, in the last several presidential debates, where split screens allowed viewers to see both the speaker and nonspeaking debater simultaneously, candidates were criticized for their silent, yet derogatory, background behavior.</p>
<p>To see if such background behavior is effective in undermining an opponent, Seiter and his colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_101">Seiter, 1999</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_102">2001</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_103">Seiter, Abraham, &#x0026; Nakagama, 1998</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_107">Seiter &#x0026; Weger, 2005</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_108">Seiter, Weger, Kinzer, &#x0026; Jensen, 2009</xref>) conducted studies that asked students to watch one of four versions of a televised debate. One version used a single-screen presentation showing only the speaker, while the other three versions used a split-screen presentation in which the speaker&#x2019;s opponent displayed constant, occasional, or no nonverbal disbelief regarding the content of the speaker&#x2019;s message. In other words, in some versions of the tape, the nonspeaking debater was shown shaking his head, rolling his eyes, and frowning while his opponent was speaking. After watching the videos, students rated the debaters. Results indicated that, in general, when any background disbelief was communicated by the nonspeaking debater, the speaker&#x2019;s credibility improved (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_103">Seiter et al., 1998</xref>). However, when the audience was led to be suspicious of the debaters&#x2019; truthfulness, moderate background behavior on the part of the nonspeaking debater made his speaking opponent appear more deceptive (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_102">Seiter, 2001</xref>). Be warned, however. If you&#x2019;re ever in a debate and are thinking about silently deriding your opponent, you&#x2019;ll probably hurt your own image in the process. To be sure, the studies also found that any derogatory background behavior led the nonspeaking debater to be perceived as more deceptive, less credible, less likable, and inappropriate (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_101">Seiter, 1999</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_102">2001</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_108">Seiter et al., 2009</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_107">Seiter &#x0026; Weger, 2005</xref>). Finally, if an opponent ever confronts you with such nonverbal behaviors, research generally suggests that you&#x2019;ll be perceived as most effective if you politely and directly ask him or her to stop (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_130">Weger, Seiter, Jacobs, &#x0026; Akbulut, 2010</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_131">2013</xref>).</p>
</boxed-text>
<sec id="sec8_1">
<title>The Direct Effects Model of Immediacy</title>
<p>People who study nonverbal behavior use the term <italic>immediacy</italic> to describe actions that communicate warmth, closeness, friendliness, and involvement with other people (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_3">Andersen, 2004</xref>). If, for instance, you smile, make a lot of eye contact, nod, and lean forward when talking to someone else, you are demonstrating some common immediacy cues. According to the <italic>direct effects model of immediacy</italic> (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_3">Andersen, 2004</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_100">Segrin, 1993</xref>), there is a simple relationship between nonverbal behavior and social influence&#x2014;that is, warm, involving, immediate behaviors lead to increased persuasion (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_3">Andersen, 2004</xref>). As you&#x2019;ll see in the remainder of this chapter, a considerable amount of research supports this model and the effectiveness of immediacy behaviors in a number of different contexts, including intercultural (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_12">Booth-Butterfield &#x0026; Noguchi, 2000</xref>), medical (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_62">Kafetsios, Anagnostopoulos, Lempesis, &#x0026; Valindra, 2014</xref>), educational (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_79">Mazer &#x0026; Stowe, 2016</xref>), organizational (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_122">Teven, 2007</xref>), athletic (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_124">Turman, 2008</xref>), and interpersonal settings (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_53">Hinkle, 1999</xref>). However, some research presents a more complicated picture. As we turn now to a discussion of the different types of nonverbal behavior, you will see that demonstrating immediacy may generally be a good rule of thumb, but an awareness of other factors may be necessary to sort out the sometimes complex relationship between nonverbal behaviors and persuasion.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec8_2">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_186">186</target>Types of Nonverbal Communication</title>
<p>Before discussing specific forms of nonverbal behavior, we think it&#x2019;s important to point out that such behaviors are interdependent. By way of illustration, we should probably tell you that the &#x201C;Shelley story&#x201D; is not yet over. There&#x2019;s still the part about Shelley&#x2019;s boyfriend, Louis, who responded to the &#x201C;pass the salt&#x201D; line by attacking the author after class. With eyes wide and fists clinched, Louis called the author a &#x201C;lousy something-or-other&#x201D; and then slugged him. In response, the author merely chuckled, because he could see that Louis was only having fun; Louis was smiling, and the punch was only a playful &#x201C;tap.&#x201D;</p>
<p>As it turns out, Louis&#x2019;s behavior was probably not all that uncommon. Indeed, like us, you may have seen people (probably men) play-fighting as a means of greeting one another. But how do we know that they are only playing? We know because we don&#x2019;t see <italic>only</italic> their punches or <italic>only</italic> their eyes; we see other cues that help us interpret their messages. In other words, although there are many types of nonverbal communication, they do not occur in isolation. Nonverbal behaviors occur simultaneously, and how we interpret one behavior can affect our interpretations of other behaviors. Thus, although we discuss each of the following codes separately, it is important to realize that each code rarely operates alone.</p>
<p>With that said, we now examine seven types of nonverbal communication that are important in the process of persuasion: kinesics, haptics, proxemics, chronemics, artifacts, physical appearance, and paralinguistics.</p>
<sec id="sec8_2_1">
<title>Kinesics: Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes, Knees and Toes</title>
<p>The word <italic>kinesics</italic> was derived from the Greek term <italic>kinein,</italic> which means &#x201C;to move&#x201D; and refers to the study of eye contact, facial expressions, gestures, and body movements and posture. We start by taking a look at eye contact.</p>
<sec id="sec8_2_1_1">
<title>The Eyes Have It</title>
<p>Several years ago, one of the authors was involved in a study that investigated the influence strategies used by panhandlers when attempting to get money from strangers (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_97">Robinson, Seiter, &#x0026; Acharya, 1992</xref>). As part of the study, 36 panhandlers were interviewed, and several claimed that, before even asking for money, the first thing they tried to do was establish eye contact with whoever was passing by. Without eye contact, the beggars argued, it was easier for their &#x201C;targets&#x201D; to ignore them and walk on by.</p>
<p>If eye contact helps beggars get more money, does it also help communicators to be more persuasive? Some evidence seems to support this notion. For example, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_86">Murphy (2007)</xref> found that people who looked more at their interaction partners while speaking and listening were perceived as more intelligent than those who did not. Moreover, in a meta-analysis of several studies on eye contact, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_100">Segrin (1993)</xref> found that in all but one study, gazing at listeners produced more compliance than averting gaze.</p>
<p>Conversely, communicators who do not use eye contact may have problems being persuasive. Gu&#x00E9;guen and Jacob (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_45">2002</xref>), for example, found that people, especially females, were less likely to comply when persuaders quickly averted their glance than when they maintained eye contact. Similarly, three studies by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_134">Wirth, Sacco, Hugenberg and Williams (2010)</xref> indicated that people who perceived averted eye gaze from others, compared to those who did not, felt more ostracized, more negative emotions (e.g., anger and sadness), and more temptation to perform aggressive behaviors. Finally, a study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_87">Neal and Brodsky (2008)</xref> found that expert witnesses who maintained less eye contact with jurors and attorneys were perceived as less credible than witnesses who maintained more eye contact. Perhaps this is why law students are taught to block eye contact between witnesses and jurors during cross-examination while encouraging their witnesses to make eye contact with jurors during direct examination (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_16">Brodsky, 1991</xref>).</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_187">187</target>Before concluding this section, we should note that more eye contact is not always associated with greater persuasion. Indeed, some situations call for less eye contact. That&#x2019;s because a fixed gaze can be perceived as a challenge or threat. Stare at someone too long on a New York subway, and you might find someone saying, &#x201C;Hey, you lookin&#x2019; at me?&#x201D; or &#x201C;Whachu lookin&#x2019; at?&#x201D;</p>
<p>Finally, a classic study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_65">Kleinke (1980)</xref> illustrates that the effectiveness of eye contact may depend on other factors, such as the legitimacy of the request you make. In the study, persuaders were instructed to approach people in an airport and ask them for money. Some of the targets were told that the money would be used to make an important phone call (a legitimate request), whereas others were told that the money would be used to pay for a candy bar or gum (an illegitimate request). It turned out that people who thought the persuader needed to make a phone call gave more money, but only when the persuader looked at them. Interestingly, however, eye contact actually decreased compliance when the persuader made an illegitimate request (see <xref ref-type="table" rid="tbl8_1">Table 8.1</xref>). Perhaps, as the researcher suggested, looking away while making an illegitimate request makes a person seem more humble or embarrassed, thereby increasing his or her persuasiveness by winning the sympathy of others (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_65">Kleinke, 1980</xref>).</p>
<table-wrap id="tbl8_1">
<label>Table 8.1</label>
<caption><title>Illustration of Kleinke&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_65">1980</xref>) Results</title></caption>
<oasis:table frame="topbot" colsep="0" rowsep="0">

<oasis:colspec colnum="1" colname="col1" align="left"/>

</table-wrap-foot>
</table-wrap>
</sec>
<sec id="sec8_2_1_2">
<title>About Face</title>
<p>Of all possible facial expressions, smiling has probably been studied the most. To be sure, research has shown that by smiling, waitresses earn more tips (Tidd &#x0026; Lockard, cited in <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_44">Gu&#x00E9;guen &#x0026; Fischer-Lokou, 2004</xref>), therapists are judged to be warmer and more competent (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_71">Leathers, 1997</xref>), job interviewees create positive impressions of themselves (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_129">Washburn &#x0026; Hakel, 1973</xref>) and are more likely to get jobs (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_31">Forbes &#x0026; Jackson, 1980</xref>), female hitchhikers get more rides (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_44">Gu&#x00E9;guen &#x0026; Fischer-Lokou, 2004</xref>), students accused of cheating are treated with greater leniency <target target-type="page" id="page_188">188</target>(<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_68">LaFrance &#x0026; Hecht, 1995</xref>), and teachers inspire students to pay more attention (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_98">Saigh, 1981</xref>). One study found that right after being smiled at, people were more willing to help a third person who dropped some computer disks on the ground (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_42">Gu&#x00E9;guen &#x0026; De Gail, 2003</xref>).</p>
<p>We do not, however, want to give you the impression that influence is always as easy as a smile. As noted in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter4">Chapter 4</xref>, persuaders need to come across as trustworthy and sincere. Not all smiles accomplish this goal, however. One study, for example, found that when smiles appear quickly, the smiling person is perceived as less trustworthy and attractive than when smiles have a slower onset (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_67">Krumhuber, Manstead, &#x0026; Kappas, 2007</xref>). Besides that, smiling may not fit the situation. Consider, for instance, advertisements seeking donations for starving children. One study found that when 4- and 8-year-olds were pictured with sad facial expressions, they generated more sympathy and donations than when they were pictured with smiles (Baberini, Coleman, Slovic, &#x0026; V&#x00E4;stfj&#x00E4;ll, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_7">2015</xref>). Additionally, in situations where an angry or dominant demeanor would be most persuasive, positive and likable facial expressions could be counterproductive. For instance, one study found that, although smiling and nodding were more persuasive when used by people of equal status, dominant behaviors are more effective in established hierarchies (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_82">Mehrabian &#x0026; Williams, 1969</xref>). Another found that while politically conservative audiences prefer leaders with dominant faces, politically liberal audiences prefer leaders with non-dominant ones (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_69">Laustsen &#x0026; Petersen, 2016</xref>). And still another found that angry facial expressions led audiences to scrutinize messages and, consequently, to prefer stronger over weaker arguments (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_24">Calanchini, Moons, &#x0026; Mackie, 2016</xref>).</p>
<p>The situational nature of facial expressions and other nonverbal behaviors is even more apparent if you consider <italic>communication accommodation theory</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_32">Giles &#x0026; Wiemann, 1987</xref>), which we discussed in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter7">Chapter 7</xref>. According to the theory, rather than using any one type of nonverbal behavior, a persuader should try to build rapport with others by <italic>mirroring</italic> or <italic>mimicking</italic> their nonverbal cues. In other words, smile when people smile and frown when people frown. For example, in one study (Gu&#x00E9;guen, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_46">2009</xref>), 66 males interacted in speed-dating sessions with women who had been instructed beforehand either to mimic or not mimic the males&#x2019; behavior (e.g., the mimickers stroked their faces or crossed their arms when the males did). Results indicated that women who mirrored the males&#x2019; behavior, compared to those who did not, were chosen more often to give their contact information and were rated as being more sexually attractive. Another study found that negotiators who mirrored others&#x2019; behavior were more likely to reach a deal than those who did not (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_73">Maddux, Mullen, &#x0026; Galinsky, 2008</xref>).</p>
<p>Interestingly, it may also be the case that mimicking another person&#x2019;s behavior makes us more susceptible to that person&#x2019;s persuasive attempts. In one study, for example, people who mimicked the movements of a person presenting a product had more intention to buy the product than people who did not mimic the person (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_114">Stel, Mastop, &#x0026; Strick, 2011</xref>). Another study showed that people who had been mimicked were more helpful and generous than those who had not been (van Baaren, Holland, Kawakami, &#x0026; van <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_126">Knippenberg, 2004</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec8_2_1_3">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_189">189</target>From the Neck Down: Persuasion and Body Language</title>
<p>Some of the principles of persuasion that we discussed in relation to the eyes and the face also apply to communication with the body. For example, just as you can mirror a person&#x2019;s facial expressions, you can mirror his or her gestures and body movements. Moreover, consistent with the direct effects model of immediacy (discussed previously), people who lean forward when communicating tend to be more persuasive than those who do not. In addition to these findings, research shows that people are more persuasive when they are pictured using open body positions (i.e., when their arms and legs are positioned away from their bodies) rather than neutral or closed positions (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_80">McGinley, LeFevre, &#x0026; McGinley, 1975</xref>). (Did you know that the way you move your body may also make you safer? See <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box8_2">Box 8.2</xref>.)</p>
<p>Perhaps most of the research on body movement and persuasion, however, has focused on the use of gestures. Although various researchers have discussed a number of different gestures, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_5">Argyle (1988)</xref> argued that it is most useful to focus on three: emblems, illustrators, and self-touching.</p>
<sec id="sec8_2_1_3_1">
<title>Emblems</title>
<p>According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_28">Ekman and Friesen (1969)</xref>, <italic>emblems</italic> are nonverbal behaviors, usually hand movements, that have precise verbal meaning. Thus, emblems can substitute for words. Traffic cops, referees, baseball catchers, and scuba divers are well-known emblem users, but we all use them. Think of all the words for which we have gestures: <target target-type="page" id="page_190">190</target>hello, good-bye, come here, crazy, quiet or shush, peace, I don&#x2019;t know, good luck, think, and shame on you, not to mention the ever-popular middle finger gesture.</p>
<boxed-text id="box8_2">
<label>Box 8.2</label>
<caption><title>Walk This Way: Are You Vulnerable to Attack?</title></caption>
<p>From an early age, you were probably instructed to use crosswalks, to look both ways before crossing the street, and to walk rather than run around swimming pools. But did you know that walking safely might also depend on how you carry yourself? According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_49">Gunns, Johnston, and Hudson (2002)</xref>, victims of attack are not chosen randomly. These researchers suggest that, in the same way that vulnerable sheep in a herd are identified, isolated, and pounced on by wolves, some people, by virtue of their gait, may appear more vulnerable to would-be attackers. Consistent with this notion, a study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_132">Wheeler, Book, and Costello (2009)</xref> found that males with higher psychopathic scores were better able to distinguish people who had been victimized from those who had not after viewing short video clips of those people walking. To shed light on the characteristics of different walking styles, Gunns and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_49">2002</xref>) asked 30 males and 30 females to watch videotapes of more than 100 male and female walkers while rating how vulnerable to attack the walkers seemed. Analysis of the ratings and videotapes revealed that the typical &#x201C;hard to attack&#x201D; walker was characterized by a longer stride, a larger range of arm swing, higher energy, lower constraint, and a faster walk. Before concluding this segment, we want to be clear, as Wheeler and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_132">2009</xref>) were, that people are not responsible for victimization because of how they walk. The attacker is always to blame. That said, knowing what perpetrators look for is a weapon you can use to defend yourself. In short, to appear less vulnerable, put some pep in your step!!!</p>
</boxed-text>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 8.1</label>
<caption><title>Dilbert.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig8_1.tif"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; Scott Adams. Reprinted with permission, United Media. All Rights Reserved.</p>
</fig>
<p>Emblems are an important part of communication and serve many functions, persuasion included. But what part do emblems play in social influence? Several scholars have argued that a prerequisite for persuasion is attention to and retention of a message (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_81">McGuire, 1968</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_95">Petty &#x0026; Cacioppo, 1986</xref>), and it seems that by providing more visual information, emblems play a large role in fostering attention and retention in persuadees. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_135">Woodall and Folger (1981)</xref>, for example, found that people recalled 34 percent of a verbal message when it was accompanied by an emblem compared to only 11 percent when other types of gestures were used.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec8_2_1_3_2">
<title>Illustrators</title>
<p>Although emblems have meaning independent of verbal communication, <italic>illustrators,</italic> a second type of gesture, accompany speech (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_28">Ekman &#x0026; Friesen, 1969</xref>). Like their name implies, illustrators illustrate, emphasize, or repeat what is being said. A child saying she loves you &#x201C;this much&#x201D; while spreading her arms wide is using an illustrator. Likewise, we can use illustrators to give directions, show our excitement, follow a rhythm, demonstrate a shape, and so forth.</p>
<p>Several studies indicate that the use of illustrators increases a speaker&#x2019;s persuasiveness. In one study, for instance, actors who used more forceful and rhythmic gestures were more persuasive than those who did not (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_78">Maslow, Yoselson, &#x0026; London, 1971</xref>). In addition, some illustrators make speakers appear more effective and composed (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_74">Maricchiolo, Gnisci, Bonaiuto, &#x0026; Ficca, 2009</xref>), which doesn&#x2019;t hurt when you are trying to be persuasive.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec8_2_1_3_3">
<title>Self-Touching Behaviors (Adaptors)</title>
<p>Although emblems and illustrators seem to increase people&#x2019;s persuasiveness, the jury is still out on the effect of <italic>self-touching behaviors</italic> (e.g., scratching your arm, rubbing your cheek, picking your nose, stroking your hair), also known as <italic>adaptors</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_28">Ekman &#x0026; Friesen, 1969</xref>). For example, while some research suggests that the use of adaptors was associated with less persuasion (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_78">Maslow et al., 1971</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_82">Mehrabian &#x0026; Williams, 1969</xref>), other research shows the opposite (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_74">Maricchiolo et al., 2009</xref>). Even so, most research agrees that self-touching behaviors are often seen as a sign of anxiety and lack of composure (unless, perhaps, you are Britney Spears or Madonna). With that <target target-type="page" id="page_191">191</target>in mind, our best advice at this point is to avoid using adaptors if you want to be persuasive.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec8_2_2">
<title>Haptics: Reach Out and Touch Someone</title>
<p>If touching yourself makes you less persuasive, does touching other people have the same effect? Many years ago, three researchers interested in the topic of <italic>haptics</italic> (or touch) conducted a simple yet classic study to explore this question. In the study, library clerks did one of two things when they handed library cards back to university students who were checking out books: Either they did not touch the students or they made light physical contact by placing a hand over the students&#x2019; palms. After their cards were returned, students were asked to rate the quality of the library, and, interestingly, those who were touched evaluated the library much more favorably than those who were not (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_30">Fisher, Rytting, &#x0026; Heslin, 1976</xref>).</p>
<p>The persuasive impact of touch has been demonstrated in other contexts as well. For example, touch has been found to increase the number of people who volunteered to score papers (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_89">Patterson, Powell, &#x0026; Lenihan, 1986</xref>), sign petitions (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_133">Willis &#x0026; Hamm, 1980</xref>), complete questionnaires (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_125">Vaidis &#x0026; Halimi-Falkowicz, 2008</xref>), return money that had been left in a telephone booth (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_64">Kleinke, 1977</xref>), accept invitations to dance in nightclubs (Gu&#x00E9;guen, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_37">2007</xref>), provide phone numbers to prospective dating partners (Gu&#x00E9;guen, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_37">2007</xref>), and help someone pick up items that had been dropped (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_42">Gu&#x00E9;guen &#x0026; Fischer-Lokou, 2003</xref>). Similarly, when food servers touch diners appropriately, the servers earn higher tips (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_55">Hornick, 1992</xref>), and the diners are more likely to take servers&#x2019; recommendations about what to order (Gu&#x00E9;guen, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_47">Jacob, &#x0026; Boulbry, 2007</xref>). <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_55">Hornick (1992)</xref> found that touching bookstore customers on the arm caused them to shop longer (22.11 minutes versus 13.56 minutes), purchase more (&#x0024;15.03 versus &#x0024;12.23), and evaluate the store more positively than customers who had not been touched. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_55">Hornick (1992)</xref> also found that supermarket customers who had been touched were more likely to taste and purchase food samples than untouched customers.</p>
<p>One common way of touching people is through handshakes, and, as it turns out, the way you shake hands may influence the impressions people form of you. For instance, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_9">Bernieri and Petty (2011)</xref> found that people make judgments about whether others are conscientious and extroverted on the basis of handshakes. Not only that, the way you shake hands might help you get a job. Specifically, in one study, men and women who used desirable handshakes (i.e., firm clasps with a full grip while looking the other person in the eye) received higher ratings of employment suitability from interviewers than did men and women with less desirable, limp-fishy types of handshakes (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_116">Stewart, Dustin, Barrick, &#x0026; Darnold, 2008</xref>).</p>
<p>Considering this research, it seems, then, that all the stuff we learned as kids about &#x201C;the Midas touch&#x201D; may not be such a fairytale. Touching people, when done appropriately, seems to be persuasive. Touch may put people in a good mood, making them more likely to comply with requests (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_55">Hornick, 1992</xref>). Another explanation is that people who touch create more favorable impressions of themselves and, therefore, are more persuasive (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_55">Hornick, 1992</xref>). Finally, people who touch may be more persuasive because, through touch, they augment their image of power (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_89">Patterson et al., 1986</xref>).</p>
<boxed-text id="box8_3">
<label><target target-type="page" id="page_192">192</target>Box 8.3</label>
<caption><title>If It Feels Good, Buy It: The Role of Touching Merchandise on Persuasion</title></caption>
<p>When you are shopping, do you find yourself picking things up, feeling the texture of fabrics, and running your fingers over merchandise? If so, you may be what researchers have called high in the need for touch (NFT) (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_90">Peck &#x0026; Childers, 2003a</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_91">2003b</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_93">Peck &#x0026; Wiggins, 2005</xref>). High NFTs get frustrated while shopping if they cannot touch things. Not all NFTs are the same, however. Some, called instrumental NFTs, use touch to evaluate products, while others, called autotelic NFTs, touch things because it is fun and pleasurable for them. With that in mind, autotelic NFTs are persuaded when there are pleasurable things to touch, even when those things are not relevant to what is being marketed (e.g., soft swatches of fabric on a pamphlet seeking donations for a nature center) (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_93">Peck &#x0026; Wiggins, 2005</xref>) and regardless of whether they are involved in the issue being considered or not (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_92">Peck &#x0026; Johnson, 2011</xref>). Instrumental NFTs, however, are persuaded only when what is being touched is relevant to what is being marketed (e.g., feathers and tree bark samples on a pamphlet seeking donations for a nature center) (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_93">Peck &#x0026; Wiggins, 2005</xref>), and when their involvement in the issue is low (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_92">Peck &#x0026; Johnson, 2011</xref>).</p>
</boxed-text>
<p>Whatever the reason for the persuasive impact of touch, one thing is clear: The use of touch for persuasive purposes is tricky because touch is so ambiguous. What one person may see as &#x201C;warm,&#x201D; for example, another may view as a &#x201C;power play.&#x201D; In fact, one study found that in competitive contexts, touching another person led to decreased cooperation, perhaps because it is perceived as an attempt to dominate (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_25">Camps, Tuteleers, Stouten, &#x0026; Nelissen, 2013</xref>). What&#x2019;s more, what one person might interpret as &#x201C;friendly,&#x201D; another may see as &#x201C;flirtatious.&#x201D; The &#x201C;brushing&#x201D; of one employee against another could be interpreted as accidental or as a form of sexual harassment. Clearly, interpretations of touch depend on a vast array of factors, including context, gender, and culture. In most of the studies we&#x2019;ve just discussed, touching generally occurred on the hands or arms. We suspect that too much touching or touching other parts of a person might actually backfire, making persuasion less likely. As potential persuadees, it is important to realize that even touches, such as those enacted in most of the studies we discussed, wield tremendous persuasive power. Such touches may be so subtle that we might not even be aware that they are being used for persuasive purposes. But do not be fooled. Touch is persuasive, as is the use of space&#x2014;our next topic. (For more on the persuasive effects of touch, see <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box8_3">Box 8.3</xref>.)</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec8_2_3">
<title>Keep Your Distance? Proxemics and Persuasion</title>
<p>The study of <italic>proxemics,</italic> or how we use space to communicate, covers a variety of topics, such as territoriality and dominance. In this chapter, however, we are less concerned with those topics and, instead, focus our discussion on the concept of <italic>personal space,</italic> which refers to what might be considered an invisible bubble that surrounds us. An obvious case in point is that a door-to-door salesperson should not <target target-type="page" id="page_193">193</target>stick his or her nose in a potential customer&#x2019;s face. However, there is some evidence that indicates that the opposite is the case: That is, violating a person&#x2019;s space may be more persuasive.</p>
<p>In a study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_8">Baron and Bell (1976)</xref>, for instance, diners in a cafeteria were approached by an experimenter and asked to volunteer for a survey for a period of 30 minutes to 2 hours and 30 minutes. The experimenter stood close to some diners (12&#x2013;18 in.) and farther away from others (3&#x2013;4 ft). Results of the study showed that diners volunteered to participate for longer periods of time when they were approached at closer distances.</p>
<p>How can we explain this finding? First, because people tend to stand closer to people they like (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_5">Argyle, 1988</xref>), persuadees may simply be reciprocating the liking by complying with the violator&#x2019;s requests (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_8">Baron &#x0026; Bell, 1976</xref>). In addition, because people find spatial invasion uncomfortable, those invaded may perceive persuaders as more demanding, desperate, and needful (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_8">Baron &#x0026; Bell, 1976</xref>).</p>
<p>As with other forms of nonverbal communication, some caution is advised when making generalizations about the role of proxemics in persuasion. Indeed, at least two studies indicate that closer distances may not encourage compliance. For instance, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_111">Smith and Knowles (1979)</xref> found that pedestrians who had their space invaded without justification were less likely to return a lost object than those who had not had their space invaded. Moreover, a study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_1">Albert and Dabbs (1970)</xref> found that speakers were more persuasive the farther they were from other people (i.e., speakers were more persuasive when standing 4&#x2013;5 or 14&#x2013;15 ft from their audiences than they were when standing 1&#x2013;2 ft from their audiences).</p>
<p>If the conflicting results of these studies seem confusing, you might be interested in a theory presented by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_20">Judee Burgoon (1978</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_21">1992</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_22">1994</xref>). It is called <italic>expectancy violations theory,</italic> and we think it provides a strong and elegant explanation for the ways in which space violations affect the process of social influence.</p>
<p>According to the theory, we all have expectations about how close other people should stand to us. When people violate those expectations and get either too close or too far away, we experience arousal and may become distracted. How we react to the violation, however, depends on several factors, perhaps the most important being the &#x201C;reward value&#x201D; of the violator. If he or she is attractive, has the power to reward or punish us, or is just plain likable, the violation is perceived as a pleasant surprise, and we are more likely to be persuaded. However, if the violator has low reward value, the violation will be perceived as negative, and compliance will be less likely. In addition, the theory states that if violations are so extreme that they are perceived as threatening, they also will decrease compliance.</p>
<p>The theory has received a considerable amount of support and implies several practical suggestions for those interested in persuading others. First, if you think the person you are trying to persuade sees you as attractive, powerful, or credible, it is best to stand a little farther or a little closer to that person than would be expected. Second, if you think you are perceived by someone as powerless and icky, you should maintain appropriate distances. Finally, never overdo it. If you stand too close or too far away, you will probably not be persuasive.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec8_2_4">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_194">194</target>Chronemics: All Good Things to Those Who Wait?</title>
<p>In science, the concepts of space and time are often discussed together. However, in the study of persuasion, although considerable research has examined the topic of proxemics, little attention has been paid to <italic>chronemics,</italic> or the study of how time is used to communicate. Even so, we know that time can be an important commodity, especially in a culture like the United States.</p>
<p>A common expression in the military, especially among soldiers with lower ranks, is &#x201C;hurry up and wait.&#x201D; Oftentimes, it seems that such soldiers are expected to be on time although their superiors can show up whenever they want to. The point is, the higher your status, the more power you have over other people&#x2019;s time.</p>
<p>This is true in other contexts as well. For instance, how much time have you spent waiting in doctors&#x2019; offices? Do you have to make appointments to see some professors or to get interviewed for a job? And don&#x2019;t be fooled: If you are a subordinate and show up more than a few minutes late to a business meeting, do you think you&#x2019;ll be very persuasive? We suspect not.</p>
<p>Practically speaking, then, you might be wondering whether it is okay to be late if you have a lot of status. Our suggestion is &#x201C;be careful.&#x201D; Indeed, a study mentioned in the work of Burgoon and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_23">1996</xref>) found that people who arrive 15 minutes late are considered dynamic, but much less competent, composed, and sociable than people who arrive on time. Plus, we think making people wait is rude.</p>
<p>Time not only affects perceptions of people but it also can be used as a persuasive ploy. For instance, for people in a hurry, drive-through banking or fast-food restaurants may have appeal, as may establishments such as Jiffy Lube, LensCrafters, and 1-Hour Photo. When such services save you time, it&#x2019;s terrific. But beware. Just because an exercise video promises to transform your buns into steel in only three minutes a day, or a flyer claims you can earn &#x0024;60,000 a year working at home in your spare time, or an audiotape claims it will teach you how to play guitar in two weeks doesn&#x2019;t mean that will really happen. Too often, people seek quick solutions to complicated problems. We want to buy a product, take a pill, or push a button, and make a problem go away. Persuaders prey on this quick-fix mentality.</p>
<p>In addition to ploys offering to save time, sometimes strategies are based on what <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_26">Cialdini (1993)</xref> calls the principle of <italic>scarcity.</italic> According to Cialdini and others (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_13">Brehm, 1966</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_14">Brehm &#x0026; Brehm, 1981</xref>), people love freedom, and when that freedom is threatened or limited, people experience something called <italic>psychological reactance</italic>, a concept we introduced in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter3">Chapter 3</xref>. For example, a shopper in a store may decide she likes a certain dress. If a salesperson explains to the customer that there is only one more dress like that in her size (i.e., the dress is <italic>scarce</italic>), the woman, who might have thought that she was free to buy the dress at any time, may now <italic>react psychologically</italic> by wanting the dress more than she did in the first place (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_26">Cialdini, 1993</xref>). As you well know, persuaders also attempt to use psychological reactance in their favor by making time scarce. For instance, by telling us that we must &#x201C;act now&#x201D; or that there is a &#x201C;limited time offer,&#x201D; advertisers are relying on the principle of scarcity. By limiting our time, they hope to make us more likely to purchase their product or service.</p>
<p>The notion that &#x201C;time is running out&#x201D; has the potential to nudge us in other ways as well. For example, one of our favorite vintage studies (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_94">Pennebaker et al., 1979</xref>) <target target-type="page" id="page_195">195</target>tested country singer Mickey Gilley&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_33">1975</xref>) prediction that &#x201C;the girls get prettier at closing time&#x201D; by asking bar patrons to rate the attractiveness of other patrons during various times in the evening. Results indicated that ratings of opposite-sex patrons increased near closing time, suggesting that people&#x2019;s standards change as the pickin&#x2019;s get slim (i.e., as time and potential partners become scarce). A recent replication of this study (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_58">Johnco, Wheeler, &#x0026; Taylor, 2010</xref>) suggests that, although these results are due, in part, to alcohol consumption (known in popular culture as the &#x201C;beer goggles&#x201D; effect), scarcity remains a viable explanation for why people&#x2019;s standards for attractiveness change over time. Of course, if you haven&#x2019;t hooked up with a &#x201C;10&#x201D; by last call, you can always settle for two &#x201C;5&#x2019;s.&#x201D;</p>
<p>Interestingly, perhaps because the psychological pressure created by scarcity is so uncomfortable, some persuaders have found that a &#x201C;nonurgency&#x201D; tactic is preferable. In other words, because people don&#x2019;t want to be rushed and pressured, sometimes coming across as if time is <italic>not</italic> an issue can be very persuasive. Starbucks and other coffee houses that offer free Wi-Fi encourage customers to stay. &#x201C;No, no, no&#x201D; sales also use this approach: A consumer buys a mattress, a big-screen TV, or an appliance and pays no money down, no interest, and no monthly payments until anywhere from 90 days to a year later. Products or services that advertise a &#x201C;free 30-day trial offer&#x201D; also facilitate sales by removing time pressures.</p>
<p>Finally, if customers get tired of waiting, there might be a creative solution. Consider, for example, how executives at a Houston airport responded when they got swamped with complaints about the long waits at baggage claim. Instead of reducing wait times, the executives routed flights to distant arrival gates, thereby forcing passengers to walk longer distances. As a result of keeping passengers busy, complaints virtually disappeared (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_117">Stone, 2012</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec8_2_5">
<title>Artifacts and Physical Features of the Environment: Dress for Success</title>
<p>While talking about the notion of time, did we mention that an expensive watch with a gold wristband couldn&#x2019;t hurt your image much? Obviously, the clothes and makeup we wear, the cars we drive, the furniture we own, and other physical objects, also known as <italic>artifacts,</italic> can communicate a great deal about our credibility and status. In our society, material goods are viewed as an extension of oneself. Why else would color analysts be getting rich by telling people whether to wear summer, autumn, winter, or spring colored makeup? And why else would someone pay thousands of dollars for an Armani suit?</p>
<p>Speaking of suits, we know a good story about how artifacts can affect people&#x2019;s perceptions. Many years ago, one of the authors sold men&#x2019;s suits for commission. Because he obviously did not earn anything unless he sold merchandise, when given a choice, the author tried to help customers who appeared as if they would spend a lot of money. One day a customer entered the store wearing a greasy T-shirt, jeans, no socks, and filthy tennis shoes. Because at the time there were plenty of other people shopping, the author decided to pick a more &#x201C;profitable-looking&#x201D; customer on whom to wait. One of the new employees, however, decided to help the &#x201C;greaseball.&#x201D; Much to the author&#x2019;s surprise, however, that greaseball ended up buying six very expensive suits. It turned out he was not a greaseball at all; he was a high-paid <target target-type="page" id="page_196">196</target>executive who had just lost all of his suits in a fire. He was restocking his wardrobe. Of course, the old saying &#x201C;you can&#x2019;t judge a book by its cover&#x201D; took on a whole new meaning that day.</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 8.2</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig8_2.jpg"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; Peter Steiner/The New Yorker Collection/<uri>www.cartoonbank.com</uri>. All Rights Reserved.</p>
</fig>
<p>Apparently, when it comes to making quick judgments like this, the author is not alone. Indeed, previous literature suggests that first impressions are not only powerful and enduring, they are often based on seemingly trivial appearance cues (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_23">Burgoon, Buller, &#x0026; Woodall, 1996</xref>). Research indicates, for example, that cues such as clothing (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_36">Gorham, Cohen, &#x0026; Morris, 1999</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_104">Seiter &#x0026; Dunn, 2000</xref>), grooming (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_6">Atkins &#x0026; Kent, 1988</xref>), cosmetics (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_59">Johnson &#x0026; Workman, 1991</xref>), hair length (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_6">Atkins &#x0026; Kent, 1988</xref>), tattooing (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_105">Seiter &#x0026; Hatch, 2005</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_119">Swami &#x0026; Furnham, 2007</xref>), and body piercing (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_106">Seiter &#x0026; Sandry, 2003</xref>) influence judgments about credibility, attractiveness, and whether or not to hire someone. In other words, if anything, such research indicates that such cues are not trivial at all and, in some contexts (e.g., when interviewing), may be more important than verbal cues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_35">Goldberg &#x0026; Cohen, 2004</xref>).</p>
<p>In addition to those discussed, other artifacts and features of the environment can be influential. For instance, power and status might be communicated through the size and location of a person&#x2019;s office. Large offices in corner spaces, for example, are often considered prestigious (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_2">Andersen, 1999</xref>). Not only that, one of our favorite studies (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_123">Teven &#x0026; Comadena, 1996</xref>) illustrates that an office&#x2019;s appearance may be important as well. In the study, 97 students went one at a time to meet a professor in his office. On arriving for the meeting, however, they found no professor and were asked to wait 5 minutes for him. Some of the students waited in a disorganized and untidy office, <target target-type="page" id="page_197">197</target>whereas others waited in a clean and neatly arranged office. After the 5 minutes were up, the students were told that the professor could not make the meeting. Later, however, they saw the professor lecture and rated him on several scales. The results of the study showed that the professor&#x2019;s office had a significant influence on students&#x2019; perceptions. Specifically, compared to students who visited the tidy office, those who visited the untidy one perceived the professor as less authoritative, less trustworthy, less open, less relaxed, less concerned about making a good impression, less animated, and less friendly. Interestingly, however, the &#x201C;untidy&#x201D; professor was seen as the most dynamic, perhaps because the disheveled office created the impression of a busy and energetic person (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_123">Teven &#x0026; Comadena, 1996</xref>). Whatever the case, after reading this study, we&#x2019;ll be straightening up.</p>
<p>And apparently, we&#x2019;re not the only ones. Other people know about the importance of structuring the environment. For example, if you&#x2019;re thinking of buying a house, before you do, remember that those dandy model homes may not look the same once you&#x2019;re living in them. Why not? The furniture is downsized to make the rooms look larger (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_75">Martin, 2000</xref>). Plus, empty closets, refrigerators without kiddie art, and the absence of other household necessities make such homes look tidy and ever so inviting. The practice of &#x201C;staging&#x201D; homes by using decluttering and inexpensive improvements is now a big business.</p>
<p>Supermarkets are another example of how environments are arranged strategically (e.g., see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_29">Field, 1996</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_84">Meyer, 1997</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_120">Tandingan, 2001</xref>). Next time you&#x2019;re shopping, for instance, take a look around. You might notice that staples such as dairy, meat, and produce are in the back or on opposite sides of the store. Why? It forces shoppers to meander through the aisles where they&#x2019;ll be tempted to buy all kinds of other goodies. You&#x2019;ll also notice that chips, dips, and other products that &#x201C;go together&#x201D; are intentionally placed side by side, encouraging additional purchases. And it&#x2019;s no accident that children&#x2019;s products (e.g., Cap&#x2019;n Crunch) are often placed on middle shelves so that they are at eye level to little precious who is seated in the shopping cart, whereas adult products (e.g., Grape Nuts) are at higher elevations. What&#x2019;s more, snack foods, which appeal to impulsive shoppers, are often located in checkout areas and at the ends of aisles where they&#x2019;re more likely to be snatched up. Clearly, such placement is adapted to particular audiences and aimed at making products noticeable to consumers.</p>
<p>In addition to the studies and tactics we&#x2019;ve mentioned so far, considerable evidence shows that artifacts and physical features of the environment can not only make products more noticeable and people appear more (or less) credible, they can also lead to persuasion. Most of this research has focused on the impact of clothing. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_70">Lawrence and Watson (1991)</xref>, for example, found that individuals asking for contributions to law enforcement and health-care campaigns earned more money when wearing sheriffs&#x2019; and nurses&#x2019; uniforms than when they did not. In another classic study, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_11">Bickman (1974)</xref> had young men dressed as either civilians or uniformed guards, approach pedestrians on the streets of New York and ask them to do one of three things. In one situation, pedestrians were shown a bag lying on the ground and were told, &#x201C;Pick up this bag for me!&#x201D; In another condition, the experimenter pointed at a man standing near a parked car and said, &#x201C;This fellow is over-parked at the meter but doesn&#x2019;t have any change. Give him a dime!&#x201D; In the final condition, a person standing at a bus stop was told, &#x201C;Don&#x2019;t you know you have to stand on the other side of the <target target-type="page" id="page_198">198</target>pole? The sign says, &#x2018;No Standing.&#x2019;&#x201D; Results of the study showed that, in all three conditions, people complied more with the guard than they did with the civilians. In other words, something about a uniform tends to make us obedient.</p>
<p>Although meta-analyses indicate that fancy suits, uniforms, and high-status clothing are related to higher rates of compliance (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_100">Segrin, 1993</xref>), such apparel might not always be necessary for persuasion. In some cases, it may also be possible to influence people by wearing clothing that makes them identify with a persuader. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_51">Hensley (1981)</xref>, for instance, found that well-dressed people were more persuasive in airports, but casually dressed people were more persuasive at bus stops.</p>
<p>In short, it appears that artifacts, particularly clothing, make a difference when trying to seek compliance. Of course, artifacts can also affect your appearance or attractiveness, which, in turn, can affect your persuasiveness. We now turn our discussion to this topic.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec8_2_6">
<title>Physical Appearance: Of Beauties and Beasts</title>
<p>Beauty may only be skin deep, but it is persuasive. And the people out there trying to influence us know this. Beauty sells. For example, if Gisele B&#x00FC;ndchen had a big nose and warts with hair growing out of them, do you think you&#x2019;d have seen her face spread across the pages of makeup and lingerie ads? It seems, in fact, that the products being endorsed by attractive spokespersons do not even have to be connected with making us more attractive. Indeed, beautiful people are trying to sell us everything from milk, to law firms, to dog food.</p>
<p>Not surprisingly, plenty of research indicates that physical attractiveness is persuasive in contexts other than advertising (see <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box8_4">Box 8.4</xref>). For instance, compared to their less-attractive counterparts, attractive people are judged to be happier, more <target target-type="page" id="page_199">199</target>intelligent, friendlier, stronger, and kinder and are thought to have better personalities, better jobs, and greater marital competence (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_66">Knapp, 1992</xref>). <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_104">Seiter and Dunn (2000)</xref> found that it did not matter whether a woman was made to appear attractive in a pristine way (e.g., conservative clothing, makeup, and jewelry) or attractive in a sexy way (e.g., revealing clothes, heavy makeup). In both cases, she was believed more when claiming to have been sexually harassed than when she was made to appear unattractive (e.g., blotchy skin, greasy hair, no makeup). Finally, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_88">Palmer and Peterson (2016)</xref> found that, when talking politics, attractive people (particularly poorly informed ones), are more likely than unattractive people to try persuading others. Not only that, they&#x2019;re perceived as better informed and more persuasive than unattractive people.</p>
<boxed-text id="box8_4">
<label>Box 8.4</label>
<caption><title>Hot by Association: How Facebook Friends Affect Your Attractiveness</title></caption>
<p>If you are one of the millions of people who use the social networking website Facebook, you might be interested to know that people may be judging you by the company you keep. It has been known for some time that judgments of attractiveness are relative. For example, when photos of average-looking people are shown beside photos of attractive and unattractive people, a contrast effect occurs: Average people are seen as more attractive when seen alongside unattractive people and less attractive when seen alongside attractive people. If, however, the people judging attractiveness are told that a relationship exists between the people in the photos, the opposite effect (assimilation) occurs: Average people are now seen as less attractive when paired with unattractive people and more attractive when paired with attractive people (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_83">Melamed &#x0026; Moss, 1975</xref>). Knowing this, it probably won&#x2019;t surprise you to learn that, if you want to appear &#x201C;hotter,&#x201D; it helps to have attractive friends on Facebook. Indeed, two studies found that Facebook users were perceived as more physically and socially attractive when they were associated with good-looking pals (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_57">Jaschinski &#x0026; Kommers, 2012</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_128">Walther, Van Der Heide, Kim, Westerman, &#x0026; Tong, 2008</xref>).</p>
</boxed-text>
<p>According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_88">Palmer and Peterson (2016)</xref>, these results may be due to a &#x201C;halo effect,&#x201D; in which one positive characteristic of a person causes us to see everything about the person in a positive light. In other words, if the person is attractive, he or she must also be trustworthy, well informed, and so forth. Whatever the case, given the preceding findings, perhaps you are wondering what physical characteristics are related to attractiveness. Although we know that standards for beauty change over time (e.g., did you know that, in medieval times, pale and plump people were perceived as the most attractive?) and that beauty is supposedly in the eye of the beholder, research tells us that some of the following characteristics are related to perceptions and/or persuasiveness:</p>
<p>1. <italic>Body shape</italic>: Dwayne &#x201C;The Rock&#x201D; Johnson, Taylor Swift, and Jonah Hill represent the three basic body shapes. The first, a <italic>mesomorph,</italic> is muscular; the second, an <italic>ectomorph</italic> is thin; and the third, an <italic>endomorph,</italic> is round. Findings summarized by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_5">Argyle (1988)</xref> show that whereas mesomorphs are rated as, among other things, strong and adventurous, ectomorphs are seen as tense, pessimistic, and quiet, and <target target-type="page" id="page_200">200</target>endomorphs are seen as warm, sympathetic, agreeable, and dependent. Because of negative stereotypes, endomorphs tend to be perceived as less powerful, successful, attractive, and enthusiastic than those with different body shapes (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_15">Breseman, Lennon, &#x0026; Schulz, 1999</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_127">Wade, Fuller, Bresnan, Schaefer, &#x0026; Mlynarski, 2007</xref>). Moreover, endomorphs are less likely to get jobs, less likely to earn high salaries, and less likely to be accepted into colleges than thinner people with the same IQs (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_5">Argyle, 1988</xref>).</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figures 8.3, 8.4, 8.5</label>
<caption><title>Celebrities sporting different body shapes: Can you spot the mesomorph, ectomorph, and endomorph?</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig8_3.jpg"/>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig8_4.jpg"/>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig8_5.jpg"/>
<p>Sources: DFree/Shutterstock.com; Kathy Hutchins/Sutterstock.com; s_buckley/Shutterstock.com</p>
</fig>
<p>Even so, one study (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_76">Martins, Pliner, &#x0026; Lee, 2004</xref>) indicated that perceptions based on body shape depend on other factors, specifically meal size. In the study, Canadian students reported their impressions of normal or overweight males and females who were portrayed as eating small or large meals. Overweight males eating large meals were perceived by all students as the least socially attractive, perhaps because they are thought to lack self-control (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_76">Martins et al., 2004</xref>). Interestingly, however, while female students perceived normal-weight females who ate small meals as the most socially attractive, male students rated normal-weight females who ate large meals as the most socially attractive. Why? The researchers suggested that males may perceive normal-weight females who eat heartily as more comfortable with themselves, more confident, and more honest (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_76">Martins et al., 2004</xref>). That being said, women may face a double standard when it comes to weight. A study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_61">Judge and Cable (2011)</xref>, for example, found that thin women earned significantly higher salaries than middleweight women, while thin men earned lower salaries than middleweight men. Being obese negatively affected the salaries of both men and women (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_61">Judge &#x0026; Cable, 2011</xref>).</p>
<p><bold>2. <italic>Facial appearance</italic></bold>: According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_5">Argyle (1988)</xref>, faces are perceived as more attractive when they have wide cheekbones, narrow cheeks, high eyebrows, wide pupils, large smiles, noses that are not too long or too short, and eyes not too far apart or too close together. Baby-faced women are perceived as more attractive but immature by men (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_10">Berry &#x0026; McArthur, 1986</xref>) and, whereas baby-faced people are cast into commercials that want to portray trustworthiness, mature-faced people are cast into commercials that want to emphasize expertise (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_18">Brownlow &#x0026; Zebrowitz, 1990</xref>). Interestingly, because baby-faced speakers may look more honest (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_77">Masip, Garrido, &#x0026; Herrero, 2004</xref>), they are more persuasive when their trustworthiness is questioned, while mature-faced speakers are more persuasive when their expertise is questioned (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_17">Brownlow, 1992</xref>). In addition, while being baby-faced seems to benefit female politicians, it works to male politicians&#x2019; disadvantage (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_72">Lee, 2013</xref>).</p>
<p>That said, the most persuasive faces, perhaps, are ones that remind us of ourselves. Indeed, in one of our favorite studies (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_96">Richards &#x0026; Hample, 2016</xref>), research participants saw photographs of a speaker. Unbeknown to the participants, the speaker&#x2019;s face was actually a composite of two faces that had been digitally morphed together. What&#x2019;s more, while some participants saw photos that merged the faces of two strangers, others saw photos that merged their own face with a stranger&#x2019;s. Compared to the first group of participants, those in the second group perceived the speaker to be more likable, credible, and persuasive. Why? According to the researchers, evolution benefits people who give preferential treatment to their kin. See the connection? People who look like us may be genetically similar. As such, we&#x2019;re prone to prefer them over dissimilar others, a concept known <italic>nepotistic altruism</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_50">Hamilton, 1964</xref>).</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_201">201</target><bold>3. <italic>Hair</italic></bold>: Do blondes, as the old saying goes, &#x201C;have more fun?&#x201D; We&#x2019;re not sure about that, but when it comes to another old saying&#x2014;&#x201C;Gentlemen prefer blondes&#x201D;&#x2014; research seems to agree. Indeed, in several studies the same women sported different hair colors, and, generally speaking, were favored by males when posing as blondes. By way of example, blonde hitchhikers (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_38">Gu&#x00E9;guen &#x0026; Lamy, 2009</xref>), waitresses (Gu&#x00E9;guen, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_40">2012b</xref>), and night clubbers (Gu&#x00E9;guen, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_39">2012a</xref>) received more rides, tips, and attention (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_118">Swami &#x0026; Barrett, 2011</xref>, Study 1), respectively. On the other hand, although blondes received more help (Gu&#x00E9;guen, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_41">2012c</xref>) and were rated as more attractive (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_113">Sorokowski, 2008</xref>), they were also perceived as more needy and less competent than brunettes (Swami &#x0026; Barrett, Study 2).</p>
<p>That said, research shows that hair of any color may be better than no hair at all. For instance, a study comparing hair loss among male governors and members of Congress to the general public found that elected politicians are more likely to have a full head of hair than would be expected of men their age (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_109">Sigelman, Dawson, Nitz, &#x0026; Whicker, 1990</xref>). Before you conclude that more hair means more persuasion, however, consider a study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_48">Guido, Peluso, and Moffa (2011)</xref>, which examined the persuasive effects of beards. Based on research suggesting that men with beards tend to be perceived as less attractive but more trustworthy and competent than men with no facial hair (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_27">De Souza, Bai&#x00E3;o, &#x0026; Otta, 2003</xref>), these researchers found that cleanshaven men were more persuasive when endorsing products related to attractiveness (i.e., underwear), while bearded guys were more persuasive when endorsing products related to trustworthiness and expertise (i.e., cellphones and toothpaste). Such research supports the <italic>match-up hypothesis</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_63">Kamins, 1990</xref>), which argues that persuasion is increased when endorsers are paired with products that emphasize characteristics of the endorsers.</p>
<p><bold>4. <italic>Height</italic></bold>: According to a meta-analysis of 45 studies (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_60">Judge &#x0026; Cable, 2004</xref>), when it comes to a person&#x2019;s height, size matters. The analysis found that being taller, especially if you are male, is positively associated with ratings of leadership, performance, and social esteem. Not only that, the study reported that taller people earn significantly more money in their careers than do their shorter counterparts (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_60">Judge &#x0026; Cable, 2004</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec8_2_7">
<title>Paralinguistics and Persuasion: Pump Up the Volume?</title>
<p><italic>Paralinguistics,</italic> or <italic>vocalics,</italic> is the study of vocal stimuli aside from spoken words. It includes such elements as pitch, rate, pauses, volume, tone of voice, silences, laughs, screams, sighs, and so forth. We know from prior research that the <italic>way</italic> in which persons speak affects how they are perceived as well as their ability to persuade. In one study, for instance, people who listened to high-pitched voices perceived the speaker as more attractive and extroverted than those who listened to low-pitched voices (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_56">Imhof, 2010</xref>). Similarly, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_54">Hinkle (2001)</xref> found that when managers spoke clearly and varied their tone, employees tended to like them better.</p>
<p>More recently, researchers have identified a quality of voice known as <italic>vocal fry</italic> or &#x201C;creaky voice,&#x201D; which is characterized by drawing out the end of sentences with a low, croaking growl in the back of the throat (to hear it, Google &#x201C;vocal fry&#x201D; or think Britney Spears, Kim Kardashian, or Matthew McConaughey). <target target-type="page" id="page_202">202</target>According to Anderson and her colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_4">2014</xref>), vocal fry is increasingly common among young American females, and leads them, more so than males, to be perceived as less competent, less trustworthy, less attractive, and less hirable. Such findings suggest that women&#x2019;s voices may be subject to more criticism than men&#x2019;s, a double standard if you ask us.</p>
<p>In addition to pitch and quality, researchers have examined the effects of speaking rate. Previous studies, for example, indicate that faster speakers are perceived as more credible (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_110">Simonds, Meyer, Quinlan, &#x0026; Hunt, 2006</xref>) and persuasive (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_85">Miller, Maruyama, Beaber, &#x0026; Valone, 1976</xref>) than those who speak slower, perhaps because they appear more competent and knowledgeable. On the other hand, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_19">Buller and Aune (1988)</xref> found that for persuasion to occur, the optimal rate of speech may depend on both the encoding ability of the sender and the decoding ability of the receiver. Specifically, although good decoders were more likely to comply with speeches delivered at fast rates, poor decoders preferred slower rates. In a related study, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_112">Smith and Shaffer (1995)</xref> found that speeches delivered at faster rates hinder people&#x2019;s ability to scrutinize messages. Thus, consistent with the elaboration likelihood model (see <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter2">Chapter 2</xref>), people who heard a speech delivered at a normal speed were persuaded when the speech contained strong arguments, whereas those who heard accelerated speeches were persuaded equally by strong and weak messages. That said, if you&#x2019;re at all like us, you&#x2019;ve undoubtedly heard that old stereotype about &#x201C;fasttalking&#x201D; salespeople. You can&#x2019;t trust them, right? We&#x2019;re not sure about that, but one study found that those end-of-commercial disclaimers are less persuasive when delivered at fast-paced rather than normal-paced speeds (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_52">Herbst, Finkel, Allan, &#x0026; Fitzsimons, 2012</xref>). If you ask us, they&#x2019;re also pretty irritating.</p>
<p>Finally, you might be interested to know that not all studies on vocalics focus exclusively on human speech. Indeed, for those of you who&#x2019;ve been unfortunate enough to answer your telephone and find one of those eerie computer-synthesized voices selling some product on the other end, here&#x2019;s an interesting study. The study asked people to listen to persuasive messages spoken by either a natural human voice or a synthetic computerized voice and then measured how persuaded the people were. Surprisingly, the results indicated that the synthetic voice was just as persuasive as the human voice (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref8_115">Stern, Mullennix, Dyson, &#x0026; Wilson, 1999</xref>). Even so, in real life, we bet those computers are easier to hang up on.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec8_3">
<title>Summary</title>
<p>In this chapter, we learned that persuasion is not as simple as what you say. How you say something may be just as, if not more, important. We also learned that there are many categories of nonverbal communication that affect the process of persuasion. In our examination of kinesics, for instance, we saw that people are generally more persuasive when they (1) make eye contact, (2) use facial expressions and body movements that signal relaxation and sociability, and (3) use more emblems and illustrators but fewer adaptors. Similarly, we noted that people tend to be more compliant when they are touched or approached at distances that violate their expectations, as long as the touch and distances are not perceived as being too inappropriate. Moreover, people can make themselves appear more credible, dominant, or powerful, and, in turn, affect their persuasiveness through the use of <target target-type="page" id="page_203">203</target>time, artifacts, or physical appearance. Those who control others&#x2019; time, wear the right clothing at the right time, and are attractive tend to be more persuasive than their counterparts. Finally, various features of the voice, particularly its rate, influence how persuasive one tends to be.</p>
</sec>
</body>

<ref id="ref8_18"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Brownlow</surname>, <given-names>S.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Zebrowitz</surname>, <given-names>L. <ref id="ref8_19"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Buller</surname>, <given-names>D.
