</book-part>
<book-part book-part-type="chapter" id="chapter9">
<book-part-meta>
<title-group>
<label>9</label>
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_210">210</target>Structuring and Ordering Persuasive Messages</title>
<alt-title alt-title-type="running-head">Structuring and Ordering Persuasive Messages</alt-title>
</title-group>
<contrib-group>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Gass</surname>
<given-names>Robert H.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Seiter</surname>
<given-names>John S.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
</contrib-group>
</book-part-meta>
<body>
<p>THE STUDY OF PERSUASION and the study of rhetoric, if not one and the same, are closely related. Aristotle, for instance, defined <italic>rhetoric</italic> as &#x201C;the faculty of discovering all the available means of persuasion.&#x201D; Although, in everyday parlance the term &#x201C;rhetoric&#x201D; is often used in conjunction with words such as &#x201C;empty&#x201D; or &#x201C;meaningless,&#x201D; the connotations surrounding the term were not always so negative. The ancient Greeks and Romans, for example, considered rhetoric an essential ingredient in a good education. By the time the great Roman orator Cicero wrote about rhetoric, its study was divided into five parts. Four were called <italic>inventio, elocutio, memoria,</italic> and <italic>pronuntiatio,</italic> which focused on finding and inventing arguments, speaking with style, remembering arguments, and delivering speeches effectively. The last part, <italic>dispositio,</italic> focused on selecting the most important arguments and ideas and on the effective and orderly arrangements of those ideas <target target-type="page" id="page_211">211</target>and arguments (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_18">Corbett, 1971</xref>). Quintilian, another Roman rhetorician, noted the significance of strategically planning and organizing a persuasive message. As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_18">Corbett (1971)</xref> wrote:
<disp-quote>
<p>Quintilian hints at the more important concern of disposition when he says that it is to oratory what generalship is to war. It would be folly to hold a general to a fixed, predetermined disposition of his forces. He must be left free to distribute his troops in the order and proportion best suited to cope with the situation in which he may find himself at any particular moment. So he will mass some of his troops at one point on the battle line, thin them out at other points, keep other troops in reserve, and perhaps concentrate his crack troops at the most crucial area. Guided by judgment and imagination, the general stands ready to make whatever adjustments in strategy eventualities may dictate.</p>
<attrib>(pp. 299&#x2013;300)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>When planning a persuasive message, we are often confronted with questions of strategy such as &#x201C;What should I leave in, and what should I leave out?&#x201D; &#x201C;How should I arrange my arguments?&#x201D; and &#x201C;Should my strongest arguments come first or last?&#x201D; However, in addition to questions concerning the order of arguments within persuasive messages, there is the issue of the sequencing of messages when more than one persuader is involved. For example, imagine that you are about to speak to a large audience and want to convince that audience to lower tuition at your school. You know that after you&#x2019;ve spoken, another person will argue just the opposite: Tuition should be raised. Is there anything you can do to make your opponent&#x2019;s arguments less powerful? In this chapter we examine these issues.</p>
<sec id="sec9_1">
<title>Implicit and Explicit Conclusions: Let Me Spell it Out For You</title>
<p>According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_37">Lee (2014)</xref>, one of the most common approaches to advertising is based on the hope that consumers will draw their own inferences, which, in turn, will lead them to hold favorable attitudes toward a specific product. Consider, for example, the following ad:
<disp-quote>
<p>A commercial &#x2026; begins when a perky young woman comes on the screen and says, &#x201C;I&#x2019;ve got a question. Pay attention, there will be a quiz later. People prefer their hamburgers at home and flame-broiled. Now, if McDonald&#x2019;s and Wendy&#x2019;s <italic>fry</italic> their hamburgers and Burger King <italic>flame-broils</italic> theirs &#x2026; where do you think people should go for a hamburger?&#x201D;</p>
<attrib>(<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_77">Sawyer, 1988</xref>, p. 159)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>Because this advertisement relies on customers to draw their own inferences (in this case, &#x201C;People should go to Burger King&#x201D;), it uses what persuasion scholars refer to as an <italic>implicit conclusions approach</italic>. Had the spokesperson said, &#x201C;People should go to Burger King,&#x201D; the ad would have used an <italic>explicit conclusion</italic> approach, in which case claims are directly stated by the person sending the message (e.g., &#x201C;You should buy our product,&#x201D; or &#x201C;Our product is simply the best&#x201D;).</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_212">212</target>One possible advantage of an implicit approach is that receivers may prefer their own conclusions (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_34">Kardes, Kim, &#x0026; Lim, 1994</xref>). On the other hand, there are risks. For example, what if receivers are unable to draw the desired conclusions? Perhaps the content of the message is too complex. Or what if the situation doesn&#x2019;t lend itself to &#x201C;filling in the blanks&#x201D;? Some forms of entertainment are meant to be persuasive. When people are reading literature or watching television shows, for instance, can they be expected to actively draw conclusions? Or are they simply caught up in the drama, lost in a good book, and better off having conclusions drawn for them?</p>
<p>To find out, one study (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_49">Moyer-Guse, Jain, &#x0026; Chung, 2012</xref>) aired an episode of a prime-time television drama (<italic>Law &#x0026; Order: SVU</italic>) that focused on the issue of drunk driving. After viewing it, one group of participants watched an epilogue, featuring an actress from the show, who explicitly emphasized the dangers of drunk driving. Other participants watched the show or the epilogue, but not both. Results indicated that a combination of episode <italic>and</italic> epilogue was most persuasive. In other words, explicit messages worked best. This seems to be the case not only when it comes to narrative-based materials (e.g., literature and television), but also with persuasive speeches and arguments as well. Indeed, according to one review (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_19">Dillard, 2014</xref>), explicit messages are most persuasive because they provide clear directions to receivers.</p>
<p>That&#x2019;s not to say that implicit messages should be abandoned altogether. Indeed, given the right conditions, they can be especially effective. For instance, when messages are personally relevant to the receiver (e.g., Bubba is in the market for a new car when a Volkswagen ad pops up), implicit conclusions are more persuasive than explicit ones (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_78">Sawyer &#x0026; Howard, 1991</xref>). Similarly, because people who are &#x201C;high in the need for cognition&#x201D; (see <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter6">Chapter 6</xref>) are more likely to &#x201C;fill in the blanks,&#x201D; they prefer implicit approaches to explicit ones (Martin, Lang, and Wong (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_41">2003/2004</xref>). Finally, when people are suspicious of persuaders&#x2019; intentions, they tend to view an explicit-conclusion approach as pushy, rendering it less effective than an implicit approach (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_42">Martin &#x0026; Strong, 2016</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec9_2">
<title>Gain-Framed Versus Loss-Framed Messages: Keep on the Sunny Side?</title>
<p>Imagine for a moment that one of those deadly swine or avian flu viruses has swept into your neighborhood and is predicted to kill 600 people unless immediate action is taken. If you were in charge and given the following choices, which action would you choose?
<disp-quote>
<p><italic>Action 1</italic>: guarantees that 200 of the 600 people will be saved.</p>
<p><italic>Action 2</italic>: gives a 33.3 percent chance that all 600 people will be saved and a 66.6 percent chance that no one will be saved.</p>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>Got your answer?</p>
<p>If you are like the majority of people in a classic study conducted by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_84">Amos Tversky and Daniel Kahneman (1981)</xref>, you picked Action 1. Interestingly, however, another group of people were presented with exactly the same scenario, with the options worded in a slightly different way:
<disp-quote>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_213">213</target><italic>Action 1</italic>: guarantees that 400 of the 600 people will die.</p>
<p><italic>Action 2</italic>: gives a 33.3 percent chance that no one will die and a 66.6 percent chance that everyone will die.</p>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>Notice the difference? The first pair of actions looks on the brighter side by focusing on how many lives will be saved, while the second pair of actions portrays the glass half empty by focusing on how many will die. Persuasion scholars refer to messages like the first pair as <italic>gain-framed</italic> and messages like the second pair as <italic>loss-framed</italic>. And it turns out that such framing of messages can make a big difference. Indeed, the majority of people in the second group chose Action 2. This, then, led early researchers to conclude that, people are <italic>risk averse;</italic> they fear losses more than they prefer gains. As such, they are willing to take greater risks in order to avoid or recoup their losses (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_84">Tversky &#x0026; Kahneman, 1981</xref>).</p>
<p>Subsequent research, however, suggests that, overall, there are no noticeable differences between the persuasiveness of loss-framed and gain-framed messages (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_19">Dillard, 2014</xref>). That said, some conditions may favor one approach over the other. For instance, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_50">Nan (2012)</xref> found that <italic>present-minded people</italic>, who tend to focus on the short-term consequences of their decisions, responded more favorably to loss-framed messages. However, <italic>future-minded people</italic>, who consider long-term consequences of their decisions, were equally persuaded by loss- and gain-framed messages. Similarly, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_30">Hull and Hong (2016)</xref> found that people who are <italic>high sensation seekers</italic> (think bungee jumpers and skydivers) are more persuaded by loss-framed messages, while <italic>low sensation seekers</italic> are more persuaded by gain-framed messages. Another study found that, when people are in a good mood, loss-framed messages are most persuasive. This might be because positive moods help people cope with aversive, yet useful, information (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_87">Wirtz, Sar, &#x0026; Ghuge, 2015</xref>). Finally, because people may perceive disease-detecting behaviors (e.g., mammography, HIV screening) as risky in the sense that such behaviors might reveal something that is feared, using loss-framed messages may be a more effective way to motivate people to follow through on preventive medical check-ups. A doctor, for instance, might tell a patient, &#x201C;if you don&#x2019;t detect cancer early, you narrow your options for treatment.&#x201D; In contrast, because people may perceive disease-preventing behaviors (e.g., wearing sunscreen, exercising) as less risky, using gain-framed messages may be more effective. For instance, a doctor might offer a health-affirming message such as, &#x201C;Eating a lot of veggies will help you maintain your good health.&#x201D; Recent research using meta-analysis suggests that, while gain-framed appeals are indeed more effective than loss-framed appeals when trying to promote dental hygiene (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_53">O&#x2019;Keefe &#x0026; Jensen, 2007</xref>), loss-framed appeals were more effective than gain-framed appeals for promoting breast cancer-detection behaviors (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_54">O&#x2019;Keefe &#x0026; Jensen, 2009</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec9_3">
<title>Quantity Versus Quality of Arguments: The More the Merrier?</title>
<p>What are you going to have for your next dinner? If given the choice between an all-you-can-eat buffet and a fancy French restaurant, which would you pick? We imagine your answer depends on whether you like to fill your belly or reward your palate. Indeed, buffets usually offer lots of mediocre food, while a good French restaurant <target target-type="page" id="page_214">214</target>typically promises small portions of fine cuisine. What appeals to you more than likely depends on your priorities.</p>
<p>The same is probably true of persuasive messages. For some people, it is the <italic>quantity</italic> of arguments presented that counts. For them, a &#x201C;kitchen sink&#x201D; approach in which an advocate throws in every available argument works best. For other people, it is the <italic>quality</italic> of arguments that counts. For such people, the number of arguments is inconsequential. They require &#x201C;gourmet&#x201D; arguments. To illustrate this notion, we return briefly to Petty and Cacioppo&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_62">1986</xref>) elaboration likelihood model (ELM), which we discussed in more detail in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter2">Chapter 2</xref>.</p>
<p>Recall that, according to the ELM, there are two routes to persuasion: the <italic>peripheral route</italic> and the <italic>central route</italic>. First, when people are persuaded by a message that they have carefully scrutinized, they are being persuaded via the central route (of course, after scrutinizing a message, they may also remain unpersuaded). Often, however, people do not scrutinize the persuasive messages. Instead, they rely on the peripheral route, which involves mental shortcuts and simple decision rules.</p>
<p>According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_61">Petty and Cacioppo (1984)</xref>, one type of peripheral cue may be the number of arguments that a persuader presents. These researchers reasoned that some people might decide that a persuasive message containing a lot of arguments must be a lot better than one that does not (&#x201C;It must be a good argument! Look at all those reasons!&#x201D;). Of course, not all people would be persuaded by a lot of weak arguments. People who carefully scrutinized the arguments, they hypothesized, would not be fooled. Results of one study (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_61">Petty &#x0026; Cacioppo, 1984</xref>) supported this hypothesis. Specifically, when people were not involved in a topic, the quality of the arguments they heard did not matter. Quantity did, however. They tended to be persuaded by a lot of arguments, even if the arguments were weak. In contrast, when people were involved in the topic they were not taken in by a lot of weak arguments. They were persuaded only when strong arguments were used, especially when there were a lot of strong arguments (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_61">Petty &#x0026; Cacioppo, 1984</xref>). The moral of this line of research, then, is the following: If you think your audience will scrutinize your message, use strong arguments, but if your audience does not seem involved in the topic, a smorgasbord of arguments may be quite effective.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec9_4">
<title>The Use of Evidence: The Proof&#x2019;s Not in the Pudding</title>
<p>Different persuasive claims require different types of proof. One common form of proof is evidence. Evidence comes in many forms including narratives, personal anecdotes, statistics, quotations, testimonials, graphs and charts, and more. Physical evidence may be offered as well (e.g., lipstick on a collar, a &#x201C;smoking gun&#x201D; memo). As a general rule, evidence facilitates persuasion. A meta-analysis by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_71">Reinard (1988)</xref> demonstrates that as long as the evidence is relevant to the claim being made, evidence is almost always persuasive. As is the case with the quantity versus quality of arguments discussed above, the quantity of evidence matters more when receivers have low involvement, whereas the quality of evidence matters more when receivers have high involvement.</p>
<p>Evidence sometimes functions as a <italic>peripheral cue</italic>. For example, a prosecutor might pile up a &#x201C;mountain&#x201D; of evidence against a defendant. The sheer quantity of evidence may seem so great that jurors infer that the defendant must be guilty. However, <target target-type="page" id="page_215">215</target>evidence is put to best use when receivers rely on <italic>central processing</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_73">Reynolds &#x0026; Reynolds, 2002</xref>). A meta-analysis by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_83">Stiff (1986)</xref> revealed a significant positive correlation between evidence use and attitude change, especially when receivers were involved in the topic or issue.</p>
<p>Another benefit of using evidence is that it tends to increase a source&#x2019;s perceived credibility (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_51">O&#x2019;Keefe, 1998</xref>). <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_71">Reinard (1988)</xref> found a <italic>ceiling effect</italic> for the persuasiveness of evidence. If a source already has very high credibility, evidence won&#x2019;t help. Most everyday persuaders, however, need all the help they can get. Unless you are the foremost expert in the world on an issue, go ahead and include high-quality evidence, and lots of it, in your persuasive message.</p>
<p>One question that has been raised is whether some types of evidence are more persuasive than others. For instance, two meta-analyses have shown that using <italic>statistical proof</italic> is more effective than using <italic>anecdotal</italic> or <italic>narrative proof</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_3">Allen &#x0026; Preiss, 1997</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_36">Kim et al., 2012</xref>). Other studies (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_11">Braverman, 2008</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_26">Han &#x0026; Fink, 2012</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_28">Hoeken &#x0026; Hustinx, 2009</xref>) suggest that statistical evidence works best under some conditions (e.g., when making generalizations, when there is a lot of evidence, or when receiver involvement is high) while narrative proof works best in others (e.g., when narratives are vivid or when receiver involvement is low) (for additional considerations, see <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box9_1">Box 9.1</xref>).</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 9.1</label>
<caption><title>A butcher and a dog are in court.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig9_1.tif"/>
<p>Source: Cartoon by John Seiter and Robert Gass.</p>
</fig>
<boxed-text id="box9_1">
<label><target target-type="page" id="page_216">216</target>Box 9.1</label>
<caption><title>The Identifiable Victim Effect</title></caption>
<p>A short time ago, in a small community where one of the authors lives, a 14-year-old girl was found lying in a dry canal, shot in the back of her head. The suspects, two teenage boys, had allegedly lured her to the secluded location with plans to murder her. And yet, she survived. As the girl clung to life, people hurried to raise money. The author was moved to contribute, partly because of the incident&#x2019;s proximity, but mostly because the girl became more than just a statistic. Her name, photo, and story not only appeared on TV and newspapers, it was posted in banks, grocery stores, and other places the author frequently visited.</p>
<p>Beyond its horrible nature, the ordeal illustrates a phenomenon known as the <italic>identifiable victim effect</italic> (IVE), which suggests that people are more willing to help specific, recognizable victims than anonymous, statistical victims (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_33">Jenni &#x0026; Loewenstein, 1997</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_80">Schelling, 1968</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_82">Small, Lowenstein, &#x0026; Slovic, 2007</xref>). Why? According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_39">Lee and Feeley (2017)</xref>, an identifiable victim evokes stronger emotional reactions than a statistical victim. According to a meta-analysis of over 40 studies, this is especially true when the victim is a photographed child suffering from poverty and/or bearing little responsibility for the need (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_38">Lee &#x0026; Feeley, 2016</xref>).</p>
</boxed-text>
<p>Although such studies are fascinating for academic reasons, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_10">Braddock and Dillard (2016)</xref> argued that they are only meaningful if we assume that narrative and statistical evidence are naturally opposed to one other, which they are not. Indeed, not only are narratives persuasive in and of themselves, &#x201C;sometimes, characters in narratives speak in statistical arguments&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_10">Braddock &#x0026; Dillard, 2016</xref>, p. 448). As such, we think it&#x2019;s better to view different types of evidence as teammates rather than competitors. Specifically, if each type of evidence contributes to the persuasiveness of a message, why not include all of them in your message? Previous literature supports this approach. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_71">Reinard (1988)</xref>, for instance, argued that a persuader might combine narrative and statistical evidence for maximum effect. He recommends starting with a narrative example and then following up with statistics to show that the example is not atypical. Moreover, a recent meta-analysis indicated that the persuasive effects of different types of evidence (i.e., assertive evidence, statistical evidence, and evidence source qualification) were additive, meaning that each contributed to the persuasiveness of a message (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_36">Kim et al., 2012</xref>). Go team!</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec9_5">
<title>Repetition and Mere Exposure: You Can Say that Again</title>
<p>Although earlier we saw that using a lot of arguments in a message can sometimes make you more persuasive, what happens if you use the <italic>same</italic> argument or message repeatedly? Stated differently, can repeating your message make you more persuasive? Several researchers have argued that <italic>message repetition</italic> can be an effective tactic, although there is some disagreement concerning why. One perspective that has received considerable attention by persuasion scholars is known as the <italic>mere exposure effect</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_89">Zajonc, 1968</xref>). According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_76">Sawyer (1981)</xref>, &#x201C;This theory hypothesizes that familiar objects are more liked than less familiar ones, and that by merely being repetitively exposed, something initially unfamiliar will be looked upon more <target target-type="page" id="page_217">217</target>favorably&#x201D; (p. 238). In other words, mere exposure theory suggests that we really do &#x201C;acquire tastes,&#x201D; that things can &#x201C;grow on us,&#x201D; and that &#x201C;familiarity does <italic>not</italic> breed contempt.&#x201D; By way of example, previous research has found that people&#x2019;s faces are rated as more likable (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_74">Rhodes, Halberstadt, &#x0026; Brajkovich, 2001</xref>) and attractive (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_59">Peskin &#x0026; Newell, 2004</xref>) after repeated viewing, suggesting that the old saying &#x201C;love at first sight&#x201D; should be reconsidered. Research also suggests that the effect might generalize to other, similar faces. For instance, one study found that, compared to White participants who had not been exposed to images of Black and Asian people&#x2019;s faces, those who had been exposed reported greater liking for a different set of Black and Asian faces (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_90">Zebrowitz, White, &#x0026; Wieneke, 2008</xref>).</p>
<p>In one of our favorite classic studies, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_89">Zajonc (1968)</xref> found that repeated exposure even made the Chinese language more likable to people who didn&#x2019;t know how to read or speak it. In the study, subjects saw pictures of Chinese characters anywhere from 1 to 25 times. Afterward, the subjects were asked to guess the meanings of the characters. Interestingly, the characters that were seen most often were &#x201C;defined&#x201D; in much more positive ways than were the characters that were seen less often. With this in mind, it&#x2019;s not surprising to us that politicians pepper front yards, telephone poles, bumpers, and just about anything they can get their hands on with their names and faces.</p>
<p>Although research has shown that mere and repeated exposure to songs, people, languages, and posters may increase likability, there has been some disagreement about whether repeating longer or more complex messages is persuasive. Several studies, for example, have found evidence for an inverted U-curve in which repetition is persuasive up to a point (about three repetitions), but after that, excessive repetition decreases a message&#x2019;s persuasiveness (e.g., see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_72">Reinhard, Schindler, Raabe, Stahlberg, &#x0026; Messner, 2014</xref>). Why? Some researchers suggest that excessive repetition damages perceptions of source credibility (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_72">Reinhard et al., 2014</xref>). Others suggest that it leads to boredom or irritation (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_60">Petty &#x0026; Cacioppo, 1979</xref>), which may depend, of course, on how creative the message is (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_40">Lehnert, Till, &#x0026; Carlson, 2013</xref>). The authors, for example, are so tired of that tedious Energizer bunny that they wish it would &#x201C;keep going and going&#x201D; and never come back!!! And as long as we&#x2019;re complaining, is anybody else as tired as we are of those advertisements repeatedly popping up on their mobile devices? If so, they&#x2019;ve apparently got company. Indeed, one study found that businesses can get away with sending two SMS advertisements a day. After that, the ads cease to be persuasive, perhaps because they&#x2019;re perceived as irritating (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_70">Rau, Zhou, Chen, &#x0026; Lu, 2014</xref>).</p>
<p>Finally, some research (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_16">Claypool, Mackie, Garcia-Marques, McIntosh, &#x0026; Udall, 2004</xref>) suggests that the way people respond to repetition depends on how personally relevant the message is to the audience. Earlier, for example, we discussed a study involving messages about comprehensive exams. For students who thought they might have to take the exams, the messages were personally relevant. The opposite was true of those who thought they would never take the exams.</p>
<p>Claypool and her colleagues found that when people were presented with a familiar message that was not personally relevant to them, they were likely to respond to the message nonanalytically (analogous to peripheral processing in the ELM). In other words, rather than actively think about the message, the people responded to it <target target-type="page" id="page_218">218</target>merely on the basis of previously stored information. As a result, repetition did not increase the persuasiveness of strong over weak arguments.</p>
<p>On the other hand, when the people were presented with a familiar message that was personally relevant to them, they were likely to process the message analytically (this is analogous to ELM&#x2019;s central route to persuasion). Because repetition provided them with more opportunities to scrutinize the message, strong messages were more persuasive than weak ones when they were repeated (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_16">Claypool et al., 2004</xref>). In short, like other studies we have seen so far, the research on repetition illustrates the importance of knowing your audience before trying to persuade it.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec9_6">
<title>Order Effects and Persuasion: First Things First</title>
<p>In the preceding sections, we&#x2019;ve seen that strong arguments are not always the most persuasive and that people are generally more willing to hear a strong argument repeated rather than a weak one. Sometimes, however, it is not so easy to separate strong from weak arguments. In other words, persuasive messages often contain many arguments, some stronger than others. When that happens, whoever is delivering the persuasive message must decide how he or she should arrange the arguments. For example, imagine you&#x2019;re planning to give a persuasive speech. Should you begin with your strongest argument to create a favorable first impression? Or would it be better to dazzle your audience at the end of your speech so that the audience leaves feeling motivated? Of course, there&#x2019;s always a third option: You could compromise and put your strongest argument in the middle of your speech.</p>
<p>When strong arguments come first, a message is said to have an <italic>anticlimax order.</italic> When they come last, a message has a <italic>climax order.</italic> A message with a <italic>pyramidal order</italic> has strong arguments in the middle. But which order works best? Most research on this subject suggests that putting your strongest argument either first <italic>or</italic> last is the best strategy (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_81">Sikkink, 1956</xref>). Both seem to work better than sandwiching strong arguments in the middle of a speech, but beyond that, strong arguments seem effective at either the beginning or end of a message.</p>
<p>Of course, other variables may determine whether strong or weak arguments should go first or last. For example, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_85">Unnaba, Burnkrant, and Erevelles (1994)</xref> argued that the medium, or channel, by which a message is transmitted should determine whether strong arguments go first or last. Their study found that when groups were visually exposed to information about the characteristics of a book bag, their attitudes about the bag were the same whether they were exposed first to strong or weak arguments about the bag&#x2019;s quality. However, if they received auditory messages about the bag, they had more favorable attitudes when strong arguments came before weak arguments. Thus, when information is presented for people to hear, order is important.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec9_7">
<title>Primacy and Recency Effects: The First Shall be Last, and the Last Shall be First</title>
<p>Up to this point, we&#x2019;ve been looking at how arguments should be selected and organized within a single speech. The issue of what goes first and what goes last extends beyond single speeches, however. It is also possible to consider whether <italic>who</italic> <target target-type="page" id="page_219">219</target>goes first and <italic>who</italic> goes last affects the process of persuasion. Nowadays, it is quite common for political candidates to be involved in debates that are not very interactive. A coin is flipped, one candidate speaks, and then the other takes a turn. When that happens, is there any advantage to speaking first, or do all good things come to those who wait? As with research on climax and anticlimax, results in this area are mixed; some studies support a <italic>primacy effect</italic> (i.e., the first arguments presented have an advantage) but others support a <italic>recency effect</italic> (i.e., the later arguments presented have an advantage). However, several studies have investigated whether some circumstances favor primacy whereas others favor recency. We consider two such circumstances now.</p>
<p>First, a classic study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_48">Miller and Campbell (1959)</xref> demonstrated that the passage of time determines whether primacy or recency prevails. Primacy, they found, works best when you hear two opposing messages, back to back, and then have to wait a while before deciding what to do about the messages. For instance, a primacy effect is likely when you hear one candidate speak right after another and then wait a week before voting for one of the candidates. Why should this scenario work to the advantage of the candidate who speaks first? According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_48">Miller and Campbell (1959)</xref>, with time we tend to remember information we receive first. In other words, first impressions may be lasting impressions.</p>
<p>However, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_48">Miller and Campbell (1959)</xref> found that the recency effect is more likely when you hear one message, wait some time before hearing the opposing message, and then decide immediately after the second message what you are going to do. For instance, a recency effect is likely if you hear one candidate give a speech and then, just before voting, hear the opposing candidate give a speech. Why, in this situation, should the second candidate prevail? The researchers argued that because we tend to forget information rapidly, we&#x2019;ll have forgotten most of the first message by the time we vote. However, voting immediately after hearing the second message should enable us to remember most of the candidate&#x2019;s message, giving him or her an advantage (see <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig9_2">Figure 9.2</xref>).<xref ref-type="fn" rid="fn9_1"><sup>1</sup></xref></p>
<fig id="fig9_2" position="float">
<label>Figure 9.2</label>
<caption><title>Primacy versus recency effects in persuasion.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig9_2.tif"/>
</fig>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_220">220</target>In addition to time delay, the content of a message may determine whether first messages are more persuasive than second messages or vice versa. For instance, some research indicates that material that is relatively unsalient, noncontroversial, uninteresting, and unfamiliar to the audience tends to produce a recency effect. However, salient, interesting, controversial, and familiar material tends to produce a primacy effect, perhaps because an audience starts with a high level of interest that decreases over time (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_24">Furnham, 1986</xref>). Thus, if given the choice to speak first or last, you may want to base your decision on the nature of your material.</p>
<p>So far, we&#x2019;ve seen that the order in which we are exposed to messages affects how we respond to such messages, but does the same hold true when we are sampling products? Nowadays, it&#x2019;s common for marketers to spend billions of dollars each year (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_86">Wadhwa, Shiv, &#x0026; Nowlis, 2008</xref>) beckoning consumers with samples of products such as cheese, music, wine, and perfume. While some folks might sample one item, others, including a couple authors we know (ahem!), make meals through the process of &#x201C;researching&#x201D; multiple items. If you, too, are a multiple sampler, you might be interested in a series of studies conducted by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_9">Biswas, Grewal, and Roggeveen (2010)</xref>. These researchers examined what would happen if people sampled and evaluated more than one product. Results of their initial studies found evidence for a recency effect. Specifically, when people sampled two equally desirable music clips, they preferred the clip they sampled second, but when they sampled two equally undesirable music clips, they preferred the one they had sampled first. The same results were found for beverage samplers. This, the authors argued, is because people have better recall for what they sampled last. As such, if whatever they sampled last seemed icky, they preferred the alternative. In contrast, if whatever they sampled last seemed delightful, they stuck with it.</p>
<p>Interestingly, however, the pattern of results changed depending on the product being sampled. Specifically, in one of their later studies, Biswas and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_9">2010</xref>) found, as they had before, that people who sampled two equally desirable music clips preferred the second clip. Conversely, people who sampled two equally desirable scissors preferred the first pair of scissors. How can these results be explained? According to Biswas et al., <italic>nonexperiential products</italic>, such as scissors, are different from <italic>experiential products</italic>, such as food and music. This is because evaluations of experiential products depend on sensory reactions rather than informational components. Such sensory reactions are more immediate, thereby giving recently sampled products an advantage. In contrast, evaluations of nonexperiential products depend on informational components (e.g., the scissors&#x2019; blade sharpness, material, shape). As such, when sampling them, consumers&#x2019; short-term working memory can become crowded, making people less likely to notice the desirable qualities of the follow-up product. As a consequence, they tend to prefer the first product.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec9_8">
<title>An Ounce of Prevention: Inoculation, Message-Sidedness, and Forewarning</title>
<p>Parents sometimes admonish their children by saying &#x201C;and if your friends told you to jump off a cliff, would you do that, too?&#x201D; Scolding kids for something they&#x2019;ve already done, however, may just make them feel dumb. We&#x2019;re sure that parents would much <target target-type="page" id="page_221">221</target>rather prevent their children from doing &#x201C;dumb stuff&#x201D; in the first place. Likewise, governments have and still wish to prevent their citizens from adopting certain political viewpoints. For instance, did you know that citizens of the former Soviet Union were not supposed to play Monopoly, a clearly capitalistic game? Moreover, after World War II, there was widespread paranoia in the United States that Americans would be brainwashed by Communist propaganda. In short, although most of this book has been devoted to examining how people persuade other people, oftentimes a more immediate concern centers on how to <italic>prevent</italic> people from being persuaded. This section discusses research and theory on such preventive attempts. Because the term &#x201C;prevention&#x201D; often implies something happening <italic>before</italic> something else, we hope it&#x2019;s clear why we&#x2019;ve included this topic in a chapter on order effects in persuasion. We begin by examining inoculation theory, a classic perspective developed by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_44">William McGuire (1964)</xref>.</p>
<sec id="sec9_8_1">
<title>Inoculation Theory: Of Needles and Arguments</title>
<p><italic>Inoculation theory</italic> might best be understood by using a biological analogy. Specifically, if you want to keep your body healthy, what should you do? One strategy is to eat your Wheaties and Flintstones vitamins, avoid fats and sugars, stay rested, and exercise. This is what is known as a <italic>supportive strategy</italic> or treatment. The rationale here is that a stronger body will be more effective at fending off diseases and viruses. A second way to stay healthy is through <italic>inoculation.</italic> Perhaps your rear end has forgotten all of those needles it encountered in your youth (e.g., DPT immunizations), but if you&#x2019;ve ever had a flu shot or treated your dog or cat to a rabies booster, you&#x2019;re familiar with the reasoning behind such injections. The idea is that if you or Fido are exposed to a small dose of a disease virus, your bodies are better able to defend themselves against the virus later. This is because a dose that is too small to give you the disease often stimulates your body&#x2019;s defenses. Thus, if exposed to a stronger dose of the virus later, your body can overpower it.</p>
<p>According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_44">McGuire (1964)</xref>, this metaphor can also be applied to situations involving persuasion. For example, imagine you are a lawyer hired to defend someone who is accused of murder but who is innocent. You realize that after you have a chance to present your case, another lawyer will argue against you, presenting evidence that he or she hopes will help convict your client. With that in mind, what might you do? First, you could use a <italic>supportive strategy</italic>, making the jury&#x2019;s belief in your client&#x2019;s innocence as &#x201C;healthy&#x201D; as possible by spending a lot of time discussing reasons why the client is not guilty. On the other hand, you could use an <italic>inoculation strategy</italic>, which consists of two parts. The first, <italic>threat</italic>, warns jurors that a challenging argument is approaching. The second, <italic>refutational preemption</italic>, exposes jurors to weak doses of the approaching arguments and shows how such arguments might be refuted. The hope is that jurors exposed to weak doses of the opposition&#x2019;s argument will be less persuaded.</p>
<p>In a classic test of inoculation theory, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_46">McGuire and Papageorgis (1961)</xref> focused on the support and refutation of <italic>cultural truisms</italic>. A cultural truism is a belief whose truth is taken for granted. For example, the idea that &#x201C;it is good to brush your teeth after every meal, if possible&#x201D; is a cultural truism because it is generally accepted in our culture. According to McGuire and Papageorgis, however, cultural truisms should <target target-type="page" id="page_222">222</target>also be especially vulnerable when attacked. This is most likely because they have never been questioned. Returning to the biological metaphor for a moment, imagine that you were raised in a plastic bubble all your life, breathing only pure, germ-free air. What would happen if you stepped out of the bubble? Your body, having never been exposed to germs, would be especially vulnerable to them. Indeed, huge numbers of Native Americans died when missionaries exposed them to smallpox and other unfamiliar European viruses. According to McGuire and Papageorgis, the same thing can happen with cultural truisms. Unlike beliefs on such topics as capital punishment and the legalization of drugs, which may be challenged frequently, cultural truisms exist in what amounts to hermetically sealed bubbles; they&#x2019;ve never been questioned, they&#x2019;ve never required defense, and, therefore, they are sitting ducks when attacked. Even so, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_46">McGuire and Papageorgis (1961)</xref> argued that inoculation could help defend such beliefs.</p>
<p>To test this notion, these researchers exposed participants in their study to several messages that attacked cultural truisms (e.g., brushing your teeth too much damages the teeth&#x2019;s protective enamel). Two days before hearing the attacking messages, however, the participants were provided with one of two defenses against the attacks. One group of participants was equipped with a <italic>supportive defense</italic>&#x2014;that is, they were presented with several arguments that supported the cultural truisms. A second group of participants received an <italic>inoculation defense</italic> against the attacking message; they heard weak messages attacking a cultural truism in addition to arguments that refuted the attacks. A third group of participants was not provided with any defense. After hearing the attacking messages, the participants rated the degree to which they believed the cultural truisms were true or false. Results of the study supported the researchers&#x2019; expectations. Specifically, both the supportive and inoculation defenses were better than no defense at all at making participants more resistant to persuasion. Moreover, the group that had been inoculated was the most resistant to the attacking messages. A recent meta-analysis of more than 40 studies arrived at the same conclusion: Inoculation treatments are more effective than supportive treatments and nontreatments at conferring resistance to persuasion (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_5">Banas &#x0026; Rains, 2010</xref>).</p>
<p>Research also suggests that inoculating people against one particular argument may make them resistant to other, different arguments (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_57">Papageorgis &#x0026; McGuire, 1961</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_58">Parker, Rains, &#x0026; Ivanov, 2016</xref>). This &#x201C;<italic>blanket of protection</italic>,&#x201D; as it has been called (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_63">Pfau, 1997</xref>), is analogous to getting penicillin for pneumonia, but, as a result, also being protected against strep throat, scarlet fever, and rheumatic fever. For example, imagine you hold the belief that a person should drink eight glasses of water a day. A counterargument might be that too much water neutralizes acids that you need for proper digestion. To get you to resist such a counterargument, we might inoculate you by providing weak doses and refutations of the &#x201C;neutralize acid&#x201D; argument. In doing so, the research shows that you will become more resistant to other, new arguments to which you weren&#x2019;t originally exposed. For instance, you will be more resistant to a message that says drinking too much water now can wear out your bladder and lead to incontinence in old age.</p>
<p>Why would such generalized immunization work? According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_57">Papageorgis and McGuire (1961)</xref>, inoculation causes people to think of more arguments that support their beliefs, thereby making subsequent attacking arguments less credible. Thus, once a cultural truism has been defended, it is easier to defend against a later attack, even if the arguments attacking it are different from the original arguments.</p>
<boxed-text id="box9_2">
<label><target target-type="page" id="page_223">223</target>Box 9.2</label>
<caption><title>When Smoke Gets in Your Eyes: Inoculation Theory Applied</title></caption>
<p>It&#x2019;s clear from our discussion of inoculation theory that inoculation works effectively with messages that attack cultural truisms in laboratory settings. But how does the theory pan out when tested in &#x201C;real-life&#x201D; settings? First, Pfau, Van Bockern, and Kang (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_65">1992</xref>) argued that inoculation might be a good approach to use if you want to prevent young adolescents from smoking cigarettes. According to these researchers&#x2019; sources, more than 3,000 teenagers become smokers each day and, as a result, millions die of smoke-related diseases later in life. Because more than half of all smokers become &#x201C;regulars&#x201D; before high school, Pfau and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_65">1992</xref>) conducted their study using seventh graders. The students were shown videos that (1) warned them that peer pressure might cause them to change their minds about smoking and (2) presented and refuted arguments that challenged the students&#x2019; attitudes about smoking (e.g., smoking is cool). Results showed that inoculation helped students resist smoking, but only if the students had low self-esteem. Interestingly, however, a follow-up study two years later found just the opposite: Inoculation worked for students with high self-esteem but not for those with low self-esteem (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_64">Pfau &#x0026; Van Bockern, 1994</xref>). Thus, inoculation may wear off for those with low self-esteem, but there may be a sleeper effect for those with high self-esteem. Whatever the case, the authors argue that inoculating children against smoking must occur between elementary school and high school. After that, resistance strategies do not seem to work (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_64">Pfau &#x0026; Van Bockern, 1994</xref>).</p>
<p>Second, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_66">Pfau, Kenski, Nitz, and Sorenson (1990)</xref> examined inoculation in political campaigns. These researchers noted that negative advertisements, in which one politician attacks another, are becoming more common and that one-third to one-half of all political ads may be negative. With that in mind, what should politicians do? One possibility is to inoculate voters; another is to wait until they are attacked and then refute the attacks. To test which strategy works best, Pfau and colleagues sent messages to voters during the 1988 presidential campaign. Voters received messages attacking their preferred candidate. Some of the voters were inoculated before being exposed to the attack message. Other voters, after being exposed to the attack message, received a message that refuted it. Results of the study found that an inoculation strategy worked the best. Those voters who had been inoculated were the least affected by the attack message.</p>
<p>In short, research has shown inoculation theory to be robust in applied contexts. Of course, given our space, we have only been able to scratch the surface here, but we hope you can imagine the wide array of contexts where an inoculation approach shows promise. For instance, recent research has detailed the ways in which inoculation might be used to defend people against conspiracy propaganda (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_4">Banas &#x0026; Miller, 2013</xref>), deceptive advertising (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_43">Mason &#x0026; Miller, 2016</xref>), and inoculation itself (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_4">Banas &#x0026; Miller, 2013</xref>).</p>
</boxed-text>
<p>Over time, inoculation theory has been refined. Researchers have discovered a number of variables that influence resistance to persuasion, including the audience&#x2019;s level of involvement with a topic (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_67">Pfau et al., 2004</xref>), and the degree to which psychological reactance (e.g., telling people that their freedom to hold a current attitude will be challenged) can give a boost to inoculation effects (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_47">Miller, Ivanov, Sims, Compton, Harrison, Parker, Parker, &#x0026; Averbeck, 2013</xref>). Although we do not have space enough to discuss such research here, if you are hungry for more on inoculation theory, check out <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box9_2">Box 9.2</xref>.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec9_8_2">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_224">224</target>One-Sided Versus Two-Sided Messages: Both Sides Now</title>
<p>In the previous section, we saw that either supportive or inoculation treatments can be effective at making people resistant to persuasion. With that in mind, you might be wondering if a <italic>combination</italic> of supportive and inoculation treatments might work even better. A considerable amount of past research has examined this issue by trying to determine whether a <italic>one-sided message,</italic> presenting arguments in favor of a single proposition, is more or less persuasive than a <italic>two-sided message,</italic> which presents arguments in favor of one proposition and considers opposing arguments as well. In other words, when trying to persuade an audience to accept your arguments and reject your opponent&#x2019;s arguments, is it best to address your opposition or ignore them?</p>
<p>The first empirical study to investigate this issue was conducted by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_29">Hovland, Lumsdaine, and Sheffield (1949)</xref>, at the request of the War Department during World War II. The study&#x2019;s purpose was to determine the best way to convince U.S. soldiers that the war in Japan would last a considerable amount of time. The researchers asked their subjects to listen to one of two messages. One presented arguments that supported the war with Japan and argued that the war would be a long one. The other message included the same arguments as the first, in addition to a brief description of opposing arguments. Results of the study found that the effectiveness of one- or two-sided arguments depended on two factors: education level and initial attitude. First, the one-sided message was more effective for persuading subjects with little education, whereas the two-sided message was more effective for persuading subjects who had at least a high school education. Second, when the subjects initially agreed with the argument presented, they were more persuaded by the one-sided argument. Just the opposite was true of subjects who initially disagreed with the argument presented.</p>
<p>Although the large number of studies examining the effects of one- and two-sided messages has produced some contradictory findings, work by Daniel O&#x2019;Keefe (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_52">1999</xref>) and <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_1">Mike Allen (1998)</xref> has demonstrated that such findings are not contradictory when you consider the type of two-sided messages that have been used in past studies. Specifically, they argue that some studies have used two-sided messages that are <italic>nonrefutational.</italic> In these messages, opposing arguments are mentioned but not argued against. However, some studies have used two-sided messages that are <italic>refutational,</italic> such as those used in the inoculation studies discussed earlier. In these messages, opposing arguments are not only mentioned but also shown to be inferior to the position advocated by the speaker.</p>
<p>These researchers suspected that <italic>two-sided messages</italic> that are refutational would be much more persuasive than those that merely mention opposing arguments. In fact, they suspected that two-sided arguments that did not refute opposing arguments might make a speaker less persuasive than would <italic>one-sided arguments</italic>. Hence, the contradictions of past research.</p>
<p>To test their idea, these researchers (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_1">Allen, 1998</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_2">Allen et al., 1990</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_52">O&#x2019;Keefe, 1999</xref>) examined a large number of previous studies on message-sidedness, this time taking into account both types of two-sided messages. What they found confirmed their hypothesis: Two-sided messages were more persuasive than one-sided messages, as long as the two-sided messages were refutational. When they were not refutational, they were less persuasive than one-sided messages (see <xref ref-type="table" rid="tbl9_1">Table 9.1</xref>). Moreover, speakers <target target-type="page" id="page_225">225</target>who used two-sided refutational messages were more credible than those who used one-sided messages (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_52">O&#x2019;Keefe, 1999</xref>), which makes sense. Indeed, such speakers may not only seem more informed, they may seem more trustworthy because they are sharing the opposing side&#x2019;s point of view. Consistent with this notion, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_20">Eisend (2010)</xref> found that speakers boosted their credibility when they presented two-sided messages, as long as they were perceived to be doing so voluntarily. This, of course, makes sense. If a spokesperson for a cigarette company disclosed all the negative side effects that might result from smoking, and we knew the spokesperson was required to do so by law, why should we trust him or her? Whatever the case, the practical implications of this research are clear: When delivering a message, present the opponent&#x2019;s perspective, but make sure you &#x201C;go all the way&#x201D; by refuting your opponent&#x2019;s position. It will make you appear more credible and help you be more persuasive. This is particularly true when your audience is ambivalent about the issue (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_17">Cornelis, Cauberghe, &#x0026; De Pelsmacker, 2013</xref>).</p>
<table-wrap id="tbl9_1">
<label>Table 9.1</label>
<caption><title>Hierarchy of Effectiveness for Message-Sidedness</title></caption>

</oasis:table>
</table-wrap>
</sec>
<sec id="sec9_8_3">
<title>Forewarning: You&#x2019;d Better Watch Out</title>
<p>In the classic film <italic>A Few Good Men,</italic> Kevin Bacon and Tom Cruise play lawyers who are prosecuting and defending two Marines accused of murder. At the beginning of the trial, Bacon&#x2019;s character, the prosecutor, tells the jury to beware; the defense attorney, he warns, &#x201C;will try a little misdirection. He&#x2019;s going to astonish you with stories of rituals and dazzle you with official-sounding terms like &#x2018;Code Red.&#x2019;&#x201D; A similar tactic was used in the 2000 presidential campaign, when Al Gore warned voters that George W. Bush would try to scare them about issues such as Medicare. In each of these cases, the warnings were not effective (both Bacon and Gore lost), but considerable research indicates that <italic>forewarning</italic> an audience of a persuasive message can be an effective way of making the audience resistant to that message. Of course, this line of research is related to inoculation, although the two tactics are distinct; whereas inoculation refutes and exposes people to a weakened dose of the attacking message, forewarning only makes people aware of a possible <italic>counterattitudinal</italic> attack.</p>
<p>According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_56">Papageorgis (1968)</xref>, there are two types of forewarning messages. First, you can simply warn people that they will hear a message intended to persuade them. Second, you can warn people by telling them about the topic and position taken in the persuasive message. Research indicates that both tactics are moderately effective at inducing resistance to persuasion (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_8">Benoit, 1998</xref>). Even so, the process by which each tactic works may be different. For instance, when people are warned about a topic and position, it permits them to arm themselves with counterarguments before <target target-type="page" id="page_226">226</target>the attack. If forewarning about a persuasive topic and position works by making people <italic>counterargue</italic>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_22">Freedman and Sears (1965)</xref> thought that the amount of time between the warning and the persuasive speech might be an important variable moderating the effect of forewarning. They hypothesized that people who were given more time between the warning and the persuasive message would be able to think of more counterarguments and should, therefore, be more resistant to persuasion than those who were given little time. To test this hypothesis, the researchers told high school students that they would hear a message arguing that teenagers were a menace on the road and should not be allowed to drive. After being warned, some of the students were exposed to the message immediately, while others did not hear the message for 2 or 10 minutes. Results of the study confirmed the hypothesis; the high schoolers who waited 10 minutes were most resistant to the message. Those who were exposed to the message immediately were least resistant.</p>
<p>Despite these findings, some scholars have questioned the notion that forewarning leads to counterarguing and then resistance. Meta-analyses by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_8">Benoit (1998)</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_69">Quinn and Wood (2004)</xref>, and <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_88">Wood and Quinn (2003)</xref>, for instance, found that the presence of a delay between a warning and a message did not matter. Thus, there is some question as to whether counterarguing is really necessary for developing resistance.</p>
<p>To examine this issue further, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_75">Romero, Agnew, and Insko (1996)</xref> conducted a study. These researchers argued that if forewarning leads people to counterargue, then we should notice two things. First, people who are more motivated to counterargue should be more affected by forewarning than those who are not. Second, people who have the ability to counterargue should be more affected by forewarning than those who do not have the ability.</p>
<p>To test this notion, Romero and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_75">1996</xref>) forewarned college students who either did or did not have the motivation or ability to counterargue with a persuasive message. The researchers motivated some of the students to counterargue by making the topic of the message more personally relevant to them. Specifically, they told some of the students that the message they were about to be exposed to argued that they all should be required to take comprehensive exams before graduation. The remaining students were told that the comprehensive exams would not be required for 10 years, long after they had left the university. Thus, this second group of students was not that motivated to counterargue. In addition, the researchers hindered some students&#x2019; ability to counterargue by distracting them. Specifically, after they were warned, some students simply waited 3 minutes before being exposed to the message about comprehensive exams. Other students, however, were distracted during the 3 minutes with difficult letter and number puzzles. Thus, their ability to counterargue was hampered. Results of the study confirmed the researchers&#x2019; suspicions; compared to students without the motivation and ability to counterargue, the students who found the topic personally relevant and who were not distracted by puzzles were more resistant to the persuasive message (for more on distraction and persuasion, see <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box9_3">Box 9.3</xref>). In short, it seems that forewarning of topic and position made people more resistant by encouraging counterarguing.</p>
<p>That said, while 3 minutes without distraction helped people who had been forewarned, some evidence suggests that the effects of forewarning can wear off over longer periods of time. One study, for example, warned a group of older adults to be wary of a particular telephone scam. Later, these same adults were contacted via <target target-type="page" id="page_227">227</target>telephone with the same mock scam. Interestingly, those who were contacted 2 weeks after being warned were generally able to defend themselves, but those who were contacted 4 weeks later were not (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_79">Scheibe et al., 2014</xref>).</p>
<p>An additional line of forewarning research is based on the <italic>strength model of self-control</italic> (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_6">Baumeister, Vohs, &#x0026; Tice, 2007</xref>). According to this model, in the same way that our muscles get tired from exertion, our mental resources become depleted when we work hard to regulate our behavior. As a result of such depletion, our willpower suffers. If you&#x2019;ve ever been to a dinner party while trying to diet, you may understand just how exhausting self-control can be. And if you&#x2019;re at all like us, by the end of such meals, you&#x2019;ve been spotted shoveling dessert into your face by the handful. But what if you&#x2019;d been warned before arriving to the party that your favorite dessert was on the menu? Would you be better able to resist it? According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_32">Janssen, Fennis and Pruyn (2010)</xref>, such warnings are effective because, when exposed to them, we conserve our mental resources so we can mobilize them when needed later. To illustrate, these researchers conducted several studies. In them, some participants were mentally tuckered out (e.g., they gave speeches about themselves but were not allowed to use the word &#x201C;I&#x201D;), while others were not. In addition, some participants were warned that they would eventually be exposed to persuasive <target target-type="page" id="page_228">228</target>messages asking them to volunteer their time or money for charitable causes. Results showed that mentally depleted participants, compared to nondepleted participants, were more persuadable unless they had been forewarned. Apparently, the forewarned participants conserved their mental energy, enabling them to counterargue effectively and, in turn, to resist influence.</p>
<boxed-text id="box9_3">
<label>Box 9.3</label>
<caption><title>Distraction and Persuasion</title></caption>
<p>Did you know that it is not unheard of for people working on political campaigns to send hecklers to their opponents&#x2019; speeches? The practice is known as bracketing (Pinocchio index, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_68">1996</xref>). It almost certainly is designed to fluster the heckled candidate. What bracketers may not be aware of, however, is that heckling may actually benefit the heckled speaker. Indeed, a study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_7">Beatty and Kruger (1978)</xref> found that when an audience identifies with a heckled speaker, the speaker is more persuasive and is perceived as more credible. But how is it possible that the effects of heckling can be exactly opposite to those intended? According to one perspective, distraction, whether caused by hecklers, flashing lights, eating, static, loud noises, or other things, prevents people from scrutinizing a counterattitudinal message. And if they cannot scrutinize the message, people are more likely to be persuaded by it.</p>
<p>Although considerable research supports this explanation (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_21">Festinger &#x0026; Maccoby, 1964</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_35">Keating &#x0026; Brock, 1974</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_55">Osterhouse &#x0026; Brock, 1970</xref>), <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_14">Buller (1986)</xref> and <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_15">Buller and Hall (1998)</xref> examined several studies and found more support for a different perspective. Specifically, learning theory (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_45">McGuire, 1969</xref>) argues that to be persuaded, people must first comprehend a message. Because distraction hinders comprehension, distraction also should decrease the persuasiveness of a message. Buller and Hall&#x2019;s work supports this notion by indicating that distraction generally reduces the effectiveness of a persuasive message. This may depend, however, on the type of distraction being examined. For instance, in addition to distraction that is external to a communicator (such as hecklers and loud noises), a second type of distraction can be initiated by the communicator. For example, you might be distracted by someone who stands too close or who uses intense language. According to Buller and Hall, when a distraction is initiated by a communicator, our reaction depends not so much on comprehension or counterarguments as on the communicator&#x2019;s credibility. Specifically, when distracted by a highly credible source, we tend to be more persuaded; when distracted by a less credible source, we tend to be less persuaded. Thus, if you are a highly credible source and want to be persuasive, feel free to distract your audience.</p>
</boxed-text>
<p>It may be the case, however, that counterarguing is not the only factor mediating the effectiveness of forewarning. To be sure, a study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_31">Jacks and Devine (2000)</xref> found that, for some people, forewarning heightened not only counterarguing but also irritation&#x2014;that is, some people, when warned that specific attitudes they held would be attacked, became more agitated and angry. This, in turn, led them to be more resistant to attacks (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_31">Jacks &#x0026; Devine, 2000</xref>).</p>
<p>Although warning people about a topic and position provides them with an opportunity to think of and rehearse counterarguments, it is clear that the other type of warning&#x2014;a warning about persuasive intent&#x2014;does not. Indeed, if people don&#x2019;t know what the topic will be, how can they think of counterarguments? But if counterarguing is not responsible for the effectiveness of this type of warning, what is? As noted in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter8">Chapter 8</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_12">Brehm (1966)</xref> and <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_13">Brehm and Brehm (1981)</xref> argued that when people feel that their freedom to behave or think in a certain way is restricted, they experience <italic>psychological reactance</italic> and attempt to restore their freedom. If you&#x2019;ve ever tried reverse psychology on a child, you are familiar with how psychological reactance works. For instance, some time ago, one of the authors was having trouble getting his preschooler to pack up his toys, leave his pals, and get in the car to go home. The child, of course, thought he had the freedom to choose: stay with his pals or get in the car. However, when dad pretended he was leaving without his son, the child gathered his toys and hurried into the car. Why? His freedom to choose the ride home was being taken away. He was reacting to the loss of freedom.</p>
<p>According to some writers (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_23">Fukada, 1986</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_27">Hass &#x0026; Grady, 1975</xref>), this phenomenon occurs when you are warned that someone intends to persuade you. It&#x2019;s like a comedian who tells you that he or she will make you laugh before telling a joke. We like to feel free to laugh or to be persuaded, and if we feel that freedom is in jeopardy, we experience <italic>psychological reactance</italic>; we don&#x2019;t laugh or we resist persuasion. To illustrate this principle, Fukada told one group of people that they would be exposed to a message intended to make them afraid and to change their attitude. Another group did not receive the warning. Later, both groups received a message that tried to persuade them to be tested for syphilis. Results indicated that the warned group not only experienced more psychological reactance, it was also less persuaded than the unwarned group.</p>
<p>Before concluding this section, we should note that not all research indicates that forewarning increases resistance to persuasion. Indeed, a meta-analysis by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_88">Wood and Quinn (2003</xref>; see also <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_69">Quinn &#x0026; Wood, 2004</xref>) found that, in some cases, forewarning shifts attitudes toward the impending message. It all depends on the motives of the audience. Specifically, as we have seen, when people want to defend their existing attitudes, forewarning is effective at increasing resistance. On the other hand, sometimes warnings threaten people&#x2019;s self-concepts by suggesting that they may be gullible or vulnerable to influence. Rather than resist, people may shift their attitude toward the future appeal in order to reduce its impact. In other cases, people may be <target target-type="page" id="page_229">229</target>concerned about the impressions they are leaving on others. For instance, they may not want to appear pigheaded to their peers. In these cases, warnings may move them to a more neutral, easily defensible position that helps them leave a good impression (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_69">Quinn &#x0026; Wood, 2004</xref>).</p>
<p>Whatever the case, because forewarning has the potential to make people more resistant to persuasion, you might be wondering what you should do if you ever want to persuade an audience that has been warned or is aware of your intent to persuade them. With that question in mind, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_8">Benoit (1998)</xref> offered the following advice:
<disp-quote>
<p>In these cases, the persuader may wish to attempt to compensate for the inhibiting effects of forewarning. The persuader could stress a lack of bias, emphasize that the audience&#x2019;s best interests were considered (and not just the persuader&#x2019;s own selfish interests), explain that both sides of the issue were carefully considered before a position was taken, or simply ask the audience to keep an open mind. At the very least, persuaders should moderate their expectations for success, keeping in mind that their persuasive task is more difficult when the audience is forewarned.</p>
<attrib>(pp. 147&#x2013;148)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec9_9">
<title>Summary</title>
<p>In this chapter, we examined the topic of message selection and organization. First, we saw that, depending on the characteristics of the audience, it&#x2019;s sometimes better for a persuader to tell the audience what to believe, but at other times it&#x2019;s best to let the audience members draw their own conclusions. Second, we saw that the ways in which messages are framed affect how they are reacted to. Third, we saw that when selecting arguments to use for persuasion, quality arguments matter with audiences that will scrutinize the message, but quantity works for less discerning audiences. Fourth, we discussed the role of evidence in the process of persuasion. Fifth, we examined message repetition and noted the conditions under which it increases and decreases persuasion. Sixth, we looked at the ways in which arguments might be ordered or arranged in a speech and indicated that the most effective order depends on several variables. Similarly, our examination of primacy and recency effects showed that when two people are giving opposing speeches, under some circumstances the first speaker may have the advantage, while under others the last speaker may have the advantage. Finally, we explored the ways in which people may be more resistant to persuasion, either by being inoculated with a weak dose of an opposing argument, by presenting two-sided refutational messages, or by being warned about the possibility of an attacking argument.</p>
</sec>
</body>
<back>
<fn-group>
<title>Note</title>
<fn id="fn9_1"><label>1</label><p><xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref9_48">Miller and Campbell (1959)</xref> also found that if there is a time delay between both messages, and between the second message and the measurement of attitude, neither primacy nor recency works better. Moreover, if there are no time delays between messages and the measurement of attitudes, neither primacy nor recency works better.<target target-type="page" id="page_230">230</target></p></fn>
</fn-group>

<ref id="ref9_74"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Rhodes</surname>, <given-names>G.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Halberstadt</surname>, <given-names>J.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Brajkovich</surname>, <given-names>G.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2001</year>). <article-title>Generalization of mere exposure effects to averaged and composite faces</article-title>. <source>Social Cognition</source>, <volume>19</volume>, <fpage>57</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>70</lpage>.<target target-type="page" id="page_234">234</target></mixed-citation></ref>

</book-part>
<book-part book-part-type="chapter" id="chapter10">
<book-part-meta>
<title-group>
<label>10</label>
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_235">235</target>Compliance Gaining</title>
<alt-title alt-title-type="running-head">Compliance Gaining</alt-title>
</title-group>
<contrib-group>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Gass</surname>
<given-names>Robert H.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Seiter</surname>
<given-names>John S.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
</contrib-group>
</book-part-meta>
<body>
<p>A POLICE OFFICER pulls a driver to the side of the road and says, &#x201C;Sir, your car was swerving all over the place. I&#x2019;d like you to blow into this breathalyzer, please.&#x201D;</p>
<p>&#x201C;I apologize,&#x201D; the driver replies, &#x201C;but I&#x2019;m asthmatic and can&#x2019;t blow into anything without having an asthma attack.&#x201D;</p>
<p>&#x201C;Alright. Let&#x2019;s head down to the station for a urine sample.&#x201D;</p>
<p>&#x201C;I don&#x2019;t think so, officer. Given my diabetes, who knows what that might do to my blood sugar?&#x201D;</p>
<p>&#x201C;You&#x2019;ll have no choice but to take a blood test, then.&#x201D;</p>
<p>&#x201C;Afraid not,&#x201D; the driver says. &#x201C;You see, I&#x2019;m a hemophiliac and even the slightest prick of a needle could make me bleed to death.&#x201D;</p>
<p>&#x201C;Fine! Step out of your car, close your eyes, and walk in a straight line.&#x201D;</p>
<p>&#x201C;Sorry, officer.&#x201D;</p>
<p>&#x201C;What now?&#x201D;</p>
<p>&#x201C;I&#x2019;m too drunk to do that.&#x201D;</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_236">236</target>We like this old joke not just because we think it&#x2019;s funny, but also because it illustrates one of the main themes in this chapter. Specifically, when faced with a situation involving persuasion, there&#x2019;s more than one way to skin a cat. Indeed, just as the police officer uses a variety of approaches&#x2014;some more polite than others&#x2014;to influence the driver, and just as the driver resists the officer in an assortment of ways, real-life persuaders often come up with any number of different approaches for persuading or thwarting the persuasive attempts of others. What types of strategies are available to people who are seeking or resisting compliance? What specific approaches are people most likely to use? Do the approaches people use vary across situations?</p>
<p>All of these issues have been explored by researchers who study what is often labeled <italic>compliance gaining</italic>, the topic of this chapter. Before we discuss how this important subject has been investigated and what has been found, let&#x2019;s begin with a few definitions.</p>
<sec id="sec10_1">
<title>Actions Speak the Loudest: A Definition of Compliance Gaining</title>
<p>We once knew a guy who liked to say, &#x201C;I don&#x2019;t care if you hate me, as long as you&#x2019;re nice to me.&#x201D; We think that this maxim is a fine illustration of the distinction between thoughts and actions that undergirds the primary difference between compliance and other forms of persuasion. As we mentioned in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter2">Chapter 2</xref>, it is useful to distinguish between the terms <italic>persuasion</italic> and <italic>compliance.</italic> Persuasion, an umbrella term, is concerned with changing beliefs, attitudes, intentions, motivations, and behaviors. Compliance is more restrictive, typically referring to changes in a person&#x2019;s overt behavior. For example, a mother might tell her 10-year-old son, &#x201C;Take out the trash.&#x201D; If the child says, &#x201C;I don&#x2019;t want to,&#x201D; the mother might respond, &#x201C;I don&#x2019;t care what you want.
