Take out the trash!&#x201D; In this case the mother is not concerned with belief or attitude change. She doesn&#x2019;t care if the child likes taking out the trash, believes in recycling, and so on. She just wants compliance, or behavior change (i.e., the trash emptied). In short, research examining compliance gaining generally focuses on persuasion aimed at getting others to do something or to act in a particular way.</p>
<p>We should also note that compliance gaining differs from more traditional notions of persuasion in other important ways. First, for the most part, studies of compliance gaining have concentrated on influence in interpersonal and/or face-to-face contexts rather than in one-to-many contexts. Beyond that, two lines of compliance-gaining research can be identified. The first has concerned itself with determining which strategies are most effective at persuading receivers, a topic we&#x2019;ll get to in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter11">Chapter 11</xref>. The second line has focused more on &#x201C;senders&#x201D; rather than &#x201C;receivers.&#x201D; Specifically, such research has attempted to identify the broad array of strategies available to people who want to influence others. What&#x2019;s more, such studies have examined which strategies people are most likely to <italic>select and use</italic> when trying to persuade others. As such, a better title for this chapter might be &#x201C;compliance seeking,&#x201D; even though we&#x2019;ll stick with the more traditional term &#x201C;compliance gaining.&#x201D; We start by discussing how this type of research got started.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec10_2">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_237">237</target>In The Beginning: The Roots of Compliance-Gaining Research</title>
<p>Imagine you are a parent with a son whose room is a pigsty. What would you do to get him to clean up? Can you think of several different approaches? If not, consider the work of two sociologists, Gerald Marwell and David Schmitt (1976), who might help add a few tactics to your repertoire. Specifically, after examining past research and theory in the areas of power and influence, these two researchers developed a taxonomy of 16 different tactics that might be used to gain compliance (these tactics are presented in <xref ref-type="table" rid="tbl10_1">Table 10.1</xref>). Afterward, they told people to imagine themselves in four scenarios (i.e., requesting a tutor, doing more studying, making a purchase, and seeking a promotion) and asked the people how likely they would be to use each of the 16 tactics in each of the scenarios. Finally, based on their responses, Marwell and Schmitt grouped the tactics in terms of their commonalities, ultimately identifying five basic types of compliance-gaining strategies:
<list list-type="bullet">
<list-item><p><italic>Rewarding activity:</italic> involves seeking compliance in an active and positive way (e.g., making promises).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Punishing activity:</italic> involves seeking compliance in an explicitly negative way (e.g., making threats).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Expertise:</italic> involves attempts to make a person think that the persuader has some special knowledge (e.g., trying to appear credible).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Activation of impersonal commitments:</italic> involves attempts to appeal to a person&#x2019;s internalized commitments (e.g., telling the person he or she will feel bad about him/herself if he/she does not comply).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Activation of personal commitments:</italic> relies on appeals to a person&#x2019;s commitment to others (e.g., pointing out that the person is indebted and should, therefore, comply to repay the favor).<target target-type="page" id="page_238">238</target></p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 10.1</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig10_1.tif"/>
<p>Source: Calvin and Hobbes &#x00A9; (1995) Watterson. Disttributed by Universal Press Syndicate. Reprinted with permission. All Rights Reserved.</p>
</fig>
<table-wrap id="tbl10_1">
<label>Table 10.1</label>
<caption><title>Marwell and Schmitt&#x2019;s Compliance-Gaining Tactics, with Examples of How You Might Get Your Son, Beaufort, to Clean His Room</title></caption>
<oasis:table frame="topbot" colsep="0" rowsep="0">
<oasis:tgroup cols="2">
<oasis:colspec colnum="1" colname="col1" align="left"/>
<oasis:colspec colnum="2" colname="col2" align="left"/>
<oasis:tbody>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>1.</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Promising a reward: You tell a person you will reward him/her if he/she complies with your request. For example, you offer to buy Beaufort an ice-cream cone if he cleans his room.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>2.</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Threatening a punishment: You tell a person you will punish him/her if he/she does not comply with your request. For example, you threaten to give away Beaufort&#x2019;s Wii system if he doesn&#x2019;t tidy up.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>3.</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Using positive expertise: Because you know what&#x2019;s best or &#x201C;how things are,&#x201D; you tell a person that he/she will benefit by complying with your request. For example, you tell Beaufort that, based on your experience, you know that clean, organized people are those who succeed in life.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>4.</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Using negative expertise: Because you know what&#x2019;s best or &#x201C;how things are,&#x201D; you tell a person that he/she will be negatively affected if he/she does not comply with your request. For example, you tell Beaufort that, based on your experience, you know that people who are slobs do not succeed in life.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>5.</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Promoting liking: You get a person to like you before asking him/her to comply with your request. For example, you act cheerful and give Beaufort a lot of attention before asking him to clean his room.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>6.</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Using reciprocity: Before seeking compliance, you give a person something he/she wants or needs. For example, you buy Beaufort a video game he&#x2019;s always wanted and then ask him to clean his room.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>7.</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Administering punishment: You keep punishing a person and don&#x2019;t stop until he/she complies with your request. For example, you forbid Beaufort to use his Wii system and explain that he won&#x2019;t be allowed to use it until he keeps his room clean for a month.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>8.</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Creating indebtedness: You tell a person that he/she owes you compliance because of something you previously did for him/her. For example, you tell Beaufort that you are a good parent who bends over backward to provide the things he wants and needs, so he owes it to you to keep his room clean.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>9.</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Generating moral obligation: You tell a person that it would be immoral for him/her not to comply with your request. You tell Beaufort that people who are disorganized and dirty are morally bad.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>10.</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Promoting positive esteem: You tell a person that complying will improve his/her self-esteem. For example, you tell Beaufort that having a clean room will make him feel good about himself.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>11.</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Promoting negative esteem: You tell a person that not complying will hurt his/her self-esteem. For example, you tell Beaufort that having a filthy and untidy room will make him feel bad about himself.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>12.</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Using positive altercasting: You note that admirable people would comply with your request, and suggest that, to be like such people, this person should comply with your request. For example, you tell Beaufort that good boys like him naturally want to keep their rooms clean and tidy (for more on this strategy, see <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box10_1">Box 10.1</xref>).</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>13.</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Using negative altercasting: You note that people with negative qualities would not comply with your request, and suggest that, to avoid being like such people, this person should comply with your request. For example, you tell Beaufort that only bratty little boys have dirty rooms, so he should clean his room.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>14.</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Being altruistic: You tell the person how much his/her assistance would help you. For example, you tell Beaufort that you are overwhelmed with work and that he could help you a great deal if he kept his room clean so you didn&#x2019;t have to do it for him.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>15.</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Using positive admiration: You tell the person that people he/she admires will hold him/her in higher regard if he/she complies. For example, you tell Beaufort that his older brother, Timmy (who Beaufort idolizes), will be proud of him if he keeps his room clean.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
<oasis:row>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>16.</p></oasis:entry>
<oasis:entry align="left"><p>Using negative admiration: You tell the person that people he/she admires will hold him/her in lower regard if he/she doesn&#x2019;t comply. For example, you tell Beaufort that his older brother, Timmy (who Beaufort idolizes), will be ashamed of him if he keeps his room messy.</p></oasis:entry>
</oasis:row>
</oasis:tbody>
</oasis:tgroup>
</oasis:table>
<table-wrap-foot>
<attrib>Based upon <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_52">Marwell &#x0026; Schmitt (1967)</xref>. (Note: Marwell and Schmitt&#x2019;s terminology differs somewhat from our own.)</attrib>
</table-wrap-foot>
</table-wrap>
<boxed-text id="box10_1">
<label><target target-type="page" id="page_239">239</target>Box 10.1</label>
<caption><title>Only a Jerk Would Refuse: An Examination of the Altercasting Tactic</title></caption>
<p>As noted in <xref ref-type="table" rid="tbl10_1">Table 10.1</xref>, negative altercasting, when used as a compliance-gaining tactic, involves projecting a person into an unflattering role and then expecting the person to comply in order to avoid fitting into that role. For example, if someone collecting donations said, &#x201C;Only a heartless person would refuse to feed hungry children,&#x201D; he or she would be using negative altercasting. Before you decide to try the tactic on your own, consider this: Research suggests that people who use it are perceived as less competent than people who use more prosocial tactics, such as liking (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_43">Johnson, 1992</xref>). Not only that, they may be less persuasive. In one study (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_72">Turner, Banas, Rains, Jang, Moore, &#x0026; Morrison, 2010</xref>), for instance, researchers tucked unmailed, stamped letters under the windshield wipers of several thousand parked vehicles. Along with the letters were messages employing one of three compliance-gaining techniques: (1) positive altercasting (&#x201C;I found this next to your car. A good person would mail it [that is, if it&#x2019;s not yours.]&#x201D;), (2) negative altercasting (&#x201C;I found this next to your car. Only a bad person wouldn&#x2019;t mail it [that is, if it&#x2019;s not yours].&#x201D;); and direct request (&#x201C;I found this next to your car. Mail it [that is, if it&#x2019;s not yours].&#x201D;). Results showed that negative altercasting did not work well. To be sure, significantly more letters were returned in the direct request and positive altercasting conditions than in the negative altercasting condition (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_72">Turner et al., 2010</xref>). Perhaps that&#x2019;s because people believe that only a jerk would use the negative altercasting tactic.</p>
</boxed-text>
<p>Marwell and Schmitt&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_52">1967</xref>) study showed that there are a wide range of tactics available to persuaders. The study was important because it became the springboard for compliance-gaining research that followed. Even so, as is often the case with research on human communication, the study made compliance gaining appear simpler than it really is. We will see later in this chapter the ways in which this study was criticized and improved on. First, however, we turn to a discussion of some of the factors that affect the selection of compliance-gaining strategies.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec10_3">
<title>Situation: The &#x201C;It Depends&#x201D; of Compliance-Gaining Behavior</title>
<p>Long before this chapter was written, one of the authors was faced with two different situations requiring persuasion. In the first, the author&#x2019;s then 2-year-old son tried to provoke a food fight at the dinner table by throwing a chunk of roast beef, gravy and all at his older brother. There was quite a splat. The 2-year-old then proceeded to reach for a second chunk, at which point the author intervened, explanining that any more &#x201C;beef bombs&#x201D; would result in a time-out (i.e., 2 minutes of sitting alone in the bedroom). Fortunately, the next hunk of beef found its way into the kid&#x2019;s mouth.</p>
<p>In the second situation, the same author needed to ask his boss to hurry up and look over some paperwork that needed the boss&#x2019;s signature. The deadline for the paperwork was nearing. Although threatening the boss with something like a time-out had appeal, quite obviously, doing so would have been inappropriate. Instead, the author tapped lightly on the boss&#x2019;s door, smiled, and asked ever so politely whether the boss had &#x201C;had a chance to look over that paperwork yet?&#x201D;</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_240">240</target>The point is that even though we can isolate a specific number of compliance-gaining strategies, not all strategies are appropriate in all situations. To be sure, even when trying to persuade the same person, different contexts require different strategies. For instance, trying to keep a 2-year-old from repeatedly playing near electrical outlets may require a different strategy than trying to get the same child to eat asparagus. Obviously, selecting a compliance-gaining strategy depends a lot on the situation.</p>
<p>For quite some time now, communication scholars have argued that compliance-gaining behavior can vary greatly from one situation to the next. By way of example, research by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_18">Cody, Woelfel, and Jordan (1983)</xref> showed that, when trying to decide which compliance-gaining strategy to use, there are seven situational dimensions that affect those decisions:
<list list-type="bullet">
<list-item><p><italic>Dominance:</italic> The level of control or power in a relationship. For example, because a boss generally has more power to influence a subordinate than vice versa, a boss&#x2019;s strategies may differ from a subordinate&#x2019;s.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Intimacy:</italic> The level of emotional attachment or knowledge one has of a partner&#x2019;s affect. For example, because they are more intimate and more concerned with the relationship, spouses may use different strategies than strangers.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Resistance:</italic> The degree to which the persuader thinks a strategy will be resisted. For example, strategies that are more likely to be resisted will probably not be used as readily as those that are less likely to be resisted. (For more information on resisting compliance, see <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box10_2">Box 10.2</xref>.)</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Personal benefits:</italic> The extent to which the self or the other is benefited by compliance. For example, strategies that are perceived to produce the greatest benefits are most likely to be used.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Rights:</italic> The extent to which a persuader thinks a request is warranted. For example, a persuader may believe that complaining about a barking dog and losing sleep is justified, but complaining about someone else&#x2019;s hairstyle is not.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Relational consequences:</italic> The degree to which a strategy will have long-term or short-term effects on the persuader&#x2019;s relationship with the persuadee. For example, a threat that may lead to divorce may be less likely than one that merely leads to an argument.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Apprehension:</italic> The degree to which a persuader perceives nervousness in the situation. For example, situations filled with anxiety may lead to different strategies than those without anxiety.</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
<p>It is clear, then, that compliance-gaining behavior depends a great deal on the situation in which it is used. In fact, research shows that these situational dimensions not only affect decisions to use strategies but also decisions to avoid them (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_32">Hample &#x0026; Dallinger, 2002</xref>). In the following sections, we discuss some research findings on several of these situational dimensions.</p>
<sec id="sec10_3_1">
<title>Seeking Compliance From Strangers and Intimates</title>
<p>In what is now considered a classic study, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_55">Gerald Miller, Frank Boster, Michael Roloff, and David Seibold (1977)</xref> examined the effects of intimacy on compliance-gaining behavior. These researchers imagined that compliance gaining in <target target-type="page" id="page_241">241</target>interpersonal relationships differ from compliance gaining in noninterpersonal relationships. Specifically, because people in interpersonal relationships know their partners well, they can tailor their messages to appeal to their partners&#x2019; specific wants, needs, interests, and so forth. The same is not true in noninterpersonal relationships, where little is known about the other person. In addition, Miller and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_55">1977</xref>) thought that the type of compliance-gaining strategy a person decided to use would depend on whether a situation had short-term or long-term consequences.</p>
<boxed-text id="box10_2">
<label>Box 10.2</label>
<caption><title>Just Say No? A Look at Strategies for Resisting Compliance and Resisting Resistance</title></caption>
<p>In our opinion, a lot of advertising makes persuasion seem pretty simple. For example, Nike&#x2019;s classic &#x201C;Just do it&#x201D; campaign suggested that we should forget all about reasoning and weighing pros and cons. On the other side of the coin, you might be familiar with the once popular slogan for keeping kids off of drugs; &#x201C;Just say &#x2018;no,&#x2019;&#x201D; it advised. But is resisting compliance really all that easy? Whatever the case, some research shows that just saying &#x201C;no&#x201D; is not the only option available to us when trying to resist the compliance-gaining attempts of others. For instance, a study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_53">McLaughlin, Cody, and Robey (1980)</xref> identified four possible strategies you might use to resist persuasion:
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p>Nonnegotiation: You overtly refuse to comply (you say, &#x201C;No&#x201D;).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Identity management: You resist by manipulating images of the other person (you say, &#x201C;I would never make such an awful request&#x201D;).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Justifying: You justify noncompliance by pointing to negative outcomes (you say, &#x201C;If I comply with your request I might lose my job&#x201D;).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Negotiation: You engage in an alternative behavior that you propose (rather than turn off the stereo, you offer to turn it down).</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
<p>Rather than look at resistance strategies, perhaps a more important issue centers on situations in which people find themselves wanting to resist compliance. One prevalent example occurs when people are pressured into having sex. Indeed, according to Impett and Peplau&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_38">2003</xref>) sources, between 26 and 40 percent of men and 50 and 65 percent of women report that they&#x2019;ve agreed to have sex even though they did not want to. With this in mind, and considering contemporary issues associated with the spread of HIV and the prevalence of date rape, researchers have examined strategies that can be used to resist sexual advances. An interesting study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_12">Byers and Wilson (1985)</xref> examined men&#x2019;s and women&#x2019;s perceptions of the different ways in which women refuse sexual advances by men. In the study, subjects watched a videotape of a man and woman engaged in romantic physical behavior. At some point in the tape, the woman refuses to go any further by (1) simply saying, &#x201C;No&#x201D;; (2) saying &#x201C;No&#x201D; and offering an excuse (i.e., &#x201C;someone&#x2019;s coming over&#x201D;); or (3) saying &#x201C;No&#x201D; and offering an explanation (i.e., &#x201C;we don&#x2019;t know each other well enough&#x201D;). Results of the study showed that most of the males in the study would comply with all of the requests, but several said they would be reluctant to do so. Moreover, both male and female subjects interpreted the simple &#x201C;No&#x201D; and the &#x201C;No, with explanation&#x201D; as meaning the man should stop his advances but interpreted the &#x201C;No&#x201D; with an excuse as meaning that the man should try making more advances later that day.</p>
<p>One possible problem with messages meant to resist sexual advances centers on the stereotype that &#x201C;when women say &#x2018;no,&#x2019; they really mean &#x2018;yes.&#x2019;&#x201D; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_56">Muehlenhard and Hollanbaugh (1988)</xref>, for <target target-type="page" id="page_242">242</target>example, found that nearly 40 percent of women in their study claimed to have said &#x201C;no&#x201D; when they meant &#x201C;yes&#x201D; because they did not want to appear promiscuous, wanted to show concern for religious issues, and so forth. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_61">Perper and Weis (1987)</xref> argued that such token resistance can cause problems by encouraging males not to take &#x201C;no&#x201D; for an answer. With this in mind, when faced with such situations, it is important to say what you mean. Indeed, research shows that direct, verbal messages, compared to indirect messages, are the best for avoiding sexual advances (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_14">Christopher &#x0026; Frandsen, 1990</xref>). A possible problem, however, is that sexual rejection messages that are moderately direct are perceived to be more comfortable and &#x201C;face saving&#x201D; than very direct messages (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_54">Metts, Cupach, &#x0026; Imahori, 1992</xref>).</p>
<p>It is apparent from this discussion so far that resistance strategies, in and of themselves, may not be as important as how people respond to those resistance strategies. For instance, research indicates that people who have met with noncompliance tend to follow up with more direct strategies than they did initially (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_33">Harris, Monahan, &#x0026; Hovick, 2014</xref>). Moreover, in some situations, noncompliance is likely to be met with physical aggression (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_22">deTurck, 1987</xref>). So, what happens if your resistance meets with resistance? If you ever find yourself confronted by a person who wants you to comply when you don&#x2019;t want to, it might help to know this: Research suggests that forceful verbal and physical resistance is related to the decreased likelihood of being raped (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_67">Senn, Eliasziw, Hobden, Newby-Clark, Barata, Radtke, &#x0026; Thurston, 2017</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_71">Tark &#x0026; Kleck, 2014</xref>). What&#x2019;s more, although some scholars have suggested that resistance may be dangerous because it might provoke rapists to become more violent, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_71">Tark and Kleck (2014)</xref> found that additional injuries besides rape following resistance are rare.</p>
</boxed-text>
<p>To test their hypotheses, these researchers asked people how likely they would be to use each of Marwell and Schmitt&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_52">1967</xref>) strategies to persuade others in four different situations:
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p><italic>Noninterpersonal; short-term consequences:</italic> You want to get a car dealer, whom you barely know, to give you a &#x0024;1,000 trade-in on your old car.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Noninterpersonal; long-term consequences:</italic> You want your new neighbors, who are planning to cut down a shade tree that adds value to your home, to leave the tree standing.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Interpersonal; short-term consequences:</italic> You have a close relationship with a man or woman and want to cancel a date with him or her in order to visit an old acquaintance who is passing through town.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Interpersonal; long-term consequences:</italic> You have a close relationship with a man or woman and want to persuade him or her to move to another geographical location so you can take a better job.</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
<p>Results of this study showed that the situation strongly affected strategy choice. In general, people preferred &#x201C;friendly,&#x201D; socially acceptable strategies (e.g., liking) in all the situations but said they were more likely to use different tactics in different situations. For instance, threat tactics were more likely in short-term, non-interpersonal contexts. Finally, in noninterpersonal situations, people picked a greater variety of strategies, perhaps because, without knowing much about the person they were trying to persuade, more trial and error was necessary (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_55">Miller et al., 1977</xref>).</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_243">243</target>Previous research suggests that intimates, compared to strangers, are perceived to be more effective in their compliance-gaining attempts. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_21">Dennis (2006)</xref>, for example, found that people expected intimates, rather than non-intimates, to be more effective when trying to persuade them to engage in healthy behaviors, especially when their intimate others used strategies showing that they cared (e.g., &#x201C;I don&#x2019;t want your weight to bother you. You should eat better.&#x201D;). For some types of health-related behavior, other strategies were perceived to be effective as well. For instance, when trying to get their romantic partners to stop smoking, intimate others were perceived to be effective when using threat (e.g., &#x201C;I don&#x2019;t know if I can handle being with you when you smoke.&#x201D;) and liking (e.g., &#x201C;I&#x2019;d like kissing you more if your mouth didn&#x2019;t taste like an ashtray&#x201D;) strategies (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_21">Dennis, 2006</xref>).</p>
<p>Thus, the choice and perceived effectiveness of compliance-gaining strategies may differ depending on whether a relationship is interpersonal or noninterpersonal. But are all interpersonal relationships the same? One of our favorite studies shows that they are not. Specifically, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_79">Witteman and Fitzpatrick (1986)</xref> argued that husbands and wives can be categorized into three different couple-types: <italic>Traditionals, Separates</italic>, and <italic>Independents</italic>. They explained that:
<disp-quote>
<p>Traditionals hold conventional values about the relationship. These values emphasize stability as opposed to spontaneity. Traditionals exhibit interdependence, both physically and psychologically, and tend not to avoid conflict. Separates hold ambivalent views on the nature of relationships, report having the least interdependence, and avoid open marital conflict. Independents hold fairly non-conventional relational values and maintain some interdependence, yet not with respect to some of the physical and temporal aspects of their lives. Also Independents report some assertiveness and tend to engage in conflict.</p>
<attrib>(p. 132)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>Because couples differed in the ways they interacted, Witteman and Fitzpatrick suspected that couples also would differ in the ways they sought compliance. Results of a study confirmed these expectations. First, Traditionals sought compliance by discussing what they expected to be the positive and negative outcomes of a proposed course of action. They tended to be open and used their relationship as a basis of power. Separates, however, did not attempt to identify with their partners or to use their relationship to seek compliance. Instead, Separates focused on the negative consequences of noncompliance and tried to constrain the behavior of their spouses. Finally, Independents, compared to other couple types, used a wider variety of power bases when seeking compliance. They also tended to discount and refute their partners more than other couple types, indicating that Independent couples debate one another relatively intensely.</p>
<p>While it is clear, then, that our use of compliance-gaining strategies depends on the type and degree of intimate relationship in which we are involved, research also suggests that our compliance-seeking behaviors are affected by the particular circumstances we face in our relationships. As one example, if the person with whom you are involved starts thinking about leaving you, are there particular strategies you <target target-type="page" id="page_244">244</target>might use to save the relationship? Research by Buchanan, O&#x2019;Hair, and Becker (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_7">2006</xref>) identified four overall strategies that people reported using while attempting to hang on to their spouses. <italic>Commitment</italic>, the most common strategy, includes tactics such as being more loving and caring, being submissive (&#x201C;I&#x2019;ll do anything to save this relationship.&#x201D;), and asking your partner to commit to the relationship. <italic>Alignment</italic>, the second most common strategy, includes tactics like demonstrating to other people that your partner is taken (e.g., by holding hands), punishing your partner&#x2019;s threats of infidelity, and trying to make your partner want you sexually. <italic>Negativity</italic>, the third strategy, includes tactics such as degrading your partner, making your partner jealous (e.g., by threatening to be unfaithful), and concealing your partner from others. <italic>Harm</italic>, the last and least frequent strategy, includes tactics such as threatening or being violent toward someone who might come between you and your partner (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_7">Buchanan et al., 2006</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec10_3_2">
<title>Power, Legitimacy, and Politeness</title>
<p>Our earlier illustration about trying to influence a child versus a boss makes it clear that power plays a large role in the selection of compliance-gaining strategies. In what is now considered a seminal work, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_29">French and Raven (1960)</xref> argued that there are five bases of power that people can draw upon to influence others:
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p>A person with <italic>reward power</italic> has control over some valued resource (e.g., promotions and raises).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>A person with <italic>coercive power</italic> has the ability to inflict punishments (e.g., fire you).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Expert power</italic> is based on what a person knows (e.g., you may do what a doctor tells you to do because he or she knows more about medicine than you do).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Legitimate power</italic> is based on formal rank or position (e.g., you obey someone&#x2019;s commands because he or she is the vice president in the company for which you work).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>People have <italic>referent power</italic> when the person they are trying to influence wants to be like them (e.g., a mentor often has this type of power).</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
<p>Regardless of the type of power that&#x2019;s at work, one thing remains clear: Power affects compliance-gaining behavior. For example, although managers are more successful when using consultation, inspirational appeals, rational persuasion, and nonpressure tactics (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_80">Yukl, Kim, &#x0026; Falbe, 1996</xref>), because they often believe that their power adds legitimacy to their requests, they may not provide justifications or explanations when seeking compliance. Their influence strategies, therefore, may tend to be more direct than the influence strategies used by their less powerful subordinates (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_36">Hirokawa &#x0026; Wagner, 2004</xref>). Moreover, regardless of the messages they use when seeking compliance, research has shown that people with power tend to be more persuasive than those without it (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_50">Levine &#x0026; Boster, 2001</xref>).</p>
<p>With that said, is there any hope for people who possess little power? To address this question, several researchers (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_2">Baxter, 1984</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_19">Craig, Tracy, &#x0026; Spisak, 1986</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_76">Wilson &#x0026; Kunkel, 2000</xref>) have applied Brown and Levinson&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_6">1987</xref>) <italic>politeness theory</italic> to the study of compliance-gaining behavior.</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_245">245</target>According to <italic>politeness theory,</italic> all people are motivated to maintain two kinds of face: positive and negative. We maintain <italic>positive face</italic> when others like, respect, and approve of us. We maintain <italic>negative face</italic> when we do not feel constrained or impeded by others. According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_6">Brown and Levinson (1987)</xref>, when making a request of someone else, both types of faces may be challenged. First, the request may constrain the other person&#x2019;s freedom, thereby challenging his or her negative face. By way of illustration, asking someone to pick you up at the airport is challenging because it keeps a person from doing something else that he or she might rather be doing. Second, the request may imply that the other person is being taken advantage of, thereby challenging his or her positive face. For example, in our opinion, the stereotypical sports slob who shouts to his wife, &#x201C;Bring me another beer!&#x201D; does not convey much respect.</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 10.2</label>
<caption><title>The use of coercive power in the workplace.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig10_2.tif"/>
<p>Source: BIZARRO &#x00A9; by Dan Piraro. Reprinted by permission.</p>
</fig>
<p>So, how does the issue of power fit into the picture? According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_6">Brown and Levinson (1987)</xref>, a person is less likely to comply if his or her face is threatened. Thus, to keep from threatening a person&#x2019;s positive or negative face, we try to be polite when making requests. Moreover, when trying to persuade someone who is more powerful than us, we may be extra polite because it is not as likely that our requests will be perceived as legitimate. Research so far has supported this conclusion. For example, in one study, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_2">Leslie Baxter (1984)</xref> found that compared to less powerful others (i.e., group members), more powerful others (i.e., group leaders) were less polite when making requests. Similarly, two studies found that when students tried <target target-type="page" id="page_246">246</target>to persuade their instructors to change grades or paper deadlines, their compliance-gaining strategies were overwhelmingly positive (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_30">Golish, 1999</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_31">Golish &#x0026; Olson, 2000</xref>). Not only that, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_50">Levine and Boster (2001)</xref> found that when people with little power tried to persuade others, positively framed messages were the only ones that met with much success. Finally, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_41">Jenkins and Dragojevic (2013)</xref> found that face-threatening messages caused people to derogate both the message and the source, leading to less persuasion.</p>
<p>Considering the preceding studies, you might be wondering which types of strategies are polite and which are not. Most would agree that threats are not as polite as hints. However, threats may be more efficient than hints. To test this notion, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_46">Kellermann and Shea (1996)</xref> asked people to rate how polite and efficient they perceived several different strategies to be. Interestingly, threats, although impolite, were not considered efficient, and hints, although inefficient, were not considered polite. Perhaps the best way to get compliance is by using direct requests (i.e., explicitly ask for what you want); such requests were among the most efficient strategies and were not considered impolite (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_46">Kellermann &#x0026; Shea, 1996</xref>). Consistent with this notion, one study found that speaking debaters who were confronted with nonverbal disparagement from their opponents were perceived as most effective and appropriate when they politely and directly requested that their opponents stop displaying such disparaging behaviors (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_73">Weger, Seiter, Jacobs, &#x0026; Akbulut, 2010</xref>).</p>
<p>While considering the topic of politeness, keep in mind that persuasion is a two-way street. As such, people not only threaten others&#x2019; face when making requests, they do so when refusing others&#x2019; requests as well (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_42">Johnson, 2007</xref>). By way of example, it would be one thing for Olga to tell Xenia, &#x201C;I can&#x2019;t take you to the airport because my driver&#x2019;s license was revoked when I was arrested for drunk driving&#x201D; (a threat to Olga&#x2019;s positive face) and quite another to tell Xenia, &#x201C;Yeah, right. You&#x2019;re not worth the time, gas, or wear and tear on my vehicle&#x201D; (a threat to Xenia&#x2019;s positive face). <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_42">Johnson (2007)</xref> has shown that the nature of refusals (i.e., do they threaten the requester&#x2019;s, the target&#x2019;s, or both the requester&#x2019;s and target&#x2019;s positive and/or negative face) affect perceptions about whether the refusal is effective or appropriate.</p>
<p>It is apparent from our discussion so far that behavior designed to gain or resist compliance depends, to a large extent, on several contextual and relational dimensions. (To learn about compliance-gaining behavior in a <italic>specific</italic> context, see <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box10_3">Box 10.3</xref>.) The context, however, is not the only factor that affects compliance-gaining behavior. In the next section we explore the impact of individual differences on interpersonal influence.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec10_4">
<title>Who are You? Individual Characteristics and Compliance-Gaining Behavior</title>
<p>Up to this point we&#x2019;ve talked about the whats and whens of compliance gaining. We&#x2019;ve shown that past research has pointed to a number of situational dimensions (e.g., interpersonal/noninterpersonal, short-term/long-term consequences) that influence strategy choice. According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_37">Hunter and Boster (1987)</xref>, however, there is but one factor that determines what types of compliance-gaining strategies will be used in a given situation. These researchers argued that when trying to decide what <target target-type="page" id="page_247">247</target>strategy we will use, we try to determine what the emotional impact of the message will be. For example, if you tried to persuade your friend to study more, the friend might become angry and resentful. However, the friend could be grateful that you cared enough to say something. According to Hunter and Boster, we prefer using strategies that have a positive emotional impact.</p>
<boxed-text id="box10_3">
<label><target target-type="page" id="page_248">248</target>Box 10.3</label>
<caption><title>Take Two Aspirin and Call Me in the Morning: Compliance Gaining Between Doctors and Patients</title></caption>
<p>One of the authors attended a dinner party at which the conversation turned to health-related matters. Several of the guests explained how they fooled their physicians to make it appear that their blood pressure was normal. One said she raised her arms above her head for five minutes beforehand. Another said he made sure he was dehydrated when visiting his doctor. &#x201C;But why would you want to deceive your doctor about your blood pressure?&#x201D; the author asked. &#x201C;Why wouldn&#x2019;t you want to?&#x201D; one of them replied.</p>
<p>This story illustrates how attitudes can pose serious concerns for people in the medical profession. Indeed, physicians not only face patients who shade the truth about their health, they are also confronted with the task of persuading patients to comply with requests to take medication, return for regular checkups, modify their behaviors, and so forth. When one considers the personal and economic costs of not complying with doctors&#x2019; requests, the study of persuasion in medical contexts is of obvious significance.</p>
<p>According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_11">Burgoon and Burgoon (1990)</xref>, compliance gaining in medical contexts is unique because, unlike most other compliance-gaining situations, patients visit physicians voluntarily, pay for physicians&#x2019; compliance-gaining directives, perceive physicians as experts, and believe that compliance will benefit themselves rather than the physician. Unfortunately, however, Klingle&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_47">2004</xref>) and Burgoon, Birk, and Hall&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_9">1991</xref>) sources indicate that patient noncompliance is the most significant problem facing medicine today and that patient noncompliance is as high as 62 percent with prescribed drug regimens, 50 percent with medical appointment keeping, and 92 percent with health promotion and lifestyle changes.</p>
<p>For these reasons, researchers have attempted to determine not only what types of compliance-gaining strategies physicians use but also what types of strategies are the most effective. For example, a review of literature by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_11">Burgoon and Burgoon (1990)</xref> found that physicians prefer to use strategies that appeal to authority, knowledge, and expertise, and tend to avoid threatening and antisocial strategies. Indeed, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_64">Schneider and Beaubien (1996)</xref> found that positive expertise, legitimacy, and liking (see strategies discussed earlier) accounted for 83.5 percent of all the compliance-gaining strategies used by doctors on patients. Physicians report that their strategies tend to become more verbally aggressive, however, when patients have not complied with previous requests and have more severe medical problems (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_11">Burgoon &#x0026; Burgoon, 1990</xref>).</p>
<p>In addition to issues about strategy use, researchers have also tried to determine what types of strategies are most effective. Some research, for instance, has found that patients are more likely to comply with doctors who express similarity (i.e., indicate that they share things in common with the patient) and are more satisfied with doctors who communicate a willingness to listen, express affection, are composed, are similar, formal, and nondomineering (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_8">Burgoon, Pfau, Parrott, Birk, Coker, &#x0026; Burgoon, 1987</xref>). Some research suggests that there are gender differences in strategy effectiveness (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_47">Klingle, 2004</xref>). Male doctors can get away with using more negative strategies than can female doctors. In addition, research indicates that both female and male doctors who vary their strategies are more effective than doctors who employ the same strategy repeatedly. Finally, in situations involving terminal illness, family members are more likely to consent to donating the patient&#x2019;s organs when compliance-gaining messages communicate additional emotional support to the family (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_1">Anker &#x0026; Feeley, 2011</xref>).</p>
</boxed-text>
<p>But how do we decide which strategies will have a positive emotional impact and which will have a negative emotional impact? <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_37">Hunter and Boster (1987)</xref> argued that each of us has a perceptual &#x201C;threshold&#x201D; that helps us make decisions about what strategies are acceptable and what strategies are not. Threatening someone, for example, may exceed the threshold, whereas promising something may not. Strategies that do not cross the threshold are more likely to be used.</p>
<p>A major implication of this model, of course, is that these thresholds are idiosyncratic, varying from one person to the next. Biff, for example, may be perfectly comfortable threatening others, whereas Babbs may not. Obviously, then, individual differences are important in determining the types of compliance-gaining messages that are used. For that reason, considerable research has examined several &#x201C;sender&#x201D; characteristics that affect strategy choice. Some of these characteristics include Machiavellianism (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_57">O&#x2019;Hair &#x0026; Cody, 1987</xref>), dogmatism (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_63">Roloff &#x0026; Barnicott, 1979</xref>), self-monitoring (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_69">Smith, Cody, Lovette, &#x0026; Canary, 1990</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_70">Snyder, 1979</xref>), type A personality (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_49">Lamude &#x0026; Scudder, 1993</xref>), verbal aggressiveness and argumentativeness (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_5">Boster, Levine, &#x0026; Kazoleas, 1993</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_40">Infante, Trebing, Shepard, &#x0026; Seeds, 1984</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_39">Infante &#x0026; Wigley, 1986</xref>), gender (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_20">Dallinger &#x0026; Hample, 1994</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_23">deTurck &#x0026; Miller, 1982</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_28">Fitzpatrick &#x0026; Winke, 1979</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_33">Harris et al., 2014</xref>), culture (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_10">Burgoon, Dillard, Doran, &#x0026; Miller, 1982</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_35">Hirokawa &#x0026; Mirahara, 1986</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_51">Lu, 1997</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_66">Sellnow, Liu, &#x0026; Venette, 2006</xref>), and age (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_34">Haslett, 1983</xref>). Because many of these characteristics were detailed in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter5">Chapter 5</xref>, we use the rest of this section to discuss the work of O&#x2019;Keefe (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_58">1988</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_59">1990</xref>), who argued that people produce different compliance-gaining messages because they think differently about communication. O&#x2019;Keefe called these different beliefs about communication <italic>design logics</italic> and argued that they are threefold:
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p><italic>Expressive design logic:</italic> A person with this design logic believes that communication is a process by which people merely express what they think and feel. Such people fail to realize that communication can be used to achieve other goals and, therefore, &#x201C;speak from the gut,&#x201D; dumping whatever they think and feel without any regard for what might be appropriate in a given situation. For that reason, such people&#x2019;s messages tend to be &#x201C;primitive.&#x201D; For instance, a person with an expressive design logic might say something like the following: &#x201C;You **&#x0023;&#x0023;*&#x0024;*&#x0040; jerk. You&#x2019;ve had it. I&#x2019;m going to get you fired for this!&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Conventional design logic:</italic> A person with this design logic believes that communication is a game played cooperatively, according to social conventions and procedures. Thus, people using this logic express their thoughts and feelings, but believe that they also must follow rules for appropriate social behavior in a given situation. For instance, a person with a conventional design logic might say something like the following: &#x201C;You missed our meeting today and I don&#x2019;t appreciate this irresponsibility. If you miss one more meeting, you&#x2019;re fired.&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Rhetorical design logic:</italic> A person with a rhetorical design logic believes that communication&#x2019;s purpose is to negotiate character, attitude, selves, and situations. The process involves repeatedly solving and coordinating problems, consensus, and harmony. Thus, someone with this logic pursues multiple goals, tends to be proactive, and uses rational arguments. Here&#x2019;s an example:
<disp-quote>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_249">249</target>You have been coming back late from lunch and we need to reach some kind of understanding about this. I don&#x2019;t want to have to force you to follow the rules, but I will if I have to. But surely you can appreciate why we have rules and what function they serve. I know if you just think about the situation you will see how your behavior could be creating a problem in this office.</p>
<attrib>(<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_58">O&#x2019;Keefe, 1988</xref>, p. 103)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
<p>Research has found that messages reflecting a rhetorical design logic are rated as more competent, favorable, and persuasive than messages reflecting the other design logics (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_3">Bingham &#x0026; Burleson, 1989</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_57">O&#x2019;Keefe &#x0026; McCornack, 1987</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_65">Scott, Caughlin, Donovan-Kicken, &#x0026; Mikucki-Enyart, 2013</xref>). What&#x2019;s more, compared to people with expressive design logics, those with rhetorical design logics feel more effective in their persuasive attempts. One study, for example, found that people with rhetorical design logics felt more confident that they could do or say something to intervene when they see others engaged in high-risk behavior (e.g., &#x201C;a guy&#x2013;girl hookup&#x201D; in which a drunk and reluctant female is heading toward a possible sexual encounter with a male (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_74">White &#x0026; Malkowski, 2014</xref>)).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec10_5">
<title>The Study of Compliance-Gaining Goals: Eyes on the Prize</title>
<p>In addition to creating typologies of compliance-gaining strategies, researchers have also examined the ways in which people&#x2019;s goals influence how they seek compliance. Simply defined, goals are states of affairs we want to attain or maintain often through persuasion (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_75">Wilson, 1997</xref>). The following sections examine the ways in which goals are important when trying to understand compliance gaining.</p>
<sec id="sec10_5_1">
<title>How Goals Bring Meaning to Compliance-Gaining Situations: What&#x2019;s It All About, Alfie?</title>
<p>Years ago, one of the authors heard a story about two men scooping mud and straw into wooden molds.</p>
<disp-quote>
<p>A passerby asked one of the men what he was doing.</p>
<disp-quote>
<p>&#x201C;Scooping mud and straw into this mold,&#x201D; the man told him.</p>
<p>&#x201C;What are you doing?&#x201D; the passerby asked the second man, who seemed much happier than the first.</p>
<p>&#x201C;I&#x2019;m part of a team making a beautiful cathedral,&#x201D; came the reply.</p>
</disp-quote>
</disp-quote>
<p>We like this story because it illustrates how goals can help people define situations. Clearly, the first man&#x2019;s goal (scooping mud) makes his situation seem dismal compared to the second man&#x2019;s. Our point here is that goals give meaning to situations, including situations that involve compliance gaining. According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_76">Wilson and Kunkel (2000)</xref>, &#x201C;Individuals interpret compliance gaining episodes based on their <target target-type="page" id="page_250">250</target>understanding of specific influence goals&#x201D; (p. 197). In a summary of literature, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_45">Kellermann (2004)</xref> identified several common compliance-gaining goals that appear meaningful to people. These included goals to provide guidance; get advice, a favor, permission, or information; share time; initiate, escalate, or end a relationship; fulfill an obligation; get a date; change an opinion; and stop an annoying habit (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_45">Kellermann, 2004</xref>).</p>
<p>How might these different influence goals affect perceptions of a situation and, in turn, the ways in which compliance is sought? By way of example, imagine that you have two different influence goals. One is to ask someone a favor. The other is to get someone who owes you a favor to repay you in some way. According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_13">Cai and Wilson (2000)</xref>, requests such as these create entirely different situations for persuaders and, as a result, may lead to different compliance-seeking behavior. Clearly, this notion relates to our earlier discussion of politeness and compliance gaining. For instance, because asking favors may impose on another person, when asking favors, you may be less direct, provide the target with a &#x201C;way out,&#x201D; and provide a lot of reasons for your imposition. However, if you&#x2019;re seeking compliance from someone who owes you a favor, you might be more direct and less polite in your compliance attempts, perhaps even making the target feel guilty if he or she does not comply.</p>
<p>Research by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_13">Cai and Wilson (2000)</xref> suggests that different types of requests, such as these, present similar concerns for persuaders in all cultures, though cultural differences may occur when making such requests. For instance, on one hand, asking a favor may lead you to feel indebted, regardless of your cultural background. On the other hand, because they are more concerned with saving face, people from Japan, compared to those from the United States, may worry more about imposing on others. As a result, the Japanese may be less direct and especially polite when seeking favors (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_13">Cai &#x0026; Wilson, 2000</xref>). Moreover, because in-group favoritism is more prevalent in collectivistic, compared to individualistic cultures, managers from collectivistic cultures (e.g., China) may be more likely to use less polite tactics (e.g., threat) when influencing subordinates they perceive to be different from themselves (i.e., out-group members), and more likely to use pro-social tactics (e.g., ingratiation) when influencing in-group members (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_68">Sheer, 2012</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec10_5_2">
<title>Primary and Secondary Goals: Wanting and Eating Your Cake</title>
<p>If we told you that the most effective strategy for getting something was to make threats, would you start threatening people every time you wanted something?
<disp-quote>
<p>&#x201C;Loan me 20 bucks, or I&#x2019;ll break your nose!&#x201D;</p>
<p>&#x201C;If you want to keep your job, get me some coffee!&#x201D;</p>
<p>&#x201C;Keep it up, and you can stand in the corner for the next hour.&#x201D;</p>
<p>&#x201C;Let me get a tattoo, or I&#x2019;ll run away from home!&#x201D;</p>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>We suspect that, for most of you, the answer to this question would be &#x201C;no.&#x201D; But why? If threats really were so effective, why not throw them around a little? Because, you might be thinking to yourself, if I made threats every time I wanted something, I might not have many friends. Plus, you probably wouldn&#x2019;t like yourself <target target-type="page" id="page_251">251</target>too much. And if the other party still refused, you might be forced to follow through with the threat.</p>
<p>In the previous section, we discussed several different types of influence goals. In this section, we note that influence goals are not the only ones affecting compliance gaining. Indeed, most of the time we are concerned with pursuing multiple goals at the same time. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_44">Kellermann (1992)</xref>, for example, argued that when seeking compliance, people are constrained by concerns for both efficiency (achieving their goal without wasting time and other resources) and appropriateness (accomplishing their goal in a socially acceptable and respectful way). Similarly, in his <italic>goals&#x2013;plans&#x2013;action theory,</italic> <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_25">James Dillard (2004</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_26">2008</xref>) argues that people pursue different types of goals when they are trying to influence someone. These goals are important because they determine the types of strategies that people plan to use when trying to gain compliance. To identify these goals, Dillard and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_27">Dillard, Segrin, &#x0026; Harden, 1989</xref>) asked students to imagine themselves in a compliance-gaining situation and to state why they would or wouldn&#x2019;t use particular influence strategies in that situation. Results of the study indicated that one primary goal, to influence the other person, is the most important in determining the type of strategy that a person uses. For example, a person may decide not to use a strategy because he or she thinks it won&#x2019;t work or because it is irrelevant.</p>
<p>In addition, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_26">Dillard (2008)</xref> identifies several secondary goals that influence people&#x2019;s choices in compliance-gaining situations. First, <italic>identity goals</italic> are concerned with maintaining one&#x2019;s moral standards and principles for living. Thus, people might decide to ignore a strategy that seems immoral. Second, <italic>interaction goals</italic> are concerned with creating a good impression and behaving in appropriate ways. For instance, people motivated by this goal might refuse to use a strategy that would make them look bad. Third, <italic>resource goals</italic> are concerned with maintaining a relationship and increasing personal rewards. Thus, using a strategy that would end a friendship would not be likely. Finally, <italic>arousal goals</italic> are concerned with maintaining levels of arousal (e.g., nervousness) within an acceptable range. Thus, people with this goal would not use a strategy that would make them too anxious (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_26">Dillard, 2008</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_27">Dillard et al., 1989</xref>).</p>
<p>According to the goals&#x2013;plans&#x2013;action theory (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_26">Dillard, 2008</xref>), then, primary and secondary goals have different degrees of compatibility. Based on the relationships among all the goals involved, a person develops <italic>plans</italic>, which are possible methods or approaches for dealing with the complex structure of goals. In order to generate and then put plans into action, people seeking compliance must consider possible strategies and tactics, which can be a complicated business. One study, for example, examined how people create messages aimed at persuading loved ones suffering from depression to seek professional help. Results indicated that, oftentimes, a focus on secondary goals (e.g., saving both parties&#x2019; face) led to the design of non-optimal messages (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_77">Wilson, Dorrance Hall, Gettings, &#x0026; Pastor, 2015</xref>).</p>
<p>Of course, a number of variables might affect goals, plans, and actions in the process of seeking compliance. Consider, for example, relational certainty. It turns out that some people are far more certain than others when it comes to knowing whether they or their partners want to pursue a relationship. Given this, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_48">Knobloch (2006)</xref> surmised that, when asking someone for a date, things would go more smoothly for people who experienced little relational ambiguity than for those who experienced <target target-type="page" id="page_252">252</target>a lot of it. Specifically, those with less certainty are more likely to worry about competing goals such as damaging a friendship. Not only that, when planning and using their compliance-gaining messages, uncertainty may make people less sure about what to say. It might also get in the way of them saying it effectively. To test these ideas, research participants were observed requesting hypothetical dates from people they were attracted to in real life. The participants were asked to leave phone messages, requesting dates from people they knew and were attracted to. Some were more certain about their relationships than others. Results of the study confirmed the researcher&#x2019;s suspicions: Relational certainty was associated with requests for dates that were judged to be more fluent, affiliative, and effective. Here are two examples of requests from the study (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_48">Knobloch, 2006</xref>, p. 273). We hope it is obvious which was produced by the person with more relational certainty:
<disp-quote>
<p>&#x201C;Hey babe, it&#x2019;s Kevin. I was just calling to see if you had any plans tonight, &#x2019;cause I wondered if I could take you out to dinner or something. So, just give me a call whenever you get the message. Bye.&#x201D;</p>
<p>&#x201C;Hey, Emily, uh, this is Bob. Um, yeah, just wondering what you were up to tonight. Uh, haven&#x2019;t talked to you in &#x2026; in a little while, so, uh, yeah, I think there&#x2019;s some stuff we need to talk about. So, um, if I don&#x2019;t end up talking to you, I guess I&#x2019;ll talk to you on the Internet later. We&#x2019;ll see ya.&#x201D;</p>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>In short, then, compliance-gaining situations are not as simple as they may seem. People not only generate and select tactics that they think will help them gain compliance but do so in the face of multiple constraints, including competing goals and other factors.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec10_6">
<title>Problems Facing Compliance Research: Trouble in Paradise</title>
<p>Up to this point, the things we have said about compliance gaining probably seem fairly simple; when trying to persuade people, we have a number of strategies at our disposal, and the strategies we use are determined in part by the situation, our personal characteristics, and our goals. Despite this rather straightforward description, however, there has been a lot of confusion and argument about research methods that have been used to draw such conclusions. Without straying too far into the weeds, we believe it is important to mention at least a couple of concerns here.</p>
<p>To illustrate one issue, imagine that you could listen to any song right now. What would it be? Can you think of three songs? Your choice of songs is open ended. Depending on how much music you listen to, coming up with your three favorites off the top of your head might not be all that easy. Now imagine you are on iTunes and looking at a list of the top 20 songs, from which you must pick 3. Your choice of songs is limited.</p>
<p>What does all of this have to do with compliance-gaining research? If you stop to think about it, the <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_52">Marwell and Schmitt (1967)</xref> study we discussed earlier is not entirely different from our iTunes example. Only, instead of asking their research participants to select from a list of song titles, Marwell and Schmitt asked people to select from a list of pre-established compliance-seeking strategies. The problems with <target target-type="page" id="page_253">253</target>such an approach, however, have been pointed out by numerous researchers (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_17">Cody, McLaughlin, &#x0026; Jordan, 1980</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_78">Wiseman &#x0026; Schenck-Hamlin, 1981</xref>). First, by way of illustration, let&#x2019;s return to the iTunes example. Let&#x2019;s say your favorite Beyonc&#x00E9; song did not appear on the list, so you settle for a song by Rihanna instead. Obviously, your choice has been constrained by the songs that are on the top 20 list. You can&#x2019;t pick a song that&#x2019;s not available. Researchers who provide their subjects with lists of compliance-gaining strategies constrain their subjects&#x2019; choices in the same way. You can&#x2019;t pick a strategy if it isn&#x2019;t on the list.</p>
<p>Second, imagine you notice a song that you hadn&#x2019;t remembered but would have selected had it come to mind. In other words, seeing the song title made you more likely to choose it. In the same way, strategies selected from a list can artificially &#x201C;cue&#x201D; participants. When participating in a study, it&#x2019;s possible that we see a strategy on a list and think, &#x201C;Oh yeah, that seems like a good one.&#x201D; But in real life, the strategy would not have occurred to us. Thus, the list makes some strategies seem more popular than they truly are.</p>
<p>Finally, imagine you hate country music but are with a group of friends who love the stuff. To fit in, you download some Carrie Underwood tunes. Researchers have argued that the same type of thing can happen when participating in research. Specifically, in order to &#x201C;fit in&#x201D; or &#x201C;look good,&#x201D; we may not report what we would do in real life but rather what makes us look the most socially desirable. Thus, although Astrid may go around threatening people in real life, she may tell researchers that she uses more prosocial compliance-gaining tactics. Having a list of tactics to choose from may make this <italic>social desirability bias</italic> more likely to occur.</p>
<p>In an attempt to overcome these problems, some researchers have scrapped &#x201C;selection&#x201D; in favor of &#x201C;construction&#x201D; procedures (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_78">Wiseman &#x0026; Schenck-Hamlin, 1981</xref>). The argument goes like this: If people are presented with a situation requiring persuasion and are asked to describe the strategy they would use (i.e., construct the strategy from scratch rather than select it from a list), the strategy will better reflect true behavior, not misrepresent strategies that are not typically used, and be less prone to social desirability bias.</p>
<p>As neat as this sounds, research indicates little difference in the results of studies using these two techniques (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_4">Boster, 1988</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_62">Plax, Kearney, &#x0026; Sorensen, 1990</xref>). What may be of even greater importance, though, are the findings of a study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_24">Dillard (1988)</xref>. To determine which of several methods for assessing compliance-gaining behavior was the best,<xref ref-type="fn" rid="fn10_1"><sup>1</sup></xref> Dillard asked people to rate, on paper, how likely they would be to use 16 different compliance-gaining messages in persuasive situations. He then observed these people in actual compliance-gaining situations but found that, regardless of the method he used to assess compliance-gaining behavior, there was no correspondence between the paper&#x2013;pencil measures and actual behavior. In other words, what people <italic>said</italic> they would do was not the same as what they actually <italic>did.</italic></p>
<p>When we consider the implications of this study, it reminds us of a story we once heard about a man who exits a cab late at night and sees a drunk on his hands and knees, snooping around a street light. The man asks, &#x201C;Is anything wrong?&#x201D; to which the drunk replies, &#x201C;Yeah, I lost my keys.&#x201D; The man says, &#x201C;Did you lose them here?&#x201D; The drunk answers, &#x201C;Naw, I lost them over there in the dark, but the light is much better here.&#x201D; In the same vein, Dillard&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_24">1988</xref>) study illustrates that investigators have been looking very hard at compliance gaining, but perhaps not in the right way. <target target-type="page" id="page_254">254</target>Rather than examining compliance gaining in artificial laboratory settings using hypothetical situations or paper&#x2013;pencil measures, investigators should look for compliance gaining as it occurs in more naturalistic contexts, a topic we discuss next.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec10_7">
<title>Compliance Gaining in Action: Seeing is Believing</title>
<p><xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_16">Robert Cialdini (2016)</xref>, one of our favorite persuasion researchers, describes himself this way:
<disp-quote>
<p>As a kind of secret agent, I once infiltrated the training programs of a broad range of professions dedicated to getting us to say yes. For almost three years, I recorded the lessons taught to aspiring automobile salespeople, direct marketers, TV advertisers, frontline managers, charity fund-raisers, public relations specialists, and corporate recruiters. My intent was to find out which practices worked time after time. So I answered the organizations&#x2019; ads for trainees or otherwise arranged to be present in their classrooms, notebook in hand, ready to absorb the wisdom born of long-standing experience in the business of persuasion.</p>
<attrib>(p. 3)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>In other words, Cialdini observed compliance gaining as it occurs in &#x201C;real life,&#x201D; and as a result, developed a &#x201C;typology&#x201D; of seven underlying principles of social influence that professional persuaders rely on to be effective (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_15">Cialdini, 1993</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_16">2016</xref>). Because other chapters have or will discuss these principles, here we provide quick glimpses of each one.</p>
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p>The principle of <italic>reciprocity</italic> suggests that we should repay, in some form or another, what other people have given us. As such, when people do us a favor, give us a gift, or provide advice, we feel indebted. As a result, we&#x2019;re more likely to comply with their requests (also see <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter11">Chapter 11</xref>).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The principle of <italic>scarcity</italic> states that when objects or opportunities are in short supply, we value them more (think gold versus dirt here). As such, when something is a &#x201C;limited edition&#x201D; or on sale for a &#x201C;limited time,&#x201D; you might be persuaded to buy it (also see <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter8">Chapter 8</xref>).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The principle of <italic>consistency/commitment</italic> says that the more you become committed to an idea, the more likely you&#x2019;ll be to behave consistently with it. For instance, after committing weeks and weeks to shopping for a particular car, you&#x2019;ll probably feel more committed to buying it (also see <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter3">Chapter 3</xref>).</p></list-item>
</list>
<list list-type="simple">
<list-item><p>4 &#x0026; 5. The principles of <italic>authority</italic> and <italic>liking</italic> suggest that we are more likely to be persuaded by people when we perceive them to be credible and likable. We may also defer to authorities when we should not (also see <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter4">Chapter 4</xref>).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>6. The principle of <italic>social proof</italic> says that other people&#x2019;s behavior guides our choices. As such, we&#x2019;re more likely to visit &#x201C;popular&#x201D; restaurants and read &#x201C;best sellers&#x201D; (also see <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter6">Chapter 6</xref>).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>7. The principle of <italic>unity</italic> says that when we share identities with people (i.e., we feel &#x201C;at one&#x201D; with them based on groups such as family, ethnicity, religious affiliation), we are more easily influenced by them (also see <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter6">Chapter 6</xref>).</p></list-item>
</list>
</sec>
<sec id="sec10_8">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_255">255</target>Summary</title>
<p>In this chapter, we focused on the study of compliance gaining. Early research in this area attempted to discover the different types of strategies that people use to get others to behave in certain ways. Research also focused on the ways in which situations, individual characteristics, and goals affect the use and selection of compliance-gaining strategies. We also discussed how compliance-gaining research has been plagued by several problems. Finally, we examined several underlying principles of compliance that were identified through observing compliance in &#x201C;real-life&#x201D; interactions.</p>
</sec>
</body>
<back>
<fn-group>
<title>Note</title>
<fn id="fn10_1"><label>1</label><p>Three prior methods have been used to assess compliance-gaining behavior, each using a different dependent variable. First, the technique approach treats each individual compliance-gaining tactic as a separate, dependent variable and assumes that the correspondence between selected tactics (selected from a checklist) and used tactics will be high. Second, the strategy approach treats groups of tactics as dependent variables and assumes that correspondence between strategy choice and use will be high. Finally, the summed-tactic approach argues that a single, dependent variable is indicative of some global compliance-gaining attempt and assumes that the summed-tactic-selection score will correspond to the frequency of compliance-gaining messages (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref10_24">Dillard, 1988</xref>).</p></fn>
</fn-group>

<ref id="ref10_24"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Dillard</surname>, <given-names>J. M.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Caughlin</surname>, <given-names>J. P.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Donovan-Kicken</surname>, <given-names>E. <ref id="ref10_66"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Sellnow</surname>, <given-names>D.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Liu</surname>, <given-names>M.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Venette</surname>, <given-names>S.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2006</year>). <article-title>When in Rome, do as the Romans do: A comparative analysis of Chinese and American new teachers&#x2019; compliance-gaining strategies</article-title>. <source>Communication Research Reports</source>, <volume>23</volume>, <fpage>259</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>264</lpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref10_67"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Senn</surname>, <given-names>C. <ref id="ref10_68"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Sheer</surname>, <given-names>V.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2012</year>). <article-title>Supervisors&#x2019; use of influence tactics for extra-role tasks: Perceptions by ingroup versus outgroup members in organizations in Hong Kong</article-title>. <source>Southern Communication Journal</source>, <volume>77</volume>, <fpage>143</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>162</lpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref10_69"><mixed-citation publication-type="book"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Smith</surname>, <given-names>S. <ref id="ref10_71"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Tark</surname>, <given-names>J.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Kleck</surname>, <given-names>G.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2014</year>). <article-title>Resisting rape: The effects of victim self-protection on rape completion and injury</article-title>. <source>Violence Against Women</source>, <volume>20</volume>, <fpage>270</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>292</lpage>. doi:<object-id>10.1177/1077801214526050</object-id></mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref10_72"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Turner</surname>, <given-names>M.
