</ref-list>
</back>
</book-part>
<book-part book-part-type="chapter" id="chapter11">
<book-part-meta>
<title-group>
<label>11</label>
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_260">260</target>Sequential Persuasion</title>
<alt-title alt-title-type="running-head">Sequential Persuasion</alt-title>
</title-group>
<contrib-group>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Gass</surname>
<given-names>Robert H.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Seiter</surname>
<given-names>John S.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
</contrib-group>
</book-part-meta>
<body>
<p>&#x201C;IF YOU&#x2019;RE A DOOR-TO-DOOR salesperson,&#x201D; we&#x2019;re told by a friend who once made his living selling encyclopedias, &#x201C;half your job is getting into people&#x2019;s houses. Once you&#x2019;re inside,&#x201D; he informed us, &#x201C;they&#x2019;re yours, all yours.&#x201D;</p>
<p>According to our friend, most door-to-door salespeople have sneaky ways of getting their feet into your doorway. Some mention your neighbors by name. Some ask for a glass of water. Our pal had a whole spiel based largely on deception. He&#x2019;s not proud of it now, he admitted, but when he greeted customers, he was trained to look like anything but a salesperson.</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_261">261</target>&#x201C;After introducing myself,&#x201D; he told us, &#x201C;I promised I was not going to try to sell them anything. I was just in the neighborhood conducting surveys. I asked them if they would give me their opinions about their family&#x2019;s educational needs and told them that, if they did, I would repay them with &#x2018;educational materials.&#x2019; That usually got me inside.&#x201D;</p>
<p>Once our friend was in the door, he asked his customers to respond to a phony &#x201C;opinion survey&#x201D; (e.g., &#x201C;Do your kids use the library?&#x201D; &#x201C;Do your kids go to the library after dark?&#x201D;) and then showed them a set of encyclopedias that he was &#x201C;willing to give them, for promotional reasons, if they promised to keep the set up to date.&#x201D; How could they do that? Simply by purchasing one yearbook per year for the next 10 years.</p>
<p>Many of the customers agreed to this seemingly unbelievable offer. What they did not realize was that the amount of money they paid for the yearbooks actually covered the cost of the encyclopedias and then some. They&#x2019;d been &#x201C;schmoozed&#x201D; into buying something they thought they were getting for free.</p>
<p>This example, together with the strategies discussed in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter9">Chapter 9</xref>, shows that oftentimes persuasion is not as simple as making a single request or giving one speech. Persuasion, quite frequently, is a process that requires a number of steps. Indeed, before making his pitch, our friend had to get himself into the customer&#x2019;s house. And for reasons we discuss later, by getting customers to agree to the survey, our friend probably increased his chances of making a sale.</p>
<p>In this chapter, we extend concepts from <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter9">Chapter 9</xref> by discussing the topic of &#x201C;sequential persuasion,&#x201D; which examines social influence as a &#x201C;multi-step&#x201D; process. Similarly, this chapter extends concepts from <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter10">Chapter 10</xref> because sequential persuasion, for the most part, encompasses a number of tactics that are aimed at gaining compliance (i.e., getting people to behave in a particular way). We explore research that shows how people increase their persuasiveness, often at the expense of others, by saying or doing something before, or sometimes after, making their request. We begin with a strategy known as <italic>pregiving.</italic></p>
<sec id="sec11_1">
<title>Pregiving: The Old &#x201C;I&#x2019;ll-Scratch-Your-Back-if-you&#x2019;ll-Scratch-Mine&#x201D; Approach</title>
<p>Many years ago, when most cameras still used film, one of the authors received a package in the mail. The package contained two unused rolls of film and a letter explaining that the film was a gift. The letter went on to explain how, after using the film, the author could mail it to the company to be processed. And the funny thing is, the author did, even though the cost of the processing was more expensive than taking the film to a local developer. Why was the author persuaded to spend more money? Because the ploy used by the processing company is a well-known and effective tactic of persuasion known as pregiving. <italic>Pregiving</italic> entails trying to get someone to comply by doing favors or giving gifts in advance. When supermarkets offer free samples of foods to taste, they are employing this strategy. And when service personnel are especially helpful (e.g., a food server boxes leftovers for you), they are using this approach (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_77">Seiter &#x0026; Weger, in press</xref>).</p>
<p>A classic study done by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_74">Dennis Regan (1971)</xref> showed how effective the pregiving strategy can be. In the study, first-year students at Stanford University who had been <target target-type="page" id="page_262">262</target>asked to participate in an experiment on &#x201C;aesthetics&#x201D; were seated in a room with another student. What the students had not been told was that the other student was a confederate who had been planted there by the researcher. After a few minutes, the confederate left the room. When he returned, he was either empty-handed or was carrying two Coca-Colas. If he was empty-handed, he simply sat back down. But if he had sodas, he offered one to the research subject and said, &#x201C;I bought one for you too.&#x201D;</p>
<p>Seems nice enough, but there&#x2019;s a catch; later, the plant informed the subject that he was selling raffle tickets for a new high school gym and would appreciate it if the subject would do him a favor by buying some tickets. Not surprisingly, the results of the study revealed that subjects who had been given a soda ahead of time bought almost twice as many raffle tickets as those who had been given nothing.</p>
<p>Real-world persuaders are also known to put the pregiving tactic to use. For example, in touristy areas of big cities (the Louvre in Paris, the Dome of the Rock in Jerusalem, the Alamo in San Antonio, the Parthenon in Athens), panhandlers have figured out a tricky way to get donations from unsuspecting tourists. The panhandlers wait a block or two from a well-known tourist attraction. When tourists walk by, clearly headed for the attraction, the panhandlers catch up with them, walk in stride, and proceed to &#x201C;guide&#x201D; the tourists to their destination. Once there, the panhandlers ask for a donation for the unrequested and unneeded service rendered.</p>
<p>The pregiving tactic works in other contexts as well. For instance, as a suit salesperson, one of the authors was trained to ask customers if they would like to have their jackets pressed while they were shopping. Very few refused the favor, and even those who did were cheerfully surprised at the offer. What they did not understand was that there was a hidden rationale behind the gesture; not only was it an effective means of getting customers to spend more time shopping, but when it came to purchasing a suit, who better to buy from than the nice salesperson who had already done them a favor?</p>
<p>Two final examples of the pregiving strategy are, to us, perhaps the most disturbing. First, the next time a man asks if he can buy you a drink, women beware; a study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_41">George, Gournic, and McAfee (1988)</xref> found that if women allow men to buy them drinks, both men and women perceive the women to be more sexually available than if the drinks are refused.<xref ref-type="fn" rid="fn11_1"><sup>1</sup></xref> Second, in another study (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_57">Happ, Melzer, &#x0026; Steffgen, 2016</xref>), experimenters posing as interviewers gave passersby a free package of chocolates before asking them to divulge confidential information such as computer passwords. Remarkably, 47.9 percent of participants revealed their passwords to complete strangers. That&#x2019;s compared to the (still remarkable) 29.8 percent who did the same without the incentive. Bottom line? That old warning&#x2014;&#x201C;never take candy from strangers&#x201D;&#x2014;is worth paying attention to.</p>
<sec id="sec11_1_1">
<title>Why Is the Pregiving Tactic Persuasive?</title>
<p>Common explanations for why pregiving works or doesn&#x2019;t work include liking, physical attraction, perceived ulterior motives, gratitude, impression management, and internalized social norms (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_12">Burger, Sanchez, Imberi, &#x0026; Grande, 2009</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_42">Goei, Roberto, Meyer, &#x0026; Carlyle, 2007</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_58">Hendrickson &#x0026; Goei, 2009</xref>). The <italic>liking explanation</italic> suggests that people who do or give something are perceived as kind and good. As a result, they are well liked, and, in turn, more persuasive. Similarly, <target target-type="page" id="page_263">263</target>the <italic>physical attraction explanation</italic> suggests that doing favors leads people to be seen as more attractive, which, in turn, leads them to be more persuasive. The <italic>perceived ulterior motives explanation</italic> suggests that when a favor is seen as a tool of manipulation, it is less likely to lead to compliance. Indeed, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_48">Groves, Cialdini, and Couper (1992)</xref> argued that pregiving actually decreases compliance when it is perceived as a bribe or a pressure tactic. The <italic>gratitude explanation</italic> suggests that receiving a favor leads to positive emotional states (i.e., feelings of gratitude) that motivate benevolent behavior. In other words, people comply because the favor creates a spirit of thankfulness and benevolence. The last two explanations, <italic>impression management</italic> and <italic>internalized social norm</italic>, are based on <italic>the norm of reciprocity</italic> (or <italic>indebtedness</italic>), which, if you recall from <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter10">Chapter 10</xref>, states that it is desirable to repay what another person has provided us (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_21">Cialdini &#x0026; Goldstein, 2004</xref>). More specifically, the impression management explanation suggests that repaying favors is desirable because it keeps you from looking like an ungrateful freeloader. The internalized social norm explanation suggests that repaying favors is desirable because it makes people feel good about themselves when they do the right thing.</p>
<p>Although all of these explanations have received support, the studies that test them side by side favor some explanations over others. For example, in a study by Burger and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_12">2009</xref>), after receiving or not receiving a favor (an unexpected bottled water), research participants were asked to complete and return a survey. Half the participants were told that the person who had done them the favor would be collecting the surveys personally, while the other half were told that they could leave the surveys in a clearly labeled drop-off box. Results indicated that participants who had received the favor were more likely to complete the surveys regardless of how they returned the surveys. This, of course, supported the internalized social norm explanation over the impression management explanation. To be sure, who cares about impressing a drop-off box?</p>
<p>A second study conducted by Goei and his colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_42">Goei et al., 2007</xref>) tested the liking, gratitude, and indebtedness explanations. Support was found for the liking and gratitude explanations but depended on whether the person seeking compliance benefited from gaining compliance. Specifically, when the person doing a favor was seeking compliance for something that would personally benefit him or her (e.g., the person could win &#x0024;50 by selling a lot of raffle tickets), the gratitude explanation was superior. If, however, the person doing the favor did not personally benefit from compliance (e.g., he or she was selling raffle tickets for a good cause), the liking explanation was superior.</p>
<p>Finally, a study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_58">Hendrickson and Goei (2009)</xref> found support for the gratitude, liking, and physical attraction explanations, at least when a favor was done by a person of low status. Regardless of which explanation holds true in a given situation, pregiving is a robust strategy that works well across cultures and persuasive contexts.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec11_2">
<title>Foot in the Door: The &#x201C;Give-Me-An-Inch-And-I&#x2019;ll-Take-A-Mile&#x201D; Tactic</title>
<p>Some time ago, one of the authors and a friend were leaving a shopping mall when they were approached by a woman. She was about 30 years old, nicely dressed, and had a small child with her.</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_264">264</target>&#x201C;Excuse me,&#x201D; she said to the author, &#x201C;would you please tell me what time it is?&#x201D; The author obliged.</p>
<p>&#x201C;I was wondering if you could also spare a few dollars?&#x201D; the woman added. She claimed that her car had run out of gas, she had forgotten her purse, and, if the author would give her his address, she would be happy to return the money to him.</p>
<p>Once again, the author obliged, giving her three or four dollars. He never heard from the woman again. The author&#x2019;s friend, however, saw the same woman several weeks later, using the same scam but at a different mall.</p>
<p>In retrospect, there were probably several things that made the woman successful in her attempt to gain compliance. The fact that she was well dressed made her story seem more believable. She gave a plausible reason for needing the money. And having a small child with her probably created more sympathy. Interestingly, however, having nice clothes, good reasons, and a small child may not have been the only keys to her success. A considerable amount of research shows that the woman might have increased her chances of compliance by asking for the time <italic>before</italic> she asked for money (hmm, maybe there is a good reason then for not giving a stranger &#x201C;the time of day&#x201D;).</p>
<p>The tactic we have just described is often referred to as the <italic>foot-in-the-door strategy,</italic> hereafter called FITD. The tactic involves making a small request first and then making a second, larger request. Of course, it is the second, larger request that most interests the persuader. The first, small request is merely a setup. For instance, the encyclopedia salesperson we talked about earlier used this tactic when he asked people if they would answer a short survey before he asked for a sale. He didn&#x2019;t really care about their responses to the survey; he simply wanted to soften them up. For reasons we discuss later, when people comply with a smaller request, it often makes them more likely to comply with a second, larger request.</p>
<p>The first study to demonstrate the effectiveness of the FITD strategy was conducted by Jonathan Freedman and <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_40">Scott Fraser (1966)</xref> at Stanford University. These researchers were interested in finding out if they could get housewives to agree to a very large request. Specifically, they asked housewives to allow a team of five or six men into their homes for two hours. The men, they were told, would have complete freedom in the house to go through the cupboards and storage spaces in order to classify all of the household products that were there. Before being approached with this request, however, some of the women were set up with a smaller initial request. That is, three days before making the large request, the researchers called some of the housewives and asked if they would participate in a survey about household products (e.g., &#x201C;What brand of soap do you use?&#x201D;). Surprisingly, about 50 percent of the housewives who agreed to answer the survey also agreed to let complete strangers rifle through their houses. However, when the researchers had not approached housewives with a smaller request first, only about 25 percent of the housewives agreed to the subsequent larger request (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_40">Freedman &#x0026; Fraser, 1966</xref>).</p>
<sec id="sec11_2_1">
<title>Why Is a Foot in the Door So Persuasive?</title>
<p>The FITD tactic appears to be a robust tactic that is effective given the right conditions (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_7">Burger, 1999</xref>). But what makes it so persuasive? The most common explanation for the effectiveness of the FITD tactic is based on Bem&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_2">1972</xref>) <italic>self-perception theory</italic> (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_28">DeJong, 1979</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_40">Freedman &#x0026; Fraser, 1966</xref>). According to this <target target-type="page" id="page_265">265</target>theory, people come to know about their attitudes, emotions, and other internal states by inferring them from their own behavior (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_2">Bem, 1972</xref>). For example, if you notice yourself eating a lot of Nutrageous candy bars, you are likely to come to the conclusion that you have a favorable attitude toward chocolate. In other words, you use your behavior to infer your attitude.</p>
<p>As an explanation for the FITD effect, self-perception theory says this: When you agree to comply with a small request, you see yourself as an altruistic person who is likely to help. Once you form that impression, you are motivated to behave in a manner consistent with that impression. Thus, when a larger request is made, you are more likely to comply.</p>
<p>Although some research points to the viability of self-perception theory as an explanation for the effectiveness of the FITD tactic, other evidence is not so optimistic. For example, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_47">Gorassini and Olson (1995)</xref> conducted a study that measured how helpful people perceived themselves to be after complying with a first, small request. They found that although people&#x2019;s self-ratings of helpfulness were affected by compliance with the small request, those changes did not always predict people&#x2019;s compliance with a second, larger request. Moreover, compliance with a second, larger request often occurred without people perceiving themselves as being more helpful. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_29">Dillard (1990)</xref> argued that results of studies such as these show that more theorizing about the FITD tactic is necessary.</p>
<p>A meta-analysis by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_7">Burger (1999)</xref>, however, suggests that self-perception <italic>does</italic> affect how much people comply with FITD requests. All research may not indicate this, however, because self-perception is probably not the only process involved. Specifically, Burger noted that other psychological processes operating in an FITD situation may overwhelm whatever impact self-perception has. As a result, not all studies will support a self-perception account of the FITD&#x2019;s effectiveness. By way of example, people may be less willing to comply with a request if they think most other people would reject the request. Thus, as <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_7">Burger (1999)</xref> notes, &#x201C;it appears that whatever push self-perception gives toward agreement with the target request can be overwhelmed by telling the individual that few people go along with such requests&#x201D; (p. 323). In short, self-perception probably plays a role in the FITD&#x2019;s effectiveness, but the tactic&#x2019;s success depends on a lot of other factors (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_21">Cialdini &#x0026; Goldstein, 2004</xref>). We discuss some of these next.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec11_2_2">
<title>When Does a Foot in the Door Work?</title>
<p>Research tells us that some of the following conditions play an important role in determining the effectiveness of the FITD tactic:
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p><italic>Size of the initial request.</italic> Is getting a person to comply with any request enough to get the person to comply with later requests? Research shows that the initial request should be neither too large nor too small. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_78">Seligman, Bush, and Kirsch (1976)</xref> argued that &#x201C;the first request must be of sufficient size for the foot in the door technique to work&#x201D; (p. 519). However, the initial request cannot be so large that it is rejected. Thus, the persuader must strike a balance between making a large enough initial request to trigger the FITD effect but not so large that it is declined. For instance, asking for a penny so you might later get a larger donation probably would not work because the penny might be perceived as <target target-type="page" id="page_266">266</target>inconsequential. However, asking the average person for &#x0024;1,000 to begin with might be a reach. In short, the persuader wants to use the largest possible request that will be accepted.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Prosocialness of the request.</italic> In a review of several studies, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_30">Dillard, Hunter, and Burgoon (1984)</xref> found that the FITD tactic is more effective when used for prosocial causes than it is when used for self-serving reasons. With this in mind, the FITD tactic would probably be more useful to social workers trying to raise money to help the homeless than it would be for commissioned salespeople.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>External incentives to comply.</italic> Meta-analyses by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_7">Burger (1999)</xref> and Dillard and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_30">1984</xref>) indicated that people are less susceptible to the FITD tactic if they are offered external incentives for complying with the first request. Most researchers use self-perception theory to explain these effects. For example, if you received a gift for agreeing to listen to a timeshare sales pitch, you would not form an impression of yourself as someone who is willing to comply readily with requests. You are only complying because you have a material reason for doing so. Thus, because the pregiving strategy (discussed earlier) uses external incentives, it may not be a good idea to use it and the FITD strategies together (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_1">Bell, Cholerton, Fraczek, Rohlfs, &#x0026; Smith, 1994</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_82">Weyant, 1996</xref>).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Who makes the requests.</italic> For the FITD strategy to work, the same person needn&#x2019;t make both the initial and the follow-up requests. Indeed, it is often the case that a person who complies with a request by one person will also comply with a second request, even when the second request is made by a different person. In fact, research by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_18">Chartrand, Pinckert, and Burger (1999)</xref> found that when a different person made the second request, compliance was more likely than when the same person made both requests. This was especially true when there was no time delay between the first and second requests (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_18">Chartrand et al., 1999</xref>).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Labeling.</italic> Imagine that just after you donated blood to the Red Cross, a nurse tells you how generous you are and thanks you. Or better yet, imagine that the nurse gives you a pin or bumper sticker that says, &#x201C;I Care Enough to Donate Blood.&#x201D; A review of studies by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_7">Burger (1999)</xref> reported that this type of labeling increases the odds that you will comply with larger follow-up requests (e.g., to donate blood every month for a year). This finding, of course, is consistent with self-perception theory&#x2014;that is, if someone labels you as someone who is helpful, you may begin to see yourself that way and, as a result, act in accordance with your self-perception. (For a different spin on social labeling, see <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box11_1">Box 11.1</xref>.)</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Preference for consistency.</italic> You may remember from <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter3">Chapter 3</xref> that most people strive for consistency in their behaviors and attitudes. How does this relate to the FITD tactic? If you agree to an initial request, you should be motivated to behave consistently by also agreeing to a second request. This is especially true if the two requests are similar (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_7">Burger, 1999</xref>). According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_25">Cialdini, Trost, and Newsom (1995)</xref>, some people have a greater need for such consistency than others. As might be expected, those with a higher need for consistency are more influenced by the FITD tactic than are those who are not (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_25">Cialdini et al., 1995</xref>). This is especially true when people with a higher need for consistency are reminded of how important consistency is (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_49">Guadagno, Asher, Demaine, &#x0026; Cialdini, 2001</xref>).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><target target-type="page" id="page_267">267</target><italic>Self-concept clarity.</italic> Did you know that some people have a clearer picture of their self-concept than others? These folks are said to have &#x201C;high self-concept clarity.&#x201D; Interestingly, research shows that these folks are more susceptible to the FITD tactic than are people with a fuzzier idea of self (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_9">Burger &#x0026; Guadagno, 2003</xref>). Why? It turns out that people with high self-concept clarity are more likely to change their self-concepts. As such, after complying with an initial request, they are more likely than people with low self-concept clarity to see themselves as helpful and, in turn, comply with a second request (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_9">Burger &#x0026; Guadagno, 2003</xref>).</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
<boxed-text id="box11_1">
<label>Box 11.1</label>
<caption><title>I&#x2019;m So Hungry I Could Eat a Horse: The Darker Side of Labeling</title></caption>
<p>Up to now, we&#x2019;ve seen that labeling people in a positive way (&#x201C;you&#x2019;re so helpful!&#x201D;) may lead them to perceive themselves in a positive way, which, in turn, may make them more likely to comply with requests for help. But what do you suppose would happen if people were labeled in a negative way? Is it possible that they would be more likely to comply with requests for help in order to restore their damaged self-esteem? A study by Nicolas Gu&#x00E9;guen (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_50">2001</xref>) tested this possibility in a devilish way. More than 100 pedestrians on a busy street in France were approached individually by three women who were part of the study. The first woman asked each unsuspecting target, &#x201C;Excuse me &#x2026;, my bag is heavy and I would like to buy a magazine. &#x2026; Would you mind keeping an eye on my bag while I go and get it?&#x201D; (p. 745). If the pedestrians agreed, they were left with a bag, which contained a package on top labeled &#x201C;Horse meat.&#x201D; Twenty seconds later, half of the pedestrians were approached by the second woman, who looked at the bag and said, &#x201C;It is really appalling to eat horse meat. When I think that it is thanks to the horse that we have evolved so much. You should be ashamed.&#x201D; (p. 745). Without waiting, the second woman left, the first woman returned with her magazine, thanked the pedestrians, and left with her bag of meat. Finally, the third woman approached the pedestrians and asked one of two things. Half of the pedestrians were asked to sign a petition favoring the proper treatment by the government of abandoned animals. The other half were asked to sign a petition favoring the limitation of traffic in the city center. Results of the study showed that pedestrians who received the negative label were significantly more likely to sign the petition, but only if asked to sign the petition about the treatment of animals. This, of course, makes sense: Having been shamed for eating pony parts, the second petition allowed pedestrians to buck the negative label and declare their unbridled love for horses.</p>
</boxed-text>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec11_3">
<title>The Door-In-The-Face Tactic: &#x201C;Ask for the Stars&#x201D;</title>
<p>One of our students used to work selling jewelry in a large department store. She tells us that her approach to sales was very different from that of the other salespeople with whom she worked. Most of them, she tells us, started by showing their customers the &#x201C;bottom of the line&#x201D; merchandise. To increase their sales, they then moved to more expensive merchandise, demonstrating that &#x201C;more money&#x201D; meant &#x201C;higher quality.&#x201D; However, our student started by showing her customers the most expensive merchandise first. Typically, they did not purchase what they were <target target-type="page" id="page_268">268</target>first shown but, even so, our student claims that while she worked at that store, her sales were always higher than anyone else&#x2019;s.</p>
<p>Actually, we are not surprised by our student&#x2019;s success as a salesperson. Whether she knew it or not, she was using a tactic of persuasion that researchers have known to be effective for many years. Often called the <italic>door-in-the-face technique,</italic> or DITF, this tactic is just the opposite of the FITD strategy. It works by first making a request so large that it is turned down, then following it up with a second, smaller request. Of course, just as with the FITD tactic, compliance with the second request is what the persuader has been aiming for all along.</p>
<p>The first empirical study of the DITF tactic was conducted by Robert Cialdini and his colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_26">Cialdini et al., 1975</xref>). To visualize the study, imagine what you would do if someone approached you, identified herself as a representative of a youth-counseling program, and asked if you&#x2019;d be willing to chaperone a group of juvenile delinquents on a one day visit to the zoo. If you were like most of the people in the study (83 percent), you would refuse the request. It turns out, however, that people were much more responsive to the request if something happened beforehand. Specifically, when people were asked to volunteer two hours per week counseling juvenile delinquents for a minimum of two years, and then asked to chaperone the delinquents on the zoo trip, they were three times more likely to serve as chaperons. In other words, people were more likely to do a smaller favor (zoo chaperon) after refusing to do a large favor (counseling twice a week for up to two years) first.</p>
<p>Since the 1975 study of Cialdini and colleagues, the effectiveness of the DITF tactic has been demonstrated again and again (see reviews by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_22">Cialdini &#x0026; Guadagno, 2004</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_30">Dillard et al., 1984</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_37">Feeley, Anker, &#x0026; Aloe, 2012</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_38">Feeley, Fico, Shaw, Lee, &#x0026; Griffin, 2017</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_39">Fern, Monroe, &#x0026; Avila, 1986</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_68">O&#x2019;Keefe &#x0026; Hale, 1998</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_69">2001</xref>). But rather than examine those studies, we turn now to a discussion of <italic>why</italic> the DITF tactic is thought to be so effective.</p>
<sec id="sec11_3_1">
<title>Why Is a Door in the Face So Persuasive?</title>
<p>A number of explanations for the persuasiveness of the DITF tactic have been proposed and tested, with some faring better than others.</p>
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p><italic>The perceptual contrast effect</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_19">Cialdini, 1993</xref>) suggests that people are likely to comply with a second, smaller request because, compared to the initial, larger request, the second request seems much smaller than it normally would have (e.g., a &#x0024;500 diamond ring seems inexpensive compared to the &#x0024;3,000 rings but expensive compared to the &#x0024;100 rings).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The <italic>self-presentation explanation</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_71">Pendleton &#x0026; Batson, 1979</xref>) suggests that when people reject an initial request, they become concerned that they will be perceived negatively and thus comply with a second request in order to make themselves look better.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Reciprocal concessions</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_26">Cialdini et al., 1975</xref>) suggests that, when a persuader employing the DITF tactic makes a concession by following up with a smaller request, we may be motivated to reciprocate the favor by complying with the second request.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>The legitimacy explanation</italic> (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_38">Feeley et al., 2017</xref>) suggests that making concessions can signal that a persuader has a greater need for compliance <target target-type="page" id="page_269">269</target>(i.e., the persuader is making a genuine request), which, in turn, engenders a greater obligation to help the persuader.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The <italic>guilt-based account</italic> (O&#x2019;Keefe &#x0026; Figg&#x00E9;, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_67">1997</xref>) argues that refusing an initial, prosocial request leads persuadees to experience guilt, which they attempt to reduce by agreeing to a second request.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The <italic>social responsibility position</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_81">Tusing &#x0026; Dillard, 2000</xref>) suggests that we think it is socially responsible to help people who deserve it. As such, we&#x2019;re more likely to comply when follow-up messages ask for our help.</p></list-item>
</list>
<p>Based on analyses of multiple experiments, the social responsibility (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_37">Feeley et al., 2012</xref>) and reciprocal concessions (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_38">Feeley et al., 2017</xref>) explanations have found the most support. That said, according to Feeley and his colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_38">2017</xref>), perceptual contrast, guilt, and the legitimacy of requests probably contribute to the tactic&#x2019;s effectiveness.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec11_3_2">
<title>When Does a Door in the Face Work?</title>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 11.1</label>
<caption><title>The door in the face tactic gone awry.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig11_1.tif"/>
<p>Source: Calvin and Hobbes &#x00A9; (1985) Watterson. Distributed by Universal Press Syndicate. Reprinted with permission. All Rights Reserved.</p>
</fig>
<p>Research tells us that some of the following conditions play an important role in determining the effectiveness of the DITF tactic:
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p><italic>Size of the initial request.</italic> For the DITF strategy to work, the first request must be large enough to guarantee rejection by the persuadee but not so large as to appear incredible (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_26">Cialdini et al., 1975</xref>). But is there a right size for the initial request? A study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_36">Even-Chen, Yinon, and Bizman (1978)</xref> addressed this question and concluded that the initial request must be large for the door in the face to work. However, they noted that the request must not be so large that it evokes anger, resentment, or incredulity in the persuadee (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_36">Even-Chen et al., 1978</xref>).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Type of compliance sought.</italic> A meta-analysis by Feeley and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_37">2012</xref>) found that the DITF tactic is not effective when used for self-serving reasons but can increase compliance when used for altruistic purposes. Moreover, the tactic works better when seeking volunteers (e.g., to participate in research) than when seeking monetary donations, and for obtaining verbal, rather than behavioral, compliance. Finally, the DITF tactic is more effective than a single request when compliance is more difficult to achieve (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_37">Feeley et al., 2012</xref>).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><target target-type="page" id="page_270">270</target><italic>Elapsed time between first and second requests.</italic> Several reviews of studies on the DITF (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_30">Dillard et al., 1984</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_37">Feeley et al., 2012</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_39">Fern et al., 1986</xref>) argue that compliance is increased when the delay between the two requests is short. By way of example, Gu&#x00E9;guen, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_53">Jacob, and Meineri (2011)</xref> found that restaurant patrons who had refused invitations to order dessert were likely to accept invitations to order tea or coffee, especially when the follow-up invitation occurred immediately after the refusal rather than three minutes later.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Can a different person make the second request?</italic> Researchers who support the reciprocal concessions explanation (discussed earlier) like to point out that the DITF strategy does not work if the first and second requests are made by different people. Indeed, if a door-to-door salesperson offers you a vacuum cleaner for &#x0024;500, and a different salesperson offers you the appliance for &#x0024;300, you might perceive a contrast but not a concession. However, if the same salesperson made both offers, you might be more likely to reciprocate the concession and comply with the second offer.</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec11_4">
<title>The That&#x2019;s-Not-All Tactic: Seeking Compliance by Sweetening the Deal</title>
<p>Remember our friend who sold encyclopedias? We began the chapter by telling you how he used to weasel his way into houses with the foot-in-the-door tactic. But that&#x2019;s not all he did to sell his books. He also used what he calls the &#x201C;but wait, that&#x2019;s-not-all&#x201D; strategy. Here&#x2019;s how it worked: After presenting the books and before asking for the sale, he showed his customers several other items they could receive for free (an atlas, a dictionary, a thesaurus) <italic>if</italic> they agreed to buy the encyclopedias. Perhaps you&#x2019;ve observed this strategy used in other contexts. For instance, haven&#x2019;t we all seen those commercials for food and vegetable slicers and dicers? Typically, after a demonstration, you&#x2019;re asked, &#x201C;How much would you pay for this?&#x201D; Then you&#x2019;re presented with an add-on knife. How much would you pay now? How about if a carrot cleaner were added? Well, you get the idea, so &#x201C;call now!&#x201D;</p>
<p>To see whether this tactic was effective, Jerry Burger (1896) conducted several studies. In one, the tactic was used on customers at a bake sale. When customers asked about the price of a cupcake, they were told one of two things. Some customers were told that a cupcake and two cookies sold for 75 cents. Other customers, however, were not told about the cookies right away&#x2014;a few seconds after they&#x2019;d been told that the cupcakes sold for 75 cents each, it was explained that the price included the cost of two cookies. Results of the study showed that the &#x201C;that&#x2019;s-not-all&#x201D; tactic sold more cupcakes. Specifically, although only 40 percent of the customers who had been presented cookies and cupcakes at the same time made a purchase, 73 percent of the &#x201C;that&#x2019;s-not-all&#x201D; customers made a purchase.</p>
<p>Why does this tactic work so well? According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_6">Burger (1986)</xref>, the &#x201C;that&#x2019;s-not-all&#x201D; tactic&#x2019;s effectiveness may be because of the norm of reciprocity and contrast effect (discussed earlier in this chapter). First, because the seller has sweetened the deal by adding on items, the customer may feel obligated to buy the product, thereby <italic>reciprocating</italic> the seller&#x2019;s action. Second, in <italic>contrast</italic> to the original deal, the revised deal may seem much better than it would have without the comparison.</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_271">271</target>But wait, there&#x2019;s more: Before concluding this discussion, we should note that the &#x201C;that&#x2019;s-not-all&#x201D; tactic can include more than adding on items to make a deal look better; it can also involve lowering the price of an item. For example, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_6">Burger (1986)</xref> found that more people bought cupcakes when the price was dropped from &#x0024;1 to 75 cents than when the price was simply stated as 75 cents. You might have noticed that, in this form, the &#x201C;that&#x2019;s-not-all&#x201D; tactic is a lot like the door in the face approach. The difference is that, when using the door in the face approach, the persuader waits for the initial request to be rejected before following up with a lesser request. Persuaders using the &#x201C;that&#x2019;s-not-all&#x201D; tactic do not wait for the initial request to be rejected before sweetening the deal. Some evidence indicates that of the two techniques, the &#x201C;that&#x2019;s-not-all&#x201D; tactic is the more persuasive (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_6">Burger, 1986</xref>). (For a look at how these two tactics and others might be used together, see <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box11_2">Box 11.2</xref>.) Even so, salespeople or others wishing to use this tactic need to be careful. Some evidence suggests that it might backfire if the salesperson&#x2019;s initial request is too large (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_11">Burger, Reed, DeCesare, Rauner, &#x0026; Rozolis, 1999</xref>). It&#x2019;s not difficult to imagine why. For example, if a salesperson asked you to buy a chocolate chip cookie for &#x0024;5 and then lowered the price to 75 cents, you&#x2019;d probably be suspicious that the initial price was purposely inflated and that the salesperson was trying to pull a fast one. (For more drawbacks on a related influence approach, see <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box11_3">Box 11.3</xref>.)</p>
<boxed-text id="box11_2">
<label>Box 11.2</label>
<caption><title>Doors and Feet: An Extension and Combination of Tactics</title></caption>
<p>If given a choice of sequential request techniques to use, which works best? Some research has addressed this question. For instance, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_17">Chan and Au (2011)</xref> found that Chinese children completed more academic work when teachers used the door-in-the-face technique (e.g., &#x201C;Complete 100 questions,&#x201D; then &#x201C;Just complete 20 questions.&#x201D;) than when they used the foot-in-the-door technique (e.g., &#x201C;Complete 5 questions,&#x201D; then &#x201C;Complete 20 questions.&#x201D;). However, rather than pitting techniques against one another, perhaps a better approach, when possible, is to use them together. Indeed, research has found that combinations of sequential tactics can be effective (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_44">Goldman &#x0026; Creason, 1981</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_45">Goldman, Creason, &#x0026; McCall, 1981</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_46">Goldman, Gier, &#x0026; Smith, 1981</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_80">Souchet &#x0026; Girandola, 2013</xref>). For example, two doors in the face or two feet in the door made people more compliant than a single door or foot. Further research by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_43">Goldman (1986)</xref> found that the door-in-the-face and foot-in-the-door techniques also can be combined. Here&#x2019;s how it works: First, people are presented with a very large request that they are almost sure to reject (e.g., &#x201C;Would you call 150 people and ask them questions about the zoo?&#x201D;). Second, people are presented with a moderate request that serves as a foot in the door. Because this request follows the very large request, however, it can be more difficult than the initial request that is typically used in the foot-in-the-door approach (e.g., &#x201C;Would you participate in a 25-minute survey about the zoo?&#x201D; versus &#x201C;Would you answer three or four questions about the zoo?&#x201D;). Finally, people are asked to comply with the request that the persuaders wanted them to comply with all along (e.g., &#x201C;Would you stuff and address 75 envelopes with information about the zoo?&#x201D;). Results of Goldman&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_43">1986</xref>) study found that this combination approach was more persuasive than either tactic alone.</p>
</boxed-text>
</sec>
<sec id="sec11_5">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_272">272</target>The Low-Ball Tactic: Changing the Deal</title>
<p>If you&#x2019;ve ever bought a car from a dealership, there&#x2019;s a chance you&#x2019;ve seen the <italic>low-ball tactic</italic> in action. Here&#x2019;s how it works. First, the salesperson makes you a deal that looks too good to refuse. Perhaps the car you want is offered for several hundred dollars less than any place else you&#x2019;ve shopped. Excited, you accept the offer. But then, a number of things might go wrong. For instance, the salesperson might inform you that the quoted price did not include an expensive option (e.g., air conditioning) that you thought was included. Or, the salesperson might check with his or her manager for approval and later report that the deal was rejected. Why? The dealership would lose money if the car were sold so cheap. In short, the original offer is taken back, and you are asked to pay a much higher price for the car.</p>
<p>Slimy? You bet. But also very effective. Indeed, two meta-analyses of multiple experiments found that the low-ball tactic increased compliance significantly (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_8">Burger &#x0026; Caputo, 2015</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_70">Pascual, Carpenter, Gu&#x00E9;guen, &#x0026; Girandola, 2016</xref>). By way of example, in one study, Cialdini and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_20">Cialdini, Cacioppo, Bassett, &#x0026; Miller, 1978</xref>) wanted to see if they could get undergraduate students to wake up <target target-type="page" id="page_273">273</target>early. Here&#x2019;s what happened: Some students were simply asked to participate in a &#x201C;thinking&#x201D; experiment at seven in the morning. Others, however, were asked to participate but were not told when the experiment would take place. If they agreed to participate, they were told the time of the experiment and asked if they were still willing to participate. In other words, the second group of students was lowballed. Results of the study showed that although only 31 percent of the non-lowballed students agreed to participate, 56 percent of the lowballed students agreed.</p>
<boxed-text id="box11_3">
<label>Box 11.3</label>
<caption><title>Cheapening Your Product by Sweetening the Deal: The Drawbacks of Including Free Gifts With Purchases</title></caption>
<p>Not long ago, one of the authors, intending to buy a Valentine&#x2019;s Day gift for his wife, ended up at a cosmetics counter in a local department store. After sniffing at a dozen samples he&#x2019;d dabbed on his arms, he settled on some perfumed lotions. It wasn&#x2019;t until he&#x2019;d paid and was leaving the counter that the salesperson called after him, explaining she&#x2019;d forgotten that those particular lotions came with a free gift&#x2014;a little handbag with an orange ribbon. The author didn&#x2019;t think much of the handbag&#x2014;after all, it was just a freebie, probably something that was out of style or didn&#x2019;t sell&#x2014;but he didn&#x2019;t mention that when he presented it, alongside the lotions, as a gift to his wife. To his surprise, she was thrilled. In fact, she made a bigger fuss over that bag than those darned expensive lotions. At the time, the author chalked up the differences between his and his wife&#x2019;s perceptions to his lack of appreciation for handbags. But then he came across a study suggesting that he was not alone; apparently, other people react the same way to free gifts. Indeed, in one study (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_72">Raghubir, 2004</xref>), research participants were asked to evaluate the desirability of a pearl bracelet. Half were told that the bracelet was a free gift accompanying the purchase of another item, while the other half were presented the bracelet as a stand-alone product. Results showed that the second group was willing to pay more for the bracelet than the first group. Similarly, another study showed that, compared to bundling items and selling them together, marketing them in &#x201C;buy-one, get-one-free&#x201D; offers led to a value-discounting effect&#x2014;the free, add-on item was perceived as less valuable than when it was bundled with something else (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_73">Raghubir, 2005</xref>).</p>
<p>This research, of course, has implications for businesses that include their regular merchandise or services as free promotional items from time to time. By doing so, such businesses may cause their customers to perceive those items or services as less desirable. With that in mind, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_72">Raghubir (2004)</xref> suggests that customers should be informed of how valuable the gift is. For example, rather than say that a handbag is a &#x201C;free gift,&#x201D; a salesperson should say something like, &#x201C;You&#x2019;ll also receive this &#x0024;50 handbag, with our compliments.&#x201D;</p>
</boxed-text>
<p>As unethical as the low-ball tactic seems, it is used far more often than might be expected. Credit card issuers, for instance, are known for tempting customers with low introductory &#x201C;teaser&#x201D; rates. The problem is that these rates may double or even triple in a few months. Rates on some adjustable mortgages do this too; a few years at a very reasonable rate, then&#x2014;BAM!&#x2014;a balloon payment is due.</p>
<sec id="sec11_5_1">
<title>Why Lowballing Works</title>
<p>According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_8">Burger and Caputo (2015)</xref>, the effectiveness of the low-ball tactic can be explained by three psychological processes, which include commitment to the action, commitment to the person, and self-presentation. To illustrate the first, let&#x2019;s use the automobile customer as an example. Specifically, when the customer agrees to the initial offer, he or she becomes psychologically committed to the idea of owning the car. Thus, even when the reasons for buying the car change, the customer has a hard time altering his or her decision and commitment (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_20">Cialdini et al., 1978</xref>).</p>
<p>Second, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_10">Burger and Petty (1981)</xref> suggested that people fall victim to the tactic because agreeing with the initial request creates a commitment to the requester. In other words, people agree to a second, more costly request because they feel obligated to make good on their promises. In support of this hypothesis, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_10">Burger and Petty (1981)</xref> found that the low-ball tactic works only when the same person who made the first request also makes the less attractive request. It does not work when a different person makes the less attractive request.</p>
<p>The third explanation, self-presentation, suggests that people want to be seen in a favorable light. As such, they comply with requests to avoid looking bad (e.g., like &#x201C;welshers&#x201D; who don&#x2019;t keep their commitments). If that&#x2019;s the case, Gu&#x00E9;guen and Pascual (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_52">2014</xref>) wondered how people might respond if asked to comply with requests that were associated with illegal behavior&#x2014;the idea being that people should be less motivated to look good in the eyes of &#x201C;deviant&#x201D; persuaders. To find out, cigarette-smoking pedestrians were approached in one of two ways. In the low-ball condition, a researcher said, &#x201C;I see that you are smoking a cigarette and I wonder if you could give me a light for my cigarette.&#x201D; If the pedestrians agreed, the researcher lowballed them by pulling out a large cannabis joint, which was illegal to smoke in the study&#x2019;s location. In another condition, a researcher produced the cannabis joint before asking for a light. What were the results? Lowballed pedestrians complied more than pedestrians who were not lowballed, leading Gu&#x00E9;guen and Pascual (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_52">2014</xref>) to conclude that, compared to commitment, self-presentation is a weaker explanation for the effectiveness of the low-ball tactic.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec11_6">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_274">274</target>&#x201C;Sorry, We Don&#x2019;t Have any More of those in Your Size, But &#x2026;&#x201D;: The Bait-And-Switch Tactic</title>
<p>The next time you see a big sale advertised, be careful. If you aren&#x2019;t, you may fall victim to a persuasion tactic that some authors (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_60">Joule, Gouilloux, &#x0026; Weber, 1989</xref>; Marchand, Joule, &#x0026; Gu&#x00E9;guen, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_64">2015</xref>) call &#x201C;the lure.&#x201D;</p>
<disp-quote>
<p>This tactic &#x2026; is frequently used when goods are put on sale. For example, a beautiful pair of shoes marked 40&#x0025; off is displayed quite conspicuously in a store window. The enticed consumer enters the store with the intention of taking advantage of this exceptional offer, but the salesperson informs him that they are out of the shoe in his size. Just when the disappointed customer is ready to leave the store, he is shown a new pair that resembles the shoes on sale but that is being sold at the regular price.</p>
<attrib>(p. 742)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
<p>The travel industry uses the same ploy, which is more commonly known as the <italic>bait-and-switch tactic.</italic> For instance, a company might advertise an inexpensive vacation package as part of a promotion. However, as many prospective travelers discover, very few of these seats or packages are available, and they are often sold out by the time people have committed themselves to the idea of a vacation. The only solution is to go home and mope or buy a more expensive option.</p>
<p>Research by Joule and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_60">1989</xref>) indicates that the bait and switch is an effective strategy for gaining compliance. In one study, these researchers got several students to sign up to participate in a rather interesting and well-paying experiment. When the students showed up for the experiment, however, they were told that it had been canceled. Even so, these students, compared to those who were not lured, were more willing to participate in another experiment that was less interesting and unpaid.</p>
<p>The low-ball and bait-and-switch tactics are similar in that both lead the customer on before pulling the rug out. How do the two differ? With the low-ball technique, the customer is still buying the product he or she wanted, but at a higher cost. There are &#x201C;strings attached&#x201D; to the deal or &#x201C;fine print&#x201D; that drives up the cost. With the baitand-switch, the customer is buying a different product altogether, often at a higher price or of lower quality. The product she or he wanted is sold out or out of stock.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec11_7">
<title>The Disrupt-Then-Reframe and Pique Techniques: I&#x2019;m so Confused</title>
<p>If we offered to sell you five Nutrageous candy bars for 400 pennies, would you buy them? It would be a bargain.</p>
<p>Before you decide to buy anything after being presented an offer like this, be careful. You might be falling for a sequential compliance tactic known as the <italic>disrupt-then-reframe technique</italic> (DTR). According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_27">Davis and Knowles (1999)</xref>, the DTR rests on the assumption that certain requests (e.g., asking for charitable donations) create a conflict within persuadees. Specifically, persuadees want to help but are also resistant to the expense or effort required to do so. The DTR overcomes this problem by disrupting the persuadees&#x2019; resistance. How? According to Davis and Knowles, <target target-type="page" id="page_275">275</target>certain confusion techniques (e.g., non sequiturs, requests stated in a peculiar way) can be used to divert people&#x2019;s minds from maintaining resistance. Once that is accomplished, reframing the request with a positive spin (e.g., &#x201C;It&#x2019;s a bargain&#x201D;) works to engage the persuadees&#x2019; underlying desire to help.</p>
<p>To test the effectiveness of this technique, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_27">Davis and Knowles (1999)</xref> examined door-to-door salespeople who were trying to sell greeting cards in order to earn money for a worthy charity. The salespeople presented different messages to potential buyers. Some customers received a straightforward sales pitch&#x2014;&#x201C;The cards are &#x0024;3. It&#x2019;s a bargain&#x201D;&#x2014;whereas others were presented with a slightly peculiar pitch (i.e., the DTR technique)&#x2014;&#x201C;The cards are 300 pennies &#x2026; that&#x2019;s &#x0024;3. It&#x2019;s a bargain.&#x201D; Results of the study indicated that when salespersons used the DTR technique, they sold significantly more cards than when they used the more straightforward approach (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_27">Davis &#x0026; Knowles, 1999</xref>). A meta-analysis of several studies suggests that this technique is effective, particularly when seeking donations in nonprofit contexts (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_15">Carpenter &#x0026; Boster, 2009</xref>).</p>
<p>A related approach, called the <italic>pique technique</italic> is simpler (and sounds more poetic) than the DTR. It also involves making a peculiar request. For example, in the first examination of the technique (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_76">Santos, Leve, &#x0026; Pratkanis, 1994</xref>), a woman posing as a vagrant asked passersby for &#x201C;a quarter,&#x201D; &#x201C;any change,&#x201D; or, more oddly, for &#x201C;17 cents&#x201D; or &#x201C;37 cents.&#x201D; Results indicated that the more unusual requests (i.e., 17 and 37 cents) were more persuasive, perhaps because they, like the DTR, disrupt people&#x2019;s refusal scripts. A recent meta-analysis indicates that the pique technique is especially persuasive when smaller amounts of money are requested, when accompanied by a legitimate reason for making the request, and when used in France (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_61">Lee &#x0026; Feeley, 2017</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec11_8">
<title>Legitimizing Paltry Contributions: Even A Penny Will Help</title>
<p>A technique known as <italic>legitimizing paltry contributions</italic> (LPC for short) involves letting people know that very small donations would be acceptable. By way of example, in the first examination of the LPC technique, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_24">Cialdini and Schroeder (1976)</xref> found that adding the phrase &#x201C;even a penny will help&#x201D; to a request for donations increased the percentage of donations that people made to the American Cancer Society. Similarly, the phrase &#x201C;even a single marble will make him/her happy&#x201D; led more people to donate toys to children from needy families (Gu&#x00E9;guen, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_54">Martin, &#x0026; Meineri, 2013</xref>).</p>
<p>Originally, the approach was considered an effective way to fend off excuses like &#x201C;I can&#x2019;t afford that right now&#x201D; or &#x201C;I don&#x2019;t have the money for that.&#x201D; A recent meta-analysis (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_3">Bolkan &#x0026; Rains, 2015</xref>), however, suggests that the LPC is effective for two alternative reasons. Specifically, the impression management (self-presentation) explanation suggests that people who refuse tiny requests might worry that they&#x2019;ll be perceived as heartless cheapskates. Meanwhile, the &#x201C;requester need&#x201D; explanation suggests that people are more willing to donate because they feel that someone willing to accept exceptionally tiny donations must be especially desperate for help.</p>
<p>Previous research suggests that LPC is an effective way of amassing a large number of donations and may be even more effective when combined with other influence techniques (e.g., social proof) (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_75">Russell &#x0026; Boster, 2016</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_79">Shearman &#x0026; Yoo, 2007</xref>). <target target-type="page" id="page_276">276</target>That said, although LPC garners a larger number of donations, research is inconsistent on whether the technique lowers the amount of money donated per person (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_3">Bolkan &#x0026; Rains, 2015</xref> versus <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_62">Lee, Moon, &#x0026; Feeley, 2016</xref>). Either way, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_3">Bolkan and Rains (2015)</xref> noted that the technique would still be effective when all-or-none behavior is requested. For instance, someone requesting a signed petition might say, &#x201C;even one signature will help&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_3">Bolkan &#x0026; Rains, 2015</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec11_9">
<title>The Evoking Freedom Technique: &#x201C;&#x2026; But You Are Free to Accept or Refuse&#x201D;</title>
<p>If you hate being pressured to comply, the <italic>evoking freedom technique</italic> (a.k.a. <italic>but you are free technique)</italic> might appeal to you. If you&#x2019;ve ever heard someone say something like &#x201C;Feel free to say no&#x201D; or &#x201C;I&#x2019;m asking, not insisting,&#x201D; he or she might have been using this technique. In the first study to examine it (Gu&#x00E9;guen &#x0026; Pascual, 2000), pedestrians were approached by an experimenter and asked, &#x201C;Excuse me &#x2026; can I ask for some change to take the bus, please?&#x201D; Only 10 percent of pedestrians complied. However, when the experimenter added the phrase &#x201C;but you are free to accept or to refuse,&#x201D; not only did compliance rates jump to 47.5 percent, the average donation was twice as large. Since then, a growing body of research indicates that the technique is effective in a large number of contexts (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_13">Carpenter, 2013</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_56">Gu&#x00E9;guen, Joule, Halimi-Falkowicz, Pascual, Fischer-Lokou, &#x0026; Dufourcq-Brana, 2013</xref>). One common explanation for the technique&#x2019;s effectiveness is that it reduces psychological reactance. Specifically, because people react negatively when their freedom is restricted (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_5">Brehm, 1966</xref>), declaring them &#x201C;free&#x201D; leads them to experience less reactance (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_16">Carpenter &#x0026; Pascual, 2016</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_65">Meineri, Dupre, Gu&#x00E9;guen, &#x0026; Vallee, 2016</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec11_10">
<title>Fear-Then-Relief and Happiness-Then-Disappointment Procedures: The Emotional Roller Coasters of Social Influence</title>
<p>If you are a fan of detective novels and movies, you&#x2019;re undoubtedly familiar with the way the &#x201C;good cop/bad cop&#x201D; interrogation operates. First, the &#x201C;bad cop&#x201D; mistreats the suspect, humiliating, yelling at, and threatening to do harm. Next, the &#x201C;good cop&#x201D; enters the interrogation room, asks the bad cop to chill out, and then woos the suspect into confessing with little more than a cup of coffee and a dose of respect. Based on this scenario, Dolinski and Nawrat (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_31">Dolinski, 2007</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_33">Dolinski &#x0026; Nawrat, 1998</xref>) identified the <italic>fear-then-relief procedure</italic>. The assumption underlying the procedure is that fear/relief confuses people, which, in turn, leads them to act rather mindlessly (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_32">Dolinski, 2016</xref>). Additionally, complying with requests can help them cope with their confusion (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_35">Dolinski, Dolinska, &#x0026; Bar-Tal 2017</xref>). As such, they become prone to influence attempts. Previous research indicates that the procedure is effective (e.g., see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_31">Dolinski, 2007</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_34">Dolinski &#x0026; Szczucka, 2012</xref>). For example, studies that have scared people (e.g., by blowing police whistles at jaywalkers or leaving &#x201C;tickets&#x201D; on illegally parked vehicles) and then relieved them (by having the people see that police weren&#x2019;t the ones blowing the whistles or that the tickets were really just leaflets), have found that those people are typically more compliant (e.g., willing to complete surveys) than people who have not undergone the procedure. Research also suggests that the <target target-type="page" id="page_277">277</target>persuasive effect of see-sawing emotions is not just confined to fear-then-relief. Indeed, one study found that a <italic>happiness-then-disappointment procedure</italic> (e.g., finding a note that had originally looked like money) also led people to comply more with later requests (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_66">Nawrat &#x0026; Dolinski, 2007</xref>).</p>
<p>Before concluding this section, we think it&#x2019;s important to reiterate that a number of ethical concerns surround the use of influence tactics, perhaps even more so when persuasion involves unpleasant emotions such as fear. Remember, just because a tactic is effective does not mean it is ethical. Given the importance of these topics, we will have more to say about emotions and ethics in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter13">Chapters 13</xref> and <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter16">16</xref>.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec11_11">
<title>Summary (And then Some)</title>
<p>This chapter featured some of the most prominently researched sequential tactics. Pregiving involves making a persuadee feel indebted so that he or she will be more compliant. The foot-in-the-door tactic involves making a small request and following up with a large one. The foot-in-the-mouth tactic works by getting people to admit to feeling terrific and then trying to get them to behave in a way consistent with their declaration. The door-in-the-face tactic involves making a large request and following up with a smaller one. The that&#x2019;s-not-all tactic seeks compliance by making deals more attractive before persuadees agree to them. When using the low-ball tactic, persuadees are asked to agree with an attractive request but are expected to agree with a less attractive request later. Similarly, the bait-and-switch technique lures people with merchandise that is attractive in order to get them to buy substitute merchandise that is less attractive. The disrupt-then-reframe and pique tactics divert people from resisting requests. The legitimization-of-paltry-favors approach minimizes excuses for making a donation. The fear-then-relief procedure uses changes in emotion to disorient and then persuade people. The dump-then-chase technique occurs when persuaders persist in their influence attempts by addressing obstacles to compliance.</p>
<p>We realize that we&#x2019;ve covered a heap of strategies this chapter. Even so, we can&#x2019;t help but wish there was more space. Indeed, plenty of additional tactics are waiting to be explored. In case you&#x2019;re interested, <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box11_4">Box 11.4</xref> provides the briefest of glimpses to get you started.</p>
<boxed-text id="box11_4">
<label>Box 11.4</label>
<caption><title>But Wait, There&#x2019;s More: A Laundry List of Additional Tactics</title></caption>
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p>The Foot-in-the-Mouth Effect: Donation seekers are especially successful if they ask people how they are feeling, acknowledge the response, and then request compliance (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_59">Howard, 1990</xref>; Meineri &#x0026; Gu&#x00E9;guen, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_63">2011</xref>). Thus, when a phone solicitor asks, &#x201C;How are you?,&#x201D; you might be putting your foot in your mouth by replying, &#x201C;Great!&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The Dump-and-Chase: Persuaders who &#x201C;won&#x2019;t take no for an answer&#x201D; and continue to chase compliance by responding to obstacles are using this tactic. &#x201C;Too expensive?&#x201D; they might reply. &#x201C;Let&#x2019;s talk about our layaway plan &#x2026;&#x201D; According to some research (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_4">Boster, Shaw, Hughes, Kotowski, Strom, &#x0026; Deatrick, 2009</xref>), <target target-type="page" id="page_278">278</target>the dump-and-chase works just as well as and sometimes better than the foot-in-the-door and door-in-the-face techniques.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The Four Walls Technique: Persuaders are more successful when you answer &#x201C;yes&#x201D; to a list of seemingly innocent questions (e.g., &#x201C;Do you like animals?&#x201D; &#x201C;Should animals be well cared for?&#x201D;) before they deliver the target request (e.g., &#x201C;Will you donate to the Humane Society?&#x201D;) (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_23">Cialdini &#x0026; Sagarin, 2005</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_55">Gu&#x00E9;guen, Joule, Halimi-Falkowicz, &#x0026; Marchand, 2013</xref>).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The &#x201C;Just One More&#x201D; Technique: People are more compliant when they believe that they are the last person required to reach a goal. So, if you want a survey filled out, you should be more successful if you follow &#x201C;Would you be willing to take a survey?&#x201D; with &#x201C;I just need one more person to take my survey&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_14">Carpenter, 2014</xref>).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The &#x201C;You Will Probably Refuse, But &#x2026;&#x201D; Technique: Perhaps because it is perceived to threaten their freedom to act, people donate more money to charity when the words &#x201C;You will probably refuse, but &#x2026;&#x201D; come before a request (Gu&#x00E9;guen, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref11_51">2016</xref>).</p></list-item>
</list>
</boxed-text>
</sec>
</body>
<back>
<fn-group>
<title>Note</title>
<fn id="fn11_1"><label>1</label><p>Although we don&#x2019;t think it&#x2019;s common, we don&#x2019;t rule out the possibility of women using this same approach on men.</p></fn>
</fn-group>

<ref id="ref11_78"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Seligman</surname>, <given-names>C.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Bush</surname>, <given-names>M.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Kirsch</surname>, <given-names>K.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>1976</year>). <article-title>Relationship between compliance in the foot-in-the-door paradigm and size of first request</article-title>. <source>Journal of Personality and Social Psychology</source>, <volume>33</volume>, <fpage>517</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>520</lpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref11_79"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Shearman</surname>, <given-names>S. H.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2007</year>). <article-title>&#x201C;Even a penny will help!&#x201D;: Legitimization of paltry donation and social proof in soliciting donation to a charitable organization</article-title>. <source>Communication Research Reports</source>, <volume>24</volume>, <fpage>271</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>282</lpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref11_80"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Souchet</surname>, <given-names>L.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Girandola</surname>, <given-names>F.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2013</year>). <article-title>Double foot-in-the-door, social representations and environment: application for energy savings</article-title>. <source>Journal of Applied Social Psychology</source>, <volume>43</volume>, <fpage>306</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>315</lpage>. doi:<object-id>10.1111/j.1559&#x2013;1816.2012.01000.x</object-id></mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref11_81"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Tusing</surname>, <given-names>K.
