</ref-list>
</back>
</book-part>
<book-part book-part-type="chapter" id="chapter12">
<book-part-meta>
<title-group>
<label>12</label>
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_283">283</target>Deception</title>
<alt-title alt-title-type="running-head">Deception</alt-title>
</title-group>
<contrib-group>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Gass</surname>
<given-names>Robert H.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Seiter</surname>
<given-names>John S.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
</contrib-group>
</book-part-meta>
<body>
<p>WHEN ONE OF YOUR AUTHORS was 5 or 6 years old, he cut the hair off several of his sister&#x2019;s Barbie dolls. He was a proud little vandal, and savvy enough to realize that an interrogation was inevitable. To prep, he practiced angelic expressions in front of a mirror and then moseyed innocently around the house until his mother, provoked by her daughter&#x2019;s shrieks, found him. &#x201C;Look me in the eye and tell me you didn&#x2019;t do it,&#x201D; his mom said, holding your author gently by his shoulders. &#x201C;It wasn&#x2019;t me,&#x201D; the author replied. He stared straight at her &#x2026; and then burst into tears.</p>
<p>Deception, he learned the hard way, is no cakewalk. Likewise, detecting lies, more often than not, is more difficult than this story makes it seem. Indeed, humans, in general, tend to be far less accurate than they believe when trying to detect deception. Some research shows that the average person can detect a liar with about the same accuracy as someone flipping a coin (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_8">Bond &#x0026; DePaulo, 2006</xref>), whereas other research presents an even less optimistic view. For example, when accuracy rates for truthful and deceptive messages are examined separately (rather than together, as in most studies), people&#x2019;s detection accuracy is above 50 percent for truths, but well below 50 percent for lies. Levine and his colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_72">Levine, 2014</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_68">Levine &#x0026; Kim, 2010</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_73">Levine, Park, &#x0026; McCornack, 1999</xref>) call this the <italic>veracity effect</italic>.</p>
<p>The fact that people are not very accurate at detecting deception is unfortunate when you consider the practical and professional contexts within which accurate detection would be desirable (e.g., for jurists, consumers, law officers, negotiators, customs inspectors, job interviewers, secret service agents, and so forth; see <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box12_1">Box 12.1</xref>). Clearly, there are practical advantages to improving detecting abilities, and this <target target-type="page" id="page_284">284</target>observation leads us to the following questions: Are there any reliable cues that can be used to detect deception? If so, what are they? Are some people better at lying than others? Can some people detect deceit more accurately than others? Are there factors that can improve people&#x2019;s ability to detect a liar?</p>
<boxed-text id="box12_1">
<label><target target-type="page" id="page_285">285</target>Box 12.1</label>
<caption><title>Something Phishy Is Going On: Beware of Internet Deception</title></caption>
<p>Some time ago, one of the authors received an email greeting him as &#x201C;Dear Bank of the West Customer.&#x201D; The email told him that because of too many failed login attempts, his banking account had been locked and could be unlocked only by following a link to a website where he could provide his ATM card number and PIN. Fortunately, he didn&#x2019;t take the bait, unlike others who have been hooked&#x2014;line and sinker&#x2014;by what are known as &#x201C;phishing&#x201D; or &#x201C;spoofing&#x201D; scams. Such scams try to lure you to a website where you provide personal or financial information, which, in turn, enables the con artists to commit identity theft or credit card fraud. Some, known as spear-phishing attacks, target specific victims and people with high net worth, often with intimate knowledge about the victim. In one study, spear phishing fooled one-third of the targets into clicking on an embedded link (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_79">Luo, Zhang, Burd, Seazzu, 2013</xref>). To prevent yourself from being filleted by such scams, beware of unfamiliar websites. Use only website addresses you have used before. If you receive an email that seems to be snooping for personal info, be especially wary. If you are suspicious, contact the legitimate company directly. Finally, if you&#x2019;ve been hooked, contact the police and file a complaint with the FBI&#x2019;s Internet Crime Complaint Center (<uri>www.ic3.gov/default.aspx</uri>).</p>
</boxed-text>
<p>These are some of the questions we address in this chapter. But, before doing so, we would like to make a point. You might ask, &#x201C;Why is a chapter on deception in a book on persuasion?&#x201D; We respond that <italic>deception is a form of persuasion.</italic> Even from the standpoint of pure cases of persuasion, deception involves an intentional attempt to get someone to believe what the liar knows to be false. As Miller (cited in <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_89">Miller &#x0026; Stiff, 1993</xref>) argued: &#x201C;Deceptive communication strives for persuasive ends; or, stated more precisely, deceptive communication is a general persuasive strategy that aims at influencing the beliefs, attitudes, and behaviors of others by means of deliberate message distortion&#x201D; (p. 28).</p>
<p>With this basic understanding of deception as persuasion under our belt, we now turn to a more in-depth discussion of some common conceptualizations of deception. The rest of the chapter examines research on the enactment and perception of deception.</p>
<sec id="sec12_1">
<title>What is Deception? Lies and Damn Lies</title>
<p>In this section, we examine what deception entails conceptually. To answer the &#x201C;conceptual question,&#x201D; scholars have attempted to outline several types of <target target-type="page" id="page_286">286</target>communication that might be considered deceptive. Many attempts to do so have focused on liars&#x2019; motivations for telling lies.</p>
<p>Although some motivations for lying are self-evident, others are less obvious. For example, various researchers have posited all of the following reasons for lying (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_5">Barnett et al., 2000</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_26">Camden, Motley, &#x0026; Wilson, 1984</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_33">DePaulo, Ansfield, Kirkendol, &#x0026; Boden, 2004</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_75">Lindskold &#x0026; Walters, 1983</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_102">Seiter, Bruschke, &#x0026; Bai, 2002</xref>).</p>
<list list-type="bullet">
<list-item><p><italic>Lie to benefit other:</italic> Because she knows that her husband does not want to be disturbed, Babbs tells a door-to-door salesman that her husband is not home.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Lie to affiliate:</italic> Buffy wants to spend some time with her father, so she tells him she needs help with her homework even though she is capable of doing it herself.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Lie to avoid invasion of privacy:</italic> Muffy tells a co-worker that she is younger than she really is because she believes her age is no one&#x2019;s business but her own.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Lie to avoid conflict:</italic> Biff tells his neighbor, who has called to complain about Biff&#x2019;s barking dog, that he cannot talk at the moment because dinner&#x2019;s on the table.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Lie to appear better:</italic> To impress a date, Rex tells her that he was captain of his debate team when, in reality, he was treasurer of the Slide Rule Club (for more on this motivation, see <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box12_2">Box 12.2</xref>).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Lie to protect self:</italic> Trudy breaks her mother&#x2019;s vase but tells her the cat did it.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Lie to benefit self:</italic> Favio tells his parents he needs extra money for textbooks so that he can buy tickets to a Lady Gaga concert.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Lie to harm other:</italic> Barney&#x2019;s in a bad mood so he points in the wrong direction when a motorist asks him directions.</p></list-item>
</list>
<p>In addition to looking at people&#x2019;s motivations for lying, another approach to conceptualizing deception is to examine the types of strategies people use when lying. For example, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_24">Burgoon, Buller, Ebesu, and Rockwell (1994)</xref> distinguished three deception strategies: <italic>distortion</italic> (or equivocation), <italic>omissions</italic> (or concealment), and <italic>falsification</italic> (outright falsehoods). Yet other researchers have come up with other categories of deception (e.g., see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_57">Hopper &#x0026; Bell, 1984</xref>).</p>
<p>In addition to looking at different types of deception, a final way of conceptualizing deception was proposed in <italic>information manipulation theory</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_82">McCornack, 1992</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_87">McCornack, Morrison, Paik, Wisner, &#x0026; Zhu, 2014</xref>).<xref ref-type="fn" rid="fn12_1"><sup>1</sup></xref> This theory argues that when we are talking with others, we typically assume that they will be cooperative, providing us information that is not only truthful but also informative, relevant, and clear. We&#x2019;re not always right, however. Indeed, people violate our assumptions by manipulating the information they communicate to us. First, they might not provide the <italic>quantity</italic> of information that we assume they will (i.e., they tell the truth, but not the <italic>whole</italic> truth). Second, they might violate our assumptions about the <italic>quality</italic> of information provided (i.e., what they tell us is not at all true). Third, they might manipulate information through <italic>manner violations</italic>, communicating messages that are vague and ambiguous. Finally, people can engage in <italic>relation violations</italic> by presenting messages that are not relevant. According to the theory, some violations (e.g., quantity) are predicted to occur more frequently than others (e.g., relation). That said, people can alter the quantity, quality, relation, and manner of messages all at the same time or in different <target target-type="page" id="page_287">287</target>combinations. In other words, there is an infinite variety in forms of deception (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_86">McCornack, Levine, Solowczuk, Torres, &#x0026; Campbell, 1992</xref>). To give you an idea, examples of the ways in which people manipulate information along each of these dimensions are presented in <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box12_3">Box 12.3</xref>.</p>
<boxed-text id="box12_2">
<label>Box 12.2</label>
<caption><title>Can I Believe Anything That Comes Out of Your Mouse? Deception and Online Dating</title></caption>
<p>If you or anyone you know has searched for love on any of the dozens of online dating sites available, beware. Apparently, people&#x2019;s motivation to create desirable impressions when trying to attract prospective partners is so powerful that they&#x2019;ll resort to some serious truth stretching in the process. In one study (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_108">Toma &#x0026; Hancock, 2010</xref>), for example, researchers invited 80 online daters to their lab. Among other things, the researchers weighed and measured the daters to see if any funny business was going on, and found out that it was. Specifically, 81 percent of the daters lied in their profiles about their height, age, or weight, with men lying more than women about their height and women lying more than men about their weight. Moreover, independent judges considered about one third of the daters&#x2019; online photographs to be deceptive representations of the daters&#x2019; current appearance. In short, if you think &#x201C;seeing is believing,&#x201D; think again.</p>
</boxed-text>
<boxed-text id="box12_3">
<label>Box 12.3</label>
<caption><title>Information Manipulation Theory: Examples of Deceptive Dimensions of Messages</title></caption>
<p>Gabriella has been babysitting several children for her neighbor, Betty Jones. The youngest child, Morgan (age 2), although usually well behaved, has been a handful all night. To top off a difficult evening, while Gabriella was cooking dinner and helping the other children, Morgan crawled behind the family&#x2019;s new leather couch and scribbled all over the back of it with a permanent marker. Although Gabriella scrubbed the couch with soap and water, she couldn&#x2019;t get the stains out. Later, after Gabriella has put the children to bed, Betty Jones returned home and inquired, &#x201C;How did the night go?&#x201D;</p>
<p>Examples of responses that:
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p>Are clear, direct, and truthful: &#x201C;Tonight was not good, Mrs. Jones. Morgan acted up most of the night. I don&#x2019;t know what got into him. As I was making dinner and helping the girls with their homework, he wrote all over the back of the couch with a Sharpie. I tried to get it off, but it was no use. I&#x2019;m sorry if I didn&#x2019;t watch him as closely as I should have.&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Violate assumptions about the quantity of information that should be provided: &#x201C;Morgan was a little naughty, but it was no big deal.&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Violate assumptions about the quality of information that should be provided: &#x201C;The kids were perfect angels, especially Morgan. We did puzzles. We played games. We laughed. What fun!&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Violate assumptions about the manner of information that should be provided: &#x201C;Oh, you know. We kept busy with this and that. We did some neat stuff &#x2026; We definitely cleaned house tonight!&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Violate assumptions about the relevance of information that should be provided: &#x201C;I don&#x2019;t mean to be rude, but I really need to be getting home, Mrs. Jones. It&#x2019;s late and I have homework to do.&#x201D;</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
</boxed-text>
<p>Having laid the groundwork for examining deception, we now discuss what happens during the process of deception&#x2014;that is, what goes on while deception is being enacted, and how is deception detected?</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec12_2">
<title>Telling Lies: The Enactment of Deception</title>
<p>If all liars had noses like Pinocchio, deception detection would not be a problem. Unfortunately, spotting lies is not that simple. In fact, even empirical research has been inconsistent when trying to identify the types of behaviors that we can expect out of liars. (Some of the behaviors that have been associated with deception are listed in <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box12_4">Box 12.4</xref>).</p>
<sec id="sec12_2_1">
<title>Theoretical Frameworks</title>
<p>Despite these inconsistencies, however, several theories of deception have been proposed that attempt to provide an understanding of the types of behaviors that are typical of liars. One such framework, known as the <italic>four-factor model,</italic> was proposed by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_116">Zuckerman and Driver (1985)</xref>. Another, known as <italic>interpersonal deception theory,</italic> was proposed by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_16">Burgoon and Buller (2004)</xref>. The following sections discuss each of these perspectives.</p>
<sec id="sec12_2_1_1">
<title>The Four-Factor Model</title>
<p>Rather than simply list all the things that people do when telling lies, the four-factor model tries to explain the underlying processes governing deceptive behavior. In other <target target-type="page" id="page_288">288</target>words, rather than tell us <italic>what</italic> people do when lying, the model tries to tell us <italic>why</italic> people behave differently when lying. According to the model, the four factors that influence behavior when lying are arousal, attempted control, felt emotions, and cognitive effort.</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 12.1</label>
<caption><title>&#x201C;I knew the suspect was lying because of certain telltale discrepancies between his voice and nonverbal gestures. Also his pants were on fire.&#x201D;</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig12_1.tif"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; Robert Mankoff/ The New Yorker Collection/ <uri>www.cartoonbank.com</uri>. All Rights Reserved.</p>
</fig>
<boxed-text id="box12_4">
<label><target target-type="page" id="page_289">289</target>Box 12.4</label>
<caption><title>How Do Liars Behave?</title></caption>
<p>A meta-analysis is a summary of several studies. Such an analysis attempts to resolve inconsistencies in research. Several of these analyses (i.e., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_31">DePaulo, Stone, &#x0026; Lassiter, 1985</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_62">Kraut, 1980</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_103">Sporer &#x0026; Schwandt, 2007</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_109">Vrij, 2000</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_116">Zuckerman &#x0026; Driver, 1985</xref>) have examined cues that were associated with deception across a number of studies, but the largest analysis, combining the results of 1,338 estimates of 158 deception cues, was conducted by DePaulo and her colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_34">DePaulo et al., 2003</xref>). Based on this analysis, a number of cues were found to be associated with deception. Keep in mind, though, that all of these cues must be prefaced with the caveat, in general:
<list list-type="simple">
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Talking time: Liars&#x2019; responses are shorter than truth tellers&#x2019; responses.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Details: Liars provide fewer details than do truth tellers.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Pressing lips: Liars press their lips (as if holding back) more than truth tellers.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Making sense: Compared to truth tellers, liars&#x2019; stories are rated as more discrepant and ambivalent and as having less plausibility and logical structure.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Lack of immediacy: Both verbally and vocally, liars seem evasive and impersonal, linguistically distancing themselves from their listeners and from the contents of their presentations (e.g., using passive vs. active voice).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Uncertainty: Liars are rated as sounding more uncertain than truth tellers.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Raising chin: Liars raise their chins more than truth tellers, perhaps to try to appear more certain about their stories.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Repetition: Liars repeat themselves more than do truth tellers.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Cooperation: Liars are rated as less cooperative in their conversations than are truth tellers.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Negative statements: Liars&#x2019; responses contain more negative expressions and complaints than do truth tellers&#x2019; responses.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Pleasantness: Liars&#x2019; faces are less pleasant than are truth tellers&#x2019; faces.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Nervousness: Overall, liars appear more nervous than truth tellers.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Vocal tension and pitch: Compared to truth tellers, liars&#x2019; voices are more tense, and liars speak in a higher pitch.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Pupil dilation: Liars&#x2019; pupils are more dilated than are truth tellers&#x2019; pupils.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Fidgeting: Liars fidget more than truth tellers.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Spontaneous corrections: Truth tellers spontaneously correct themselves more than do liars.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Admitted lack of memory: Truth tellers admit not remembering things more than do liars.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x25AA; Related external associations: Compared to truth tellers, liars are more likely to mention events or relationships peripheral to the key event they are discussing.</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
<p>Although the meta-analysis by DePaulo and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_34">2003</xref>) examined some verbal behaviors, it focused primarily on nonverbal behaviors. Given that, some researchers have wondered whether a reliable set of verbal cues to deception might be uncovered. According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_2">Ali and Levine (2008)</xref>, however, although verbal indicators of deception appear to exist, they have not been consistent from situation to situation or from study to study.</p>
</boxed-text>
<p>First, the model assumes that people are more aroused or anxious when telling lies than when telling the truth. This is also the principle on which the polygraph operates. Of course, we know that results from polygraphs are inadmissible in courts because they are not 100 percent accurate. Why? Because a sociopath, for instance, who feels no remorse for murder certainly won&#x2019;t get anxious when lying. Even so, not all people are sociopaths. We know that many people do feel anxious when they lie. Perhaps they fear getting caught. Perhaps telling the lie reminds them of information they want hidden. Perhaps they are simply motivated to succeed in the deceptive task. Whatever the case, we know that such arousal can lead to certain behaviors during deception. Poker players, for example, are said to wear sunglasses because their pupils dilate when they get a good hand. Similarly, pupil dilation can be a reliable indicator of deception (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_34">DePaulo et al., 2003</xref>). What other cues to arousal accompany deception? A few that researchers have investigated include speech errors, speech hesitations, word-phrase repetitions, increased adaptors (e.g., finger fidgeting), eye blinks, vocal pitch, and leg movements.</p>
<p>Second, because people do not want to get caught telling lies, the four-factor model argues that they try to control their behaviors. This seems to be the case both before and during deception. For example, Hartwig, Granhag, and Str&#x00F6;mwall (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_52">2007</xref>) found that when planning to be interrogated, liars strategized more than truth tellers by planning to remain calm and pleasant. Moreover, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_109">Vrij (2000)</xref> reported that during deception, liars tend to limit their movement to keep from looking nervous. Similarly, according to Ekman and Friesen&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_37">1969</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_38">1974</xref>) <italic>sending capacity hypothesis,</italic> when people tell lies, they try to control their behaviors but, in the process, pay more attention to some cues than others. Because it is difficult to monitor everything they do, liars try to control behaviors that communicate the most information, such as facial expressions and the words they use. But, while busy monitoring their faces and words, they tend to forget about parts of their body that communicate little information such as their legs and feet. So, according to the sending capacity hypothesis, those parts of the body that communicate little information reveal the most when people are lying. In other words, because people are concentrating so much on their faces and words, deception &#x201C;leaks&#x201D; in other places. At least some research tends to support this notion. First, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_27">Caso, Vrij, Mann, and De Leo (2006)</xref> found that, even when they were taught how to avoid looking deceptive, research participants were more effective at controlling their words than their nonverbal behavior. Moreover, one study found that people who watched liars&#x2019; heads and faces (higher sending capacity) were less accurate at detecting deception than people who watched liars&#x2019; bodies (lower sending capacity) (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_38">Ekman &#x0026; Friesen, 1974</xref>). Finally, in a summary of more than 30 studies in which judges tried to detect others&#x2019; deception from either single channels (i.e., only the face, body, tone of voice, or words of the liar) or from particular channel combinations, DePaulo and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_31">1985</xref>) found that in all conditions in which judges relied on facial cues, detection accuracy was lower.</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 12.2</label>
<caption><title>Duping delight in action.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig12_2.tif"/>
<p>Source: Calvin and Hobbes &#x00A9; (1989) Watterson. Distributed by Universal Press Syndicate. Reprinted with permission. All Rights Reserved.</p>
</fig>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_290">290</target>In addition to arousal and attempted control, the four-factor model asserts that affective factors influence our behavior when telling lies. And if you stop to think about it, you could probably figure out what types of emotions would be associated with telling a lie. Indeed, in our culture, deception is generally frowned on. Children are taught that &#x201C;the truth shall set them free,&#x201D; &#x201C;honesty is the best policy,&#x201D; &#x201C;what tangled webs are weaved,&#x201D; and often chide one another with rhymes such as &#x201C;liar, liar, pants on fire.&#x201D; It&#x2019;s no surprise, then, that deceptive behavior would be associated with negative emotions such as guilt. It is because of these negative affects that researchers (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_34">DePaulo et al., 2003</xref>) hypothesized that when compared to truthful communicators, deceivers display less facial pleasantness and make more negative remarks. We should note, however, that not all deception is associated with the display of negative emotions. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_36">Paul Ekman (1985)</xref>, for instance, argued that liars may experience &#x201C;duping delight,&#x201D; as the result of facing or successfully meeting the challenge of deceiving another person.</p>
<p>Finally, the four-factor model asserts that cognitive factors play a role in the way people behave when lying. Stated differently, lying requires you to think a lot harder than telling the truth does. Why? Because it&#x2019;s fairly easy to tell a story about something you&#x2019;ve already heard or experienced. When you lie, however, you are oftentimes required to &#x201C;make things up as you go along.&#x201D; Not only that, you must be careful not to contradict something you&#x2019;ve said before. (Remember the old saying <target target-type="page" id="page_291">291</target>&#x201C;Liars need a good memory&#x201D;?) Because lying requires extra cognitive effort (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_110">Vrij, 2014</xref>), it&#x2019;s no wonder that researchers have hypothesized that liars, compared to people telling the truth, would take a longer time to respond, pause more when speaking, and deliver messages with few specifics (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_112">Vrij, Granhag, Mann, &#x0026; Leal, 2011</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_116">Zuckerman &#x0026; Driver, 1985</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec12_2_1_2">
<title>Interpersonal Deception Theory</title>
<p><italic>Interpersonal deception theory</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_16">Burgoon &#x0026; Buller, 2004</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_21">2008</xref>) views deception as an interactional phenomenon in which both senders and receivers simultaneously encode and decode messages over time. In the process, both the liar&#x2019;s and the detector&#x2019;s goals, expectations, and knowledge affect their thoughts and behaviors. In turn, such thoughts and behaviors affect how accurately lies are detected and whether liars suspect that they are doubted. Later in this chapter, we examine other assumptions that detail the theory. At this point, however, the aspect of interpersonal deception theory that is most relevant is its distinction between <italic>strategic</italic> and <italic>nonstrategic</italic> behaviors during deception. Specifically, interpersonal deception theory argues that a liar&#x2019;s communication consists of both intentional (strategic) attempts to appear honest and unintentional (nonstrategic) behaviors that are beyond the liar&#x2019;s control.</p>
<p>First, interpersonal deception theory says that, to avoid being detected, liars strategically create messages with certain characteristics. For instance, liars might (1) <italic>manipulate the information in their messages</italic> to dissociate themselves from the message (e.g., liars might refer to themselves very little so they distance themselves from the responsibility of their statements), convey uncertainty or vagueness (because creating messages with a lot of specific details would increase the likelihood of detection), or withhold information (e.g., liars might create brief messages). Liars might also (2) <italic>strategically control their behavior</italic> to suppress deception cues (e.g., liars might withdraw by gazing or nodding less than people telling the truth). Finally, liars might try to strategically (3) <italic>manage their image</italic> by smiling or nodding to make themselves appear more credible (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_20">Buller, Burgoon, White, &#x0026; Ebesu, 1994</xref>). Research by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_115">White and Burgoon (2001)</xref> found that during interactions, deceivers continue to modify and adapt their behaviors, thereby supporting the notion that some deceptive behaviors are strategic.</p>
<p>Second, although liars try to control their behaviors strategically, they also exhibit some <italic>nonstrategic communication.</italic> In other words, some behaviors &#x201C;leak out&#x201D; beyond the liar&#x2019;s awareness or control. As noted previously (see the four-factor model), such communication might result from arousal (e.g., blinks, pupil dilation, vocal nervousness, speech errors, leg and body movements, and shorter responses) or negative emotions (e.g., less nodding, less smiling, more negative statements).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec12_2_1_3">
<title>Criticisms of Theoretical Assumptions</title>
<p>Before concluding this section, we should note that many scholars have expressed skepticism about certain assumptions contained in interpersonal deception theory and the four-factor model (for reviews and criticism, see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_42">Feeley &#x0026; Young, 1998</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_72">Levine &#x0026; McCornack, 2014</xref>). For example, McCornack and his colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_83">McCornack, 1997</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_87">McCornack et al., 2014</xref>) argued that, in some cases, telling lies may be less cognitively difficult and arousing than telling the truth. Imagine what <target target-type="page" id="page_292">292</target>you&#x2019;d do if a close friend asked you how you liked her new hairstyle. Imagine also that you thought the hairstyle looked hideous. In such situations, rather than creating a truthful yet tactful message that would preserve your relationship and spare your friend&#x2019;s feelings, it might be less cognitively taxing and less stressful to simply tell your friend that you loved her hair. In short, the underlying differences between truths and lies may not be as simple as some models make them out to be (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_83">McCornack, 1997</xref>).</p>
<p>What do we think of such criticisms? Recall from <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter1">Chapter 1</xref> that the complex nature of persuasion provides one of the most compelling reasons for studying it. When research seems confusing or contradictory, oftentimes it&#x2019;s because the research is approaching the study of persuasion too simplistically. With that in mind, we believe that the preceding criticisms should not be ignored by those who study deception. They are important because they suggest that deceptive behaviors are far more complex than many of us originally imagined. However, while such criticisms should be applauded, we do not think that they render assumptions from the four-factor model and interpersonal deception theory useless. Instead, they suggest that these assumptions apply to some but not all deceptive encounters. Telling different types of lies may lead to different types of behavior (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_102">Seiter et al., 2002</xref>). For example, fabricating lies may require more mental effort than telling the truth, but only when lies are narrative or spontaneous in nature (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_110">Vrij, 2014</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_111">Vrij, Kneller, &#x0026; Mann, 2000</xref>). Moreover, the notion that deception leads to arousal may apply less to fibs and white lies than to more serious forms of deception, such as cheating on a spouse or denying a crime. Even then, what qualifies as a &#x201C;serious&#x201D; form of deception is subject to interpretation. For example, previous research indicates that a person&#x2019;s cultural background not only influences how acceptable that person perceives a lie to be (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_88">Mealy, Stephan, &#x0026; Urrutia, 2007</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_102">Seiter et al., 2002</xref>), but also the emotions (e.g., guilt and shame) that person expects to experience after telling a lie (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_100">Seiter &#x0026; Bruschke, 2007</xref>). In short, our assumptions about deceptive behavior may need to be more qualified or complex in nature. For instance, in <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box12_3">Box 12.3</xref>, we list several cues to deception. It turns out that under certain conditions, the list gets longer. With that in mind, we turn to a discussion of factors affecting successful deception.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec12_2_2">
<title>What Makes a Liar Persuasive?</title>
<p>Previous research suggests that some people are better at &#x201C;pulling the wool over our eyes&#x201D; than others. For instance, research by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_9">Bond and DePaulo (2008)</xref> and Levine and his colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_74">Levine, Serota, et al., 2010</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_65">Levine, 2016</xref>) indicates that while some people are especially <italic>transparent</italic>, leaking the fact that they are lying, others have an honest <italic>demeanor</italic> and, consequently, are typically seen as being truthful even when they are lying. In this section, we discuss the ways in which characteristics of the liar&#x2014;in addition to characteristics of the lie being told and the deceptive situation&#x2014;affect the process of deception.</p>
<sec id="sec12_2_2_1">
<title>The &#x201C;Wool Pullers&#x201D;</title>
<p>The boy who cried wolf should have quit while he was ahead. Or, before he got eaten, he should have at least taken a personality test. If he had, our guess is that he would have scored high on a test that measures a trait known as <italic>Machiavellianism.</italic> The Machiavellian personality is not interested in interpersonal relationships, <target target-type="page" id="page_293">293</target>manipulates others for selfish purposes, and has little sense of social morality (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_28">Christie &#x0026; Geis, 1970</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_46">Geis &#x0026; Moon, 1981</xref>). Machiavellian personalities are truly &#x201C;wolves in sheep&#x2019;s clothing.&#x201D; Not only do they lie and intend to cheat more often than their counterparts (i.e., low Machiavellians) (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_15">Brewer, &#x0026; Abell, 2015</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_58">Jonason, Lyons, Baughman, &#x0026; Vernon, 2014</xref>), they appear more innocent while doing so. Indeed, a classic study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_11">Braginsky (1970)</xref> backs up this claim. In the study, high and low Machiavellian children tasted bitter crackers and then were offered a nickel for each cracker they could get their little chums to eat. The results of the study showed that the high Machiavellian children were not only the most successful in their persuasive attempts, but were also seen as more innocent and honest than the low Machiavellian children.</p>
<p>In addition to Machiavellianism, a person&#x2019;s social skills influence how successful he or she is at deceiving others. For example, high self-monitors, people who use situational information to behave more appropriately, tend to be more skilled at deception than low self-monitors (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_39">Elliot, 1979</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_90">Miller, deTurck, &#x0026; Kalbfleisch, 1983</xref>). Moreover, people skilled at communicating basic emotions are particularly good at convincing others to believe their deceptive messages (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_95">Riggio &#x0026; Friedman, 1983</xref>), whereas those who are apprehensive in their communication tend to leak more deceptive cues (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_92">O&#x2019;Hair, Cody, &#x0026; Behnke, 1985</xref>). Similarly, people who are expressive and socially tactful (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_96">Riggio, Tucker, &#x0026; Throckmorton, 1987</xref>); socially skilled (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_97">Riggio, Tucker, &#x0026; Widaman, 1987</xref>); competent communicators (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_40">Feeley, 1996</xref>); and attentive, friendly, and precise in their communication (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_94">O&#x2019;Hair, Cody, Goss, &#x0026; Krayer, 1988</xref>) are more successful at deceiving others than those who do not possess such skills.</p>
<p>Finally, who do you suppose is better at not being detected when lying&#x2014;males or females? The results of two meta-analyses found that males tend to be more successful at lying than females (Kalbfleisch, cited in <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_25">Burgoon, Buller, Grandpre, &#x0026; Kalbfleisch, 1998</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_117">Zuckerman, DePaulo, &#x0026; Rosenthal, 1981</xref>). Even so, a review of literature by Burgoon and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_25">1998</xref>) suggests that such gender differences are small, perhaps because the deceptive strategies of men and women both have shortcomings. Specifically, when they are lying, men tend to restrict their nonverbal behavior. Although this may prevent them from leaking deceptive cues, if they overdo it, they run the risk of appearing deceptive. Women, however, try to appear more involved in conversations. As a result, this greater activation may cause them to leak more arousal cues and appear more nervous than usual (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_25">Burgoon et al., 1998</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec12_2_2_2">
<title>Are Some Lies Easier to Tell Than Others?</title>
<p>Imagine that Babbs, a 15-year-old high school sophomore, has a curfew of 9 p.m. It&#x2019;s Thursday, a school night, but Babbs is on the dance floor, partying it up when she suddenly notices the time: 11 p.m! Knowing that her parents usually go to bed around 8 p.m., she hopes they&#x2019;ll be asleep but, on arriving home, she finds herself face to face with her parents, who have been waiting up for her. &#x201C;Where have you been?&#x201D; they demand to know, at about the same time Babbs decides that she had better start lying her pants off if she doesn&#x2019;t want to spend the next two weeks in solitary confinement.</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_294">294</target>How successful do you think Babbs will be? According to previous research (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_93">O&#x2019;Hair, Cody, &#x0026; McLaughlin, 1981</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_110">Vrij, 2014</xref>), behavior during deception depends, to a large extent, on whether the liar is telling a prepared lie or a spontaneous lie. To be sure, think about some of the components of the four-factor model we discussed earlier. When telling a prepared lie, compared to a spontaneous lie, Babbs should be less aroused, have more control, and should not find lying as cognitively difficult. Not surprisingly, research on deceptive cues supports this idea; in general, spontaneous lies are accompanied by more cues associated with deception than are prepared lies. And, because prepared liars make a more credible impression, they are more difficult to detect than spontaneous liars (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_35">deTurck &#x0026; Miller, 1985</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_76">Littlepage &#x0026; Pineault, 1979</xref>; Str&#x00F6;mwall, Granhag, &#x0026; Landstr&#x00F6;m, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_106">2007</xref>).</p>
<p>Spontaneity, though, is not the only dimension of a lie that seems to affect deceptive success. Indeed, research also has shown that the length and the content of a lie influences how well a person can tell it. Longer lies, for instance, are more difficult to tell than short ones (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_61">Kraut, 1978</xref>). And concerning content, in a study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_107">Thackray and Orne (1968)</xref>, subjects played the role of an espionage agent who attempted to conceal both his or her identity and certain code words he or she had learned. The results of the study showed that subjects were more successful when telling lies about personally relevant information (i.e., their identity) than when telling lies about neutral information (i.e., code numbers). Similarly, one study (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_114">Warren, Schertler, &#x0026; Bull, 2009</xref>) found that people detected emotional lies (e.g., liars describing Hawaiian landscapes while watching videos of grisly surgeries) more successfully than they detected unemotional lies (liars describing surgeries while watching landscape videos). This finding is consistent with a meta-analysis showing that deceivers displayed fewer nods and illustrators when lying about facts and feelings than when lying about facts only (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_103">Sporer &#x0026; Schwandt, 2007</xref>). Finally, a meta-analysis by DePaulo and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_34">2003</xref>) found that when lying about transgressions, people took longer to respond, talked faster, blinked more, and fidgeted less than truth tellers.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec12_2_2_3">
<title>Deceptive Situations and Deceptive Success</title>
<p>The context in which a lie is told can influence how successful the liar is. Several situational features have been found to influence deception success. One is motivation. Certainly, there are times when you are simply more motivated to lie successfully than others. A fisherman, for example, may not care so much when someone discovers that his trophy &#x201C;bass&#x201D; was really a guppy. A playboy husband cheating on his wife, however, might have more at stake if his affair were discovered. So who, then, is the better liar: the fisherman or the cheat?</p>
<p>To address this question, recall the four-factor model, which suggests that liars attempt to control their behavior to avoid being detected. As you might suspect, this attempt to control behavior increases as people&#x2019;s motivation to lie successfully increases. Consequently, as people become more motivated to lie successfully, their behavior becomes more rigid and over-controlled, a phenomenon known as the <italic>motivational impairment effect</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_30">DePaulo &#x0026; Kirkendol, 1989</xref>). In short, being overly motivated may cause you to be especially detectable.</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_295">295</target>To further illustrate the role of motivation in the process of deception, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_45">Frank and Ekman (1997)</xref> gave 20 males &#x0024;10 each for participating in their research. As part of the study, the males were provided with an opportunity to commit a &#x201C;mock&#x201D; crime&#x2014; they would either steal or not steal &#x0024;50 from a briefcase. Before given the opportunity, the participants were told that if they took the money and were able to convince an interrogator that they were innocent, they could keep the &#x0024;50. If, however, they were caught lying, they would be punished. Specifically, if caught, they would be forced to forfeit both the stolen &#x0024;50 and their initial &#x0024;10 participation fee. Worse yet, they would be required to sit on a cold, metal chair inside a cramped, darkened room, where they would have to endure anywhere from 10 to 40 randomly sequenced, 110-decibel startling blasts of white noise over the course of an hour. Needless to say, the liars in this study were motivated to succeed. Unfortunately for them, results of the study showed that telling such high-stakes lies made them consistently detectable to certain types of people (if you were worried about how they fared in the &#x201C;torture chamber,&#x201D; rest assured, the researchers didn&#x2019;t follow through on their threat). In short, telling high-stakes lies motivates people to succeed and, as a result, makes them more detectable.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec12_3">
<title>Detecting Deception: I Can See Right Through You</title>
<p>Just as persuaders need someone to persuade, liars need someone to lie to. In the preceding pages we discussed deception from the liar&#x2019;s perspective. In this section, we examine the opposite side of the coin: deception detection. One framework, proposed by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_99">Seiter (1997)</xref>, suggests that we treat deception detection a lot like reaching a verdict in a trial (see also <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_56">Henningsen, Valde, &#x0026; Davies, 2005</xref>). Whichever verdict we reach (i.e., the person is lying or the person is telling the truth) depends on how we integrate a vast array of verbal and nonverbal information (e.g., Biff is twitching), past knowledge (e.g., Biff doesn&#x2019;t like Gummi Bears), and inferences (e.g., Biff is nervous). Sometimes the information we observe is contradictory (e.g., Biff seems nervous but tells a plausible story), and, sometimes new information causes us to discount our earlier perceptions. This illustrates how complex and idiosyncratic the process of deception detection can be. In other words, the information that one person uses to detect deception may be quite different from the information that another uses. With that as a backdrop, we turn now to a discussion of factors that affect the detection process.</p>
<sec id="sec12_3_1">
<title>Factors That Influence Detection</title>
<sec id="sec12_3_1_1">
<title>Truth Bias: Presuming That People are Honest</title>
<p>Suppose what would happen if everyone in the world always suspected that everyone else was lying. Cooperation would become impossible. So instead, people tend to assume that other people are being honest. In other words, we go through life with a &#x201C;<italic>truth bias,&#x201D;</italic> mostly believing what other people tell us. This notion forms the basis of Levine&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_64">2014</xref>) <italic>truth-default theory</italic>. According to the theory, the truth bias is adaptive and functional because most of the time people are being honest. When they&#x2019;re being deceptive, however, the truth bias makes detecting them less likely.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec12_3_1_2">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_296">296</target>&#x201C;Look Me in the Eye&#x201D;: Stereotypes and Intuitions About Deception</title>
<p>What kinds of things do you look for to detect deception? When we ask our students this question, the most common response we get is &#x201C;eye contact.&#x201D; When people are lying, our students suggest, they won&#x2019;t look you in the eye or they look up and to the right.</p>
<p>If you&#x2019;ve ever thought the same thing about lying and eye contact, you and our students are not alone. According to Lock&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_77">2005</xref>) sources, research in more than 60 countries indicates that, from Afghanistan to Zimbabwe, people report that eye contact is one of the most common behaviors they use for detecting deception. Here&#x2019;s the catch, though: Generally, research has shown that liars do not avoid eye contact (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_34">DePaulo, et al., 2003</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_103">Sporer &#x0026; Schwandt, 2007</xref>), and in some situations engage in more deliberate eye contact than truth do tellers (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_81">Mann, Vrij, Shaw, Leal, Ewens, Hillman, Granhag, &#x0026; Fisher, 2013</xref>). Likewise, evidence that people look in certain directions when lying&#x2014;a hypothesis derived from neurolinguistic programming&#x2014;is weak at best (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_80">Mann, Vrij, Nasholm, Warmelink, Leal, &#x0026; Forrester, 2012</xref>). What&#x2019;s more, many of the other behaviors people say they use to detect deception are not reliable indicators of deception (e.g., see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_49">Granhag, Giolla, Sooniste, Stromwell, &#x0026; Lui-Jonsson, 2016</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_50">Hart, Hudson, Fillmore, &#x0026; Griffith, 2006</xref>).</p>
<p>Given that, you might be thinking that such stereotypes are to blame for our generally less-than-stellar ability to detect deception. If so, think again. Although this notion, known as the <italic>wrong subjective cue hypothesis</italic> (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_51">Hartwig &#x0026; Bond, 2011</xref>), prevailed for decades, recent research suggests that people tend to be unaware of the cues they actually rely on to detect deception. In other words, people <italic>say</italic> they look for one set of cues, but they actually use a different set of cues. In one meta-analysis, for instance, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_51">Hartwig and Bond (2011)</xref> found that rather than relying on lack of eye contact and other stereotypical cues, people tend to look for signs of ambivalence, uncertainty, and indifference to detect deception. What&#x2019;s more, the latter group of cues was more reliable, suggesting that people&#x2019;s intuitions about deceptive cues are less flawed than the stereotypical cues they report using. As such, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_51">Hartwig and Bond (2011)</xref> note that one possible avenue for improving detection might be to promote (and improve) more automatic, intuitive processing of messages. This, they suggest, might occur if people receive feedback about the accuracy of their judgments often enough to develop useful intuitions about deceptive behaviors.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec12_3_1_3">
<title>Training People to Be Effective Lie Detectors</title>
<p>Training people to be better at spotting lies, however, could prove to be tricky business. Indeed, an analysis of 30 studies indicated that training people to spot verbal and nonverbal cues to deception improved their detection accuracy, but the effect was small (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_54">Hauch, Sporer, Michael, &#x0026; Meissner, 2016</xref>). Not only that, two studies found that training might actually backfire (Akehurst, Bull, Vrij, &#x0026; K&#x00F6;hnken, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_1">2004</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_59">Kassin &#x0026; Fong, 1999</xref>)&#x2014;that is, people who had been trained to spot cues to deception, compared to those who had not, were significantly <italic>less</italic> accurate at spotting lies.</p>
<p>That said, if you&#x2019;re thinking that deception detection is a hopeless endeavor, don&#x2019;t surrender just yet. Instead, keep in mind that when experts are allowed to actively question suspects, accuracy rates get much higher (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_67">Levine, Clare, Blair, McCornack, Morrison, &#x0026; Park, 2014</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_78">Luke, Hartwig, Joseph, Brimbal, Chan, Dawson, Jordan, Donovan, &#x0026; Granhag, 2016</xref>). <target target-type="page" id="page_297">297</target>With that in mind, a more promising approach might be to focus on improving people&#x2019;s interrogation techniques, a topic we&#x2019;ll return to later in this chapter.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec12_3_1_4">
<title>Humans as Polygraphs</title>
<p>Just as some people are better at deceiving others, are some people more skillful at detecting deception? Some research seems to indicate that this is the case. For example, earlier we mentioned that some, but not all people, were fairly consistent when trying to detect high-stakes lies. What, then, you might wonder, distinguishes these people from more gullible folks? Is there some type of trait or individual difference that separates effective from ineffective deception detectors? If so, research has not identified it. Although some studies have identified individual differences such as involvement (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_44">Forrest &#x0026; Feldman, 2000</xref>), self-monitoring (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_13">Brandt, Miller, &#x0026; Hocking, 1980b</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_47">Geizer, Rarick, &#x0026; Soldow, 1977</xref>), and sex (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_32">DePaulo, Zuckerman, &#x0026; Rosenthal, 1980</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_98">Rosenthal &#x0026; DePaulo, 1979</xref>) as characteristics that may help or hinder successful deception detection, one meta-analysis examining over 140 studies (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_9">Bond &#x0026; DePaulo, 2008</xref>) found that when large numbers of studies are examined side by side, individual differences do not appear to play a significant role in deception detection. Such differences do, however, predispose some people to be more suspicious and others to be more trusting, which, in turn, may make them less accurate when trying to distinguish lies from truths. We will examine these biases later in the chapter. For now, though, we should mention that <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_9">Bond and DePaulo (2008)</xref> do not completely rule out the possibility that individual differences may affect deception detection in the real world. For example, they suggest that individual differences in people&#x2019;s ability to analyze nonverbal behaviors some time after an interaction might lead to more accuracy.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec12_3_1_5">
<title>Familiarity, Biases, and Deception Detection</title>
<p>Does knowing a person help us detect his or her deception? Several researchers have asked this question but, for quite some time, results of such studies seemed mixed. For instance, in five studies (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_12">Brandt, Miller, &#x0026; Hocking, 1980a</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_13">1980b</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_14">1982</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_41">Feeley &#x0026; deTurck, 1997</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_43">Feeley, deTurck, &#x0026; Young, 1995</xref>), people rated communicators&#x2019; veracity after either watching or not watching videotapes of the communicators&#x2019; normal, truthful behavior. The results of these studies showed that people who were familiar with the communicators&#x2019; previous, truthful behaviors were more accurate in their judgments than those who were unfamiliar. Similarly, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_29">Comadena (1982)</xref> found that spouses could detect each other&#x2019;s deception better than friends could. However, Miller and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_91">1981</xref>) found that when judging lies about emotional information, friends were more accurate than either strangers or spouses, and two studies (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_3">Al-Simadi, 2000</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_101">Seiter &#x0026; Wiseman, 1995</xref>) found that people who tried to detect the deception of people from their own ethnic or cultural group (e.g., those with whom they would presumably be the most familiar) were less accurate than people who tried to detect the deception of people from ethnic or cultural groups other than their own.<xref ref-type="fn" rid="fn12_2"><sup>2</sup></xref></p>
<p>Although such results may seem inconclusive, interpersonal deception theory (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_17">Buller, Stiff, &#x0026; Burgoon, 1996</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_21">Burgoon &#x0026; Buller, 2008</xref>) suggests that they may not be when you consider the possible effects of familiarity on deception. The theory <target target-type="page" id="page_298">298</target>argues that familiarity is a double-edged sword: In some ways, it may help you to be a better deception detector; in other ways, it might hinder your ability to detect deception. First, because of certain biases, the better you know someone, the less effective you are at detecting his or her lies. Specifically, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_85">McCornack and Parks (1986)</xref> found that familiarity increased a person&#x2019;s confidence about judging veracity which, in turn, led to a <italic>truth bias</italic> (see above). The results of their study and others (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_104">Stiff, Kim, &#x0026; Ramesh, 1992</xref>) support this idea by showing that the truth bias was positively associated with familiarity and negatively associated with detection accuracy. In other words, people were less accurate when judging familiar others because they thought the others were always honest and trustworthy. In positive relationships based on trust, a truth bias is likely. However, in &#x201C;negative&#x201D; relationships, a <italic>lie bias</italic> (i.e., the perception that people are being dishonest) becomes more likely (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_84">McCornack &#x0026; Levine, 1990</xref>). Whatever the case, both the truth and lie biases make you less accurate when judging veracity because they prevent you from distinguishing truths from lies.</p>
<p>Although truth and lie biases make you less accurate at detecting the deception of familiar others, the knowledge you&#x2019;ve gained about familiar others can also make you more accurate at detecting them (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_18">Buller, Stiff, &#x0026; Burgoon, 1996</xref>). Specifically, because you have more background information about familiar others, you might be more likely to notice contradictions in what they say (e.g., your significant other has told you that he or she has never been to San Francisco but later says, &#x201C;The view from the Golden Gate Bridge is fantastic&#x201D;). Moreover, because you have more knowledge about the way a familiar other typically behaves, you may be more likely to detect his or her deception when the behavior suddenly changes (e.g., your significant other, who is normally calm, becomes very nervous whenever he or she talks about espionage agents). Finally, when you know another person well, you may be more likely to recognize idiosyncratic behaviors that that person only enacts while lying (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_4">Anderson, Ansfield, &#x0026; DePaulo, 1999</xref>). In short, then, familiarity can both help and hinder accurate deception detection. Familiarity is related to biases that decrease accuracy and knowledge that increases accuracy.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec12_3_1_6">
<title>Suspicion</title>
<p>According to interpersonal deception theory (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_18">Buller, Stiff, &#x0026; Burgoon, 1996</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_16">Burgoon &#x0026; Buller, 2004</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_21">2008</xref>), as a deceptive interaction is unfolding, people may become suspicious of being lied to and, in turn, may behave in certain ways because of it. In some cases, they may hide their suspiciousness. For example, at least two studies show that when we suspect that someone is lying to us, we alter our behavior so we don&#x2019;t look suspicious (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_19">Buller, Strzyzewski, &#x0026; Comstock, 1991</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_23">Burgoon, Buller, Dillman, &#x0026; Walther, 1995</xref>). Specifically, suspicious people tend to use shorter responses, take longer to answer, and manage their body movements more. In other situations, however, our behaviors may reveal our suspicion and, in turn, may affect our partner&#x2019;s behavior. Indeed, if someone who is lying to us thinks we are suspicious, the liar may try even harder to be convincing. Previous research has supported this notion, demonstrating that deceivers&#x2019; verbal and nonverbal behavior changes during the course of interactions, often becoming indistinguishable from truthful behavior well into the interaction (see, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_16">Burgoon &#x0026; Buller, 2004</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_22">Burgoon &#x0026; Qin, 2006</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_115">White &#x0026; Burgoon, 2001</xref>). On the other hand, one study found that interviewers who <target target-type="page" id="page_299">299</target>displayed a supportive demeanor during an interrogation encouraged truth tellers, but not liars, to provide more details (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_81">Mann et al., 2013</xref>).</p>
<p>Although it is apparent that suspiciousness plays a role in both senders&#x2019; and receivers&#x2019; behaviors, does it affect people&#x2019;s ability to judge veracity? Research suggests the answer to this question is no. In other words, there appears to be a weak relationship between suspicion and the ability to discriminate lies from truths. To help understand why, imagine that a person is making a number of statements and you are trying to decide which of the statements are true and which are false. The <italic>opposing effects model</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_60">Kim &#x0026; Levine, 2011</xref>) suggests that suspicion decreases the truth bias. As such, being suspicious makes you more accurate when judging lies and less accurate when judging truths. Such opposing effects cancel each other out, making little difference in your overall ability to tell truths from lies. In short, suspicion helps you spot lies but misjudge truths.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec12_3_1_7">
<title>Probing and Deception Detection</title>
<p>In the previous section we learned that when trying to detect deception, people sometimes try to alter their behavior so they don&#x2019;t look suspicious. But sometimes, probing a potential liar for more information may be necessary. To be sure, if a liar won&#x2019;t talk, it&#x2019;s difficult to find contradictions or inconsistencies in his or her story. Interestingly, however, most research indicates that probing suspects for more information (e.g., &#x201C;Tell me more about where you were when the book bag was stolen&#x201D;) does <italic>not</italic> increase the accuracy with which you can detect that suspect&#x2019;s deception (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_19">Buller et al., 1991</xref>). Perhaps even more interesting is the fact that probing a suspect for more information causes third parties to perceive the suspect as more honest (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_19">Buller et al., 1991</xref>). This phenomenon has been called the <italic>probing effect</italic> by those who study deception (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_69">Levine &#x0026; McCornack, 1996a</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_70">1996b</xref>).</p>
<p>Although scholars agree that the probing effect occurs, there is some disagreement on what causes it. (For a more detailed debate, see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_18">Buller, Stiff, &#x0026; Burgoon, 1996</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_69">Levine &#x0026; McCornack, 1996a</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_70">1996b</xref>.) For instance, several authors argue in favor of the <italic>behavioral adaptation explanation,</italic> which in a nutshell asserts that when probing occurs, liars realize they are suspected of lying and alter their behavior to be more believable. Levine and McCornack (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_69">1996a</xref>), however, assert that this explanation is flawed and in one study found evidence that contradicts it (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_71">Levine &#x0026; McCornack, 2001</xref>). In the study, liars were videotaped being probed. Afterward, research participants watched one of two versions of the videotaped liars. Both versions showed exactly the same footage of the liars, but one had the probes edited out. Interestingly, participants who watched the videos in which probes were deleted perceived liars to be significantly less honest than those who saw the probed liars. Thus, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_71">Levine and McCornack (2001)</xref> showed that the probing effect occurred, but not because liars changed their behaviors.</p>
<p>What, then, is responsible for the probing effect? According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_71">Levine and McCornack (2001)</xref>, when trying to tell if someone is lying, judges often rely on shortcuts rather than on scrutinizing the behavior of the suspect. One shortcut judges rely on is called the <italic>probing heuristic</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_71">Levine &#x0026; McCornack, 2001</xref>). Here&#x2019;s how it works. Imagine you&#x2019;re watching a suspect and trying to decide if he or she is lying or telling the truth. Also imagine that the suspect is being probed. Rather than scrutinize the suspect&#x2019;s words and behaviors, you use a shortcut. Specifically, you think to <target target-type="page" id="page_300">300</target>yourself: &#x201C;It&#x2019;s mighty difficult and nerve racking to lie while being probed, so, given the choice, people being probed will choose to tell the truth.&#x201D; Based on such thinking, you decide that people being probed are also being honest. Your judgment has nothing to do with the suspect&#x2019;s behavioral adaptation but rather a simple shortcut that saves you the effort of scrutinizing the suspect&#x2019;s behavior (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_71">Levine &#x0026; McCornack, 2001</xref>).</p>
<p>Before concluding this section, we should note that others have questioned whether behavioral adaptation happens. For example, in contrast to behavioral adaptation, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_36">Ekman (1985)</xref> suggests that an opposite phenomenon may occur: When suspected of deceit, a <italic>truthful</italic> communicator may become anxious. This, in turn, may cause a detector to commit what Ekman calls the <italic>Othello error&#x2014;</italic>that is, the detector wrongly assumes that the anxious behavior is indicative of deception. A study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_55">Henningsen, Cruz, and Morr (2000)</xref> supported this notion by finding that people who were perceived as nervous were also perceived as deceptive.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec12_3_1_8">
<title>Eliciting Cues to Deception: Puttin&#x2019; the Squeeze On</title>
<p>Earlier in this chapter, we suggested that one possible way to improve deception detection is by training people to spot reliable cues to deception. A second, and, according to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_51">Hartwig and Bond (2011)</xref>, perhaps more promising strategy, is less passive in nature. Specifically, rather than simply observing a person&#x2019;s verbal and nonverbal cues, this approach actively attempts to increase behavioral differences between liars and truth tellers, thereby making them easier to distinguish from one another. Let&#x2019;s examine two techniques for doing so.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec12_3_1_9">
<title>The Imposing-Cognitive Load Approach: Too Much to Think About</title>
<p>The <italic>imposing-cognitive load approach</italic> (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_112">Vrij et al., 2011</xref>) is based on the assumption that lying is more mentally taxing than telling the truth (see above). As such, if you increase cognitive demands further, liars, who have fewer cognitive resources, will struggle more than truth tellers. By way of example, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_113">Vrij, Mann, Fisher, Leal, Milne, and Bull (2008)</xref> asked liars and truth tellers to provide an account in either chronological or reverse chronological order. It turns out that liars who told the story backward were more detectable than those who told it from front to back, presumably because of increased cognitive load. Another study found that describing an event in different ways (i.e., verbally and pictorially) was more difficult for liars than for truth tellers. As such, liars were less consistent between descriptions (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_63">Leins, Fisher, &#x0026; Vrij, 2012</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec12_3_1_10">
<title>Strategic Questioning: Designed to Trip You Up</title>
<p>A second approach suggests that specific types of interrogation questions may be particularly useful for detecting deceit. Consider, for example, the <italic>strategic use of evidence (SUE) technique</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_48">Granhag &#x0026; Hartwig, 2008</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_53">Hartwig et al., 2005</xref>). In it, interrogators who possess certain evidence about a case do not reveal that evidence, hoping instead that suspects will say something to contradict it. Later, the interrogator pounces, revealing the evidence and asking the suspect to explain the contradiction. Recent research indicates that revealing evidence late in the interrogation, rather than early or gradually, is most effective. Indeed, revealing evidence early or gradually <target target-type="page" id="page_301">301</target>allows a suspect to adapt. What&#x2019;s more, revealing evidence gradually causes innocent suspects to appear guilty (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_105">Sorochinski, Hartwig, Osborne, Wilkins, Marsh, Kazakov, &#x0026; Granhag, 2014</xref>).</p>
<p>A compatible approach suggests that deception detectors are more accurate when they consider <italic>context-sensitive information</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_66">Levine, Blair, and Clare, 2014</xref>). To illustrate, imagine that a middle-aged woman whom you know nothing about has just told you Nutrageous bars are her favorite type of candy. And then imagine a tiny, 5-year-old girl tells you that she has just been signed as the new quarterback for the Denver Broncos, her favorite football team. Assuming both people are lying, which would be easier to detect? Obviously, if you know anything about the typical size and demographics of professional football players, the little girl should be easier to detect. Indeed, according to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_6">Blair, Levine, and Shaw (2010)</xref>, when given meaningful information about context (e.g., professional football players are usually large males), the typical 50 percent detection rates we told you about at the beginning of this chapter increase drastically.</p>
<p>In fact, one series of studies (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_66">Levine et al., 2014</xref>) increased accuracy rates to over 70 percent! In the studies, students tried to win cash prizes while playing a trivia game with a teammate. Unbeknown to the students, however, their teammates were really part of the study. What&#x2019;s more, the teammates encouraged the students to cheat, which many of them did. Later, the students were interrogated using several questions that were strategically designed to garner diagnostically useful information about whether they were lying or telling the truth. For example:
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p>&#x201C;When I interview your partner, what will they say about cheating?&#x201D; (The rationale for asking this question: Liars, compared to truth tellers, should be less confident that their teammates will exonerate them).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x201C;For the answers you got right, explain how you got the right answer?&#x201D; (Rationale: Cheaters, compared to noncheaters, should feel the need to justify their performance).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>&#x201C;If someone did cheat, what should happen to them?&#x201D; (Rationale: Cheaters, compared to noncheaters, should be more likely to suggest leniency).</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
<p>Given such research, it is clear that interrogation strategies can be vital when trying to detect deception.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec12_4">
<title>Summary</title>
<p>Deception is a multifaceted and complex communication phenomenon that has been broadly conceptualized. In this chapter we explored some of these conceptualizations. We also learned that although people are not very good at detecting deception, some factors improve their accuracy. Other factors (e.g., the truth bias), however, can impede detection accuracy. We also examined some of the behaviors that distinguish truthful from deceptive individuals and some of the frameworks that explain such differences. Finally, we discussed various approaches for eliciting cues to deception.</p>
</sec>
</body>
<back>
<fn-group>
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_302">302</target>Notes</title>
<fn id="fn12_1"><label>1</label><p>Although there are two versions of information manipulation theory, for our purposes, we treat them as one.</p></fn>
<fn id="fn12_2"><label>2</label><p>Results of research on inter- and intra-ethnic deception detection are mixed. Though the two studies already mentioned (i.e., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_3">Al-Simadi, 2000</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_101">Seiter &#x0026; Wiseman, 1995</xref>) found that interethnic detection is more accurate than intraethnic detection, other studies have found the opposite (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_7">Bond &#x0026; Atoum, 2000</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref12_10">Bond, Omar, Mahmoud, &#x0026; Bosner, 1990</xref>).</p></fn>
</fn-group>
