<book-part-meta>
<title-group>
<label>13</label>
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_309">309</target>Motivational Appeals</title>
<alt-title alt-title-type="running-head">Motivational Appeals</alt-title>
</title-group>
<contrib-group>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Gass</surname>
<given-names>Robert H.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Seiter</surname>
<given-names>John S.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
</contrib-group>
</book-part-meta>
<body>
<p>IF REAL LIFE WERE A CARTOON, the salesperson who showed up at the home of one of the authors could have been Elmer Fudd. The author needed rain gutters on his house. On the advice of a neighbor, he contacted a company located a good 40 miles from where he lived to come out and provide an estimate. The salesperson, a paunchy fellow in his mid-40s, arrived in a beat-up clunker. He looked tired and disheveled as he got out. He fumbled with his clipboard, calculator, and an armload of gutter samples as he made his way up the sidewalk.</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_310">310</target>&#x201C;Find the place okay?&#x201D; the author asked.</p>
<p>&#x201C;The diwections wuh gweat,&#x201D; the salesperson answered, &#x201C;but the twaffic was tewwible, and I got a ticket on the way.&#x201D;</p>
<p>&#x201C;That&#x2019;s too bad,&#x201D; the author replied.</p>
<p>&#x201C;I didn&#x2019;t have my seat belt on,&#x201D; the salesperson lamented, &#x201C;because it&#x2019;s bwoken, and it costs &#x0024;300 to fix. I can&#x2019;t affawd it wight now.&#x201D;</p>
<p>Owing to the salesperson&#x2019;s unkempt appearance, his speech impediment, and his sad tale, the author felt sympathetic. Even though the salesperson&#x2019;s estimate was slightly higher than those of several local businesses, the author signed a contract. How could he do otherwise? The salesperson had come all that way&#x2014;risked his life, in fact&#x2014;to provide an estimate. He&#x2019;d gotten a ticket for his trouble. The way the author saw it, the difference in the salesperson&#x2019;s price from that of the local competitors was probably less than the cost of the ticket. And the guy obviously needed the sale.</p>
<p>Or did he? After the salesperson drove away, the author began wondering if it were all a ruse. What if the salesperson told every potential customer he&#x2019;d gotten a ticket? What if his seat belt worked just fine? What if he faked or exaggerated the speech problem to elicit sympathy and help make the sale? The author never did find out whether the &#x201C;sad sack&#x201D; character was genuine or a guise, but the rain gutters have worked splendidly.</p>
<p>Whether the salesperson&#x2019;s strategy was honest or not, it&#x2019;s clear that his success was based, to a large extent, on pity. His sad story plucked at the author&#x2019;s heartstrings. And in the end, the author was willing to pay more because he felt sorry for the fellow. The salesperson&#x2019;s appeal to pity, if it were designed as such, represents but one example of a <italic>motivational appeal,</italic> the topic of this chapter. Motivational appeals may be generally defined as external inducements, often of an emotional nature, that are designed to increase an individual&#x2019;s drive to undertake some course of action. By external inducements, we mean incentives that exist apart from the substance of a message itself. Such external inducements typically seek to alter people&#x2019;s moods, feelings, or emotions as a means of persuasion.</p>
<sec id="sec13_1">
<title>Intrinsic Versus Extrinsic Motivation</title>
<p>Motivational appeals can be thought of as attempts to jump-start an individual&#x2019;s drive to do something. They provide an external incentive for performing some action. <italic>Intrinsic motivation</italic> is drive that comes from within (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_31">Deci, 1975</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_32">Deci &#x0026; Ryan, 1978</xref>). If you &#x201C;live to work,&#x201D; your motivation for doing your job is internal. <italic>Extrinsic motivation</italic> is instilled by some outside factor (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_92">Petri, 1991</xref>). If you &#x201C;work to live,&#x201D; your motivation for going to work each day is external. All the motivational appeals we discuss here can be thought of as extrinsic in nature. Motivational appeals are found everywhere. Daily entreaties include anxiety, fear, guilt, health, honor, humor, patriotism, pity, pride, sex, warmth, and more. One might be tempted to think that all emotional appeals are ethically suspect. However, as Corbett and Conners (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_29">1999</xref>) advise, &#x201C;there is nothing necessarily reprehensible about being moved to action through emotion; in fact, it is perfectly normal&#x201D; (p. 206). We begin with an examination of emotional appeals in marketing.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec13_2">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_311">311</target>Emotion and Persuasion: Oh, What A Feeling!</title>
<sec id="sec13_2_1">
<title>Emotions and the ELM</title>
<p>Emotions tend to exert more influence when receivers rely on peripheral processing, as opposed to central processing (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_51">Greifeneder, Bless, &#x0026; Pham, 2011</xref>). However, central processing and peripheral processing can coexist, a phenomenon known as <italic>parallel processing</italic>. A patient, for example, might perceive that her doctor was offering rational arguments for taking her medication and demonstrating empathy for her as well.</p>
<p>Emotions sometimes precede thinking. In such cases, a person&#x2019;s emotional state may bias subsequent thinking (Petty &#x0026; Bri&#x00F1;ol, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_93">2015</xref>). For example, if an art patron were in a foul mood before attending an art exhibit, the patron might decide the display was &#x201C;a pile of rubbish&#x201D; and the artist was a &#x201C;buffoon.&#x201D; Sometimes emotions follow thinking, in which case they tend to validate the thought process used (Petty &#x0026; Bri&#x00F1;ol, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_93">2015</xref>). For instance, a traveler who planned a trip carefully, might become elated as the date of departure neared.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec13_2_2">
<title>Emotional Marketing</title>
<p>Marketers often design ad campaigns to elicit emotions such as fear, love, and regret in consumers (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_6">Achar, So, Agrawal, &#x0026; Duhachek, 2016</xref>). According to <italic>attachment theory</italic>, people develop emotional ties to specific brands (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_113">Thomson, MacInnis, &#x0026; Park, 2005</xref>). Apple products are a case in point. Mac, iPhone, and iPad owners share an emotional connection with their devices unlike that of their counterparts who use non-Apple products. Such emotional attachments enable marketers to engage consumers, making them passionate about, and loyal to, their brands.</p>
<p>In an episode of the popular television series <italic>Mad Men</italic>, advertising guru Don Draper clearly grasps this concept. His clients, from Kodak, want Draper to create an ad campaign that touts the technology of the new &#x201C;wheel&#x201D; on their slide projector. Draper advises them to drop the &#x201C;glittering lure&#x201D; of technology and establish a deeper emotional connection with consumers. Nostalgia, Draper stresses, is the key.</p>
<disp-quote>
<p>In Greek, nostalgia literally means the pain from an old wound. A twinge in your heart, far more powerful than memory alone. This device &#x2026; is a time machine. It goes backwards and forwards. It takes us to a place where we ache to go again. It&#x2019;s not called the wheel. It&#x2019;s called the carousel. It lets us travel the way a child travels. Around and around and back home again. To a place where we know we are loved.</p>
<attrib>(<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_123">Weiner &#x0026; Veith, 2007</xref>)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
<p>His pitch invokes the nostalgia he wants consumers to feel. The concept of a carousel establishes a sentimental bond between the consumer and the product.</p>
<p>Don Draper isn&#x2019;t the only one who understands the power of emotional marketing. Persuaders in the real world have acknowledged the effectiveness of motivational appeals for years. Traditional thinking on this topic suggested that such appeals are effective in some contexts but not in others. Specifically, traditionalists suggested that decisions, such as buying gasoline, a microwave, or detergent are more <italic>utilitarian</italic> in <target target-type="page" id="page_312">312</target>nature and are prompted by practical concerns (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_12">Babin, Darden, &#x0026; Griffin, 1994</xref>). Other decisions, such as purchasing clothing or music, are more <italic>hedonic</italic> in nature and are driven more by pleasure seeking (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_68">Khan, Dhar, &#x0026; Wertenbroch, 2005</xref>). Some decisions, like buying a car, are a mixture of both. A two-seater convertible may seem fun, but what if there are five people in the family?</p>
<p>More recently, however, thinking has shifted in favor of a greater role for emotion compared to reason. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_78">Livingston (2007)</xref>, for instance, argued that &#x201C;people buy for emotional reasons, and then justify their purchases with logic&#x201D; (p. 16). By way of example, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_7">Adler, Iacobelli, and Gutstein (2016)</xref> found that positive emotional appeals outperformed positive rational appeals in an online persuasion context. Similarly, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_45">Geuens, De Pelsmacker, and Faseur (2011)</xref> found that emotional ads outperformed nonemotional ads for both hedonic <italic>and</italic> utilitarian products. Some go so far as to say that all consumer purchases are dictated by emotion rather than reason (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_96">Robinette &#x0026; Brand, 2001</xref>).</p>
<p>While we agree that emotions play an important role in persuasion, we don&#x2019;t believe that emotions rule all our decisions. A wealth of studies show that highly involved receivers favor high-quality arguments and evidence, or what <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_94">Petty and Cacioppo (1986)</xref> call <italic>central processing</italic>. What&#x2019;s more, the distinction between logic and emotion is not altogether clear, as we point out next.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec13_3">
<title>Logical and Emotional Appeals: A Fuzzy Distinction</title>
<p>People often think of &#x201C;logical&#x201D; and &#x201C;emotional&#x201D; appeals as opposites. This distinction dates back to Aristotle, who classified <italic>logos</italic> (logic, reasoning) and <italic>pathos</italic> (passion, emotion) as separate, distinct forms of influence (Aristotle, trans. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_11">1932</xref>). This way of thinking, however, represents something of an artificial dichotomy. Whether a message is perceived as logical or emotional has as much to do with the person <italic>perceiving</italic> the message as it does with the message itself (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_14">Becker, 1963</xref>). In fact, researchers (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_41">Evans, Barston, &#x0026; Pollard, 1983</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_89">Oakhill &#x0026; Garnham, 1993</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_95">Reuchelle, 1958</xref>) have learned that when people agree with a message, they tend to perceive it as being more logical or rational in nature. When they disagree with a message, they tend to think of it as being more emotional in nature.</p>
<p>In an advertising context, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_8">Akbari (2015)</xref> found that rational appeals were more effective for low-involvement products (sunscreen), while emotional appeals were more effective for high-involvement products (laptops). This finding was borne out in a meta-analysis (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_60">Hornik, Ofir, &#x0026; Rachamim, 2016</xref>) that showed emotional appeals are generally more effective than rational appeals. In addition, positive emotional appeals (humor, for example) were generally more effective than negative appeals (fear, guilt). Purely emotional ads, however, may capture consumers&#x2019; attention, without persuading them.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec13_4">
<title>Fear Appeals: If You Don&#x2019;t Stop Doing that, You&#x2019;ll Go Blind</title>
<p>&#x201C;If you cross your eyes, they&#x2019;ll stay that way.&#x201D; &#x201C;Don&#x2019;t run with scissors, you&#x2019;ll poke your eye out.&#x201D; &#x201C;Don&#x2019;t stuff beans up your nose, they&#x2019;ll sprout.&#x201D; What child hasn&#x2019;t heard these or similar admonitions from a parent? When he was a little tyke, one of <target target-type="page" id="page_313">313</target>the authors put beans up his nose anyway. While having them removed at the doctor&#x2019;s office, he had to endure his mother&#x2019;s &#x201C;I told you so&#x201D; lecture.</p>
<p>Fear appeals are not only a staple of child-rearing, they are also prevalent in the workplace, in public health messages, advertising, and elsewhere. Advertisements for dandruff shampoos, deodorants, mouthwashes, and acne medications, for example, are often predicated on the fear of social ostracism. Pharmaceutical ads tell us to ask our doctor if a new prescription pill is right for us. Then those ads go on to describe a litany of side effects that sound worse than the original illness.</p>
<p>Some commentators charge that America has become a culture based on fear (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_9">Altheide, 2002</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_43">Gardner, 2009</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_46">Glassner, 1999</xref>). Whether to sell products, garner votes, or increase ratings, persuaders use scare tactics to increase our anxiety about all sorts of things. We&#x2019;re afraid of exotic diseases such as Ebola, mad cow, and West Nile. We stress out about school shootings, child abductions, homeland security, and road rage. The world is a scary place.</p>
<p>When designed properly, fear appeals can be highly effective. Reviews of the fear appeal literature have shown that inducing fear can bring about changes in attitudes, intentions, and behavior (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_19">Boster &#x0026; Mongeau, 1984</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_26">Cho &#x0026; Witte, 2004</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_58">Higbee, 1969</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_84">Mongeau, 1998</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_97">Ruiter, Abraham, &#x0026; Kok, 2001</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_110">Sutton, 1982</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_130">Witte &#x0026; Allen, 2000</xref>). But how and when do fear appeals work best? Two well-known models explain. We discuss these next.</p>
<sec id="sec13_4_1">
<title>The Stage Model: Scared Stiff</title>
<p>Natascha de Hoog and her colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_33">2007</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_34">2008</xref>) developed a dual process model, known as the <italic>stage model</italic>, that explains how fear level or intensity works. According to the model, when a person is exposed to a fear-arousing message, the person engages in <italic>threat appraisal</italic> to assess the <italic>perceived severity</italic> of the threat and her or his <italic>perceived vulnerability</italic> to the threat. The stage model posits four possible threat conditions, based on the combination of low versus high severity and low versus high vulnerability to a threat (see <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig13_1">Figure 13.1</xref>).</p>
<fig id="fig13_1" position="float">
<label>Figure 13.1</label>
<caption><title>Stage model of fear-arousing communication.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig13_1.tif"/>
</fig>
<p>If both severity and vulnerability are seen as low, a person will tend to ignore the threat or rely on peripheral processing. For example, Simone, who lives in Manhattan, might know that bee stings hurt (mild severity), but if she&#x2019;s not allergic to them and doesn&#x2019;t spend much time trekking in meadows (low vulnerability), she might think, &#x201C;No big deal. I&#x2019;ll worry about it if it happens.&#x201D;</p>
<p>If a person perceives that a threat is severe, but vulnerability is low, the person will engage in moderate cognitive processing, mostly to make sure that the threat is assessed accurately. For example, Dieter, who lives in Stuttgart, might believe that Ebola is a deadly disease (high severity), but that there is little or no risk of contracting it in Germany (low vulnerability). He might be motivated to support eradication efforts in Africa, though, and health screening to prevent travelers from infected areas entering Germany. A converse scenario, with low severity, but high vulnerability, would also prompt moderate central processing. For example, Dieter is mindful of pickpockets on public transit, so he holds his backpack on his lap.</p>
<p>When perceived severity and perceived vulnerability are both high, <italic>defense motivation</italic> kicks in and the person utilizes central processing (see <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig13_1">Figure 13.1</xref>). Under defense motivation, a person actively scrutinizes the message and evaluates strategies for minimizing the harm. For example, suppose Alain lives in Nice, which was the <target target-type="page" id="page_314">314</target>target of a horrific terrorist attack in 2016. In that incident, a truck plowed into a crowd on Bastille day killing 86 people and injuring 434 more. As a resident of the French city, Alain might perceive that he and other residents are highly vulnerable to another deadly attack. In the high-severity/high-vulnerability condition, the person would examine the message carefully, not just to be clear about the threat, but to identify specific strategies for avoiding or minimizing the threat. The latter process is referred to as <italic>coping appraisal</italic>.</p>
<p>A person using coping appraisal would ask &#x201C;What can I do to avoid having this happen to me?&#x201D; In Alain&#x2019;s case, he would likely assess ways of reducing his risk during another attack. He could, of course, move to another city that is less likely to be targeted. He could also avoid places where large crowds congregate. &#x201C;Why make myself a target?&#x201D; he might reason. He might be vigilant about possible methods of attack; explosives, assault weapons, or vehicle ramming. He might increase his situational awareness by noting exits or avenues of escape in case of an emergency. He might still drink coffee at outdoor caf&#x00E9;s, but not sit street side or near glass windows.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec13_4_2">
<title>The Extended Parallel Process Model: Nothing to Fear but Fear Itself</title>
<p>When are people likely to use coping strategies? When are they more likely to panic? Although the stage model excels at explaining how threat level or intensity functions, we think another model is better at explaining how people actually respond to threats. Kim Witte&#x2019;s <italic>extended parallel processing model</italic> (EPPM) addresses these concerns (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_82">Maloney, Lapinski, &#x0026; Witte, 2011</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_128">Witte, 1992</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_129">1994</xref>). According to the model, when a person encounters a fear-arousing message, the person can respond in one of three ways. Let&#x2019;s say a Japanese student, Mayumi, is thinking of visiting South Africa. Her friends, however, have expressed concerns about contracting a disease there. First, she might ignore the message altogether, believing she is not at risk. Mayumi might think to herself, &#x201C;I&#x2019;ve traveled a lot and I&#x2019;ve never gotten seriously ill.&#x201D;</p>
<p>Second, if Mayumi perceives that she is at risk, she can try to avoid the danger. She would use <italic>danger control</italic>, by focusing on constructive ways of preventing or minimizing the threat. For example, there are vaccines that prevent hepatitis A and typhoid, two diseases that are found in South Africa. Malaria is also a risk, so she might wear insect repellent or avoid being outdoors at night.</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_315">315</target>Third, Mayumi might fixate on her fear, which is a non-constructive response known as <italic>fear control</italic>. Fear control essentially involves &#x201C;worrying about worry.&#x201D; Such a reaction can result in panic. If she decided to visit South Africa anyway, but spent every moment riddled with fear, she would be engaged in fear control.</p>
<p>In the EPPM, danger control is a far more effective response because it focuses on the solution. Fear control, conversely, is counterproductive because it focuses on managing one&#x2019;s fear. A persuader&#x2019;s goal in using fear appeals, then, should be to arouse fear in a manner that triggers danger control rather than fear control.</p>
<p>Returning to our example, for danger control to occur, Mayumi must believe there is a clear course of action that she can take to avoid the threat. This element of the EPPM is called <italic>perceived efficacy</italic>. Perceived efficacy has two components. The first, <italic>response efficacy</italic>, has to do with whether there are effective steps for avoiding the harm. For example, Mayumi might reason that by staying current on immunizations and taking reasonable precautions, she can avoid contracting a disease. The second, <italic>self-efficacy</italic>, has to do with whether she, personally, is capable of taking those steps. If Mayumi is allergic to some vaccines, or she will be visiting rural areas with no potable water, or she will be sleeping outdoors at night, she may not believe she can avoid hepatitis A, typhoid, or malaria.</p>
<p>Both response efficacy and self-efficacy are important components of perceived efficacy. If both are present, a person is more likely to engage in danger control. If either is missing, the person is more likely to resort to fear control. Indeed, a meta-analysis (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_23">Casey, Timmermann, Allen, Krahn, &#x0026; Turkiewicz, 2009</xref>) demonstrated this very result: High-response efficacy and self-efficacy correlated significantly with greater condom use. At the point where &#x201C;perceptions of threat begin to outweigh perceptions of efficacy &#x2026; people begin to shift from danger control to fear control&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_82">Maloney, Lapinski, &#x0026; Witte, 2011</xref>, p. 210).</p>
<p>According to the stage model, then, fear appeals that heighten the perceived severity of, and vulnerability to, a threat, are most likely to succeed. According to the EPPM, identifying specific actions, that the target audience can perform, is essential too. An excellent summary of fear&#x2019;s effectiveness based on these and other models was provided by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_112">Tannenbaum, Hepler, Zimmerman, Saul, Jacobs, Wilson, and Albarracin (2015)</xref>. After reviewing 128 different studies on fear appeals, they concluded, &#x201C;fear appeals are particularly effective when the communication depicts relatively high amounts of fear, includes an efficacy message, stresses severity and susceptibility, recommends one-time only behaviors, and targets audiences that include a larger percentage of female message recipients&#x201D; (p. 1198).</p>
<p>We would be remiss if we didn&#x2019;t acknowledge that there are serious ethical concerns surrounding the use of fear appeals. We address these in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter16">Chapter 16</xref>. For the time being, suffice it to say that a persuader should exercise caution in using fear appeals. Nevertheless, if the harmful consequences are real or genuine, we would suggest it is not only acceptable for a persuader to employ fear appeals, but also that the persuader has an obligation to use them.</p>
<p>The beans, by the way, did not sprout.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec13_5">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_316">316</target>Negative Emotions: Woe Is Me, Shame On You</title>
<p>Persuaders often seek to stir negative emotions in people. Pity, guilt, and shame are three such negative emotions that can be leveraged to a persuader&#x2019;s advantage. Appeals involving these emotions are often interrelated. Becheur and Valette-Florence (2014), for example, found that a combination of guilt and shame was more effective than guilt alone in persuading young people, ages 18&#x2013;25, to limit their alcohol consumption. As another example, charitable organizations regularly air television spots portraying starving children or abused pets. The ads induce pity for the kids or animals and guilt in viewers for not donating. &#x201C;For just a few cents per day,&#x201D; the ads claim, &#x201C;you can make a difference.&#x201D; Is it possible for nonprofits to use a different approach? Absent pity ploys, guilt trips, and shaming, will people still donate?</p>
<p>One study suggests it may not be possible to have it both ways. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_37">Eayres and Ellis (1990)</xref> asked males and females to evaluate 10 posters for charitable causes that used different appeals. Some posters depicted people with mental disabilities in a negative light (dependent, incapable), whereas others portrayed them in a positive light (valued, capable). The researchers found that the negative depictions were most likely to induce participants to donate money. Participants were less likely to donate if the posters featured positive portrayals. As the researchers noted, &#x201C;this tends to validate the supposition that in order to produce a successful poster in charity terms it is necessary to play on people&#x2019;s feelings of guilt and pity&#x201D; (p. 356). Interestingly, the participants were more willing to become actively involved in, and donate time to, charitable causes that were featured positively in the posters. This bodes well for charities seeking increased voluntarism, but not for ones seeking monetary contributions.</p>
<p>On the subject of guilt itself, some researchers have found that invoking feelings of guilt in another person can facilitate compliance (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_90">O&#x2019;Keefe, 2002</xref>). Inducing guilt made people more likely to comply with a subsequent request (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_42">Freedman, Wallington, &#x0026; Bless, 1967</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_57">Hibbert, Smith, Davies, &#x0026; Ireland, 2007</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_76">Lindsey, 2005</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_77">Lindsey, Yun, &#x0026; Hill, 2007</xref>). Surprisingly, they were more likely to comply even if the person making the request, or the person benefiting from the request, was not the source of their guilt. However, other research (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_16">Bessarabova, Turner, Fink, &#x0026; Blustein, 2015</xref>) found that inducing guilt can be counterproductive. Stronger guilt appeals may produce <italic>psychological reactance</italic>, which refers to resistance to a perceived threat to one&#x2019;s freedom. According to Bessarabova et al., internally generated guilt is more effective than externally induced guilt.</p>
<p>A second caution regarding guilt appeals is that the target of the appeal may seek to avoid further interaction with the source, to avoid further embarrassment or minimize the risk of a confrontation. Guilt appeals should, therefore, be designed to emphasize the positive self-feelings that come from doing the right thing, rather than focusing on further loss of face.</p>
<p>There is a dark side to guilt appeals as well. Unscrupulous persuaders can use guilt appeals to extract money from people who are in mourning, as we point out in <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box13_1">Box 13.1</xref>.</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_317">317</target>Along the same lines, several investigations have examined people&#x2019;s emotional reactions to others who possess varying maladies or stigmas. How people react to others&#x2019; stigmas (obesity, paraplegia, blindness, AIDS, etc.) depends on the causal inferences they make about those stigmas (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_18">Blaine &#x0026; Williams, 2004</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_124">Weiner, Perry, &#x0026; Magnusson, 1988</xref>). For example, these researchers analyzed college students&#x2019; emotional reactions to people with varying stigmas (obesity, drug addiction, etc.), based on how controllable the students thought the stigma was. Students expressed more feelings of guilt and sympathy if the stigma was uncontrollable (e.g., obesity ascribed to a glandular dysfunction) and more feelings of anger and reluctance to help if the stigma was controllable (e.g., obesity due to overeating). Thus, persuaders seeking to use emotional appeals such as pity or guilt for fundraising or other purposes need to ensure that the beneficiaries are <italic>not</italic> perceived as having a physical or social malady that they brought on themselves.</p>
<boxed-text id="box13_1">
<label><target target-type="page" id="page_318">318</target>Box 13.1</label>
<caption><title>Funeral Home Persuasion</title></caption>
<p>&#x201C;You can&#x2019;t take it with you &#x2026; but you don&#x2019;t have to give it all to the mortuary!&#x201D;</p>
<p>Funerals are expensive. In the USA the price of a typical funeral is &#x0024;8,000-11,000 (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_83">Miller, 2016</xref>, <uri>www.parting.com</uri>). A funeral is a &#x201C;distress purchase&#x201D; that is often made under emotional duress. Unfortunately, consumers are quite naive about funeral home practices. What&#x2019;s more, the process of negotiating the price of a funeral comes at the worst possible time: when thinking is impaired by the loss of a loved one. We may feel it is crass to engage in hard bargaining over prices (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_44">Gentry, Kennedy, Paul, &#x0026; Hill, 1995</xref>), but this is exactly why some unscrupulous funeral home directors try to take advantage of us. They know that a person who is grieving is an easy mark.</p>
<p>Not all, or even most, mortuaries prey on those who are grieving, but some clearly do (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_118">Wasik, 1995</xref>). To increase your consumer awareness, and to arm you against the unscrupulous practices employed by some funeral homes, we offer the following list of dos and don&#x2019;ts when making funeral arrangements. The suggestions apply to a traditional burial. If cremation, burial at sea, or some other option is chosen, not all the suggestions will apply.</p>
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p>Do try to be as rational as possible. Grieve for the deceased with all your heart, but negotiate the price of the funeral with your head. A funeral home is a for-profit enterprise. You need to be a savvy consumer when negotiating the arrangements and the price.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Don&#x2019;t give in to guilt appeals, such as &#x201C;Don&#x2019;t you think he/she deserves genuine brass handles on his/her coffin?&#x201D; The amount you love someone isn&#x2019;t measured by the amount you spend on that person&#x2019;s funeral. You can always spend more on that person later. For example, you could make a donation in the deceased&#x2019;s name to a worthwhile charity or social cause.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Do conduct price comparisons, just as you would when buying a car or making any other major purchase. Websites such as Parting.com and FuneralDecision.com allow consumers to shop online. Telephone mortuaries and ask for quotes over the phone. The FTC now requires funeral homes to provide prices by phone. Ask what a complete funeral would cost, including embalming, casket, burial, flowers, and so on. If you don&#x2019;t feel up to making the calls, ask a trusted friend.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Do ensure that everything you are promised is itemized in writing. The FTC now requires mortuaries to provide itemized prices. Don&#x2019;t take the funeral director&#x2019;s word for it if he or she says, &#x201C;leave it to us, we&#x2019;ll take care of everything.&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Do shop around for prices on caskets. Funeral homes mark up casket prices astronomically. You can save thousands of dollars by purchasing a casket factory-direct from a manufacturer, or even Costco, and having it delivered to the funeral home. Federal law requires funeral homes to accept a casket purchased elsewhere and prohibits the imposition of &#x201C;handling fees.&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Don&#x2019;t pay for unnecessary frills. Rather than paying for brass handles, silk ruffles, or carved wood panels, consider personalizing the casket with family photos, poetry, or artwork. Decide what is within your budget and have the funeral director accommodate your needs. If the price isn&#x2019;t right, use outside vendors to provide additional services.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Don&#x2019;t pay more than you must for basic services. These include transporting the remains, embalming, a casket, interment, and a plot. Try calling around to see if the same services can be obtained more cheaply elsewhere. Cremation is a cheaper option than burial (no casket required, no plot or mausoleum, no gravestone or marker). To learn about what fees funeral homes may and may not charge legally, see <uri>www.consumer.ftc.gov/articles/0301-funeral-costs-and-pricing-checklist</uri></p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Don&#x2019;t prepay for a plot, casket, or other services without discussing the contract with an attorney or accountant. Prepaid plans might seem like a good idea, but most consumer groups advise against them. If you change your mind about where you want to be buried, or how you want to be disposed of, it may be impossible to alter the contract or obtain a refund. You also lose the potential interest your money could earn in a bank account (see item 10).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Do consider opening a &#x201C;Totten&#x201D; trust, a payable on-demand account at a bank or savings institution for the cost of a funeral. The trust is revocable, so it can be moved, altered, or closed completely (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_62">Jaffe, 1996</xref>).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Do make use of helpful information sources. You can locate excellent advice and information on planning a funeral at <uri>www.funerals.org</uri>, <uri>www.clarkhoward.com</uri></p></list-item>
</list>
</boxed-text>
</sec>
<sec id="sec13_6">
<title>Humorous Appeals: Stop Me If You&#x2019;ve Heard this One</title>
<p>You might not think of comedians as being particularly persuasive, but <italic>Time</italic> magazine&#x2019;s list of the 100 most influential people in 2017 included three comics: Samantha Bee, Leslie Jones, and Jordan Peele (<italic>Time</italic>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_114">2017</xref>). An Egyptian comedian, Bassem Youssef, who is referred to as the &#x201C;John Stewart of Egypt,&#x201D; hosted a top-rated political satire show that lampooned the Egyptian government. He was arrested repeatedly for skewering powerful elites and eventually fled to the USA where he is now living in exile. In China, Zhou Libo, another comedian, used humor to draw attention to government corruption. In Paris in 2015, Al Queda terrorists gunned down the editor and staff members of the satirical magazine, <italic>Charlie Hebdo</italic>. Why? Because the magazine published cartoons critical of Islam.</p>
<p>Why do authoritarian governments and religious extremists fear comedians? Political satire is subversive. Beyond the laughs, comedians offer social commentary. &#x201C;Good comics,&#x201D; say <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_27">Cohen and Richards (2006)</xref> &#x201C;are playing an important function <target target-type="page" id="page_319">319</target>in society by holding up a mirror and forcing us to confront realities that we would prefer to ignore&#x201D; (para. 2).</p>
<p>The use of humor in persuasion is pervasive, and not just the political kind. Humorous advertisements account for 24 percent of all advertising in the USA (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_71">Laroche, Nepomuceno, Huang, &#x0026; Richard, 2011</xref>). Internet memes rely heavily on humor to offer pithy social and political commentary. Humor is common in the boardroom, the courtroom, the classroom, interpersonal conversations, and even the pulpit. Using humor to influence is like skinning a cat; there&#x2019;s more than one way. A humorous appeal can consist of a pun, satire, an anecdote, innuendo, irony, a metaphor, slapstick, or just a plain old joke, as in &#x201C;an armadillo walks into a bar &#x2026;&#x201D; Humor can be directed at oneself, which is known as <italic>self-disparaging humor,</italic> or at others. All in all, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_15">Berger (2011)</xref> identified 45 different types of humor.</p>
<sec id="sec13_6_1">
<title>Humor as an Indirect Form of Influence: All Kidding Aside</title>
<p>Typically, jokes themselves don&#x2019;t persuade. Humor tends to operate in a more roundabout manner using the peripheral route to persuasion. Two well-established ways in which humor assists persuasion are by <italic>capturing attention</italic> and <italic>increasing liking</italic> for the source (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_40">Eisend, 2011</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_54">Gulas &#x0026; Weinberger, 2006</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_88">Nabi, Moyer-Gus&#x00E9;, &#x0026; Byrne, 2007</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_121">Weinberger &#x0026; Gulas, 1992</xref>). This explains why comedians like Ellen DeGeneres, Tina Fey, Jim Gaffigan, and Jerry Seinfeld are popular endorsers. A meta-analysis of humor in advertising revealed that humor was highly effective in increasing attention and positive feelings toward a brand (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_38">Eisend, 2009</xref>).</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 13.2</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig13_2.tif"/>
<p>Source: Jerry King, <uri>www.CartoonStock.com</uri></p>
</fig>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_320">320</target>A third way in which humor may facilitate persuasion is by serving as a <italic>distraction</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_88">Nabi, Moyer-Gus&#x00E9;, &#x0026; Byrne, 2007</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_109">Strick, Holland, van Baaren, &#x0026; van Knipperberg, 2012</xref>). Specifically, because the cognitive effort required to comprehend a joke trades off with the mental energy needed to analyze the substance of a message, humor tends to suppress <italic>counterarguing</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_131">Young, 2008</xref>). For example, one study found that participants who read a series of jokes told by late-night comedians were less inclined to scrutinize the statements carefully, compared to a control group of participants who read nonhumorous versions of the same statements. This suggests that a persuader facing a hostile audience could use humor to &#x201C;soften up&#x201D; the crowd.</p>
<p>A fourth way in which humor may aid a persuader is by serving as a form of <italic>social proof</italic>, which involves modeling our behavior after the actions or reactions of others (see <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter6">Chapter 6</xref>). The use of &#x201C;laugh tracks&#x201D; or live audience laughter on television sitcoms illustrates this principle. Researchers have found that the perceived funniness of low- to medium-quality jokes can be enhanced by including canned laughter (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_30">Cupchik &#x0026; Leventhal, 1974</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_73">Leventhal &#x0026; Cupchik, 1975</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_74">1976</xref>). Speakers often use &#x201C;shills&#x201D; or &#x201C;plants&#x201D; in an audience to initiate laughter or applause to help sway audience members.</p>
<p>Finally, the use of humor might affect perceptions of a source. One meta-analysis, for example, found that overall, humor tends to reduce perceptions of a source&#x2019;s credibility (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_38">Eisend, 2009</xref>). That said, humorous sources are perceived as being more socially attractive (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_87">Murnstein &#x0026; Burst, 1985</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_117">Wanzer, Booth-Butterfield, &#x0026; Booth-Butterfield, 1996</xref>) and more competent communicators (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_117">Wanzer et al., 1996</xref>). Our advice, then, would be to employ humor judiciously, tailoring your message to the audience, the situation, and your goals.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec13_6_2">
<title>Self-Disparaging Humor: LOLing at Yourself</title>
<p>Should you ever make yourself the brunt of a humorous appeal? On one hand, it might seem that putting yourself down, even lightheartedly, would damage your image. On the other hand, it might seem that the ability to poke fun at yourself would bolster your image. Again, the answer depends on the type of image you are aiming to create. The ability to laugh at yourself demonstrates that you are friendly and good-natured (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_50">Graham, Papa, &#x0026; Brooks, 1992</xref>). Presidential candidates often appear on late-night comedy shows. By showing a lighter side, they hope to seem more natural, genuine, and spontaneous.</p>
<p>Actual studies on self-disparaging humor have yielded mixed results (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_25">Chang &#x0026; Gruner, 1981</xref>). <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_55">Hackman (1988)</xref> revealed that self-disparaging humor led to lower ratings of speaker competence. Our advice is to avoid self-disparaging humor if you think you have low credibility to begin with or if you need to bolster your credibility in the competence dimension. If you have moderate to high credibility to begin with, then making light of some of your human frailties might make you appear more genuine and good-natured.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec13_6_3">
<title>But Is Humor Persuasive?</title>
<p>Earlier attempts to determine whether the use of humor enhanced persuasion produced inconsistent results (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_54">Gulas &#x0026; Weinberger, 2006</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_105">Skalski, Tamborini, Glazer, &#x0026; Smith, 2009</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_121">Weinberger &#x0026; Gulas, 1992</xref>). This is understandable, given that humor takes many forms. And let&#x2019;s face it, some jokes are funnier than others. A recent meta-analysis, however, suggests that humor enhances at least two measures of persuasion: attitudes toward a brand and purchase intentions (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_38">Eisend, 2009</xref>). Although humor may be effective, it doesn&#x2019;t appear to be superior to other appeals, such as fear and pride (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_115">Verma, 2009</xref>). An additional study (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_88">Nabi, Moyer-Gus&#x00E9;, &#x0026; Byrne, 2007</xref>) also found that humorous appeals may benefit from a <italic>sleeper effect</italic>&#x2014; that is, humor may grow on people over time, leading to more persuasion later on.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec13_6_4">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_321">321</target>Maximizing Humor&#x2019;s Potential</title>
<p>Some advice for maximizing humor&#x2019;s persuasive potential seems in order. First, if you aren&#x2019;t good at telling jokes, don&#x2019;t. Another suggestion is to use <italic>related humor</italic>, which integrates the humor into the content of the message. <italic>Unrelated humor</italic>, such as a stand-alone joke, is not as effective (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_54">Gulas &#x0026; Weinberger, 2006</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_121">Weinberger &#x0026; Gulas, 1992</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_122">Weinberger &#x0026; Spotts, 1989</xref>). Another suggestion is to add gravitas toward the end of a humor-laden message. Let the audience know your message is not all fun and games. Stress the seriousness of the point you are trying to make through your use of humor (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_88">Nabi, Moyer-Gus&#x00E9;, &#x0026; Byrne, 2007</xref>).</p>
<p>Another important piece of advice is <italic>don&#x2019;t overdo it</italic>. Too much humor may cause listeners to discount the message as little more than a joke (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_52">Gruner, 1967</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_88">Nabi et al., 2007</xref>). After all, if you don&#x2019;t appear to take your own message seriously, why should others? Similarly, the use of inappropriate humor can decrease perceptions of credibility (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_36">Derks, Kalland, &#x0026; Etgen, 1995</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_86">Munn &#x0026; Gruner, 1981</xref>).</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec13_7">
<title>Pride and Patiotism: Turning Red, White, and Blue into Green</title>
<p>In the summer of 2016, Budweiser beer temporarily renamed itself, <italic>America</italic>. Skittles offered packages with red, white, and blue candies. M&#x0026;Ms followed suit with its own patriotic palette. If the trend continues, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_98">Schultz (2016)</xref> observed, &#x201C;Buyers might have to salute each time they walk into a grocery store.&#x201D;</p>
<p>Politicians are fond of wrapping themselves in the flag, standing next to veterans at public events, and declaring theirs to be the greatest nation on earth (whatever nation that happens to be). Does flag waving work? The answer is yes, quite well. Several investigations suggest that patriotic ploys are effective, when used appropriately. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_101">Seiter and Gass (2005)</xref>, for example, compared the tips earned by food servers who wrote a patriotic message (&#x201C;United We Stand&#x201D;) on patrons&#x2019; checks with a more traditional message (&#x201C;Have a Nice Day&#x201D;). Food servers who used the patriotic slogan earned significantly higher tips.</p>
<p>Even brief exposure to a patriotic emblem can sway people. Those who saw an American flag on a survey of voter attitudes shifted their attitudes in a more conservative direction. Voting intentions also leaned more toward the right after a single exposure to the flag (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_22">Carter, Ferguson, &#x0026; Hassin, 2011</xref>). Why? As a patriotic symbol, the flag may be more closely associated with the Republican than the Democratic party (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_65">Kalmoe &#x0026; Gross, 2016</xref>). <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_56">Han (1988)</xref> found that patriotism had a positive effect on consumers&#x2019; intentions to purchase domestic as opposed to foreign <target target-type="page" id="page_322">322</target>brands, but didn&#x2019;t necessarily alter their perceptions of brand quality or reliability. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_91">Pedic (1990)</xref> discovered that nationalistic ads were more effective than non-nationalistic ads, but only if the receivers were themselves nationalistic.</p>
<p>In America, patriotic appeals have a lot going for them. Even so, recent evidence suggests that the effectiveness of flag waving may be wearing off (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_125">Wellner, 2002</xref>). In the USA, there has been pushback against Trump&#x2019;s anti-immigration policies. Shepard Fairey&#x2019;s series of pro-diversity posters, entitled &#x201C;We the People&#x201D; illustrates this trend (see <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig13_3">Figure 13.3</xref>).</p>
<fig id="fig13_3" position="float">
<label>Figure 13.3</label>
<caption><title>Poster by Shepard Fairey.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig13_3.jpg"/>
<p>Source: Christopher Penler/Shutterstock.com</p>
</fig>
<p>Not only that, patriotic appeals can backfire, as Samuel Johnson&#x2019;s famous remark that patriotism is the &#x201C;last refuge of scoundrels&#x201D; warns. Companies can still use American branding successfully, but if a persuader appears to be &#x201C;cashing in&#x201D; on patriotic ploys or using patriotism as a wedge issue, then receivers may reject the message or the source.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec13_8">
<title>For Mature Audiences: Sex Appeals</title>
<p>Television is replete with sexual appeals. So are print ads. One analysis found that half of all print ads depict women as sex objects (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_107">Stankiewicz &#x0026; Rosselli, 2008</xref>). And then there&#x2019;s the Internet. There&#x2019;s more sex on the Web than flies on a cowpie. &#x201C;Sex sells,&#x201D; goes the advertising adage.</p>
<p>Although the use of sexual appeals has been a fixture of advertising for decades, two things have changed. First, the use of more overt sexual appeals has increased (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_81">Malik, 2016</xref>). Second, increasingly younger audiences are being targeted. Media is sexualizing children at younger and younger ages (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_10">American Psychological Association, 2010</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_59">Hill, 2011</xref>).</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_323">323</target>Historically, females have been depicted as sex objects in advertising (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_106">Snigda &#x0026; Venkatesh, 2011</xref>), a situation decried by feminists and other media critics. Grounded in <italic>objectification theory,</italic> females are more likely to be seen as objects or things. Accordingly, females are more likely than males to be portrayed as passive, submissive, and subordinate (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_80">Mager &#x0026; Helgeson, 2011</xref>). Women also are depicted as being disembodied, silenced, and occupying less space than men (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_28">Conley &#x0026; Ramsey, 2011</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_39">Eisend, 2010</xref>). Not surprisingly then, women respond less favorably to sex appeals than men (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_17">Black &#x0026; Morton, 2017</xref>).</p>
<p>Despite the media&#x2019;s obsession with sex appeals, studies show that simply increasing the amount of sexual imagery does not make a message more persuasive. As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_79">Ma and Gal (2016)</xref> warn, &#x201C;in general, research has found that sex in advertising does not improve brand recall or sales effectiveness&#x201D; (p. 479).</p>
<p>The sexual objectification of males is also well underway (Sexualization of men, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_104">2016</xref>). For example, the Magic Mike franchise, starring Channing Tatum, rides the current wave of toned dudes. David Beckham is hunky in H&#x0026;M&#x2019;s underwear ads. Duckett (cited in <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_20">Brown, 2016</xref>) emphasized that &#x201C;the trend for using hyper-athletic male models and celebrities in advertising has grown significantly in recent years, giving rise to the term &#x2018;hunkvertising&#x2019;&#x201D; (para. 7). And while one in six males under 24 reported being more self-conscious about their bodies, more than half of males said they pay little attention to male advertising physiques (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_20">Brown, 2016</xref>). Men, therefore, have far less reason to worry about women ogling them than women do from the &#x201C;male gaze.&#x201D;</p>
<sec id="sec13_8_1">
<title>How Sex Sells</title>
<p>How do sex appeals work? Typically, the unspoken message in ads employing sexual appeals is either (1) if you use product &#x201C;X&#x201D; you will look, act, or feel more sexy or (2) if you use product &#x201C;X&#x201D; other sexy people will be attracted to you. Of course, such ads rarely make explicit cause&#x2013;effect claims about the benefits of the product. Rather, the product is paired with sexually laden imagery. Through this associative process (see <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter3">Chapter 3</xref>) the receiver comes to identify the product with sexiness or sensuality.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec13_8_2">
<title>Caveats and Cautions</title>
<p>Although it is true that sexual appeals can be effective, there are also cautions regarding their use (see, for example, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_103">Sengupta &#x0026; Dahl, 2008</xref>). First, despite their prevalence, sex appeals are not always effective. A study conducted in a pharmaceutical sales context found that a female sales representative who showed cleavage was no more persuasive than a female salesperson who did not (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_47">Glick, Chrislock, Petersik, Vijay, &#x0026; Turek, 2008</xref>). Context means a lot, however. A study conducted in France found that males were much more likely to approach a female in a bar if she had large breasts (Gu&#x00E9;gu&#x00E9;n, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_53">2007</xref>). Who says research has to be boring? The conclusion might seem obvious. The point is that sex appeals may not function the same way in professional settings as they do in social settings. A boardroom is not a barroom.</p>
<p>Second, in some cases the targeted audience may resent the use of sexual appeals. For example, sexual stimuli are frequently included in ads aimed at women. Yet if women perceive the ads as sexist, the ads may backfire. Nowadays, an advertiser <target target-type="page" id="page_324">324</target>must walk a fine line between creating ads that are considered sexy and ads that are considered sexist.</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 13.4</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig13_4.tif"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; Darrin Bell, All Rights Reserved. Reprinted with permission. <uri>www.BellCartoons.com</uri></p>
</fig>
<p>A third liability in using sex appeals is that they may function as a <italic>distraction</italic>, inhibiting receiver recall. If a consumer is salivating over a sexy model in a magazine ad, his or her attention may be diverted from the product being advertised. Several studies have shown this to be the case (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_21">Bushman &#x0026; Bonacci, 2002</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_64">Judd &#x0026; Alexander, 1983</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_81">Malik, 2016</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_108">Steadman, 1969</xref>). Advertisers face something of a dilemma here: A sexual appeal that is too mild may not stand out in the crowd, yet a sexual appeal that is too strong may serve as a distraction.</p>
<p>A fourth downside to using sex appeals is that they may produce undesirable social consequences. Objectification of women in media can lead to <italic>self-objectification</italic>, whereby females begin viewing themselves as objects (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_106">Snigda &#x0026; Venkatesh, 2011</xref>). This, in turn, may result in lower self-esteem, negative body image, and eating disorders (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_28">Conley &#x0026; Ramsey, 2011</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_69">Kilbourne, 1999</xref>). We don&#x2019;t fault the media entirely for the current obsession that people have with their bodies. We do think, however, that advertisers, the movie industry, and the fashion industry must shoulder some of the blame for exploiting people&#x2019;s insecurities about their looks.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec13_9">
<title>Warmth Appeals: Straight from the Heart</title>
<p>&#x201C;Nothing says lovin&#x2019; like something from the oven, and Pillsbury says it best.&#x201D; Some advertisements convey a warm, cozy feeling. They emphasize family, friends, and a sense of belonging. They make us feel sentimental or nostalgic about life. Such ads are based on <italic>warmth.</italic> <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_1">Aaker and Bruzzone (1981)</xref> identify warmth as one of a half-dozen basic dimensions people use to describe advertisements. The use of warmth in <target target-type="page" id="page_325">325</target>advertising is quite common (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_5">Aaker, Stayman, &#x0026; Hagerty, 1986</xref>). A little more than one in five prime-time commercials include warmth as an advertising theme (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_3">Aaker &#x0026; Stayman, 1990</xref>). State Farm&#x2019;s &#x201C;Like a good neighbor &#x2026; State Farm is there&#x201D; campaign is based on this theme, as is Olive Garden&#x2019;s &#x201C;When you&#x2019;re here, you&#x2019;re family&#x201D; slogan. So are ads for Hallmark cards, &#x201C;Poppin&#x2019; Fresh,&#x201D; the Pillsbury doughboy, and Snuggle fabric softener, which features a cuddly teddy bear. Insurance companies, airlines, health-care providers, restaurants, and hotel chains all use warmth to convey images of folksiness, hominess, friendliness, and familiarity (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_48">Goldman &#x0026; Papson, 1996</xref>).</p>
<p>So how do they work? Primarily through association. A product or service is associated with the image of being warm, caring, or friendly. When we think of that product or service we get a warm-fuzzy feeling.</p>
<p>Warmth appeals aren&#x2019;t limited to television advertising. One study found that parental warmth was more effective in influencing adolescents&#x2019; eating habits than the use of negative pressure (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_72">Lessard, Greenberger, &#x0026; Chen, 2010</xref>). Real-estate listings often use words like <italic>charming</italic>, <italic>cozy</italic>, or <italic>rustic</italic> to describe houses that are for sale. Restaurants boast of &#x201C;home-style&#x201D; cooking. Frozen foods claim to be based on &#x201C;authentic family recipes&#x201D; that are &#x201C;made the old-fashioned way.&#x201D; In interpersonal encounters, warmth can be conveyed through actions that generate a sense of friendship, bonding, or camaraderie. The Walmart &#x201C;greeter&#x201D; is a living embodiment of a warmth appeal. When a food server introduces himself or herself by name and smiles, the food server is also conveying warmth.</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 13.5</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig13_5.jpg"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; Peter C. Vey/ The New Yorker Collection/ <uri>www.cartoonbank.com. All RightsReserved</uri>.</p>
</fig>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_326">326</target>Warmth appeals can be quite effective, but their success depends on their believability. The warm-fuzzy images being portrayed must come across as sincere for the appeal to work (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_2">Aaker &#x0026; Stayman, 1989</xref>). As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_3">Aaker and Stayman (1990)</xref> note, the appeal &#x201C;need[s] to avoid creating the perception of an ad&#x2019;s being phony, pointless, or contrived; such perceptions could interfere with the emotional response&#x201D; (p. 59). Warmth appeals, then, are a persuader&#x2019;s friend. They offer a positive approach to using motivational appeals by engendering warm, happy feelings in receivers.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec13_10">
<title>Ingratiation: Polishing the Apple</title>
<p>You may know it as &#x201C;brownnosing,&#x201D; &#x201C;sucking up,&#x201D; or &#x201C;boot-licking,&#x201D; but <italic>ingratiation</italic> is the term researchers use for flattery as a motivational inducement. Ingratiation has been thoroughly studied in organizational settings (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_35">Deluga &#x0026; Perry, 1994</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_75">Liden &#x0026; Mitchell, 1988</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_111">Tal-Or, 2010</xref>). Indeed, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_126">Westphal and Shani (2016)</xref> report that &#x201C;ingratiation is perhaps the most widely studied form of interpersonal influence behavior in the organization literature&#x201D; (p. 481). Will flattery get you everywhere? An overall assessment of the research to date suggests that ingratiation works&#x2014;and works well (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_49">Gordon, 1996</xref>). For instance, a study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_119">Watt (1993)</xref> found that ingratiators were perceived by their supervisors as being more competent, more motivated, and more qualified for leadership positions than their noningratiating counterparts. Another study (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_120">Wayne, Kacmar, &#x0026; Ferris, 1995</xref>) found that the use of ingratiation tactics by subordinates resulted in higher satisfaction for the supervisor and co-workers. In fact, one study quantified the advantage enjoyed by ingratiators over noningratiators. In a study of 152 pairs of managers and employees, Deluga (cited in <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_67">Kelleher, 1997</xref>) found that ingratiators enjoyed a 5 percent edge over noningratiators in getting favorable evaluations. Ziemke and Brodksy (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_132">2015</xref>) found that the use of ingratiation by defense attorneys during their closing arguments increased their perceived attractiveness, likability, and credibility. Two studies in organizations&#x2014;one conducted in restaurants (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_99">Seiter, 2007</xref>), the other in hair styling salons (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_100">Seiter &#x0026; Dutson, 2007</xref>)&#x2014;found that food servers and hair stylists earned significantly higher tips when they complimented (ingratiated) their customers than when they did not.</p>
<p>Researchers know that ingratiation works, but just how does it work? What is the secret behind its success? There are three interrelated explanations for ingratiation&#x2019;s effectiveness (Dubrin, cited in <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_67">Kelleher, 1997</xref>). First, ingratiatory behavior tends to increase <italic>liking</italic> (&#x201C;I love that outfit on you!&#x201D;). Second, ingratiatory behavior can create perceptions of <italic>similarity</italic> (&#x201C;You love polka music? Hey, I do too!&#x201D;). Third, ingratiation can work through <italic>social labeling.</italic> The use of positive social labels (&#x201C;You sure are in a good mood today,&#x201D; &#x201C;You are so thoughtful&#x201D;) can produce changes in the target&#x2019;s self-concept that, in turn, lead to changes in the target&#x2019;s behavior (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_70">Kraut, 1973</xref>). The person being ingratiated thus lives up to the positive label bestowed on her or him.</p>
<p>How many kinds of ingratiation are there? <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_63">Edward Jones (1963)</xref>, who authored the first major work on ingratiation, identified three basic categories of ingratiation. The first is <italic>other enhancement,</italic> such as paying compliments or engaging in flattery. A derivative of this technique is to have a third party deliver the compliment, so that it seems more genuine (&#x201C;Biff speaks highly of you. He says you are the nicest boss he&#x2019;s <target target-type="page" id="page_327">327</target>ever had&#x201D;). The second technique is <italic>opinion conformity.</italic> This involves agreeing with the target&#x2019;s statements, ideas, and views. A variation on this technique is to initially disagree, then subsequently yield, creating the impression the target has changed your mind (&#x201C;Okay, you&#x2019;ve convinced me, Godiva chocolates taste better than See&#x2019;s chocolates&#x201D;). A third approach is <italic>self-presentation.</italic> This involves bragging or otherwise displaying one&#x2019;s attributes to increase the target&#x2019;s evaluation of oneself (&#x201C;Gee, I&#x2019;d love to play golf with you, but I&#x2019;m helping at the homeless center this weekend&#x201D;). Some scholars include <italic>performing favors</italic> as a fourth type of ingratiation (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_133">Zin, Ngah, Ismail, Tajuddin, Abdullah, &#x0026; Salleh, 2010</xref>). So you see, there is more than one way to engage in brownnosing.</p>
<p>But, you might ask, wouldn&#x2019;t the other person <italic>know,</italic> or at least suspect, that the ingratiator was trying to curry favor? If so, can ingratiation backfire? The answer is yes, although some studies find that shameless ingratiation still works, though perhaps not as well (e.g., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_24">Chan &#x0026; Sengupta, 2010</xref>).</p>
<p>Research on the &#x201C;slime effect&#x201D; suggests that inept ingratiators are seen as unlikable and are suspected of ulterior motives (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_116">Vonk, 1998</xref>). In one study, for example, food servers who delivered compliments to large parties in one fell swoop (&#x201C;You all made good choices!&#x201D;) received lower tips than food servers who complimented smaller parties, thereby seeming more sincere (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_102">Seiter &#x0026; Weger, 2010</xref>).</p>
<p>That said, some ingratiators are more skilled at disguising their motives. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_126">Westphal and Shani (2016)</xref>, for instance, found that effective ingratiators self-regulate their thought process to focus on the positive characteristics of another person, rather than on his or her negatives. Successful ingratiators also rely on more subtle forms of flattery, such as turning a compliment as a question&#x2014;e.g., &#x201C;Ralph, you&#x2019;re always dressed sharp. Do you think I should wear black or brown shoes with a blue suit?&#x201D;</p>
<p>Considering such manipulative tactics, you might be thinking that ingratiation is an unethical influence strategy. We tend to agree, but not in all cases. If the ingratiator <italic>believes</italic> in the praise he or she is offering, we see no ethical problem in focusing on the positive side of things. Indeed, if the praise is genuine, this strategy offers the prospect for a &#x201C;win&#x2013;win&#x201D; communication encounter. We discuss the ethical implications of ingratiatory behavior in more detail in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter16">Chapter 16</xref>.</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 13.6</label>
<caption><title>Beetle Bailey.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig13_6.tif"/>
<p>Source: Reprinted with permission from King Features Syndicate.</p>
</fig>
</sec>
<sec id="sec13_11">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_328">328</target>Mixed Emotions: Other Appeals and Combinations of Appeals</title>
<p>There are many other types of motivational appeals that we do not have space to cover here. Some of these include appeals to honor, youth, beauty, shame, freedom, and the environment. Almost any human drive or emotion can serve as the basis for a motivational appeal.</p>
<p>Motivational appeals also can be used in combination. A threat of punishment can be coupled with a promise of reward, for example. A prosecutor might tell a defendant, &#x201C;If you cooperate, I&#x2019;ll cut you a deal. If you don&#x2019;t, I&#x2019;ll throw the book at you.&#x201D; The &#x201C;good cop/bad cop&#x201D; technique used in police interrogations also combines positive and negative appeals (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_61">Inbau, Reid, &#x0026; Buckley, 1986</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_66">Kassin &#x0026; McNall, 1991</xref>). One study found that adding humor to a fear appeal about skin cancer reduced defensiveness by providing a &#x201C;margin of safety&#x201D; to the audience (Mukherjee &#x0026; Dub&#x00E9;, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_85">2012</xref>).</p>
<p>Guilt is commonly coupled with pity in charity fund-raisers (&#x201C;If you don&#x2019;t help, who will?&#x201D;). In a twist involving &#x201C;strange bedfellows,&#x201D; the animal rights group known as PETA (People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals) has collaborated with <italic>Penthouse</italic> magazine for the past few years to produce an anti-fur advertisement. The ads feature sexy supermodels who proclaim they would rather go naked than wear fur, thus combining a sex appeal with a guilt appeal. Evidence suggests that when people experience mixed emotions, they don&#x2019;t recall them clearly (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_4">Aaker, Drolet, &#x0026; Griffin, 2008</xref>). For example, riding a roller coaster might evoke positive (e.g., excitement, exhilaration) and negative (e.g., fear, apprehension) emotions. Over time, though, the person would tend to remember the ride as mostly exciting and enjoyable or mostly scary and unpleasant.</p>
<p>We see definite advantages in combining appeals. If one appeal proves ineffective, another may still work. And there is always the prospect that combinations of appeals will have an additive effect&#x2014;that is, the combination of appeals may work better than they would individually. A danger in combining appeals is that they may appear contradictory or cancel one another out. Combining humor with pity, for instance, might create the appearance that a persuader was insensitive or disingenuous. Some research suggests that inducing conflicting emotions (happiness and sadness) may be better suited for Asian American than Anglo-American receivers (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref13_127">Williams &#x0026; Aaker, 2002</xref>). In selecting motivational appeals, then, a persuader must be judicious.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec13_12">
<title>Summary</title>
<p>Motivational appeals are external inducements used to increase another&#x2019;s drive to do something. The use of motivational appeals is an omnipresent phenomenon. Attempts at casting logical and emotional appeals as opposites are suspect. Although motivational appeals aren&#x2019;t necessarily rational, neither are they irrational. Eight types of motivational appeals were discussed: fear, pity, guilt, humor, patriotism, sex, warmth, and ingratiation. These represent only a fraction of the appeals available to persuaders. Experimental studies have shown some of these to be highly effective in facilitating persuasion, whereas others have been shown to be less effective. It also was suggested that motivational appeals can be successfully combined if certain precautions are followed.<target target-type="page" id="page_329">329</target></p>
</sec>
</body>
<back>

<ref id="ref13_105"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Skalski</surname>, <given-names>P.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Tamborini</surname>, <given-names>R.</given-names></string-name>, <string-name><surname>Glazer</surname>, <given-names>E.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Smith</surname>, <given-names>S.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2009</year>). <article-title>Effects of humor on presence and recall of messages</article-title>. <source>Communication Quarterly</source>, <volume>57</volume>(<issue>2</issue>), <fpage>136</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>153</lpage>.<target target-type="page" id="page_334">334</target></mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref13_106"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Snigda</surname>, <given-names>S.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Venkatesh</surname>, <given-names>S.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2011</year>). <article-title>Impact of female sexual objectification in advertising on women</article-title>. <source>Advances in Management</source>, <volume>4</volume>(<issue>12</issue>), <fpage>10</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>13</lpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
