</ref-list>
</back>
</book-part>
<book-part book-part-type="chapter" id="chapter14">
<book-part-meta>
<title-group>
<label>14</label>
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_336">336</target>Visual Persuasion</title>
<alt-title alt-title-type="running-head">Visual Persuasion</alt-title>
</title-group>
<contrib-group>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Gass</surname>
<given-names>Robert H.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Seiter</surname>
<given-names>John S.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
</contrib-group>
</book-part-meta>
<body>
<p>WANT TO CAPTURE AN AUDIENCE&#x2019;S ATTENTION? Try taking off your clothes. You wouldn&#x2019;t be the first to use this approach. People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) use this strategy to protest wearing leather and fur. Their &#x201C;Naked Truth&#x201D; campaign features attractive models and celebrities, sans clothing, with the caption &#x201C;I&#x2019;d rather go naked than wear fur.&#x201D; Not to be outdone, Spencer Tunick, a performance artist/photographer convinced 18,000 people in Mexico City to strip naked for a photo shoot. He sees mass nudity as a form of collective defiance against social norms. Nudity, however, is not reserved for <target target-type="page" id="page_337">337</target>protesters and artists. When a German supermarket offered free groceries to the first 100 naked shoppers, more than 200 people showed up (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_83">Zimmerman, 2012</xref>). The promotion worked! We suspect that the male shoppers avoided the frozen food aisle.</p>
<p>Hang on. Before you give your next class presentation in the buff, we should warn you that while nudity may be a great attention getter, your &#x201C;visual aids&#x201D; may serve as a distraction during the rest of your presentation. Moreover, you may encounter a good deal of audience resentment. Lots of folks tend to react negatively to nudity (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_16">Christy &#x0026; Haley, 2008</xref>). With that said, and, now that we have your attention, we&#x2019;d like to examine the role of images in persuasion.</p>
<sec id="sec14_1">
<title>Image is Everything</title>
<p>We are living in an increasingly visual society. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_33">Gurri, Denny, and Harms (2010)</xref> underscored this trend, commenting that &#x201C;Many more images than ever before are available, and many more people are paying a disproportionate amount of attention to them&#x201D; (p. 101). Fewer people are reading newspapers and books. More people are watching movies and TV. As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_56">Metros (2008)</xref> observed:
<disp-quote>
<p>politicians wage campaigns not on issues, but through their visual persona; wars are televised live through the eyes of embedded journalists; criminal trials have become 24/7 international spectator events; newspapers have had to reduce text to pack their pages with charts, graphics, and photos to compete for market-share; and even radio directs its listeners to Web sites to illustrate the spoken word.</p>
<attrib>(p. 109)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>In television commercials, magazine ads, and billboards, images are primary and words are secondary. Politicians worry about &#x201C;bad optics,&#x201D; such as being on vacation when a crisis unfolds. The Internet is chock-full of images. Facebook, Instagram, YouTube, and other social media are saturated with images. Internet memes are ever popular. Selfies are all the rage. And it is not only mass media that rely on visual cues. Protest marches, sit-ins, demonstrations, rallies, and picketing are highly visual acts that are intended to persuade.</p>
<p>In this chapter, we examine some of the important ways in which images shape beliefs, attitudes, and behaviors. First, we consider the importance of visual stimuli and how images persuade. Next, we examine art as a form of persuasion, cinematic influence, images in advertising, and photojournalism as a form of persuasion.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec14_2">
<title>Overlooked and Under-Appreciated</title>
<p>&#x201C;Visual images,&#x201D; writes <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_74">Taewon Suh (1999)</xref>, &#x201C;have become a predominant means of transmitting information in the twentieth century and may be even more so in the next century&#x201D; (p. 3). Yet, despite the increasing importance of visual persuasion, the topic has been under-studied in the field of communication. Traditionally, the study of persuasion has focused on influence attempts that take place within the world of words. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_54">Messaris (1997)</xref> underscored this point when he noted:
<disp-quote>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_338">338</target>although the study of persuasive communication has a history of more than two millennia, the focus of this scholarly tradition has tended overwhelmingly to be on verbal strategies. With a few notable exceptions, the systematic investigation of visual persuasion is still in its infancy.</p>
<attrib>(p. vii)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec14_3">
<title>The Power of Images: A Thousand Words</title>
<p>Images are powerful. They can move us in ways that words cannot. Their potency stems partly from their perceived &#x201C;realness,&#x201D; or the idea that seeing is believing. As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_33">Gurri, Denny, and Harms (2010)</xref> noted, &#x201C;with visual media, however, the illusion is created that we are gazing out a window at the real world&#x201D; (p. 102). The power of images also arises from their emotional force. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_40">Joffe (2008)</xref> emphasized the advantages of images over words when she noted that &#x201C;the most salient distinction between the relative effects of textual/verbal versus visual messages concerns their emotive impact&#x201D; (p. 84). The grim photo of a Sudanese infant starving to death (see <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig14_1">Figure 14.1</xref>) demonstrates this capacity. The ghoulish image won a Pulitzer Prize in 1993.</p>
<fig id="fig14_1" position="float">
<label>Figure 14.1</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig14_1.jpg"/>
<p>Source: Photo: Kevin Carter 1993 Getty Images.</p>
</fig>
<p>Despite the traditional emphasis on words, studies have revealed a <italic>picture superiority effect</italic> for images. Pictures are more easily recognized and recalled than words (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_39">Hockley, 2008</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_60">Pelli, Farell, &#x0026; Moore, 2013</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_72">Stenberg, 2006</xref>). <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_53">Medina (2014)</xref> reports, for example, that people remember only about 10 percent of what they hear three days hence, compared to 65 percent recall when pictures are included. Images also cross languages and cultures more easily.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec14_4">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_339">339</target>How Images Persuade</title>
<p>What is it about images and other visual stimuli that make them so persuasive? We take up this question here. In doing so, we rely heavily on Paul Messaris&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_54">1997</xref>) conceptualization of the role of images in persuasion. He suggests that images persuade in three basic ways: through <italic>iconicity, indexicality,</italic> and <italic>syntactic indeterminacy.</italic></p>
<sec id="sec14_4_1">
<title>Iconicity: Bearing a Resemblance</title>
<p>One way that images persuade is by functioning as <italic>icons</italic>, which simply means that they stand for and resemble the things they represent. An image can sum up a concept. The stick figure on a &#x201C;pedestrian crossing&#x201D; sign is an icon. An emoji is an icon for an emotion. A caricature of a politician drawn by an editorial cartoonist is also iconic. The Statue of Liberty, Uncle Sam, and the bald eagle are all icons of America. It doesn&#x2019;t matter whether they are accurate representations or not (silhouettes of pedestrians on a crossing sign lack hands and feet) as long as people understand what they represent. This is, perhaps, the most important property of images: to summarize ideas and concepts. As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_54">Messaris (1997)</xref> noted, &#x201C;If there is one property that most clearly distinguishes pictures from language and other modes of communication, that property is iconicity&#x201D; (p. 3).</p>
<p>A good illustration of the iconic nature of images can be found in Philip Morris&#x2019;s Marlboro man. The Marlboro man is immediately recognizable around the world. He is a mythical American hero. He represents the Old West. He symbolizes an idealized image of the cowboy&#x2014;a rugged, self-reliant individual. He&#x2019;s always pictured outdoors, on the range. Without even seeing the brand-name or the slogan, most people can spot the Marlboro man in an instant. And boy, can he sell cigarettes! Marlboro cigarettes are the most popular brand in the world (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_21">de Guzman, 2007</xref>). For this reason, the Marlboro man has been called &#x201C;the most universally recognized, consistently profitable, and aesthetically appealing image in the advertising world&#x201D; (Selling tobacco, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_67">1990</xref>, p. 84). Now that&#x2019;s an icon.</p>
<p>As part of their iconic nature, images also can be selective. Lighting, camera angle, perspective, distance, cropping, and editing all figure into what a viewer sees. Ads for Weightwatchers and Nutrisystem, for example, can choose which &#x201C;before&#x201D; and &#x201C;after&#x201D; photos to show.</p>
<p>Another iconic function of images is that they can violate the reality they represent (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_54">Messaris, 1997</xref>). An image can make something look real that isn&#x2019;t. For example, a busy mother who has her hands full doing the laundry, cooking dinner, cleaning house, and taking care of the kids could be pictured with four arms rather than two. An ad for a pain reliever might show someone suffering from a splitting headache, whose head actually appears to be splitting in two. Images can thus simulate a reality that doesn&#x2019;t exist.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec14_4_2">
<title>Indexicality: Seeing Is Believing</title>
<p>A second way in which images persuade is through <italic>indexicality</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_54">Messaris, 1997</xref>). This refers to the ability of images, in particular photos and video, to document that an event happened or that something took place. For example, photos of Iraqi detainees being abused by U.S. soldiers at Abu Ghraib prison or images of Syrian <target target-type="page" id="page_340">340</target>children killed by U.S. drone missile strikes function as &#x201C;proof&#x201D; to many in the Middle East that the United States does not value Muslim lives.</p>
<p>Indexical images often function as a form of sign reasoning or circumstantial evidence. For example, a high school yearbook photo might document who was in the glee club. An image of a zipper-shaped scar down the center of a person&#x2019;s chest is evidence the person had open heart surgery. Airline passenger &#x201C;shaming&#x201D; photos verify that some travelers, like the slob in seat 15A with his bare foot on your arm rest, are disgusting reprobates. A poignant example of indexicality involves police shootings that have been recorded by witnesses on smartphones or dashboard cameras. Such footage contributed to the rise of the Black Lives Matter movement.</p>
<p>A recent study (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_18">Cornelis &#x0026; Peter, 2017</xref>) demonstrated that consumers consider the veracity of images when evaluating products. Female respondents rated photos of models with labels stating that &#x201C;the model in this ad has been retouched&#x201D; versus &#x201C;the model in this ad has <italic>not</italic> been retouched&#x201D; versus no label. The photos labeled as not retouched were perceived as more authentic and increased purchase intentions.</p>
<p>The documentary aspect of images, however, also can be misleading. Pictures are not always faithful representations of reality. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_32">Gunning (2004)</xref> refers to the common misconception that &#x201C;the camera never lies&#x201D; as the <italic>truth claim</italic> of photography. In this regard, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_54">Messaris (1997)</xref> cautioned, &#x201C;photographs, of course, can lie. The picture of a model in a fashion ad can be made more attractive through airbrushing, and voter interviews or product demonstrations can be staged&#x201D; (p. xvii). A controversy over what images do or do not prove involved the size of the crowd at Trump&#x2019;s presidential inauguration. Although Trump declared his audience was the largest in history, the National Park Service released photos that challenged that claim. You can judge for yourself at <uri>www.nps.gov/aboutus/foia/foia-frd.htm</uri> (scroll halfway down the page to inaugural photos).</p>
<p>Staged events also call the veracity of images into question. Let&#x2019;s say we are watching the news and we see a political candidate, shirtsleeves rolled up, wearing a hardhat, while touring a factory. The image emphasizes the candidate&#x2019;s &#x201C;plain folks&#x201D; appeal. He or she identifies with ordinary workers. But would the candidate have rolled up his or her sleeves, donned a hardhat, and toured the factory in the absence of any camera crews? The cameras are recording an event that might not take place in their absence.</p>
<p>We&#x2019;ve all seen news footage of angry citizens in foreign lands burning the American flag to protest U.S. foreign policies. It seems fair to ask, however, whether the cameras are there because the protesters are burning the flag or the protesters are burning the flag because the cameras are there. A critical viewer should, therefore, question the indexicality of visual records of events. Media events can be staged. Hey, some people think the moon landing was faked! We don&#x2019;t, but the presence of cameras and film crews can alter people&#x2019;s behavior. Photographs and videotapes can be digitally altered to create the appearance that events occurred when, in fact, they did not, or did not occur in the way they are pictured.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec14_4_3">
<title>Syntactic Indeterminacy: Don&#x2019;t Look for Logic in Images</title>
<p>A third way in which images persuade is through <italic>syntactic indeterminacy.</italic> This simply means that, unlike words, pictures cannot convey precise relationships between things. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_54">Messaris (1997)</xref> thus noted, &#x201C;what visual syntax lacks, especially in comparison to <target target-type="page" id="page_341">341</target>verbal language, is a set of explicit devices for indicating causality, analogy, or any other relationships other than those of space or time&#x201D; (pp. xvii&#x2013;xviii). The problem is that images lack logical operators&#x2014;that is, they can&#x2019;t explicitly state cause&#x2013;effect, if&#x2013;then, either&#x2013;or relationships, or other logical connections between people, objects, and events. As an example, a picture can show what a person&#x2019;s abdominal muscles looked like before using the new &#x201C;Monster Ab-Cruncher.&#x201D; Another picture can show what the person&#x2019;s abdominal muscles look like afterward. However, pictures themselves can&#x2019;t specify a cause&#x2013;effect relationship.</p>
<p>The fact that images can&#x2019;t convey logical relationships, such as &#x201C;A causes B,&#x201D; &#x201C;A is analogous to B,&#x201D; or &#x201C;either A or B will happen,&#x201D; is both a blessing and a curse. The blessing is that pictures can be used to equate one thing with another, via association. Images can be juxtaposed to imply an association without actually saying so. This can work to a persuader&#x2019;s advantage. For example, researchers found that a picture of 14 sugar cubes stacked next to a can of Coke was more effective at reducing intentions to consume sugary soft drinks than a text-only label stating that the same Coke can contained 35 grams of sugar (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_1">Adams, Hart, Gilmer, &#x0026; Lloyd-Richardson, 2014</xref>).</p>
<p>A persuader can also foster subtle associations through images without making the associations explicit in words. For example, an advertiser can equate a product with being cool, or sexy, or conferring social status simply by pairing the product with cool, sexy, or classy images.</p>
<p>The curse is that images can never suggest the precise nature of relationships, so it is up to the observer to guess what the relationship is. A car commercial might depict a happy family carrying kayaks from their hybrid SUV to a river. Rather than make the consumer want a hybrid SUV, as the advertiser intends, the sequence of images may make the consumer want to go camping, or buy a kayak, or spend more time with the family instead. This is not a serious drawback, however, for two reasons. First, advertisers have decades of practice at manipulating lighting, camera angle, color, and other aspects of images to achieve the results they want. Second, advertisers use words when they want to make a point explicitly and pictures when they want to make a point implicitly. Thus, they enjoy the best of both worlds.</p>
<p>Now that you have a better understanding of how images persuade, we can turn our attention to some of the intriguing and important ways visual stimuli affect us. We begin by examining art as a visual form of influence.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec14_5">
<title>The Art of Persuasion includes Art as Persuasion</title>
<p>The use of art to further political and religious ends dates to ancient civilizations. Greek friezes and frescoes taught citizens moral lessons involving Greek gods and Greek mythology. In the Middle Ages, organized religions sponsored art to further religious ends. The Catholic Church commissioned thousands of works of art to promote Catholicism. As only one example, Michelangelo&#x2019;s painting of the finger of God reaching out to man that adorns the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel endorses a biblical view of creation.</p>
<sec id="sec14_5_1">
<title>The Paintbrush Is Mightier than the Sword</title>
<p>Governments, especially totalitarian governments, have used art as a form of political propaganda (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_17">Clark, 1997</xref>). Under Stalin, the Soviet Union declared all art to be <target target-type="page" id="page_342">342</target>subservient to the interests of the state. &#x201C;Socialist Realism&#x201D; became the officially recognized standard for art, and its purpose was to advance the political and social ideals of communism. All art projects were commissioned by the government. Not surprisingly, paintings and posters from this era featured members of the proletariat working side by side in factories and on farms. Such iconic representations idealized communism. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_17">Clark (1997)</xref> explains how such politicized art modeled behavior for the masses:
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 14.2</label>
<caption><title>This poster from the Chinese cultural revolution portrays an idealized view of agrarian life.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig14_2.jpg"/>
<p>Source: Reprinted by permission. AP / Dita Alangkara.</p>
</fig>
<disp-quote>
<p>in paintings, novels, and films, Socialist Realism created a parallel world peopled by heroes and heroines who personified political ideals. As tireless labourers, courageous Red Army soldiers, diligent schoolchildren, or dedicated Party activists, they demonstrated exemplary behaviour and the attitudes of perfect citizens.</p>
<attrib>(p. 87)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>Similarly, under Mao, China produced a great deal of art aimed at promoting Communist ideology. When the Communists assumed power in 1949, posters and murals contributed to the deification of Chairman Mao. Graphic arts also were used to mobilize and indoctrinate the people during the Cultural Revolution. Posters <target target-type="page" id="page_343">343</target>showed smiling, cherubic children, peasants, and soldiers all harvesting bumper crops together&#x2014;a tribute to the agricultural achievements of the revolution.</p>
<p>Meanwhile, in the Western world, art was not only sponsored by governments but was directed against governments as well. Eug&#x00E8;ne Delacroix&#x2019;s well-known painting <italic>Liberty Leading the People</italic> (1830) now hangs in the Mus&#x00E9;e du Louvre in Paris. The painting shows a mythical lady liberty, rifle in one hand and French flag in the other, leading French citizens in a charge during the French Revolution. Through its iconicity, the painting both endorses and romanticizes the revolution. Diego Rivera&#x2019;s <italic>History of Mexico</italic> (1929&#x2013;1935), a large mural painted on the walls of the National Palace in Mexico City, depicts the domination of Mexico&#x2019;s peasants first by Spanish conquistadors, then the Catholic Church, then the Mexican army, and finally by wealthy landowners. The painting reveals the struggle of the downtrodden against oppression, a struggle that culminated in the Mexican Revolution. These are but two examples of socially and politically inspired art.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec14_5_2">
<title>Art and Social Change: I Must Protest</title>
<p>As we noted in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter1">Chapter 1</xref>, not all art is created for art&#x2019;s sake. Art serves more than an aesthetic or decorative function. Contemporary artists have strong opinions on political and social issues, and they express them in and through their work. Bertolt Brecht&#x2019;s oft-cited quip that &#x201C;art is not a mirror to reflect reality, but a hammer with which to shape it&#x201D; (as cited in <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_52">McLaren &#x0026; Leonard, 1993</xref>, p. 80) sums up this view.</p>
<p>A contemporary manifestation of this perspective can be found in protest art or the art of social activism. Such art critiques society and promotes social change (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_38">Hobbs &#x0026; Woodard, 1986</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_46">Lippard, 1984</xref>). This activity typically occurs in public spaces. For example, a bronze sculpture, called <italic>Fearless Girl</italic>, was unveiled in a highly public space near Wall Street in 2017 in honor of International Women&#x2019;s Day. The girl stands with her hands on her hips, head held high, facing down a sculpture of a charging bull that was already in place. The statue immediately sparked a public debate. Admirers said <italic>Fearless Girl</italic> sent a powerful message about the need for gender diversity in corporate America. Congresswoman Carolyn Maloney of New York declared, &#x201C;this statue has touched hearts across the world with its symbolism of the resiliency of women&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_58">O&#x2019;Connor, 2017</xref>, para. 3).</p>
<p>Critics, however, complained that the sculpture represented faux feminism, since it was commissioned by a Wall Street investment firm promoting a gender diverse fund called SHE. Arturo Di Modica, the sculptor who created the charging bull, complained that his sculpture had been hijacked. He demanded that <italic>Fearless Girl</italic> be relocated. The juxtapositioning of one icon opposite another suggested an adversarial relationship between the girl and the bull. Mayor de Blasio countered with the tweet shown in <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig14_3">Figure 14.3</xref>.</p>
<fig id="fig14_3" position="float">
<label>Figure 14.3</label>
<caption><title>Screen capture of de Blasio&#x2019;s Tweet on <italic>Fearless Girl</italic> statue.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig14_3.jpg"/>
</fig>
<p><italic>Fearless Girl</italic> achieved her purpose by provoking a public debate about gender representation in the boardroom. Activist artists seek to engage the public in their art and increase the public&#x2019;s social consciousness. As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_25">Felshin (1995)</xref> notes, such artists are &#x201C;attempting at the very least to &#x2018;change the conversation&#x2019; to empower individuals and communities, and ultimately to stimulate social change&#x201D; (p. 26). For example, a popular graffiti artist, known as Banksy, stencils images onto walls and buildings in public places at night (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_62">Pryor, 2007</xref>). One of his works depicts Dorothy and Toto, from the <italic>Wizard of Oz</italic>. Her basket is being searched by an officer in riot gear wearing <target target-type="page" id="page_344">344</target>latex gloves. The image suggests that society&#x2019;s paranoia over security has gone too far. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_22">Duncombe (2016)</xref> identifies a number of goals and functions of activist art, including altering perceptions, building community, causing disruption, fostering dialogue, promoting political change, and transforming the environment. We focus on two such functions here, involving increased awareness.</p>
<sec id="sec14_5_2_1">
<title>Awareness Through Interpretation</title>
<p>How do activist artists go about persuading? One method is by increasing <italic>awareness through interpretation</italic>. Activist art might consist of an exhibit that is odd, disturbing, or peculiar. The artist seeks to pique the viewer&#x2019;s curiosity and pull him or her in. In the process of trying to understand the work, the viewer&#x2019;s awareness is increased. Interpretation requires active thinking or central processing, which, as we learned earlier, is more likely to trigger lasting attitude change.</p>
<p>For instance, Suzanne Lacy re-created an earlier work, called <italic>Three Weeks in May</italic>, again in 2012, this time called <italic>Three Weeks in January</italic> (<uri>www.suzannelacy.com/three-weeks-in-january/</uri>). As part of a collaboration with SafeLA.org and other groups, she sought to increase public awareness of sexual assault. On a huge map of Los Angeles, she stenciled the word &#x201C;rape,&#x201D; in red block letters, at the locations where rapes had been reported, from January 12 to February 1, 2012. Before long, the map was peppered with red stencils. The exhibit provided a graphic revelation of the scope and severity of the problem.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec14_5_2_2">
<title>Awareness Through Participation</title>
<p>Yet another approach is to increase <italic>awareness through participation</italic>. Such art is collaborative or interactive. As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_25">Felshin (1995)</xref> comments, &#x201C;participation is a catalyst for social change&#x201D; (p. 12). By way of example, Wafaa Bilal created an interactive installation, called <italic>Domestic Tension</italic>, in a Chicago art gallery (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_11">Bilal &#x0026; Lydersen, 2008</xref>). Bilal, an Iraqi artist living in political asylum in the United States, occupied a Plexiglas room for one month. During this time, people went online and shot at him using a robotically controlled paintball gun. This went on 24 hours a day. They shot him in the head when he fell asleep and in the groin when he stood up. More than 60,000 shots were fired at him by strangers from more than 120 countries. Over time, some sympathetic viewers formed a &#x201C;human shield&#x201D; by trying to aim the <target target-type="page" id="page_345">345</target>gun away from Bilal. Others hacked in to the system to make the gun fire more rapidly. By the project&#x2019;s end, the room was drenched in paint and Bilal was suffering from posttraumatic stress disorder.</p>
<p>So what did viewers&#x2019; participation mean? Clearly, many people had no qualms about shooting a person online. Others were confronted with their own morality in choosing to shoot, or not to shoot, another human being. The project laid bare cultural, ethnic, and religious tensions between Westerners and Middle Easterners. By allowing virtual strangers to shoot him, Bilal focused attention on how desensitized modern societies are to violence. Killing has become robotic, clinical, and&#x2014;as in his project&#x2014;carried out from afar. When innocent civilians are killed by drone missiles, they are simply labeled &#x201C;collateral damage.&#x201D; People living comfortably in stable societies are blithely unaware of the suffering of people in conflict zones.</p>
<p>Another example of collaborative art is the AIDS Memorial Quilt, founded by Cleve Jones (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_41">Jones &#x0026; Dawson, 2000</xref>). The quilt, also known as the NAMES Project, is a folk-art project commemorating those who died of AIDS. It comprises thousands of 3 ft. &#x00D7; 6ft. panels, each dedicated to the memory of a specific person. The quilt was first displayed on the Washington Mall in 1987, and again in 1992 and 1996. It became the largest community art project in the world. Portions of the quilt are now part of traveling displays that are shown throughout the world. The panels are preserved in an archive (<uri>www.aidsquilt.org/about/the-aids-memorial-quilt</uri>).</p>
<p>The AIDS Memorial Quilt persuades on multiple levels. We often hear statistics about AIDS, but the quilt puts a human face on these numbers. Every panel is a handmade testimonial to a specific individual&#x2019;s life. When people see the quilt they understand, in concrete rather than abstract terms, the toll taken by the disease. The very choice of making a quilt was a persuasive one. Cleve Jones was attracted to the idea of quilting because it is a traditional American folk art. Quilts conjure up images of home and family. AIDS, however, was thought of as a promiscuous gay male disease. The quilt served as a means of countering that image. As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_41">Jones and Dawson (2000)</xref> note:
<disp-quote>
<p>There was hope we could beat the disease by using the quilt as a symbol of solidarity, of family and community; there was hope that we could make a movement that would welcome people&#x2014;men and women, gay and straight, of every age, race, faith, and background.</p>
<attrib>(p. 108)</attrib>
</disp-quote>
</p>
<p>The AIDS Memorial Quilt increased the public&#x2019;s awareness of the disease. It also brought people together. Loved ones who didn&#x2019;t know how to grieve found an outlet in creating a panel. This was truly participatory art. Students who have seen the quilt reported that the experience reduced their homophobia and increased their desire to practice safe sex. This fact alone demonstrates the quilt&#x2019;s persuasiveness as a work of art.</p>
<p>Activist art is often controversial. Indeed, that is its purpose. It is precisely because art has the capacity to arouse people&#x2019;s interest, attention, and ire that it is influential. A primary goal of activist artists is to raise the public&#x2019;s consciousness on a variety of social and political issues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_25">Felshin, 1995</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_38">Hobbs &#x0026; Woodard, 1986</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_46">Lippard, 1984</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_76">Von Blum, 1976</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_77">1994</xref>). Art can challenge the existing social order. It can make <target target-type="page" id="page_346">346</target>people angry. It can offend. At the same time it can heighten people&#x2019;s awareness. It can make people question their assumptions. It can change the way they see things. It can make them reconsider long-held beliefs. In doing so, art persuades.</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 14.4</label>
<caption><title>The AIDS Memorial Quilt, also known as the NAMES Project, is an example of folk art, activist art, and a social movement all in one.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig14_4.jpg"/>
<p>Source: NAMES project/AIDS Memorial Quilt. Reprinted by permission.</p>
</fig>
</sec>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec14_6">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_347">347</target>Cinematic Persuasion: Sex, Drugs, and Popcorn</title>
<p>Upon receiving an award from the American Museum of the Moving Image, Steven Spielberg remarked that cinema &#x201C;is the most powerful weapon in the world&#x201D; (cited in <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_27">Fuller, 1995</xref>, p. 190). There are several factors at work that lend films their power to persuade.<xref ref-type="fn" rid="fn14_1"><sup>1</sup></xref> First, there is the potential for mass suggestion. Millions of people are exposed to movies in the United States and abroad. In fact, movies are one of America&#x2019;s leading exports. Thus, movies reach vast audiences. Second, movies are told in a <italic>narrative</italic> form&#x2014;that is, as stories. Stories possess an aura of believability not found in other mediums for communication. When we watch a movie, we engage in a &#x201C;willing suspension of disbelief.&#x201D; In order to follow the story, we must lose ourselves in the imaginary world of the film. In so doing, we give up some of our ability to think and reason. Third, the power of films to persuade is aided by the fact that when people sit down in a theater they don&#x2019;t expect to be persuaded, they expect to be entertained. Therefore, they tend to let down their guards and become more open to suggestion. We believe this is one of the reasons that <italic>product placement</italic>&#x2014;the practice of inserting brand-name items into movie scenes&#x2014;is so prevalent. Lastly, films are carefully crafted works. Considerable planning and attention to detail go <target target-type="page" id="page_348">348</target>into the making of a film. Something as simple as a close-up or a swell in the music can enhance the intensity of emotion on the big screen. Thus, motion pictures represent finely crafted messages. Few real-world persuaders, such as salespeople, attorneys, or politicians, have the luxury of lavishing so much time and attention on their persuasive messages.</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 14.5</label>
<caption><title>&#x201C;What kind of moviemaking do we want to reinforce?&#x201D;</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig14_5.jpg"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; William Haefeli, <uri>www.cartoonbank.com</uri>. All Rights Reserved.</p>
</fig>
<sec id="sec14_6_1">
<title>Acting Out: How Movies Persuade</title>
<p>Movies persuade in multiple ways and on multiple levels. Some of the influential features are unique to particular genres of film. Docudramas, such as <italic>JFK</italic> or <italic>Titanic</italic>, for instance, may convince viewers that a subjective interpretation of events is an objective recounting of the facts (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_70">Simpson, 2008</xref>). Dramas and romantic comedies may model traditional or nontraditional gender roles. Violent movies, such as <italic>Pulp Fiction</italic>, <italic>Kill Bill</italic>, and <italic>Natural Born Killers</italic>, may desensitize people to violent or aggressive behavior. We examine some of the most important ways that films persuade here.</p>
<sec id="sec14_6_1_1">
<title>Exporting Values Abroad</title>
<p>The first of the ways in which films persuade is that American movies export <italic>Western values</italic>. As one commentator noted, &#x201C;Hollywood films are America&#x2019;s biggest cultural export, consumed by billions around the globe&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_37">Hey, 2001</xref>, p. 4). People in remote areas of the world know who Sylvester Stallone is, based on the film character <italic>Rocky.</italic> They know who Julia Roberts is from her role in <italic>Pretty Woman.</italic> American films embody Western values. Rocky was the blue-collar guy who made his dream come true. Julia Roberts was the prostitute with a heart of gold.</p>
<p>Not everyone is happy about the values promoted by American movies. Some view the movie industry as a form of cultural imperialism (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_19">Crane, 2014</xref>). As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_73">Su (2016)</xref> observes, &#x201C;American popular culture in general, and Hollywood films in particular, explicitly and actively advocate American values and the American way of life, thereby threatening other national and local cultures&#x201D; (p. 46). Foreign audiences often resent the infusion of Western values such as promiscuity, violence, and drug use into their own culture (many in the United States aren&#x2019;t too thrilled with these values either). Others resent the emphasis on materialism and conspicuous consumption. At the same time, movies can advance positive values such as freedom, human rights, and equality. The point is that movies tacitly endorse Western values that may or may not be shared by people in other cultures.</p>
<p>On the positive side, movies can promote prosocial values. Movies often champion the underdog. In <italic>Hunger Games</italic>, <italic>Rudy</italic>, and <italic>Slumdog Millionaire</italic>, the underdog perseveres and, ultimately, wins. Other films, such as <italic>Finding Nemo</italic>, <italic>My Left Foot</italic>, and <italic>Theory of Everything</italic> feature those with disabilities in a favorable light. <italic>Forrest Gump</italic> demonstrated that values such as honesty and compassion can triumph over mental and physical limitations. Fate threw hardships in his way, but Forrest showed us that it is how we deal with adversity that determines who we are. More recently, animated Disney movies, such as <italic>Brave, Mulan,</italic> and <italic>Frozen</italic> have abandoned the &#x201C;damsel in distress&#x201D; refrain in favor of assertive, independent roles for female protagonists. Films like <italic>Akeelah and the Bee</italic>, <italic>Hidden Figures</italic>, and <italic>The Princess and the Frog</italic> offer positive, uplifting roles for African American females.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec14_6_1_2">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_349">349</target>Promoting Popular Culture</title>
<p>A second way in which movies persuade is by <italic>promoting popular culture</italic> both at home and abroad. Fashions, hairstyles, habits, lifestyles, and slang terminology are often emulated by moviegoers (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_15">Chansanchai, 2001</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_75">Unterberger, 2001</xref>). If you are old enough, or into retro fashion, you may recall the popularity of white, three-piece suits following the release of the disco film <italic>Saturday Night Fever</italic>, starring John Travolta. <italic>Donnie Darko</italic> and <italic>The Crow</italic> inspired &#x201C;Goth&#x201D; culture. Katniss Everdeen&#x2019;s braided hair in <italic>Hunger Games</italic> popularized the side plait. Edward Cullen&#x2019;s upswept hair in <italic>Twilight</italic> made him a heartthrob among brooding, moody teens. After seeing Mark Wahlberg, Taylor Lautner, or Chris Hemsworth on the big screen, many guys hit the gym to work on their abs and pecs. As a function of their iconicity, movies have a way of idealizing and romanticizing trends and lifestyles. Cinema, then, is a major vehicle for the dissemination of fads, fashions, and trends.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec14_6_1_3">
<title>Modeling Behavior: Social Proof</title>
<p>A third way in which movies persuade is by <italic>modeling behaviors</italic>. People may gauge what constitutes appropriate behavior in social situations by taking a movie character&#x2019;s lead. Albert Bandura&#x2019;s <italic>social cognitive theory</italic> maintains that adolescents observe behaviors that are modeled in the media and then imitate those behaviors in real life (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_5">Bandura, 1986</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_6">1989</xref>). For example, young teens who watch movies about dating and relationships, such as <italic>Mean Girls</italic>, <italic>American Pie</italic>, and <italic>Superbad</italic>, may take their cue about how to deal with love and relationships based on behaviors they see in movies (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_8">Behm-Morawitz &#x0026; Mastro, 2008</xref>). At a subconscious level, people may enact scripts they&#x2019;ve learned from movies as well.</p>
<p>Characters in movies also model risky, unsafe, or violent behaviors. This can have the effect of legitimizing such behaviors. Movie characters rarely wear seat belts. They often engage in unprotected sex. They frequently smoke, use drugs, get drunk, and drive recklessly. Oh, and they kill lots of people. Regardless of whether these activities are intentional, their prevalence in movies tends to glamorize them. The actions of the characters in movies may be seen as placing a stamp of approval on those behaviors. For example, there is strong evidence that adolescents who see a lot of smoking on the big screen are more likely to light up. A study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_36">Heatherton and Sargent (2009)</xref> reported that teens with high exposure to smoking in movies were three times more likely to smoke than those with low exposure. The same applies to unprotected sex. More than 80 percent of PG and PG-13 rated movies include some sexual content. Exposure to sexual content increases the likelihood of unprotected sex (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_59">O&#x2019;Hara, Gibbons, Gerrard, Li, &#x0026; Sargent, 2012</xref>). Yet 98 percent of movies with sex scenes make no mention of safe sex (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_31">Gunasekera, Chapman, &#x0026; Campbell, 2005</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec14_6_1_4">
<title>Cultivation Theory: It&#x2019;s a Mean, Scary World</title>
<p>A fourth way in which movies persuade is by fostering beliefs about a world fraught with danger. Other studies have examined the effects of a steady diet of violence on TV. Would it surprise you to learn that gun violence in the top PG-13 rated movies was greater than in the top R-rated films? Such is the case (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_14">Cha, 2017</xref>). <italic>Cultivation theory</italic> maintains that the more violence people watch on TV, the more likely they are to develop an exaggerated belief in a <italic>mean, scary world</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_28">Gerbner, Gross, Morgan, &#x0026; Signorielli, 2002</xref>). In addition to developing a jaded view of the world, viewing <target target-type="page" id="page_350">350</target>violence tends to increase aggression and antisocial behavior in people. &#x201C;Fifty years of research on the effects of TV violence,&#x201D; notes <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_57">John Murray (2008)</xref>, &#x201C;leads to the inescapable conclusion that viewing media violence is related to increases in aggressive attitudes, values, and behaviors&#x201D; (p. 1212). With respect to cinema&#x2019;s influence on behavior, Oliver Stone, who directed <italic>Natural Born Killers</italic>, commented, &#x201C;Film is a powerful medium. Film is a drug. It goes into your eye. It goes into your brain. It stimulates, and that&#x2019;s a dangerous thing&#x201D; (cited in <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_45">Leiby, 1995</xref>, p. G1).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec14_6_1_5">
<title>Viewer Identification</title>
<p>A fifth way in which movies persuade is by promoting viewer identification. Moviegoers may idolize a particular actor or actress or a specific character played by that actor or actress. Perhaps you know a few Kristen Stewart or Johnny Depp &#x201C;wannabes.&#x201D; Young adults may discover &#x201C;possible selves&#x201D; from seeing movies or may derive a sense of validation from a character (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_30">Greenwood &#x0026; Long, 2015</xref>).</p>
<p>Sometimes the story of the character overlaps with the viewer&#x2019;s own experience, causing the viewer to identify with the character in the film. If you&#x2019;ve ever felt like an outcast, a nerd, the underdog, or misunderstood, you might identify with movies such as <italic>Napoleon Dynamite</italic>, <italic>Ghost World</italic>, <italic>My Big Fat Greek Wedding</italic>, <italic>Happy Times</italic>, or <italic>Pretty in Pink</italic>. In this way, movies establish a common bond with viewers.</p>
<p>Viewer identification can take place even if a viewer&#x2019;s experience doesn&#x2019;t directly overlap with that of a character in a movie. None of us have met an extraterrestrial (okay, <italic>most</italic> of us haven&#x2019;t), but we can still identify with a movie such as <italic>E.T.</italic>, because all of us have had to say goodbye to someone we love. None of us are green ogres, but we can identify with Shrek because we&#x2019;ve all felt like outsiders from time to time.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec14_6_1_6">
<title>Perpetuating Stereotypes</title>
<p>A final way in which cinema shapes public perceptions is by fostering and perpetuating stereotypes. Hollywood frequently typecasts minorities, women, overweight people, the elderly, and other groups into limited roles (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_9">Benshoff &#x0026; Griffin, 2009</xref>). This may create the impression that these are the only roles these groups are capable of performing. Although the number of parts for minorities has increased, the roles often involve the same predictable stereotypes. Middle Easterners, for example, are frequently cast as terrorists (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_68">Shaheen, 2009</xref>). When they aren&#x2019;t terrorists, they are often playboys or cab drivers. Hispanics are often depicted as drug dealers or gang-bangers. While the situation has improved, many roles for Hispanics remain tied to cultural stereotypes. Asians also tend to occupy stereotypic roles in films. If Hollywood is to be believed, every Asian is skilled in martial arts. They are often undersexed and romantically awkward (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_81">Whitty, 2001</xref>). As with other minorities, things are changing, but slowly.</p>
<p>In a similar vein, African Americans have been historically typecast (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_24">Entman &#x0026; Rojecki, 2001</xref>). African American males fit the mold of athlete, drug dealer, or musician (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_79">Waxman, 2000</xref>). African American women tend to be relegated to stereotypic roles such as beautiful wife, beautiful girlfriend, or beautiful prostitute. African Americans also are typecast as the funny sidekick in &#x201C;buddy&#x201D; movies. Eddie Murphy, Martin Lawrence, Chris Rock, and Chris Tucker have all played such parts. These, too, are narrowly defined roles. The situation has improved. Halle Berry, Jamie Foxx, Denzel Washington, and Forest Whitaker have all won Oscars for best <target target-type="page" id="page_351">351</target>actress or actor. Their success may convince filmmakers and the movie-going public that African Americans can be taken seriously on screen. In 2016, the dearth of African American Oscar nominees sparked a &#x0023;OscarsSoWhite movement, with numerous black stars boycotting the Academy Awards ceremony.</p>
<p>When it comes to stereotypic roles, women fare no better. With few exceptions women must be thin and beautiful to land starring roles (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_9">Benshoff &#x0026; Griffin, 2009</xref>). In action-adventure movies, women are depicted as powerful and objects of desire (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_50">McClearen, 2015</xref>). Women also tend to be confined to traditional roles: mother, wife, mistress, girlfriend. This isn&#x2019;t particularly surprising, given that fewer than 10 percent of screenplays are written by women, and fewer than 6 percent of movies are directed by women (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_47">Maher, 2009</xref>). Admittedly, there are some women in nontraditional roles. Nevertheless, roles for women, especially older women, remain limited.</p>
<p>If there is a silver lining, it is that younger moviegoers tend to be more tolerant, if not completely color-blind (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_80">Welkos, 2001</xref>). This is evidenced by the box-office success of recent multiethnic, multicultural movies, such as <italic>Joy Luck Club</italic>, <italic>Moana</italic>, <italic>Slum Dog Millionaire</italic>, <italic>the Big Sick</italic>, and <italic>The Help</italic>. Because youth culture includes more African Americans, Asian Americans, and Hispanic Americans, filmmakers are producing more multiethnic movies to meet the demands of a new generation of viewers.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec14_7">
<title>Images in Advertising: And Now A Word from Our Sponsors</title>
<p>&#x201C;Advertising,&#x201D; write <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_82">Woodward and Denton (1999)</xref>, &#x201C;is undoubtedly the most pervasive form of persuasion in our society&#x201D; (p. 286). When we think of pure cases of persuasion, advertising immediately comes to mind. Over &#x0024;200 billion per year is spent on advertising in the United States, with an increasing share going to digital advertising (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_71">Statista, 2017</xref>). Various estimates suggest that the average person is exposed to more than 3,000 advertising messages per day (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_23">Dupont, 1999</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_69">Simons, 2001</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_82">Woodward &#x0026; Denton, 1999</xref>). Some estimates are even higher. One estimate places daily media exposure at 15.5 hours per day (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_78">Walsh-Childers, 2017</xref>). If all the money spent on advertising were divvied up, it would work out to about &#x0024;800 per person in the United States and &#x0024;40 per person in all other countries combined (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_10">Berger, 2011</xref>). Most of us are &#x201C;armchair&#x201D; experts in advertising, having watched so many commercials during our lives. Indeed, the average American spends about one hour per day watching television commercials (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_65">Salter, 2009</xref>). That works out to more than two years of commercial viewing over an average lifespan.</p>
<p>Advertisements, whether on television, in a magazine, online, or some other medium, feature images. The visual components of such ads are often key to their effectiveness. Visually oriented ads work their magic in a variety of ways. We don&#x2019;t have enough space to examine all the ways here, so we focus on four of the most important ones.</p>
<sec id="sec14_7_1">
<title>Visual Extravaganzas: Now You&#x2019;ve Got My Attention</title>
<p>One challenge that advertisers face in trying to convince consumers to buy their products is <italic>media clutter.</italic> There are so many ads competing for consumers&#x2019; attention <target target-type="page" id="page_352">352</target>that it is difficult for a message to stand out in the crowd. Commercials must grab and hold viewers&#x2019; attention. Thanks to CGI, it is now possible for advertisers to create and manipulate images in ways previously not possible. A plain-vanilla commercial simply won&#x2019;t hold up to an eye-popping extravaganza, especially when viewers have low involvement with the topic or issue.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec14_7_2">
<title>Anti-Ads: You Can&#x2019;t Fool Me</title>
<p>Another challenge facing advertisers is that consumers are increasingly cynical about advertising. They don&#x2019;t trust Madison Avenue. But that skepticism is the very premise on which <italic>anti-ads</italic> are based. Anti-advertising, or &#x201C;subvertising&#x201D; as it is sometimes called, caters to consumers who distrust the media. Anti-ads mock advertising itself (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_4">Axelton, 1998</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_7">Beato, 1999</xref>). They denounce traditional advertising to gain acceptance by consumers.</p>
<p>Many anti-ads are spoofs on commercial advertising (see <uri>www.adbusters.org</uri>). Others are designed to sell actual products and services. Geico spoofed insurance comparison ads by conducting a mock insurance &#x201C;taste test.&#x201D; Consumers who sampled a glass of Geico said &#x201C;mmm, yum,&#x201D; while consumers who taste-tested a competing brand of auto insurance said &#x201C;ugh, yuck!&#x201D;</p>
<p>An antismoking commercial also offers an example of an anti-ad. The spot shows two cowboys in a downtown setting, one playing guitar and the other singing. The singing cowboy, however, is singing through a hand-held device pressed against his neck (an electro larynx). He&#x2019;s had a laryngectomy. He sings, &#x201C;You don&#x2019;t always die from tobacco, sometimes you just lose a lung. Oh, you don&#x2019;t always die from tobacco, sometimes they just snip out your tongue.&#x201D; This ad mocks the rugged cowboy mystique associated with Marlboro cigarettes.</p>
<p>In essence, anti-ads are telling viewers, &#x201C;Hey, you&#x2019;re on to us. You&#x2019;re too smart to be fooled.&#x201D; But of course, that strategy is itself a ploy designed to appeal to jaded consumers. Such an approach creates the perception that the advertiser respects the viewer&#x2019;s intelligence. Advertisers are constantly finding ways to reinvent themselves. As consumers have grown more skeptical, advertisers have found ways to adapt to, and capitalize on, their skepticism. Anti-ads or subvertising thus mark another evolutionary phase in advertising.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec14_7_3">
<title>Image-Oriented Advertising: Materialism as Happiness</title>
<p>In addition to using vivid imagery and anti-advertising, advertisers also seek to create positive associations between their brands and idealized images or lifestyles. This approach is known as <italic>image-oriented</italic> or <italic>image-based advertising</italic> and it is the bread and butter of modern advertising campaigns. Image-oriented ads rely on the syntactic indeterminacy of images. Remember, images don&#x2019;t contain logical operators, so they can&#x2019;t make clear-cut claims. That turns out to be a plus, however, because by pairing a product with a favorable image, an advertiser can equate the two without actually saying so in words. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_54">Messaris (1997)</xref> underscored this feature, stating that &#x201C;this ability to imply something in pictures while avoiding the consequences of saying it in words has been considered an advantage of visual advertising since the first days of its development as a mass medium&#x201D; (p. xix).</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_353">353</target>Let&#x2019;s consider some examples of this in action. Oil companies don&#x2019;t want you to think about tar-covered birds on an oil-stained beach when you envision petroleum products. They want you to associate oil companies with pro-environmental attitudes. Hence, Chevron&#x2019;s &#x201C;People do&#x201D; advertising campaign, which portrays Chevron as a guardian of endangered species.</p>
<p>Image-oriented ads portray a brand as the embodiment of an idealized lifestyle. Equating the brand with an idealized lifestyle creates identification with that brand. When we buy that brand we are buying into that lifestyle. Some brands are <italic>luxury brands</italic>, prestigious, yet within reach of many consumers (Ralph Lauren, Mercedes). Some are <italic>aspirational brands</italic>; few people can afford them, but they hope to own them one day (Armani, Rolls Royce). Still others are <italic>authentic or genuine brands</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_29">Gilmore &#x0026; Pine, 2007</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_64">Rosica, 2007</xref>). These brands are unpretentious. In a marketplace filled with fake, phony products, consumers value what seems real. A smaller brand with a story to tell may be more desirable than a mass-produced commodity. Organic foods, handmade goods, and artisanal beers fall into this category. With a little practice, you should be able to watch a TV commercial or view a magazine ad and decipher the favorable image or association the advertiser is trying to manufacture. Some of the most common associations are as follows:
<list list-type="bullet">
<list-item><p><italic>Social status and elitism:</italic> Ads for luxury cars and expensive watches often associate owning these products with prestige and success. Ads for expensive wines, luggage, jewelry, and other upscale goods often imply that the products are symbols of taste and refinement.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Sex or romance:</italic> Ads for perfume, lingerie, and hair-care products often equate the products with sexiness, allure, and romance. The association established by many perfume ads is that if you wear that fragrance you&#x2019;ll be more sexy, or other sexy people will be attracted to you.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Cause-related:</italic> Some brands have a cause to promote. Consumers aren&#x2019;t just buying a product or service, they are also helping to feed starving children, save rainforests, or protect endangered species (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_2">Adkins, 1999</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_61">Pringle &#x0026; Thompson, 1999</xref>). TOMS shoes and (Product) Red exemplify this approach. Ben &#x0026; Jerry&#x2019;s promotes social change as well by donating a percentage of their profits to social causes.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Power, speed, and strength:</italic> Ads for tools, trucks, SUVs, computers, and nutritional supplements often equate buying a product with conferring power on the user. Dodge trucks are &#x201C;Ram tough.&#x201D; Chevy trucks are built &#x201C;Like a rock.&#x201D; You, too, can have rock-hard abs or buns of steel. If you&#x2019;ve got the newest, fastest computer, you are a &#x201C;power user.&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Youth culture:</italic> A number of products are marketed by associating products with youth culture, rebelliousness, and an alternative lifestyle. Soft drinks, clothing, fast food, skateboards, small electronics, makeup, and many other goods and services appeal to what is hip, trendy, or cool. These commercials are often shot with handheld cameras and employ rapid editing techniques to simulate the look of &#x201C;reality TV.&#x201D;</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><italic>Safety, security:</italic> Ads for banking, insurance, and retirement accounts try to foster images of being safe and secure. Consumers want peace of mind and a sense of stability when it comes to their finances and retirement.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p><target target-type="page" id="page_354">354</target><italic>Sense of place, belonging:</italic> Ads for foods, restaurants, furniture, and other household goods often strive to create a sense of hominess. The advertisers want you to get a warm, comfortable, familiar feeling when you think of their products.</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
<p>These are only some of the important values and lifestyles to which advertisers attempt to link their brands. When you watch a commercial or read a print ad, you should examine the associations the advertiser is trying to establish. For decades, cigarette ads fostered the association that smoking was cool. More recently, antismoking ads have associated smoking with being uncool. Both approaches rely on the underlying assumption that &#x201C;being cool&#x201D; is what really counts in life. Is it? When evaluating a commercial or print ad, ask yourself three important questions:
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p>What image or lifestyle is being associated with the product?</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Is that image or lifestyle truly desirable? Is that the image I&#x2019;m really seeking or the lifestyle to which I truly aspire?</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Would buying the product actually grant me the image or lifestyle equated with the product? If so, how?</p></list-item>
</list>
</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec14_7_4">
<title>Shock Ads: Edgy Images as Persuasion</title>
<p>Some pro-life videos feature grisly images of late-term abortions in which the fetus has been dismembered prior to extraction. The images are intended to be repulsive. Is it acceptable to use gory images to persuade? <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_42">Kelland and Macleod (2015)</xref> note that anti-abortionists view such gruesome images as revealing the truth about the practice of abortion. Only by showing such images, anti-abortionists argue, can the immorality of the practice be revealed. Images of abortion, pro-life proponents claim, are analogous to images of the Holocaust. They must be seen to be believed.</p>
<p>In contrast, pro-choice proponents argue that grisly photos are misleading, because a small percentage of abortions are late-term. Shocking photos, pro-choice advocates maintain, ignore the circumstances of a woman who opted for a late-term abortion, such as rape, incest, severe birth defects, or a threat to the woman&#x2019;s life. The contested nature of pro-life imagery illustrates the tension between images that appeal to the head or the heart (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_42">Kelland &#x0026; Macleod, 2015</xref>).</p>
<p>Images also figure heavily into the form of advertising known as <italic>shock ads.</italic> Shock ads, or &#x201C;shockvertising&#x201D; as it has also been called, push the boundaries of taste and propriety (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_44">Lazar, 2003</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_49">McCarthy, 2000</xref>). The goal is to sell products by being edgy. Some shock ads are vulgar, some erotic, some humorous, and others nauseating. Some adopt an &#x201C;in your face&#x201D; style of advertising.</p>
<p>The Montana Meth Project ran a series of public service announcements graphically depicting the consequences of meth use. One depicted a boyfriend who &#x201C;pimped out&#x201D; his girlfriend to support their meth habit (<uri>www.youtube.com/watch?v=E-iEA6-I1xU</uri>). A billboard showed a young woman with a thousand-yard stare and the caption &#x201C;15 bucks for sex isn&#x2019;t normal, but on meth it is.&#x201D; The effectiveness of the MMP has been questioned, however (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_3">Anderson, 2010</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_48">Marsh, Copes, &#x0026; Linnemann, 2017</xref>).</p>
<p>Even shock ads can go too far. In the United Kingdom, hundreds of readers complained when they found a full-page ad showing a newborn infant with a <target target-type="page" id="page_355">355</target>cockroach in its mouth. The ad was sponsored by Barnardo&#x2019;s, a children&#x2019;s charity group, and was designed to draw attention to the plight of children living in poverty. The ad was banned by Britain&#x2019;s Advertising Standards Authority.</p>
<p>Given their widespread use, do shock ads really work? A study by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_20">Dahl, Frankenberger, and Manchanda (2003)</xref> suggests they do. These researchers concluded that &#x201C;shocking content in an advertisement significantly increases attention, benefits memory, and positively influences behavior&#x201D; (p. 1). Other studies also support the effectiveness of shock ads (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_66">Scudder &#x0026; Mill, 2009</xref>). But shock ads must walk a fine line. If they aren&#x2019;t shocking enough, they won&#x2019;t provoke the public dialogue and publicity they seek. If they are overly shocking, they may prompt a consumer rebellion. Furthermore, consumers may build up a tolerance to shocking images. One commentator warned that shock ads were analogous to drug addiction; a larger and larger dose is required to achieve the desired effect until consumers eventually overdose on the strategy (Black, cited in <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_43">Klara, 2012</xref>).</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec14_8">
<title>Photojournalism as Persuasion: The Camera Does Lie</title>
<p>Even without any accompanying text, photographs tell their own persuasive stories. Because there are entire courses offered in photojournalism, we won&#x2019;t attempt to explore the whole field here. What we wish to emphasize is that still photographs can make powerful statements. They can affect people&#x2019;s perceptions of events. They also can reach people on an emotional level in ways that words alone cannot. As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_84">Zumwalt (2001)</xref> noted, &#x201C;There is tremendous potential in a photograph to inflame emotions&#x201D; (p. B12). Because photographs don&#x2019;t require literacy or familiarity with a particular language, they also are more universally understood than messages that rely on words. Photographic images also can distort reality, as we shall see.</p>
<p>Many well-known photos serve as iconic representations of events or eras in history (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_35">Hariman &#x0026; Locaites, 2007</xref>). In all likelihood, you&#x2019;ve seen Joe Rosenthal&#x2019;s famous 1945 photo of U.S. Marines raising the Stars and Stripes at Iwo Jima. The picture symbolizes the determination of the United States to win the war in the Pacific. You may have seen John Filo&#x2019;s photo of a female student at Kent State University in 1970, kneeling over the body of a fellow student who was slain by the National Guard. That picture symbolized the schism between the protest movement and the government, as well as the generation gap of the late 1960s. You may have seen the photograph taken by Nick Ute in 1972 of a naked, 9-year-old Vietnamese girl, running down the road, with napalm burns from the bombs that had just been dropped on her village. The photo epitomized the feelings of many Americans that the United States was involved in an unjust war in Vietnam.</p>
<p>Photos can sum up social problems or controversies. They can document events in ways that words cannot. This is where the old saying, &#x201C;a picture is worth a thousand words&#x201D; applies. Owing to their iconicity, photographs can cement themselves in the public&#x2019;s mind. They function as touchstones that capture entire events in our collective conscience. The fact that so many cellphones now have cameras has elevated the role of amateur photographers. Photos can be uploaded instantly to Facebook, Twitter, and other social media.</p>
<sec id="sec14_8_1">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_356">356</target>Playing Tricks With the Camera: Photographic Deception</title>
<p>An important point to keep in mind about photographic images is that they aren&#x2019;t objective, impartial representations of things. The <italic>truth claim</italic> implied by a photograph can be misleading. All photographs are mediated by the photographer. Someone must aim the camera. Photographs give us the photojournalist&#x2019;s point of view, which is simply that&#x2014;one point of view. The photographer decides which events to capture on film, and which aren&#x2019;t worth preserving. The photographer decides on the distance, camera angle, lighting, shutter speed, and so on. The photographer decides which pictures to develop, how to edit or crop them, and which prints to offer for public consumption.</p>
<p>For example, photojournalists and news editors make decisions about which photos of war zones to publish and how gory or sanitized those images are. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_51">McEntee (2015)</xref> found that more graphic war photos (showing human carnage) evoked greater empathy than less graphic photos (showing building rubble). She contended that news outlets function as gatekeepers, deciding what the public sees, thereby shaping public opinion about conflict zones.</p>
<p>Some well-known historical and recent examples of photographic deception serve to illustrate how easily this medium can be manipulated. On June 27, 1994, <italic>Time</italic> magazine darkened O. J. Simpson&#x2019;s mug shot on one of its covers, making him appear more sinister and menacing. In the year 2000, a brochure for the University of Wisconsin&#x2013;Madison was doctored by adding an African American student into a photo of fans cheering at a football game. The manipulation was done to make the campus seem more ethnically diverse. Kim Kardashian once &#x201C;broke the Internet&#x201D; with a photo of a champagne glass balanced on her behind. But when a non-airbrushed photo of Kim Kardashian&#x2019;s derriere surfaced on the Web, fans realized all her other photos were digitally altered (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_13">Cacich, 2017</xref>). She lost 100,000 Instagram followers in a week. Wait, her fans were unaware that she had some physical and digital sculpting done? Not to worry, with 99 million followers she can afford the loss.</p>
<p>Outside of photojournalism, photos also are not carbon copies of reality either. Political attack ads often show a politician at his or her worst. Fashion magazines show models at their best. When people join online dating services, they often alter their profile photographs to appear more attractive (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_34">Hancock &#x0026; Toma, 2009</xref>). These examples underscore the point that seeing is not necessarily believing. Just because someone claims to have captured an image on film doesn&#x2019;t necessarily mean the image is genuine and unaltered. <xref ref-type="boxed-text" rid="box14_1">Box 14.1</xref> offers some useful suggestions on how to avoid being duped by photos and other visual media.</p>
<boxed-text id="box14_1">
<label>Box 14.1</label>
<caption><title>On Your Guard: Remaining Vigilant Against Visual Deception</title></caption>
<p>Images, whether in the form of television commercials, cinema, magazine ads, photojournalism, Web pages, or other media, function as powerful tools for influence. They give us a vicarious sense of &#x201C;being there.&#x201D; For this reason, we must remain wary of visual communication designed to persuade us. We&#x2019;ve all seen supermarket tabloids with doctored photos claiming &#x201C;Martian now on Supreme Court&#x201D; or some other such nonsense. We know these images can&#x2019;t be trusted. But images may be manipulated by others as well. Politicians may manipulate images for propaganda purposes. Images <target target-type="page" id="page_357">357</target>may be manipulated by lawyers to make a defendant seem innocent or guilty (&#x201C;If it doesn&#x2019;t fit, you must acquit.&#x201D;). Images may be used by the media to increase ratings (&#x201C;Stay tuned, film at 11!&#x201D;) and by advertisers to sell goods (&#x201C;Get the body you want now!&#x201D;). With this in mind, we offer the following tips and advice when evaluating persuasive images.</p>
<list list-type="order">
<list-item><p>Try to improve your <italic>visual literacy</italic>&#x2014;that is, the ability to critically analyze and evaluate visual communication (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_26">Felton, 2008</xref>). As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_55">Messaris and Moriarty (2005)</xref> note, &#x201C;visual literacy can &#x2026; be seen as a potential antidote to attempted manipulation of the viewer in TV, print, and Web-based advertising; visual journalism; and other forms of pictorial entertainment, information, or persuasion&#x201D; (p. 482).</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Don&#x2019;t succumb to the adage &#x201C;Seeing is believing.&#x201D; The camera does lie (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_12">Brugioni, 1999</xref>). What you are seeing may well be a manipulated image. When you see a fashion model on a magazine cover, for example, don&#x2019;t assume she or he looks that good in real life. The cover photo has probably been digitally altered to remove blemishes, whiten teeth, highlight hair color, etc.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Be especially wary of images on the Internet. Anyone can digitally alter an image on a home computer nowadays using Photoshop and mobile apps. If you are unsure whether to trust an image or not, try checking out some useful Web-based resources that identify hoaxes. Using Google, you can conduct a reverse image search (see <uri>www.youtube.com/watch?v=p5e9wTdAulA</uri>. <uri>www.Tineye.com</uri> also does reverse searches. We like <uri>www.snopes.com</uri> (check out their photo gallery link); factcheck.org, and Skeptical Enquirer, at <uri>www.csicop.org</uri>. For celebrity gossip, Gossip.com is useful.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>When watching so-called reality shows on TV, remember they may bear little resemblance to reality. Reality shows are carefully engineered productions. Guests or contestants typically try out for the show and are carefully vetted. This selection process allows producers to cast contestants for maximum dramatic effect. Footage can be edited so that a contestant seems braver, cleverer, more devious, more hostile, or more psycho than she/he really is. Hosts may encourage or reward certain types of behavior while discouraging others. You don&#x2019;t really think that every guest on the Jerry Springer show threw a chair on his or her own initiative, do you?</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>When viewing documentaries, keep in mind that they do not objectively recount events. They advocate a point of view. Documentaries often use techniques such as re-enactment (recreating scenes for which no original footage is available), substituted or modified footage (film of something similar or related, but not the same thing), time compression (cramming years or even centuries into a one-and-a-half-hour-long movie), and composite characters (combining several different people into one). While all these techniques may make the story easier to follow and the narrative more compelling, they come at the expense of impartiality. Some exemplars of this genre, such as Michael Moore&#x2019;s <italic>Fahrenheit 9/11</italic> and Morgan Spurlock&#x2019;s <italic>Supersize Me,</italic> have been dubbed &#x201C;mockumentaries&#x201D; or <italic>&#x201C;shockumentaries&#x201D;</italic> because the director&#x2019;s bias is so intense.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>Beware of images in diet ads, cosmetic surgery ads, supplement ads, and infomercials. Take a typical ad for a weight loss product: Notice that the person in the &#x201C;Before&#x201D; photo usually has a bland expression, poor posture, pasty skin, unkempt hair, unflattering clothes, and unflattering lighting. In comparison, the person shown in the &#x201C;After&#x201D; picture is usually smiling, has an upright posture, stylish hair, a tan and/or makeup, and flattering lighting. Does the ad say both photos are unretouched? Does the fine print acknowledge &#x201C;Results may vary&#x201D; or &#x201C;Results not typical?&#x201D; If a diet ad claims a user lost 30 pounds in two weeks, but you can see the person&#x2019;s hair is much longer in <target target-type="page" id="page_358">358</target>the &#x201C;After&#x201D; photo, then you would know that more than two weeks had passed between photos. Testimonials and the photos that accompany them are always subject to the &#x201C;hasty generalization&#x201D; fallacy.</p></list-item>
<list-item><p>The context and captioning of images can have an important impact as well. Following the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, newspapers printed two photos of survivors wading in the flood water. One Associated Press photo showed an African American male clutching a six-pack of Pepsi with the caption &#x201C;A young man walks through chest deep flood water after looting a grocery store &#x201C; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref14_63">Ralli, 2005</xref>). Another AFP/Getty photo, showed a white couple and carried the caption, &#x201C;two residents wade through chest deep water after finding bread and soda from a local grocery store.&#x201D; The captioning implied a clear double-standard: Blacks were looting, but white folks were acting out of necessity.</p></list-item>
</list>
</boxed-text>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec14_9">
<title>Summary</title>
<p>In this chapter, we&#x2019;ve examined a variety of ways in which visual stimuli, including but not limited to images, facilitate persuasion. We have not touched on all the ways in which visual cues persuade. Yet the principles we&#x2019;ve discussed about how images persuade through iconicity, indexicality, and syntactic indeterminacy apply to other forms of visual communication as well. Our society is becoming increasingly visually oriented. More people now get their news from television than from newspapers. More people now watch movies than read books. Persuaders are capitalizing on this trend by enlisting images in support of their persuasive endeavors. Based on what you&#x2019;ve learned in this chapter, you should be able to watch a television commercial, see a movie, or read a print ad with a sharper eye toward the strategic choices made by the persuader. In short, we hope you will be a wiser consumer of visual persuasion.</p>
</sec>
</body>
<back>
<fn-group>
<title>Note</title>
<fn id="fn14_1"><label>1</label><p>Most of our comments about cinematic persuasion apply equally to television shows. Television shows, however, typically have smaller budgets and tighter production schedules. Hence, they are less polished works. Nevertheless, many TV series have altered attitudes and behavior in the same ways as films.</p></fn>
</fn-group>
