<ref id="ref14_75"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Unterberger</surname>, <given-names>L.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2001</year>, <month>July</month> <day>16</day>). <article-title>Mimicking a movie star</article-title>. <source>The Milwaukee Sentinel Journal</source>, p. <fpage>4E</fpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref14_76"><mixed-citation publication-type="book"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Von Blum</surname>, <given-names>P.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>1976</year>). <source>The art of social conscience</source>. <publisher-loc>New York</publisher-loc>: <publisher-name>Universe Books</publisher-name>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref14_77"><mixed-citation publication-type="book"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Von Blum</surname>, <given-names>P.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>1994</year>). <source>Other visions, other voices: Women political artists in greater Los Angeles</source>. <publisher-loc>Lanham, MD</publisher-loc>: <publisher-name>University Press of America</publisher-name>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref14_78"><mixed-citation publication-type="book"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Walsh-Childers</surname>, <given-names>K.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2017</year>). <source>Mass media and heath: Examining media impact on individuals and the health environment</source>. <publisher-loc>New York</publisher-loc>: <publisher-name>Routledge</publisher-name>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref14_79"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Waxman</surname>, <given-names>S.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2000</year>, <month>December</month> <day>21</day>). <article-title>1999 saw more roles for minorities in film, TV</article-title>. <source>The Washington Post</source>, p. <fpage>C7</fpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref14_80"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Welkos</surname>, <given-names>R. W.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2001</year>, <month>July</month> <day>2</day>). <article-title>Multiethnic movies ringing true with youths</article-title>. <source>Los Angeles Times</source>, p. <fpage>A1</fpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref14_81"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Whitty</surname>, <given-names>S.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2001</year>, <month>August</month> <day>26</day>). <article-title>Who are the Asians on screen? New stereotypes no better than old</article-title>. <source>The San Diego Union Tribune</source>, p. <fpage>F2</fpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref14_82"><mixed-citation publication-type="book"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Woodward</surname>, <given-names>G. C.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Denton</surname>, <given-names>R. E.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>1999</year>). <source>Persuasion and influence in American life</source> (<edition>3rd</edition> ed.). <publisher-loc>Prospect Heights, IL</publisher-loc>: <publisher-name>Wadsworth</publisher-name>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref14_83"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Zimmerman</surname>, <given-names>N.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2012</year>, <month>June</month> <day>22</day>). <article-title>Supermarket offers free groceries to first 100 naked shoppers</article-title>. <uri>www.gawker.com</uri>. <date-in-citation content-type="retrieved">Retrieved on <month>July</month> <day>7</day>, <year>2012</year></date-in-citation> from: <uri>http://gawker.com/5920613/supermarket-offers-free-groceries-to-first-100-naked-shoppers</uri></mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref14_84"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Zumwalt</surname>, <given-names>J.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2001</year>, <month>November</month> <day>13</day>). <article-title>How a powerful image can shape a war</article-title>. <source>Los Angeles Times</source>, p. <fpage>B12</fpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
</ref-list>
</back>
</book-part>
<book-part book-part-type="chapter" id="chapter15">
<book-part-meta>
<title-group>
<label>15</label>
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_363">363</target>Esoteric Forms of Persuasion</title>
<alt-title alt-title-type="running-head">Esoteric Forms of Persuasion</alt-title>
</title-group>
<contrib-group>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Gass</surname>
<given-names>Robert H.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
<contrib contrib-type="author">
<name name-style="western">
<surname>Seiter</surname>
<given-names>John S.</given-names>
</name>
</contrib>
</contrib-group>
</book-part-meta>
<body>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_364">364</target>PREVIOUS CHAPTERS HAVE DEALT with fairly &#x201C;mainstream&#x201D; types of persuasion. In this chapter, we examine more esoteric forms of persuasion. The topics we discuss in this section often receive short shrift or are neglected entirely by other texts. Yet we find that these are among the most interesting topics to students and laypersons. We include them here partly because they are so intriguing, partly because there are important research findings, and partly to debunk some of the myths and superstitions surrounding these topics. The topics we&#x2019;ll examine are color, subliminal persuasion, backward masking or reverse speech, neurolinguistic programming, music as persuasion, and the role of smell in persuasion.</p>
<sec id="sec15_1">
<title>Color as Persuasion: The Grass is Always Greener</title>
<p>Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Arizona was known as &#x201C;America&#x2019;s toughest sheriff.&#x201D; Besides making male prisoners work on chain gangs, he also required them to wear pink underwear&#x2014;that is, until an appeals court overturned the practice. Wrote one justice, &#x201C;it is a fair inference that the color is chosen to symbolize a loss of masculine identity&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_27">Williams, 2012</xref>, p. AA-2). Whether one agrees with Arpaio&#x2019;s methods or not, clearly color was being used as an instrument of power and control.</p>
<p>In this section, we examine some of the ways in which color influences people. The meanings we assign to color are based, in part, on biology and, in part, on culture and socialization (Genschow, Reutner, &#x0026; W&#x00E4;nke, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_9">2012</xref>). In nature, for example, red often serves as a warning, or <italic>aposematism</italic>, signifying toxicity. In human society, red often signifies danger as well. Ignore a red stop sign or a red traffic light, for example, and you do so at your own risk.</p>
<sec id="sec15_1_1">
<title>Color Coded at Birth: Dyed in the Wool</title>
<p>Color exerts an enormous influence on our lives&#x2014;and not just in our choice of undies. Take clothing colors, for instance. In much of the United States and Western Europe, newborn girls are swaddled in pink, boys in blue. Thus, gender differentiation, through color, begins in infancy (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_22">Paoletti, 2012</xref>). In old Westerns, the good guys wear white hats, the bad guys black. Good and evil are thus differentiated by color. Business executives often wear &#x201C;power&#x201D; colors to signify their status. Brides traditionally wear white to symbolize their purity. Schools adopt uniforms to minimize clothes consciousness and focus students&#x2019; attention on learning. Soldiers and hunters wear camouflage clothing to evade detection. Scientists wear white lab coats, at least on TV, to convey their expertise. Gang members display their gangs&#x2019; colors to mark their turf. Sports fans wear color-coordinated clothing, or even face paint, to express their identification with their team.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_1_2">
<title>Colorful Associations: A Blonde Walks Into a Bar &#x2026;</title>
<p>In <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter3">Chapter 3</xref>, we discussed the importance of attitudinal associations. We also have strong associations with colors. In politics, for instance, states are referred to as red or blue based on their political leanings. Likewise, we often classify occupations according to colors of collars: white, blue, and sometimes pink or green. The meanings attached to such colors shape our beliefs, attitudes, and behaviors. For example, companies boast about their green initiatives&#x2014;which, not coincidentally, makes for good PR. A recent study shows this strategy is effective. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_24">Seo and Scammon (2017)</xref> <target target-type="page" id="page_365">365</target>asked college students to evaluate a product, based only on its packaging. All versions included a label expressing support for the Sierra Club&#x2019;s environmental work. What differed was the color of the packaging: Green, red, blue, yellow, or gray. Products with green or blue packaging were rated more positively than the other colors.</p>
<p>The associations we have with colors are highly contextual. At a funeral, wearing black conveys grief or sorrow. At a nightclub, however, wearing black may suggest class or elegance. Red may signify sin in one context (red light district, scarlet woman) or reverence in another (the Pope&#x2019;s red shoes, red vestments). The meanings associated with colors are also culture bound. Traditionally, brides in America have worn white gowns, while brides in China have worn red gowns. That has changed, though, with more Chinese brides adopting the Western white wedding gown (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_17">Labrecque, Patrick, &#x0026; Milne, 2013</xref>).</p>
<sec id="sec15_1_2_1">
<title>Seeing Red</title>
<p>To better illustrate how associations with colors can affect attitudes and behavior, let&#x2019;s examine the color red in a specific context: Grading students&#x2019; papers. Has a teacher ever returned a paper to you that was &#x201C;bleeding&#x201D; with red ink? Did it make you feel like a dunce? If so, you are not alone. Studies on the <italic>red pen effect</italic>, as it is known, have prompted many school districts to encourage teachers to avoid marking papers in red, which is associated with failure, in favor of purple or some other color. You may scoff, but as it turns out, the color red significantly affects students and teachers alike. Studies show that even brief exposure to the color red before or during a challenging intellectual task can activate thoughts of failure and hinder performance (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_5">Elliot, Maier, Binser, Friedman, &#x0026; Pekrun, 2009</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_7">Elliot, Maier, Moller, Friedman, &#x0026; Meinhardt, 2007</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_19">Lichtenfeld, Maier, Elliot, &#x0026; Pekrun, 2009</xref>). What&#x2019;s more, using a red pen affects the grader, too. Evaluators who graded essays using red pens identified significantly more mistakes than evaluators who used blue pens. Red pens thus predisposed the evaluators to grade more harshly (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_23">Rutchick, Slepian, &#x0026; Ferris, 2010</xref>). Our advice: Give your instructor a purple pen when you submit your next paper. If you are a teacher, manager, or other evaluator, consider using a less pejorative color to minimize defensiveness. Even positive feedback in red may be ignored.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_1_3">
<title>Color and Branding: Big Blue, Red Bull, and Pink (Victoria&#x2019;s Secret)</title>
<p>Not only do corporations use logos to identify their brands, they also rely on color. Color is &#x201C;a central aspect of a brand&#x2019;s visual identity&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_17">Labrecque, Patrick, &#x0026; Milne, 2013</xref>, p. 193). To illustrate, if you were told that a laptop was white, could you guess the brand? A Mac, no doubt. Color serves as an identifier for many brands, such as McDonald&#x2019;s (golden arches), Coke (red), and Rabobank (orange and blue). According to one source, color can increase brand recognition by 80 percent (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_11">Goldstein, 2011</xref>). Philanthropic causes also use color to gain recognition. Livestrong&#x2019;s yellow wristbands and the Susan G. Komen Foundation&#x2019;s pink ribbons are cases in point.</p>
<p>In some instances, a color becomes synonymous with a brand, such as UPS&#x2019;s ubiquitous Pullman brown trucks or Reese&#x2019;s Pieces&#x2019; orange, yellow, and brown wrappers. What&#x2019;s more, the distinctive colors of a particular brand are often trademarked. T-Mobile&#x2019;s specific shade of magenta is a trademarked color. So is Tiffany&#x2019;s distinctive robin-egg blue. Owens-Corning even trademarked the shade of <target target-type="page" id="page_366">366</target>pink used in its fiberglass insulation. One of the ever-gullible authors bought a John Deere tractor largely because he liked its venerable green and yellow color, which is trademarked (see <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig15_1">Figure 15.1</xref>). Companies protect their brand colors, too. Cadbury won a lawsuit for trademark infringement when Nestl&#x00E9; also tried to market a chocolate bar with a purple wrapper (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_4">Clark, 2011</xref>). A similar suit was filed by high heel designer, Christian Louboutin, whose pricey shoes have distinctive red soles, against Yves Saint Laurent.</p>
<fig id="fig15_1" position="float">
<label>Figure 15.1</label>
<caption><title>An author aboard his trusty John Deere tractor.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig15_1.jpg"/>
<p>Source: Photo by Debora Seiter.</p>
</fig>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_1_4">
<title>Color and Emotion: Mood Indigo</title>
<p>We often refer to emotions by color. You might hear someone say, &#x201C;I&#x2019;m feeling blue,&#x201D; &#x201C;He&#x2019;s seeing red,&#x201D; &#x201C;She was green with envy,&#x201D; or &#x201C;I&#x2019;m tickled pink.&#x201D; A meta-analysis revealed that different colors can and do affect our emotional state (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_13">Jalil, Yunus, &#x0026; Said, 2012</xref>). Individual color preferences, quite obviously, are a major determinant in whether a given color is viewed favorably or unfavorably. Generally speaking, warm colors such as red, orange, and yellow tend to be more stimulating, while cool colors, such as blue, green, and purple tend to be more calming. As Gob&#x00E9; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_10">2009</xref>) explains, &#x201C;Colors with long wavelengths are arousing (e.g., red is the most stimulating color that will attract the eye faster than any other) and colors with short wavelengths are soothing (e.g., blue, which actually lowers blood pressure, pulse, and respiration rates)&#x201D; (p. 80).</p>
<p>Consistent with this generalization, males rated a female wearing a red blouse as more sexually attractive than the same female wearing a blue blouse (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_6">Elliot &#x0026; Niesta, 2008</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_21">Niesta Kayser, Elliot, &#x0026; Feltman, 2010</xref>). Similarly, waitresses wearing red lipstick, as compared with pink, brown, or no lipstick, earned higher tips, but only <target target-type="page" id="page_367">367</target>from male customers (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_12">Gu&#x00E9;guen &#x0026; Jacob, 2012</xref>). In addition, observers rated rooms with warm colors as more exciting and cool colors as more restful (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_28">Yildirim, Hidayetoglu, &#x0026; Capanoglu, 2011</xref>). Want your new store to encourage hustle and bustle? Use warm colors. Want it to foster a sense of relaxation? Go with cool colors.</p>
<sec id="sec15_1_4_1">
<title>Women in White, Men in Blue</title>
<p>Uniform colors also evoke different emotional responses in people. Suppose you were a little kid about to get a vaccination. Would the nurse&#x2019;s uniform color affect your anxiety level? It just might. One study found that blue uniforms were perceived by kids as more calming than white uniforms (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_1">Albert, Burke, Bena, Morrison, Forney, &#x0026; Krajewksi, 2013</xref>). For adult patients, nurses in white uniforms were perceived as more competent, professional, and efficient, whereas nurses wearing printed patterns were perceived as more caring, attentive, and approachable (Kucuk, L., &#x00C7;&#x00F6;mez, T., Ka&#x00E7;ar, S., S&#x00FC;meli, F., &#x0026; Tas&#x00B8;kiran, &#x00D6;, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_16">2015</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_25">Skorupski &#x0026; Rea, 2006</xref>). Thus, one color of scrubs might be better suited for an emergency room (ER) and another color or pattern for an intensive care unit (ICU).</p>
<p>Let&#x2019;s consider another type of uniform. Imagine you&#x2019;ve just been pulled over by a police officer. Would the color of the officer&#x2019;s uniform affect your emotional state? Research shows that all-black uniforms are the most intimidating (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_14">Johnson, 2005</xref>). Black is authoritative, commanding more respect and attention (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_20">Nickels, 2008</xref>). However, a uniform consisting of a light-blue shirt and navy pants was judged to be more warm, friendly, and honest than all black (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_14">Johnson, 2005</xref>). Which image is most important for cops to project? Uniform colors may affect police officers&#x2019; behavior too. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_15">Johnson (2013)</xref> found that police departments with dark uniforms were significantly more likely to use deadly force than departments with lighter uniforms.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_1_5">
<title>Color and Behavior: Hue Made Me Do It</title>
<p>Color influences consumer ratings of products and product purchases. Color is one of the first cues that we perceive about products, often before we can touch, smell, or taste them. The use of color in product packaging therefore matters a great deal (Lichtl&#x00E9;, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_18">2007</xref>). A color&#x2013;product mismatch can turn off consumers. Would you buy Pepto Bismol if it were grey? Would you like Tidy Bowl if it made your toilet water red? We suspect not. Color also can be used to prime consumer reactions. In one study, participants were given orange or green pens to evaluate two soft drinks, one in an orange container (Fanta orange), the other in a green container (Sprite). Pen color functioned as a peripheral cue, such that ratings for Fanta were higher when using an orange pen and higher for Sprite when using a green pen (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_2">Berger &#x0026; Fitzsimons, 2008</xref>).</p>
<p>Some of the ways in which color affects behavior are a bit weird. Take snacking, for example. When snacks are served on red plates or drinks in red cups, people tend to consume less (Genschow, Reutner, &#x0026; W&#x00E4;nke, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_9">2012</xref>). Why? Partly due to biology and partly due to social conditioning, red evokes avoidance reactions. As noted earlier, red is associated with danger, risk, and hazards. This finding may seem trivial until you consider the current epidemic of childhood obesity in the United States and elsewhere. If simple measures such as serving meals on red plates or trays can help reduce food intake, they are worth considering by parents, school districts, and health agencies.</p>
<sec id="sec15_1_5_1">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_368">368</target>The Color&#x2013;Aggression Link: Men in Black</title>
<p>A host of studies have examined whether uniform color affects sports performance. Does donning a black uniform make an athlete think, &#x201C;I&#x2019;m <italic>bad</italic>&#x201D;? An early study (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_8">Frank &#x0026; Gilovich, 1988</xref>) found that NFL and NHL teams with black uniforms racked up more penalties. The finding was attributed, in part, to greater aggression by players and, in part, to selective perception by referees. Other studies have questioned the <italic>color&#x2013;aggression link</italic>, finding no differences (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_3">Caldwell &#x0026; Burger, 2011</xref>). A larger study, however, confirmed the link. Data from 25 NHL seasons (52,098 games) revealed that players wearing black uniforms were penalized more often, about two minutes of penalty time per game on average, than players wearing white (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_26">Webster, Urland, &#x0026; Correll, 2012</xref>). There may a &#x201C;chicken&#x2013;egg&#x201D; question involved as well. Do black uniforms make teams more aggressive or do more aggressive teams choose to wear black uniforms?</p>
<p>Color is not the &#x201C;be all and end all&#x201D; of persuasion. Nevertheless, color has an important supporting role to play on the stage of persuasion. Color can facilitate or inhibit influence attempts through associations, by activating attitudes or stereotypes, by evoking moods and emotional responses, and by altering behavior.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_2">
<title>Subliminal Influence: Hidden Messages or Hokum?</title>
<p>A good deal of misinformation surrounds the topic of subliminal influence. Most Americans believe subliminal messages are not only common in advertising but that they are highly effective as well (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_33">Broyles, 2006</xref>). Public belief in subliminal persuasion dates to the 1950s, when James Vicary claimed to have flashed the words &#x201C;Eat popcorn&#x201D; and &#x201C;Drink Coca-Cola&#x201D; on a movie screen. Allegedly, popcorn sales increased by almost 58 percent and Coke sales by 18 percent (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_51">Rogers, 1992</xref>&#x2013;1993). Thus was born an urban myth. Vicary never achieved the results he claimed. His so-called experiment was merely a publicity stunt.</p>
<sec id="sec15_2_1">
<title>The Laboratory Versus the Real World</title>
<p>The fact of the matter is that subliminal effects have been documented clearly and convincingly in controlled laboratory conditions but almost never in real-world settings. The examples found in the real world tend to be isolated cases rather than organized attempts at &#x201C;mind control.&#x201D; Most cases involving the use of subliminals appear to be pranks. Some Disney movies, for example, contain embedded images, but these appear to be acts of mischief by individual artists and animators rather than a corporate conspiracy (see, for example, <uri>www.snopes.com/disney/films/films.asp</uri>). Mind you, these cases only demonstrate that subliminal messages exist, not that they work.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_2_2">
<title>What Is and Isn&#x2019;t Subliminal</title>
<p>Let&#x2019;s begin by clearing up some confusion surrounding the term <italic>subliminal</italic>. Literally, the term means below (<italic>sub</italic>) the threshold (<italic>limen</italic>) of human consciousness. Thus, a subliminal stimulus is one that is processed without conscious awareness. This is in contrast to <italic>supraliminal</italic> messages that are consciously processed. An image that is flashed so quickly that a person can&#x2019;t consciously register it is subliminal. An image <target target-type="page" id="page_369">369</target>that is fleeting yet recognizable is supraliminal. Subtle is not the same as subliminal. This distinction is important, because product placements in movies and TV shows are <italic>not</italic> subliminal. Advertisers <italic>want</italic> you to notice their products and/or logos.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_2_3">
<title>Subliminal Advertising: Much Ado About Nothing</title>
<p>In the 1970s and 1980s, &#x201C;pop psychology&#x201D; books and magazine articles made it seem as if every ice cube in a magazine ad contained a hidden phallic symbol. Brian Wilson Key championed this view with his popular but unscientific books on subliminal advertising (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_41">Key, 1972</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_42">1976</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_43">1980</xref>). We&#x2019;ve looked at the particular ads in question and, although we can discern some of the symbols and shapes Key mentions, we find his approach somewhat akin to staring at clouds. If one looks long enough and hard enough, one is bound to see a rubber ducky, the Virgin Mary, or some other vaguely discernible shape.</p>
<sec id="sec15_2_3_1">
<title>Embedded Images</title>
<p>More rigorous studies were carried out from the mid-1970s through the mid-1990s, many of which focused on <italic>embedded images</italic>. Embedded images are buried or hidden within an advertisement. Researchers, however, were unable to substantiate any of the grandiose claims about hidden images making people want things or buy things (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_36">Gable, Wilkens, &#x0026; Harris, 1987</xref>).</p>
<p>Studies examining embedded sexual imagery have found some effects, but only in controlled laboratory settings. For example, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_37">Gillith and Collins (2016)</xref> found that subliminal exposure to unclothed versus clothed opposite sex images increased the desire to have sex. This was measured, however, only by whether participants (mostly males) were more likely to choose a condom or a pen as a reward for participating. Another investigation (Wernicke, Hofter, Jordan, Fromberger, Dechent, &#x0026; M&#x00FC;ller, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_65">2017</xref>) using fMRI (neural imaging) identified some brain activity associated with subliminal sexual stimuli, but the findings were inconclusive.</p>
<p>Results like these led <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_58">Trappey (1996)</xref> to conclude in his meta-analysis that &#x201C;the results show no significant positive or negative effect &#x2026; subliminal advertising does little to influence consumer behavior&#x201D; (p. 527). After reviewing 50 years&#x2019; worth of research on subliminal advertising, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_33">Broyles (2006)</xref> similarly announced that &#x201C;subliminal advertising just is not effective&#x201D; (p. 405). More recent books, such as Bullock&#x2019;s <italic>The Secret Sales Pitch</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_34">2004</xref>), also have been faulted for making unsubstantiated claims about subliminal ads (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_33">Broyles, 2006</xref>). In 2011, Jeff Warrick aired a documentary entitled <italic>Programming the Nation?</italic>, which relied on dated, anecdotal evidence of subliminal advertising (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_35">Catsoulis, 2011</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_2_3_2">
<title>Proof of Existence Is Not Proof of Effectiveness</title>
<p>A key point to bear in mind is that the mere existence of subliminal messages does not prove their effectiveness. Let&#x2019;s assume, for the sake of argument, that there are subliminal messages in some Disney movies. In what way are they influential? Where is the proof that they have any effect on viewers, other than providing fodder for conspiracy theorists? If they are more than isolated pranks, how would they advance Disney&#x2019;s business model of providing family-friendly entertainment?</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_2_4">
<title><target target-type="page" id="page_370">370</target>Subliminal Priming: That Rings a Bell</title>
<p>There is scant evidence that subliminal influence works in advertising. In laboratory studies, however, a method known as <italic>subliminal priming</italic> has enjoyed considerable success (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_29">Bargh, 2002</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_44">Kouider &#x0026; Dehaene, 2007</xref>). A meta-analysis of masked prime studies found strong support for the technique (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_59">Van den Bussche, Van den Noortgate, &#x0026; Reynvoet, 2009</xref>). So compelling is the evidence for priming that Brintazzoli, Soetens, Deroost, and Van den Bussche (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_32">2012</xref>) declared, &#x201C;the existence of unconscious subliminal perception is no longer questioned in an experimental context&#x201D; (p. 824).</p>
<p>Methods vary, but a typical priming technique is as follows. First, participants view a <italic>masked prime</italic>. The mask is simply a string of characters covering up a word. For example, the characters &#x0023;&#x0023;&#x0023;&#x0023; could be used to mask the word <italic>salt</italic>. Second, the mask is removed and the <italic>subliminal prime</italic> is presented. Thus, the word <italic>salt</italic> might appear for 30 milliseconds, too quickly to be consciously perceived. Third, a <italic>target word</italic> that is consciously visible, for example, the word <italic>pepper</italic>, replaces the prime. Participants who are primed by the word <italic>salt</italic> tend to recognize the word <italic>pepper</italic> faster than participants who are not primed.</p>
<sec id="sec15_2_4_1">
<title>Importance of a Prior Need or Drive</title>
<p>For priming to work, however, it appears that a prior need or drive state must exist (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_56">Strahan, Spencer, &#x0026; Zanna, 2002</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_60">Verwijmeren, Karremans, Bernritter, Stroebe, &#x0026; Wigboldus, 2011</xref>). That is, for a subliminal prime about food to work, a person must be hungry. For a subliminal prime about a beverage to be effective, a person must be thirsty. The need or drive state increases receptivity to priming. In a controlled setting, for example, participants were exposed to subliminal images of happy or angry faces (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_66">Winkielman, Berridge, &#x0026; Wilbarger, 2005</xref>). Then they sampled a lemon-lime-flavored drink. After reporting how thirsty they were, the participants were instructed to drink as much as they wanted. Participants exposed to the happy faces consumed much more of the new drink than those exposed to the angry faces, but only&#x2014;and this is the key&#x2014;if they were already thirsty. The amounts consumed by nonthirsty participants, whether exposed to happy or angry faces, did not differ significantly. Priming thus appeared to act as a trigger, but only for those whose thirst needed to be quenched.</p>
<p>Other studies have found similar results. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_31">Bermeitinger, Goelz, Johr, Neumann, Ecker, and Doerr (2009)</xref> asked participants to complete a task requiring high concentration. Half were well rested; the other half were tired. Before completing the task, participants in each group were subliminally primed with logos for a sugar pill called Dextro. Primed participants, who were also tired, consumed far more sugar pills than those who were not tired. The investigators concluded that &#x201C;subjects&#x2019; choice of a specific product is influenced by subliminally presented information only if there is a motivational state congruent with the subliminally presented stimulus&#x201D; (p. 325).</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_2_5">
<title>Not So Fast: Limitations of Subliminal Priming</title>
<p>Although priming has been demonstrated in controlled laboratory settings, we wish to emphasize the practical limitations of this technique. Participants in laboratories are free from other distractions. They are instructed to pay close attention to the priming messages. The target words immediately follow the primes. The effects of priming are <target target-type="page" id="page_371">371</target>also fleeting. As Brintazzoli and colleagues (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_32">2012</xref>) cautioned, &#x201C;the short-lived nature of the influence of subliminal information casts serious doubt on its effectiveness in everyday life and advertising&#x201D; (p. 825). What&#x2019;s more, the minor effects of priming in laboratory studies can be nullified simply by informing participants of the presence of a subliminal message and warning them not to be influenced (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_61">Verwijmeren, Karremans, Bernritter, Stroebe, &#x0026; Wigboldus, 2013</xref>). The real world is a very different environment, one chock-full of media clutter. A myriad of supraliminal stimuli vie for our attention. People don&#x2019;t always pay close attention to messages. We are aware of no studies demonstrating any commercial success at using subliminal priming.</p>
<p>By the way, do you suddenly feel smarter or like this book even more? The reason we ask is because we included a &#x201C;subliminal&#x201D; message at the top of p. 369. It is in very small type. Did you see it? Did it consciously register? Did it work?</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_2_6">
<title>Subaudible Messages: The Power of Suggestion</title>
<p>How would you like to lower your blood pressure, improve your memory, lose weight, release your body&#x2019;s natural healing forces, stop procrastinating, and win the lottery? These are just <italic>some</italic> of the claims that have been made on behalf of subliminal self-help audiotapes and CDs. The problem is that they don&#x2019;t work (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_30">Benoit &#x0026; Thomas, 1992</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_39">Greenwald, Spangenberg, Pratkanis, &#x0026; Eskenazi, 1991</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_47">Mitchell, 1995</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_53">Spangenberg, Obermiller, &#x0026; Greenwald, 1992</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_55">Staum &#x0026; Brotons, 1992</xref>). Other than provide soothing sounds, hiding reaffirming messages in ambient music accomplishes nothing. Believing can, in and of itself, produce changes in people, but such changes are the result of a <italic>placebo effect</italic> and have nothing to do with the content of the tapes or CDs themselves. A placebo effect follows the age-old notion that &#x201C;thinking makes it so.&#x201D;</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_2_7">
<title>Backward Masking and Reverse Speech: Turn Me On, Dead Man</title>
<p>Can satanic, backward-masked lyrics cause impressionable teens to commit suicide? That is what the plaintiffs in a lawsuit filed against Ozzy Osbourne&#x2019;s record label claimed. The suit charged that backward-masked lyrics on the <italic>Blizzard of Ozz</italic> album drove a teen to commit suicide (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_40">Harmon, 1995</xref>). A similar suit was filed by the parents of two teens who committed suicide after listening to backward-masked lyrics on Judas Priest&#x2019;s <italic>Stained Class</italic> album (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_38">Goleman, 1990</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_49">Phillips, 1990</xref>). In both cases, the judges ruled in favor of the defendants, citing the lack of any causal connection between the reversed lyrics and the teens&#x2019; deaths. The authors have listened to both albums and have experienced no suicidal tendencies. Justin Bieber tunes, however, are another story! All kidding aside, there are no credible studies showing that listening to reversed speech produces any effects. As <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_52">Smith (2011)</xref> noted, &#x201C;Psychological studies have produced no evidence that listeners are influenced, consciously or unconsciously, by the content of backward messages&#x201D; (p. 539).</p>
<p>It is possible to infer meanings from reversed speech, but these may be a matter of coincidence. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_62">Vokey (2002)</xref>, for example, noted that the phrase &#x201C;Jesus loves you,&#x201D; when played backward, sounds like &#x201C;we smell sausage&#x201D; (p. 248). Some rock songs do contain backward-masked lyrics (the Beatles&#x2019; song &#x201C;Revolution 9&#x201D; and Pink Floyd&#x2019;s &#x201C;Goodbye Blue Sky,&#x201D; for example) but, as is the case with subliminal messages, their mere <italic>presence</italic> doesn&#x2019;t prove their <italic>effectiveness</italic>. Scientific studies of <target target-type="page" id="page_372">372</target>backward masking have failed to demonstrate any effects on listeners (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_45">Kreiner, Altis, &#x0026; Voss, 2003</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_46">Langston &#x0026; Anderson, 2000</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_57">Swart &#x0026; Morgan, 1992</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_63">Vokey &#x0026; Read, 1985</xref>).</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 15.2</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig15_2.tif"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; Robert Mankoff/ The New Yorker Collection/ <uri>www.cartoonbank.com</uri>. All Rights Reserved.</p>
</fig>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_2_8">
<title>What Advertisers Really Do</title>
<p>Advertisers are not really interested in subliminals, subaudible messages, or reverse speech. What advertisers seek to do is to connect their products with favorable images and idealized lifestyles. Product placement is one way of accomplishing this. Placements in movies and TV exceed &#x0024;6 billion dollars per year (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_50">PQ Media, 2015</xref>). According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_48">Morgan (2005)</xref> &#x201C;between 15&#x2013;30 products are inserted into every half hour of television programming&#x201D; (p. 62). Morgan Spurlock&#x2019;s (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_54">2011</xref>) documentary <italic>The Greatest Movie Ever Sold</italic> lampoons this trend.</p>
<p>Placements may be blatant or subtle, but they are in no sense subliminal. Some product placements operate at a low level of awareness, but they remain a form of supraliminal persuasion. In sum, we believe consumers have little to fear from subliminal advertising at this time.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_3">
<title>Neurolinguistic Programming: The Emperor&#x2019;s New Clothes</title>
<p>Did you know that by uttering a few magical words, you can get anyone to do your bidding? Some folks would like you to believe in such hocus-pocus. They claim <target target-type="page" id="page_373">373</target>that they can teach you, in a few easy steps, how to hypnotize people with your words. Some claim their techniques will help you get dates, overcome phobias, cure depression, improve spelling, alleviate colds and flu, and enlarge your breasts or penis.</p>
<p>Don&#x2019;t reach for your wallet just yet. What these folks are peddling is based on <italic>neurolinguistic programming,</italic> or NLP, which is a mix of linguistics, psychology, and hypnotism (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_71">Gow, Reupert, &#x0026; Maybery, 2006</xref>). The original theory, developed by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_67">Richard Bandler and John Grinder (1975</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_68">1979</xref>), lies somewhere between pop psychology and junk science. It is popular with authors of self-help books, such as Tony Robbins, and others on the lecture circuit. Despite the extravagant claims, there is scant evidence that NLP works. Indeed, although one meta-analysis (Zaharia, Reiner, &#x0026; Sch&#x00FC;tz, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_80">2015</xref>) found positive results when using NLP to reduce phobias, the authors acknowledged that &#x201C;there is a major lack of high-quality data from observational, experimental studies or randomized trials on this field&#x201D; (p. 361). What&#x2019;s more, most credible experts, e.g., those who don&#x2019;t stand to profit by writing, speaking, or training about the subject, denounce NLP as a form of pseudoscience (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_69">Corballis, 1999</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_72">Gumm, Walker, &#x0026; Day, 1982</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_73">Heap, 1988</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_74">2008</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_77">Sharpley, 1984</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_78">1987</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_79">Thaler Singer &#x0026; Lalich, 1996</xref>).</p>
<p>The basic idea behind NLP is that a person&#x2019;s inner, unconscious mind determines how he or she responds to persuasive messages. All persuaders have to do is use a few clever linguistic strategies and&#x2014;presto!&#x2014;they can &#x201C;program&#x201D; another person&#x2019;s responses. Certain words and nonverbal behaviors allegedly have hypnotic power and evoke a subconscious reaction in people, or so the theory goes. They do this by activating a person&#x2019;s <italic>primary representational system</italic> (PRS), which is reflected in the five senses.</p>
<p>For example, a salesperson who sensed that a consumer was &#x201C;visually&#x201D; oriented, based on the consumer&#x2019;s language style, mannerisms, and gaze, could adapt a message to emphasize visual features about a product&#x2014;e.g., &#x201C;As you can see &#x2026;&#x201D; &#x201C;take a look &#x2026;&#x201D; &#x201C;watch this &#x2026;&#x201D; A salesperson who perceived a customer was &#x201C;auditory&#x201D; would adjust the sales pitch by saying &#x201C;I hear you &#x2026;&#x201D; &#x201C;it sounds like this is what you&#x2019;re after &#x2026;&#x201D; But how, you might wonder, does a salesperson know if a customer is primarily visual or auditory? According to NLP, a customer who looks up and to the left (memory) or right (invention) is accessing visual information; a customer who looks horizontally left (memory) or right (invention) is accessing auditory information (see <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_75">Lankton, 1980</xref>).</p>
<p>Although NLP&#x2019;s proponents assert that certain words and phrases have hypnotic power, their claims are suspect. The theory itself is nebulous and the evidence for its effectiveness is largely anecdotal. We agree that people respond reflexively to certain words, such as <italic>free</italic> or <italic>sale</italic>. That is a long way from saying, however, that specific words, phrases, and nonverbal cues have hypnotic power. By way of example, in one study, the investigators compared an indirect message using NLP with a direct message without NLP (Dixon, Parr, Yarbrough, &#x0026; Rathael, 2001). They found that the direct message without NLP was significantly more effective than the indirect message employing NLP. As the investigators concluded, &#x201C;Neurolinguistic programming may not be an effective device for improving the persuadability of messages&#x201D; (p. 549).</p>
<p><target target-type="page" id="page_374">374</target>In our view, NLP is much like the emperor&#x2019;s new clothes&#x2014;people believe in it because others seem to believe in it. The underlying assumptions of NLP so annoyed one expert in neuroscience that he declared it &#x201C;neurobabble&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_76">Miller, 1986</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_4">
<title>Music As Persuasion</title>
<p>Have you ever heard an advertising jingle and then been unable to get the tune out of your head the rest of the day? Are you able to sing along to tunes like &#x201C;Break me off a piece of that ____ ____ bar,&#x201D; or, &#x201C;I&#x2019;m stuck on ____ ____ &#x2019;cause ____ ____ stuck on me&#x201D;? If so, you&#x2019;re not alone. In fact, advertising agencies spend big bucks developing &#x201C;earworms&#x201D; like these. What&#x2019;s more, 86 percent of prime-time television commercials include some form of music (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_82">Allan, 2008</xref>). And when you stop to consider the role of music in persuasion, it&#x2019;s easy to see why. Indeed, music facilitates persuasion in a variety of ways that we examine next.</p>
<sec id="sec15_4_1">
<title>Music as a Central and Peripheral Cue</title>
<p>Song lyrics persuade. The lyrics to the famous McDonald&#x2019;s song &#x201C;You deserve a break today&#x201D; offer a case in point. When song lyrics persuade, they may do so through what Petty and Cacioppo (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_125">1986a</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_126">1986b</xref>) call the central route to persuasion&#x2014;that is, the song lyrics are thought about and reflected on by listeners. This was the case with anti-war protest songs in the 1960s. It may be the case with rap and hip-hop lyrics today.</p>
<p>Music also can persuade via the peripheral route to persuasion. Peripheral processing occurs when listeners hear, but don&#x2019;t actively attend to, the music. You may, for example, prefer to study with music playing (or blaring) in the background. Background music can affect a person&#x2019;s mood or emotions, without the person&#x2019;s full awareness.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_4_2">
<title>Music in Advertising and Sales</title>
<sec id="sec15_4_2_1">
<title>Music and Branding: What&#x2019;s That Song?</title>
<p>Music is often used to bolster a brand&#x2019;s image by creating favorable associations. As Danny Turner, the head of Mood Media, the company formerly known as Muzak, emphasized, &#x201C;major brands realize that to move forward &#x2026; positive, emotional connections have to be made&#x2014;and there&#x2019;s no better way to do that than music&#x201D; (cited by <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_112">Lazarus, 2017</xref>, p. C1). Chevy&#x2019;s &#x201C;Like a rock &#x2026;&#x201D; song, for example, reinforces a rugged image for its pickup trucks. The congruity of a song with a brand, known as <italic>musical fit</italic>, affects consumers&#x2019; perceptions of a product or service (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_118">North, Sheridan, &#x0026; Areni, 2016</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_140">Zander, Apaolaza-Ib&#x00E1;&#x00F1;ez, &#x0026; Hartmann, 2010</xref>). Coca-Cola, for example, has been particularly successful at pairing pop songs with its brand image of joy, happiness, and love (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_130">Sanchez-Porras &#x0026; Rodrigo, 2017</xref>). A Nielsen study found that TV commercials with music outperformed those without in four key areas; creativity, empathy, emotive power, and information power (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_116">2015</xref>).</p>
<p>Brand endorsements now appear regularly in song lyrics (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_102">Gloor, 2014</xref>). One study found that 30 percent of all songs, and 73 percent of rap songs in particular, included brand mentions (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_94">Craig, Flynn, &#x0026; Holody, 2017</xref>). For example, Busta Rhymes&#x2019;s hit &#x201C;Pass the Courvoisier&#x201D; is credited with increasing sales of the cognac brand by 30 percent (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_100">Emling, 2004</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_131">Schemer, Matthes, Wirth, &#x0026; Textor, 2008</xref>). In another song, <target target-type="page" id="page_375">375</target>Run-DMC love their Adidas. Lady Gaga&#x2019;s song &#x201C;Telephone&#x201D; mentions at least eight brands, including Miracle Whip, Virgin Mobile, and Polaroid. Some of these are paid endorsements, but many are not. Such endorsements appear to enhance brand identity, even if consumers know that the artist was paid for the brand mention (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_135">Van Vaerenbergh, 2017</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_4_2_2">
<title>Mere Exposure Effect: Hearing Is Believing</title>
<p>Another way that music helps to sell products is through the <italic>mere exposure effect</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_136">Wang &#x0026; Chang, 2004</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_139">Zajonc, 1968</xref>), which we discussed in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter9">Chapter 9</xref>. Repeated exposure to an unfamiliar stimulus increases liking for the stimulus over time. If a commercial includes a popular song or a likable jingle, repeated airings of the spot will facilitate liking for the product (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_105">Hargreaves, 1984</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_120">Obermiller, 1985</xref>). This is only true up to a point, however. Excessive repetition of a song or jingle can become annoying.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_4_2_3">
<title>Music as a Mnemonic Device</title>
<p>Music also functions as a <italic>mnemonic device</italic> in advertising (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_138">Yalch, 1991</xref>). A mnemonic device is simply a memory aid that facilitates recall. Can you remember which insurance company goes with &#x201C;We are ______________, Bum Puh Dum Bum, Bum Bum Bum&#x201D;? Hint: J. K. Simmons is the spokesman. Some tunes help the consumer to spell out the product&#x2019;s name and thus remember it. The Oscar Mayer bologna song is an example. Other jingles surround the product&#x2019;s name with positive associations. Can you fill in the company name for the tune &#x201C;Like a good neighbor, _____________ is there&#x201D;? If you are familiar with these commercials, you probably came up with the brand names. According to <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_119">North, Mackenzie, Law, and Hargreaves (2004)</xref>, the right kind of music can increase brand recall by as much as 96 percent. To be effective, jingles must be simple. This is because the words in a jingle tend to be processed phonetically (e.g., as mere sounds) rather than semantically (as meanings).</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_4_3">
<title>Background Music: Shop Till You Drop</title>
<p>Retailers rely heavily on background music. Some stores, such as Abercrombie &#x0026; Fitch, Starbucks, and Victoria&#x2019;s Secret, provide their own in-store music. Background music has been shown to affect mood (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_89">Bruner, 1990</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_116">Nielsen, 2015</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_137">Wiesenthal, Hennessy, &#x0026; Totten, 2003</xref>), regulate shopping pace (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_96">Ding &#x0026; Lin, 2011</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_101">Garlin &#x0026; Owen, 2006</xref>), improve sports performance (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_87">Boutcher &#x0026; Trenske, 1990</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_99">Elliott, Carr, &#x0026; Savage, 2004</xref>), lower anxiety in healthcare settings (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_123">Pelletier, 2004</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_129">Rudin, Kiss, Wetz, &#x0026; Sottile, 2007</xref>), and enhance task performance (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_114">Mayfield &#x0026; Moss, 1989</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_115">Miller &#x0026; Schyb, 1989</xref>). In one of our favorite studies, researchers played either French or German music in a wine shop and kept track of which wines sold the most. The sobering findings were that French wine sold better when French music was playing, while German wine sold better while German music was playing (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_117">North, Hargreaves, &#x0026; McKendrick, 1999</xref>). The shoppers&#x2019; affective responses to the background music thus influenced their purchase decisions.</p>
<p>In their meta-analysis, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_151">Roschk, Loureiro, and Breitsohl (2017)</xref> concluded that background music significantly increases pleasure, satisfaction, and purchase intentions. Of course, one would expect the results to be modest, given that <target target-type="page" id="page_376">376</target>background music is only one of many environmental cues. Because background music is now so pervasive, some suggest that <italic>habituation</italic> may occur, whereby people become desensitized to background music over time (K&#x00E4;mpfe, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_109">Sedlmeier, &#x0026; Renkewitz, 2010</xref>).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_4_4">
<title>Music Videos and Persuasion: Is Hip-Hop Harmful?</title>
<p>A great deal has been written about the influence of music videos on the attitudes and behaviors of young people. Today, a typical music video is essentially a three-minute commercial for the artist, the brands that he or she endorses, and the lifestyle he or she espouses. There is little doubt that music videos influence fashions, trends, slang, sexual mores, and model social behavior. The question is how much they do so and how beneficial or detrimental the social proof found in music videos is.</p>
<p>Concerned parents and media critics have roundly criticized music videos for glorifying materialism and wealth (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_110">Kalis &#x0026; Neuendorf, 1989</xref>), for being overly sexual (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_104">Hansen &#x0026; Hansen, 1990</xref>; Kistler &#x0026; Lee, 2012), and for promoting sexism (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_85">Barongan &#x0026; Hall Nagayama, 1995</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_124">Peterson &#x0026; Pfost, 1989</xref>). Indeed, as <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_134">Wright and Qureshi (2015)</xref> reported, &#x201C;1/3 of popular songs contain explicit sexual content and 2/3 of these references are degrading&#x201D; (p. 228). The <italic>general aggression model</italic> (GAM) posits that music can prime aggressive behavior by activating negative thoughts or scripts in listeners (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_83">Anderson &#x0026; Bushman, 2002</xref>). Support for the GAM is well-documented (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_84">Anderson, Carnagey, &#x0026; Eubanks, 2003</xref>). A reverse effect has also been found, however, such that songs with pro-equality lyrics generate more favorable attitudes toward women (B&#x00F6;hm, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_86">Ruth, &#x0026; Schramm, 2016</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_103">Greitmeyer, Hollingdale, &#x0026; Traut-Mattausch, 2015</xref>).</p>
<p>With regard to musical genres, rap and hip-hop, in particular, have been singled out for criticism (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_97">Dunbar, Kubrin, &#x0026; Scurich, 2016</xref>). &#x201C;Rap music,&#x201D; one group of scholars notes, &#x201C;has been blamed for youth violence, the rise of gangs and gang-related crime, drug use, and violence against women&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_127">Reyna, Brandt, &#x0026; Tendayi, 2009</xref>, p. 362). Some critics have warned that frequent exposure to rap and hip-hop is associated with illicit drug use, alcohol abuse, and misogyny (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_81">Adams &#x0026; Fuller, 2006</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_91">Chen, Miller, Grube, &#x0026; Waiters, 2006</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_122">Parker-Pope, 2007</xref>).</p>
<p>In response, defenders argue that rap and hip-hop music give a voice to the disenfranchised and serve as a medium for urban empowerment (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_127">Reyna et al., 2009</xref>). Proponents argue that some music videos make important socio-political statements and that others simply mirror the crass materialism and rampant sexism of the larger society. Rap and hip-hop artists respond that the mainstream media paint a distorted picture of rap and that the language and images used reflect the harsh realities of inner-city life (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_88">Brown &#x0026; Campbell, 1986</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_90">Chambers &#x0026; Morgan, 1992</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_95">Cummings &#x0026; Roy, 2002</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_133">Tiddle, 1996</xref>). <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_98">Dyson (1993)</xref>, for example, classifies rap music as a form of resistance that empowers African Americans. He stresses that rap combines social protest, musical creation, and cultural expression all at the same time. <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_113">Lynch (2003)</xref> states that hip-hop brings people from different races and cultures together.</p>
<p>Whether one perceives the messages in music videos as positive or negative, it is difficult to deny that such music serves to shape attitudes, beliefs, intentions, motivations, and behaviors. This is particularly true for adolescents who are heavy viewers of music videos (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_93">Council on Communications and Media, 2009</xref>). One must be cautious about making direct causal inferences, however, between what juveniles <target target-type="page" id="page_377">377</target>see or hear and their subsequent behavior. There are plenty of alternative sources for modeling behavior.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_4_5">
<title>Weaponizing Music: What a Buzz Kill</title>
<p>Is subjecting someone to awful music akin to waterboarding? How much Miley Cyrus music can one human being take? It was reported that the U.S. military used music as a form of &#x201C;torture lite&#x201D; during the war in Iraq (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_92">Connor, 2008</xref>). One of the songs was Barney the Dinosaur&#x2019;s &#x201C;I Love You, You Love Me.&#x201D; Amnesty International is investigating the use of music in interrogations.</p>
<p>Music has also been used as a deterrent. In 2009, the U.S. Border Patrol commissioned a CD, <italic>Migra Corridos</italic>, comprising popular Mexican ballads warning of the dangers of crossing the border illegally. The U.S. Border Patrol did not reveal that it was behind the CD, songs from which were played on several dozen Mexican radio stations (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_132">Surdin, 2009</xref>). Should music be used like barbed wire to repel people?</p>
<p>There have been reports that classical music was used to drive away the homeless, panhandlers, and gang members from fast-food restaurants and convenience stores (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_107">Hirsch, 2012</xref>). One officer commented, &#x201C;If you&#x2019;re a tough guy and you like rock or rap, you&#x2019;re not going to sit there and listen to Tchaikovsky&#x201D; (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_108">Holt, 1996</xref>, p. 2). In what has been termed the &#x201C;Manilow Method,&#x201D; the town of Rockdale, near Sydney, initiated a campaign to discourage teens from congregating at a park late at night. Music by Barry Manilow was played over loudspeakers from 9 p.m. until midnight (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_106">Hirsch, 2007</xref>). We have to wonder, did the town pay Mr. Manilow any royalties?</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_4_6">
<title>Cautions: Face the Music</title>
<p>Before you get a hankering to use music to persuade others, bear in mind the following caveats. First, for music to be persuasive, there must be a good fit; the type of music must match the particular product, brand, purpose, and audience for which it is intended. Second, music shouldn&#x2019;t overpower the verbal content of a message. In a sales setting, for example, quieter music allows for more interaction between the salesperson and the customer. Third, music will probably have little effect on highly involved receivers who tend to concentrate on the substance of the message anyway. Music is best used on low-involved receivers who will process the message peripherally (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_121">Park &#x0026; Young, 1986</xref>). In most cases, music functions as a useful supplement to verbal persuasion. Rarely can music be used as a substitute for verbal persuasion.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_5">
<title>Aroma and Persuasion</title>
<p>Although few texts discuss the subject, smell plays an important role in the process of persuasion. Selling smells is a big business. Sales of fragrances and perfumes are expected to grow to &#x0024;51 billion by 2022 (Global Industry Analysts, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_146">2016</xref>). Think of all the fragrances you can buy to make you feel better; you can douse yourself in cologne or perfume, scent your car&#x2019;s interior, and place air fresheners throughout your home. You can use scented deodorants, soaps, and laundry detergent, as well as scented dishwashing liquid and toilet paper. In addition to personal uses of <target target-type="page" id="page_378">378</target>fragrances, the use of ambient (background) fragrances in the workplace and in retail settings is beginning to play an increasingly prominent role. In this section, we examine the role of fragrances and aromas as forms of influence.</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 15.3</label>
<caption><title>&#x201C;It&#x2019;s the smell of money.&#x201D;</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig15_3.jpg"/>
<p>Source: &#x00A9; Peter Steiner/The New Yorker Collection/<uri>www.cartoonbank.com</uri>. All Rights Reserved.</p>
</fig>
<sec id="sec15_5_1">
<title>Perfume: Romance in a Bottle</title>
<p>The fragrance industry is one in which a product often &#x201C;wins by a nose.&#x201D; But is it the actual fragrance that sells or the associations that are paired with it? Scent alone isn&#x2019;t what sells perfume. The promise of romance sells perfume. The marketing themes associated with fragrances revolve around images of romance, intrigue, sensuality, and, of course, sex. &#x201C;Between madness and infatuation,&#x201D; a Calvin Klein ad proclaims, &#x201C;lies obsession&#x201D; (for Obsession perfume). The slogan for FCUK&#x2019;s fragrance was far less subtle. &#x201C;Scent to Bed,&#x201D; the ads proclaimed.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_5_2">
<title>Love Stinks</title>
<p>Through images and innuendo, fragrance ads create the impression that using their products will increase your sexual attractiveness. But do perfumes make any actual difference? Do they help attract dates, win over lovers, or make one feel better about oneself? Empirical research on this question is mixed, with some studies showing that fragrances increase attraction and others showing they do not (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_141">Baron, 1983</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_145">Cann &#x0026; Ross, 1989</xref>).</p>
<p>An interesting study that casts doubt on the allure of perfumes was conducted by Hirsch (cited in <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_154">Stolberg, 1994</xref>). Male medical students were recruited as subjects for the study. Blood pressure monitors were attached to the volunteers&#x2019; genitals while they smelled a variety of fragrances, including Chanel No. 5 and Obsession. The <target target-type="page" id="page_379">379</target>results? The only smell that consistently increased blood pressure, the measure of sexual arousal used in the study, was that of cinnamon buns! The results seem to reinforce the adage that the way to a man&#x2019;s heart is, after all, through his stomach. As with the preceding study, these results may also be questioned. Let&#x2019;s face it, having an apparatus attached to one&#x2019;s genitals doesn&#x2019;t approximate a real-world setting for arousal (not for most folks, anyway). In such a clinical environment, the participants may not have responded as they otherwise would.</p>
<p>Bear in mind that scent is only <italic>one</italic> factor in the overall attractiveness equation. Other factors include such things as physical appearances, personalities, and common interests, to name but a few. One would be foolish, indeed, to believe that fragrance alone could serve as the basis for a meaningful, lasting relationship.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_5_3">
<title>Ambient Aromas: Something Special in the Air</title>
<p>Although there is little research on the relationship between fragrance and attraction, there is a sizable body of research on the ways in which ambient aromas affect people. We consider three such ways here: Mood or emotion, task performance, and shopping behavior.</p>
<fig position="float">
<label>Figure 15.4</label>
<caption><title>A fragrance designer for Givaudan-Roure Corp. plies his trade.</title></caption>
<graphic orientation="portrait" xlink:href="fig15_4.jpg"/>
<p>Source: Photo by Joe Tabacca.</p>
</fig>
<sec id="sec15_5_3_1">
<title>Aromas and Moods: Am I Blue?</title>
<p>Background fragrances have been shown to have a calming effect on patients in healthcare settings. For example, vanilla and heliotropin (similar to baby powder) reduced anxiety in patients undergoing an MRI scan (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_150">Redd &#x0026; Manne, 1991</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_154">Stolberg, 1994</xref>). Researchers have found that scents can influence people&#x2019;s emotional states in nonmedical settings as well. For example, investigators asked college students to write a brief essay about a childhood memory. Half the students composed their essays in a room with a mild floral scent. The other half wrote in an unscented room. The students in the scented condition used happy, positive terms three times more <target target-type="page" id="page_380">380</target>often than their counterparts in the unscented condition. What&#x2019;s more&#x2014;and this is the part of the study we love&#x2014;students in both groups were then instructed to direct a mime to act out their childhood memory. Some 75 percent of the students in the scented condition touched the mime while giving directions, compared to only 15 percent in the unscented condition (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_159">Welsh, 2011</xref>).</p>
<p>Another of our favorite studies (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_147">Hanisch, 1982</xref>), because of its unusual method, examined whether pleasant fragrances could reduce arachnophobia (fear of spiders) among females. The researcher dangled a spider at varying distances from the participants&#x2019; faces. Part of the time, the participants were exposed to a pleasant, unfamiliar scent. Part of the time they were not. The pleasant fragrance reduced anxiety and allowed the spider to be placed closer to the participants&#x2019; faces than the no-fragrance condition. The researcher didn&#x2019;t mention whether the spider liked the fragrance or not.</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_5_3_2">
<title>Aromas and Task Performance: Smell That Productivity</title>
<p>One area in which scents have been shown to have an effect is task performance. Several studies have shown that mild fragrances can improve the speed, accuracy, and efficiency with which people complete tasks (Hirsch, cited in <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_154">Stolberg, 1994</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_152">Rotten, 1983</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_155">Sugano &#x0026; Sato, 1991</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_158">Warm, Parasuraman, &#x0026; Dember, 1990</xref>). For example, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_143">Baron and Kalsher (1998)</xref> found that a pleasant ambient fragrance improved driving performance on a simulated driving task. Moreover, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_142">Baron (1997)</xref> found that shoppers in a mall were more than twice as likely to help a stranger in the presence of pleasant ambient aromas (roasting coffee or baking cookies).</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_5_3_3">
<title>Scent Marketing: Follow Your Nose</title>
<p>Branded fragrances are increasingly being used to promote brand identity. Abercrombie &#x0026; Fitch was among the first to market its own fragrance, called <italic>Fierce</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_153">Smiley, 2014</xref>). Other brands soon followed suit. Cadillac, Lincoln, Marriott, United Airlines, and Verizon all have branded fragrances. As of 2017, Ikea was poised to launch its own fragrance. Early reports hint at the smell of cinnamon buns. We haven&#x2019;t gotten a whiff yet, but we think the true essence of Ikea should be redolent of the tears, bitterness, and frustration that comes with trying to assemble one of their products. Finally, in a bizarre twist of fragrance, the fast-food chain KFC created fried-chicken scented sunscreen. What better way to fight sunburn than to wade into shark-infested waters smelling like meat?</p>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_5_3_4">
<title>Ambient Aromas and Consumer Behavior</title>
<p>Retail stores are increasingly using ambient odors to motivate shoppers. But does pumping fragrances into the air make customers buy more? A meta-analysis of aroma studies found that background fragrances resulted in increased arousal, pleasure, satisfaction, and intention to purchase (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_128">Roschk, Loureiro, &#x0026; Breitsohl, 2017</xref>). Other research has shown that pleasant ambient aromas can increase shopping time (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_148">Knasko, 1989</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_156">Teerling, Nixdorf, &#x0026; Koster, 1992</xref>) and improve product evaluations (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_144">Bosmans, 2006</xref>).</p>
<p>That said, researchers seem to agree that purchasing decisions are too complex to be influenced solely by smell, and not all studies find aromas to be persuasive. For instance, one study conducted in a shopping mall found no effects for background smells (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_157">Teller &#x0026; Dennis, 2012</xref>). <target target-type="page" id="page_381">381</target>Not only that, one study shows that if consumers get wind of the fact that ambient aromas are being manipulated as a marketing ploy, they will become more skeptical toward the brand, the store, or the product in question (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref15_149">Lunard, 2012</xref>).</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_5_4">
<title>Caveats and Qualifications</title>
<p>Before you rush out to buy a case of room air-fresheners to make you feel better, study harder, and work more efficiently, keep the following in mind: First, there are large variations in individual preferences for smells. A scent that works on one person may not work on another. One of the authors, for example, likes the smell of a skunk from afar. Second, as was the case with subliminal research, some of the effects reported in these studies may be attributed to a placebo effect. The participants&#x2019; expectations that smells affect behavior might account for the changes observed. Third, the repetitive use of scents can lead to counterconditioning such that an initially pleasant scent comes to be perceived as unpleasant. The smell of vanilla, for example, has been shown to be relaxing. But if it is introduced every time a child receives a vaccination, the smell may become aversive. Finally, there may be ethical as well as health-related concerns involved in using fragrances to influence people. People can close their eyes or look away from an image that offends them. They can&#x2019;t stop breathing or turn off their noses, however. We address ethical questions arising from the use of fragrances in <xref ref-type="book-part" rid="chapter16">Chapter 16</xref>.</p>
</sec>
</sec>
<sec id="sec15_6">
<title>Summary</title>
<p>In this chapter, we examined several esoteric forms of persuasion: Color, subliminal messages, subaudible messages, backward masking or reverse speech, neurolinguistic processing, music as persuasion, and smell as persuasion. Despite the public&#x2019;s belief in subliminal persuasion, subliminal effects have only been demonstrated in highly controlled laboratory settings. At present, subliminal priming is not commercially viable. Embedded words and images, subaudible messages, and backward masking have not been shown to influence people. Neurolinguistic processing is a popular, but unproven phenomenon. Music was shown to be an important component of persuasion. Music facilitates persuasion in a variety of ways such as reinforcing advertising images, serving as a mnemonic device, and influencing receivers&#x2019; moods. Though overlooked by most persuasion researchers, smell was also shown to be a useful tool for persuasion if the right conditions are met. Ambient fragrances can enhance moods, improve task performance, and influence consumer behavior.</p>
</sec>
</body>
<back>

A.</given-names></string-name>, &#x0026; <string-name><surname>Totten</surname>, <given-names>B.</given-names></string-name></person-group> (<year>2003</year>). <article-title>The influence of music on mild driver aggression</article-title>. <source>Transportation Research, Part F: Traffic Psychology and Behaviour</source>, <volume>6</volume>(<issue>2</issue>),<fpage>125</fpage>&#x2013;<lpage>134</lpage>.</mixed-citation></ref>
<ref id="ref15_138"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Yalch</surname>, <given-names>R. <ref id="ref15_139"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Zajonc</surname>, <given-names>R. <ref id="ref15_140"><mixed-citation publication-type="book"><person-group person-group-type="author"><string-name><surname>Zander</surname>, <given-names>M. </ref-list>
<ref-list>
<title>Smell</title>
